It is also said: When used raw, it treats scabies and ringworm, and cures alternating chills and fever with cough and counterflow qi. When refined and ingested, it governs deficiency detriment and seminal emission.

Tao Yinju states: Donghai Commandery belongs to Beixuzhou, and Mount Ji also produces it. Today, the finest comes from Funan and Linyi, its color like that of a newly hatched gosling—called "Kunlun Yellow." The next best comes from foreign lands, transported through Shu, its color deep and radiant. Folk remedies use it to treat weak feet and chronic cold, with excellent results. The *Immortal Classics* make frequent use of it. The wondrous transformations it undergoes all pertain to the methods of "yellow-and-white" alchemy and compounding elixirs. Here it is called "alum liquid," but today the South has no alum, so this may not be accurate.

The *Rihuazi* states: Realgar and azurite serve as its guides; it fears asarum, flying thistle, and iron. It fortifies the Yang Dao, treats hard lumps and cold qi, supplements sinew and bone from taxation damage, wind taxation, and qi disorders, checks cough and counterflow qi, and heals lower-body hemorrhoids, fistulas, malignant sores, scabies, and ringworm. It kills abdominal worms and dispels demonic influences. Boiled with emblic myrobalan juice, it neutralizes its toxicity.

Master Lei says: In selection, do not use green, red, half-white half-green, or half-red half-black varieties. Only those naturally yellow, internally lustrous and pure like living matter, are precious. For every four taels used, first prepare one yi of natural juice from *Artemisia dubia*, three yi of east-flowing water, one yi of purple-backed *Semiaquilegia adoxoides* juice, and one yi of *Euphorbia lathyris* stem juice. Combine these and stir evenly. Seal the bottom of a crucible with Six-One Mud, then crush the sulfur and place it inside. Gradually add the prepared medicinal juices and heat until the liquid is exhausted. Next, boil the sulfur with ten taels of *Stemona* powder, two jin of willow borer powder, and two jin of finely chopped *Miscanthus* grass in east-flowing water for one full day and night. Remove the sulfur, wash it with prepared licorice decoction, and grind it in a mortar twenty thousand times before use.

Yu Xi notes: According to Mr. Wu, sulfur is also called "stone-retained yellow." Shennong, the Yellow Emperor, and Lei Gong: flavor acrid, toxic. Yi He and Bian Que: flavor bitter, non-toxic. It may grow in Yiyang, Hexi, or appear in five colors. Yellow is the essence of panshui stone; when burned, it emits a purple flame. Harvest in the eighth and ninth months. It treats blood congealment in women.

The *Haiyao* states: According to the *Guangzhou Ji*, it grows beneath the sun’s rays in Kunlun, appearing as lustrous, pure lumps without stone inclusions—this is the finest. It governs wind-cold deficiency exhaustion, kidney cold, checks qi, treats weak and emaciated legs and knees, promotes flesh growth, augments qi and strength, addresses seminal emission, hemorrhoids, fistulas, and elderly wind-constipation. All these conditions benefit from refined ingestion. Daoist elixir methods call it "yellow sal ammoniac"; it can corrode the five metals and also produce a golden hue. Those who can subdue and return it to its original nature may ingest it to cure all diseases. If adverse reactions occur, neutralize them with pork, duck broth, or emblic myrobalan decoction. Shu’s Yazhou also produces it, very lustrous and fine, but its efficacy does not match that imported by sea.

The *Danfang Jingyuan* states: Sulfur can dry mercury. The formula says: "This sulfur blackens the five metals upon contact and reddens when combined with mercury." It is also called "yellow tooth."

Sun Shangyao says: It treats qi deficiency with cold damage, sudden watery diarrhea with twenty or thirty bowel movements day and night, and unremitting abdominal pain—a summer travel emergency remedy. The *Chaozhen Dan*: Two taels of sulfur, ground extremely fine with ox horn; half a tael of calcined alum, finely ground together and soaked in water. Steam with cake, remove the water veins, and form into pills the size of firmiana seeds, coated with cinnabar. Take fifteen to twenty pills with warm rice water or salt broth.

The *Jingyan Fang*: Greatly effective for original visceral qi depletion, chronic cold, abdominal pain, and deficiency diarrhea—an urgently needed remedy. The *Yufen Dan*: Five taels of raw sulfur, one tael of halite, ground together finely, and formed into pills the size of mung beans with steamed cake. Take five pills on an empty stomach with hot wine, followed by food.

The *Meishi Fang*: For yin-generated damp sores, grind sulfur into powder and apply to the sores three times daily.

The *Shenghui Fang*: For various sores with protruding flesh like snakes, several inches long, grind one tael of sulfur finely and apply thinly to the flesh—it will immediately dissolve.

The *Waitai Miyao*: From the *Qianjin*, for treating childhood suppurative ear: Apply sulfur powder to the ear once daily and once nightly until cured.

The *Taiqing Fulian Lingsha Fa*: Sulfur originally comes from Persia, in the lands of Nanming, where it crystallizes from the pure Yang essence of fiery stone. Its nature is fluid and penetrating, containing fierce toxicity. Among medicinal substances, it is called the "General." Its powers can break through evil and restore rectitude, return stagnation to clarity, fortify Yang essence, and dissolve Yin into po.

The *Yanyi* states: Today, sulfur is used to treat lower-origin deficiency cold, original qi on the verge of collapse, chronic cold diarrhea, and spleen-stomach weakness with life nearly exhausted—none fail to respond. Once the condition improves, cease administration; do not complete the full course. People often know how to use it for benefit but not how prolonged use brings harm.

This substance brings both harm and benefit. If one were to abandon it entirely and not use it, how could it be dispensed with in times of urgent need? Yet some further refine it with methods, resist its fire, and take it regularly—this too is thoughtless. The *Shennong Bencao Jing* does not describe such consumption but focuses solely on its use for women. The uninformed often take it with wine—how can this be proper? For those with long-standing cold in the viscera, initial doses may induce purgation. If the condition is critical, increase the number of pills; too few will be ineffective. Combine it with aconite, dried ginger, and cinnamon.

**Orpiment**
Flavor: acrid, sweet; nature: neutral, greatly cold; toxic.
Governs malign sores, bald scalp, scabs, and scabies; kills poisonous worms, lice, and body itch; dispels pathogenic qi and all toxins; erodes nasal polyps; treats lower-body sores, facial and bodily white patches; disperses dead flesh in the skin; and resolves delirious pathogenic qi. It neutralizes the venom of bees and snakes. When refined, long-term consumption lightens the body, extends years, prevents aging, and fills the brain.
It grows in the valleys of Wudu Mountains, emerging from the same mountains as realgar. On the shady side of these mountains, where gold is present, the fumes of gold essence give rise to orpiment. Harvested at no fixed time.

The *Tujing* states: Orpiment grows in the valleys of Wudu Mountains, sharing its mountain with realgar. On the shady side, where gold is found, the fumes of gold essence produce orpiment. Today, it comes from Jiezhou. The finest specimens are golden in color, resembling mica with layered, separable flakes. Those mixed with stone or darkened like iron are unusable. Some say a four-ounce piece, when split, can yield a thousand layers—this is especially rare and excellent. Harvested at no fixed time.

Tao Hongjing says: Today, orpiment from Wudu Chichi is called "Wudu Chichi yellow," with a slightly reddish hue. That from Funan Linyi is called "Kunlun yellow," golden in color and resembling mica with layered flakes, prized by painters. Given these distinctions—both in the names of "male" and "female" and the yin-yang of the same mountain—when compounding medicines, Wudu orpiment should be superior. Yet it is rarely used and less valued than Kunlun orpiment.

The *Immortal Classics* contain no method for taking it alone; it is only used with cinnabar and realgar, refined together into an elixir.

Leigong says: When using orpiment, do not mistakenly substitute stone-bound yellow, fumigated yellow, or amber-yellow. A single piece should weigh four ounces. According to the *Qianning Record*, the best orpiment, when split, yields a thousand layers and is as soft as molten gold. For processing, avoid the presence of any woman, chicken, dog, those who have recently engaged in intercourse, the ill, eunuchs, the deformed, or those who have been in prisons or polluted places. If contaminated, the orpiment turns black as iron, becomes unusable, and harms longevity.

The *Baocang Lun* states: Orpiment subdues fire, retains its fetal color without change, and when smelted into liquid, can transmute silver into gold and copper into silver.

The *Danfang Jingyuan* says: Yellow on the shady side is female. Pure and soft varieties can dry mercury. The finest comes from foreign ships, marked with "blood" (#25); that from Hunan is secondary. Green orpiment retains its original nature. Leaf-like specimens can transform sulfur and subdue powder frost. Note this well—do not use it mistakenly.

The *Qingxiazi* says: Orpiment repels evil and dispels malign influences.

The *Shenghui Fang*:
- For treating black leprosy sores and killing worms: Grind orpiment into powder, mix with vinegar and egg yolk until even, and apply to the sores. Reapply when dry.
- For chronic heart pain with unpredictable flare-ups, frequent vomiting of clear fluid, and inability to eat: Simmer two liang of orpiment in two sheng of good vinegar until it forms a paste. Use dry steamed cakes to form pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take seven pills each time with ginger decoction.

The *Baiyi Fang*: For abdominal fullness and inability to urinate: Grind orpiment into fine powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of jujube pits. Insert one pill into the urethra, about half an inch deep, and secure it with a bamboo tube pressed tightly against the genitals to allow qi to pass.

The *Jingyan Fang*: To reduce urination: Grind one and a half liang of granular orpiment into powder. Stir-fry with half a liang of sliced dried ginger and four large coins of salt until the ginger turns yellow. Grind together into powder, mix with dry steamed cakes and water to form pills the size of mung beans. Take ten to twenty pills on an empty stomach with salt water.

*The Doumen Fang*: For consumptive lung disease with coughing: Take one liang of orpiment and place it in an earthenware container, without sealing it tightly. Set the container on the ground and surround it with ash, packing it firmly to a thickness of two inches. Arrange one jin of charcoal around it, ignite the top with fire, and calcine until one-third remains. Remove the fire and allow it to cool. Grind the residue into a fine powder and form pills the size of millet grains with toad venom. Take three pills daily on an empty stomach with apricot kernel decoction. This will cure the condition.

*The Yan Yi* states: Orpiment is most effective when refined for medicinal use. Those who consume mineral drugs should exercise great caution. Its external applications are numerous, and alchemists frequently employ it for transmutation, though its ultimate effects remain uncertain. Painters also use it.

**Mercury**
Flavor: Pungent
Nature: Cold
Toxicity: Toxic
It governs scabies, fistulas, crusty sores, white bald patches, and kills lice on the skin. It induces abortion and clears heat. When transmitted to a man’s genitals, it causes the yang qi to dissipate. It neutralizes the poison of gold, silver, copper, and tin, and when smelted, reverts to cinnabar. Prolonged consumption confers immortality. Also called *gong*. It is produced in the flatlands of Fuling and is derived from cinnabar. It is averse to magnetite.

*The Yaoxing Lun* states: Mercury is a sovereign drug that neutralizes the poison of gold and copper. It is the "maiden" (alchemical term). It is highly toxic. It is the liquid within cinnabar and the primordial mother of reverted cinnabar, the elixir of immortality. When refined, it subdues the five metals into a paste. In its raw form, it induces abortion. It treats scabies and other conditions by killing parasites.

Tao Hongjing says: Nowadays, mercury is found in both raw and processed forms. The type said to be produced in the flatlands of Fuling is raw, extracted from the interior of cinnabar or from sandy deposits, both of which are bluish-white and of the highest quality. The mercury derived from cinnabar is obtained by burning coarse cinnabar powder, yielding a slightly white and turbid product inferior to the raw form. It powerfully dissolves gold and silver into a paste, which is used for gilding. Its reversion to cinnabar is described in the *Immortal Classics*. When mixed with wine and exposed to sunlight, it confers longevity. When burned, the mercury that flies onto the cauldron’s soot is called *gong fen* (mercury powder), commonly known as "mercury ash," which is highly effective at killing lice.

*The Tang Ben* notes: Mercury is produced from cinnabar through heat, though it is not known to emerge spontaneously from within cinnabar. The method of burning and collecting it is widely understood. Southerners extract it through steaming, yielding less mercury but preserving the cinnabar, though its color darkens slightly.

Chen Cangqi says: Beyond its primary functions, mercury promotes urination and clears heat toxins. When introduced into the ear, it consumes the brain entirely. When it enters the flesh, it causes all joints to contract and spasm, inverts the yin and severs the yang. Many apply mercury to sores and scabies, but its slippery heaviness allows it to penetrate deeply into the flesh—caution is advised. Formerly, the Prince of Xu of the Northern Qi treated contractures and paralysis by cauterizing with heated gold objects. When mercury encounters gold, it corrodes it; the gold turns white, confirming the effect. Repeating this process several times cures the condition.

*Rihua Zi* states: Mercury is non-toxic. It treats epidemic febrile diseases, hastens childbirth, expels stillborn fetuses, heals malignant sores, dispels wind, and calms the spirit to settle the heart. Those who gild objects with mercury ash often suffer from wind disorders; if large amounts are used, consuming alcohol, fatty pork, or iron-infused water can counteract the toxicity.

Lei Gong says: When using mercury, do not employ that collected from plants, from old vermilion lacquer, or that which has been processed with other drugs. Avoid mercury from corpses or that which is half-living and half-dead. Mercury produced from cinnabar has a slightly reddish hue. After collection, store it in a gourd to prevent loss. If first boiled for one full day with the natural juices of *zi bei tian kui* (purple-backed *Semiaquilegia adoxoides*) and *ye jiao teng* (*Polygonum multiflorum*), its toxicity will be neutralized. For refining ten liang of mercury, use seven *yi* of each of the aforementioned juices and boil until complete.

*The Inner Biography of Emperor Wu of Han* states: Feng Junda, a native of Longxi, initially consumed *Coptis chinensis* for over fifty years. He then entered Wufeng Mountain, where he ingested mercury for over a hundred years, returning to his hometown appearing as a man of twenty. He often rode a black ox, hence his epithet, the Black Ox Daoist.

*The Taiqing Method for Refining Divine Cinnabar*: It receives the numinous essence of the five yang spirits, uniting and harmonizing into one body. Thus, it can lightly ascend and transform, interacting with the myriad spirits.

*The Sheng Hui Fang*: For accidental ingestion of silver rings or hairpins: Take half a liang of mercury; a second dose will expel the object.

*The Later Proven Formulas*: For heart wind with constipation: Take one liang of mercury and eight lotus root nodes. First grind the lotus nodes finely, then add the mercury and grind into a sandy mixture. Form pills the size of *Euryale ferox* seeds. Take two pills with whetstone water; one or two doses will cure the condition.

*The Mei Shi Fang*: For a fetus that has died in the womb and will not be expelled, causing the mother’s qi to expire: Swallow two liang of mercury; the fetus will be expelled immediately.
Another formula: For hemorrhoids with incessant itching from worms in the anus: Take two liang each of mercury and jujube paste, grind together, and shape into jujube-like forms. Wrap in a thin layer of cotton and insert into the anus. The next day, the worms will emerge. If pain occurs, add three large portions of powder to form pills.

*The Yan Yi* states: Though mercury is used in medicine in various ways, extreme caution is necessary due to its toxicity. Women who consume it often become infertile. Today, it is frequently used to treat infantile convulsions with heat and phlegm, though no classical text mentions this—prudence is advised. It solidifies when combined with lead, congeals with sulfur, and disperses when ground with jujube pulp. Another method involves calcining it into a fine powder (*ni fen*) or *fen shuang* (calomel), which, when ground with saliva, kills lice. It brightens copper. When poured into a corpse, it hastens decomposition. When placed atop gold, silver, copper, or iron, it causes them to float. When combined with *zi he che* (purple river vehicle, i.e., human placenta), it is subdued.

Gypsum (*shigao*) has a pungent and sweet taste, is slightly cold and greatly cold, and is non-toxic. It governs wind-stroke with alternating chills and fever, counterflow qi below the heart with fright and panting, dry mouth and scorched tongue with inability to breathe, hardness and pain in the abdomen, expels demonic influences, aids childbirth and lactation, treats metal-inflicted wounds, dispels seasonal epidemics, headache, generalized heat, great heat in the Triple Burner, skin heat, qi obstruction in the intestines and stomach, resolves the flesh to induce sweating, stops wasting-thirst, counterflow vexation, abdominal distension, sudden qi panting, and heat in the throat. It may also be used in bath decoctions.

It is also called *xishi* ("fine stone"); those with fine texture and lustrous white are superior, while yellow ones cause strangury.

It grows in the mountain valleys of Qishan, as well as Qilu Mountain and Lumeng Mountain. It may be gathered at any time. Egg is its guiding substance. It is incompatible with *mangcao* (Illicium lanceolatum) and *mamudu* (Aconitum lycoctonum).

*The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica* states: Gypsum grows in the mountain valleys of Qishan, Qilu Mountain, and Lumeng Mountain. Today, it is also found in Fen, Meng, Guo, and Yao prefectures, as well as Xingyuan Prefecture. It grows on mountain rocks, its color brilliantly white; the yellow variety is unusable. This stone closely resembles *fangjieshi* (calcite), and genuine specimens are now difficult to obtain. When in use, only unbroken pieces are selected to distinguish it. *Fangjieshi* does not grow attached to rock but stands alone, its outer skin bearing the color of earth and water moss. When broken, it fractures into square prisms. Gypsum, by contrast, is naturally lustrous like jade—this is the difference.

It may be gathered at any time. *Fangjieshi* was formerly listed in the inferior grade. *The Divine Farmer’s Classic of Materia Medica* states it grows on Fang Mountain. Tao Hongjing considered it *changshi* (long stone), also called *fangshi* (square stone), and noted that their therapeutic effects are similar, suggesting they may be the same substance. Tao Hongjing also remarked that the mountains of the two commanderies refer to Qingzhou and Xuzhou. Today, it is found in Qiantang County, all emerging from the earth after rain, resembling chess pieces. The most excellent are translucent white; those from Pengcheng are also good. Specimens from nearby regions are abundant and large but inferior in use.

*The Immortals’ Scriptures* do not require this substance. *The Tang Materia Medica* states: Gypsum and *fangjieshi* are broadly similar, differing only in that the former remains unbroken. Today, merchants commonly substitute *fangjieshi* for gypsum, and genuine gypsum is rarely seen. Gypsum grows beside stone, whereas *fangjieshi* does not depend on stone for its growth but stands alone. Large pieces may be the size of a *sheng*, small ones like a fist, some found in soil, others in streams. Its outer skin takes the color of earth or water moss, and when broken, it fractures into square pieces, some as large as a square *chi*. Today, this is used as gypsum. Though it shares gypsum’s ability to dispel wind and clear heat, it is inferior in resolving the flesh and inducing sweat.

Chen Cangqi states: Tao [Hongjing] said it comes from Qiantang County. However, Qiantang lies in flatlands and has no gypsum—Tao’s annotation is erroneous. Su [Gong] also notes in his commentary on the Five Stone Resins that among them is a stone resembling bone, jade-like in firmness and luster, whose consumption surpasses that of stalactites. This "gypsum" is distinct from the present substance, sharing only a name—they must not be confused in use.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: It treats epidemic heat mania, promotes lactation, alleviates vertigo from head wind, and relieves vexation and agitation. Applied to the teeth, it benefits them. Those that are translucent and textured like mica are superior; it is also called *fangjieshi*.

Lei Gong states: In all applications, do not use *fangjieshi*. Though *fangjieshi* is white, it is not translucent and is drying in nature. Gypsum from Yishan County in Mingshan Prefecture is lustrous and pure as crystal, its nature gentle and benign. For use, first pound it in a stone mortar into powder, sift through fine silk, levigate with licorice water, allow the water to settle, dry, and grind again before use.

Ma Zhi states: According to *The Treatise on Medicinal Properties*, gypsum is guided by [egg], incompatible with croton, and averse to iron. It treats splitting headache from cold damage, high fever with skin as hot as fire, vexation and thirst, resolves the flesh to expel toxic sweat, unblocks stagnation in the stomach, relieves oppression below the heart, vexation, and agitation, and treats dry, scorched lips. Boiled with scallions and tea, it dispels headache.

*The Supplementary Commentary* states: Tao [Hongjing] said it emerges naturally in Qiantang’s mountains after rain. Today, the people of Qiantang quarry the mountains to obtain it in great quantities, pound it into powder, and sell it as tooth powder. The people of Zhe call it *hanshuishi* ("cold water stone"), and it is superior to specimens from other regions for medicinal use. Since it is now quarried from mountain stone, it grows in dependence on stone—this is indeed gypsum. Chen Cangqi claimed Qiantang County lies in flatlands and has no gypsum, revealing his ignorance of Qiantang.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For steaming disease within five days of onset—"within" refers to external cold with internal heat, where heat clings to the bones. Its root lies in the five viscera and six bowels, often arising after illness. The flesh and bones waste away, food and drink lose their savor, the skin becomes dry, and the complexion loses its luster. At the height of steaming, the limbs gradually thin while the insteps swell. Grind ten *liang* of gypsum into a fine powder as for milk powder, mix with water, and take one square *cun* spoonful twice daily until the body cools.

*The Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*: For sudden frequent urination without strangury, causing emaciation, pound half a *jin* of gypsum, boil in one *dou* of water to reduce to five *sheng*, and drink five *ge* at a time.

*Master Mei’s Prescriptions*: For unbearable pain from burns caused by hot oil, boiling water, or fire, pound gypsum into fine powder and apply to the wound.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: The two texts debate endlessly without resolution, failing to grasp the principle. *The Divine Farmer’s Classic of Materia Medica* originally contains no mention of *fangjieshi*; it was only due to *The Tang Materia Medica*’s note that "gypsum and *fangjieshi* are broadly similar" that later generations became confused. *The Classic* states: "It grows in the mountain valleys of Qishan, Qilu Mountain, and Lumeng Mountain, and may be gathered at any time"—thus specimens from elsewhere are not genuine.

The present *Illustrated Classic* further includes specimens from Fenzhou, though earlier and later scholars alike have failed to examine this carefully. *The Classic* states that those with fine texture and white luster are superior—thus, anything not matching this description is not true gypsum. Below, under *lishi* (striated stone), the entry in *The Classic* reads: "resembling gypsum but with fine, orderly striations," which clarifies the distinction. Now, among the so-called gypsum and *fangjieshi* of today, how many possess the fine, orderly striations and white luster described above? If present, it is gypsum; if absent, it is not. Moreover, only those from the regions specified in *The Classic* may be used medicinally—all others reflect partial views and should be disregarded.

In Master Zhongjing’s *White Tiger Decoction*, its effects are divine. The newly collated and corrected *Treatise on Cold Damage* appended a note stating that the decoction is to be used from the fourth month onward, when the weather grows hot. However, as climates vary across regions and yearly qi-movements differ, and given the divergence in local conditions, though this account is elegant, one must carefully consider both perspectives in practice. For cold damage with heat disease, or after profuse sweating—when the pulse is surging and large, the mouth and tongue parched, the head aching, and unquenchable thirst persists—or for those afflicted by summerheat, with body aches and fatigue, the *White Tiger Decoction* proves invariably effective.

**Gold Flakes**
Flavor: acrid. Nature: neutral. Slightly toxic.
Governs: settling the spirit, strengthening bones and marrow, unblocking and harmonizing the five viscera, expelling pathogenic qi and toxins. Consumed, it bestows immortality.
Grows in Yizhou. May be gathered at any time.

**The Illustrated Classic** states: Gold flakes originate from Yizhou. Silver flakes come from Yongchang. Tao Hongjing’s annotation notes: Gold is found everywhere, but Liangzhou, Yizhou, and Ningzhou yield it in abundance. It emerges from river sands as flakes, called "raw gold." Silver, too, is found in the same regions as gold, though it always forms within stone. Su Gong, however, believed that gold and silver occur in different places, with gold also found in water. Today, in Raozhou, Xinzhou, Nanzhou, Jianzhou, and Dengzhou—where gold is mined—it is gathered in various forms: some resembling mountain stones, others like grains of rice or beans. Such unrefined types, untouched by fire, may all be called "raw gold." Silver, however, lies mixed with copper in ore, and locals must repeatedly smelt it with lead before it is purified, so it cannot be considered "raw silver." Thus, a separate entry for "raw silver" states: It is found in the mines of Raoping in Raozhou, emerging from silver ore in hard, tin-like chunks with rough, angular veins—only the naturally formed kind is genuine. What is now extracted from mines appears in soil and stone, seeping into strands like hair, which locals call "old man’s beard." Such specimens are exceedingly rare. When medical texts prescribe raw silver, only this form is truly effective.

Gold flakes are rarely mentioned in ancient formulas. Silver flakes appear only in Ge Hong’s *Five-Stone Decoction* for treating abscesses and swellings. Today, they are seldom used directly; instead, thin sheets of gold or silver are incorporated into medicines for convenience. Formulas like *Jinshi Ling*, *Hongxue*, and *Zixue* also employ gold and silver, but only after refining.

Tao Hongjing further notes: Gold is found everywhere, though Liangzhou, Yizhou, and Ningzhou produce it in abundance from river sands as flakes, called "raw gold." It repels evil but is toxic—consuming it unrefined is lethal. Jin’an and Jianping also yield gold sand from stone, which is smelted into cauldrons. Even after firing, it remains unrefined and requires further smelting. In Gaoli, Funan, and the Western Regions, gold is crafted into vessels only after thorough refining, making it safe for consumption. The *Immortal Classics* describe softening it through refining with vinegar, honey, lard, *Vitex negundo*, or wine, then consuming it to attain immortality. It is also used with mercury to produce cinnabar, though medical texts rarely employ it, likely due to concerns over its toxicity. The *Immortal Formulas* refer to gold as *Tai Zhen*.

**Rihuazi** states: Gold is neutral and non-toxic, but it fears mercury. It settles the heart, fortifies the five viscera, replenishes essence, nourishes marrow, and harmonizes the blood vessels.

**Kou Zongshi** respectfully notes: The *Materia Medica* states that gold flakes and gold foil share the same properties. They treat childhood convulsions, damage to the five viscera, wind epilepsy, and loss of consciousness, calming the heart and stabilizing the hun and po spirits. Yang Sunzhi adds: Only thoroughly refined gold is safe; raw gold is lethal. If consumed with water or fat, it remains unrefined. Modern annotations clarify: Physicians use only refined gold, either as foil or by decocting gold vessels to extract their essence, ensuring it is non-toxic.

Chen Cangqi’s *Supplement* records a claim from Lingnan that raw gold is serpent excrement, hence its toxicity. It is said that miners dig over a *zhang* deep until they reach "fringe stone," which is blackened at one end. Beneath it lies gold, ranging from finger-sized to sesame-seed proportions, with a color like mulberry and a softness when bitten—this is true gold. Artisans who steal and swallow it show no signs of poisoning. Flake gold, found in river sands and collected by panning on felt or recovered from the stomachs of geese and ducks, can be forged into objects without further refining. Its decocted essence is effective for settling the heart. These are merely hearsay from Cangqi and entirely unfounded. Upon the Song dynasty’s reconquest of Lingnan, inquiries revealed no evidence of serpent excrement. For medicinal use, only refined gold should be employed. This clarification is provided lest later readers be misled by Cangqi’s claims.

The *Overseas Materia Medica* states: According to the *Annals of Haizhou*, gold originates from Dashi (Arabia), where it is most abundant and used for all trade. Its nature is predominantly cold; raw gold is toxic, while refined gold is non-toxic. It governs epilepsy, wind-heat ascending qi, cough, cold damage, lung injury with blood ejection, bone steaming, consumptive thirst, and dispels pathogenic qi from the five viscera. It fortifies the heart and may be incorporated into pills or powders as thin sheets.

The *Strange Records* note: Gold is born in the Lishui River. The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* describes countless mountains yielding gold, too numerous to record in full.

In Caizhou, melon-seed gold is produced; in the mountains of Yunnan, nugget gold is found, mined from between rocks. In the waters of Qiannan, Suifu, and Jizhou, flake gold is yielded. The *Records of the Lingbiao Region* further states: In Zhili County of Guangzhou, there is a gold pond where locals who raise geese and ducks occasionally find flakes of flake gold in their droppings. They thus raise more of these birds, collect their excrement, and pan it daily, obtaining one or half a tael of gold, thereby growing wealthy.

The *Treatise on the Treasury of Treasures* states: There are twenty types of gold—realgar gold, orpiment gold, azurite gold, sulfur gold, earth gold, raw iron gold, wrought iron gold, raw copper gold, steatite gold, placer gold, earth-green placer gold, mother-of-gold placer gold, white tin gold, black lead gold, and cinnabar gold. Of these fifteen, only the following five are true gold: cyclically refined gold, water gold, melon-seed gold, green flake gold, and grass-sand gold; the rest are all counterfeit.

The *Amplification of Materia Medica* states: Gold fragments are not simply called "gold" but are instead termed "fragments," signifying that they have been ground into usable form, akin to the meaning of "jade pulp." The two classics do not explain that "fragments" refer to powdered gold, for it must first be smelted and hammered into thin sheets before being ground into fragments for medicinal use. Tao Hongjing notes: When using silver fragments, they are amalgamated with mercury into a paste. If not hammered into thin sheets, how could they be blended with mercury into a paste? Yet he omits mention of gold fragments—another oversight. Raw gold is toxic, even lethal, and difficult to neutralize. Those poisoned by it may be cured only by partridge meat. Without being hammered into fragments, it cannot be used.

Nugget gold is mined from mountain caves, sometimes reaching depths of a hundred or more feet, where it is found alongside gold-bearing stone. This stone is brown, with one end appearing charred as if burned by fire.

Silver fragments are acrid in flavor, neutral in nature, and toxic. They govern the stabilization of the five viscera, settle the spirit and heart, arrest fright palpitations, and dispel pathogenic qi.

Prolonged consumption lightens the body and extends the years. It is produced in Yongchang. There is no fixed season for its gathering.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: The details are provided under the entry for gold fragments. Tao Hongjing says: The places where silver is found are the same as those for gold, though it is always embedded in raw stone, and the methods for refining and ingesting it are likewise similar. Today, medical formulas incorporate it into "heart-settling pills," but it should not be taken directly. To prepare the fragments, one must grind them with mercury until they dissolve.

Yongchang originally belonged to Yizhou but now falls under Ningzhou. The *Immortal Scriptures* also contain methods for its refinement and ingestion, though as it has no primary therapeutic use, it is not recorded in the *Materia Medica*.

In ancient times, gold was called "yellow gold," silver "white gold," and copper "red gold." Today, copper is classified as raw or refined—refined copper is soft and red, yet the *Materia Medica* makes no use of it. Instead, verdigris and large coins, both forms of raw copper, are employed in formulas and should be listed among the inferior substances.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: Silver and gold are not found in the same places; gold is also produced in water. When alchemists use silver fragments, they should take ready-made silver foil, dissolve it with mercury into a paste, then grind it with saltpeter and salt into a powder. After burning off the mercury and washing away the salt and saltpeter, the resulting powder is extremely fine and suitable for use. Only when absolutely necessary should one resort to filing fragments.

Moreover, silver is found everywhere, but that from Guo Prefecture is superior, while most other sources are adulterated with tin and inferior. The silver sheets from Goryeo are said not to come from silver ore, and their color is not as lustrous as that from Guo Prefecture.

There is also "yellow silver," which the *Divine Farmer’s Classic* does not record. Common belief holds that vessels made from it repel evil and are considered auspicious objects. Ma Zhi says: According to the *Drug Properties Treatise*, silver fragments are a sovereign remedy. Silver foil has the same effects. They stabilize the mind, dispel fright epilepsy, and treat children’s manic running fits and convulsions.

*The Secret Records of Mother and Child* states: For sudden lumbar and back pain in pregnancy as if broken, boil one liang of silver in three sheng of water until reduced to two sheng, and drink.

Master Qingxia says: The *Treatise on the Golden Elixir of Returned Cinnabar* states: Silver breaks cold and dispels wind.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: The meaning of "silver filings" has already been explained in the entry on gold. Silver is originally derived from ore and must be smelted to become refined silver, hence the name "wrought silver"—this is why a separate entry for "raw silver" is established later. Its uses largely align with those of wrought silver. There are alchemists in the world who claim to produce silver from cinnabar, or from lead and mercury, or from scorched copper. How could such methods retain the generative *qi* of creation? How could they be used in medicine? Since such imitations exist, they must be distinguished. Raw silver, then, refers to that which does not emerge from ore but forms spontaneously—it is also called "Old Man’s Beard," a name derived from its resemblance. However, the *Classic* states that silver filings are toxic, while raw silver is said to be non-toxic. Commentators have overlooked this distinction. The reason is that raw silver, having already manifested externally, lacks the pent-up *qi* of ore, and thus is non-toxic. Ore-bound silver, still concealed within stone, retains its pent-up and unvented *qi*, hence its toxicity. It also abhors tin.

Raw silver is cold and non-toxic. It governs manic heat, fright palpitations, epilepsy, disorientation, restless sleep, delirious speech, malevolent *qi*, and demonic afflictions. Ingested, it brightens the eyes, settles the heart, calms the spirit, and stabilizes the mind. For all heat-induced rashes and toxins in children, grind it in water and administer—its efficacy surpasses that of *zixue* powder. It is produced in the raw silver mines of Raozhou and Leping, resembling hard tin with a coarse, interlaced grain. Only the naturally occurring form is genuine.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Details are provided under the entry for gold filings.

Ma Zhi says: According to Chen Cangqi, raw silver has a pungent taste. *Ri Hua Zi* states it is cold and slightly toxic, and is averse to realgar and magnetite. It treats children’s sudden fright, heat toxins, and vexing agitation. Grind it in water for administration, and avoid raw blood. It is also said: Cinnabar silver is cold and non-toxic, averse to realgar, magnetite, and iron. It prolongs life, enhances complexion, settles the heart, calms the spirit, arrests fright palpitations, and repels evil. It treats possession by malevolent forces, *gu* toxins, heart heat, vexation, forgetfulness, and debility. Avoid all blood.

*Divine Cinnabar* is sweet in taste, warm in nature, and non-toxic. It governs the hundred diseases of the five viscera, nourishes the spirit, pacifies the hun and po, augments *qi*, brightens the eyes, unblocks the blood vessels, relieves vexation and fullness, boosts vitality, and dispels spectral and demonic influences. With prolonged use, it connects one to the divine, prevents aging, lightens the body, and bestows transcendence, rendering the heart numinous. It is also called "Dual-*Qi* Cinnabar." Grind one *liang* of mercury with six *zhu* of sulfur into a fine powder, first stir-fry to form "green sand," then place in a water-and-fire *ji-ji* furnace and refine until it resembles bundled needles—this indicates completion. It is averse to magnetite and fears saltwater.

*Mercury Powder* is pungent, cold, and non-toxic. It is averse to magnetite and orpiment.

*Mercury Powder* unblocks the large intestine, treats childhood *gan* malnutrition, scrofula, and *luo li* nodules, kills sores, scabies, ringworm, and parasites, and eliminates rosacea on the nose, wind sores, dryness, and itching. It is also called "Mercury Powder," "Light Powder," or "Steep Powder." It is contraindicated with all blood.

*Newly Supplemented.* Cited from Chen Cangqi and *Ri Hua Zi*.

*Empirical Formulas*:
To treat children who eat mud or have purulent abdominal distension: Take one *fen* of *Ni Fen* (Mercury Powder), mix with granulated sugar, and form pills the size of hemp seeds. Administer one pill on an empty stomach with rice broth, inducing the expulsion of earth to effect a cure.

*Sun Yonghe’s Formulas*:
To treat deficiency wind: *Er Bu San* (Incomparable Powder): Take one *liang* of *Ni Fen*, decoct five times in boiling water like tea dregs, dry over a slow fire, then grind with half a *liang* of musk into a fine powder. For each dose, take one *zi* mixed with warm water. For wind conditions, administer half a *qian* or one *qian bi* at the appropriate time, adjusting the dosage based on deficiency or excess.

Another formula: To treat bloody dysentery: Grind five *qian* of *Ni Fen* with three *qian* of *Ding Fen* (Lead Powder), mix with a small amount of steamed bun crumb soaked in water, and form pills the size of mung beans. For each dose, take seven to ten pills. Decoct one mugwort twig in one cup of water and administer the pills with the decoction—using more mugwort broth is also effective.

*Extended Meanings* states: *Mercury Powder* is a phlegm-expelling medicine, frequently used for childhood phlegm surges, convulsions, and spasms. However, it should not be taken regularly or in excess, as overuse may cause harm and depletion. If combined with fright, particular caution is required. Fright arises from insufficiency of heart *qi*, and purgation should be avoided, for it exacerbates deficiency, allowing fright *qi* to enter the heart, rendering the condition incurable. If the patient is inherently deficient, this substance must be strictly prohibited. Utmost care is essential.

*Illustrated Classic and Extended Meanings of Materia Medica, Volume Three* concludes.

**Textual Variants and Emendations**

1. 岩 (*yán*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 岩 (*yán*).
2. 正 (*zhèng*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 贞 (*zhēn*).
3. □: Originally 协 (*xié*); emended according to *Huiming Studio Edition*.
4. 胴 (*dòng*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 脂 (*zhī*).
5. 杯 (*bēi*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 石 (*shí*).
6. 皮 (*pí*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 肛 (*gāng*).
7. 治遍身风二灵散 (*"Two Spirits Powder for Wind Throughout the Body"*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 治偏头痛至灵散 (*"Most Effective Powder for Migraine"*).
8. 金 (*jīn*): Originally followed by three redundant characters 苗今有 (*"shoots now exist"*); deleted according to *Huiming Studio Edition*.
9. 刑 (*xíng*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 形 (*xíng*).
10. 盐 (*yán*): Likely should read 临 (*lín*).
11. 背 (*bèi*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 皆 (*jiē*).
12. 水中 (*shuǐ zhōng*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 中水 (*zhōng shuǐ*).
13. 榻 (*tà*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 拓 (*tuò*).
14. 篦 (*bì*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 粗 (*cū*).
15. 用 (*yòng*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 则 (*zé*).
16. 捻 (*niǎn*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 抖 (*dǒu*).
17. 衣 (*yī*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 头 (*tóu*).
18. 挺 (*tǐng*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 梃 (*tǐng*).
19. 傅信 (*fù xìn*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 经验 (*jīng yàn*).
20. 嗽 (*sòu*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 漱 (*shù*).
21. 一镒 (*yī yì*): These two characters were originally omitted; supplied according to *Huiming Studio Edition*.
22. 止 (*zhǐ*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 上 (*shàng*).
23. 亦 (*yì*): Originally 赤 (*chì*); emended according to *Huiming Studio Edition*.
24. 末 (*mò*): Originally 木 (*mù*); emended according to *Huiming Studio Edition*.
25. 撰 (*zhuàn*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 噀 (*xùn*).
26. 朔 (*shuò*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 嗍 (*suō*).
27. 释 (*shì*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 稀 (*xī*).
28. 者 (*zhě*): *Huiming Studio Edition* adds 用 (*yòng*) before 者.
29. 海 (*hǎi*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 广 (*guǎng*).
30. 钱 (*qián*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 金 (*jīn*).
31. 此 (*cǐ*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 异 (*yì*).
32. 妬 (*dù*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 青 (*qīng*).
33. 燥 (*zào*): *Huiming Studio Edition* reads 瘙 (*sào*).

*Illustrated Classic and Extended Meanings of Materia Medica, Volume Four: Mid-Grade Minerals Section* concludes.

**Mid-Grade Minerals Section: Magnetite**

Magnetite (*cishi*), acrid and salty in flavor, cold in nature, non-toxic. It governs *zhoubi* (generalized impediment). According to Xuxi et al., the *Shu Ben* annotation states: "In all cases of impediment, if the condition follows the blood vessels up and down but cannot move laterally, it is called *zhoubi*." It treats wind-dampness pain in the limbs and joints, inability to grasp objects, and washing-induced soreness. It dispels intense heat, vexation, and fullness, as well as deafness. It nourishes the kidney viscera, strengthens bone *qi*, augments essence, eliminates vexation, unblocks the joints, resolves welling-abscesses and swellings, scrofula, neck nodules, throat pain, and childhood fright epilepsy. When refined in water and consumed, it also enables one to bear children.

Alternative names: *Xuanshi* (Mysterious Stone) and *Chushi* (Residing Stone). It grows in the mountain valleys of Mount Tai and the shady side of Mount Ci, appearing where iron is present on the sunny side. Harvestable at any time. Bupleurum serves as its guiding herb. It counteracts iron poisoning, abhors tree peony and *Illicium lanceolatum*, and fears yellow halloysite.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Magnetite grows in the mountain valleys of Mount Tai and the shady side of Mount Ci, appearing where iron is present on the sunny side. Today, it is found in Cizhou, Xuzhou, and the mountainous regions near the South Sea. The Cizhou variety is the finest annual tribute, capable of attracting over ten needles in a chain or holding one or two catties of iron tools without them falling—such specimens are especially authentic. Harvestable at any time. Some stones contain cavities with a yellowish-red hue and fine hairs on the surface; these are warm in nature and superior in efficacy.

According to the *Strange Things of the Southern Regions*: "In the shallow waters of the Zhang Sea’s rocky headlands, magnetite abounds. Foreign ships clad in iron plates often cannot pass through. Thus, the South Sea yields it in great quantities."

Magnetite is also called *Xuanshi* (Mysterious Stone), yet the entry below lists *Xuanshi* separately, stating it grows on the sunny side of Mount Tai, where copper appears on the shady side—copper being yin, iron yang. Their therapeutic effects are somewhat similar, but their cold/warm natures and affinities for copper/iron differ. Su Gong considered it iron’s essence. Magnetite without cavities, glossy and purely black, is inferior in function and cannot suspend needles. Today, northern tribes use it as tribute; their pieces are often glossy but weak in attracting needles, possibly this stone. Medical formulas rarely employ it.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: Magnetite, a ministerial herb, is salty in flavor and slightly toxic. It supplements male kidney deficiency, wind deficiency, bodily stiffness, lumbar discomfort, and is used in elixir formulas. Tao Hongjing notes: "Fine specimens from the south can suspend and attract needles, linking three or four in a chain—these are best. It counteracts iron poisoning and dissolves gold. Daoist elixir formulas for yellow and white alchemy employ it."

Chen Cangqi states: *Cishi mao* (Magnetite Hair), salty and warm, non-toxic, supplements severed injuries, enhances yang potency, stops frequent white urine, treats lumbar and leg ailments, resolves sores and fistulas, promotes flesh growth, and aids conception—best taken in wine. It grows in the northern mountains of Xiangzhou. Magnetite Hair is the mother of iron, drawing it as a mother summons her child. *The Divine Husbandman’s Classic* lists magnetite but does not mention its "hair." The hair and stone differ in function. It also incorrectly describes magnetite as cold.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: Magnetite, sweet and astringent, neutral in nature, treats dim vision, sinew and bone weakness, supplements the five taxations and seven damages, eliminates vexation and agitation, resolves swelling toxins, and addresses childhood accidental ingestion of iron needles. Grind it finely, ensuring the sinew remains unbroken, and administer it with magnetite.

Lei Gong states: In preparation, do not mistakenly use *xuanzhongshi* or *zhongmashi*. These two stones resemble magnetite but cannot attract iron. *Zhongmashi* has a red core and rough skin, being an iron mountain stone. Misuse causes malignant sores, incurable. To verify: a catty of magnetite that attracts a catty of iron on all sides is called *Yanniansha* (Longevity Sand); if it attracts eight taels, it is *Xuweishi* (Continuous Stone); if five taels or less, it is magnetite.

*Formulas from the Sagely Benefit*: For childhood accidental ingestion of needles, take a magnetite piece the size of a jujube pit, polish it smooth, bore a hole, thread it with silk, and have the child hold it—the needle will emerge.

*Essential Secrets from the Imperial Library*: For *ding* swellings, pound magnetite into powder, mix with strong vinegar, and apply as a poultice—the root will immediately emerge, resolving the condition.

*Ghost-Bequeathed Formulas*: For sword wounds with intestines protruding, grind three taels each of magnetite and talc into powder, mix with white rice water, and take a square-inch spoonful twice daily.

*The Extended Meanings* states: Magnetite is light purple, with a rough, fissured surface capable of attracting and linking needles or iron—commonly called *xietieshi* (iron-attracting stone). It nourishes and benefits kidney *qi*, supplements and fills essence and marrow, and is used for kidney deficiency deafness and dim vision. For medicinal use, it must be fired until red and quenched in vinegar. *Xuanshi* (Mysterious Stone) is the black variety of magnetite, often slippery and contentious. Its therapeutic effects largely align with minor differences; they must not be conflated.

When magnetite is polished, it can point south, though it consistently deviates slightly eastward. The method: take a single silk thread from new silk floss, affix it to the needle’s waist with a wax grain half the size of a mustard seed, and suspend it in a windless place—the needle will always point south. Alternatively, thread the needle through rush pith and float it on water; it will also point south, though slightly eastward. This occurs because *bing* (fire) dominates, and *gengxin* (metal) is constrained by it—such is the mutual resonance of natural principles.

---

**Mysterious Stone (*Xuanshi*)**

Salty in flavor, warm in nature, non-toxic. It governs fright epilepsy in adults and children, female infertility, cold pain in the lower abdomen, scant essence, and bodily heaviness. Consumption enables conception.

**Mysterious Stone** (*Xuanshi*)

Also called *Xuanshui Stone* or *Chushi*. It grows on the southern slopes of Mount Tai. On the northern slopes, there is copper—copper is female, while the black stone is male. It is averse to pine resin, cypress seeds, and *jun* cassia. The *Illustrated Classic* provides details under *lodestone*.

Tao Hongjing notes: The *Shennong’s Classic* lists *lodestone* as also called *Xuanshi*. The *Supplementary Records* treats them as distinct. However, since one of its names (*Chushi*) is shared, and its therapeutic properties are similar, yet its temperature, affinity for copper or iron, and aversions differ, folk remedies no longer employ it, nor do people recognize its form. It remains unclear whether it resembles *lodestone*.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This substance is iron essence, yet it cannot attract needles. Its therapeutic effects align with the classics but are inferior to *lodestone*. High-quality *lodestone* contains fine pores, within which lies a yellow-red hue. When first broken, it can link ten needles, and a one-catty iron knife will turn toward it. That which lacks pores, gleams purely black, is *Xuanshi*—it cannot attract needles.

**Frost Water Stone** (*Ningshuishi*)

Pungent and sweet in flavor, cold to greatly cold in nature, non-toxic. It governs bodily heat, accumulations of pathogenic *qi* in the abdomen, sensations of burning in the skin, vexation and fullness—taken with water. It dispels seasonal epidemic heat, latent heat in the five viscera, stomach heat, vexation and fullness, quenches thirst, reduces water swelling, and treats lower abdominal numbness. Prolonged consumption eliminates hunger.

Also called *White Water Stone*, *Cold Water Stone*, or *Ice Water Stone*. That which resembles mica and can be split is superior—it is the essence of salt. It grows in the valleys of Mount Chang, as well as in Zhongshui County and Handan. It counteracts *croton* poisoning and is averse to *sanguisorba*.

The *Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states: *Cold Water Stone* can suppress the toxicity of cinnabar and mineral drugs, dispel heart vexation and thirst, and resolve *shaoyang* relapse after cold damage.

Tao Hongjing notes: Mount Chang belongs to Bingzhou; Zhongshui County belongs to Hejian Prefecture.

Handan belongs to Zhaojun, both lying within the borders of Jizhou. The land here is saline and alkaline, hence it is called the essence of salt, and when crushed, it resembles *sodium sulfate*. The finest variety of this stone, when not yet placed in water, can turn to ice in summer.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This stone has two types—one with vertical veins and one with horizontal veins. Those of clear and bright color are superior. Some say the vertically veined is *Cold Water Stone*, while the horizontally veined is *Congealed Water Stone*. Today, it is produced in Hancheng of Tongzhou, where the bluish-yellow variety with mica-like veins is considered best; that from Chengcheng, with slanted veins and white color, is inferior.

Xiao Yuxi notes: According to Mr. Wu, *Shennong* classifies it as pungent; *Qibo*, *Yihe*, and *Bian Que* as sweet and non-toxic; the Ji family as extremely cold. It may also grow in Yunzou, and can be gathered at any time. Its color resembles mica.

*Master Lei* states: For use, it must first be boiled in fresh ginger juice until the juice is exhausted, then ground into fine powder. For every ten taels, use one yi of ginger juice.

The *Essentials of Cold Damage* records: It treats *flesh jaundice*, where the patient’s urine is white, using *Congealed Water Stone*.

The *Mirror of Alchemical Sources* states: *Congealed Water Stone* can be used to make oil-resistant clothing, is edible, and restrains cinnabar to serve as a vessel for *mysterious essence*.

The *Tested Prescriptions* records: To treat infantile *cinnabar toxin* with red, hot skin, use half a tael of *Cold Water Stone* and two fen of white clay, ground into powder and mixed with rice vinegar for application.

The *Collected Effective Prescriptions* records: For wind-heat vexation, parched mouth, raving speech, generalized high fever, and various poisonings, the *Dragon Brain Sweet Dew Pill* is used—half a jin of *Cold Water Stone* is fired for half a day, then placed in a pit covered with a basin, surrounded by damp earth, and left overnight. After retrieval, two taels each of licorice powder and *tabasheer*, and two fen of *borneol*, are added, mixed with glutinous rice paste into pills the size of a bullet, to be taken with honey water.

The *Amplification* states: *Congealed Water Stone*, also called *Cold Water Stone*, has translucent veins. Some carve it into vessels for use in summer. For medicinal use, it must be fired; some merchants fire it and mix it into face powder to counterfeit the genuine, which must be carefully discerned. Tao Hongjing’s claim that the best variety turns to ice in summer—if so, it would be unattainable in the world, and his words seem exaggerated.

---

**Actinolite**

Flavor: salty; slightly warm; non-toxic.
Governance: Uterine flooding and spotting, breaking blood stasis in the uterus, concretions and conglomerations, alternating chills and fever, abdominal pain, infertility, impotence, supplementing insufficiency, treating coldness at the glans penis, damp itching of the scrotum, eliminating malodorous sweat, and dispersing water swelling. Prolonged consumption eliminates hunger and enables childbearing.

Also called *White Stone*, *Stone Birth*, or *Sheep-Rising Stone*; it is the root of mica. It grows in the valleys of Mount Qi and Langye, or Yunshan and Yangqi Mountain. It may be gathered at any time. *Mantis egg-case* serves as its guiding substance. It is averse to *alisma*, *cassia bark*, *omphalia*, and *snake slough*, and fears *cuscuta*.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: *Actinolite* grows in the valleys of Mount Qi and Langye, or Yunshan and Yangqi Mountain. Today, it is found only in Qizhou; other regions no longer produce it. Some say it also exists on Magpie Mountain in Xingzhou, but the quality is inferior. West of Qizhou’s city lies a single earthen hill where the stone is mined—locals call it Yangqi Mountain. This mountain is perpetually warm; even in midwinter, when snow blankets the region, this hill alone remains bare, as the stone’s qi steams and dispels it. The mountain has only one cave, which the authorities keep sealed. At the onset of winter, the prefecture dispatches laborers under supervision to extract the stone. Over time, the cave has deepened, and chiseling through other rocks to reach it has become arduous. The finest variety is white with a lustrous texture resembling *wolf’s tooth*; those mixed with other stones are unusable. Each year, the best specimens are selected for tribute, while the remainder is sold in the prefecture. Otherwise, merchants would have no means to obtain it. Though much is sold, high-quality specimens remain rare.

The *Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states: *Actinolite* is averse to *stone mallow* and contraindicated with sheep’s blood. Its flavor is sweet and neutral. It governs supplementing kidney qi, treating seminal exhaustion, lumbar pain, cold-damp impediment, warming the long-cold uterus, addressing cold concretions and conglomerations, and stabilizing menstrual irregularity.

Tao Hongjing notes: This stone’s origin is the same as mica’s, and it closely resembles mica but is thicker and more substantial. Today, it is produced in Yizhou alongside *alum*, with a slightly yellow-black color like alum. It is unclear which is the true "root of mica," and its common use is rare. The *Immortal Scriptures* also record its consumption.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: The best *actinolite* is white with a texture resembling *stalactites*, still interspersed with green, moist mica—hence the *Divine Farmer’s Classic* also names it *White Stone*. Today, some use a pure black variety like charcoal, which is erroneous. The mica entry already states that black mica is called *cloud gall* or *earth lacquer*, and its consumption harms people; thus, black *actinolite* must be malign. The *Classic* states it grows on Mount Qi—Mount Qi lies five or six li northwest of Licheng in Qizhou, but inquiries reveal no *actinolite* there. *Actinolite* is actually produced on Lushan, six or seven li northwest of Mount Qi. The *Classic*’s "or Yunshan" is a corruption of *Lu* (庐) to *Yun* (云). Today, only black *actinolite* is found on Mount Tai and in Yizhou; the white variety is exclusive to Qizhou.

Xiao Yuxi notes: Mr. Wu states: *Actinolite*—*Shennong* and *Bian Que* classify it as sour and non-toxic; *Tongjun*, *Leigong*, and *Qibo* as salty and non-toxic; the Ji family as slightly cold. It may also grow on Mount Tai.

The *Southern Seas Pharmacopoeia* states: The finest *actinolite* is the yellow variety from Mount Tai; the white variety from Magpie Mountain in Xingzhou is also good.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: For *actinolite*, the variety resembling wolf’s fang is finest. Externally, its color is not white but resembles ginger stone. In large pieces, however, the interior is white. It treats vacuity cold in the lower regions of men and women, exhaustion of kidney qi, and enduring cold in the child’s palace. It must be water-ground and levigated for use. All mineral drugs, whether cold or hot, are toxic; their use should be carefully weighed.

*Konggongnie* is acrid and warm, non-toxic. It governs undigested food, perverse qi binding malignities, sores, ulcers, fistulas, and hemorrhoids; frees the nine orifices; promotes lactation; and treats yin sores in men and yin erosion in women, as well as somnolence following food damage. Also called *tongshi* ("penetrating stone"), it is the root of *yinni*. It is greenish-yellow and grows in the mountain valleys of Liangshan. Magnolia bark serves as its courier. It is incompatible with asarum. *The Illustrated Classic* notes: Details are provided under the entry for *stalactite*.

*The Materia Medica of Drug Properties* states: *Konggongnie* is contraindicated with sheep’s blood. It is sweet and slightly toxic, governing cold in the lower back, knee impediment, toxic wind, and yin erosion sores in men and women. It treats habitual somnolence and clarifies the voice. Tao Hongjing says: Liangshan belongs to Fengyi Prefecture; this is today’s *stalactite bed*, also found in Shixing, where it is broken into large pieces. All varieties of *stalactite* share a single body but differ in form. That which accumulates from dripping fluid in stone chambers over time is called *stalactite bed*—this is *konggongnie*. The next grade, with small stalactites, is *yinni*, now commonly called *konggongnie*. The finest, lightest *yinni* is *stalactite*. Though of the same class, their therapeutic effects differ, and their market value varies greatly. These two *nie* are unsuitable for pills or powders; people crush them, steep them in wine, and drink the infusion to strongly treat leg weakness. For the foregoing indications, decoction in water may be preferable. Nowadays, the three varieties share a common root but grow in different places, their quality depending on the land.

*Ri Huazi* states: *Konggongnie* is sweet and warming, treating concretions and conglomerations. This is the *yinni* bed.

Xiao Yuxi notes: According to *The Sichuan Materia Medica*, there are five varieties of *stalactite*: (1) *stalactite*, (2) *yinni*, (3) *konggongnie*, (4) *stone bed*, and (5) *stone flower*. Though of the same body, their therapeutic effects differ. These two *nie* are only suitable for steeping in wine and cannot be used in pills or powders, yet they strongly treat leg weakness and leg qi. *Stone flower* and *stone bed* are detailed in later entries.

*Qingxiazi* says: *Nie* lightens the body and allays hunger.

*Yinni* is acrid and warm, non-toxic. It governs rotting wounds, static blood, diarrhea with cold and heat, scrofula, concretions, conglomerations, and binding qi, as well as cold and painful leg weakness. Also called *jiangshi* ("ginger stone"), it is the root of *stalactite*. It grows in the mountain valleys of Zhaoguo, as well as Liangshan and the Southern Seas. It may be gathered at any time. It is incompatible with *fangji* and fears atractylodes.

*The Illustrated Classic* notes: Details are provided under the entry for *stalactite*. Tao Hongjing says: Zhaoguo belongs to Jizhou; this is what people today call *konggongnie*, resembling ox or sheep horns, one or two *chi* long, also found in Shixing. The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This is the root of *konggongnie* beneath stone chambers, coiled like ginger—hence the name *jiangshi*. Common people mistakenly call it *konggongnie*.

Xiao Yuxi notes: According to *Ri Huazi*, *yinni* treats weak sinews and bones, hemorrhoids, fistulas, and other ailments, as well as promoting lactation.

*Mituoseng* is salty, acrid, and neutral, slightly toxic. It governs enduring diarrhea, the five hemorrhoids, metal wounds, facial scars, and is used in facial ointments.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Mituoseng* is not recorded in *The Divine Farmer’s Classic* as to its place of origin. The annotation says it comes from Persia. Today, it is also found in silver and copper smelters in Lingnan and Minzhong, being the dross of silver and lead. When ore is first mined, silver and copper are mixed; lead is added and smelted, and the silver follows the lead out. Then, mountain leaves are burned to ash, and a furnace is dug in the ground and filled with ash, called an *ash pit*. The silver-lead mixture is placed on the ash, and intense fire is applied. The lead seeps into the ash below, while the silver remains on top. When the fire ceases and cools, the silver is removed. The ash pit, infused with lead and silver qi over time, accumulates this substance. What is used today is often this product, not necessarily imported from abroad. The best resembles *huanglongchi* (fossilized dragon’s teeth) but is harder and heavier.

*Ri Huazi* states: It is sweet, neutral, and non-toxic, settling the heart, supplementing the five viscera, and treating fright epilepsy, coughing, vomiting, and phlegm ejection.

Lei Gong says: For processing *mituoseng*, pound it finely and place it in a porcelain crucible. Fill a heavy paper bag with willow borer powder, heat it over the crucible, then add flowing water to fill it, and boil for a full day and night. Remove the willow powder and paper bag, and use the *mituoseng*.

Xiao Yuxi notes: According to the *Sichuan Materia Medica* annotation, the five hemorrhoids are: *muzhi* (prolapsed hemorrhoids), *jiuzhi* (alcoholic hemorrhoids), *changzhi* (intestinal hemorrhoids), *xuezhi* (bleeding hemorrhoids), and *qizhi* (qi hemorrhoids).

*The Sagely Benefit Formulas*: For freckles and macules: Grind two *liang* of *mituoseng* finely, mix with human milk, and apply to the face nightly.

Another formula: For red and white dysentery with scant but frequent discharge: Burn three *liang* of *mituoseng* until yellow, grind to powder, and take one *qianbi* with vinegar tea, three times daily.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For facial shine and cold: Decoct *mituoseng* with human milk and apply to the face; it is also excellent for rosacea and pimples.

*Tan’s Pediatric Formulas*: For smallpox scars and facial blemishes: Grind *mituoseng* finely, mix with water, and apply at night; wash off in the morning, and the complexion will be restored.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: *Mituoseng* (litharge) is best when hard and heavy, and when struck, reveals a golden hue. **Iron essence** is balanced and slightly warm in nature; it brightens the eyes and transforms copper. It treats palpitations, stabilizes the heart-qi, addresses pediatric wind-epilepsy, yin *tuo* (prolapse), and rectal prolapse.

*The Illustrated Classic* notes: Details are provided under the entry for iron. **Tao Hongjing** remarks: *Tieluo* (iron filings) is the iron slurry used for dyeing black. **Raw iron** refers to unworked iron from spears, cauldrons, and the like, while **steel** is wrought by smelting raw iron with *shengfou* (unrefined iron) to forge blades and sickles. **Iron essence** emerges from the forge as a fine, purple-hued dust—lighter varieties are superior. It is also used to polish steel implements. **Chen Cangqi** adds: **Needle sand** is balanced in nature and non-toxic. It can dye white fabrics black and, when mixed with *moshizi* (gallnuts), dyes beards a deep black. When refined into powder, its effects resemble those of iron powder, and it is also essential in the preparation of iron powder. Only pure steel sand is effective; adulteration is common and erroneous. He further states: **Iron filings** from beneath the forge, pungent and balanced in flavor, are non-toxic. They govern demonic strikes, *gu* (venomous) infestations, and malevolent qi. Soak them in water, stir until froth appears, then strain and discard the dregs. Drink one or two cups of the warm liquid. **Rihuazi** notes: Iron filings treat fright-induced disorders, epilepsy, pediatric *kewu* (visitation), aid digestion, and dispel cold qi—all by decocting and consuming the liquid. Another source states: The tip of a plowshare soaked in water yields **iron essence**, which can neutralize the toxicity of cinnabar, realgar, and mercury.

*The Sagely Benefit Formulas*: For **yin prolapse**: Mix iron essence with sheep fat until thick, wrap in cloth, heat, and apply as a hot compress to reduce the prolapse. Another formula: For **gu-poison** in food, causing abdominal hardness, pain, greenish-yellow eyes, emaciation, and unpredictable symptoms: Grind iron essence finely, pound with chicken liver, and form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take five pills with wine before and after meals.

**Raw iron** is slightly cold in nature.

Governs treatments for the lower body and anal prolapse.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Details are provided under the entry for iron rods.

Yu Xi notes: According to *Ri Hua Zi*, raw iron is forged, then refined by flying; the coarse red liquid is washed away, and the residue is dried by baking before use. It treats epilepsy, calms the heart, stabilizes the five viscera, and can blacken hair and beard. It also treats ringworm, malignant sores, scabies, and spider bites—grind with garlic and apply, or mix with raw oil for application. **Note**: Explanation is found under the entry for iron essence.

*The Handbook of Emergency Remedies*: For poisonous pain from bear or tiger injuries, boil raw iron until the water is flavored, then wash the wound. Another formula: For bruising with stagnant blood lodged in the joints or ribs that will not disperse, boil one jin of iron in three sheng of wine until reduced to one sheng, and consume.

*The Collected Effective Formulas*: For chronic anal prolapse, boil three jin of raw iron in one dou of water until reduced to five sheng, remove the iron, and wash the affected area with the liquid twice daily.

*The Secret Records of Mother and Child*: For sudden *biao*-sores in children (also called festering sores), heat iron and quench it in water twenty-one times, then bathe the child with the water two or three times. The resulting liquid can be used as a *biao*-sore decoction.

**Soft iron**
Flavor: sweet. Non-toxic.
Governs sword wounds, vexation and fullness, heat in the center, cold qi in the chest and diaphragm, and indigestion. Another name: *tiao*.
**Note**: Explanation is found under the entry for iron essence.

**The Illustrated Classic** states: Details are provided under the entry for iron. Iron governs the strengthening of muscles and endurance of pain.

**The Illustrated Classic** states: The specific prefectures and commanderies where various irons are produced are not recorded, though they likely originate from the same regions. Today, smelting furnaces exist in Jiangnan and West Shu, with foundries present in all such locations.

*Iron filings* refer to the fine flakes that fall when a blacksmith heats iron until red-hot and forges it on the anvil—commonly called "iron blossoms."

Iron initially smelted to remove ore, used for casting vessels and implements, is called *raw iron*. When repeatedly melted and hammered to form sheets, it becomes *wrought iron*, also known as *refined iron*. When raw and refined iron are blended to forge the edges of knives and swords, it is called *steel*.

The fine, purple-hued, lightweight particles that fly from the forge like dust—used for polishing bronze vessels—are called *iron essence*. The fine powder ground by needle-makers from their grinding wheels is called *needle sand*.

When any iron is submerged in water for an extended period, a blue-green froth emerges, which can be used to dye silk—this is called *iron broth*. When iron sheets are placed in vinegar lees for a long time, a coating forms that can be scraped off—this is called *iron blossom powder*. When refined by fire, it becomes *iron powder*.

The method for making *iron blossom powder* is elaborate and not recorded here. None of the various irons are typically used in medicinal pills or powders; only their decocted liquids are employed. *Iron blossom powder*, however, is ground extremely fine and combined with other medicines. Items such as horse bits, steelyard weights, axle pins, pestles, and saws are heated and quenched in wine for use. The water from sharpening knife and axe blades is also used medicinally. These folk remedies have proven effective, hence their inclusion.

---

**Coral**
Flavor: sweet. Neutral. Non-toxic.
Governs stagnant blood, removes corneal opacity, and treats nasal polyps. Ground into powder and blown into the nose.

Grows in the South Seas.

**The Illustrated Classic** states: Coral grows in the South Seas. Some sources say it also comes from the Persian and Sinhala kingdoms. Today, it is also found in Guangzhou, where it is said to grow on the seabed in branching forms, lustrous and translucent like red jade. Many specimens are porous, though some are not; those with more branches are rarer. Harvested at no fixed time.

According to the *Classic of the Sea*, coral is obtained by sinking an iron net to the seafloor, where coral grows through its mesh, reaching heights of two to three *chi* over the years. It has branches but no leaves. The net is then hauled up, breaking the coral, which is why intact specimens are rare. It is unclear whether modern harvesting methods follow this practice.

The *Jade Pool* of the Han dynasty contained coral twelve *chi* tall, with a single trunk branching into three limbs and 463 smaller offshoots. Said to have been a tribute from Zhao Tuo, the King of Nanyue, it emitted light at night.

Shi Chong of the Jin dynasty owned coral six to seven *chi* tall, though such large specimens are no longer heard of today.

The *Tang Materia Medica* notes: It resembles jade, red and lustrous, often porous, though some are not. It also comes from Persia, the Sihu kingdom, and Sinhala.

First appended in the *Tang Materia Medica*.

Chen Cangqi states: It grows on rocky cliffs, and when scratched, its sap flows like blood. When gold is cast into it, it forms *golden nectar*; when jade is cast into it, it becomes *jade marrow*. Long-term consumption grants longevity.

Ma Zhi comments: According to *Ri Huazi*, it calms the heart, arrests fright, and brightens the eyes.

The *Overseas Materia Medica* states: As recorded in the *Jin Annals*, the Golden Valley Garden of Shi Chong was adorned with interlacing coral trees. It is sweet, neutral, and non-toxic, governing the dissipation of stagnant blood and wind-epilepsy. Its therapeutic properties resemble those of gold.

The *Record of Strange Things* states: It comes from Persia and is among the most precious treasures of the human world.

**Iron Minister’s *Basket of Formulas***: For treating children aged seven or eight with superficial corneal opacity that has not yet hardened, avoid applying medicine indiscriminately. Instead, apply *coral powder*, ground finely and thoroughly, using a small amount to dot the eye for a cure.

**Extended Meanings** states: Coral treats corneal opacity and is now used as an applicator for eye medicine. One variety is a rich, oily red with fine vertical striations, prized for its beauty. Another, resembling red lead and lacking striations, is considered inferior.

For medicinal use, the rich, oily red variety is preferred. I once saw a specimen over a foot tall, with two main branches rising straight upward, dividing into more than ten offshoots. Near the top, these branches intertwined and fused, their red luster and fine vertical striations forming a remarkable sight.

In the seas of Persia lies Coral Isle. Fishermen sail large vessels and lower iron nets to the seabed. Coral first grows upon submerged rocks as white, fungus-like formations. After one year, it turns yellow; by the third year, it becomes red, its branches and trunks intertwining to reach three or four feet in height. The iron nets uproot the coral, which is then hauled aboard the vessels. If not harvested in time, it rots.

**Stone Crab**
Flavor: salty
Nature: cold
Toxicity: none
Therapeutic effects: Treats green blindness, superficial corneal opacity, nail-like opacity, and lacquer sores. Found in the Southern Sea.
Some say it is an ordinary crab that, over long years, becomes encrusted with sea foam and transforms into stone, drifting ashore with the tides. Another variety enters caves, and over time, undergoes the same transformation. For medicinal use, it is finely ground and water-processed, then combined with other ingredients to dot the eyes, yielding excellent results.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: It comes from the Southern Sea, and today is found in all prefectures near the sea in Lingnan. Its substance is stony, yet its form resembles that of a crab. Some say it is a sea crab that, over many years, becomes encrusted with sea foam and turns to stone, drifting ashore with the wind and tides to be gathered by people. Another variety enters caves, and over time, undergoes the same change. When ground with vinegar and applied, it treats abscesses and resolves metal and mineral poisoning. It may be gathered at any time.

Lu Yuxi notes: According to *Ri Hua Zi*, Stone Crab is cooling. It resolves all drug poisons and *gu* toxins, hastens childbirth, induces abortion, treats blood dizziness, disperses abscesses, and cures epidemic heat diseases—all when ground and taken with boiled water.

It is also said: **Floating Stone** is neutral and non-toxic. It quenches thirst, treats strangury, and neutralizes wild animal toxins.

The *Extended Meanings* states: Stone Crab is simply the common live crab, with no difference, except that it is encrusted with mud and coarse stone. For use, remove the mud and stone, retaining only the crab. When ground with other ingredients to dot the eyes, it must first be water-processed.

**Long Stone**
Flavor: pungent, bitter
Nature: cold
Toxicity: none
Therapeutic effects: Clears bodily heat, resolves stagnant *qi* in the stomach, treats cold extremities, promotes urination, unblocks the blood vessels, brightens the eyes, removes corneal opacity and blurred vision, expels the three worms, kills parasitic toxins, stops wasting-thirst, descends *qi*, and dispels pathogenic *qi* from the flanks, ribs, and lungs. Prolonged consumption eliminates hunger.
Alternate names: Square Stone, Earth Stone, Straight Stone. Its texture resembles horse’s teeth—square, moist, and lustrous, with a jade-like hue. It grows in the valleys of Changzi Mountain, as well as Mount Tai and Linzi. It may be gathered at any time.

Master Tao Yinju states: Changzi County belongs to Shangdang Prefecture, while Linzi County belongs to Qingzhou. Neither folk remedies nor *Daoist scriptures* (*Xianjing*) make use of this stone.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This stone resembles gypsum but is thicker and larger, with longitudinal veins and an elongated form. Its grain resembles horse’s teeth.
