*Rihuazi* states: *Qiang huo* treats all wind disorders and qi stagnation, muscle spasms, weakness of the four limbs, dizziness, improves vision, relieves red and painful eyes, as well as *fu liang* water qi, the five taxations and seven injuries, vacuity detriment, cold qi, and aching bones and joints. It is the mother of *qiang huo*.

The *Thousand Gold Prescriptions* states: It unblocks and disinhibits the five viscera. *Du huo* treats wind stroke with generalized cold, clenched jaw, and loss of consciousness. Steep four liang of *du huo* in one sheng of good wine, decoct to half a sheng, and take warm in two divided doses.

The *Infallible Prescriptions* states: For postpartum abdominal colic and stabbing pain, decoct two liang of *qiang huo* in one sheng of wine, reduce to one sheng, strain, and take in two doses.

The *Minor Prescriptions* states: For postpartum wind vacuity, *Du Huo Decoction* is the ruling formula. Alternatively, *Bai Xian Pi Decoction* governs it. It may also be combined with *du huo* and *bai xian pi*, each three liang, decocted in three sheng of water to one and a half sheng, and taken in three divided doses.

Another formula: For postpartum wind stroke with slurred speech and tetanic reversal of the four limbs, grind three liang of *qiang huo* into powder. Take five qian per dose, decocted in half a cup each of water and wine, strained, and taken warm.

Minister Wen Lu states: For wind attacking the gums causing swelling and pain, grind three liang each of *du huo* and rehmannia into powder. Take three qian per dose, decocted in one cup of water, and taken warm.

**Cimicifuga** (*Sheng Ma*)

Produced in Chuzhou and Hanzhou. Flavor: sweet, bitter. Nature: neutral, slightly cold. Non-toxic. It governs resolving the hundred poisons, killing the hundred spirits, old entities, and baleful ghosts, and repelling warm epidemics, miasmic qi, evil qi, and *gu* toxins.

If taken, it causes immediate vomiting. It treats sudden affliction with abdominal colic, seasonal epidemic toxins, pestilential qi, headache with alternating chills and fever, wind-swelling, and all poisons, as well as sore throat and sores. Prolonged consumption averts premature death, lightens the body, and prolongs life. It is also called *zhou ma*. It grows in the mountain valleys of Yizhou. The root is harvested in the second and eighth months and dried in the sun.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Today, it is found in Shu-Han, Shaanxi, and the Huainan prefectures, with the variety from Shu being superior. In spring, the seedling grows to over three *chi* in height. The leaves resemble hemp leaves and are green. In the fourth and fifth months, it bears flowers resembling millet spikes, white in color. After the sixth month, it sets black fruit. The root is purple like mugwort root, with many fibrous rootlets. Modern physicians use it to treat swollen and painful throat, sores of the mouth and tongue, and to resolve headache from cold damage. For all types of swelling and poison, one *liang* is finely chopped, decocted in one *sheng* of water, and reduced to a thick decoction for consumption—once it enters the mouth, it immediately halts the spread of toxic qi. The people of Shu frequently use it.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: *Shu sheng ma* governs the treatment of infantile wind, fright epilepsy, seasonal qi, and febrile illnesses. It can treat wind-erosion swelling and pain of the mouth and teeth, floating and rotting tooth roots with foul odor, pus and blood from heat toxin, and eliminates wind-toxin heat from the heart and lungs causing obstruction and blockage. It also treats mouth sores, vexation, and oppression. It heals abscesses and *wandou* sores—decoct in water, soak cotton, and apply to the sores. It controls the hundred malevolent spirits and demons.

Tao Yinju states: The finest variety formerly came from Ningzhou—slender and black, exceedingly firm and solid—but such has long since vanished. Now it comes only from Yizhou; the superior kind is finely shaved, with a bluish-green skin, called "chicken-bone *sheng ma*." Some also grow in the northern regions, but these are hollow and large, yellow in color. Those from Jianping are likewise coarse in form and weak in flavor, unfit for use.

Master Lei says: After harvesting, scrape off the rough outer bark with a knife, then fumigate it. Soak overnight in the natural juice of *huangjing* (Solomon’s seal), remove, and dry in the sun. Chop finely, steam, then dry in the sun again before use.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: It settles the hun and po souls, halts ghostly wailing and weeping, and treats wandering wind swellings, toxic sores, and oral *gan* erosions. It is also called *luoxinfu* (falling bridewort).

*The Sagely Benefit Formulas*: For treating infantile maculae and *dou* sores with heart vexation and restless sleep, take an unspecified amount of Sichuan *sheng ma*, chop finely, decoct in one cup of water, strain, and use the liquid to wash the sores with cotton.

*The Supplement to the Thousand Gold Wing Formulas*: For postpartum retention of stagnant blood lasting months or even half a year, take three *liang* of *sheng ma*, boil in five *sheng* of clear wine, reduce to two and a half *sheng*, and divide into two warm doses.

*Master Mei’s Formulas*: For epidemic sores. Take five *liang* of *sheng ma*, decoct with water and honey until boiling three times, then take half internally and apply half topically to the sores.

*Yao Hezhong’s Formulas*: For infantile bloody urine. Take five *fen* of Sichuan *sheng ma*, decoct in five *ge* of water, reduce to one *ge*, strain, and administer the full dose in one day for a one-year-old child.

*The Handbook of Emergency Formulas*: For throat impediment. Chop *sheng ma* and hold it in the mouth; the same applies to throat obstruction.

*Cheqianzi* (plantain seed) from Chuzhou.

Flavor sweet, salty; nature cold; non-toxic. Governs qi blockage of the bladder, relieves pain, facilitates the water pathways and urination, eliminates damp impediment, treats male internal injury, female dripping strangury, loss of appetite, nourishes the lungs, strengthens the yin and augments essence, enables conception, brightens the eyes, and heals redness and pain. Prolonged consumption lightens the body and confers resistance to aging.

Leaves and root: flavor sweet; nature cold. Govern metal-inflicted wounds, stanch bleeding, nosebleed, static blood, blood conglomerations, blood descent, red urine, relieve vexation, downbear qi, and expel small worms. Also called *dangdao*, *fuyi*, *xiamayi*, *niuwei*, and *shengxi*. Grows in the plains, marshes, hills, and slopes of Zhengding. Harvest on the fifth day of the fifth month; dry in the shade.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Now found everywhere in the Jianghu, Huaidiao, near the capital, and northern regions. In early spring, the seedling emerges, its leaves spreading along the ground like spoon faces. In subsequent years, they grow over a *chi* long, resembling rat tails. The flowers are very fine, greenish with a slight red hue. The fruit resembles that of *tingli*, with red clusters.

The *Zhujing* Pill employs *cheqian* and *tusi* as its two ingredients, formed into honeyed pills and taken after meals—now regarded as a remarkable formula.

*The Materia Medica Properties* states: *Cheqian* seed is a sovereign ingredient, flavor sweet, nature balanced. It dispels wind-toxin, liver wind-heat, toxic wind attacking the eyes, red and painful eyes, screen and shades, brain pain with tearing, and suppresses mineral toxin. It eliminates heart and chest vexing heat. The leaves govern seminal emission disorders, treat bloody urine, supplement the five viscera, brighten the eyes, disinhibit urination, and free the five types of strangury.

*Rihuazi* states: With *changshan* as its guide, it frees inhibited urination, strengthens yang, treats seminal collapse, heart vexation, and downbears qi.

Yuxi notes: Respectfully citing *The Erya*: *Fuyi* is *maxi*; *maxi* is *cheqian*.

**Annotation:**
Today’s *cheqian* herb has large leaves and long spikes, thriving along roadsides. In Jiangdong, it is called "toad’s cloak." The commentary cites Lu Ji’s annotation: *Maxi* is also named *cheqian* and *dangdao* ("by the way"), as it delights in growing in ox tracks—hence the names *cheqian* ("before the cart") and *dangdao*. The people of Youzhou call it "ox-tongue grass," which can be boiled as a vegetable; it is very slippery. Its seeds treat difficult childbirth in women.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library* states: For bloody urine, pound *cheqian* herb to extract five *ge* of juice and take it on an empty stomach.

*The Sagely Benefit Formulas* states: For chronic internal eye obstructions, take equal parts *cheqian* seed, dried *dihuang* (Rehmannia), and *maimendong* (Ophiopogon), grind into powder, form honeyed pills the size of *wutong* seeds, and consume. This has proven effective through repeated trials.

*The Hundred and One Formulas* states: For inhibited urination, decoct one *jin* of *cheqian* seed and herb in three *sheng* of water until one and a half *sheng* remain; divide into three doses.

Another formula: For stone strangury, place two *sheng* of *cheqian* seed in a silk pouch, boil in eight *sheng* of water until three *sheng* remain, and consume the entire decoction without eating. Shortly after, the stones will descend.

*Master Mei’s Formulas* states: For strangury during pregnancy with heat obstructing the water passage, decoct five *liang* of *cheqian* seed with one *sheng* of sliced *kuigen* (mallow root) in five *sheng* of water until one and a half *sheng* remain; divide into two doses.

*The Secret Records of Mother and Child* states: For transverse presentation preventing delivery, take a two-*qianbi* dose of powdered *cheqian* seed with wine.

*A Formula for Diarrhea* records: Minister Ouyang Wenzhong once suffered from sudden diarrhea, which imperial physicians could not cure. His wife said: "A market vendor sells this medicine—three *wen* per packet, and it is highly effective." She purchased it, and the imperial physicians’ remedies were administered alongside it. After one dose, he recovered. Later, the vendor was summoned and asked for the formula, which consisted solely of powdered *cheqian* seed, taken in a two-*qianbi* dose with rice broth. It was said to disinhibit the water passage.

*Extended Meanings* states: Tao Hongjing said: "Its leaves, pounded to extract juice, treat seminal emission." This is a grave error. This herb is sweet and slippery, disinhibiting urination and draining seminal *qi*. The *Classic* states it governs red urine and downbears *qi*. Someone who ate it as a vegetable suffered from urinary incontinence, nearly misled by it.

**Mu Xiang** (Aucklandia)
*Haizhou, Guangzhou*

**Aucklandia (Mu Xiang)**

Aucklandia is acrid in flavor, warm in nature, and nontoxic. It governs malign *qi*, repels pestilential toxins and febrile *gui*-spirits, strengthens resolve, governs *lin* and *lu* (dripping discharge), remedies *qi* deficiency, treats localized cold in the muscles, supplements insufficiency of *qi*, resolves toxins, slays demonic essence-beings, warms malaria and *gu* toxins, and conveys the essence of medicinals. With prolonged consumption, one no longer dreams of waking nightmares, the body becomes light, and one attains the state of spirit immortality. It is also called *mixiang* (honey fragrance). It grows in the mountain valleys of Yongchang.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Only that which comes aboard ships from Guangzhou is available; there is no other source. Tao Hongjing said: There is also a variety in the Jiang-Huai region called *shangqing muxiang* (upper green aucklandia), but it is unfit for medicinal use. *The Book of Cultivation and Nourishment* states: On the first day of the first lunar month, boil five kinds of wood to make a decoction for bathing, and it will keep one’s hair and beard black even in old age.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: Aucklandia, as a sovereign medicinal, treats women’s blood-*qi* stabbing the heart, unbearable heart pain, and when powdered and taken with wine, it remedies nine kinds of heart pain, long-standing cold *qi*, *xuanpi* (abdominal masses) and *zheng* (fixed accumulations) with distention and pain, dispels all obstructing *qi* surging upward, vexation and oppression, and treats cholera with vomiting and diarrhea, as well as heart and abdominal stabbing pain.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: There are two varieties; that which comes from Kunlun is superior, while that from the Western Hu is inferior. Its leaves resemble sheep’s sorrel but are longer and larger; its flowers resemble chrysanthemums, and its seeds are yellow-black. It is also found elsewhere. Now, according to the *Alternative Annotation*: Its leaves resemble *shuyu* (Chinese yam) but its roots are large; its flowers are purple, and its efficacy is great, making it a key medicinal. Tao’s claim that it is unfit for use is incorrect.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: It treats all *qi* in the heart and abdomen, stops diarrhea, cholera, and dysentery, calms the fetus, fortifies the spleen, promotes digestion, remedies emaciation, and treats cold pain in the bladder, retching, and counterflow stomach *qi*.

Xiao Bing said: That which comes aboard Kunlun ships, with a form like withered bone, is of the finest quality.

Yu Xi notes: According to *The Sichuan Materia Medica*, it is now cultivated in gardens. Its flowers are yellow, its stalks grow three to four *chi* tall, its leaves are eight to nine *cun* long, wrinkled, soft, and hairy.

*The Book of Sui* records: When Fan Zigai was governor of Wuwei and the imperial carriage journeyed west, about to enter Tuyuhun, Zigai, knowing the region was rife with miasmic *qi*, presented green aucklandia to ward off mist and dew.

*The Materia Medica of Overseas Medicinals* states: According to *The Classic of Mountains and Seas*, it grows on Kunlun Mountain in the Eastern Sea.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: A formula for treating armpit odor. Soak green aucklandia in sour vinegar and place it under the armpits as a compress; this will cure it.

*The Categorized Essentials of Cold Damage*: For epidemic febrile diseases with red and black macules like *lao* (scabies), boil two *liang* of green aucklandia in two *sheng* of water, reduce to one *sheng*, and take all at once for efficacy.

*Extended Meanings* states: Aucklandia is especially effective at draining and resolving stagnation and cold *qi* in the chest and abdomen; other uses are secondary. Combined with tangerine peel, nutmeg, and fresh ginger as assistants, its effects are exceptionally swift and potent.

There is another variety: once, while traveling beyond Min, I obtained fresh green aucklandia beyond the frontier and brought it back to Luoyang. Its leaves resemble *niulao* (a type of grass) but are narrower and longer; its stems grow three to four *chi* tall, its flowers are yellow like gold coins, and its root is green aucklandia. Chewing it raw is intensely acrid and fragrant, and it is particularly effective at moving *qi*.

---

**Coix Seed (Yiyi Ren)**

Coix seed is sweet in flavor, slightly cold in nature, and nontoxic. It governs hypertonicity and cramping with inability to flex or extend, wind-damp impediment, downbears *qi*, eliminates *qi* of deviant *bi* and numbness in the sinews and bones, disinhibits the intestines and stomach, disperses water swelling, and enables one to eat. With prolonged consumption, the body becomes light and *qi* is augmented. Its root expels the three kinds of worms.

It is also called *jieli*, *wutan*, *qishi*, and *gan*. It grows in the plains and marshes of Zhending and in the wild. The seeds are harvested in the eighth month; the root may be collected at any time.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Coix seed grows in the plains and marshes of Zhending and in the wild; it is now found everywhere. In spring, it sprouts, with stalks growing three to four *chi* tall. Its leaves resemble those of millet.

The plant bears red and white flowers in spikes. In the fifth and sixth months, it produces fruit—greenish-white in color, shaped like pearls but slightly elongated, hence the name "coix pearls." Children often string them on threads like beads for play. Ancient formulas generally employ it in remedies for the heart and lungs.

Ge Hong’s method for sudden heart and abdominal vexation and fullness, as well as chest and rib-side pain, involves finely chopping the root, boiling it to a thick decoction, and consuming three *sheng* to settle the condition. Today, people often use the leaves to make a fragrant infusion.

Zhang Zhongjing’s treatment for wind-dampness with generalized vexing pain that worsens at dusk employs the *Ephedra, Apricot Kernel, and Coix Seed Decoction*: three *liang* of ephedra, thirty apricot kernels, one *liang* each of licorice and coix seed. These four ingredients are decocted in four *sheng* of water until two *sheng* remain, then divided and taken warm in two doses.

Tao Yinju states: Zhen Ding County belongs to Changshan Prefecture, and the plant is found everywhere along the roads and in households. The seeds from Jiaozhi are the largest, and the locals call them "dried pearls." When Ma Yuan transported a large quantity back, slanderers claimed they were real pearls. The heavier and more densely clustered the seeds, the better. When using them, select those of medium size.

For childhood ascariasis, decoct the root to make a gruel and feed it to the child—its fragrance is most appealing, and it proves highly effective in expelling roundworms.

Chen Cangqi adds: It governs wasting-thirst and kills roundworms. The root, when decocted and taken, induces abortion.

Lei Gong states: For proper preparation, select the variety with large, flavorless grains—these are what people commonly call *jingmi*. If using *yiyiren*, choose the small, greenish grains with a sweet taste that cling to the teeth when chewed. For a standard dose of one *liang*, stir-fry it with two *liang* of glutinous rice until the rice is fully cooked, then discard the rice and use the *yiyiren*. Alternatively, it may be boiled in saltwater—this constitutes another method of preparation.

Ma Zhi notes: According to the *Yaoxing Lun*, it treats heat-wind and spasmodic contraction of the sinews, stimulating the appetite. It governs lung atrophy, lung qi disorders, expectoration of pus and blood, coughing, nasal discharge, and sputum, as well as counterflow ascent of qi.

Meng Shen states: Its nature is neutral, and it effectively dispels both dry and damp leg qi.

The *Shiyi Xinjing* records: It treats spasmodic contraction of the sinews, chronic wind-damp impediment, downbears qi, eliminates perverse qi from the bones, disinhibits the intestines and stomach, disperses water swelling, and with prolonged consumption, lightens the body and augments qi and strength. Take one *sheng* of *yiyiren*, pound it into powder, and for each dose, boil two *sheng* of water with two spoonfuls of the powder to make a congee, consuming it on an empty stomach.

The *Meishi Fang* states: For lung disorders with expectoration of pus and blood, take ten *liang* of *yiyiren*, pound it to pieces, decoct in three *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains, add a small amount of wine, and take.

The *Yanyi* remarks: *Yiyiren*—this is what Li Shangyin referred to in his *Tai Cang Ming* as "the *yiyi* resembling pearls, a matter not to be taken lightly." Select the grains for use.

The *Shen Nong Bencao Jing* states: It is slightly cold and governs spasmodic contraction of the sinews. There are two types of spasmodic contraction: as noted in the *Suwen* commentary, when the great sinews are affected by heat, they contract and shorten, leading to spasms and inability to extend—this is spasmodic contraction due to heat, for which *yiyiren* is suitable. However, if the *Suwen* describes spasmodic contraction due to cold, this remedy should not be used further.

Ze Xie (Water Plantain) [from] Qizhou.

Flavor sweet and salty, cold, non-toxic. Governs wind-cold-damp impediment, difficult lactation, disperses water, nourishes the five viscera, augments qi and strength, promotes plumpness and vigor, supplements vacuity detriment and the five taxations, eliminates glomus and fullness in the five viscera, raises yin qi, checks seminal emission, wasting-thirst, and strangury, and expels water retention in the bladder and triple burner. With prolonged consumption, it sharpens hearing and vision, prevents hunger, extends years, lightens the body, brightens the complexion, and enables one to walk upon water.

Bian Que states: Excessive consumption harms the eyes.

Alternative names: *shuixie*, *jixie*, *mangyu*, *huxie*. Grows in the ponds and marshes of Runan. Harvest the root in the fifth, sixth, and eighth months, and dry in the shade.

It fears *haige* and *wenxia*.

The leaf—flavor salty, non-toxic. Governs great wind, failure of lactation, difficult childbirth, and strengthens yin qi. With prolonged consumption, it lightens the body. Harvest in the fifth month.

The fruit—flavor sweet, non-toxic. Governs wind impediment and wasting-thirst, boosts kidney qi, strengthens yin, supplements insufficiency, and dispels evil dampness. With prolonged consumption, it brightens the complexion but renders one childless. Harvest in the ninth month.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Alisma (*ze xie*) grows in the ponds and marshes of Runan. Today, it is also found in Shandong, the Yellow River region, Shaanxi, Jiang, and the Huai River basins, with the finest specimens coming from Hanzhong. In spring, its shoots emerge, often in shallow waters. Its leaves resemble those of *niusheshe* (plantain), with a single long stem. In autumn, it bears white flowers in clusters resembling *gujingcao* (pipewort). The root is harvested in the fifth, sixth, and eighth months and dried in the shade.

*The Plain Questions* describes a condition of bodily heat, lassitude, profuse sweating as if bathed, aversion to wind, and shortness of breath, naming it "wine wind." It is treated with a formula of alisma and *zhu* (atractylodes), each in ten parts, and *mixian* (loranthus) in five parts, combined and taken in two-finger pinches before meals. "Before meals" (*hou fan*) means taking the medicine prior to eating.

Zhang Zhongjing treats miscellaneous diseases where phlegm-rheum (*zhi yin*) lingers beneath the heart, causing dizziness, with *Ze Xie Tang* (Alisma Decoction): five *liang* of alisma, two *liang* of *zhu*, decocted in two *sheng* of water until reduced to half a *sheng*, then divided and taken warm in two doses. For cold damage, there are the *Da Ze Xie Tang* (Major Alisma Decoction) and *Xiao Ze Xie Tang* (Minor Alisma Decoction), as well as *Wu Ling San* (Five-Ingredient Powder with Poria), all of which employ alisma to promote the movement and drainage of stagnant water.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: Alisma is a chief herb, bitter in flavor. It governs kidney deficiency with spontaneous seminal emission, treats the five types of strangury (*wǔ lín*), clears bladder heat, and facilitates the waterways.

Tao Hongjing notes: Runan Commandery belongs to Yuzhou. Though alisma also grows nearby, it is unfit for use. Only the varieties from Hanzhong, Nanzheng, and Qingsuo—large and long, with two forks at the tail—are considered excellent. This herb is prone to decay and insect damage, so it must be stored carefully. Its narrow, long leaves grow in clusters in shallow waters.

*The Immortals' Scriptures* prescribe it for grain avoidance (*duan gu*) in Daoist practices, claiming it lightens the body and enables one to walk upon water.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: It treats the five taxations and seven injuries, dizziness, empty ringing in the ears, spasms and contractions of the sinews and bones, unblocks the small intestine, arrests seminal leakage and urinary bleeding, hastens childbirth in difficult labor, supplements the blood sea in women, and restores fertility.

The leaves strengthen the water viscera, promote lactation, and activate the blood vessels.

*Tested Prescriptions* records: For regular consumption, boil alisma in water with *zaojia* (Gleditsia sinensis) until soft, dry, and grind into powder. Mix with refined honey to form pills the size of *tongzi* (millet). Take fifteen to twenty pills on an empty stomach with warm wine—highly effective. It is especially beneficial for treating wind in the kidney viscera with sores.

*An Extension of the Materia Medica* states: Alisma excels in promoting water movement. Zhang Zhongjing’s *Ba Wei Wan* (Eight-Ingredient Pill) includes it not for any other purpose but to guide *gui* (cinnamon) and *fu* (aconite) into the kidney channel. Those who take alisma powders invariably experience increased urination. With frequent urination, how can kidney qi be replenished? Thus, many today avoid its use for arresting seminal emission.

*Shu Yu* (Dioscorea) — Chuzhou, Mingzhou.

Flavor sweet, warm, balanced, non-toxic. It governs internal injury, supplements deficiency and emaciation, dispels cold-heat pathogenic qi, fortifies the center, boosts qi and strength, promotes muscle growth, treats wandering wind of the head and face, wind-induced head dizziness, descends qi, arrests lumbar pain, replenishes deficiency taxation and emaciation, fills the five viscera, eliminates vexing heat, and strengthens yin. With prolonged consumption, it sharpens hearing and vision, lightens the body, banishes hunger, and extends years.

Alternate names: *shanyu* (mountain taro); in Qin and Chu, *yuyan* (jade tendril); in Zheng and Yue, *tuzhu* (earth tuber). It grows in the valleys of Mount Songgao. Harvest the root in the second and eighth months, then dry in the sun. *Zizhi* (purple ganoderma) serves as its guiding herb; it is incompatible with *gansui* (kan-sui).

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Those from Beidu and Siming are of the finest quality. In spring, the seedling sprouts and the vine spreads along fences. The stem is purple, the leaves green, with three pointed lobes resembling those of *qianniu* (morning glory) but thicker and more lustrous. Guo Pu’s commentary notes: The root resembles taro and is edible. Today, people in Jiangnan simply call it *zhu*, though pronunciation may vary slightly. According to this annotation, *shuyu* (dioscorea) and *zhu* (tuber) are one and the same. The produce of the north and south may differ, hence slight variations in form. Yet the divergence in pronunciation and storage suggests a long-standing misattribution.

Alternate name: *shanyu* (mountain taro).

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: *Shuyu* (dioscorea) is a ministerial herb. It can supplement the five taxations and seven damages, dispel cold wind, relieve lumbar pain, settle the heart spirit, pacify the hun and po souls, open the orifices of the heart, enhance memory, and supplement insufficiency of heart qi. For those suffering from bodily deficiency and emaciation, it may be used in greater quantities.

Tao Yinju observes: Today, it grows abundantly in nearby regions. In Dongshan and Nanjiang, people dig it up in large quantities for food, using it as a staple. Those from Nankang are the largest and finest, and are also used in medicinal preparations.

Meng Xishi states: According to Master Wu, *shuyu* (dioscorea) is also called *zhushu*; in Qi and Yue, it is named *shanyu* (mountain taro), and is further known as *xiucui* and *ercao*. The Divine Farmer classifies it as sweet and slightly warm. Tong Jun and Master Lei declare it sweet and non-toxic. It sometimes grows on Mount Zhong in Linqu, beginning with red stems and slender vines. Its flowers bloom white in the fifth month; its fruits turn greenish-yellow in the seventh month and ripen to fall in the eighth. Its root is white within, yellow-skinned, resembling taro.

*The Heart Mirror of Food and Medicine* states: It governs deficiency and cold in the lower burner, frequent urination, emaciation, and lack of strength. Take half a catty of fresh taro, peel and chop finely, then grind to a pulp. Place in a wok with wine, adding *shuyu* once the wine boils—do not stir. When cooked, season with salt and scallion whites, then add more wine. Drink two or three cups on an empty stomach; wondrously effective.

*The Sagely Benevolence Formulary*: To supplement deficiency, enhance complexion. Grind *shuyu* finely in a stone mortar, then transfer to a pot. First, heat one large spoonful of butter until fragrant, then gradually add a cup of wine while simmering. Stir evenly and drink on an empty stomach.

*Chongweizi* (motherwort seed):
Flavor: pungent, sweet; slightly warm, slightly cold; non-toxic.
It brightens the eyes, augments essence, dispels water qi, and treats counterflow blood with great heat, headache, and heart vexation. Prolonged consumption lightens the body.
Its stem governs urticaria and itching; it may be used to prepare a bath decoction.
Alternate names: *yimu* (benefits mothers), *yiming* (brightens the eyes), *dazha*, and *zhenwei*. It grows in seashore marshes and wetlands.

The herb is gathered in the fifth month.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: All refer to it as *tui*, which is motherwort. Thus, when Master Zeng saw it, he was moved to gratitude. Liu Xin also said: *Tui* is foul and filthy—this foul and filthy plant is none other than motherwort.

*The Extensive Relief Formulary*: To treat children suffering from gan dysentery on the verge of death, boil motherwort and feed it to them until satiated; cease when the condition improves. It is highly effective. It also governs difficult labor: pound the herb to extract seven *ge* of juice, reduce by half through simmering, and administer in one dose to induce immediate delivery. If fresh herb is unavailable, use one large handful of dried herb, decoct in seven *ge* of water, and take.

Tao Hongjing says: It grows everywhere today. Its leaves resemble those of *ren* (perilla), its stem is square, and its seeds are slender and three-angled. It is rarely used in prescriptions.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: Pound motherwort stems and apply to clove sores; ingesting the juice causes the toxin to dissipate internally. It also expels a dead fetus from the womb, treats postpartum blood distension and oppression, various toxic swellings, cinnabar sores, and other swellings. Drip juice the size of a soybean into the ear to treat festering ears. For viper bites, apply topically—it is highly effective.

Chen Cangqi says: In the fields and wilds, people call it "rank-smelling grass."

Further, *The Alternative Annotation* states: Its seeds resemble those of *ximing* but are slightly coarser and larger, with a faint cold steam. When prepared as a decoction or pounded to extract juice for consumption, it expels a dead fetus.

*Ri Hua Zi* says: It treats postpartum blood distension; the shoots and leaves share the same efficacy. These are the seeds of motherwort. Its stem is jointed, and flowers resembling cockscombs bloom at the nodes. The seeds are black and are gathered in the ninth month.

*The Sagely Benevolence Formulary*:
- To treat constricted breast pain leading to abscess in women: Grind motherwort into powder, mix with water, and apply to the breast overnight—it will resolve spontaneously. Freshly pounded herb may also be used.
- Another formula: To treat postpartum blood stasis. Pound motherwort to extract juice; take one small cup per dose, mix with one *ge* of wine, warm, stir evenly, and consume.

*The Handbook of Emergency Remedies*:
- For all blood disorders in women and all injuries in postpartum women: Cut motherwort with a bamboo knife, wash clean, refine into a paste in a silver vessel, and seal in a porcelain container. Take with wine.

*Master Sun’s Formulas*:
- For horse bites: Finely chop motherwort, stir-fry with vinegar, and apply as a poultice.

*The Collected Effective Formulas*:
- For women’s red and white vaginal discharge: When motherwort flowers bloom, gather and pound into powder. Take two *qian* per dose before meals, mixed with warm water.

*The Alchemical Mirror Source*:
- Burn motherwort to ash, knead with wheat-flour water, and fire it to produce *pian* (a refined mineral product). It treats facial wind acne and also regulates sulfur.

*The Amplification of Materia Medica* says: Motherwort leaves, even in early spring, may be boiled and eaten as a vegetable; they remain verdant through winter’s harshness. Empress Wu of Tang once burned this ash and incorporated it into high-grade facial preparations.

*Nuwei* (also called *weirui*)
- **Produced in**: Chuzhou, Shuzhou
- **Flavor**: Sweet; neutral; non-toxic.
- **Governance**: Wind-stroke with sudden heat, inability to move, sinew and flesh contractions, all insufficiencies, bound qi in the heart and abdomen, deficiency heat with damp toxin, lumbar pain, cold in the penis, and eye pain with canthus erosion and tearing.

Prolonged consumption dispels facial dark **, enhances complexion, imparts moisture and luster, and lightens the body to prevent aging. It is also called *ying*, *dijie*, *yuzhu*, or *maxun*. It grows in the mountain valleys and hills of Mount Tai. Harvest after the Beginning of Spring and dry in the shade. It is averse to brine and salt.

*The Illustrated Classic* says: Guo Pu’s commentary states it is a medicinal herb. It does not share the alternate names of *nüwei*, and it is suspected to be a distinct substance. Moreover, the *Divine Farmer’s Classic* lists it in the middle rank and separately includes an entry for *nüwei*. Su Gong says: This is indeed *nüwei*, where the red-inked text in the current *Classic* records the efficacy of *nüwei*, while the black-inked text describes the functions of *weirui*. A review of ancient formulas suggests a distinction. *The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: *Weirui* is a sovereign herb. It governs seasonal illnesses with alternating chills and fever, internally supplements insufficiency, dispels deficiency taxation with guest heat, and relieves restless head pain—its effects are enhanced when used in combination.

Tao Hongjing says: The *Divine Farmer’s Classic* includes *nüwei* but not *weirui*, while the *Supplement to the Materia Medica* omits *nüwei* but includes *weirui*, yet their uses are identical, differing only in name. Thus, *nüwei* should indeed be *weirui*. It is now found everywhere. Its root resembles *huangjing* (Siberian Solomon’s seal) but with minor differences, and it is also used by those who consume it for longevity.

*Ri Huazi’s Materia Medica* says: It dispels vexation and oppression, quenches thirst, moistens the heart and lungs, supplements the five taxations and seven injuries of deficiency detriment, relieves lumbar and leg pain, and treats epidemic heat mania—there are no contraindications for its consumption.

Master Lei says: When using, do not mistake it for *gouwen* (gelsemium) or *huangjing*, as these two resemble it. *Weirui* differs in that its nodes bear fine hairs, its stem is speckled, and its leaf tips have small yellow dots. After harvesting, first scrape off the nodal skin with a bamboo knife, wash it clean, then soak it in honey water overnight, steam it, and dry by baking.

Xiao Bing says: *Weirui* supplements the center and boosts qi; it is produced in Junzhou.

*Yang’s Obstetrics and Lactation Formulas*: To treat unremitting chronic dysentery with rectal prolapse, take one *sheng* of *nüwei*, slice it, and burn it for fumigation.

*Fangji* (prevents *kui*).

**Xiangzhou**—flavor pungent, sweet, bitter; nature cold; non-toxic. Governs hernia and abdominal masses, intestinal flux, heat binding in the bladder with inhibited urination, cough with counterflow qi, warm malaria, epilepsy, fright-induced madness and wandering, and treats vacuity qi of the five viscera, propping fullness in the lesser abdomen, drum distention, dry mouth, expels kidney evil, and strengthens the will. Long-term consumption hardens the bones and marrow, boosts qi, and lightens the body. Those with central fire must not consume it, as it causes disorientation and visions of spirits.

Alternate names: *Ligai*, *Fangci*, *Jueli*, *Nongguo*, *Liru*, *Fanggai*.

Grows in the river valleys of Linzi, as well as on Songgao, Mount Tai, and Shaoshi. The root is harvested on the third day of the third month and dried in the sun.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Tao Yinju says, "It shares the same root as *langdu* (wolfsbane), but does not sink in water." Now, however, withered and decayed *langdu* is mistakenly used in its place—this is gravely erroneous. The root is harvested on the third day of the third month; it blooms in the sixth month and sets seed. The root is used medicinally.

*The Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This herb is of the superior grade, non-toxic, and long-term consumption governs diseases of evil qi and fright-madness. Its root and leaves resemble those of sunflower, and its fragrance and flavor resemble *fangfeng* (saposhnikovia), hence the name *fangkui* (preventive malva). When harvested at the proper time, it too can sink in water. Now, withered and decayed *langdu* is mistakenly used in its place—this is gravely erroneous.

Chen Cangqi says: According to this, the two substances—one of the superior grade—are distinct, though Tao states that *fangkui* shares the same root as *langdu* but does not sink in water. Yet these two differ in nature and efficacy, and their forms are distinct. Tao’s claim has led later generations to conflate them. *Fangkui* is used to break hard accumulations as a lower-grade substance, equated with *langdu* in function. Through the ages, this confusion has persisted without correction—this is a grievous error.

Master Lei says: When using, do not mistake it for *langdu*, for though they closely resemble each other, their effects differ. Exercise utmost care to avoid harming the patient.

Yu Xi says: Respectfully citing *The Treatise on Medicinal Properties*: *Fangkui*, as a sovereign herb, has slight toxicity. It treats qi hernia, congealed accumulations, chronic water in the bladder, and blood-qi tumors as large as bowls, all of which it can disperse. It governs ghost malaria, all manner of demonic and spectral afflictions, and unblocks qi.

*The Handbook of Emergency Remedies*: To treat epilepsy and madness, take *fangkui* powder with warm wine, one *daogui* per dose, up to two or three doses. The signs of efficacy are a moistened body and slight numbness.

*Illustrated Classic of the Materia Medica, Expanded and Discussed*, Scroll Eight—End.
*Minghui Studio Edition* reads "consider" for "pour."
*Cold*: Originally "causes," emended per *Minghui Studio Edition*.
*Cold*: Originally "causes," emended per *Minghui Studio Edition*.
*Cease*: *Minghui Studio Edition* reads "vomit."
*Form*: *Minghui Studio Edition* reads "large."
*Accumulation*: *Minghui Studio Edition* reads "black."
*Formula*: *Minghui Studio Edition* reads "ancient," to be read with the following character.
*Ox*: Originally "one," emended per *Minghui Studio Edition*.
*Especially*: *Minghui Studio Edition* reads "hold."
*Three*: Originally "two," emended per *Minghui Studio Edition*.
*Qian*: Originally "cotton," emended per *Minghui Studio Edition*.
*Substance*: *Minghui Studio Edition* reads "do not."
*Great*: *Minghui Studio Edition* reads "husband."
*Distress*: Originally "gate," emended per *Minghui Studio Edition*.
*Cold steaming*: *Minghui Studio Edition* reads "stale qi."
*Partial*: *Minghui Studio Edition* reads "pervasive."

*Illustrated Classic of the Materia Medica, Expanded and Discussed*, Scroll Nine
Compiled by Kou Zongshi, *Tongzhilang* of the Song, Discerning Medicinal Materials
Collated by Xu Hong, *Taiyi Assistant* of the Song, Discerning Medicinal Materials
**Herbs, Superior Grade (Upper Tier)**
*Yuanzhi* (Polygala)

**Yuanzhi (Polygala)**

Produced in Shangzhou, Weisheng Commandery, and Qizhou, where it serves as the sovereign herb. Flavor: bitter. Nature: warm, non-toxic. Governs cough with counterflow qi, damage to the center, supplements insufficiency, dispels evil qi, frees the nine orifices, augments wisdom, sharpens hearing and vision, prevents forgetfulness, strengthens the will, doubles strength, benefits men, stabilizes heart qi, arrests fright palpitations, augments essence, expels qi below the heart and diaphragm, heat in the skin, and yellowing of the face and eyes. Long-term consumption lightens the body, prevents aging, improves complexion, and prolongs life.

Its leaves, called *xiaocao* ("small herb"), govern augmenting essence, supplementing yin qi, arresting vacuity detriment, and stopping dream emissions.

Alternate names: *jiwan*, *yaorao*, and *xicao*. Grows in the valleys of Mount Tai and Yuanju. The root and leaves are harvested in the fourth month and dried in the shade.

Combines well with *fuling* (Poria), *dongkuizi* (winter malva seeds), and *longgu* (dragon bone); counteracts the toxins of *tianxiong* (Aconitum) and *fuzi* (prepared aconite); and is averse to *zhenzhu* (pearl), *lilu* (Veratrum), *feilian* (cockroach), and *qige* (gecko).

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Now also found in the prefectures of He, Shaan, and Jingxi. The root is yellow and shaped like mugwort root. The seedling, called *xiaocao*, resembles *mahuang* (ephedra) but is green, and also resembles *bidou* (caltrop). Its leaves may also resemble those of *daqing* (woad) but are smaller. It blooms in the third month with white flowers, and its roots grow up to one *chi* in length. The root and leaves are harvested in the fourth month and dried in the shade. The variety from Sizhou has red flowers, and its roots and leaves are larger than those from other regions. The roots from Shangzhou are black. Popular tradition holds that the finest *yuanzhi* comes from Yimen.

*Fan Wang’s Remedies* treats chest impediment, heart pain, counterflow qi, and inability to swallow fluids in the diaphragm.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: *Yuanzhi* is averse to *qicao* (grubs). It treats forgetfulness due to heart-spirit weakness, pacifies the hun and po souls, prevents confusion, strengthens the yang path, and governs dream evil.

Tao Yinju notes: Among medicinal names, there is no *qige* (gecko); this may refer to *baihe* (lily). Yuanju County belongs to Yanzhou’s Jiyin Commandery and is still brought from north of Pengcheng via Lanling. When using it, remove the core and retain the bark—one *jin* of the herb yields only three *liang* of bark. Some say: Tao’s suggestion that it may be *baihe* is incorrect.

*Ri Huazi* states: It governs diaphragm qi, nightmares, promotes flesh growth, aids sinews and bones, treats women’s blood lock with loss of voice, and childhood fright reversal. There are no contraindications to its consumption.

*The Inner Chapters of the Master Who Embraces Simplicity* states: Lingyang Zhongzi consumed *yuanzhi* for thirty years, fathered thirty-seven sons, and could recall anything he read without forgetting.

Master Lei states: For *yuanzhi*, first remove the core—if not removed, consumption causes oppression. After removing the core, soak it overnight in a decoction of prepared *gancao* (licorice), then strain, dry in the sun, and use.

*The Handbook of Emergency Remedies* states: To treat dullness and blockage of the heart’s orifices, frequent forgetfulness, and errors in judgment, secretly purchase *yuanzhi* at the market on a *dingyou* day, place it in the corner of your headscarf, return home, grind it into powder, and consume it without letting others know. *Xixin* (Asarum).

**Kelan of Huazhou (Hua Prefecture)**

*Asarum (Xixin)*: Pungent in flavor, warm, non-toxic. Governs cough with counterflow qi, headache, brain movement, stiffness of the hundred joints, wind-damp impediment pain, dead flesh, warms the center and downbears qi, breaks phlegm, disinhibits the waterways, opens the chest, dispels impediment, nasal congestion, wind epilepsy and manic disorders, resolves breast lumps, promotes lactation, checks sweating, quickens the blood, quiets the five viscera, boosts the liver and gallbladder, and frees the essence qi. With long-term consumption, it brightens the eyes, disinhibits the nine orifices, lightens the body, and prolongs the years. Another name: *xiaoxin* ("small pungent"). Grows in the mountain valleys of Huayin. The root is collected in the second and eighth months and dried in the shade. *Zengqing* and jujube root serve as its couriers. It is incompatible with *langdu*, *shanzhuyu*, and *huangqi*; it is averse to *xiaoshi* and *huashi*; it is antagonistic to *lilu*.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: It is now found everywhere, yet what is produced elsewhere does not compare to the genuine from Huazhou. Its root is fine and its flavor extremely pungent, hence the name *xixin* ("fine pungent"). Today, many mistake *duheng* for it. *Duheng* induces vomiting, so one must carefully distinguish them. In the Jiang-Huai region, it is popularly called *mati xiang* ("horseshoe fragrance"), and because of frequent misuse, this is explained in detail.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: *Xixin* is a ministerial drug. Avoid raw vegetables. Bitter and pungent in flavor. It treats cough with counterflow qi, malign wind and wind-head, spasm of the hands and feet, quiets the five viscera and six bowels, augments gallbladder qi, dispels skin wind-damp itch, checks eye wind and tearing, brightens the eyes, opens chest stagnation, relieves toothache, governs blood block, and treats women’s blood spotting with lumbar pain.

Master Lei states: For every use, carefully remove the paired leaves—consuming them harms the person. Remove the soil from the head, soak it overnight in melon water, strain it out at dawn, and dry in the sun before use.

Yu Xi states: According to Fanzi, *xixin* from Huayin is white in color and bitter.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: To treat sudden guest counterflow with locked jaw and inability to speak, insert equal parts *xixin* and *guixin* into the mouth.

*Separate Remarks* states: Carefully note that only *xixin* from Huazhou may be used as *xixin*. If it is something like *duheng*, it should be employed according to its own nature. Moreover, if *xixin* is used alone as a powder, the dose must not exceed half a *qianbi*—excess causes qi block and suffocation, leading to death.

*The Sagely Benefit Formulas* states: To treat foul breath and swollen, painful gums, boil *xixin* to obtain a thick decoction, hold it warm in the mouth, and spit it out—this will cure it.

*Extension of the Materia Medica* states: *Xixin* uses the root. Today, only that from Huazhou is excellent: supple, extremely fine and straight, deep purple in color, and intensely pungent in flavor. When chewed, it tingles like pepper. It is indispensable for treating head and facial wind pain. Its leaves resemble those of mallow, also black. Anything else is *duheng*. The leaves of *duheng* resemble a horse’s hoof, hence the popular name *mati xiang*. Its root resembles *baiqian* and also *xixin*. In the Xiang-Han region, there is a kind of *xixin* that is extremely fine and straight, yellow-white in color—this is *guidusheyou* and must not be used.

---

**Shihu of Chunzhou and Wenzhou**

*Dendrobium*: Sweet in flavor, neutral, non-toxic. Governs center damage, dispels impediment, downbears qi, supplements the five viscera, treats vacuity taxation with emaciation, strengthens yin, boosts essence, supplements inner exhaustion, levels stomach qi, grows flesh, expels skin heat and miliaria qi, and treats painful cold impediment and weakness of the knees and legs. With long-term consumption, it thickens the intestines and stomach, lightens the body, extends the years, settles the mind, and eliminates fright. Other names: *linlan*, *jinsheng*, *dulan*, and *shisui*. Grows on rocks by water in the mountain valleys of Liu’an. The stem is collected in the seventh and eighth months and dried in the shade. *Luying* serves as its courier. It is incompatible with *ningshuishi* and *badou*; it is averse to *jiangcan* and *leiquan*.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: It is now found in the commanderies of Jing, Hu, Chuan, and Guang, as well as in Wenzhou and Taizhou, with that from Guangnan being the finest. It grows in mountain valleys.

In the fifth month, it sprouts, its stem resembling bamboo nodes, with small leaves emerging between the nodes. In the seventh month, it blooms, and by the tenth month, it bears fruit. Its roots are slender and long, yellow in color. Some say the stem is harvested, washed with wine, stripped, steamed, and dried without using lye water.

Those growing in Jiangnan have two varieties: one resembles barley, with grains strung together, its head bearing a single leaf—called *maihu* (barley dendrobium); the other is as large as a sparrow’s thigh, named *quebihu* (sparrow-thigh dendrobium), with only those growing on rocks being superior. Some also grow on trees, called *muhu* (wood dendrobium), but these are unusable.

Tao Yinju states: The *shihu* (stone dendrobium) now in use comes from Shixing. Growing on rocks, it is fine and solid. When rinsed with mulberry ash water, it turns golden, resembling a grasshopper’s thigh—this is the finest. Those found near roads are inferior. Those growing on oak trees in Xuancheng are called *muhu* (wood dendrobium), with longer, larger stems and a lighter color. Liu’an belongs to Lujiang, and now Shian also produces *muhu*, which is hollow and long, unsuitable for pills or powders, only for wine infusions or decoctions.

Folk remedies most often use it to tonify deficiency and treat weakness of the knees and legs.

*The Ri Hua Zi* states: It treats deficiency and emaciation, strengthens sinews and bones, warms the water viscera, lightens the body, sharpens the mind, harmonizes stomach qi, and dispels deficiency evil.

Lei Gong states: For use, first remove the soil from the head, soak in wine overnight, strain, sun-dry, then steam with butter from *si* (9–11 a.m.) to *you* (5–7 p.m.), and slowly dry over a fire.

Yu Xi states: According to *The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties*, *shihu* is a sovereign herb. It boosts qi, clears heat, treats weakness and softness of men’s waist and legs, strengthens yang, dispels wind impediment in skin and muscles, addresses long-standing cold and deficiency in bones, tonifies the kidneys, accumulates essence, relieves lumbar pain, nourishes kidney qi, and enhances strength.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: *Shihu* is slender like small grass, three to four *cun* long, supple and tough—when broken, it resembles flesh yet is solid. Nowadays, *muhu* is often used indiscriminately, and even physicians cannot clearly distinguish them. The world also calls it *jinchai shihu* (golden hairpin dendrobium), a name later coined for its resemblance. However, *muhu* is hollow when broken, like millet stalks, over a *chi* long, with only a deep color and slight luster. True *shihu* is effective in treating deficiency heat in the stomach.

---

**Bajitian** (Morinda Root)
*Guizhou, Chuzhou*
Flavor: pungent, sweet; slightly warm; non-toxic.
Governance: Major wind and evil qi, impotence, strengthens sinews and bones, stabilizes the five viscera, tonifies the center, enhances will, boosts qi, treats wandering wind on the head and face, dragging pain in the lower abdomen and genitals, descends qi, tonifies the five taxations, augments essence, and benefits men.
Grows in Bajun and the mountain valleys of Xiapi. The root is collected in the second and eighth months and dried in the shade. *Fupenzi* (raspberry) serves as its courier. It is averse to *chaosheng*, *leiquan*, and *danshen*.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: It is now also found in the commanderies of Jianghuai and Hedong, though none compare to those from Shu. Its leaves resemble tea, remaining green through winter—commonly called *sanmancao* (three-vine herb) or *bufuicao* (evergreen herb). Some leaves resemble *maidong* (dwarf lilyturf). There are now two types: when struck open, those with purple and fresh interiors are counterfeit. The genuine, when struck, shows purple with a faint white sprinkling like powder.

Tao Yinju states: Now those from Jianping and Yidu are also used, resembling peony but finer, with a red exterior and black interior. The core is removed before use.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: The seedling of *bajitian* is commonly called *sanmancao*. Its leaves resemble tea, remaining green through winter. The root resembles a string of pearls, with more being better. Old roots are green, while young roots are white-purple, used similarly. Those with thick, connected pearls are superior.

*The Ri Hua Zi* states: Flavor: bitter. It stabilizes the five viscera, calms heart qi, dispels all wind, treats evil qi, and cures edema. Also called *bufuicao*, it is purple like small prayer beads, with tiny holes, hard and difficult to pound.

Lei Gong states: For use, first soak in *gouqizi* (goji berry) decoction overnight until slightly softened, strain, then soak in wine for a full day and night. Next, simmer with chrysanthemum until scorched yellow, remove the chrysanthemum, wipe dry with cloth, and use.

Yu Xi states: According to *The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties*, purple *bajitian* is an envoy herb. It treats men’s nocturnal emissions and ghostly intercourse, strengthens yang, dispels wind from the head and face, governs descending qi, and major wind with blood *lai* (leprosy). It is added for patients with deficiency and taxation.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: *Bajitian* originally has a core, which sometimes falls out when dried or can be pulled out, leaving the center hollow—not naturally having small holes. Now, to achieve a purple center, some counterfeit it by soaking in soybean juice—this must be examined. The exterior is hard to dye, so the purple starts from the center. There was a man fond of wine, drinking five to seven cups daily. Later, he suffered from severe beriberi and was in danger. Someone advised him to stir-fry half a *liang* of *bajitian* with glutinous rice until the rice slightly changed color, discard the rice, then mix with one *liang* of *dahuang* (rhubarb), stir-fried and ground into powder, and form into pills with cooked honey. Taking fifty to seventy pills with warm water while abstaining from wine, he recovered.

---

**Chijian** (Red Arrowroot)
*Yanzhou*

**Chijian (Red Arrowroot)**
Flavor: pungent. Nature: warm.
Governs the expulsion of demonic essences, *gu* toxins, and malign *qi*; disperses abscesses and swellings; relieves distension in the limbs, *shan* disorders, and blood descent. Prolonged consumption augments *qi* and strength, lengthens the yin, fosters robustness, lightens the body, and extends the years.
Alternative names: *Limu* (Separated Mother) and *Guiduoyou* (Ghostly Courier).
Grows in the river valleys of Chencang, Yongzhou, as well as Mount Tai and Shaoshi. The root is harvested in the third, fourth, and eighth months, then dried in the sun.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Chijian* grows in the river valleys of Chencang, Yongzhou, Mount Tai, and Shaoshi. It is also found in the Jiang-Hu region, though it is not used medicinally there.
According to *The Master Who Embraces Simplicity*: In the immortal formulas, there is a herb called *Helicao* (Uniting-Separating Grass), also known as *Duyao* (Solitary Shaker) and *Limu* (Separated Mother). It is so named because its lower root resembles a taro corm, encircled by twelve wandering offshoots at a distance of several *chi* from the main corm. Though they appear interdependent, they are not physically connected—only linked by *qi*. Tao Yinju notes: Chencang belongs to Fufeng Prefecture in Yongzhou. This herb is also a type of *zhi* (mushroom). Its stem is red like an arrow shaft, with leaves growing at its tip. The root resembles a human foot or a taro, with twelve offshoots as guardians. It remains still in the wind but sways on its own when the air is calm. Such traits are rarely seen by common folk. Xu Changqing is also called *Guiduoyou*. There is another *Guijian* (Ghost Arrow), whose stem bears feathers; though its therapeutic effects resemble *Chijian*, its benefits differ, and it is likely not the same herb.
Yu Xi cites *The Treatise on Medicinal Properties*: *Chijian* is non-toxic.
*The Alternative Explanation* states: Modern physicians use *tianma* (heavenly hemp), which is the root of this *Chijian*. However, the *Supplementary Annotations* and *The Illustrated Classic* describe a different plant. In the lower rank of the middle grade, another entry for *tianma* appears, noted as originating from Yunzhou. Upon examination, the finest *Chijian* roots and shoots currently come from Qi and Yun. Shen Gua, the most erudite scholar of the Imperial Academy, once resolved this discrepancy: Ancient formulas using *tianma* do not include *Chijian*, and those using *Chijian* omit *tianma*. Though the other herbs in these formulas are identical, the names differ—implying that *tianma* and *Chijian* are the same entity, both utilizing the root. The separate entry for *tianma* in the lower rank of the middle grade bears no relation to the *Chijian* described here, confirming they are one and the same. However, the *tianma* listed in the lower rank of the middle grade has never been used in practice. If *Chijian*’s root is taken as *tianma*, it aligns with contemporary usage. *Chijian* refers to the shoot, which acts from the exterior inward, while *tianma* refers to the root, functioning from the interior outward. The root sends forth a shoot that ascends directly, while the shoot produces seeds that mature and fall, descending through the stem to the ground, where they germinate anew. This roughly illustrates the principles of its internal and external therapeutic actions.
*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: *Chijian* is the shoot of *tianma*. However, their therapeutic uses differ, so later generations distinguished them as two. The *Classic* specifies harvesting the root in the eighth month and drying it in the sun, confirming that *Chijian* is the shoot.
*Anchunzi*: Qinzhou, Ningzhou.

Flavor bitter, slightly cold and slightly warm, non-toxic. It governs static blood in the five viscera, water-qi in the abdomen, drum-like distension with retained heat, wind-cold-damp impediment, various pains throughout the body, and treats hardness below the heart, cold and heat in the diaphragm, generalized impediment, menstrual block in women, disperses food, and brightens the eyes. Prolonged consumption lightens the body, extends years, and prevents aging; the *juxu* beast that eats it becomes a transcendent. It grows in river valleys of Yongzhou, and also in Shangdang and along roadsides. The fruit is harvested in the tenth month and dried in the shade. *Jingshi* and *yiyi* serve as its guides.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: It is also found in the Jiang-Huai region today. The seedling emerges in spring, with leaves resembling mugwort, growing two to three *chi* tall. It blooms in the seventh month, sets fruit in the eighth month, and is harvested in the tenth month, then dried in the shade. Today, people commonly harvest it in the ninth month. Households in the Jiangnan region often cultivate it to repel snakes. Modern practitioners frequently employ it to treat traumatic injuries, whether in decoctions or powders, and its effects are swift. It is not seen in longevity recipes.

*Rihuazi* says: It treats heavy pain in the lower back and legs, bladder pain, brightens the eyes, and relieves vexing pain in the bones and joints, as well as loss of appetite.

Yuxi notes: According to *The Treatise on Medicinal Properties*, *anchun* serves as a guide. Its flavor is acrid and bitter. It boosts qi, governs male impotence, treats distension and fullness in the heart and abdomen, and disperses static blood.

*The Broadly Beneficial Recipes*: To treat static blood that fails to disperse and transforms into abscesses, pound fresh *anchun* and take one *sheng* of its juice.

---

Flavor acrid, slightly warm, non-toxic. It brightens the eyes, treats eye pain with tearing, dispels impediment, supplements the five viscera, augments essence and radiance, and treats pain in the heart, abdomen, and lower back. Prolonged consumption lightens the body and prevents aging. It has alternate names: *miexi*, *daji*, *maxin*, and *daji*. It grows in the river marshes of Xianyang and along roadsides. It is harvested in the fourth and fifth months and dried in the sun. It is enhanced by *jingshi* and *xixin*, and is incompatible with dried ginger and *kushen*.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *The Erya* says: *Ximing* is *daji*. Guo Pu notes: It resembles shepherd’s purse, with fine leaves, and is commonly called *laoji*. Su Gong also says it is *daji*. However, he adds that *ximing* is acrid, while *daji* is sweet. Chen Cangqi holds that *daji* is actually *tingli*, not *ximing*. *Ximing* is large and flat, while *tingli* is fine and round—these two are distinct. Yet *The Erya* separately lists *tingli*, calling it *dian*, with a note that its fruit and leaves resemble mustard, and it is also called *gouji*. Generally, both belong to the shepherd’s purse family, so people often fail to distinguish them clearly, leading to such confusion. It is frequently used in ancient and modern formulas for eye disorders.

Cui Yuanliang’s *Overseas Recipes* treats heat and pain in the eyes with unceasing tears: grind *ximing* seeds into a fine powder, and before sleep, apply it to the eyes with a copper rod. This will induce the discharge of hot tears and foul matter, and remove pterygium. Applying it for thirty or forty nights yields excellent results.

*The Treatise on Medicinal Properties* says: *Ximing* seeds use *kushen* as a guide. They treat accumulations in the liver and red, swollen eyes.

Tao Hongjing says: It is found everywhere today and is the seed of *daji*, though it is rarely used in folk practice.

Chen Cangqi says: *Ximing* seeds are listed in *The Divine Farmer’s Classic* under the alternate name *daji*. Su [Gong] cites *The Erya* in his annotation, calling it *daji*. But *daji* is *tingli*, not *ximing*. *Ximing* is large and flat, while *tingli* is fine and round—these two are entirely distinct.

---

*Shishi*
Qinzhou

Flavor bitter, sour; nature balanced, non-toxic. Governs boosting qi, filling the flesh and skin, brightening the eyes, and sharpening wisdom with foresight. Long-term consumption eliminates hunger, prevents aging, and lightens the body.

Grows in the valleys of Mount Shaoshi. Harvest the seeds in the eighth and ninth months, then dry them in the sun.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Today, near the White Tortoise Shrine in Shangcai County, Caizhou, it grows like mugwort in clusters, reaching five or six *chi* in height. A single plant may have ten to twenty stems, or even thirty to fifty at most. Its stems grow straight and upright, distinguishing it from common mugwort. After autumn, flowers bloom at the tips of the branches, red-purple in color, resembling chrysanthemums. The seeds are harvested in the eighth and ninth months, dried in the sun, and used in medicine. Physicians today rarely employ it. Its stems are used for divination to inquire of spirits and discern fortune or misfortune, which is why sages praise it as a divine object.

*The Records of the Grand Historian: Treatise on Tortoises and Divination Sticks* says: When a tortoise reaches a thousand years, it roams upon lotus leaves; when *shi* grass reaches a hundred stems, they share a single root. Where it grows, beasts such as tigers and wolves are absent, and no venomous insects dwell. Xu Guang’s commentary notes: Liu Xiang states that a tortoise becomes spiritually attuned at a thousand years, while *shi* grass produces a hundred stems from one root after a hundred years. Master Chu adds: Where *shi* grass grows with a hundred stems, a divine tortoise guards its roots, and a yellow cloud perpetually hovers above it.

*The Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This herb is found everywhere, and its stems are used for divination. Tao [Hongjing] mistakenly substituted *chu* seeds for it. *The Divine Farmer’s Classic* records its flavor as bitter, whereas *chu* seeds are sweet; thus, *chu* seeds have been moved to the section on trees.

*Juanbai*
Yanzhou, Haizhou

Flavor pungent, sweet; nature warm, balanced, slightly cold, non-toxic. Governs pathogenic qi in the five viscera, cold and heat in the female genitalia with pain, abdominal masses, blood blockage, and infertility. Stops coughing with counterflow, treats prolapsed anus, disperses urinary stones, wind-dizziness in the head, atrophy and paralysis, strengthens *yin*, and replenishes essence. Long-term consumption lightens the body, harmonizes complexion, and enhances beauty and physique.

Also called *wansui*, *baozu*, *qiugu*, and *jiaoshi*.

It grows in the mountain valleys and among rocks of Mount Chang. Harvested in the fifth and seventh months, then dried in the shade.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: It is also found in the regions of Guanzhong, Shaanxi, Yi, and Yanzhou. Its perennial roots are purple with many fibrous strands. In spring, it sprouts shoots resembling cypress leaves but finer and curled, like a chicken’s foot, in a blue-green to yellow hue, growing three to five *cun* tall. It bears no flowers or seeds and thrives on rocks. Harvest in the fifth and seventh months, then dry in the shade. Remove the portion near the stone and sandy soil before use.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: *Juanbai* is a sovereign herb. It treats menstrual blockage, corpse-*zhū* and ghost-*zhū*, abdominal pain, and dispels all manner of demonic influences.

Tao Hongjing notes: It now grows in nearby regions, clustering on rocky soil. Its fine leaves resemble cypress, curled like a chicken’s foot, in a blue-green to yellow hue. Before use, remove the portion near sandy soil.

*Ri Huazi* states: It calms the heart and treats demonic influences, wailing and weeping, removes facial freckles, head wind, and warms the water viscera. Used raw, it breaks up blood stasis; stir-fried, it stanches bleeding.

---

**Longdan**
Mountain Gentian from Luzhou; [also from] Xiangzhou

Flavor bitter; nature cold, strongly cold, non-toxic. Governs cold and heat in the bones, fright seizures, pathogenic qi, knits severed sinews, stabilizes the five viscera, kills *gu* toxins, eliminates latent heat in the stomach, seasonal warm-heat, heat-induced diarrhea and dysentery, expels intestinal parasites, augments the qi of the liver and gallbladder, and arrests fright and palpitations. Long-term consumption sharpens the intellect, prevents forgetfulness, lightens the body, and prolongs life.

Also called *lingyou*.

Grows in the mountains and valleys of Qi and Quju. The root is harvested in the second, eighth, eleventh, and twelfth months, then dried in the shade. *Aspidium* serves as its guiding herb; it is incompatible with *Stephania* and *Rehmannia*. The *Illustrated Classic* states: It is also found in nearby regions. The perennial root is yellowish-white, sending forth over ten roots below, closely resembling those of *Achyranthes*. The seedling grows straight upward, reaching over a foot in height. Leaves emerge in the fourth month, resembling willow leaves but finer. The stem branches like small twigs. In the seventh month, it blooms with flowers like those of *Pharbitis*, shaped like bells, of a bluish-green hue. After winter, it sets seed, and the seedling withers. Commonly called "cloud herb" gentian. In Xiangzhong, there is also a mountain gentian, bitter and astringent in flavor—this is a related but distinct species. Ancient formulas frequently employ it to treat jaundice. The *Collected Efficacy Formulas*’ "Grain Jaundice Pill": *Sophora flavescens* (three liang), gentian (one liang). Grind the two ingredients, sift, and mix with ox bile to form pills. Take before meals with a wheat infusion.

Tao Hongjing states: It now grows in nearby regions, with Wuxing producing the finest. Its form resembles *Achyranthes*, and its flavor is extremely bitter, hence the name "gentian" (lit. "dragon’s gall"). According to the *Alternative Annotation*: Its appearance resembles *Solanum nigrum*, and its bitterness is like gall, thus the name. *Ri Hua Zi* states: *Vigna angularis* serves as its guiding herb. It treats visiting hostility, *gan* qi, heat-induced delirium in febrile diseases, sores, scabies, brightens the eyes, relieves vexation, augments the intellect, and cures forgetfulness.

Lei Gong states: After harvesting, dry in the shade. When preparing for use, cut off the root hairs and soil with a bronze knife, then slice. Soak overnight in a licorice decoction, strain at dawn, and dry in the sun. Do not consume on an empty stomach, as it may cause urinary incontinence.

Zhang Yuxi notes: According to the *Materia Medica Theory*, gentian governs infantile fright epilepsy, enters the heart, treats vigorous heat, bone heat, swelling with obstruction, seasonal epidemics, heat jaundice, and mouth sores. The *Sagely Benefit Formulas*: For roundworms attacking the heart like stabbing, with watery vomiting: Take one liang of gentian (remove the root head), slice, and decoct in two cups of water down to one cup. Strain and consume at dawn after fasting overnight.

*The Essential Secrets from the Outer Terrace*: To treat sudden, unremitting bloody stool: Take one handful of gentian, decoct in five *sheng* of water down to two and a half *sheng*, divide into five warm doses, and consume until recovery.

*The Handbook of Emergency Remedies*: To treat sudden heart pain: Decoct four *liang* of gentian in three *sheng* of wine down to one and a half *sheng*, and consume in one dose.

**White Mugwort**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
Governs: pathogenic qi in the five viscera, wind-cold-damp impediment, supplements the center and boosts qi, promotes hair growth and blackens it, treats heart suspension, and relieves constant hunger with little food intake. Prolonged consumption lightens the body, sharpens hearing and vision, and prevents aging.
Grows in the rivers and marshes of Zhongshan. Harvest in the second month.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: White mugwort is *penghao*. It grows everywhere today. It resembles green mugwort but with coarser leaves, covered in rough white hairs. From sprouting to withering, it remains whiter than other mugworts, somewhat resembling fine mugwort. Harvest in the third month. This is the *fan* mentioned in the *Erya*, that is, *pohao*. The commentary explains: *Penghao*—now called white mugwort—sprouts in spring and becomes fragrant and delicious by autumn. It can be eaten raw or steamed. Another name is *youhu*; people of Beihai call it *pangbo*. Thus, the *Xiaoxiaozheng* in the *Rites of the Elder Dai* states: "*Fan* is *youhu*. *Youhu* is *pangbo*." This herb was once used by people as □. Meng Shen of the Tang also notes: It can be mashed and eaten with vinegar. Today, people only eat *louhao* and no longer consume this. Some suspect this mugwort is *louhao*. Tao Hongjing says: There are many types of mugwort, yet common speech does not mention white mugwort. Since physicians do not use it, it has become unrecognizable. Given its distinct therapeutic properties, further investigation is warranted. The *Seven-Animal Powder for Longevity* states: White hares that eat it become immortal. The method is the same as for *anluzi*. Meng Shen says: White mugwort is cold. In early spring, it sprouts before other grasses. Pound to extract its juice to dispel heat jaundice and heart pain. Its leaves can be mashed raw, pickled in vinegar as a vegetable, and are highly beneficial.

**White Solanum**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: cold. Non-toxic.
Governs: cold-heat, the eight types of jaundice, wasting-thirst, supplements the center and boosts qi. Prolonged consumption lightens the body and extends life.
Other names: *gucai*, *baicao*. Grows in the mountain valleys of Yizhou. Harvest leaves in spring, stems in summer, flowers in autumn, and roots in winter.

Tao Hongjing says: No formulas use this herb. There is a *hucai* that grows in water and is steamed and eaten by people. This grows in mountain valleys and is likely not the same. There is also a *baicao* whose leaves are made into soup, highly effective for taxation fatigue, though its roots and flowers are unused. In Yizhou, there is a bitter vegetable that locals eat exclusively, all appearing robust and free of illness—this may be it. The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This is *guimu* grass. It is a vine with leaves resembling *wanggua*, slightly elongated and five-lobed. Its fruit is round like *longkui* seeds, green when unripe and purple-black when mature. Decoct the juice to drink, resolving taxation. People of the East call it *baicao*. Tao’s description of *baicao* suggests recognition but not precise identification. Chen Cangqi says: White solanum governs vexing heat, wind papules, cinnabar toxin, malaria miasma with cold-heat, and childhood heat bind. Decoct the juice and drink. Another name: *guimu*.

The *Erya* states: "Fu is *guimu*." The annotation reads: It resembles *ge* vine, with hairy leaves, and its seeds are red like earrings strung with pearls. The claim that its seeds turn black when ripe is mistaken.

**Purple Zhi**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: warm.
Governs deafness, frees the joints, preserves the spirit, augments essence and qi, strengthens sinews and bones, and enhances complexion. Prolonged consumption lightens the body, prevents aging, and extends years.
Another name: *mu zhi* (Wood Zhi).
Grows in the mountain valleys of Gaoxia.
All six zhi are non-toxic; harvest in the sixth month.
*Shuyu* serves as its guiding herb. It works well with *mazi ren*, *baigua zi*, and *mu gui*, enhancing their benefits for humans. It is incompatible with *changshan* and fears *bianqing* and *yinchen hao*.

The *Yaoxing Lun* states: Purple Zhi is a guiding herb, fearing *fa*. Flavor: sweet. Nature: neutral, non-toxic. It preserves the spirit and extends life.

Tao Yinju notes: No commandery or county is named Gaoxia; it is likely a mountain name. These six zhi all belong to the category of immortal herbs. Rarely seen in common use, they comprise many varieties, differing in form and color, all recorded in the *Illustrated Manual of Zhi Herbs*. The purple zhi commonly used today grows on rotting tree stumps, resembling *mu nou*, and is called purple zhi. It only treats hemorrhoids and is unsuitable for compounding with other tonic pills.

Whenever zhi herbs are obtained, they are eaten directly without further preparation, so no specific method of consumption is prescribed.

The *Baopuzi* states: The red zhi resembles coral, the white like sliced fat, the black like lacquer, the green like kingfisher feathers, and the yellow like purple gold—all luminous and translucent, like solid ice. It also says: Wood Zhi arises from the resin of pine and cypress buried in the earth. After a thousand years, it transforms into *fuling*; after ten thousand years, a small tree grows atop it, resembling a lotus flower, called *mu wei xi zhi*. It glows at night, feels very slippery to the touch, and does not char when burned. Wearing it repels weapons.

**Red Zhi**
Flavor: bitter. Nature: neutral.
Governs chest bind, augments heart qi, supplements the center, and increases wisdom. It prevents forgetfulness. Prolonged consumption lightens the body, prevents aging, and extends years to attain immortality.
Another name: *dan zhi* (Cinnabar Zhi).
Grows on Huo Mountain.

Tao Yinju notes: Nanyue was originally Mount Heng. Emperor Wu of Han later substituted the lesser Huo Mountain for it, which is incorrect. It should properly grow on Mount Heng.

**Black Zhi**
Flavor: salty. Nature: neutral.
Governs urinary block, frees the waterways, augments kidney qi, opens the nine orifices, and sharpens perception. Prolonged consumption lightens the body, prevents aging, and extends years to attain immortality.
Another name: *xuan zhi* (Mysterious Zhi).
Grows on Mount Chang.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: The five zhi, as the *Classic* states, all arise in five colors corresponding to the Five Peaks. Yet the white zhi offered from various regions is not necessarily from Mount Hua, nor is the black zhi always from Mount Chang. Moreover, zhi are mostly yellow or white; black and green are rare. Purple zhi is the most common but does not belong to the five zhi. Since zhi are difficult to obtain, even if one or two are acquired, how can they be consumed indefinitely?

**Green Zhi**
Flavor: sour. Nature: neutral.
Governs brightening the eyes, supplementing liver qi, settling the ethereal soul, and fostering benevolence and forgiveness. Prolonged consumption lightens the body, prevents aging, extends years, prevents forgetfulness, and strengthens the will.
Another name: *long zhi* (Dragon Zhi).
Grows on Mount Tai.

**Yellow Zhi**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: neutral.
Governs the five evils of the heart and abdomen, augments spleen qi, settles the spirit, and fosters loyalty, trust, harmony, and joy. Prolonged consumption lightens the body, prevents aging, and extends years to attain immortality.
Another name: *jin zhi* (Golden Zhi).
Grows on Mount Song.

**White Zhi**
Flavor: acrid. Nature: neutral.
Governs cough and counterflow qi ascent, augments lung qi, frees the mouth and nose, strengthens the will and intent, fosters courage and boldness, and settles the corporeal soul. Prolonged consumption lightens the body, prevents aging, and extends years to attain immortality.
Another name: *yu zhi* (Jade Zhi).
Grows on Mount Hua.

**Doumu Fragrance**
Burning it dispels malign qi and eliminates epidemics. In the *Stories of Emperor Wu of Han*, the Queen Mother of the West descended, and the emperor burned powdered *doumu* fragrance. *Doumu* fragrance, presented by the Kingdom of Douqu, resembles large beans. When applied to palace gates, its fragrance carries a hundred *li*. During a great epidemic in Guanzhong, where the dead lay piled together, burning this incense halted the plague. An internal transmission states: The dead all revived. This is a numinous incense, not produced in the Central Kingdom. Its efficacy is recorded here, placing it at the head of all herbs.

**Windless Self-Swaying Grass**
Wearing it causes husband and wife to love each other.

Born in Lingnan. Its head resembles a pellet, its tail like a crow’s, and its two leaves open and close—moving of their own accord when people approach, hence the name *Windless Self-Swaying Grass*. The *Overseas Materia Medica* states: According to the *Guangzhi*, it grows in Lingnan. It is also said to grow in the Da Qin kingdom. Its nature is warm and balanced, non-toxic. It governs wandering wind on the head and face, and generalized itching. Boil it and bathe with the decoction.

Tao Zhu’s techniques record: Harvest it on the fifth day of the fifth month; it is also found in many mountain wilds.

**Sheep-Averse Grass**
