*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Gegen* (Pueraria root) grows in the river valleys of Wenshan, though it is now found everywhere, particularly abundant in Jiang and Zhe. In spring, it sprouts vines that extend one or two *zhang*, purplish in color; its leaves closely resemble those of the *jiu* (paper mulberry) but are green. In the seventh month, it bears flowers resembling pea blossoms, though it does not set fruit. The root is shaped like an arm. Zhang Zhongjing’s treatments for cold damage include *Gegen* Decoction, as well as *Gegen* Decoction with Banxia, *Huangqin*, and *Huanglian*, employing it for its governance of high fever, muscle-release, and opening of the interstices. Tao Hongjing says: This is the *Gegen* of today. People commonly steam and eat it. One should select those roots that are deeply buried and large, splitting and sun-drying them.

Fresh *Gegen* may be pounded to extract its juice, which, when drunk, resolves toxin-induced illnesses and fever. Its flowers, together with small bean flowers, dried and ground into powder, taken in a square-inch spoonful, prevent intoxication when drinking wine. The finest specimens come from Nankang and Luling, being fleshy, low in fiber, sweet, and delicious.

Chen Cangqi states: *Gegen* breaks up stagnant blood, closes sores, induces abortion, counteracts alcohol poisoning, and treats flushed complexion, alcohol-induced jaundice, and dark, scant urine. It can be used to abstain from grain without hunger, and its root yields starch.

*Rihuazi* says: *Gegen* is cold in nature. It treats heat in the chest and diaphragm, vexation and oppression, heat bind, stops bloody dysentery, unblocks the small intestine, expels pus and breaks up blood stasis, and is applied topically for snake and insect bites and to counteract arrow poison. Dried *Gegen* has the same efficacy.

*The Dietary Therapy* states: Steamed *Gegen* dispels alcohol toxicity, and its starch is also highly effective.

*The Sagacious Benevolence Formulary*: To treat seasonal qi with headache and high fever, thoroughly wash fresh *Gegen*, pound it to extract one large cup of juice, add one *ge* of fermented soybeans, and decoct to six-tenths. Remove the soybeans and divide into two doses, to be taken at any time. Sweating brings resolution; if no sweat appears, take again. For heat in the heart, add ten gardenia kernels, decoct together, strain, and take.

Another formula: To treat persistent heat and thirst in children, finely slice half a *liang* of *Gegen*, decoct in one medium cup of water to six-tenths, strain, and administer warm in frequent doses.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: To treat severed sinews, pound *Gegen* to extract its juice and drink. Roast *Gegen* white shavings until yellow and apply to sores to stop bleeding.

*The Thousand Gold Formulary*: For alcohol intoxication with loss of consciousness, pound *Gegen* to extract one or two *sheng* of juice and drink to regain sobriety.

*The Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*: To treat sudden unceasing dry retching, pound *Gegen*, squeeze out the juice, and take one *sheng* to resolve the condition.

Another formula: For poisoning from various vegetables causing madness, vexation, oppression, vomiting, and diarrhea to the point of death, decoct *Gegen* and drink the juice.

*Master Mei’s Formulas*: To treat early-stage cold damage with headache and high fever, finely slice five *liang* of *Gegen* and one *sheng* of fragrant fermented soybeans, decoct in six *sheng* of boy’s urine to two *sheng*, divide into three doses, and take to induce sweating. If exposed to wind, eat scallion and fermented soybean congee.

*The Extensive Benefit Formulary*: To treat unceasing heat-induced vomiting of blood, take half a large *sheng* of fresh *Gegen* juice in one dose to resolve immediately.

*The Classified Essentials of Cold Damage*: To treat heat disease during pregnancy with heart oppression, take two *sheng* of *Gegen* juice and divide into three doses.

*Extended Meanings* says: In Li and Ding prefectures, fresh *Gegen* is harvested in winter, its starch extracted by kneading in water, then settled into blocks. First boil water to a rolling boil, then break the starch into chunks and add to the water. After a long while, it becomes glue-like, its texture quite tenacious. Mix with honeyed water and consume; adding a little fresh ginger is even better. It greatly treats internal heat, alcohol-induced illness, and thirst. Eating much of it promotes urination and may cause diarrhea. For those suffering from alcohol toxicity or thirst, it is highly effective. The locals also slice it into cooked tea to serve guests, though it is merely sweet and of no benefit. Fresh *Gegen* may also be boiled until tender and served as a fruit. This is sold in Qian, Ji, and Nan’an prefectures.

*Gegen* starch: Flavor sweet, greatly cold, non-toxic. It suppresses cinnabar and mineral toxins, dispels vexing heat, disinhibits urination and defecation, and stops thirst. For heat bind in children, soak *Gegen*, pound to extract the juice, and drink—highly effective.

*The Illustrated Classic* says: See the entry under *Gegen* root.

Chen Cangqi states: *Supplement to Materia Medica* says: It is wondrous for steaming children’s heat sores.

Yu Xi says: According to the entry on *Gegen* root in the upper volume of the middle grade, its functions and uses correspond with this.

*The Sagacious Benevolence Formulary*: To treat poisoning by *zhen* toxin with qi on the verge of collapse, mix three *ge* of *Gegen* starch with three medium cups of water and drink. If the mouth is locked, pry it open and administer.

Another formula: To treat vexing heat in the chest or thirst and heart agitation, soak half a *sheng* of millet overnight, strain, mix evenly with four *liang* of *Gegen* starch, and cook until done to eat.

*The Heart Mirror of Food Therapy*: Formula for children with high fever, unceasing vomiting, inability to retain food, and fright epilepsy: Mix two large coins’ weight of *Gegen* starch with two *ge* of water until even, pour into a pot, tilt to coat the sides, steam in a double boiler until cooked, then mix with rice porridge and eat.

*Gualou* (Hubei, Henan)

**Root**: Bitter in flavor, cold, non-toxic. Governs wasting-thirst, bodily heat with vexing fullness, high fever, supplements deficiency and settles the center, reconnects severed injuries, eliminates deep-seated heat in the intestines and stomach, the eight *ju* sores, bodily and facial yellowing, dry lips and mouth, shortness of breath, unblocks menstrual flow, and checks profuse urination. Also called *dilou*, *guoluo*, *tiangua*, or *zegu*.

**Fruit**: Called *huanggua*. Governs chest impediment and brightens the complexion.

**Stem and leaves**: Treat heat stroke from summerheat.

Grows in the river valleys of Hongnong and shady mountain slopes. Those with deep roots are superior; those growing in saline-alkaline soil are toxic. Harvest the root in the second and eighth months, dry in the sun, and it will be ready in thirty days. *Gouqi* (wolfberry) serves as its guiding herb; it is incompatible with dried ginger, fears *niuxi* (achyranthes) and dried lacquer, and counteracts *wutou* (aconite).

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Gualou* grows in the mountain valleys of Hongnong and shady slopes, and is now found everywhere. Its fruit is called *huanggua*. As in *The Book of Songs*, "the fruit of the *guoluo*." Its root is also called *baiyao* (white medicine), with yellow skin and white flesh. The vine sprouts in the third or fourth month, trailing and climbing. Its leaves resemble those of sweet melon, forked and covered in fine hairs. It blooms in the seventh month, with flowers like those of the bottle gourd, pale yellow. The fruit grows beneath the flowers, fist-sized, green when young, ripening by the ninth month.

Sun Simiao’s method for making starch: Dig deep for large roots, peel thickly down to the white part, cut into inch-long pieces, soak in water, changing the water daily for five days. Remove, pound to a pulp, strain through a silk bag, and filter until extremely fine, like powder.

Cui Yuanliang’s *Tang* formula for arrowheads that will not emerge: Pound the root and apply to the wound, changing three times daily, and it will come out on its own.

Another formula for seasonal epidemics with jaundice, severe vexing heat, and delirium: Take one large yellow fruit, soak in nine *ge* of freshly drawn water, strain to obtain the juice, add half a *dahe* of honey and eight *fen* of *poshao* (mirabilite), mix without dissolving completely, and divide into two doses. Recovery follows.

Tao Hongjing said: It grows nearby, a vine resembling *tugua* (earth melon) but with forked leaves. *The Mao Poetry* states: "The fruit of the *guoluo*, also hung beneath the eaves." Its fruit is now used in hand balms. Roots buried six or seven *chi* deep, two or three spans in girth, are also used in medicinal diets.

The *Tang Materia Medica* notes: The root is now made into starch, highly suitable for dietary use, especially for those with deficiency heat. The method for making starch follows that for *gegen* starch—pure, white, and fine. The best white fruit now comes from Shanzhou.

Zhang Yuxi said: According to *The Approaching Elegance*, "The fruit of the *guoluo* is *gualou*." The explanation states: The fruit of the *guoluo* plant is called *gualou*. Guo Pu said: Today, the people of Qi call it *tiangua* (heavenly melon).

*Rihuazi* states: *Gualou* seeds are bitter, cold, and non-toxic. They supplement deficiency taxation, dry mouth, moisten the heart and lungs, treat chapped hands and face, coughing of blood, intestinal wind with bloody stool, red and white dysentery—use stir-fried. The root unblocks the small intestine, expels pus, disperses swelling and toxins, generates flesh and muscle, dissipates static blood from traumatic injury, treats heat mania and seasonal epidemics, breast abscesses, carbuncles on the back, hemorrhoids and fistulas, sores and boils.

Lei Gong said: *Gualou*—its skin, seeds, stem, and root each have distinct effects. The *gua* and *lou* types differ entirely. The *gua* is round, with thick yellow skin and a small stem; the *lou* is elongated, with red skin and a thick stem, suitable for women. When processing, remove the outer shell, skin, membrane, and oily seeds before use.

*The Sagely Grace Formulary*: For heat disease with headache and alternating fever. Take one large *gualou*, finely chop the pulp, place in a porcelain bowl, infuse with one cup of hot water, cover for a long while, strain, and take at any time.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: Formula for wasting-thirst with copious urination. Take thirty *jin* of fresh *gualou*, boil in one *hu* of water until one and a half *dou* remain, strain, add five *ge* of beef tallow, and simmer until the water evaporates. Take with warm wine before meals, the size of a chicken egg, three times daily—marvelously effective.

*The Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*: For wasting-thirst with profuse urination. Thinly slice *gualou*, roast to obtain five *liang*, boil in five *sheng* of water until four *sheng* remain, and drink freely.

Another formula: For prolapsed intestine that cannot be returned after prolonged inversion. Pound fresh *gualou* to obtain juice, warm it in pork broth, wash the hands in it, and gently massage the prolapse until warm—it will retract on its own.

*Master Mei’s Formulas*: For all carbuncles on the back and early-stage breast abscesses with slight redness. Pound *gualou* into powder, mix with well water to the size of a square *cun*, and apply.

*Collected Effective Formulas*: To promote lactation. Wash *gualou* seeds, dry, stir-fry until fragrant and cooked, then roast on a tile until white. Grind into powder, take one *fangcunbi* with wine, and cover with a cloth for a short while.

*Du Ren’s Formulas*: For chest and diaphragm pain radiating to the back, epigastric fullness and distension, and qi blockage, as well as phlegm cough. Remove the pulp from a large *gualou*, take the seeds, stir-fry until cooked, grind separately, mix with the seed skin, and form into pills with flour paste the size of *wutong* seeds. Take fifteen pills with rice water.

*The Arcane Record of Child and Mother*: For swollen, painful breasts. Take one large, ripe, yellow *gualou*, pound thoroughly, boil in one *dou* of white wine until four *sheng* remain, strain, and take one *sheng* warm, three times daily. If no large fruit is available, use two small, ripe yellow ones.

*Yang’s Obstetrics and Lactation Formulas*: For wandering erysipelas with red swelling. Mix two large *liang* of *gualou* powder with strong vinegar and apply.

*The Treasured Formulas for Obstetrics*: For postpartum lack of breast milk.

Powdered *gualou*, taken with morning well-water in a *fangcunbi* spoonful, twice daily, will cause nocturnal discharge.

*Yang Wenwei’s Formulas*: For phlegm cough and unblocking the chest and diaphragm. Take a large, plump, ripe *gualou*, split open, wash the seeds clean, pound the rind, cut finely, and dry by slow roasting. Take forty-nine *banxia* rhizomes, wash in hot water ten times, pound, dry by slow roasting, and grind to powder. Boil the *gualou* pulp and the water used to wash it into a thick paste, then form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take twenty pills with fresh ginger decoction.

*The Extension of Meanings* states: In the ninth and tenth months, gather ripe *gualou* fruit, mix with dried *ge* powder, dry by slow roasting, then stir-fry in a silver or stone vessel over a slow fire until cooked, and grind to powder. After meals and before sleep, steep one or two *qian* in boiling water and take to treat lung dryness, heat-thirst, and constipation of the large intestine. Its root, along with *beimu*, *zhimu*, *qinjiao*, and *huangqin*, all treat equine heat.

*Sophora flavescens*
Produced in Shaozhou, Chengzhou, Qinzhou, and the Western Capital
Flavor: bitter
Nature: cold, non-toxic
Governs bound qi in the heart and abdomen, concretions and conglomerations, jaundice, dribbling urine, expels water, resolves abscesses and swellings, supplements the center, brightens the eyes and stanches tears, nourishes the qi of the liver and gallbladder, quiets the five viscera, stabilizes the will and augments essence, frees the nine orifices, dispels hidden heat and intestinal afflux, stops thirst, sobers intoxication, treats dark yellow urine, cures malign sores and lower-body [afflictions], harmonizes stomach qi, stimulates the appetite, and lightens the body.

Also known as *shuihuai* ("water locust"), *kushi* (pronounced *shi*), *dihuai* ("earth locust"), *tuhuai* ("hare locust"), *jiaohuai* ("proud locust"), *baijing* ("white stem"), *huma* ("tiger hemp"), *cenjing* ("slender stem"), *lubai* ("official’s white"), and *linglang* ("hill gentleman"). It grows in the mountain valleys and fields of Runan. The root is harvested in the third, eighth, and tenth months, then dried in the sun. *Xuanshen* serves as its guiding herb; it is incompatible with *beimu*, *loulu*, and *tusi*, and contraindicated with *lilu*.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: *Sophora flavescens* grows in the mountain valleys and fields of Runan, and today it is found everywhere in nearby regions. Its root is yellow, about five to seven *cun* long, and as thick as two fingers. Three to five stems grow together, with the seedlings reaching two to three *chi* in height. The leaves are finely divided and green, closely resembling locust leaves—hence the name *shuihuai* ("water locust")—and they sprout in spring and wither in winter. Its flowers are yellow-white, and in the seventh month, it bears fruit like small beans.

It treats leprosy. The method is as follows: slice five *jin* of *Sophora flavescens* and steep it in three *dou* of good wine for thirty days. Drink one *ge* three times daily, maintaining regular consumption. If numbness is felt, recovery is near.

Tao Hongjing says: "Today, it grows everywhere in nearby regions."

The leaves closely resemble those of the locust tree—hence the name *huai*—its flowers are yellow, and its seeds form pods. The root is exceedingly bitter and foul-tasting. When steeped in wine, it often cures those afflicted with illness. For those suffering from scabies, consuming one or two *liang* also eliminates the condition, as it is capable of killing parasites.

Xu Xi says: According to the *Yaoxing Lun* (*Treatise on the Properties of Medicinals*), *Sophora flavescens* can treat heat-toxin wind, vexing dryness of the skin and flesh with sores, red leprosy with loss of eyebrows, and it dispels great heat, excessive salivation, cold pain in the abdomen, sudden abdominal pain from malign influences, and oppression of the body. It also treats accumulations and gatherings in the heart and abdomen. It is not used in decoctions.

The *Rihuazi* says: It kills *gan*-parasites. Stir-fry until smoke rises, then grind into powder. Take with rice water to treat intestinal wind with bloody stool and heat dysentery.

Lei Gong says: For use, regardless of quantity, first soak it overnight in thick rice-water. The foul, fishy qi will float to the surface; repeatedly rinse it away. Then steam it from *si* (9–11 a.m.) to *shen* (3–5 p.m.), dry in the sun, and finely slice for use.

The *Waitai Miyao* (*Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*): To treat epidemic disease on the fourth or fifth day with chest fullness and pain, high fever, and generalized heat: slice one *liang* of *Sophora flavescens*, boil it in two *sheng* of vinegar until reduced to one *sheng* and two *ge*, then drink it all. This will induce vomiting and bring recovery. For epidemic toxic disease, nothing but *Sophora flavescens* and vinegar can resolve it; warming the body and inducing sweating also cures.

Another formula: For children with fever, bathing them in a *Sophora flavescens* decoction is effective.

The *Qianjin Fang* (*Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold*): To treat erratic madness, disheveled hair, loud shouting, homicidal impulses, and disregard for water or fire: form *Sophora flavescens* into honeyed pills the size of *tong* seeds. Take ten pills each time with mint decoction.

**From the *Mei Shi Fang* (*Master Mei’s Prescriptions*):**
To treat food poisoning from fish, meat, or vegetables: take three *liang* of *Sophora flavescens*, boil it in one *sheng* of bitter wine until bubbling five times, strain, and drink the liquid—vomiting will bring recovery. Alternatively, boiling one *sheng* of rhinoceros horn juice is also effective.

Another formula: For cold damage after four or five days, with headache, high fever, and vexing pain in the chest: finely slice five *liang* of *Sophora flavescens* and twenty *Wumei* (*Prunus mume*), boil in two *sheng* of water until reduced to one *sheng*, and take warm.

**From the *Shengjin Fang* (*Superior Gold Prescriptions*):**
To treat seasonal epidemic heat disease with raving and heart vexation: stir-fry *Sophora flavescens* until yellow, grind to powder, and take two *qian* each time. Boil in one *zhong* of water until reduced to eight *fen*, take warm, and repeat for three doses. Recovery follows whether sweating occurs or not.

**From the *Jiyan Fang* (*Collected Effective Prescriptions*):**
To treat toxic heat with foot swelling and unbearable pain: steep *Sophora flavescens* in wine and apply as a soak.

The Grand Historian records: Chunyu Yi treated the decayed teeth of a high minister of Qi by moxibustion on the *yangming* pulse of the left hand, and rinsing daily with three *sheng* of *Sophora flavescens* decoction. The condition improved with use, and recovery came in five or six days.

**The *Yanyi* (*Extension of Meanings*) states:**
There was once an official suffering from heavy lumbar strain, unable to walk more than ten paces after prolonged sitting. A military aide remarked, “I observe you daily using medicine to rub your teeth—its flavor harms the kidneys, hence your lumbar strain.” Later, the Vice Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, Shu Zhaoliang, also used *Sophora flavescens* to rub his teeth for years and developed lumbar pain. After discontinuing its use entirely, his lumbar ailment resolved. Such cases were not recorded in earlier medical texts.

Another case: A man suffered from wind-heat rashes covering his entire body, with unbearable itching and pain extending to his chest, neck, navel, abdomen, and even private areas. He also had copious phlegm and could not sleep at night. One *liang* of *Sophora flavescens* powder was mixed with two *liang* of *Gleditsia sinensis* (Chinese honey locust), steeped in one *sheng* of water, and strained to obtain the juice. This was simmered in a silver or stone vessel until thickened into a paste, then combined with *Sophora flavescens* powder to form pills the size of *wutong* seeds. After meals, he took twenty to thirty pills with warm water, and the next day he recovered.

---

**Chinese Angelica (*danggui*)**
Flavor: sweet, acrid.
Nature: warm, strongly warming.
Non-toxic.
Governs cough and counterflow qi ascent, warm malaria with alternating chills and fever, *xian* (lichen-like skin disorders), flooding and spotting in women, infertility, all malign sores and ulcers, and metal-inflicted wounds. Boil and drink to warm the center, relieve pain, dispel congealed blood from internal blockages, treat wind-stroke with rigidity, absence of sweating, damp impediment, malign influx, vacuity cold from guest qi, and supplement the five viscera. It generates flesh and muscle.
Alternate name: *gan gui* (dried return).
Grows in the river valleys of Longxi. Harvest the root in the second and eighth months; dry in the shade.

**The *Tu Jing* (*Illustrated Classic*) states:**
Chinese angelica grows in the river valleys of Longxi. Today, it is found in various prefectures of Shu, Shaanxi, Jiangning, and Chuzhou, with the Shu variety being superior. In spring, it sprouts green leaves divided into three lobes. In the seventh and eighth months, it blooms with flowers resembling *shiluo* (a type of aster), in a pale purple hue. The root is black-yellow. Harvest the root in the second and eighth months; dry in the shade. There are two types of seedlings, both resembling *xiongqiong* (Sichuan lovage), differing only in leaf size. The stems are much shorter than those of *xiongqiong*. The roots also come in two varieties: the broad-leaved type is called *mawei danggui* (horse-tail angelica), and the fine-leaved type is called *cantou danggui* (silkworm-head angelica). The best specimens have thick flesh and do not wither.

**The *Yaoxing Lun* (*Treatise on Medicinal Properties*) states:**
Chinese angelica is a ministerial drug. It dislikes hot faces. It checks retching and counterflow, treats vacuity taxation with alternating chills and fever, breaks static blood, governs flooding in women, warms the intestines and stomach, supplements all insufficiencies, relieves dysentery and abdominal pain. Boiled alone to drink the juice, it treats warm malaria and governs lumbar pain from bloody discharge in women. It also treats unbearable toothache. For those with vacuity cold, add it to the formula.

**Tao Yinju says:**
Today, the *dangyang heishui* angelica from Longxi has abundant flesh and few branches, a fragrant aroma, and is called *mawei danggui*. It is somewhat rare. The angelica from northern Shu has many root branches and is slender. The variety from Liyang is pale in color with a weak aroma, quite unlike the others, and is called *cao danggui* (herbal angelica), used only when superior varieties are unavailable. Physicians claim the “true angelica” refers to this, as quality varies. It is widely used in folk remedies and occasionally required in Daoist formulas.

**The *Tang Ben* (*Tang Materia Medica*) notes:**
Chinese angelica seedlings come in two types: one resembles broad-leaved *xiongqiong*, the other fine-leaved *xiongqiong*, though their stems and leaves are shorter than those of *xiongqiong*. Today, it grows in Dangzhou, Yanzhou, Yizhou, Songzhou, and Dangzhou, with the Dangzhou variety being the finest. The fine-leaved type is called *cantou danggui*, and the broad-leaved type *mawei danggui*. Most of what is used today is *mawei danggui*; *cantou danggui* is not as effective and is no longer used. Tao’s reference to the Liyang variety is *cantou danggui*.

**The *Rihuazi* states:**
It treats all wind patterns, all blood disorders, supplements all taxation, breaks malign blood, nourishes new blood, and governs concretions and conglomerations.

**Lei Gong says:**
For all applications, first remove the dust and the hard tip (about one *fen*), then soak in wine overnight. If breaking blood is desired, use the hard, solid head section. If stopping pain or stanching blood is desired, use the tail. Using the whole root at once is ineffective; single-use preparations are best.

**Yu Xi says:**
According to the *Erya*: “*Bi* is mountain *qi*.” The *Guang Ya* annotates: “Mountain *qi* is Chinese angelica.” Today’s angelica resembles *qi* but is coarser and larger.

**Wu Pu says:**
Chinese angelica—Shennong, the Yellow Emperor, Tongjun, and Bian Que: sweet, non-toxic. Qibo and Leigong: acrid, non-toxic. The Ji family: slightly warming.

Some varieties grow in the Qiang and Hu regions.

**Supplementary Notes states:**
It is prudent to note: Since ancient times, medical formulas and treatises have employed Chinese angelica to treat postpartum *xue* surging upward in women, achieving swift efficacy—nothing is more urgent. For those with chaotic *qi* and blood, consumption immediately restores order. This is because it directs *qi* and blood to their proper places. Thus, it serves as an emergency remedy for postpartum depletion, offering rapid replenishment. One may surmise that the name *danggui* ("returning to one’s proper place") originates from this very function.

**The *Waatai Miyao* prescribes:**
For splitting headaches: Stew two *liang* of Chinese angelica in one *sheng* of wine, reducing it to six *ge*. Consume in two doses.

Another formula treats heart pain: Grind Chinese angelica into powder and take one *fangcunbi* with wine.

**The *Zhouhou Fang* records:**
Infants often suffer from fetal cold, crying incessantly day and night, which may develop into epilepsy. Administer Chinese angelica powder the size of a small bean with breast milk, three or four times daily.

**The *Ge’s Formulas* states:**
For bloody urine: Finely chop four *liang* of Chinese angelica, stew in three *sheng* of wine, reducing it to one *sheng*, and consume in one dose.

**The *Mei’s Formulas* offers:**
For fetal movement with bleeding, heart and abdominal pain, and uncertain prognosis: This decoction revives the living and expels the dead. Use four *liang* of Chinese angelica and nine *liang* of *xiongqiong*, finely chopped. Stew in three *sheng* of wine and four *sheng* of water, reducing it to three *sheng*, and divide into doses.

**The *Zimu Milu* prescribes:**
For inverted birth with the child dead in the womb: Pound Chinese angelica into powder and take one *fangcunbi* with wine.

**The *Zhi Taiyi’s Formulas* states:**
For all women’s ailments and various deficiencies: Grind four *liang* of Chinese angelica and two *liang* of *dihuang* into powder, mix with honey, and form pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take fifteen pills with rice broth before meals.

*Mahuang* (Hebei)

Flavor: bitter. Nature: warm, slightly warm. Non-toxic. Governs wind-stroke, cold damage, and headache; dispels warmth-malaria; induces sweating to release the exterior; expels pathogenic heat *qi*; arrests coughing and counterflow *qi*; eliminates alternating chills and fever; breaks concretions, hardness, accumulations, and gatherings; resolves spasms and tension from the five viscera’s pathogenic *qi*; treats rib-side pain due to wind; addresses postpartum and lactation-related ailments; checks excessive salivation; unblocks the interstices; disperses cold damage headache; relaxes the muscles; drains malign and noxious *qi*; and dissipates red and black macules and toxins. Should not be taken in excess, as it may cause deficiency.

Alternative names: *beixiang*, *longsha*, *beiyan*. Grows in Jin territories and Hedong. Harvest the stems at the *Start of Autumn* and dry in the shade to retain their green color. *Houpu* serves as its guiding herb; incompatible with *xin yi* and *shiwei*.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: *Mahuang* grows in Jin territories and Hedong, and is now abundant near the capital. The finest comes from Xingyang and Zhongmou. Its sprouts emerge in spring, growing to about a *chi* by the fifth month. The tips bear yellow flowers, and its fruit resembles the petals of a lily but smaller, or the seeds of *zaojia*, with a sweet taste and a faint *mahuang* aroma. The outer skin is red, while the kernel inside is black. Its roots are purplish-red. Folk tradition distinguishes two types: the female, which blooms between the third and fourth months and bears fruit by the sixth month; and the male, which produces no flowers or fruit. After the *Start of Autumn*, the stems are harvested and dried in the shade to preserve their green hue.

Zhang Zhongjing’s treatments for cold damage include *Mahuang Decoction* and the *Major* and *Minor Blue Dragon Decoctions*, all of which use *mahuang*. For lung atrophy with counterflow *qi*, he prescribes *Shegan Mahuang Decoction* and *Houpu Mahuang Decoction*, both major formulas. In ancient formulas, when *mahuang* is used in decoctions, it is first boiled to remove the froth before adding the other ingredients. This method is not followed in pills or powders.

Tao Yinju states: Today, the finest *mahuang* comes from Qingzhou, Pengcheng, Yingyang, and Zhongmou, distinguished by its green hue and abundant froth. That from Shu is also available but inferior. When using it, break off and discard the nodes, for the nodes arrest sweating. First boil it for one or two rolls, then skim off the surface froth, as the froth induces vexation. Its root also arrests sweating and is mixed with powder for summer use. Folk tradition holds it as the foremost remedy for resolving the flesh in cold damage.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: In Zhengzhou’s Lutai and the sandy shoals along the rivers of Guanzhong’s Shayuan, it grows in great abundance. The varieties from Qing and Xu are no longer used. Tongzhou’s Shayuan yields the most. *Rihuazi* states: It unblocks the nine orifices, regulates the blood vessels, opens the pores and skin, dispels wind, breaks concretions and accumulations, expels pathogenic *qi* from the five viscera, abates heat, and guards against mountain miasma.

Lei Gong says: For all applications, remove the nodes and froth; if not fully removed, it will cause oppression. Use shears to trim off the nodes and stem tips, then finely chop on a sophora block with a bronze knife. Boil for thirty or forty rolls, skim off all froth with a bamboo strip, strain, and dry in the sun before use.

Yu Xi notes: According to the *Drug Properties Treatise*, *mahuang* is a sovereign herb, sweet in flavor and neutral in nature. It treats toxic wind afflicting the body, numbness of the skin and flesh, and governs intense heat. It resolves the flesh to induce sweating, warms malaria, and treats warm epidemics. The root and nodes arrest sweating. One formula advises: grind an old bamboo fan into powder and apply it. Another combines equal parts oyster shell powder, millet powder, and *mahuang* root, placed in a raw silk pouch; when night sweats occur, dust the body and rub by hand.

The *Essentials of Cold Damage* records Zhang Zhongjing’s *Treatise on Cold Damage*: For jaundice, *Mahuang Unfermented Wine Decoction* is the ruling formula. Take a handful of *mahuang*, remove the nodes, wrap in silk, and boil in five *sheng* of fine wine until reduced to half a *sheng*. Strain and consume in one dose.

The *Secret Records of Mother and Child* states: For postpartum abdominal pain and persistent lochial discharge, pound *mahuang* (nodes removed) into powder and take one square *cun* with wine, two or three times daily. Discontinue once the discharge ceases. *Zelan Decoction* is also effective.

The *Amplifications* says: The finest *mahuang* comes from Zhengzhou. Trim the nodes, take half a *liang*, and stir-fry with one spoonful of honey. After a long while, decoct in half a *sheng* of water. Once boiling, skim off the froth, then reduce by one-third. Discard the dregs. For cases of inverted pox with blackened sores, consume the decoction while hot, avoid wind, and await the re-emergence of the sores. An alternative method uses ash-free wine for decoction. However, children who cannot tolerate wine may find it difficult to ingest, though its efficacy is swifter. From this, we know this herb enters the exterior.

**Rice-paper Plant (Tongcao)**
*Xingyuan Prefecture, Haizhou*
*Tongtuo Wood, Jiezhou*
Flavor: acrid, sweet; nature: neutral, non-toxic.
Governs: expelling malign worms, eliminating cold-heat from the spleen and stomach, unblocking the nine orifices, blood vessels, and joints, preventing forgetfulness, treating spleen jaundice with constant somnolence, heart vexation, hiccups, loss of voice, deafness, dispersing abscesses and swellings, resolving all types of stagnation, as well as metal wounds, malign sores, scrofula, fractures, nasal polyps, stillbirth, and expelling the three worms.
Alternate names: *Fuzhi*, *Dingweng*.
Grows in the mountain valleys of Shicheng and Shanyang. Harvest the branches in the first month and dry in the shade.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: *Tongcao* grows in the mountain valleys of Shicheng and Shanyang. Today, it is also found in Ze, Lu, Hanzhong, Jianghuai, and the prefectures of Hunan. It grows as a vine, finger-thick, with stems up to three *cun* in diameter. Each node bears two or three branches, and the branch tips produce five leaves, somewhat resembling *shiwei*. What people today call *mutong* is commonly known as *tongcao*, whereas the true *tongcao* is *tongtuo wood*.

Tao Yinju says: It now grows in nearby regions, twining around trees as a vine with white sap. The stem has fine pores, open at both ends. Blowing into one end causes air to exit the other, indicating quality. Some say it is the stem of *futei* vine.

Chen Cangqi states: *Tongtuo wood* is non-toxic. The powder from its flowers governs all worm sores and pheasant disease; apply the powder to the sores. It grows on mountainsides, with leaves resembling *bima*. The pith inside is light and white, prized by women for ornamentation.

The *Erya* says: *Linan* is *huotuo*. One text states: This medicinal herb grows in Jiangnan and governs worm diseases. Today, it is also called *tongcao*. Additionally, its seeds are sweet, promoting urination and defecation, dispersing vexing heat. Consuming them induces a sense of ease, quenches thirst, and descends *qi*. In Jiangdong, it is called *chufuzi*; in Jiangxi, *nazi*. They resemble a counting pouch, with dense yellow seeds and black interiors. When eaten, the skin should be removed.

Su says: The white variety is *houfu*.

*Rihuazi* states: *Mutong* calms the heart, eliminates vexation, quenches thirst, abates heat, treats forgetfulness, brightens the ears and eyes, and governs nasal congestion. It unblocks the small intestine, promotes urination, breaks blood stasis and accumulations, discharges pus, treats sores and boils, alleviates pain, hastens delivery and afterbirth, addresses women’s blood blockage and irregular menstruation, seasonal epidemics, headaches, dizziness, emaciation, breast lumps, and promotes lactation. Its seeds, called *□zi*, are harvested in the seventh and eighth months.

Yu Xi notes: According to the *Drug Properties Treatise*, *mutong* is a ministerial herb, slightly cold, also called *Wangweng Wannian*. It governs the five types of strangury, promotes urination, opens obstructions, treats excessive sleepiness, and governs edema with generalized swelling. The root treats goiter and tumors of the neck.

Chen Shiliang says: *Yan□zi* is cold and non-toxic. It governs heat obstruction at the stomach opening, counterflow stomach *qi* with inability to eat, and eliminates guest heat from the triple burner.

This is *mutong* (Akebia stem), its fruit called *fuyanzi*, and its stem called *mutong*. It governs wind-heat strangury, frequent and painful urination, and empty fullness in the lower abdomen. It is effective when decocted in soup and eaten with scallions. It grows wild.

The *Overseas Materia Medica* states: According to the *Xu Biao’s Record of Southern Regions*, it grows in the mountain valleys of Guangzhou. Its flavor is warm and neutral. It governs all types of fistula sores, throat pain, and throat impediment; decocting and taking it is appropriate, or grinding it for use, and in emergencies, holding it in the mouth.

The *Dietary Therapy* states: Boiling it as a drink unblocks women’s blood and *qi*; drinking three to five cups of a thick decoction will promptly restore flow. It also dispels obstructed *qi* with alternating chills and fever, disperses rat fistula, gold wounds, sprains, and fractures; its juice is used to brew wine.

---

**Peony (Shaoyao) from Zezhou**
Peony’s flavor is bitter and sour, neutral and slightly cold, with slight toxicity. It governs abdominal pain from pathogenic *qi*, eliminates blood impediment, breaks up hard accumulations, cold-heat mounting conglomerations, stops pain, disinhibits urination, boosts *qi*, unblocks and harmonizes the blood vessels, relaxes the center, disperses malign blood, expels thief blood, removes water *qi*, disinhibits the bladder and large and small intestines, disperses welling-abscesses, seasonal cold-heat, center strike, abdominal pain, and lumbar pain. It has alternate names: *baimu* (white wood), *yurong*, *lishi*, *jiecang*, and *ting*.

It grows in the river valleys and hills of Mount Song. The root is collected in the second and eighth months and dried in the sun. *Xuan* fungus is its guiding herb.

Yu Xi et al. note: According to the *Alternative Text*, it is *leifan* (thunderball fungus), is averse to dendrobium and mirabilite, fears saltpeter, turtle shell, and small thistle, and counteracts veratrum.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: Peony grows in the river valleys and hills of Mount Song; today it is found everywhere, with those from Huainan being superior. In spring, red shoots emerge in clusters; the stem bears three branches with five leaves, resembling tree peony but narrower and longer, growing one to two *chi* tall. In summer, it blooms with red, white, or purple flowers; the seeds resemble those of tree peony but are smaller. The root is collected in autumn; the root also has red and white varieties.

Cui Bao’s *Records of Past and Present* states: There are two types of peony: herbaceous peony and woody peony. The woody type has large, deeply colored flowers, commonly called tree peony, which is incorrect.

The *Zhengyuan Guangli Formula* treats chronic red and white vaginal discharge in women: three *liang* of white peony root and half a *liang* of dried ginger are finely sliced, stir-fried until yellow, ground, and sifted. One *qianbi* is taken on an empty stomach with rice water.

The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: Peony is a ministerial herb. It can treat lung pathogenic *qi*, abdominal *qi* pain, blood and *qi* accumulations, unblock and disseminate *qi* congestion in the viscera and bowels, treat pain from pathogenic *qi* and decayed blood, govern seasonal epidemics with bone heat, strengthen the five viscera, supplement kidney *qi*, treat abdominal hardness and distention, women’s blood blockage, disperse static blood, and erode pus.

Tao Yinju states: Today, the best come from Baishan, Jiang, and Maoshan, being white, long, and large. Other places also produce it, but many are red; red ones are slightly less effective. Commonly, it is said to stop pain, being no less effective than *danggui*. Daoists also consume it as food and use it in stone-cooking.

The *Alternative Text* annotation states: There are two types: red, which disinhibits urination and downbears *qi*; and white, which stops pain and disperses blood. Its flowers also have red and white varieties.

*Ri Huazi* states: It treats wind, supplements taxation, governs all women’s diseases, and all illnesses before and after childbirth, unblocks menstruation, abates heat, eliminates vexation, and boosts *qi*.

Lei Gong states: After collection, dry it in the sun, scrape off the rough bark and soil from the head with a bamboo knife, slice, mix with honey water, steam from *si* (9–11 a.m.) to *wei* (1–3 p.m.), and dry in the sun for use.

Yu Xi states: According to *Mr. Wu’s Text*, peony: Shennong: bitter; Tongjun: sweet, non-toxic; Qibo: salty; the Ji family: slightly cold; Lei Gong: sour.

The *Alternative Explanation* states: Today, Zhenyang in Huainan has many. Drug sellers see its plumpness but do not know its fragrance and flavor are poor, so it cannot be relied upon for efficacy. Now, upon examination, it is best to follow the *Divine Farmer’s Classic* and use those growing in river valleys and hills.

*Experiential Later Formula*: Treats wind toxin with bone marrow pain. Two *fen* of peony and one *liang* of tiger bone are roasted, ground into powder, placed in a double-layered silk bag, steeped in three *sheng* of wine for five days. Take two *ge* each time, three times daily.

*Boji Formula*: Treats the five types of strangury. One *liang* of red peony root and one areca nut are wrapped in dough and baked, then ground into powder. Take one *qianbi* each time, decoct in one *zhong* of water to seven *fen*, and take on an empty stomach.

*Guangli Formula*: For unstopped bleeding and pain from gold wounds. One *liang* of white peony root is stir-fried until yellow and ground into fine powder. Take two *qian* with wine or rice water; initially take three doses, gradually increasing. For the first dose, take less.

Chu Yushi: Treats coughing and spitting blood and nosebleed. One *liang* of white peony root and one *fen* of rhinoceros horn powder are ground into powder. Take one *qianbi* with fresh water until the bleeding stops.

The *Amplification* states: Peony uses the whole root; there are many varieties. Those with red, single-petaled flowers growing in the mountains are best. If the flowers and leaves are numerous, the root is weak. However, most roots are red, with an astringent and bitter flavor; those that are white, coarse, and plump are better. The rest is as in the *Classic*. However, people with blood vacuity and cold should avoid this herb. The ancients said: "Reduce peony to avoid central cold." This must not be taken lightly.

*Lishi* (water caltrop fruit)

**Yizhou**

Flavor: sweet. Nature: balanced, warm. Non-toxic.
Governs: skin chills and fevers, stomach heat *qi*, wind-cold-damp impediment, strengthens sinews and bones, stimulates appetite, relieves heart vexation and fullness, disinhibits urine and stool, and promotes muscle growth and plumpness. Prolonged consumption lightens the body.

Flowers and leaves: expel *bai* worms, treat throat impediment. Excessive consumption causes sloppy stool.

Alternate names: *Lishi*, *Jucao*, *Sanjian*, *Shishou*.
Grows in river valleys of Hedong. Harvest the fruit in the fifth month and dry in the shade.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Lishi* is the seed of *ma lin* (iris lactea). Northerners mispronounce it as *ma jian zi*. It grows in the river valleys of Hedong; today, it is also found in various prefectures of Shaanxi and in Ding and Li prefectures, with particularly abundant growth near the capital. Its leaves resemble those of *xie* (Chinese chive) but are longer and thicker. In the third month, it blooms with purple-green flowers; in the fifth month, it bears fruit in pods like sesame seeds but red and angular. Its roots are slender and long, uniformly yellow; people gather them to make brushes. Harvest the flowers in the third month and the fruit in the fifth month, drying both in the shade for use.

Cui Yuanliang’s remedy for throat impediment with swelling and pain: take twelve *fen* of *li* flowers, peel, and roots, boil in one *sheng* of water until six *ge* remain, strain, and hold the liquid in the mouth, swallowing the juice slowly until the condition resolves.

Tao Yinju says: This herb is no longer used in formulas, and common folk do not recognize it. Its original name was *jing*, and it was also called *shishou*.

*Rihuazi* states: *Ma lin* treats women’s blood *qi* vexation and oppression, postpartum blood dizziness and incessant menstrual flow, flooding and spotting, and flooding collapse. It disperses all sores, boils, and toxic swellings, stanches nosebleed and vomiting of blood, frees the small intestine, resolves alcohol toxicity, treats jaundice, and is applied topically for snake and insect bites. It also kills mushroom toxins. Its stems and leaves may be eaten as a vegetable.

*The Outer Canon of Secrets*: For throat impediment on the verge of death, pound a handful of *li* root, squeeze out the juice, and swallow it gradually. For clenched jaws, administer it by infusion.

*The Thousand Gold Prescriptions*: For *gu* toxin with passage of blood like chicken liver, where the other four viscera are all damaged and only the heart remains intact, or where the nose is broken and death is imminent: take *ma lin* root powder, mix one *fangcunbi* with water, and swallow. The toxin will be expelled by vomiting—extremely effective. Its seedlings resemble *ge* (kudzu) vines, green-purple, and its seeds resemble tangerine seeds.

*The Amplification* states: Tao Yinju says *li* is no longer used in formulas, and common folk do not recognize it. The annotations in the *Classic* and other texts do not align. If this were truly *ma lin*, *Rihuazi* would not have said it could also be eaten as a vegetable. *Ma lin*’s leaves are inedible to horses and cattle, for as soon as they emerge from the soil, they are tough—how much less palatable to humans? For now, I dare not equate *li* with *ma lin* seeds; I await the judgment of those with broader knowledge.

**Qumai (Dianthus superbus), Jiangzhou**

Pungent and bitter in flavor, cold in nature, non-toxic. It governs blockage and obstruction, all types of urinary retention and strangury, promotes urination, removes thorns, resolves abscesses and swellings, brightens the eyes and dispels nebula, induces abortion and expels retained placenta, breaks through congealed blood, nourishes kidney qi, rectifies counterflow in the bladder, checks cholera, and promotes hair growth. It is also called *jujumai*, *daju* (great chrysanthemum), and *dalan* (great orchid). It grows in the mountain valleys of Mount Tai. The seeds are harvested at the start of autumn and dried in the shade.

*Sheath Grass* and *Peony* serve as its guiding herbs; it is incompatible with *mantis egg-case*.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Qumai grows in the mountain valleys of Mount Tai, but is now found everywhere. It reaches a height of about one *chi*, with slender, pointed leaves of a greenish hue. Its roots are purplish-black, resembling the fine tendrils of *field mustard*. The flowers are red, purple, or crimson, similar to *azalea*, blooming from the second to the fifth month. In the seventh month, it bears fruit in spikes, the seeds resembling wheat—hence the name *qumai* (wheat of the *qu* kind). After the start of autumn, both seeds and leaves are gathered and dried in the shade for use. In ancient and modern formulas, it is most essential for unblocking the Heart channel and promoting urination in the Small Intestine.

Zhang Zhongjing’s *Gualou Qumai Pill* treats urinary difficulty with water retention. Tao Yinju says: "It now grows in nearby regions. A single stem bears fine leaves, and its red, purple, or crimson flowers are lovely. Both seeds and leaves are harvested; the seeds resemble wheat, hence the name *qumai*." This category actually includes two varieties: one is stout and large, with forked branches on the flower edges—it is unclear which is the true one. Today, people generally use the smaller variety. There is another kind with broader leaves, similar in shape but hairy, and its flowers bloom late, deep red in color.

The *Classic* states: "Harvest the seeds." The seeds within the fruit are extremely fine and scatter once dried and ripe. Today, however, people only use the stems and leaves, while the fruit is merely an empty husk, devoid of seeds.

*Rihuazi* says: Qumai induces labor and is also called *dumucao* (mother’s herb), *yanmai* (swallow wheat), *yuemai* (moon wheat), and *shizhu* (stone bamboo). It treats hemorrhoids, fistulas, and bloody diarrhea, and may be consumed as a decoction or porridge.

Master Lei states: "For use, only the floral calyx is employed; the flowers and leaves are discarded. If used indiscriminately, it will cause qi to lodge in the throat on an empty stomach and lead to urinary incontinence. Before use, it must be soaked in *jinzhu* bamboo sap for a full day and night, then strained and dried in the sun."

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: To treat fish bones lodged in the throat, grind *qumai* into powder, mix one *fangcunbi* with water, and take.

*The Thousand Gold Prescriptions*: For delayed delivery after several days, or a dead fetus in the womb endangering the mother, boil *qumai* into a thick decoction and administer.

*Master Mei’s Formulas*: To remove bamboo or wooden splinters embedded in the flesh, grind *qumai* into powder and take one *fangcunbi* with water. Alternatively, boil *qumai* into a decoction and drink, three times daily. (Same as in *The Thousand Gold Prescriptions*.)

*The Master Cui’s Formulas*: To treat fish-belly sores and toxic swellings, burn *qumai* to ash, mix with oil, and apply to the swelling—highly effective.

*The Extended Meanings* states: *Qumai* is used in the *Eightfold Rectification Powder*, and today it is considered an essential medicinal. If the Heart Channel has heat while the Small Intestine is deficient, taking it may fail to clear the Heart’s heat while causing additional disorders in the Small Intestine. The reasoning appears to be that since the Heart and Small Intestine are paired in transmission, this herb is employed as a Small Intestine-targeting agent. According to the *Classic*, *qumai* does not treat Heart heat at all. If the Heart’s heat is not severe, one should focus solely on treating the Heart; if the condition is not fully resolved, one must seek its associated organs to weaken it. This is the intent behind using the *Eightfold Rectification Powder*.

*Xuanshen* (figwort root):
- **Xiezhou** (production region)
- **Jiangzhou** (production region)
- **Hengzhou** (production region)

Flavor: bitter, salty; slightly cold; non-toxic.
Governs accumulations of cold and heat in the abdomen, postpartum ailments in women, and supplements Kidney qi to brighten the eyes. Treats sudden windstroke, febrile illnesses with bodily heat, propping fullness, manic disorders, disorientation, intermittent chills, blood conglomerations, cold blood in the lower body, chest qi obstruction, water retention, vexing thirst, swollen neck nodules, abscesses, heart and abdominal pain, hardness and masses, and stabilizes the Five Viscera.

Prolonged consumption supplements deficiency, brightens the eyes, strengthens yin, and replenishes essence. It is also called *Chongtai*, *Xuantai*, *Luchang*, *Zhengma*, *Xian*, and □#53. It grows in the river valleys of Hejian and Yuanqu. The root is harvested in the third and fourth months and dried in the sun. It is incompatible with *huangqi* (astragalus), dried ginger, jujubes, and *shanzhuyu* (cornelian cherry), and contraindicated with *lilu* (black false hellebore).

*The Illustrated Canon* states: *Xuanshen* grows in Hejian and Yuanqu, and is now found everywhere. The seedlings emerge in the second month. The leaves resemble those of sesame or willow. The slender stems are bluish-purple. It blooms with greenish-blue flowers in the seventh month, and the seeds, harvested in the eighth month, are black. Some varieties have white flowers, square and thick stems of purplish-red with fine hairs, and nodes like bamboo, growing five to six *chi* tall. The leaves are palm-sized, pointed, and serrated like a saw. The roots are long and tapering, greenish-white when fresh and purplish-black when dried, plump and greasy when new. Each root produces five to seven tubers, harvested in the third, eighth, and ninth months and dried in the sun. Some say it should be steamed and then sun-dried.

Tao Hongjing said: It now grows in nearby regions and is found everywhere. The stems resemble those of ginseng but are longer and larger. The roots are very black and slightly fragrant. Daoists sometimes use it, and it is also employed in incense-making.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: The roots and seedlings of *xuanshen* are foul-smelling, and the stems do not resemble ginseng. Tao’s claim that Daoists use it in incense-making is unfounded.

*Ri Huazi* states: It treats head wind, heat-toxin wandering wind, supplements consumption and deficiency, calms heart palpitations, vexation, and fatigue, resolves bone steaming and corpse transmission, stops forgetfulness, and disperses swelling toxins.

Lei Gong said: After harvesting, it must be layered with cattail leaves and steamed in a steamer for two full days, then removed and sun-dried. When using, avoid contact with copper, as ingestion may cause throat obstruction and harm the eyes. Remove all cattail remnants before use.

Zhang Yuxi said: According to *The Drug Properties*, *xuanshen* (also called *Zhuma*), is a guiding herb with a bitter flavor. It treats sudden heat accumulation, heat-wind headache, relapse after febrile illness, and disperses goiter, scrofula, and lymph node swellings.

*Tested Prescriptions*: For consumptive patients, a method for burning incense. Grind one *jin* of *xuanshen* and six *liang* of *gansong* (spikenard) into powder, mix with one *jin* of refined honey, and seal in a porcelain jar. Bury it underground for ten days, then remove. Add six *liang* of ash powder and six *liang* of refined honey, mix well, seal in the jar, and bury for another five days. Burn it so the fragrance is constantly inhaled, and the illness will resolve.

*The Broadly Beneficial Prescriptions*: For long-standing scrofula that does not heal, apply fresh *xuanshen* pounded into a paste, changing it twice daily.

---

*Qinjiao* (gentian root)
Production regions: Ninghua Commandery, Shizhou, Taizhou, Qizhou
Flavor: bitter, acrid; neutral, slightly warm; non-toxic.
Governs cold-heat pathogenic qi, cold-damp wind impediment, pain in the limbs and joints, drains water, disinhibits urine, and treats wind disorders of any duration, as well as generalized hypertonicity.

It grows in Feiwu Mountain valleys. The root is harvested in the second and eighth months and dried in the sun. *Changpu* (sweet flag) is its guiding herb.

*The Illustrated Canon* states: *Qinjiao* grows in Feiwu Mountain valleys and is now abundant in the commanderies of He and Shaan. The roots are yellow, intertwined, and about one *chi* long, varying in thickness. The stems and branches grow five to six *cun* tall, with sprawling leaves and stems all green, resembling lettuce leaves. It blooms with purple flowers in the sixth month, like kudzu flowers, and sets seed in the same month. The roots are harvested in spring and autumn and dried in the shade.

Tao Hongjing said: Feiwu may be a place name. It now grows in Gansong, Longdong, and Canling, with large, yellow-white roots being the best. The roots are all intertwined in a net-like pattern, often containing earth that must be removed before use. Physicians often write it as *Qinjiao* (秦胶), and it is commonly used with *duhuo* (angelica) to treat wind disorders, though Daoists have no need for it.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: The best now comes from Jingzhou, Fuzhou, and Qizhou. Originally written as *zha* (札), it may also be written as *jiu* (纠) or *jiao* (胶), but the correct character is *jiao* (艽).

*Ri Huazi* states: Flavor sweet, cold. Governs corpse transmission and bone steaming, treats gan-illness and seasonal qi. Also called *Qinjiao*, the net-veined variety is best.

Lei Gong said: When using *Qin* and *Jiao*, examine the vein patterns at the base: those with leftward veins are *Qin* and treat illnesses; *Jiao* triggers leg qi. Before using *Qin*, wipe off the yellow flesh and hairs with a cloth, then soak it overnight in *huanyuan* decoction. Remove it the next day and dry it in the sun.

Zhang Yuxi said: According to *The Drug Properties*, *Qinjiao* resolves rice bran, and if one’s diet lacks nourishment, it fears cow’s milk. When applied as a medicinal paste, it disinhibits urine and stool. It cures the five types of jaundice, resolves alcohol toxicity, and dispels head wind.

Xiao Bing said: *The Divine Farmer’s Classic* calls it *Qingua*. It is highly effective for treating alcohol jaundice and yellowing disorders.

*The Sage’s Benefit Prescriptions*: For febrile illness with heart vexation, heat agitation, dry mouth, and thirst, take one *liang* of *Qinjiao*, remove the seedlings, and finely slice. Decoct with one large cup of cow’s milk to six *fen*, remove the dregs, and take warm in divided doses at any time.

Another prescription: For difficult urination with abdominal fullness and oppression (if not treated urgently, it may be fatal), take one *liang* of *Qinjiao*, remove the seedlings, and decoct with one large cup of water to seven *fen*. Remove the dregs and take in two doses before meals.

*Sun Zhenren’s Prescriptions*: For jaundice with golden skin and eyes and reddish urine, take five *liang* of *Qinjiao* and three *sheng* of cow’s milk, decoct to one *sheng*, remove the dregs, and add one *liang* of *mangxiao* (mirabilite) to take.

**Lilium (Baihe)**

*Chuzhou, Chengzhou*: Flavor sweet, nature neutral, non-toxic. Governs perverse *qi* and abdominal distension, heart pain, promotes urination and defecation, supplements the center and augments *qi*, eliminates superficial edema and drum-like distension, glomus and fullness, alternating chills and fever, generalized pain, and difficult lactation, throat impediment, and stops snivel and tears. Also called *Chongxiang*, *Moluo*, *Zhongfeng Hua*, or *Qiangqu*. Grows in the river valleys of Jingzhou. Harvest the root in the second and eighth months, and dry in the sun.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Lilium grows in the river valleys of Jingzhou, and is now found everywhere in nearby regions. In spring, it sprouts shoots several *chi* tall. The stem is as thick as an arrow, with leaves on all sides resembling a chicken’s spur or willow leaves, green in color. The leaves near the stem are slightly purple, and the stem’s tip is jade-white. In the fourth and fifth months, it bears white flowers resembling the mouth of a pomegranate but larger. The root resembles garlic, with twenty or thirty layers overlapping. Harvest the root in the second and eighth months and dry in the sun. People also steam and eat it, which greatly benefits *qi*.

Zhang Zhongjing’s treatments include *Baihe Zhimu Tang*, *Baihe Huashi Daizhe Tang*, *Baihe Jizi Tang*, and *Baihe Dihuang Tang*. In all four formulas, the condition is named *baihe* (hundred-fold convergence), and *baihe* is used to treat it, though the rationale is unclear. Tao Yinju says: It is found everywhere in nearby regions. The root resembles garlic, with dozens of layers overlapping. People also steam and boil it to eat, claiming it originally formed from earthworms coiling together. Common folk call it *Qiangchou* (strong enemy), where *chou* is a corruption of *qu*. It is also suitable for medicinal consumption.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: This herb has two varieties: one with fine leaves and red-white flowers, and another with large leaves, long stems, coarse roots, and white flowers, which is not used medicinally.

*Rihuazi* states: White lilium calms the heart and steadies the gallbladder, benefits the will, nourishes the five viscera, treats manic possession, weeping, wild shouting, fright palpitations, kills *gu* toxins, harmonizes *qi*, and treats breast abscesses, carbuncles on the back, and all sores and swellings. It also treats postpartum blood dizziness.

Yu Xi says: According to *The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties*, lilium is an envoy herb with slight toxicity. It governs possession by the hundred perverse spirits, incessant sniveling and weeping, relieves urgent fullness and pain below the heart, and treats leg *qi* and hot cough reversal.

*The Dietary Therapy* states: It is neutral. It governs heart urgency and jaundice. Steamed with honey and eaten, or made into powder, it is especially fine. The red-flowered variety is called *Shandan* (mountain cinnabar) and is inedible.

*Imperial Grace Formulary*: For lung visceral obstruction with heat and vexation, take four *liang* of fresh lilium and half a cup of honey, steam until soft, and frequently hold a jujube-sized portion in the mouth, swallowing the saliva.

Another formula: For cold damage with abdominal fullness and pain, take one *liang* of lilium, stir-fry until yellow, pound into powder, and take two *qian* mixed with rice porridge at any time.

*Sun Zhenren’s Dietary Prohibitions*: For yin-toxic cold damage, decoct lilium into a thick juice and take one *sheng*; it is effective.

*Superior Gold Formula*: For deafness with pain, grind dried lilium into powder and take two *qian* with warm water after meals.

*Extension of the Materia Medica* states: Lilium is what Zhang Zhongjing used to treat *baihe* disease following damaged cold damage. The stem grows about three *chi* tall, with leaves like large willow leaves, clustering upward on all sides. At the top, it bears pale yellow-white flowers hanging downward, with long stamens. The flower’s center is sandalwood-colored, and each stem’s top bears five or six flowers. The purple seeds are round like sterculia seeds, growing between the branches and leaves. Each leaf bears one seed, not within the flower—this is another peculiarity. The root is lilium, white in color, shaped like a pine nut shell, clustering in all directions, with the shoot emerging from the center.

For *tongtuo* wood:¹
Its roots were originally miswritten as "few" (少).² The thin bark was originally miswritten as "algae" (藻).³ It grows in cliffs, originally miswritten as "caves" (宕).⁴ Dry it in the sun, originally miswritten as "liver" (肝).⁵ It is also—originally miswritten as "now" (今)—produced in Luzhou, originally miswritten as "road" (路).⁶

For *tongtuo* wood causing panting:⁷
Take one liang of its pith, originally miswritten as "two" (二).⁸ Scrape it clean, originally miswritten as "carve" (刊).⁹ If abundant, select the finest, originally miswritten as "ridgepole" (栋).¹⁰ Boil it—originally omitting "extract" (取)—with one liang of *huangqi* root, originally miswritten as "heaven" (天).¹¹ For those with emaciation, originally miswritten as "slight" (微),¹² use the flower, originally miswritten as "stem" (茎).¹³ At the tip—originally miswritten as "end" (端)—¹⁴ gather it, originally miswritten as "bind" (结).¹⁵ For those with dryness, originally miswritten as "moist" (润),¹⁶ use the branches, originally miswritten as "limbs" (枝).¹⁷ From the earth—originally miswritten as "soil" (土)—¹⁸ take it. Bitter in flavor, originally miswritten as "sweet" (甘).¹⁹ Simmer until—originally omitting "to"—²⁰ reduced to one sheng, originally miswritten as "two" (二).²¹ Divide into two doses and take before meals, originally miswritten as "after meals."²²

For *baihe* with red flowers, originally omitting "red" (红):²³
Take ten petals, originally omitting "petals" (瓣).²⁴ Earthworms—originally miswritten as "leeches" (蚯)—²⁵ should not—originally miswritten as "suitable" (宜)—²⁶ be used for manic disorders, originally miswritten as "endure" (任).²⁷ For purple *baihe*, originally miswritten as "seeds" (子).²⁸

Song Dynasty Imperial Medical Assistant Instructor Xu Hong, Verifier of Medicinal Materials

**Herbs, Middle Grade (Upper Division): *Zhimu***

**Production Regions:** Weizhou, Xizhou, Chuzhou, Jiezhou, Weisheng Commandery

**Flavor:** Bitter
**Nature:** Cold, non-toxic

**Therapeutic Actions:**
Resolves wasting-thirst and internal heat, dispels pathogenic qi, reduces limb edema, promotes diuresis, replenishes insufficiency, augments qi, treats cold damage, chronic malaria, vexing heat, pathogenic qi beneath the flanks, thoracic malign obstruction, wind-induced sweating, and internal jaundice. Excessive consumption induces diarrhea.

**Alternate Names:**
*Qimu* (蚑母, *qi* pronounced as in 岐), *Lianmu* (连母), *Yeliao* (野蓼), *Dishen* (地参), *Shuishen* (水参), *Shuijun* (水浚), *Huomu* (货母), *Ti* (蝭, pronounced as 匙 or 提母), *Nülei* (女雷), *Nüli* (女理), *Ercao* (儿草), *Lulie* (鹿列), *Jiufeng* (韭逢), *Erzhongcao* (儿踵草), *Donggen* (东根), *Shuixu* (水须), *Shenfan* (沈燔), *□* (pronounced as 杜 with initial *han* cut).

**Minister Yu Xi et al. respectfully note:** The *Tang Materia Medica* records an additional name, *Changzhi* (昌支).

**Habitat:** River valleys of Henan.
**Harvest:** Roots collected in the second and eighth months, dried in the sun.

**The Illustrated Canon states:**
*Zhimu* grows in the river valleys of Henan; it is also found in various prefectures along the Yellow River, as well as in Jiezhou and Chuzhou. Its roots are yellow, resembling those of *changpu* (*Acorus calamus*) but softer and more moist. The plant is remarkably tenacious—once unearthed, it revives unless thoroughly dried. It blooms with green flowers in the fourth month and sets seed in the eighth. Roots are harvested in the second and eighth months and sun-dried for use.

**The *Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states:**
*Zhimu*, as a sovereign herb, is neutral in nature. It governs vexation and restlessness, consumptive bone heat, postpartum *ru lao* (puerperal exhaustion), taxation of kidney qi, aversion to cold due to deficiency, and wasting with dry mouth. It is applied in cases of vacuity.

**Tao Yinju notes:**
Today, it is produced in Pengcheng. Its appearance resembles *changpu* but is softer and more moist. The leaves are nearly indestructible—once dug up, they regrow unless completely desiccated. It powerfully treats heat bind and also governs malarial heat and vexation.

**Guo [Pu] states:**
It grows on mountains, with leaves resembling those of leeks.

**Fan Zi notes:**
*Timu* (提母) from the Three Adjuncts is best when yellow-white.

**The *Ri Hua Zi Materia Medica* states:**
Flavor: bitter, sweet.
It treats heat taxation, corpse-transmitted consumption, unblocks the small intestine, dispels wind-phlegm, arrests cough, moistens the heart and lungs, supplements vacuity and fatigue, calms the spirit, and relieves fright palpitations.

**Lei Gong states:**
For processing: first finely slice on a locust-wood chopping block, then dry by baking. Pound in a wooden mortar, ensuring no contact with iron implements.

**Bei Mu**
**Production Regions:** Xiazhou, Yuezhou

Flavor: acrid, bitter; nature: balanced, slightly cold; non-toxic. It governs febrile disease with vexing heat, strangury with dribbling urine, perverse qi, mounting-conglomeration, throat impediment, difficult lactation, metal-inflicted wounds with wind tetany, and treats abdominal concretions and repletion, glomus below the heart, shivering with aversion to wind and cold, dizzy vision, stiff nape, cough with counterflow qi ascent, checks vexing heat and thirst, promotes sweating, quiets the five viscera, and disinhibits the bone marrow.

Alternative names: *kongcao* (hollow herb), *yaoshi* (medicinal fruit), *kuhua* (bitter flower), *kucai* (bitter vegetable), *shangcao* (mourning herb), and *lemu* (restraining mother).

It grows in Jin territory. The root is collected in the tenth month and dried in the sun.

*Houpo* (magnolia bark) and *baiwei* (swallowwort root) serve as its couriers. It is incompatible with peach blossoms, and is averse to *qinjiao* (large gentian), *yushi* (arsenic), and *mangcao* (illicium). It counteracts *wutou* (aconite).

**The *Illustrated Classic* states:**
*Beimu* grows in Jin territory. Today, it is also found in Hezhong, Jiangling Prefecture, Ying, Shou, Sui, Zheng, Cai, Run, and Chuzhou. The root has paired bulblets, yellow-white in color, resembling clustered cowrie shells—hence the name *beimu* (cowrie mother). The seedling emerges in the second month, with a slender green stem and green leaves resembling those of buckwheat, the leaves growing as the stem extends. In the seventh month, it blooms with greenish flowers shaped like those of *pengzi* (mallow). It is harvested in the eighth month. It is also said that the best time to collect it is when garlic ripens in the fourth month. This herb also treats malign sores.

A Tang account records the following: In Jiangzuo, there was once a merchant whose left arm bore a sore resembling a human face, though it caused no other suffering. When the merchant playfully dripped wine into its mouth, the face flushed red. When fed with food, it too could eat, and excessive feeding caused the flesh within his arm to swell. If left unfed, his entire arm would grow numb. A skilled physician instructed him to test various medicines—metals, stones, herbs, and trees—none of which caused distress. When *beimu* was applied, the sore furrowed its brows and closed its mouth. The merchant rejoiced, saying, "This medicine can cure it!" He then used a small reed tube to break its mouth and pour the medicine in. After several days, a scab formed, and he was healed—though the nature of the affliction remained unknown.

**The *Drug Properties Treatise* states:**
*Beimu*, a ministerial drug, is slightly cold. It treats vacuity heat and governs difficult birth; taken as a powder, it is effective. It also treats retained placenta: take seven pieces as a powder with wine. As a powder, it is applied to the eyes to remove corneal opacity. It governs counterflow qi in the chest and treats seasonal epidemics and jaundice. Combined with *lianqiao* (forsythia), it governs tumors and goiter in the neck.

**Tao Hongjing states:**
It now grows in nearby regions. Its form resembles clustered cowrie shells, hence the name *beimu*. For those practicing grain avoidance, consuming it prevents hunger.

**The *Tang Materia Medica* annotation states:**
Its leaves resemble those of garlic. It is best harvested when garlic ripens in the fourth month. If the seedling withers in the tenth month, the root is also inferior. The finest specimens come from Runzhou, Jingzhou, and Xiangzhou, though it is also found in various Jiangnan prefectures. Its flavor is sweet and bitter, not acrid.

According to the *Erya*, it is also called *□*. **The *Ri Hua Zi* states:** It dissolves phlegm and moistens the heart and lungs. Ground with granulated sugar into pills and held in the mouth, it arrests cough. Burned to ash and mixed with oil, it is applied to malign sores on humans and livestock.

**Lei Gong states:**
For processing: first roast in willow-wood ash until yellow, then split open. Remove the small grain-sized core from the inner "mouth" and "nose." Then mix with glutinous rice and stir-fry on a griddle until the rice turns yellow. Discard the rice and remove the drug. Among the pieces, those that are single, round, and unbroken by fissures are called *danlongjing* (cinnabar dragon essence) and are not used medicinally. If mistakenly ingested, they cause permanent flaccidity of the sinews and vessels. This can be remedied by taking *huangjing* (solomon’s seal) and *xiaolan* (indigo) juice together.

**The *Supplementary Notes* states:**
Carefully considering, *beimu* excels at dispersing qi stagnation in the heart and chest, and its efficacy is remarkable. Thus, the *Book of Songs* speaks of "gathering its *meng*," for the poet originally expressed frustration at unfulfilled aspirations. Today, it is indeed effective in treating those afflicted by heart qi stagnation, melancholy, and excessive sorrow.

**Baizhi**
**Production Region:** Zezhou

White atractylodes has a pungent taste, is warming in nature, and non-toxic. It governs women’s red and white vaginal discharge, amenorrhea, yin swelling, alternating chills and fever, wind-induced tearing of the eyes, promotes flesh growth, and moistens the skin. It can be made into facial creams, treats wind evil, chronic thirst, vomiting, fullness in the flanks, wind pain, dizziness, and itchy eyes. It may also be used in medicinal plasters and facial creams to enhance complexion.

It has alternate names: *fangcao* (fragrant herb), *baichi* (white thoroughwort), *xiaoxu* (pronounced *qiao*), *wan* (luxuriant), *fuli* (marsh thoroughwort), and *zefen* (marsh fragrance). Its leaves, called *li* (pronounced *li*, hemp-like), can be used to prepare bath infusions.

It grows in river valleys and marshes of Hedong. The root is harvested in the second and eighth months and dried in the sun.

*Danggui* (Chinese angelica) serves as its guiding herb, while it is incompatible with *xuanfuhua* (inula flower).

**The *Illustrated Classic* states:**
White atractylodes grows in river valleys and marshes of Hedong, though it is now found everywhere, with Wu region also producing much of it. The root is over a foot long, white, and varies in thickness. Its stems rise five inches above the ground. In spring, leaves emerge in opposite pairs, spreading gracefully, purple in color, and about three fingers wide. The flowers are white with a slight yellow hue. After the *fu* (dog days) period, it sets seed, and the plant withers after the Beginning of Autumn. Those with yellowish, moist roots are considered superior.

Tao Yinju says: "It now grows abundantly in nearby regions, particularly in low-lying wetlands of Hedong. Its leaves can also be used for bath infusions, and Daoists use this herb for fragrant bathing to expel corpse worms."

Yuxi notes: "According to the *Fanzi Jiran*, white atractylodes from Qi Prefecture is best when harvested in spring and has a yellowish, moist appearance."

**The *Materia Medica Properties* states:**
White atractylodes is a sovereign herb. It treats stabbing pain in the heart and abdomen due to blood stasis, dispels wind evil, governs women’s flooding and spotting, stops vomiting and counterflow, brightens the eyes, and arrests tearing. It also treats women’s bloody vaginal discharge with lumbar pain and can erode pus."

**The *Ri Hua Zi* states:**
It treats red eyes with pterygium, prevents miscarriage and threatened abortion, breaks up static blood, generates new blood, addresses breast abscesses, carbuncles on the back, scrofula, intestinal wind, hemorrhoids, fistulas, expels pus, heals sores and scabies, relieves pain, promotes flesh regeneration, and removes facial blemishes and dark spots."

**Lei Gong says:**
After harvesting, do not use specimens with four stems growing from a single base—these are called *sanggongteng* (widower vine)—nor use *malin* (iris), as neither is suitable for medicinal use. After harvesting, scrape off the outer skin, finely chop, and also finely chop *huangjing* (solomon’s seal) with a bamboo knife. Mix the two herbs in equal parts, steam twice for a full day and night, then dry in the sun. Discard the *huangjing* and use the white atractylodes.

**The *Secret Records of Mother and Child* states:**
To treat fever in children, boil white atractylodes to make a bath infusion, ensuring the child avoids wind afterward.

**The *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library* states:**
For cinnabar rash, boil white atractylodes—roots and leaves—to make a decoction for washing, which is effective.

**The *Extension of the Materia Medica* states:**
White atractylodes is *zu* (pickled greens). Those from Wu region are of superior quality. The *Classic* states: "It can erode pus."

For contemporary use, white atractylodes treats *dai xia* (chronic vaginal discharge), intestinal putrid pus, incessant dripping discharge, and severe foul odor, which may progress to cold pain in the navel and abdomen. This is caused by putrid pus and blood, with no prospect of spontaneous resolution—it must be expelled with this formula to clear the pus.

**Ingredients:**
- White atractylodes (1 *liang*)
- Single-leaf red hollyhock root (2 *liang*)
- White peony root (½ *liang*)
- White alum (½ *liang*)

Burn the alum until desiccated and grind separately; pulverize the remaining ingredients into powder. Mix with beeswax to form pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take ten to fifteen pills on an empty stomach or before meals with rice broth. Once the pus is fully expelled, switch to other medicines for supplementation.

**Epimedium (*yin yang huo*)**
**Produced in:** Yongkang Commandery, Yizhou
**Flavor:** Pungent
**Nature:** Cold, non-toxic

**Functions:**
- Treats impotence, severe injury, and pain in the penis
- Promotes urination
- Boosts qi and strength
- Strengthens will and sinews
- Resolves scrofula, red abscesses, and lower-body sores (wash to expel worms)
- Long-term use in men may induce infertility

**Alternate names:** *Gangqian*
**Grows in:** Yangshan mountain valleys of Shang Commandery
**Guide herb:** Dioscorea (*shu yu*)

**The *Illustrated Classic* states:**
Epimedium, commonly called *xian ling pi* (immortal’s liver), grows in the Yangshan mountain valleys of Shang Commandery. It is now found throughout Jiangdong, Shaanxi, Mount Tai, Hanzhong, and the Hunan-Hubei region. The herb resembles apricot leaves with thorns, its stems like millet stalks, and its roots purple with fibrous strands. It blooms white flowers in the fourth month—some varieties bear small, solitary purple seeds. The leaves are harvested in the fifth month and dried in the sun. In Hunan-Hubei, the leaves resemble small beans, with slender, tight stems that remain evergreen through winter. The roots resemble *huang lian* (coptis). In Guanzhong, it is called *san zhi jiu ye cao* (three-branch nine-leaf herb), growing one to two *chi* tall. Both roots and leaves are usable.

Tao Hongjing noted: "Consumption induces excessive sexual desire." In the western Sichuan highlands, there exists a species of goat (*yin yang*) that copulates a hundred times daily, allegedly due to feeding on this herb—hence the name *yin yang huo* (epimedium).

**The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates:**
The leaves resemble small beans but are rounder and thinner, with slender yet sturdy stems. It grows everywhere and is commonly called *xian ling pi*.

Kou Zongshi stated: According to the *Sichuan Materia Medica*, epimedium is warm. The annotation notes: "The best specimens grow where no sound of running water is heard."

**The *Ri Hua Zi Materia Medica* states:**
*Xian ling pi* uses *zi zhi* (purple ganoderma) as its guide herb and is enhanced by wine. It treats all cold-wind and consumptive qi disorders, strengthens the waist and knees, fortifies the heart and vitality, addresses male impotence and female infertility, relieves spasms and rigidity of sinews, and restores mobility to the limbs. It also alleviates senile dementia and forgetfulness.

**Alternate names:** *Huang de zu*, *Qian liang jin*, *Gan ji jin*, *Fang zhang cao*, *Qi zhang cao*

**Lei Gong’s Processing Methods:**
