It grows in the mountain valleys of Hexi and Longxi. The root is harvested in the second and eighth months and dried over fire. Combined with *shaoyao* (芍药), *huangqin* (黄芩), *muli* (牡蛎), *xixin* (细辛), and *fuling* (茯苓), it treats fright, rage, and palpitations beneath the heart. Combined with *xiaoshi* (消石), *zishiying* (紫石英), and *taoren* (桃人), it treats women’s blood blockage. *Huangqin* serves as its assistant, and it has no aversions.

Tao Yinju notes: Today, specimens gathered from Wenshan in the northern part of Yizhou and the western mountains, though not from Hexi or Longxi, are still of good quality—deep purple like brocade, intensely bitter and astringent, with a profoundly dark hue. Those from western Sichuan dried in the shade are superior. In the northern regions, they are sun-dried, though some are fire-dried; the latter have slightly scorched skins but resist moth damage and keep well. This herb is exceedingly potent, and coarse specimens are unsuitable for ingestion. It is highly prized in common remedies. Daoists occasionally use it to expel phlegm and illnesses, though it is not required for nourishing one’s nature. The title "General" aptly captures its swift and vigorous action.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: It is greatly toxic, of moist and lubricating nature, and prone to spoilage and moth damage; fire-drying yields the best results. Harvesting in the second and eighth months avoids the fierce sun, as untimely drying renders it unusable. Its leaves, seeds, and stems resemble those of *yangti* (羊蹄), though coarser, longer, and thicker. Its roots, when slender, resemble old *yangti*, while larger ones may be as wide as a bowl and two *chi* long. For processing, heat stones until hot, cut the root into inch-long sections, and roast them on the stones. Once slightly dry, thread them with a string and hang to dry thoroughly. Specimens from Youzhou, Bingzhou, and further north grow progressively finer, with qi and potency inferior to those from Sichuan. Today, it is found in Dangzhou, Liangzhou, Qiang territories, and Sichuan. Its stems taste sour and can be eaten raw, also serving to resolve heat, though excessive consumption is harmful. Tao’s claim that Sichuan specimens are inferior to those from Longxi is mistaken.

Now, according to Chen Cangqi’s *Materia Medica*: When using *dahuang*, one must distinguish its strength. For deep, harmonious, and penetrating efficacy capable of attacking disease, Sichuan specimens resembling ox-tongue slices—firm and hard—are suitable. For swift purgation, expelling the old and clearing heat, Hexi specimens with brocade-like veins are appropriate. It may be prepared steamed, raw, or cooked, and must not be used indiscriminately.

Yu Xi et al. note: The *Shu Materia Medica* states: Its leaves resemble those of *bima* (蓖麻), its roots like large taro, with lateral fine roots resembling *niubang* (牛蒡), while smaller ones also resemble *yangti*. The *Illustrated Classic* adds: It grows six to seven *chi* tall, with brittle stems. The *Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states: Sichuan *dahuang* serves as an envoy, dispelling cold and heat. Avoid cold water. Flavor bitter and sweet. It disperses food, refines the five viscera, regulates women’s menstrual cycles, resolves water swelling, breaks phlegm repletion, cold and heat, accumulations of stagnant food, and benefits the large and small intestines. Applied topically, it treats heat-toxin swellings, governs children’s alternating chills and fever, seasonal illnesses, vexing heat, and pus erosion, and breaks static blood. *Rihuazi* states: It unblocks all qi, regulates the blood vessels, benefits the joints, drains congested water qi, harmonizes cold and heat in the four limbs, treats warm and miasmic heat illnesses, and facilitates urination and defecation. It also treats all sores, boils, abscesses, and toxic swellings. Specimens from Matixia in Kuozhou are of secondary quality.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Da Huang (Rhubarb) grows in the mountain valleys of Hexi and Longxi. Today, it is found in the Shu region, Hedong, and the prefectures of Shaanxi, with the finest specimens bearing brocade-like veins from the Shu region. Those transported from Qin and Long are called "Tufan Da Huang." In the first month, it sprouts green leaves resembling castor leaves, with large ones as broad as a fan. Its roots resemble taro, with the largest as wide as a bowl and one to two *chi* in length. Slender lateral roots grow like burdock, with smaller ones also resembling taro. In the fourth month, it blooms with yellow flowers, though some are greenish-red like buckwheat blossoms. The stems are greenish-purple, resembling bamboo. The roots are harvested in the second and eighth months, the black skin removed, and then dried over fire. Specimens from Jianghuai are called "Tu Da Huang" (Local Rhubarb), blooming with yellow flowers in the first month and bearing fine seeds. Another variety from Dingzhou, called "Yangti Da Huang," is particularly effective for treating scabies and itching. Its seedlings resemble sheep’s hooves, and as it matures over years, the leaves grow larger, resembling *Phytolacca* but narrower and pointed. In the fourth month, spikes emerge from the stems, with five to seven stalks clustered together, their flowers and leaves sharing the same color. The seeds resemble buckwheat but are lighter and smaller, ripening to a yellow hue in the fifth month—hence also called "Golden Buckwheat." The seedlings are gathered in the third month, the seeds in the fifth, both dried in the shade. The roots are harvested in the ninth month, split to reveal brocade-like veins, and sun-dried. These are also called "Tu Da Huang."

Regarding the method of harvesting Da Huang, Su Gong states: Heat stones until hot, then slice the roots into inch-thick sections and place them on the stones to dry. After a day, when slightly desiccated, thread them with string and hang to dry completely. Today, "Tu Da Huang" is often cut into transverse slices and previously subjected to fire-drying. Shu Da Huang, however, is sliced into tight, ox-tongue-shaped pieces, called "Niushe Da Huang." Both forms are used equivalently.

*The Divine Farmer’s Classic* praises Da Huang for "purging the old to usher in the new," its efficacy most divine. Thus, ancient formulas frequently employ it to dispel accumulations and stagnation. Zhang Zhongjing’s treatments for *shanghan* (cold damage) make extensive use of it. Another formula, the *Three Substances Emergency Pill*, devised by Sikong Pei Xiu as a powder, treats all sudden afflictions of the heart and abdomen. The recipe calls for one *liang* each of Da Huang, dried ginger, and croton, all of the finest quality. These are pounded, sifted, mixed with honey, and further pounded a thousand times into pills the size of small beans. Three pills are taken, with dosage adjusted for the elderly and children. As a powder, it is less effective. For cases of *zhong’e* (possession by malevolent spirits), *kewu* (sudden fright), abdominal distension, sudden pain as if stabbed by a knife, breathlessness, lockjaw, or sudden death resembling a corpse, administer with warm water or wine. If the patient does not swallow, force the head back and pour it down the throat—the condition should resolve momentarily. If not, administer three more pills. The abdomen will rumble, followed by vomiting or diarrhea, and recovery will ensue. If the mouth is already locked, pry the teeth apart to administer the medicine, and relief will follow upon ingestion.

Cui Zhiti’s treatment for *wugu* (innocent infantile malnutrition), *shanpi* (abdominal masses), scrofula, or symptoms such as dry, yellow, and protruding heads, or intermittent dysentery, relies on a Da Huang decoction. Take nine *liang* of Da Huang with brocade-like veins—if even slightly decayed, it is unusable. Peel away the rough skin, pound, and sift into a powder. Mix with three *sheng* of fine rice vinegar in a copper bowl, placed in a large pot of floating water over a charcoal fire. Stir the medicine with a bamboo or wooden spatula until it can be formed into pills, then store in a small ceramic vessel. For a three-year-old child, administer seven pills the size of *wutong* seeds, twice daily, until greenish-red pus is discharged. If no pus appears or only a little is passed, gradually increase the dosage. If excessive pus is discharged, reduce the pills accordingly. Severe cases may require seven or eight courses to eradicate the root. Dosage for adults and children should be adjusted accordingly. This medicine solely expels pus and stagnation without inducing diarrhea in the child. Strict dietary restrictions are necessary, and for nursing infants, the mother must adhere to the same prohibitions.

Cui Yuanliang’s *Remedies from the Sea* treats cold wind in the lower back and legs. Cut two large slices of Da Huang into checkerboard pieces, stir-fry with a small amount of butter until fully absorbed, ensuring it does not scorch—otherwise, it loses potency. Pound and sift into a powder. Each day, on an empty stomach, boil three *ge* of water with two coin-sized slices of fresh ginger for over ten minutes. Remove the ginger, place two *qian* of Da Huang powder in a separate bowl, and mix with the ginger decoction. Consume in one draught on an empty stomach. If any ginger decoction remains, sip it slowly to finish. This will expel cold pus and foul matter, resolving the ailment. Ancient physicians used potent medicines to attack diseases, tailoring treatments to the patient’s strength or weakness—never applying them indiscriminately.

Yao Sengyuan initially served the Liang dynasty. Emperor Wu, suffering from fever, wished to take Da Huang. Sengyuan cautioned: "Da Huang is a swift-acting purgative. Your Majesty is advanced in years and should not use it lightly." The emperor disregarded his advice and nearly collapsed from exhaustion. Emperor Yuan later suffered from a heart and abdominal ailment. All physicians recommended mild medicines for gradual relief. Sengyuan, however, declared: "The pulse is surging and replete—this is an old obstruction. Without Da Huang, there is no cure." The emperor heeded his advice and recovered. From this, it is clear that modern physicians often use a single potent medicine to treat myriad diseases, attributing any success to the formula’s miraculous nature. When treatments fail, they never acknowledge their misjudgment in prescribing the medicine. Such cases are numerous—how can one not be cautious?

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: "Its leaves resemble castor, its root is like a large taro, with slender lateral roots akin to burdock."

The *Illustrated Classic* states: "It grows six to seven *chi* tall, its stem is brittle and sour, and it sobers one from drunkenness."

Master Lei says: "For use, finely chop it. The inner texture should resemble water ripples with tight, heavy veins. After chopping, steam it from *si* (9–11 a.m.) to *wei* (1–3 p.m.), then dry in the sun. Next, sprinkle it with preserved winter water and steam again from *wei* (1–3 p.m.) to *hai* (9–11 p.m.). Repeat this steaming process seven times. After drying in the sun, sprinkle it with diluted honey water and steam for one *fu* period. When properly prepared, the Da Huang will split like black paste. Dry it in the sun for optimal use."

The *Sagely Benefit Formulas*:
- For treating seasonal outbreaks of pea-like sores: Take half a *liang* of Sichuan Da Huang, lightly stir-fry, then decoct in one large cup of water until reduced to seven parts. Strain and divide into two doses.
- For heat-induced delirium and various types of jaundice: Take five *liang* of Sichuan Da Huang, chop and stir-fry until slightly red, then grind into powder. Decoct with five *sheng* of preserved winter snow water until it forms a paste. Take half a spoonful at any time, mixed with cold water.

The *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*:
- For treating abdominal masses: Pound and sift ten *liang* of Da Huang, mix evenly with three *sheng* of vinegar, and add two spoons of white honey. Decoct until it can be formed into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take thirty pills per dose with fresh ginger decoction, adjusting until purgation occurs; reduce the dose for milder cases.

The *Thousand Gold Formulas*:
- For postpartum blood surging to the heart, retained placenta, or abdominal blood clots: Take one *liang* of brocade-pattern Da Huang, pound and sift into powder, then simmer with half a *sheng* of premium vinegar until it forms a paste. Form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. The patient should dissolve five pills in seven parts of a cup of warm vinegar and take it. After a while, purgation will follow.

Also treats internal injuries from horse falls.

*The Supplement to the Thousand Gold Formulas*:
- For treating blood masses causing pain in women: Pound and sift three *liang* of Da Huang, then decoct with two *sheng* of wine for ten boils. Take the entire dose at once.

*The Experiential Later Formulas*:
- For treating wind-heat, phlegm accumulation, heat-induced wind congestion, promoting digestion, transforming qi, guiding blood, and thoroughly resolving congestion: Use four *liang* of Da Huang and four *liang* of Qian Niu Zi (half raw, half prepared), grind into powder, and form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds with refined honey. Take ten pills per dose with tea; if mild purgation is desired, take fifteen pills. Most suitable for use during the winter months, as it does not disturb the person.

*Master Mei’s Formulas*:
- For sudden unilateral swelling and pain of the external testicles: Mix equal parts of Jiao (unidentified) and Da Huang powder with vinegar and apply topically; reapply when dry.

*The Doumen Formulas*:
- For lumbar pain: Use half a *liang* of finely cut Da Huang and add half a *liang* of fresh ginger, cut into small bean-sized pieces. Stir-fry in a wok until yellow, then add two bowls of water. Take the entire dose at the fifth watch (around 3–5 AM), and by dawn, the discharge will follow. Collect the dark blood-like substance from the waist in a basin—it will resemble chicken liver—and the condition will cease.

*The Simple and Essential Relief for the Multitudes*:
- For vomiting blood: Pound one *liang* of Sichuan Da Huang into powder. Take one *qian* per dose with one *ge* of fresh Rehmannia juice and half a cup of water, decocting for three to five boils. Take at any time.

*The Broadly Beneficial Formulas*:
- For heat in the joints, chronic emaciation, and yellowing: Use four *fen* of Da Huang and decoct with five large *ge* of a boy’s urine until reduced to four *ge*. Strain and divide into two doses, taking on an empty stomach. Take the second dose after walking four or five *li*.

*The Categorized Essentials of Cold Damage*:
- For treating acute jaundice: Coarsely cut two *liang* of Da Huang, soak in three and a half *sheng* of water overnight, then decoct in the morning to extract two and a half *sheng* of juice. Add two *liang* of Mang Xiao, stir, and take. Shortly after, purgation will occur.

*Yao Hezhong*:
- For treating persistent eye closure in children due to brain heat: Coarsely file one *fen* of Da Huang and soak in three *ge* of water overnight. For a one-year-old child, administer half a *ge* daily; apply the remainder to the crown of the head, reapplying when dry.

*The Alternative Explanation* states: Carefully note that when Da Huang is harvested, it is always dried over fire-heated stones. To sell it quickly, there is no longer any raw form available. When using it, no further processing such as excessive steaming or boiling is necessary.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* says: The benefits and harms of Da Huang have already been fully discussed in previous texts. Master Zhongjing treated insufficiency of heart qi with vomiting blood and nosebleed using the *Xie Xin Tang* (Drain the Heart Decoction), which contains Da Huang, Huang Qin, and Huang Lian. Some ask: If heart qi is insufficient, why not use a heart-tonifying decoction but instead a heart-draining one? The answer is: If heart qi alone were insufficient, there would be no vomiting or nosebleed. This condition arises from pathogenic heat exploiting the insufficiency, hence the vomiting and nosebleed. Using bitter herbs to drain the heat simultaneously serves to supplement the heart—this is a twofold approach. For those with this pattern, its efficacy is unfailing. Adjust the dosage according to the degree of deficiency or excess. (Ting Li)

Tingli (葶苈), produced in Caozhou, Danzhou, and Chengde Commandery, is acrid and bitter in flavor, cold and greatly cold in nature, and non-toxic. It governs accumulations and gatherings of bound qi, cold and heat from dietary causes, breaks up hardness and expels pathogenic qi, unblocks and facilitates the water pathways, drains bladder water, subdues latent heat qi, expels pathogenic water from the skin that ascends to cause facial and orbital swelling, and treats sudden wind-heat stroke with itching rashes. It disinhibits the lower abdomen. Prolonged consumption causes vacuity.

It has alternate names: Dingli, Dianhao, Dashì, and Dashì. It grows in Gaocheng’s marshlands and fields. Its seeds are harvested after the Beginning of Summer and dried in the shade. It works well with wine. Elm bark serves as its guiding herb, while it is incompatible with stiff silkworms and *Ranunculus sceleratus*.

Tao Hongjing states: The finest variety comes from Pengcheng, though it is also found near the roads. Its mother plant resembles shepherd’s purse, while its seeds are fine, yellow, and extremely bitter; they should be stir-fried before use.

Modern observation: This medicinal also treats lung congestion with counterflow qi, cough, panting, and hasty breathing, and eliminates phlegm-rheum from the chest.

Su Song et al. note: The *Shu Ben* states: Its sprouts resemble *Adenophora trachelioides*, emerging in late spring and growing two to three feet tall. Its flowers are yellow, and its pods contain fine yellow seeds. The seeds ripen in the fifth month and are harvested and dried in the sun. The *Yaoxing Lun* states: Tingli is a ministerial medicinal, sour in flavor and slightly toxic. It disinhibits urination, drains lung qi in cases of counterflow panting and hasty breathing, and checks cough. The *Erya* states: *Dian* is tingli. The commentary notes: Its seeds and leaves resemble those of mustard; another name is *gouji* (dog shepherd’s purse). *Rihuazi* states: It disinhibits the small intestine and frees water qi in vacuity swelling.

The *Tu Jing* states: Tingli grows in Gaocheng’s marshlands and fields. Today, it is found throughout the prefectures of Jingdong, Shaanxi, and Hebei, with the finest coming from Caozhou. Its early spring sprouts and leaves grow six to seven inches tall and resemble shepherd’s purse. Its roots are white, and its stems and branches are green. It blooms in the third month with pale yellow flowers. Its pods contain seeds that are slightly smaller than millet grains, elongated, and yellow. The seeds are harvested after the Beginning of Summer and dried in the sun. The *Monthly Ordinances* states: In the first month of summer, the *mí* grasses die. Xu Shen and Zheng Xuan both comment: *Mí* grasses refer to plants like shepherd’s purse and tingli, which wither and die by summer, hence they are harvested at this time.

Zhang Zhongjing treats lung abscess with panting and inability to lie down using *Tingli Dazao Xie Fei Tang* (Tingli and Jujube Lung-Draining Decoction). The tingli is stir-fried until yellow, ground to powder, and formed into pills the size of a bullet. For each dose, twenty jujubes are decocted in three *sheng* of water until two *sheng* remain. One pill is then added, and the decoction is reduced to one *sheng* and taken in one draught. It also governs propping rheum with inability to breathe.

The *Cui Zhiti Fang* treats counterflow qi with cough, prolonged inhalation, inability to lie down, generalized qi swelling, unilateral facial swelling, or foot swelling. Three *sheng* of tingli seeds are stir-fried over a low flame, ground, and sifted into a powder. Five *sheng* of clear wine are used to steep the powder, for seven days in winter or three days in summer. The initial dose is the size of a peach pit, taken three times during the day and once at night (twice during the day and twice at night in winter). The dosage is adjusted based on the patient’s qi strength, aiming for slight diarrhea once or twice. In urgent cases, the wine may be strained through silk and taken immediately. The tingli used should have a single stem growing upward, with pods emerging from the leaf tips—these pods are thick and short. Another variety, *goujie* grass, has leaves clustered near the root and produces slender, elongated pods. Care must be taken to distinguish between these two types when harvesting.

The *Qie Zhong Fang* treats cough with the *Han Gao Wan* (Pill for Sucking): One *liang* of Caozhou tingli seeds is stir-fried on paper until black, combined with one *liang* each of *zhimu* and *beimu*, and ground together. Half a *liang* of jujube pulp and one and a half *liang* of melted rock sugar are added to the powder, and the mixture is formed into pills the size of bullets. Each dose consists of one pill wrapped in fresh silk and held in the mouth, allowing the saliva to be swallowed slowly. Severe cases require no more than three pills. This formula is widely used by physicians today.

Lei Gong states: When using tingli, do not mistake it for *chixuzi* (red-bearded seeds), which closely resemble tingli seeds but have a slightly sweet-bitter flavor. True tingli seeds have a bitter taste. For processing, mix the seeds with glutinous rice and dry-fry them over a low flame until the rice is cooked. Remove the rice and grind the seeds alone for use.

The *Sheng Hui Fang* treats counterflow qi with hasty breathing and generalized floating swelling: One *sheng* of sweet tingli is stir-fried on paper until purple, ground to an extremely fine powder, and placed in a raw silk bag. Five *sheng* of clear wine are used to steep the bag for three days. Each dose consists of one spoonful taken with congee broth, three to four times daily.

The *Wai Tai Mi Yao* treats inability to breathe after eating or drinking: Three *liang* of tingli seeds are stir-fried until yellow, ground to powder, and decocted in three *sheng* of water with thirty jujubes until one *sheng* of liquid remains. The powder is added to this liquid. Each dose is the size of a jujube, decocted to seven *ge* and taken in one draught.

The *Qian Jin Fang* treats abdominal distention with accumulations, gatherings, concretions, and conglomerations: One *sheng* of tingli seeds is stir-fried and steeped in five *sheng* of wine for seven days. Three *ge* are taken daily.

The *Qian Jin Yi Fang* treats head wind: Tingli seeds are pounded, steeped in hot water, and the liquid is used to wash the head.

The *Jing Yan Fang* records a proven formula from the Hebei Pei family for treating water swelling and sudden swelling: Three *liang* of tingli are pounded six thousand times until pulpy. Four *liang* of *hanfangji* powder are added, and a green-headed duck is decapitated over the mortar, allowing its blood to drip in. Once the blood is fully incorporated, the duck’s head is added, and the mixture is pounded another five thousand times, then formed into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. In severe cases, ten pills are taken on an empty stomach with plain hot water; in milder cases, five pills are taken. The treatment is repeated frequently, stopping after five days. This formula disinhibits urination and has miraculous efficacy.

The *Mei Shi Fang* treats generalized floating swelling with inhibited urination: [The formula is as described above, using tingli.]

Two *liang* of tingli seeds and twenty jujubes are simmered in one large *sheng* of water until reduced to one small *sheng*. The jujubes are removed, and the tingli seeds are added to the jujube decoction, then simmered into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Ten pills are taken with water.

Another formula: For treating lung congestion with wheezing and inability to lie down.
Three *liang* of stir-fried tingli seeds and thirty jujubes are boiled in three *sheng* of water. The jujubes are simmered until two *sheng* remain, then further reduced to one *sheng*, strained, and taken in two doses.

*Jianyao Jizhong*: For treating childhood water qi with abdominal swelling, concurrent dysentery with pus and blood, and inhibited urination.
Half a *liang* of tingli seeds is lightly stir-fried and pounded into a paste, then mixed with jujube pulp and formed into pills the size of mung beans. Five pills are taken with jujube decoction on an empty stomach, morning and evening, adjusting the dosage according to the child’s age.

*Xu Shiquan Fang*: For treating all poisons entering the abdomen that cannot be cured, and horse sweat.
One *liang* of stir-fried tingli seeds is ground, steeped in one *sheng* of hot water, and taken to purge malign blood.

*Cui Shi*: For treating water qi.
Three *liang* of tingli seeds are placed in a container and steamed over rice until cooked, then pounded ten thousand times. If forming pills, they are made the size of *wutong* seeds without honey. Five pills are taken initially, gradually increasing to seven, until mild purgation is achieved. Overuse may impair appetite. If qi surges, take until purgation occurs, then cease once qi stabilizes. This formula is unparalleled for treating water qi. Master Xiao, the imperial son-in-law, suffered from water swelling and was cured solely by this remedy.

*Shanghan Leiyao*: For treating kidney impediment with dry lips, tingli is the remedy.

*Zimu Milu*: For treating childhood white scalp sores.
Tingli is pounded into powder, washed with hot water, and applied topically.

*Yao Hezhong*: For treating childhood roundworms.
One *fen* of raw tingli seeds is ground into powder, simmered in three *ge* of water until reduced to one *ge*, and taken over the course of a day.

*Shenghui*: Another formula: For treating enduring branch rheum, great abdominal water swelling, and unceasing wheezing.
Three *liang* of sweet tingli seeds are stir-fried between paper until purple, then pounded into a paste. Pills the size of a bullet are taken with one *zhongzhan* of water and four jujubes, simmered to five *fen*, strained, and taken at any time.

*Yanyi* states: Tingli uses the seeds. The seeds have two flavors—sweet and bitter—though their form is identical. Since the text describes them as acrid and bitter, sweet tingli is no longer used medicinally. Generally, their therapeutic action relies on promoting water movement and purgation, hence the caution that prolonged use weakens the body. This aligns with the principle of bitter purgation, and the rationale is clear. The *Yaoxing Lun* exhaustively describes their properties, though it incorrectly attributes an sour flavor.

---

**Platycodon Root** (*Jiegeng*)
*Producing regions*: Jiezhou, Chengzhou, Hezhou
*Flavor*: Acrid, bitter; slightly warm; mildly toxic.
*Therapeutic actions*: Governs stabbing pain in the chest and rib-sides, abdominal fullness with rumbling intestines, fright palpitations and fearful qi; disinhibits the five viscera and intestines and stomach; supplements blood and qi; dispels wind impediment with cold-heat; warms the center and disperses grain; treats throat and pharynx pain; expels *gu* poison.
*Alternate names*: Liru, Fangtu, Baiyao, Gengcao, Jini.
*Growth habitat*: Grows in the valleys of Mount Songgao and Yuanju. The root is harvested in the second month and dried in the sun.
*Pharmaceutical relationships*: Node skin serves as its envoy. Combined with oyster shell and *yuanzhi*, it treats pent-up anger. Combined with nitre and gypsum, it treats cold damage. It is contraindicated with *baiji*, longan, and *longdan*.

Tao Hongjing notes: It is found everywhere in nearby regions. Its leaves are called *yinren*. It sprouts in the second or third month and can be boiled for food. Platycodon is highly effective for *gu* poison and is commonly used in folk remedies under the name *jini*. However, there is another *jini* that resolves drug poisoning—this is the one mistaken for ginseng. It is not this platycodon, though their leaves are very similar. The difference lies in *jini*’s leaves being glossy, smooth, and hairless beneath, and its leaves do not grow in opposing pairs like ginseng.

The *Tang Ben* annotation states: Ginseng’s seedlings resemble *wuji* but are shorter and broader, with round stems branching three or four times, each branch bearing five leaves. Tao’s claim that *jini* is mistaken for ginseng is erroneous. Moreover, *jini* and platycodon may have varying leaf arrangements—some leaves grow in three or four pairs—all on a single upright stem. Since their leaves are easily confused, the only distinction lies in whether the root has a core.

Yuxi et al. note, citing the *Yaoxing Lun*: Platycodon is a ministerial drug, bitter in flavor, neutral, and non-toxic. It treats diarrhea, breaks blood stasis, dispels stagnant qi, dissolves phlegm and accumulations, governs lung qi with rapid breathing and counterflow cough, eliminates cold pain in the abdomen, and treats malign influx and childhood fright epilepsy.

*Rihuazi* states: It descends all qi, stops cholera with cramping, relieves abdominal distension and pain, supplements the five taxations, nourishes qi, dispels evil and repels epidemics, supplements deficiency, dissolves phlegm and breaks concretions, nourishes blood and expels pus, treats internal leakage and throat impediment, and neutralizes poison. White congee resolves its effects.

*Tujing* states: Platycodon grows in the valleys of Mount Songgao and Yuanju, and is now found everywhere. The root is as thick as a little finger and yellow-white in color. In spring, it sprouts seedlings a *chi* tall. The leaves resemble apricot leaves but are longer and elliptical, growing in groups of four opposing leaves. When tender, they can be boiled for food. In summer, it blooms with purple flowers resembling morning glory seeds. After autumn, it sets seed. The root is harvested in the eighth month, finely sliced, and dried in the sun. Its leaves are called *yinren*. The root has a core; those without a core are *jini*. *Jini* also resolves poison, and the two are often confused. The difference is that *jini*’s leaves are glossy and hairless beneath. The platycodon from Guanzhong has a yellow root resembling the root of *shukui*.

The stem is slender and green. The leaves are small and green, resembling chrysanthemum leaves. Ancient formulas also use it alone.

*The Ancient and Modern Record of Proven Formulas* treats sudden *gu* poisoning with bleeding like chicken liver, discharging over a *shi* of blood day and night, damaging the four viscera while the heart remains intact, or nosebleeds leading to near death. Pound platycodon into powder and take a square-inch spoonful with wine, three times daily. If unable to swallow, pry the mouth open with an object to administer it. The heart will feel vexed, but it will soon settle. Continue for seven days, then cease. Eat pork liver broth to replenish; the effect is divine.

*The Collected Proven Formulas* treats chest fullness with shivering, rapid pulse, dry throat without thirst, frequent expectoration of turbid, foul-smelling sputum, and eventual expectoration of pus like rice porridge—a case of lung abscess. Treat it with two *liang* each of platycodon and licorice (roasted), boiled in three *sheng* of water to reduce to one *sheng*. Divide and take twice daily; recovery follows when pus and blood are expectorated morning and evening.

Master Lei states: In preparation, do not use *mugeng* (wood platycodon), which closely resembles platycodon but tastes fishy and astringent when chewed. Remove the hard tip (two to three *fen*) and side branches. Finely slice on a locust-wood chopping block, soak in lily bulb water for a full day and night, strain, and dry over a slow fire. For every four *liang* prepared, use five *fen* of fresh lily bulb, pound into a paste, and steep in the water.

*The Sage’s Benevolent Formulas*: To treat horse throat impediment and toxic qi obstruction, take two *liang* of platycodon (remove the rhizome), decoct in three large cups of water to reduce to one cup, strain, and take warm in three divided doses at any time.

Another formula: For pregnancy with sudden malign attack and heart-abdominal pain, finely slice one *liang* of platycodon, decoct in one medium cup of water with three slices of fresh ginger to reduce to six *fen*, strain, and take warm at any time.

*The Outer Terrace Secret Essentials*: To treat sudden guest counterflow with corpse-like inability to speak, burn one *liang* of platycodon into powder and take with rice water, also swallowing musk the size of a soybean; excellent.

*The Thousand Gold Formulas*: To treat throat closure and toxic qi, decoct two *liang* of platycodon in three *sheng* of water to reduce to one *sheng* and take all at once.

Another formula: For nosebleed, take platycodon powder with water, a square-inch spoonful four to five times daily; it also stops hematemesis and bloody stool.

*The Hundred and One Formulas*: For trauma with static blood in the intestines that does not resolve and periodically flares, take platycodon powder with boiled water, a knife-point’s measure.

*The Experiential Later Formulas*: To treat *gucao* wind with swollen, painful teeth, grind platycodon into powder, mix with jujube pulp into pills the size of soap beans, wrap in silk and bite. For swelling, rinse with *jingjie* decoction.

*The Concise Aid for the Multitudes*: For unrelenting phlegm cough with wheezing, pound one and a half *liang* of platycodon into powder, decoct in half a *sheng* of boy’s urine to reduce to four *ge*, strain, and take warm.

*The Secret Record of Child and Mother*: To treat sudden guest counterflow death in children, burn platycodon, take three *qianbi* of the powder with water.

Du Ren: To treat heat in the upper burner with mouth, tongue, and throat sores, and cough with pus and blood, take one *liang* of platycodon and two *liang* of licorice, grind into powder, and take two *qian* per dose. Decoct in one cup of water to reduce to six *fen*, strain, and take warm after meals in small sips; it also treats lung obstruction.

*Master Mei’s Formulas*: To treat sudden *gu* toxin with bleeding like goose liver, unceasing day and night, and visceral decay, pound platycodon to extract juice and take seven *ge*; excellent.

*Extended Meanings* states: Platycodon treats lung heat with hasty qi, cough reversal, and lung abscess with pus discharge. Tao Yinju says: Common formulas use this under the name *jini*. Now, the *jini* that causes confusion with ginseng is not this platycodon.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: Tao’s reference to *jini* confusing ginseng is mistaken. Upon examination, it is not so. Yinju’s intent was only to describe the root, hence the ancient confusion with ginseng. The *Tang Materia Medica*’s annotation, however, errs in focusing on the seedling.

*Lang* is pronounced *lang*, *dang* is pronounced *dang*. Qinzhou.

Flavor bitter, sweet; nature cold; toxic. Governs toothache and expels worms, muscle numbness and spasms, enables swift walking, induces visions of spirits, and treats manic madness, wind epilepsy, mental inversion, and cramping spasms. Excessive consumption causes manic running. Long-term use lightens the body, enabling one to run as fast as a galloping horse, strengthens will and increases strength, and connects with the divine.

Also called *hengtang* or *xingtang*. Grows in river valleys by the sea and in Yongzhou. Harvest seeds in the fifth month.

Tao Yinju states: Now found everywhere. The seeds resemble the kernels of *wuwei* but are extremely small. Used only in formulas for treating manic madness; one must not consume excessive doses. Long-term use, however, incurs no harm, as it connects with the divine and enhances swift movement, offering great benefit—yet it is not mentioned in the *Scriptures of the Immortals*. Today’s physicians often call it *langtang*.

Now, according to Chen Cangqi’s *Materia Medica*: *Langdang* seeds govern *xuanpi* (abdominal masses), calm the mind and stabilize will, sharpen hearing and vision, dispel evil and expel wind, reverse graying, and are warm rather than cold in nature. Take the seeds, dry them quickly, and on alternate days, swallow a pinch on an empty stomach with water—do not crush the seeds, for if broken, they induce madness. Alternatively, soak the seeds in urine until fully absorbed, then dry them in the sun and consume as before.

Yu Xi et al. note: According to the *Illustrated Classic of the Materia Medica of Shu*, the leaves resemble those of *wangbuliuxing* (vaccaria) and *songlan* (woad). The stems and leaves bear fine hairs; the flowers are white. The seed pods resemble small jars, with flat, fine seeds like millet, greenish-yellow in color. Found everywhere. Harvest seeds in the sixth and seventh months, then dry in the sun.

The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: *Langdang* may be used alone. Flavor bitter, acrid; slightly hot; highly toxic. In its raw state, it causes one to see spirits and induces frenzied needle-grabbing. When stir-fried, it stops cold diarrhea. Governs toothache and decayed tooth cavities; chewing the seeds expels worms. Boil with limewater for a full day, remove, and dry in the sun. Form into pills with *fuzi* (aconite), *ganjiang* (dried ginger), *chenjupi* (aged tangerine peel), *guixin* (cinnamon bark), and *houpo* (magnolia bark) to dispel all cold qi, chronic qi-induced dysentery, and extreme cold. If heat arises, use mung bean juice to resolve it. Stir-fry until scorched, grind into fine powder, and apply to treat rectal prolapse.

*Rihuazi* states: Warm; toxic. Licorice, *shengma* (cimicifuga), and rhinoceros horn all counteract its toxicity. Burn to fumigate decayed teeth and wash sweaty genitals.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: *Langdang* seeds grow in river valleys by the sea and in Yongzhou; now found everywhere. The stems reach two to three *chi* in height. The leaves resemble those of *dihuang* (rehmannia), *wangbuliuxing* (vaccaria), and *honglan* (red indigo), about three fingers wide. Flowers bloom in the fourth month, purple in color. The stems, pods, and leaves bear white hairs. Fruits form in the fifth month, with pods shaped like small jars, resembling miniature pomegranates. The seeds inside are extremely fine, greenish-white like grains of rice. Also called *tianxianzi* (seeds of celestial immortals). Harvest seeds in the fifth month and dry in the shade.

Carefully noting the *Divine Farmer’s Classic*: *Langdang* is cold in nature, though later scholars often describe it as extremely hot. Yet in the *Records of the Grand Historian*, the *Biography of Chun Yuyi* states: The consort of the King of Zichuan was pregnant but unable to lactate. Yuyi administered a pinch of *langdang* medicine in wine, and she soon produced milk. How could a failure to lactate be treated with a hot drug? Moreover, ancient formulas for sudden manic madness often use *langdang* alone. Is its nature truly cold?

The *Minor Essentials* records a formula for treating manic madness: Take three *sheng* of *langdang*, grind into powder, and steep in one *sheng* of wine for several days. Remove, pound, mix with the strained liquid, and simmer over a fire until it can be formed into pills the size of small beans. Take three pills three times daily. One will feel tightness in the mouth and face, sense insects crawling in the head, and notice red patches on the forehead, hands, and feet—these are signs of recovery. If unsure, take again until the medicine is finished; the effect is excellent.

The *Box of Formulas* treats intestinal wind with *langdang* decoction: Take one *sheng* of *langdang* seeds, process them, dry quickly, and sift. Extract juice from half a *jin* of fresh ginger. Combine the two in a silver pot, add two *sheng* of ash-free wine, and simmer over a fire until thick like malt syrup. Gradually add wine until about five *sheng* have been used, then stop simmering. Form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Each morning, take three pills with wine, increasing to five or seven pills. If the pills stick to the hands during formation, use *tusi* (cuscuta) powder as a barrier. When simmering, avoid high heat, lest the medicine scorch and lose potency. Initial doses may cause slight heat—do not be alarmed. For severe illness, after three days of use, diarrhea will occur; when the illness resolves, the diarrhea ceases. The effect is absolute.

Leigong states: When using, do not mistake it for *cangmingzi*, which resembles it but is ineffective. Many people mix them. *Cangmingzi* is slightly reddish. To process ten *liang*, boil with one *yi* of vinegar until the vinegar is exhausted. Then soak in cow’s milk overnight; by dawn, if the milk has turned black, it confirms the seeds are *langdang*—highly toxic. Dry in the sun, grind again, and sift for use. Do not consume in error, as it will rush to the heart, causing great agitation and fiery vision.

The *Separate Notes* states: Carefully noting: The benefits of *langdang* do not match its reputation, yet its toxicity is extreme. After boiling for one or two days, teeth only then begin to grow—those who use it should exercise caution.

**Mugwort (Caohao)**
Flavor bitter; nature cold; non-toxic. Governs scabies, itching, scabs, malignant sores, kills lice, expels lingering heat in the bones and joints, and brightens the eyes. Also called *qinghao* or *fangkui*. Grows in the marshes and river valleys of Huayin.

Tao Yinju states: Found everywhere. This is the *qinghao* (green mugwort) that people mix with fragrant vegetables for consumption.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This mugwort, when crushed and applied to sword wounds, greatly stops bleeding, promotes flesh growth, and relieves pain—excellent.

Here follows the translation:

Now examining Chen Cangqi’s *Materia Medica*: Mugwort governs demonic qi, corpse transmission, and recurrent consumptive disorders; regulates women’s blood and qi, abdominal fullness, and chronic cold-heat dysentery. In autumn and winter, use the seeds; in spring and summer, use the shoots—both are pounded and strained for juice, or dried in the sun and powdered, then taken in urine. If coldness is sensed, decoct with wine. Alternatively, burn to ash, strain the juice through eight or nine layers of paper, and mix with lime to remove nasal polyps and moles.

Yuxi et al. note: The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica of Shu* states: Its leaves resemble those of *yinchen* mugwort but lack white undersides; the plant reaches about four *chi* in height. The shoots are gathered in the fourth and fifth months and dried in the sun. People of Jiangdong call it *□* mugwort for its odor resembling *□*, while northerners call it green mugwort. The *Erya* states: Mugwort is *qin*. The commentary explains: Mugwort is also called *qin*. The *Book of Songs · Minor Court Hymns* says: “They eat the mugwort of the wilds.” Lu Ji comments: This is green mugwort. In Jing and Yu, between Runan and Ruyin, it is all called *qin*. Sun Yan notes: In the regions of Jing and Chu, mugwort is called *qin*. Guo Pu adds: Today, people call the green mugwort used for grilling and eating *qin*.

The *Ri Huazi Materia Medica* states: Green mugwort supplements the center and boosts qi, lightens the body and replenishes deficiency, preserves complexion, promotes hair growth, blackens hair to prevent aging, and eliminates garlic breath. Crushed fresh for juice and applied, it treats diarrhea and dysentery. Five *qian* of the powdered herb, mixed with rice water, or burned to ash and decocted with lime, treats malignant sores and is also used for the penis. It further states: The seeds are sweet, cold, and non-toxic. They brighten the eyes and stimulate the appetite. Stir-fried, they treat consumptive disorders and strengthen the robust. Soaked in urine, they treat malignant sores, scabies, ringworm, wind rashes, and kill lice when decocted for washing. It also states: The seeds of *chouhao* (fetid mugwort) are cooling and non-toxic. They treat consumptive disorders, downbear qi, stimulate the appetite, arrest night sweats, and expel demonic qi and toxins. Another name is mugwort.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: Mugwort, that is, green mugwort, grows in the marshes and river valleys of Huayin, and is now found everywhere. In spring, it sprouts tender, finely divided leaves, which people mix with fragrant vegetables for consumption. By summer, it reaches three to five *chi* in height. After autumn, it bears small, pale yellow flowers, beneath which seeds form, the size of millet grains. The seeds are gathered in the eighth and ninth months and dried in the shade. Roots, stems, seeds, and leaves are all used medicinally; dried and roasted, they make an especially fine fragrant beverage. Green mugwort is also called *fangkui*. When using, take the seeds but not the leaves, the roots but not the stems—if all four are used together, they may instead cause illness. Soaking in boys’ urine enhances its efficacy. It is most effective for treating steaming bone heat and consumptive disorders. Ancient formulas often use it singly.

Ge’s method for treating wounds from metal blades: Take green mugwort, pound it, and apply to the wound, then bind with silk; the bleeding will stop and the wound will heal.

Cui Yuanliang’s *Remedies from the Seashore*: To treat steaming bone heat and ghostly qi, take five *dou* of boys’ urine, clarified, and five *dou* of green mugwort, gathered in the eighth or ninth month with seeds—this is best—finely chopped. Combine the two in a large cauldron and decoct over a fierce fire until three *dou* remain; strain out the dregs and wash the vessel clean. Return the liquid to the cauldron and decoct over a gentle fire until two *dou* remain. Then add ten pig gallbladders, decoct until one and a half *dou* remain, remove from the fire, and let cool. Store in a new ceramic vessel. When ready to take, roast two or three *liang* of licorice until fragrant, pound to powder, mix with the decoction, and pound one thousand times to form pills. Take twenty pills on an empty stomach with rice porridge, gradually increasing to thirty pills.

Master Lei states: For use, only the middle portion is excellent—when it reaches the knee, it bends upward; when it reaches the waist, it bends downward. Use the seeds but not the leaves, the roots but not the stems; if all four are used together, they may instead cause chronic illness. For the leaves, gather any quantity, soak in the urine of seven seven-year-old boys for seven days and nights, then strain, dry in the sun, and use.

The *Dietary Therapy* states: Green mugwort is cold. It boosts qi, promotes hair growth, lightens the body, strengthens the center, prevents aging, brightens the eyes, and dispels wind toxin. Pounded and applied to sores, it stops bleeding and promotes flesh growth. It sprouts earliest in spring, and the white variety is authentic. Naturally fragrant, it may be pickled with vinegar as a vegetable, benefiting the person. To treat steaming bone heat, soak in boys’ urine for one or two nights, dry, and grind into pills—this powerfully dispels heat and consumptive disorders. For ghostly qi, take the seeds as powder, and consume one *fangcunbi* with wine to cure. Burn to ash, strain the liquid, mix with lime, and decoct to treat malignant sores and scars.

The *Hundred and One Remedies*: To treat bee stings, chew green mugwort and apply to the sore; it will heal immediately.

The *Doumen Remedies*: To treat emaciation from overwork in men, finely chop green mugwort, decoct with three *sheng* of water and five *sheng* of boys’ urine until one and a half *sheng* remain, strain, and decoct in a vessel to form a paste. Form pills the size of *wutong* seeds, and take twenty on an empty stomach or before bed with warm wine.

The *Extension of Meanings* states: Grass mugwort is today’s green mugwort. It grows everywhere, sprouting earliest in spring, and people gather it as a vegetable. Its roots are red and its leaves fragrant. Today it is called green mugwort, though distinctions exist. Among its kind, the deep green variety is preferred. In the regions of Shaanxi, Sui, and Yin, amid clusters of mugwort, one or two patches stand out with a vivid green hue; locals call this "fragrant mugwort." Its stems and leaves resemble common mugwort, but while common mugwort is pale green, this variety is deep green—hence its rich fragrance. Perhaps the ancients prized the deep green variety; otherwise, why would all mugworts not be green? *Xuanfuhua* [Inula flower] in Suizhou...

**Flavor and Nature:**
Salty, sweet; warm, slightly cooling, and draining. Slightly toxic.

**Therapeutic Actions:**
Resolves bound *qi* and fullness beneath the flanks, calms fright palpitations, dispels water, eliminates cold-heat in the five viscera, supplements the center and descends *qi*, dissolves phlegm-bindings in the chest, and treats viscous sputum like lacquer, phlegm-water in the heart and flanks, retained fluids in the bladder, wind-*qi* damp impediment, dead flesh in the skin, eye gum (read *chī*), benefits the large intestine, unblocks the blood vessels, and enhances complexion and luster.

**Alternate Names:**
*Dàishèn*, *Jīnfèicǎo*, *Shèngshèn*.

**Root:**
The root governs wind-damp.

**Habitat and Harvest:**
Grows in level marshlands and river valleys. The flowers are gathered in the fifth month and dried in the sun; they are ready in twenty days.

**Táo Yǐn Jū’s Notes:**
Found in low-lying damp areas near roads, resembling chrysanthemum but larger. There is also a distinct *xuánfú* root from Hénán, which is also found in the northern regions. Its form resembles *xiōngqióng* (Sichuan lovage), and it is used exclusively for preparing *xuánfú* ointment; it has no other applications and is not the root of this *fùhuā*.

**Táng Běn Annotation:**
The *xuánfú* root is listed in the middle grade. Táo states: "Its shoots resemble ginger, and its root resembles *gāoliángjiāng* (galangal) but is thinner—this is mountain ginger." This does not match the *xuánfú* root. Now, specimens from the northern regions resemble *xiōngqióng*, which bears no resemblance to *gāoliángjiāng*.

**Yǔ Xī et al. Note:**
According to the *Shǔ Běn Tú Jīng*: "*Xuánfùhuā* has leaves like *shuǐsū* (water mint) and yellow flowers like chrysanthemum. It is found everywhere, and its flowers are gathered from the sixth to the ninth month."

**Yào Xìng Lùn:**
*Xuánfùhuā* is an envoy. Sweet and non-toxic. It directs *qi* downward from the flanks, treats cold-heat and water swelling, resolves long-standing water in the bladder, reduces abdominal distension, stimulates the stomach, and checks counterflow nausea with inability to eat.

**Ěr Yǎ:**
*Fú* is *dàogēng*. Annotation: *Xuánfù* resembles chrysanthemum. Exegesis: *Fù* is also called *dàogēng*.

**Xiāo Bǐng’s Note:**
*Xuánfù* uses the flower; *fúxuán* uses the root.

**Rì Huá Zǐ’s Note:**
Non-toxic. Brightens the eyes, treats head wind, and unblocks the blood vessels. Its leaves stanch bleeding from metal-inflicted wounds.

**Tú Jīng:**
*Xuánfùhuā* grows in level marshlands and river valleys and is now found everywhere. Its shoots emerge after the second month, often near water. It is as large as *hónglán* (red indigo) but without thorns, growing one to two *chǐ* tall. Its leaves resemble willow, and its stems are slender. In the sixth month, it blooms with flowers like chrysanthemum, the size of copper coins, deep yellow. In the wilds of Shàngdǎng, people call it *jīnqiánhuā* (gold coin flower). The flowers are gathered in the seventh and eighth months and dried in the sun for twenty days. Now, in gardens near the capital, people cultivate *jīnqiánhuā*, whose flowers and leaves match the above description. It grows extremely vigorously, and this may well be *xuánfù*.

**Medical Formulas:**
- **Zhāng Zhòngjǐng’s** *Seven-Ingredient Xuánfù Dàizhě Decoction* treats *shānghán* (cold damage) after sweating and purging, with glomus and hardness below the heart and unrelieved belching.
- His *Three-Ingredient Xuánfù Decoction* is used for miscellaneous women’s disorders.
- **Hú Qià’s** *Xuánfùhuā Pill* is frequently employed for phlegm-rheum distending fullness in the flanks and similar conditions.

**Léi Gōng’s Note:**
After gathering, remove the inner floral receptacle, husk, calyx, and seeds. Steam the flowers from *sì* (9–11 a.m.) to *wǔ* (11 a.m.–1 p.m.), then dry in the sun for use.

**Wài Tái Mì Yào:**
- **Emergency Continuation of Severed Sinews:** Wash the *xuánfù* herb’s root clean, pound it, and apply an amount appropriate to the wound’s size. Change the dressing once or twice daily until healed.
- **Severed Sinews:** For completely severed sinews, pound the *xuánfù* root to extract its juice and drip it into the wound. Then apply the dregs as a poultice. After fifteen days, the severed sinews will rejoin. This formula comes from Sū Jǐngzhòng’s household servant, who used it effectively.

**Jīng Yàn Hòu Fāng:**
For wind stroke and accumulations: Wash *xuánfùhuā* to remove dust, pound it into powder, and refine with honey into pills the size of *wútóng* seeds. At bedtime, take five to ten pills with tea.

**Méi Shī Fāng:**
To stanch bleeding from metal-inflicted wounds, pound *xuánfùhuā* shoots and apply to the wound.

**Yǎn Yì:**
*Xuánfùhuā* has leaves like large chrysanthemum or *àihāo* (mugwort). In the seventh and eighth months, it bears flowers the size of *wútóng* seeds, pale yellow-green, dense and lush, round and drooping—quite unusual. Its fragrance surpasses chrysanthemum. It moves phlegm-water and dispels wind from the head and eyes. Its flavor is sweet, bitter, and acrid, making it a dispersing medicinal. The *xuánhuā* blooms in the fourth and fifth months and is a different species, not this flower. This has already been detailed in *Volume Eight*.

*End of Tújīng Yǎnyì Běn Cǎo, Volume Sixteen.*

*Tújīng Yǎnyì Běn Cǎo, Volume Seventeen*
Compiled by Kòu Zōngshì, *Tōngzhí Láng* of the Song Dynasty, Examiner of Medicinal Materials.

Assistant Professor of the Imperial Medical Bureau Xu Hong of the Song Dynasty, Collator of Medicinal Materials

*Herbal Section, Lower Grade (Upper Division)*
1. *Lílu* (Black False Hellebore, *Veratrum nigrum*)
**Jiezhou** (Jiezhou Prefecture)

Flavor: acrid, bitter; nature: cold, slightly cold; toxic.
Governs: *gu* poison, cough with counterflow qi, diarrhea and dysentery with intestinal afflux, head sores, scabies, pruritus, malign sores; kills all *gu* poisons; removes dead flesh; treats hiccup with counterflow, throat impediment with blockage, nasal polyps, *madao* (scrofula) and festering sores.
Not to be decocted.

Alternate names: *cōngrǎn*, *cōngtǎn* (pronounced *tǎn*), *shāncōng* (Mountain Scallion).
Grows in the mountain valleys of Mount Tai.
Harvest the root in the third month; dry in the shade.

*Huanglian* (Coptis) serves as its guiding herb.
Counteracts *xìxīn* (Asarum), *sháoyào* (Peony), and the Five *Shen* (Ginsengs).
Inimical to *dàhuáng* (Rhubarb).

Tao Yinju states: "Found everywhere in nearby regions. The root closely resembles scallion but is more hirsute. For use, only the root is taken; lightly roast it."

Yuxi et al. note: According to the *Illustrated Classic of the Shu Materia Medica*, "The leaves resemble those of *yùjīn* (Curcuma), *qínjiāo* (Gentian), and *ránghé* (Zingiber mioga). The root is like *lóngdǎn* (Gentian), with abundant hairs at the base of the stem. It sprouts in summer and withers in winter. Now found in all mountain valleys."

The root is harvested in the eighth month and dried in the shade.

Master Wu states: *Lilu* (Black False Hellebore) is also called *congkui*, *lilu*, or *huikui*.

Shennong and Leigong: pungent, toxic.
Qibo: salty, toxic.
Master Ji: highly toxic, extremely cold.
Bian Que: bitter, toxic.

Its leaves are large, its roots small and interconnected.

The *Fanzi* records: *Lilu* from Hedong is best when yellow-white.

The *Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states: *Lilu* serves as a guiding herb and is highly toxic. It governs counterflow qi, expels long-standing pus and blood, checks diarrhea, dispels malign wind, sores, scabies, ringworm, and baldness, and kills parasites.

The *Illustrated Classic* records: *Lilu* grows in the mountain valleys of Mount Tai; today, it is found in all prefectures of Shaanxi and the eastern and western regions of Shannan. The shoots are harvested in the third month. The leaves are green, resembling the newly sprouted heart of a palm or the plantain. The stem resembles scallion white, greenish-purple in color, five to six *cun* tall, wrapped in a black skin like that of a palm. Its flowers are flesh-red. The root resembles *machang* (Dioscorea) root, four to five *cun* long, yellow-white in color. The root is harvested in the second and third months and dried in the shade.

There are two varieties:
1. *Shuili lu* (Water Black False Hellebore), whose stems and leaves are largely identical, grows near water in mountain streams and rocky crevices. Its roots bear over a hundred fibrous strands and are unsuitable for medicinal use.
2. The variety used today is called *congbai lilu* (Scallion-White Black False Hellebore). Its roots have few fibrous strands, only twenty or thirty, and those growing on high mountains are superior. In Junzhou, it is also called *lucong* (Deer Scallion) by local custom.

This herb powerfully induces vomiting of wind-phlegm in the upper diaphragm, treats dark wind epilepsy, and childhood wheezing. A dose of one *qianbi* (scant spoonful) will cause violent vomiting. It is also used to clear the nasal passages, inducing sneezing. Ancient and modern materia medica texts claim it treats counterflow retching, though its efficacy in this regard remains unclear. The daylily is also called *lucong*, but the two are entirely distinct, and their therapeutic uses differ.

Leigong states: When harvesting, remove the root head and boil it in glutinous rice water from *si* (9–11 a.m.) to *wei* (1–3 p.m.). Remove, dry in the sun, and use.

From the *Holy Beneficence Formulary*: To treat black moles growing on the body or face, take five *liang* of *lilu* ash, add one large bowl of water, and strain the ash liquid into a copper vessel. Simmer in a double boiler until it thickens into a black paste. Prick the mole lightly with a needle and apply the paste. No more than three applications are needed for miraculous efficacy.

From the *Supplement to the Thousand Gold Prescriptions*: To treat toothache, insert powdered *lilu* into the tooth cavity. Do not swallow the saliva. Miraculously effective.

From the *Tested Later Formulary*: To treat wind-stroke with loss of speech, wheezing in the throat like a saw, and foaming at the mouth, take one *fen* of *lilu* and one *tiannanxing* (Jack-in-the-Pulpit). Remove the outer skin of the *tiannanxing* and hollow out a small pit on the navel side. Fill it with two *cuo* of aged vinegar, then heat all sides over a fire until yellow. Pound together, grind to an extremely fine powder, and mix with raw wheat flour to form pills the size of red beans. Take three pills per dose with warm wine.

From the *Hundred and One Prescriptions*: To treat jaundice, roast *lilu* in ash until slightly discolored, then pound into powder. Take half a *qianbi* with water to induce mild vomiting. No more than several doses are needed.

From the *Dumen Formulary*: To treat scabies and ringworm, finely pound *lilu* into powder and mix with raw oil for application.

From the *Concise Aid for the Multitudes*: To treat wind-stroke with loss of consciousness and clenched jaw, take one *liang* of *lilu*, remove the root head, bathe thoroughly in a strong decoction of *fangfeng* (Saposhnikovia), dry over a fire, chop finely, and stir-fry until slightly brown. Pound into powder. Take half a *qian* per dose with warm water, inducing vomiting of wind-phlegm as the sign of efficacy. If no vomiting occurs after the time it takes to walk three *li*, take another dose.

From the *Extension of the Materia Medica*: *Lilu* powder mixed with oil treats itchy scabies in horses.

---

**Gouwen** (Hook Vine)
Flavor: acrid. Nature: warm. Highly toxic.
Governs: metal-inflicted wounds, mammary abscesses, malign wind-stroke, counterflow cough with rising qi, edema, and kills demonic miasmas, *gu* toxins, breaks concretion accumulations, dispels painful impediment in the feet and knees, spasms of the four limbs, malign sores, scabies, and parasites. It also kills birds and beasts.
Also called *yegé* (Wild Kudzu). The variety that emits green smoke when broken is called *guhuo*. Extremely hot; not used in decoctions.
Grows in high mountain valleys and the eastern wilds of Kuaiji.

*Banxia* (Pinellia) serves as its guiding herb. It is incompatible with *huangqin* (Scutellaria).

Tao Hongjing states: The *Five Talismans* also refers to *gouwen* as *yegé*. It is said that when ingested, it hooks the throat and lips. Some say *wen* (吻) should be written as *wan* (挽), meaning it pulls and severs the intestines. Examining the matter, these are two distinct plants. *Yegé* is a root resembling peony, and the places where it grows are also toxic—birds cannot alight there. Today, people use it in ointments without issue. *Gouwen* is a separate herb with leaves like *huangjing* (Solomon’s Seal) but purple stems. It sends up a flower from its center, yellow in color. When young, it closely resembles *huangjing*, hence it is considered the lethal counterpart to *huangjing*. Some claim *gouwen* is *maogen* (Ranunculus), but the accounts here and later are contradictory and unclear.

There is another plant called *yinming*, red in color, that clings to trees and bears its seeds in clusters. It grows in mountain seas and is extremely toxic—ingestion can kill a person instantly.

The *Tang Materia Medica* notes: *Yegé* grows south of Guizhou, found in villages and alleys. The locals universally call it *gouwen*, also distinguishing the vine as *gouwen* and the root as *yegé*. It is a climbing plant. Those who mistakenly eat its leaves invariably die, yet sheep that consume its leaves grow fat—such is the way of mutual suppression in things. Just as mice grow fat on *badou* (Croton).

Tao’s claim that birds cannot alight where it grows is baseless. Freshly harvested *yegé* has white skin and yellow pith. Older roots resemble *digupi* (Lycium bark), while young roots resemble *hanfangji* (Stephania). The best specimens have broken skin and nodes. It closely resembles the root of *baihuateng* (White Flower Vine), and those who do not examine it closely may be misled. When freshly cut, it emits no dust. After a year, dust arises when broken. The root resembles *gouqi* (Lycium) with fine holes—when broken, dust emerges from these holes, just as when breaking *gouqi* roots.

The classics say the variety that emits green smoke when broken is called *guhuo* and is superior, but this is also an uninformed claim. True *huangjing* resembles raw *longdan* (Gentian), while *zeqi* (Sun Spurge) has two, four, or five opposite leaves. *Gouwen* is a climbing plant with leaves like persimmon. The *Bowu Zhi* states that *gouwen* leaves resemble *fukui* (Duckweed), and it is not of the *huangjing* family. *Maogen* is hairy, and *shilongrui* (Ranunculus) has no relation to *gouwen*.

Su Song et al. note: According to the *Shu Materia Medica*, *Qin gouwen* governs throat impediment, blockage in the throat, bodily transformation, and counterflow cough. Its leaves warm the center.
Also called *chuxin*.
Grows on cold rocky mountains.

Harvest in the second and eighth months.

Careful examination: *Gouwen*, also called *yegé* (Wild Kudzu), resembles *xuchangqing* (Cynanchum paniculatum), *chijian* (Gastrodia elata), and *guijian* (Euonymus alatus), all of which share the alternate name *guiduyou*. Yet these are distinct entities. Now, *gouwen* is also called *yegé*, which clearly indicates that *yegé* is a separate species. Moreover, many medicinal substances share names but differ in form—this is not unique.

According to Tao Hongjing’s annotation: *Gouwen* has leaves resembling *huangjing* (Polygonatum) but with purple stems, and a yellow flower emerging from the center. Su Song states: *Yegé* grows in Guizhou, with leaves like persimmon, and is lethal if ingested—this must be a different plant. He also notes: The seedling is called *gouwen*, while the root is called *yegé*, though this is not a universal rule. Today, market vendors identify *gouwen* by its leaves resembling *huangjing*.

The *Lei Gong Paozhi Fang* warns: Do not mistake *gouwen* for *huangjing*—*gouwen*’s leaves resemble *huangjing* but have two hooked hairs at the tip. Wu Pu records: *Qin gouwen*, also called *dugen* (Poison Root). Shen Nong: Pungent. Lei Gong: Toxic, lethal to humans. Grows in the mountains of Nanyue or Yizhou. Leaves like kudzu, red stems as thick as arrows, yellow roots; harvest in the first month. The *Ge Hong Fang* states: *Gouwen* resembles edible celery but grows where no other plants thrive; its stems are hairy, and accidental ingestion is fatal. The *Lingbiao Luyi* records: *Yegé* is a poisonous herb, commonly called *humananca* (Barbarian Vine). If mistakenly consumed, sheep’s blood can neutralize its toxicity. Chen Cangqi notes: Those who eat its leaves and drink cold water will die, as cold water activates its poison. Locals fatten people by feeding them *yegé*, then administer cold water to kill them. The corpse is hung from a tree, and the dripping fluid spawns mushrooms; these are collected as *junyao* (Fungus Medicine), more potent than *yegé*. *Humananca* has slender, glossy leaves.

Lei Gong states: When using *gouwen*, do not substitute *dijing* (Rehmannia), as its stems and leaves resemble *gouwen*. *Gouwen* effectively treats malignant sores and toxins on the body, while *dijing* is lethal. After harvesting, finely chop and pound it, then extract the natural juice for ointments—do not ingest it.

The *Yellow Emperor’s Questions to Tian Lao* asks: Among all things born of Heaven and Earth, is there anything that kills when eaten? Tian Lao replies: The essence of *Taiyin* is called *gouwen*; it must not be consumed, for it brings instant death.

The *Bowu Zhi* records: *Gouwen* is poisonous. *Guixin* (Cinnamon Heart), scallion leaves, or nasal mucus can counteract it.

*Shegan* (Belamcanda chinensis), pronounced *yegan*, is bitter, neutral, slightly warm, and toxic. It governs counterflow cough, rising qi, throat impediment, throat pain, inability to swallow, disperses bound qi, abdominal evil counterflow, intense heat from food and drink, and treats old blood lodged between the heart and spleen, coughing, spitting, and foul breath. It disperses chest heat but weakens the body with prolonged use. Alternate names: *wushan* (Black Fan), *wupu* (Black Cattail), *wusha* (Black Ribbon), *wubi* (Black Screen), and *caojiang* (Herbal Ginger). Grows in the river valleys and fields of Nanyang. Harvest the root on the third day of the third month and dry in the shade.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: *Shegan*—this refers to *yuanwei* (Iris tectorum), whose leaves resemble *shegan* but bear purple-green flowers without tall stems. Its root resembles *gaoliangjiang* (Galangal) but with white flesh, called *yuantou* (Kite’s Head). Tao’s account is entirely mistaken.

Su Song et al. note: The *Shu Materia Medica* states *shegan* is slightly cold. The *Illustrated Classic* records: It grows two to three *chi* tall, with yellow flowers and black seeds. The root has many fibers, with yellow-black skin and yellow-red flesh. Found everywhere today. Harvest the root in the second and eighth months, remove the skin, and dry in the sun.

Chen Cangqi states: *Shegan* and *yuanwei*—these two are often confused. In fact, there are three types of *shegan*. The Buddhist sutras mention *yegan diaojiu*, a vicious beast resembling a yellowish dog that eats humans. Guo Pu notes it can climb trees. Ruan Ji’s poem says: *Yegan* approaches the layered city—this refers to a tree. Today’s *shegan*, which grows tall, is the *shegan* of the *Materia Medica*, commonly cultivated as an ornamental called *fengyi* (Phoenix Wing). Its leaves resemble bird wings, and it blooms red flowers with red spots in autumn. *Yuanwei* is also widely cultivated, with shorter stems than *shegan*, resembling a kite’s tail, and bearing purple-green flowers in spring and summer.

Another annotation notes: This remains incorrect—*yegan* has yellow flowers and yellow roots. The *Yaoxing Lun* states: *Shegan*, an assistant herb with mild toxicity, treats throat closure where no water can enter, regulates menstrual blockage, dispels *zheng* qi (lingering pathogenic qi), and resolves stasis. The *Rihua Zi* records: It dissolves phlegm, breaks abdominal masses, relieves chest and diaphragm fullness, abdominal distension, wheezing, *xuanpi* (abdominal lumps), stimulates appetite, aids digestion, reduces swelling and toxins, calms the liver, and brightens the eyes. The root, resembling *gaoliangjiang* in size, is reddish-yellow, pale, and hard; harvest from the fifth to the eighth month.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: *Shegan* grows in the river valleys and fields of Nanyang and is found everywhere today, often cultivated in household gardens. The seedling emerges in spring, growing two to three *chi* tall. Its leaves resemble *manjiang* (Wild Ginger) but are narrower, longer, and spread horizontally like wings, hence the name *wusha* (Black Ribbon), referring to its leaves. A stem rises from the leaves, resembling *xuancao* (Daylily) but sturdier. It blooms in the sixth month with yellow-red flowers bearing fine patterns. In autumn, it forms seed pods with black seeds. The root has many fibers, with yellow-black skin and yellow-red flesh. Harvest the root on the third day of the third month and dry in the shade.

Tao Hongjing notes: Many remedies for toxic swellings use *yegan*. Today, *shegan* is pronounced *ye* (night). He also records: There is another *shegan* with similar appearance but white flowers and long stems, resembling a hunter’s staff.

Ruan Gong’s poem thus speaks of *shegan* standing by the layered city. This variety is not used medicinally.

Su Gong states: The *shegan* described here is actually *yuanwei* (Iris). Its leaves closely resemble *shegan*, but its flowers are purple-green, it does not send up a tall stem, and its root resembles *gaoliangjiang* (Galangal) but with white flesh—this root is called *yuantou* (Kite’s Head).

Further, *Xunzi* records: In the west, there is a tree called *shegan*. Its stem grows four *cun* long, thriving on high mountains and overlooking abysses of a hundred *ren*. Its stem is not inherently long; rather, its position makes it so. Yang Bao’s commentary notes: This should be a herb, yet it is called a tree—an error.

Observing the form of *shegan*, its stem is sparse and elongated, precisely resembling a long pole, whence its name derives. Tao [Hongjing] questioned the pronunciation *ye* (night), yet ancient characters often share homophonous readings. For instance, the Han official *yushi* (Imperial Censor) is also pronounced *ye*, without any distinct meaning.

Moreover, *shegan* often grows among mountain cliffs. Though its stem is slender, it resembles a woody stalk, which is why *Xunzi* calls it a tree, and Su [Gong] identifies Tao’s account as *yuanwei*. Yet *yuanwei*’s flowers are not white; the white-flowered variety is a distinct type of *shegan*, not *yuanwei*. *Yuanwei* spreads along the ground, its leaves broader and flatter than *shegan*. Su Gong’s description—flowers purple-green, root like *gaoliangjiang*—refers to this.

*The Divine Farmer’s Classic of Materia Medica* states: It grows in the valleys of Mount Jiuyi. Today, it is found everywhere, closely resembling *manjiang* (Wild Ginger). Harvest in the fifth month. Another account says: Collect the root in the ninth or tenth month and dry in the sun.

Lei Gong notes: For use, first soak in rice-water overnight, then strain and boil with bamboo leaves from noon to midnight. Strain again and dry in the sun before use.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For throat impediment, hold a slice of *shegan* in the mouth to absorb its juice for relief.

*The Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*: For childhood *shan*-hernia with stabbing pain and swelling, take fresh *shegan* juice orally, or administer in pill form.

*Zhang Yuxi* states: This is the *shegan* described in *Xunzi*—the so-called "tree of the west." The commentary mistakenly cites *The Divine Farmer’s Classic*, claiming *shegan* should not be classified as a tree. Yet the Five Phases are limited to water, fire, wood, metal, and earth. Thus, scholars consider herbs and trees as both "wood," lead and gold as both "metal," dung and soil as both "earth," ash and flame as both "fire," and water and ponds as both "water." By this logic, it is not the "beast of the burning house" from Buddhist scriptures, nor the "tree by the layered city" in Ruan Gong’s verse. Moreover, *The Divine Farmer’s Classic* also calls it *caojiang* (Grass Ginger), confirming its identity as a herb beyond doubt. Today, it is excellent for treating lung *qi* and throat impediment.

*Rihuazi* notes: It is similar in size to *gaoliangjiang* (Galangal), with a reddish-yellow hue. This description is accurate.

*Shehe* (Snake’s Tongue) is a miswritten form of *shehan* (Snake’s Containment).
**Xingzhou**
Flavor bitter, slightly cold, non-toxic. Governs fright epilepsy, cold-heat pathogenic *qi*, clears heat, treats metal wounds, abscesses, hemorrhoids, rodent fistula, malignant sores, head ulcers, expels heart and abdominal pathogenic *qi*, abdominal pain, damp impediment, nourishes the fetus, and benefits children. Another name: *shexian* (Snake’s Clasp). Grows in the mountain valleys of Yizhou. Harvest in the eighth month and dry in the shade.

Tao Hongjing notes: This is *shexian* (Snake’s Clasp). There are two varieties, both growing on rocks. The one with fine leaves and yellow flowers should be used. It is found everywhere, also growing in yellow earth, not exclusively on rocks.

*The Tang Materia Medica* commentary: The character *he* (合) is a miswriting of *han* (含). Tao [Hongjing] followed an erroneous text and should correct it to *han*. *Han* and *xian* share the same meaning, as seen in ancient *bencao* texts.

Chen Cangqi’s *Materia Medica* states: *Shehan* (Snake’s Containment) treats snakebites. Planting it also prevents snakes. Placing the herb in a snake’s mouth, even if it bites a person, will neutralize the venom.

Ma Zhi et al. note: *The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica from Shu* records: It grows on rocks and in damp lowlands. Its flowers are yellow-white, and households also cultivate it. Harvest the seedling in the fifth month for fresh use.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: *Shehan* (Snake’s Clasp), as a ministerial herb, is toxic. It treats cinnabar rashes and childhood cold-heat.

*Rihuazi* notes: *Shehan* (Snake’s Containment) treats injuries from snakes, insects, bees, and vipers, as well as red eyes, stanches bleeding, dispels wind rashes, and reduces abscesses. Both stem and leaves are used. Another name: *weishe* (Snake’s Might).

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Shehan* (Snake’s Containment) grows in the mountain valleys of Yizhou. Today, it is also found in nearby regions, thriving on soil, rocks, or damp lowlands. Households in Shu also cultivate it.

A single stem bears five or seven leaves. There are two varieties of this herb; the fine-leaved, yellow-flowered kind is considered superior. Harvest the root in the eighth month and dry it in the shade.

*The Ancient and Modern Record of Proven Formulas* treats red rashes: pound *shehan* grass until thoroughly pulped and apply as a poultice to heal. Red rashes arise when cold-dampness contends within the flesh, generating heat and forming red eruptions. They worsen in hot weather and subside in cold—such is their nature. This herb is universally employed in formulas for cinnabar toxins, sores, and swellings.

Below, under the entry for *nüqing* (Female Green), it states: *Shehan* root grows in Zhuya. Tao Yinju and Su Gong both noted that if this were truly *shehan* root, it should not grow exclusively in Zhuya. Some say it is *quepiao* (Sparrow’s Ladle), an alternate name for *luomo* (Metaplexis). Others claim the two share the same name due to their resemblance. Physicians rarely use it and seldom distinguish between them, so it is merely appended here.

Master Lei states: When preparing, do not use the variety with budding pointed leaves, called *jingming* grass (Herb of Imminent Fate). Its flavor is uniquely hollow—merely sour and astringent—and unfit for use. If mistakenly ingested, it induces unceasing blood vomiting; hasten to administer *zhishizi* (Gardenia) to counteract it. After harvesting, remove the root and stem, retaining only the leaves. Mince finely and dry in the sun, ensuring no exposure to fire.

*The Handbook of Emergency Remedies* treats metal-inflicted wounds: pound and apply as a poultice for excellent results. Another formula: for centipede stings, knead *shehan* grass and apply.

*The Doumen Formulary* treats postpartum diarrhea and dysentery: steep a handful of *xiaolongya* (Little Dragon’s Tooth) root in a strong decoction and administer—highly effective. This is *shehan*.

*The Master Who Embraces Simplicity* states: *Shehan* ointment reattaches severed fingers.

*The Record of Marvels* from the Jin Dynasty recounts: A peasant saw an injured snake, then observed another snake place a herb upon the wound. After some time, the wounded snake departed. The peasant took the herb to treat sores, finding it invariably effective. Thus, it was named *shehan* grass.

**Changshan (Dichroa Root)**
Flavor: bitter, acrid.
Nature: cold, slightly cold. Toxic.
Governs: cold-damage with alternating chills and fever, heat effusion, warm malaria, demonic toxins, phlegm binding in the chest, vomiting with counterflow, and treats demonic *gu* toxins, intermittent chills, watery distension, and scrofula.
Another name: *hucao* (Alternating Grass).
Grows in the river valleys of Yizhou and Hanzhong.
Harvest the root in the eighth month and dry in the shade.
Averse to *yuzha* (Black Cardamom).

Tao Yinju notes: It comes from Yidu and Jianping.

The fine, solid, yellow variety is called "Rooster-Bone Changshan," and is considered the most effective.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: Changshan has leaves resembling tea but narrower and longer, with a round stem and opposite leaves. White flowers bloom in the third month, with green calyces. Fruits form in the fifth month, green and round, with three seeds per capsule. It grows in mountain valleys, reaching no more than three to four *chi* in height.

Ma Zhi et al. note: According to the *Illustrated Classic of the Shu Materia Medica*, the plant grows three to four *chi* tall, with roots resembling those of *Vitex*, yellow and fissured. It is now found in Jinzhou, Fangzhou, and Liangzhou. Leaves are harvested in the fifth and sixth months and are called *shuqi*.
