The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: Changshan is averse to scallions. Its flavor is bitter and slightly toxic. It treats various malarial disorders, induces vomiting of phlegm and saliva, and dispels alternating chills and fever. When boiled with wheat and bamboo leaves, it is particularly effective for children. For malaria with intermittent chills and fever, excessive dosage should be avoided, as it may cause severe vomiting. It also treats goiters and tumors of the neck.

Xiao Bing notes: Combined with licorice, it induces vomiting for malaria.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: It is averse to *song* greens.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: Details are provided under the *shuqi* entry.

Lei Gong notes: For use, employ the stems and leaves in spring, and all parts in summer, autumn, and winter. Soak in wine overnight, then strain and dry in the sun. Roast and grind before use, but administer sparingly. Avoid use in the elderly or those with chronic illnesses.

The *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library* prescribes: For malaria, steep three *liang* of Changshan in three *sheng* of fermented water overnight, then decoct to one *sheng*. Take the entire dose before an attack to induce mild vomiting.

The *Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies* prescribes: For malarial disorders, grind three *liang* of Changshan into powder, mix with egg white, and form into pellets the size of *wutong* seeds. Take thirty pellets on an empty stomach.

The *Amplification of Materia Medica* states: Changshan is the root of *shuqi*. It also treats malaria and induces vomiting of phlegm, with the "rooster-bone" variety being the finest.

*Shuqi*
- Haizhou
- Mingzhou
- Mingzhou

Flavor: pungent. Nature: neutral, slightly warm. Toxic. Governs malaria and cough with counterflow cold and heat, abdominal concretions and hardness, glomus and bind, accumulations and gatherings, pathogenic qi, *gu* poison, demonic infestation, and treats pathogenic qi in the chest, expelling it through vomiting. Grows in riverside mountains and valleys of Jianglin and in Shu and Hanzhong. It is the seedling of Changshan. Harvest the leaves in the fifth month and dry in the shade. Trichosanthes root is its guiding herb; it is incompatible with *guanzhong*.

Tao Yinju states: This is the seedling of Changshan, yet its place of origin differs. Jianglin Mountain is the name of a mountain in Yizhou’s Jiangyang, so it is from the same region. The locals gather it and twist it into coils; when dried at the proper time, it is of the finest quality.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: When this herb is sun-dried until slightly wilted, it may be bundled to dry, turning a greenish-white color and becoming usable. If dried in the shade, it blackens, rots, and spoils. Tao [Hongjing] speaks of it being coiled—this refers to *tu* cakes, not *shuqi*.

Yu Xi et al. note: The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica of Shu* states: Harvest in the fifth month and sun-dry.

The *Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states: *Shuqi* is a guiding herb, fears *tuowu*, has a bitter flavor, and is slightly toxic. It is the seedling of Changshan. It effectively governs miasmic *gui*-malaria of long duration, dispels cold-heat malaria, and treats warm malaria with alternating cold and heat. It must not be taken in excess, as it causes vomiting and counterflow. It governs hardened concretions, drains fat-qi, and disperses accumulations and gatherings.

Xiao Bing states: Platycodon root is its guiding herb.

The *Ri Hua Zi Materia Medica* states: *Shuqi* treats concretions and conglomerations. It is also called "chicken-dropping herb" and "duck-dropping herb."

Li Hanguang states: It is the stem of Changshan. Harvest in the eighth or ninth month.

*The Illustrated Classic of the Materia Medica* states: *Shuqi* grows in the river valleys and mountain streams of Jianglin Mountain and in Shu and Han; it is the seedling of Changshan. Changshan grows in the mountain valleys of Yizhou and in Hanzhong; it is the root of *Shuqi*. Jianglin Mountain is the name of a mountain in Jiangyang of Yizhou, meaning they are in the same location. Today, it is also found in the prefectures of Jingxi, Huai, Zhe, and Hunan. Its leaves resemble those of tea but are longer, growing in opposite pairs, with a round stem and nodes. In the third month, it produces red flowers with green calyces. In the fifth month, it bears round green fruit, with three seeds per capsule. The seedling grows no taller than three or four *chi*. Its root resembles that of the chaste tree, yellow in color. The variety from Haizhou has leaves like those of the peach, flowers in the eighth month that are red and white, and green seeds resembling those of the *shanlian* but smaller. The leaves are harvested in the fifth month, and the root in the eighth month, then dried in the shade. These two are the most essential medicines for treating malaria. Zhang Zhongjing’s *Shuqi Powder* uses equal parts *shuqi*, mica, and dragon bone, ground into powder. At the onset of an attack, the patient takes half a *qian* mixed with fermented water. For warm malaria, add half a *fen* of *shuqi*, taking one *qianbi* at the time of the attack. Today, on Tiantai Mountain, there grows a plant called *tu changshan* ("local Changshan"), whose seedling and leaves are extremely sweet. People use it as a fragrant beverage, its taste like honey, and it is also called *mixiangcao* ("honey-fragrance herb"). Its nature is also cooling, and drinking it benefits people, but it is not the same as this Changshan.

Master Lei states: After harvesting, include both root and seedling. When using, remove the root and take the stem and leaves together, mixing them with four *liang* of finely chopped licorice. Moisten with water and steam together. When ready, remove the licorice and take five *liang* of *shuqi*, finely chop it, mix evenly with licorice water, and steam again before use. Do not consume bamboo shoots.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: *Shuqi* is the seedling of Changshan. For treating malaria, it often induces vomiting. No other particular strengths have been observed.

Concerning this herb, I foresee that over time, people may hold differing opinions, and thus I state this in advance. The rest follows the *Classic*.

**Gansui** (*Kansui*, *Euphorbia kansui*)
**Jiangning Prefecture**
Flavor: bitter, sweet; Nature: cold, greatly cold; Toxic.
Governs: abdominal *shan*-lumbar hernias, abdominal fullness, facial and orbital edema, retained fluids (*yin*), chronic food stagnation; breaks concretions, hard accumulations, and gatherings; facilitates the water and grain pathways; drains the five types of water; disperses retained heat in the bladder; resolves *pi*-obstruction in the skin, and swelling due to hot qi.

Alternative names: *gangao*, *linggao*, *lingze*, *zhutian*.
Grows in the river valleys of Zhongshan. Harvest the root in the second month; dry in the shade.

*Guadi* (melon pedicel) serves as its guiding herb. Incompatible with *yuanzhi* (polygala); antagonizes *gancao* (licorice).

Tao Yinju states: Zhongshan is in Daijun. The earliest records describe it as coming from Mount Tai, but the variety now used in Jiangdong, sourced from Jingkou, differs greatly. The red-skinned variety is superior. The white-skinned variety, also found in the capital, is called *caogansui* ("herb gansui"), which is markedly inferior—here, *cao* refers not to the herbaceous nature of the plant but to its spurious (*yan*, lit. "wild goose") falsity.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: The so-called *caogansui* is in fact *zaoxiu* (*Paris polyphylla*), which has entirely different therapeutic properties. True gansui’s seedling resembles *zeqi* (*Euphorbia helioscopia*). The gansui seedling has a single stem, with six or seven leaves at its apex, resembling those of *bima* (castor bean) or *guijiu* (*Podophyllum*). Consuming a *sheng* of it raw cannot induce purgation, but it powerfully treats abscesses, deep-rooted sores, and snakebite. Moreover, true gansui is characterized by its red skin and white flesh, forming a string of pearls, and is heavy when solid. There is no white-skinned variety; white-skinned specimens are *zaoxiu*, commonly called *chongtai* ("double terrace").

Xiao Yi et al. note: The *Drug Properties Treatise* states that Jing gansui, bitter in flavor, can drain the twelve types of water swelling, treat hardness and fullness in the heart and abdomen, promote water discharge, expel phlegm-water, and resolve skin and muscle edema.

*Rihuazi* states: The finest comes from Jingxi, followed by those from Bian, Cang, and Wu. Its form resembles licorice with bark intact, and it is cut node by node.

The *Illustrated Classic* says: Gansui grows in the river valleys of Zhongshan. Today, it is also found in Shaanxi and Jiangdong. Some say the best comes from Jingxi, with those from Bian, Cang, and Wu being secondary. Its seedling resembles *zeqi*, with a short, small stem and juicy leaves. The root has red skin and white flesh, forming a string of pearls, and also resembles licorice with bark intact. Harvest the root in the second month, cut it at the nodes, and dry in the shade. The solid and heavy specimens are superior.

There is also a type called *caogansui*, with a single stem and six or seven leaves at its apex, resembling those of *bima* or *guijiu*. It is markedly inferior in use, and consuming a *sheng* of it raw cannot induce purgation. The Tang annotation states that *caogansui* is *zaoxiu*. *Zaoxiu* has its own entry. Ancient formulas also use it alone to drain water.

The *Minor Essentials* treats pregnancy with lower abdominal fullness, difficulty in urination and defecation, and dyspnea. If symptoms persist after administering *Zhuling Powder*, use *Gansui Powder* to induce purgation: two *liang* of red-skinned gansui from Mount Tai, pounded and sifted, mixed with two *liang* of white honey to form pills the size of soybeans. If one feels vexation below the heart and slight purgation occurs, take once daily. After purgation, resume *Zhuling Powder*. If no purgation occurs, take twice daily, gradually increasing the dose to half a *qianbi*, with slight purgation as the measure. Administer the powder in between.

(*Zhuling Powder* is found under the *zhuling* entry.)

Master Lei states: After harvesting, remove the stem and finely chop the root on a locust wood block. Soak it in a mixture of fresh licorice decoction and natural juice of *xiaojini* (*Adenophora trachelioides*) for three days, until the water turns as dark as ink. Strain it out, then rinse six or seven times with east-flowing water until the water runs clear. Strain again, dry in an earthenware vessel until brittle, and then use.

The *Handbook of Emergency Remedies* treats sudden swelling and fullness, with the entire body and face greatly enlarged: powder one *fen* of gansui, divide one pig kidney into seven pieces, insert the gansui powder into each, and roast over fire until cooked. Consume four or five pieces; one will feel borborygmi in the abdomen and flanks, and urination will become unobstructed.

*Yang’s Obstetrics and Pediatrics* treats abdominal fullness, difficulty in urination and defecation, and dyspnea: divide two *fen* of gansui into five doses, and take with boiled water. If one feels vexation below the heart and slight purgation occurs, take once daily.

The *Extension of the Materia Medica* states: Today, only the string-of-pearls variety of gansui is used, though the *Classic* does not mention it. This herb specializes in moving water and breaking through blockages; its use in formulas must be carefully considered.

**Bailian** (*Ampelopsis japonica*)
**Chuzhou**
Flavor: bitter, sweet; Nature: neutral, slightly cold; Non-toxic.
Governs: abscesses, deep-rooted sores, and ulcers; disperses bound qi; relieves pain; clears heat; treats red eyes; resolves infantile fright epilepsy, warm malaria, swelling and pain in the female genitalia, and red and white vaginal discharge; neutralizes fire toxin.

Also called *tuhu* (Hare’s Kernel), *baicao* (White Herb), *baigen* (White Root), and *Kunlun*. Grows in mountain valleys. Harvest the root in the second and eighth months, and dry in the sun. *Daizhe* (hematite) serves as its guiding herb.

Tao Hongjing states: It is found everywhere in nearby regions. It grows as a vine, with roots resembling *baizhi* (Angelica dahurica). Slice the roots and thread them with bamboo to dry in the sun. Fresh roots, when pounded and applied as a poultice, are also effective for abscesses.

The *Tang Materia Medica* notes: Its roots resemble *tianmendong* (Asparagus cochinchinensis), with ten or so roots growing from a single plant. The skin is reddish-black, and the flesh is white, like *shaoyao* (peony), and quite unlike *baizhi*.

Ma Zhi et al. quote the *Illustrated Classic of the Materia Medica of Shu*: It grows as a vine, with five leaves at the tips of its branches, and is found everywhere today.

The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: *Bailian* is a guiding herb that neutralizes fire toxin. Its flavor is bitter, its nature neutral, and it is toxic. It is incompatible with *wutou* (aconite). It governs qi congestion and swelling. When ground with *chixiaodou* (adzuki bean) and *wangcao* (lithospermum) into a powder and mixed with egg white, it can be applied to all types of toxic swellings. It treats facial blisters. Its seeds govern warm malaria, alternating chills and fever, and bound qi with heat and swelling.

*Ri Huazi* states: It checks fright and madness, treats carbuncles on the back, scrofula, intestinal wind, hemorrhoids and fistulas, sword and arrow wounds, traumatic injuries, warm and heat-type malaria, bloody dysentery, scalds and burns, promotes flesh regeneration, and relieves pain.

The *Illustrated Classic* says: *Bailian* grows in the mountain valleys of Hengshan. Today, it is found in the Jiang-Huai prefectures, as well as in Jing, Xiang, Huai, Meng, Shang, and Qi. The seedling emerges in the second month, often growing as a vine in forests with reddish stems and leaves like small mulberry. It blooms in the fifth month and bears fruit in the seventh. The roots resemble chicken or duck eggs, with three to five clustered together. The skin is reddish-black, and the flesh is white. Harvest the roots in the second and eighth months, slice them, and dry in the sun. Today, physicians frequently use it in formulas for wind disorders, metal-inflicted wounds, and facial treatments. In Haozhou, there is a variety called *chilian* (Red *Lian*), whose functions are identical to *bailian*, and whose flowers and fruits are also similar, except that both its exterior and interior are red.

The *Sagely Benefit Formulas* states: For *ding* sores, mix *bailian* powder with water and apply to the sore.

The *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library* records: The *Emergency Formulas* treats severe burns from fire or boiling water with *bailian* powder applied topically.

The *Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies* states: For carbuncles on the back, *bailian* powder is also effective when applied.

The *Extension of the Materia Medica* says: *Bailian* and *bai ji* (Bletilla striata) are rarely used in ancient or modern internal elixir formulas but appear frequently in formulas for healing sores. The two are often used together.

*Qingxiangzi* (Celosia seeds)

In Chuzhou, *qingxiangzi* (Celosia seeds) is bitter in taste, slightly cold, and non-toxic. It governs pathogenic qi, heat in the skin, wind-itching over the body, kills the three worms, and treats malign sores, scabies, lice, erosive sores, and genital or anal ulcers. Its seeds are called *caojueming* (herbal *jueming*) and treat cyanotic lips and mouth. It is also known as *caohao* or *qihao*. It grows in plains and along roadsides. The stems and leaves are collected in the third month and dried in the shade. The seeds are gathered in the fifth and sixth months.

Tao Hongjing states: It grows everywhere. Its flowers resemble those of wheat, and its seeds are very fine. Later, there was another *caohao*, which the *Alternative Text* also calls *caogao*. Its therapeutic effects are remarkably similar, and their forms and names are extremely alike, leading to confusion, though they are in fact two distinct species.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This herb grows to about a foot in height, with fine, soft leaves. Its flowers are purplish-white, and its seeds form pods. The seeds are black, flat, and glossy, resembling *xian* seeds but larger. It grows in low, damp areas and is collected in the fourth and fifth months. People in Jing and Xiang call it *Kunlun grass*. Pounded into juice and taken alone, it powerfully treats warm epidemics and *gan* disorders.

Ma Zhi et al. note: The *Illustrated Classic of the Materia Medica of Shu* states: Its leaves are fine, soft, and long, and it also creeps. It now grows in low, damp areas everywhere.

The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: *Qingxiangzi*, also called *caogao*, is bitter in taste, neutral, and non-toxic. It can treat heat toxins in the liver attacking the eyes, red obstructions, green blindness, and nebula swelling. It governs malign sores, scabies, itching, and genital or anal worm ulcers.

Xiao Bing states: It is now primarily used to treat the eyes, as in the *Qingxiangzi Pill*. There is also a variety with yellow flowers called *taozhushu*, which resembles it in appearance.

The *Ri Hua Zi Materia Medica* states: It treats pathogenic qi in the five viscera, augments brain marrow, brightens the ears and eyes, calms the liver, strengthens sinews and bones, and dispels wind, cold, and damp impediment. Its shoots stanch bleeding from metal-inflicted wounds.

The *Illustrated Classic* says: *Qingxiangzi* grows along roadsides in plains. Today, it is also found near roads in Jiang and Huai prefectures. Green shoots emerge in the second month, growing to three or four feet in height. Its leaves are broad like willow leaves but fine and soft, and its stems resemble those of mugwort, being greenish-red. Flowers bloom in the sixth and seventh months, red above and white below. The seeds are black, glossy, and flat, resembling those of *langdang*. Its roots resemble mugwort roots but are white, growing straight down as a single stem. The seeds are collected in the sixth and eighth months. There is also a variety with yellow flowers called *taozhushu*, which resembles it in appearance but is likely unusable.

Lei Gong states: When using it, do not mistake it for *simingzi* or *shuxizi*, as these two closely resemble *qingxiangzi* but differ in taste. *Simingzi* is acrid in taste and produces saliva when decocted. Before use, first heat an iron mortar and pestle, then pound it alone.

The *Extensive Benefit Formulas* states: To treat unceasing nosebleed, instill three *ge* of *qingxiangzi* juice into the nostrils.

The *Records of the Three Kingdoms* states: In the *Wei Lue*, it is recorded that during the *Chuping* era, there was a Master Green Ox who regularly consumed *qingxiangzi*. Though he appeared to be fifty or sixty years old, some who recognized him claimed he was over a hundred.

The *Extension of the Materia Medica* says: The *Classic* does not mention *qingxiangzi* for treating the eyes, but the *Drug Properties Treatise* first records this use. It can treat heat toxins in the liver attacking the eyes, red obstructions, and green blindness. Xiao Bing also states it governs the eyes. The *Ri Hua Zi* says it augments brain marrow, brightens the ears and eyes, and calms the liver. Today, people often use it to treat eye disorders, though this does not align with the *Classic*’s intent.

*Guan* (heron)
Pronounced *huan*, *jun* pronounced *jun*
Salty and sweet in taste, neutral and slightly warm, slightly toxic. It governs heart pain, warms the center, expels long worms, *bai* worms, *nao* worms, and *hui* worms, neutralizes venomous stings, treats concretions and conglomerations, various worms, deep-rooted ulcers, and *wo* sores. It expels roundworms and tapeworms and treats malign sores. It is also called *guanlu*. It grows in the marshes of the Eastern Sea and in Zhangwu of the Bohai region.

Gathered in the eighth month, dried in the shade. Works well with wine; incompatible with chicken eggs.

Tao Yinju states: It comes from the north, though this variety is not found here. Its form resembles a mushroom, said to be transformed from heron droppings, hence also called *guan jun* (heron mushroom). Ground into powder and taken with pork stew, it can expel roundworms.

The *Tang Ben* annotation says: *Guan jun* now grows in the reed marshes of Bohai’s saline-alkaline lands, naturally occurring as a mushroom, not transformed from heron droppings. This mushroom is white, light, and hollow, with a uniform appearance inside and out, unlike other mushrooms. It effectively treats roundworms.

Yu Xiet al. note: The *Shu Ben Tu Jing* states it is now found in Cangzhou. It appears when autumn rains arrive on time and is scarce during droughts or prolonged rains. Sun-dried specimens are best.

The *Yaoxing Lun* says: *Guan jun* is bitter in taste. It dispels cold pain in the abdomen and treats white scalp ringworm.

The *Shiliao* states: Mushrooms trigger wind in the five viscera, obstruct the meridians, aggravate hemorrhoids, cause excessive drowsiness, and weaken the back and limbs. Moreover, there are several types of mushrooms—those growing on pagoda trees are best. Those in the wild may be toxic and fatal. They also often induce cold qi.

The *Waitai Miyao* records: For roundworms attacking the heart like stabbing pain with clear fluid vomiting, grind one *liang* of *guanlu* into powder and mix with mutton stew, taking one dose daily for best results.

The *Jinkui Yuhan* states: Mushrooms that curl upward or are red should not be eaten. Wood ear mushrooms that are green or grow upward should also not be eaten.

*Bai Ji* (from Xingzhou)

White Orchid (Bai Ji)

Flavor: bitter, acrid; nature: neutral, slightly cold; non-toxic.
Governs: abscesses, malignant sores, necrotic ulcers, yin lesions with dead flesh, pathogenic qi in the stomach, predatory winds and demonic strikes, flaccid paralysis with loss of control, and eliminates white scalp ringworm and scabies mites.
Alternate names: Sweet Root, Continuous Grass.
Grows in mountain valleys of the northern ranges, as well as in Yuanju and Yueshan.
Acts as an envoy for fluorite; incompatible with selenite; antagonized by plum and apricot kernels.

Tao Hongjing states: Found everywhere in nearby regions. Its leaves resemble those of *Pollia japonica*, and its roots are shaped like water caltrop grains with hairy nodes. Rarely used in formulas, it can be made into paste.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: When mountain villagers suffer from chapped hands and feet, chewing and applying it proves effective.

Ma Zhi et al. note: The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica of Shu* states: Its leaves resemble those of young *Trachycarpus fortunei* and *Veratrum nigrum*. A single stalk emerges from the stem’s end, bearing purple flowers in the fourth month. Its fruit ripens in the seventh month, turning yellow-black, and withers in winter. The root resembles water caltrop, triangular, white, with buds at the angles. Currently produced in Shenzhou. Harvest the root in the second and eighth months.

Wu Pu states:
- Shennong: bitter.
- The Yellow Emperor: acrid.
- The Ji Clan: greatly cold.
- Leigong: acrid, non-toxic.
Its stems and leaves resemble those of ginger and *Veratrum nigrum*, blooming in the tenth month with upright, purple-red flowers. The white roots are connected; harvest in the second, eighth, and ninth months.

The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: White Orchid serves as an envoy. It resolves stagnant heat, treats yin atrophy, facial acne, and smooths the skin.

The *Ri Hua Zi* states: Flavor sweet and acrid. Arrests fright-induced pathogenic blood, epilepsy, red eyes with obstructions, carbuncles, scrofula, intestinal wind and hemorrhoids, arrow and blade wounds, traumatic injuries, warm malaria, bloody dysentery, burns and scalds, promotes flesh regeneration, relieves pain, and treats wind impediment.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: White Orchid grows in mountain valleys of the northern ranges, as well as in Yuanju and Yueshan. Today, it is found in Jianghuai, He, Shaan, Han, and Qian prefectures, thriving on rocky mountains. In spring, it sprouts, growing about a foot tall. Resembling *Trachycarpus fortunei* and *Veratrum nigrum*, a single stalk emerges from the stem’s end, with leaves as wide as two fingers and green. Purple flowers bloom in summer, and by the seventh month, the fruit ripens to a yellow-black hue. The leaves wither in winter. The root resembles water caltrop grains, triangular and white, with buds at the angles. Harvest the root in the second and seventh months. Modern physicians frequently use it in formulas for sword wounds and abscesses.

---

Knoxia Root (Da Ji)

Flavor: bitter, sweet; nature: cold, greatly cold; slightly toxic.
Governs: gu poison, twelve types of water swelling, abdominal fullness with acute pain and accumulations, wind-strike with skin pain, vomiting and counterflow, neck and axillary abscesses, headaches, induces sweating, and promotes bowel and bladder movement.
Alternate name: Qiong Ju.
Grows in Changshan. Harvest the root in the twelfth month and dry in the shade. Antagonistic to licorice.

Tao Hongjing states: Found everywhere in nearby regions, extremely common.

Ma Zhi et al. note: The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: Antagonized by sweet flag, reed grass, and rat droppings.
The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica of Shu* states: The seedling resembles *Euphorbia kansui* but is taller, with leaves exuding white sap and yellow flowers. The root resembles slender *Sophora flavescens*, with yellow-black skin and yellow-white flesh. Harvest the seedling in the fifth month and the root in the second and eighth months.

The *Erya* states: *Qiao* is *Qiong Ju*. The annotation reads: The *materia medica* refers to knoxia root.

The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: Knoxia Root serves as an envoy, antagonistic to *Daphne genkwa* and seaweed. Its toxicity is resolved by sweet flag. Flavor bitter and acrid, greatly toxic. Breaks up old and new accumulations, drains stagnant blood and concretions, abdominal rumbling, unblocks menstruation, effectively treats static blood, and can induce abortion.

The *Ri Hua Zi* states: Adzuki bean serves as its envoy; incompatible with *Dioscorea opposita*. A purgative for toxic substances, it drains epidemic jaundice and warm malaria, and breaks up abdominal masses.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: Knoxia Root is the root of *Euphorbia helioscopia*. Grows in Changshan; now found everywhere in nearby regions. In spring, red shoots emerge, gradually forming clusters about a foot tall.

The leaves resemble small clusters of young willow. In the third and fourth months, it blooms with yellow-purple flowers, round like apricot blossoms or *Fructus Ulmi Macrocarpae*. The root resembles slender *Radix Sophorae Flavescentis*, with yellow-black skin and yellow-white flesh. The root is harvested in autumn and winter, then dried in the shade. Those from Huaidian have round stems, growing three to four *chi* tall, with yellow flowers and leaves resembling lily shoots at the heart. Those growing south of the Yangtze have leaves like *Radix Paeoniae Alba*. Physicians use it to treat urticaria and wind-toxin-induced leg swelling, boiling it in water for hot compresses twice daily; recovery occurs within three days.

Li Jiang’s *Handbook of the Ministry of War* states it treats water diseases, regardless of duration or severity—even with adverse pulses, it remains effective. Take one large *liang* each of Knoxia Root, *Radix Angelicae Sinensis*, and tangerine peel, cut them, and decoct in two large *sheng* of water until reduced to seven *fen*. Drink the entire dose at once, inducing a purge of two to three *dou*; do not be alarmed. In severe cases, a second dose suffices. Avoid toxic foods for one year; after the water descends, take further doses to prevent recurrence. This formula was transmitted by Zhang Shangke.

Master Lei states: Do not use those growing as epiphytes. If cold diarrhea or uncontrolled qi occurs after ingestion, decoct *Radix Adenophorae* to resolve it. After harvesting, finely chop the root on a locust-wood block, mix with finely chopped *Colocasia* leaves, and steam from *si* (9–11 AM) to *shen* (3–5 PM). Remove the *Colocasia* leaves and dry in the sun before use.

The *Tai Shang Ba Di Xuan Bian Jing* states: Knoxia Root must purge.

*Euphorbia helioscopia*
Ji Province

Flavor bitter and pungent, slightly cold, non-toxic. Governs skin heat, abdominal water-qi, swelling of the four limbs and face, insufficiency of male yin qi, frees the large and small intestines, brightens the eyes, and lightens the body.

Also called "lacquer stem," it is the seedling of *Euphorbia helioscopia*. Grows in the rivers and marshes of Mount Tai. Harvest stems and leaves on the third day of the third month or the seventh day of the seventh month, and dry in the shade. *Phaseolus angularis* (adzuki bean) serves as its assistant; incompatible with *Dioscorea* (shu yu).

Tao Yinju states: This is the seedling of *Euphorbia helioscopia*. When fresh, plucking its leaves yields a sap, hence the name "marsh lacquer"; it can also corrode human flesh.

Yu Xi et al. note: According to the *Illustrated Classic of the Shu Materia Medica*, harvest in the fifth month and dry in the sun for use.

The *Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states: *Zeqi* (marsh lacquer) serves as an assistant. It treats heat in the skin and muscles and frees the urine.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: Cold, slightly toxic. Stops malaria, dissolves phlegm, and reduces heat. This is the flower of *Euphorbia helioscopia*, found in rivers and marshes. Its stems are slender, with yellow flowers and leaves resembling tender greens. Harvest in the fourth or fifth month.

The *Illustrated Classic* says: *Zeqi* is the seedling of *Euphorbia helioscopia*. It grows in the rivers and marshes of Mount Tai, and is now also found in Jizhou, Dingzhou, Mingzhou, and nearby regions. When fresh, plucking its leaves yields a white sap that can corrode flesh, hence its name.

However, Zhang Zhongjing’s treatment for lung cough with rising qi and a sunken pulse uses three *jin* of *zeqi*, boiled in five *dou* of east-flowing water until reduced to one *dou* and five *sheng*. Then, half a *sheng* of *Rhizoma Pinelliae* (ban xia), five *liang* each of *Radix et Rhizoma Bistortae* (zi shen), fresh ginger, and *Radix et Rhizoma Cynanchi Stauntonii* (bai qian), and three *liang* each of licorice, *Radix Scutellariae* (huang qin), ginseng, and cassia are chopped and added to the *zeqi* decoction, then simmered to five *sheng*. Take five *ge* per dose, three times daily, finishing the entire dose by night.

The *Tang Materia Medica Supplement* states: Slightly toxic.

**Zeqi** expels water and governs *gu* toxins.

*The Sagacious Benefit Formulas* states: For treating the ten types of water qi, take ten *jin* of *zeqi*. In summer, gather its stems and tender leaves, steep in one *dou* of water, and grind to extract approximately two *dou* of juice. Simmer slowly in a silver pot over low heat until it thickens to a syrup, then stop. Store in a ceramic vessel. Take one teaspoon daily on an empty stomach, mixed with warm wine, until cured.

**Yinyu** (from Bingzhou)
Flavor: bitter. Nature: warm, slightly warm. Slightly toxic.
Governs: evil qi of the five viscera, cold in the heart and abdomen, emaciation with malaria-like symptoms, periodic onset, wind-damp impediment pain in all joints. Treats chronic wind-damp, wandering through the four limbs, and weak feet.
Alternate names: *yuanhua*, *beigong*.
Grows in the mountain valleys of Mount Tai. Leaves are gathered on the third day of the third month and dried in the shade.

Tao Hongjing notes: *Yinyu* grows in Pengcheng, and is also found in nearby regions. Its stems and leaves resemble *mangcao* but are finer and softer. All parts used include the slender stems. It is rarely employed in formulas, used chiefly to prepare medicinal wines for wind disorders.

Ma Zhi et al. quote *The Illustrated Classic of the Shu Materia Medica*: The plant grows three to four *chi* tall, with leaves resembling those of pomegranate but shorter and thicker, and red stems. Nowadays, its leaves resemble those of *shinan*. Stems and leaves are gathered in the third and fourth months and dried in the sun.

*The Drug Properties Treatise* states: *Yinyu* is bitter and acrid, slightly toxic. It treats alternating chills and fever in the five viscera resembling malaria, wind impediment in all joints, spasms, cramps, and pain. It cures weak feet due to toxic wind in men and women, and intermittent warm malaria.

*Ri Huazi* states: It treats all cold-wind disorders, weakness of sinews and bones, and emaciation. For medicinal use, it is prepared by roasting. It grows in Haiyan, resembling *shinan*—a tree with thick leaves, gathered in the fifth, sixth, and seventh months.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Yinyu* grows in the mountain valleys of Mount Tai and is now also found in Yongzhou, Bingzhou, Huazhou, and Hangzhou. The plant sprouts in spring, growing three to four *chi* tall, with red leaves and stems resembling pomegranate but shorter and thicker, or like *shinan* leaves. It blooms with fine white flowers in the fourth month and bears fruit in the fifth. Leaves and slender stems are gathered in the third, fourth, and seventh months and dried in the shade—or, some say, in the sun.

Hu Qia’s treatment for predatory wind, withered impediment of the hands and feet, and spasms of the four limbs uses *yinyu* wine. The formula: one *liang* each of *yinyu*, *Radix Aconiti Lateralis* (fu zi), *Radix Aconiti* (tian xiong), *Radix Aconiti* (wu tou), *Radix Gentianae Macrophyllae* (qin jiao), *Radix Clematidis* (nü wei), *Radix Saposhnikoviae* (fang feng), *Radix Stephaniae Tetrandrae* (fang ji), *Flos Rhododendri Mollis* (zhi zhu), *Folium Photiniae* (shi nan), *Herba Asari* (xi xin), and *Cortex Cinnamomi* (gui xin)—twelve ingredients in total, chopped and placed in a silk bag, steeped in one *dou* of clear wine. In winter, steep for seven days; in summer, three days; in spring and autumn, five days. When ready, begin with one *ge* per dose, three times daily, gradually increasing until mild numbness occurs.

**Zhe** (pronounced *zhe kui*)
Flavor: sweet. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
Governs: accumulations and gatherings in the heart and abdomen, expels the three worms.
Grows in mountain valleys. Gathered in the second month.

Master Tao Yinju states: Its form resembles small taro, with white flesh and yellow skin, and it is also found near the Daoist paths. The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: *Zhe kui* may grow as large as a *dou* or as small as a *sheng*; its leaves resemble those of *Asarum forbesii* (du heng), and its vines climb upon grasses and trees. It possesses slight toxicity. What Master Tao describes is merely *tu luan* (earth egg), unfit for medicinal use. In Liang and Han, people call it *huang du*, steaming and eating it—this is not *zhe kui*.

Yu Xi and others note: According to the *Shu Ben Tu Jing*, its vines spread and grow; its leaves resemble those of *Metaplexis japonica* (luo mo), and its roots are like those of *Smilax china* (ba qia), with purple-black skin and yellow-red flesh. The larger specimens resemble *lun jun* (wheel fungi) the size of a *sheng*, while smaller ones are like fists. It is now found everywhere. Based on the *Shen Nong Ben Jing*, which states it is non-toxic, while Su [Gong] claims it has slight toxicity, and further asserts that what Master Tao describes—what people in Liang and Han steam and eat—is clearly non-toxic, it is evident that Master Tao’s account is correct.

Chen Cangqi states: As for *tu luan*, its vines grow, and its roots resemble taro. People boil it in lye water to eat it, though no therapeutic effects are recorded.

*Guan zhong* [is found in] Zizhou.

Flavor bitter, slightly cold, toxic. It governs pathogenic heat qi in the abdomen, all poisons, kills the three worms, expels *cun bai* (tapeworm), breaks *zheng jia* (abdominal masses), eliminates head wind, and stanches wounds from metal blades. Its flower: treats malignant sores and induces diarrhea.

Alternative names: *guan jie*, *guan qu*, *bai tou*, *hu juan*, *bian fu*, *bo ping*, and *yao zao*. This is called "herb-owl’s head." It grows in the mountain valleys of Mount Xuanshan and in Yuanju and Mount Shaoshi. Harvest the root in the second and eighth months, and dry in the shade.

*Guan jun* (a type of fungus) serves as its adjuvant.

Tao Yinju states: It is also found near the Dao. Its leaves resemble those of large ferns, and its root—with its shape, color, and bristles—entirely resembles an old owl’s head, hence the name "herb-owl’s head."

Yu Xi et al. note: The *Erya* states: *Luo* is *guan zhong*. The commentary explains: its leaves are round and pointed, its stem hairy and black, spreading across the ground; it does not die in winter. Another name is *guan qu*. The *Guang Ya* calls it *guan jie*, while the *Shu Ben* states another name is *yao* (pronounced *luo*) *zao*. The *Tu Jing* further states: its seedling resembles *gou ji* (cibotium), shaped like a pheasant’s tail; its root is straight with many branches, black-skinned and red-fleshed. The curved ones are called "herb-owl’s head" and are used to treat head wind. It is now found in shady mountain valleys everywhere.

The *Yao Xing Lun* states: *Guan zhong* is an adjuvant. It governs abdominal heat. *Chi xiao dou* (adzuki bean) serves as its adjuvant. It kills *cun bai* (tapeworm).

The *Tu Jing* says: *Guan zhong* grows in the mountain valleys of Mount Xuanshan and in Yuanju and Mount Shaoshi. Today, it is abundant in the prefectures of Shaanxi and Hedong, as well as in the regions of Jing and Xiang, though few bear flowers. Its seedling emerges in spring, red, with leaves as large as ferns.

The stem is three-ridged. The leaves are green, resembling small chicken feathers, and it is also called "phoenix-tail grass." The root is purple-black, shaped like a large melon, with black fibrous hairs below, resembling an old owl. The *Erya* states: *luòshū* (pronounced *ruòshū*), *guànzhòng*. Guo Pu’s commentary notes: its leaves are round and pointed, its stem hairy and black, spreading across the ground, and it does not die in winter. The *Guang Ya* calls it *guànjié*. The root is harvested in the third month and dried in the sun. People in Jingnan grind the root into powder, mix one *qiánbǐ* with water, and take it to effectively stop nosebleeds.

*Ráo* (pronounced *yáo*) flower tastes bitter and pungent, is cold or slightly cold, and toxic. It governs febrile diseases and warm malaria, drains the twelve types of water retention, breaks up hard accumulations and conglomerations, flushes stagnant food and phlegm-rheum from the intestines and stomach, expels pathogenic qi of cold and heat, promotes urination, and treats phlegm-rheum cough. It grows in the river valleys of Xianyang and Zhongmou in Henan. The flowers are collected in the sixth month and dried in the shade.

Tao Hongjing states: the Zhongmou variety was formerly only brought from the Yellow River region; its form resembles *yuánhuā* (genkwa) but is extremely fine and white. Recently, it has become nearly unobtainable due to isolation. The *Tang Ben* commentary notes: this herb’s seedling resembles coriander, its stem is thornless, its flowers are fine and yellow, and it is harvested in the fourth and fifth months—completely unlike *yuánhuā*.

Ma Zhi et al. note in the *Shu Ben Tu Jing*: the seedling grows to over two *chi* tall on hills and plains; it is now found everywhere, though the variety from Yongzhou is considered best. The *Yao Xing Lun* states: *ráohuā* is an adjuvant. It treats cough with counterflow qi, throat swelling and fullness, *zhù* qi and *gǔ* toxins, *xuánpǐ* (concretion) qi masses, and drains water swelling.

The *Yan Yi* states: *ráohuā* is now abundant in the regions of Jing and Luo. Zhang Zhongjing’s *Treatise on Cold Damage* uses *ráohuā* to treat diarrhea, as it moves water. When water is expelled, diarrhea ceases—this is its rationale. However, when using it today, one must carefully consider the dosage to avoid excess or deficiency. It should only be used when the corresponding pattern is present.

*Yázi* (from Jiangning Prefecture)

The root has a bitter, sour taste, is cold in nature, and is toxic. It governs pathogenic qi and heat qi, scabies, itching, malignant sores, hemorrhoids, and expels white worms. It is also called *langya* (wolf’s fang), *langchi* (wolf’s tooth), or *langzi* (wolf’s seed). It grows in the river valleys of Huainan and Yuanju. The root is harvested in the eighth month and dried in the sun. If it becomes damp and rots, it develops a mold that can kill a person. *Wuyi* (elm cake) serves as its adjuvant; it is incompatible with *diyu* (burnet root) and *zaoji* (jujube flesh).

Tao Yinju states: It is found everywhere in nearby regions, and its root sprouts resemble the teeth of beasts. Yu Xi et al. note: The *Shu Jing* records that its seedlings resemble *shemei* (snake strawberry) but are thicker and larger, with a deep green color. The root sprouts resemble the teeth of beasts. It is now found everywhere. The sprouts are gathered in the second and third months and dried in the sun.

The *Yao Xing Lun* states: *Langya* (wolf’s sprout) is an adjuvant, bitter in taste. It treats floating wind and itching, kills *cunbai* worms (tapeworm segments), and its decoction is used to wash malignant sores. The *Ri Hua Zi* states: It kills all worms in the abdominal viscera, stops red and white dysentery, and is taken as a decoction.

The *Tu Jing* records: *Yazi* (sprout) is the seed of *langya* (wolf’s tooth). It grows in the river valleys of Huainan and Yuanju, and is now abundant in the Jiangdong and Jingdong prefectures. Its seedlings resemble *shemei* but are thicker and larger, with a deep green color. The root is black and resembles the teeth of beasts, hence its name. The root is harvested in the third and eighth months and dried in the sun. Ancient formulas often use it to treat snake venom. The method: take a single-stemmed *langya*, pound it, mix with lard in the twelfth month, and apply to the affected area for immediate relief. Yang Yan’s *Nan Xing Fang* states: Use the leaves before the sixth month and the root afterward. Chew it fresh, wrap in a leaf, roast in embers until hot, and apply as a poultice to the sore; stop when it cools.

Zhang Zhongjing treats female genital sores with it alone. The *Sheng Hui Fang* provides a washing formula for genital sores: finely chop five *liang* of *langya*, boil in five *sheng* of water until reduced to three *sheng*, and wash the area warm. The *Wai Tai Mi Yao* records Fan Wang’s formula for *cunbai* worms: pound five *liang* of *langya* into powder, mix with honey into pills the size of sesame seeds. After fasting overnight, take one *ge* with fermented water the next morning; the condition will resolve once the dose is finished.

Another formula treats metal-inflicted wounds: pound the stems and leaves of *langya* grass into a paste and apply to stop bleeding. Another formula treats female genital erosion or ulceration: boil three *liang* of *langya* in four *sheng* of water, strain, add a cup of vinegar the size of a chicken egg, soak cotton in the liquid, and apply to the affected area four or five times a day for healing. The *Qian Jin Fang* treats infantile genital sores by washing with a thick decoction of *langya* grass. It also treats *shegong* (water-borne parasites, i.e., water fleas): in winter, take the root of *langya* leaves, pound it thoroughly, and apply as a poultice.

*Jiji*
Flavor: bitter; nature: neutral; toxic. It governs all malignant sores, scabies, crusts, fistulas, and erosions, as well as various sores in cattle and horses.

Tao Yinju states: Today, it is often used in ointments for sores and scabies, with remarkable efficacy. The *Tang Ben* annotation states: This herb has a single stem with four leaves at the top, and white flowers in the leaf axils. It thrives in shady, damp mountain valleys. The root resembles *xixin* (asarum) but is black and toxic—ingestion causes hemoptysis. It is now mistakenly used as *duheng* (asarum), which is incorrect. It is essential for treating scabies and itching.

Yu Xi et al. note: The *Shu Ben Tu Jing* records that the root is harvested in the second month and dried in the sun. The *Yao Xing Lun* states: *Jiji* can also be used alone to treat scabies. The *Ri Hua Zi* states: It governs head sores, white baldness, wind itching, and skin pruritus. Its decoction can be used for soaking and application.

*Yangzhizhu* (Yellow Azalea)

**Haizhou** and **Runzhou**: Flavor pungent, warm, highly toxic. It governs pernicious wind lodged in the skin and flesh causing lingering pain, warm malaria, malignant toxins, all types of impediment, perverse qi, demonic infestation, and gu poison. It is called *Yuzhi*. It grows in the river valleys of Mount Taihang and the mountains of Huainan. The flowers are gathered in the third month and dried in the shade.

Tao Yinju states: It is found in all nearby mountains. Its flowers and seedlings resemble *lucong* (daylily), but when sheep mistakenly eat its leaves, they stagger and die—hence its name. It must not be brought near the eyes.

The *Tang Ben* annotation states: *Yuzhi* and *zhizhu* (staggering) are one and the same. Tao, in his annotation on *zhizi* (gardenia), claims it is the seed of *zhizhu*, called *Yuzhi*—this is incorrect. Its flowers do not resemble *lucong* but rather *xuanfu* (creeping fig) flowers, which are yellow.

Modern annotation: Its seedling grows as a shrub, three to four *chi* tall. The leaves resemble peach leaves, and the flowers resemble those of *shanshilou* (wild pomegranate).

Yu Xi et al. note: The *Shu Ben Tu Jing* records: The shrub grows two *chi* tall, with leaves resembling peach leaves and yellow flowers like melon blossoms. The flowers are gathered in the third and fourth months and dried in the sun. It is now found everywhere.

The *Yaoxing Lun* states: *Yang zhizhu* (sheep staggerer) is incompatible with all minerals and flour; it must not be decocted for oral consumption.

The *Tu Jing* records: *Yang zhizhu* grows in the river valleys of the Taihang Mountains and the mountains of Huainan; it is now found everywhere. In spring, its seedling resembles *lucong* (daylily), with leaves like safflower and stems three to four *chi* tall. In summer, it blooms with flowers resembling *lingxiao* (Chinese trumpet creeper), *shanshilou* (wild pomegranate), and *xuanfu* (creeping fig), though pure yellow in color. Sheep that mistakenly consume its leaves stagger and die—hence its name. The flowers are gathered in the third and fourth months and dried in the shade. Today, it grows abundantly in the mountain valleys of Lingnan and the Shu roads, its deep red blossoms resembling brocade. However, some claim this variety is not used medicinally. Ancient major formulas frequently employed *zhizhu*, such as Hu Qia’s *Shixing Chi San* for seasonal epidemics, the *Wisou Siman Wan* for five types of cough and abdominal fullness, and various wine-based remedies for wind disorders, all of which incorporate it. Additionally, the *Lu Wang Jiu* for treating the hundred diseases of wind-dampness also uses *zhizhu* flowers. Modern medical formulas, such as the *Luojiao Tang* (foot-soaking decoction), often include it. In the south, the *Zhizhu Hua San* is highly effective for treating *gu* poison and bloody stool.

*Three Kinds of Haiyao Yu*:
*Bingxiang* (vase incense)

Careful examination of Chen Cangqi’s account states: It grows in the mountain valleys of Nanhai, resembling a herbaceous plant. Its flavor is cold and non-toxic. It governs seasonal epidemics and miasmic qi, as well as demonic and malevolent spirits—burning it is appropriate in all such cases. Boiled in water, it effectively washes away edema and floating qi. Combined with *tujiang* and mustard seeds, it is decocted into a bath to treat wind-malaria, yielding remarkable results.

*Chai Zigu*
Careful examination of Master Chen’s account states: It grows in the mountains of Lingnan and the various ranges of Nanhai. Each stem bears thirty roots, resembling *xixin* in form. Its flavor is bitter, its nature balanced, and it is non-toxic. It governs the resolution of toxic sores and abscesses, demonstrating divine efficacy. The varieties from Zhongzhou and Wanzhou are superior. The herbaceous stems possess similar therapeutic effects and are taken as a water decoction. As Lingnan abounds in poisons, every household stores it.

*Yi Nan Cao*
Careful examination of the *Guangzhou Ji* states: It grows in the mountain valleys of Guangnan. Its pods reach over two *chi* in length, containing thin, paper-like sheets, large or small as cicada wings, which govern malevolent influences. Young boys and girls place them in crimson silk pouches, wearing them on their arms to repel evil and prevent fright. This herb grows in the south—hence the character *nan* (south) in its name. Today, many mistakenly associate it with *nannü* (male and female). The *yinancao* (herb for bearing sons) refers to the daylily.

Twenty-five kinds from *Chen Cangqi’s Remaining Works*
*Qie* (read as *qiechexiang*)

Flavor: pungent, warm. Governs demonic qi, removes foul odors and infestations of insects, fish, and moths. Grows in Pengcheng. Several *chi* tall, with white flowers. The *Erya* states: *Qieche*, pronounced *qiyu*. Guo’s commentary: a fragrant herb. The *Guang Zhi* states: yellow leaves and white flowers. *Marine Materia Medica*: According to the *Guang Zhi*, it grows in the mountain valleys of Hainan. Master Chen states: governs cholera, repels malign qi, and is excellent for scenting clothes. For moth-infested items, decoct this fragrance and sprinkle the cooled liquid—it effectively repels moths and borers.

**Morning-Blooming, Evening-Falling Flower**
Governs malign sores, abscesses, scabies, ulcers, and ant fistulas. Dry in the sun, then grind into powder and mix with raw oil to apply. Grows in filthy places, its cap shaped like a brush, purple in color. Morning-blooming, evening-falling, children call it "dog’s urine pedestal," also named "ghost’s brush mushroom." Those emerging from the earth all govern sores and scabies. The black mushrooms growing on cow dung are especially effective. Additionally, when burned to ash and left through autumn rains, mushrooms with layered caps grow anew, called "immortal’s hat," which strongly governs blood disorders.

**Street Cave Root**
Flavor: bitter, neutral, non-toxic. Governs heat toxins, snakebites, dog bites, insect stings, and sores. Its effects are identical to Chen’s white medicine. The seedling vines are also similar. In Lingnan’s Enzhou, the roots are harvested and dried in the shade. *Marine Materia Medica*: According to the *Guangzhou Ji*, it grows in Lingnan and coastal regions. The vines resemble *tu gua* (earth melon), and the roots are similar. Flavor: pungent, warm, non-toxic. Governs all toxic qi and snakebites. Grind the root and administer; it induces vomiting of all ingested poisons.

**Wellside Grass**
Governs infant crying. Place it beneath the mother’s mat without her knowledge.

**Pig’s Ear Grass**
Governs *xidu* (stream toxins) and *shegong* (arrowhead insect) poison. Squeeze the juice to drink, and apply the dregs to the sore. *Hundred and One Remedies*: There are many kinds of pig’s ear grass—it is unclear which is correct. The white-leaved *songcai* (mustard greens) is also called pig’s ear. *Yan’s Family Instructions*: *Ma xian* (purslane), also called *tun*, is *machixian* (purslane). Additionally, the round-leaved *cheqian* (plantain) is also called pig’s ear.

**Lamp Wick Ash**
Apply to metal-inflicted wounds to stanch bleeding and promote flesh growth, turning the wound black. Today, when candlewick ash falls, it foretells joyous events—or else the sign of receiving money.

**Thousand-Gold Grass**
Governs snake venom, insect bites, and other poisons. Pound the herb and apply to the sore to regenerate flesh and relieve pain. Grows in Jiangnan, two to three *chi* tall.

**Broken Jar Grass**
Governs *ding* sores. Combine with *baiya* (white tooth powder), *yangti* (sheep’s bleat vegetable), *qingtai* (green moss), *banxia* (pinellia), *digupi* (lycium bark), *fengwo* (wasp nest), *xiao’er fa* (children’s hair), and *feibo* (crimson silk), all in equal parts, burned to ash. Harvest in the fifth month, pound, and mix with the other medicinal powders. Take one *qianbi* to expel the root of *ding*.

**Luo Ba Grass**
Its autumn spikes, when used for dyeing, blacken hair and prevent aging.

Grows by mountain roadsides.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Luo Ba Grass governs the treatment of bloody dysentery in men, but not in women. For chronic *gan*-dysentery, use its root—frequent consumption among the common folk has proven effective. For bloody dysentery, take two *jin* of Luo Ba Grass, pound and press to extract one small *sheng* of juice, then mix with half an egg’s worth of white flour until even. Consume on an empty stomach in one dose. Even in severe cases, no more than three doses are needed. If fresh grass is unavailable, gather the shoots, dry them in the shade, and grind into powder. For dysentery, take one *fangcunbi* of the powder mixed with half a cup of honey water.

Yu Xi and others note: Luo Ba Grass emerged in recent times, and its use is not found in ancient formulas. Though Chen Cangqi once mentioned its ability to blacken hair and prevent aging, growing by roadsides, the details remain unclear. His Majesty Emperor Taizong’s imperial writings record its therapeutic properties with great precision, and it is thus respectfully included at the beginning of the *Supplementary Categories* in *The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica*.

**Hundred-Herbs Ash**
Governs armpit odor and metal-inflicted wounds. Harvest on the fifth day of the fifth month, selecting one hundred varieties exposed to dew and drying them in the shade. Burn to ash, then mix with well water to form cakes. Re-bake until white, then combine with strong vinegar to make pastilles. Place under the armpits, replacing when dry. This may induce body-wide pain and distress, ceasing only when sores appear. Wash with water or urine; no more than two or three applications are needed. It also governs metal-inflicted wounds, stopping bleeding and regenerating flesh. Mix the ash with lime, form into cakes, bake until white, then scrape and apply to the wound.

**Grass from the Grave of a Woman Who Died in Childbirth**
Governs *cu* sores in children. Gather the grass without looking back, then prepare a bath infusion. No more than three washes are needed for excellent results.

**Ash of a Filial Son’s Collar**
Apply to facial *kuai*.

**Shoes and Sandals from Beneath the Bed**
Governs *jiaoqi*.¹

**Vampire-Fly Mother Grass**
Its leaves curl like pods, within which dwell bloodworms that metamorphose into horseflies, then bite humans. It grows in the far north. The leaves resemble those of mallow; when ground with cassia and applied to humans or horses, no horseflies will approach while traveling through the mountains.

**Worn Raincoat**
Knot and burn to ash, then mix with oil to apply to sores caused by earwig urine. Excellent.

**Old Cooking Stove Belt**
Governs white patches on the face. On the night of a lunar eclipse, burn with other medicinal ingredients to ash, then mix with bitter wine into a paste and apply.

**Heavenly Ocimum**
Governs *xi* poison.² Crush and apply to the sore.

A plant resembling *Heavenly Ocimum* grows on the plains of Jiangnan.

**Hairy Knotweed**
Governs abscesses, ulcers, fistulas, and scrofula. Crush and insert into the sore to draw out pus and blood, promoting flesh regeneration. Also prepare as a decoction to wash sores or soak the feet to treat *jiaoqi*. It grows at the foot of mountains, resembling black knotweed but with hairy leaves; its roots do not die in winter.

**Snake’s Bane Grass**
Governs bites from snakes, vipers, and venomous insects. Crush the roots and leaves, then apply to the bite, which will drain yellow fluid. It grows on level ground. Its leaves resemble those of *Polygonum cuspidatum* but are smaller, with red nodes, and grow one to two *chi* tall. Cultivating it repels snakes.

Another variety of grass, with round stems resembling ramie, also treats snakebites. *The Hundred and One Remedies* states: "In Dongguan, there is a grass resembling ramie, with square stems and red nodes. When crushed and applied to snakebites, it removes the venom as if plucked away; it is also called *Snake’s Bane Grass*." Both grasses treat snakebites, but it is unclear which is the true variety.

**Rat’s Bane Grass**
Resembles sweet flag, growing on mountain rocks. Its root is used to poison rats, killing them instantly.

**Ten-Thousand-If Vine**
Governs snakebites. Crush, sift, and mix with water into a paste to apply to the sore. Its vines resemble those of small beans. It grows in Lingnan and is also called *Ten-Thousand Luck*.

**Snail Mark Grass**
Governs abscesses, wind rashes, and swollen *jiaoqi*. Crush and apply. Also boil into a decoction to wash swollen areas.

---
¹ *Jiaoqi*: A condition characterized by weakness, numbness, or swelling of the legs, often associated with *qi* stagnation or dampness.
² *Xi* poison: A category of venomous afflictions from waterborne or environmental toxins.

**Vine Growing on Rocks Resembling Snail Mark Grass**
Grows on rocks, resembling *Snail Mark Grass*, with a slight reddish hue and sparse hairs on the underside.

**Stepmother Grass**
Governs malignant sores. Crush and apply. Grows in the plains and fields of the northern frontiers. Bears purple and green flowers with angular pods, each pod bearing thorns—resembling mugwort. Also called *Stepmother’s Mat*.

**Jia Jian**¹
Flavor: pungent. Nature: neutral, non-toxic.
Governs *jia ju* sores² and various intractable sores, pain from bites of insects, bees, snakes, or scorpions, sores on children’s heads, lip sores, and *moon-eaten sores*³ behind the ears. Apply topically. When mixed with various medicinals, fine fruits, or flowers and burned to ash, then blended with wax to form a lip balm, its applications are largely the same as *Jia Jian*. Specimens aged three years treat worm-infested sores, sores beside the mouth, *chan* sores⁴, *jia ju* sores, and similar afflictions.

**Golden Wound Small Grass**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: neutral, non-toxic.
Governs metal-inflicted wounds, stanches bleeding, and promotes flesh regeneration. Stops nosebleeds. Crush the leaves and apply. Alternatively, mix with lime in advance, pound into pellets, and dry in the sun; scrape and apply when needed. May also be boiled and taken internally to stop blood stasis and sudden bloody flux. Grows in damp lowlands of villages and fields in the Jiangnan region, reaching one or two *cun* in height. Its leaves resemble those of *qi*⁵ but are shorter. In spring and summer, it bears pale purple flowers, each the length of a grain of rice.

**Ghost Hairpin Grass**
Flavor: bitter. Nature: neutral, non-toxic.
Governs snake and spider bites. Crush and apply. May also be pounded to extract juice for oral consumption.

---
¹ *Jia Jian*: A medicinal preparation, possibly a resin or wax-based ointment.
² *Jia ju*: A type of deep-rooted, stubborn sore, often under the nails.
³ *Moon-eaten sores*: Recurrent sores, possibly eczema or impetigo, likened to the moon’s cyclical waxing and waning.
⁴ *Chan* sores: Ulcerative or erosive sores, often around the mouth.
⁵ *Qi*: Likely referring to *Lactuca sativa* (garden lettuce) or a similar leafy plant.

It grows by the edges of ponds. Its leaves are forked, its stem square. Its seeds form hairpin-like projections that cling to clothing like needles. In the north, it is called *Ghost Needles*.

*Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica, Expanded and Discussed*, Scroll Seventeen, concludes the section on "Lower Grade Herbs (Part One)."

[The following text appears to contain editorial notes and variants from alternate editions, which are not part of the main content and have been omitted in accordance with the translation guidelines.]

**He Shou Wu (Fleeceflower Root)**

*Revised and Corrected by Xu Hong, Imperial Medical Assistant for the Verification of Medicinal Materials, Song Dynasty*

**Category:** Lower Grade Herbs (Part Two)

**He Shou Wu (Polygonum multiflorum)** – *Xijing*
**Flavor:** Bitter, astringent; **nature:** slightly warm; **toxicity:** none.
**Functions:** Resolves scrofula, disperses abscesses and swellings, treats wind-sores on the head and face, addresses the five types of hemorrhoids, relieves heart pain, augments blood and qi, darkens the beard and hair, and enhances complexion. Prolonged consumption strengthens sinews and bones, enriches essence and marrow, and confers longevity. Also treats postpartum disorders in women and various conditions of vaginal discharge.
**Origin:** Originally from Nanhe County in Shunzhou; now found throughout Lingwai and the Jiangnan regions. The vine is purple, the flowers yellow-white, and the leaves resemble those of *Dioscorea* but lack luster. They invariably grow in pairs. The root, as large as a fist, comes in red and white varieties—red being male, white female. Alternative names: *Wild Seedling*, *Intertwining Vine*, *Night Union*, *Earth Essence*, and *Chen Zhibai*. Harvest in spring and summer. At the time of use, slice with a bamboo knife, soak overnight in rice-water, and dry in the sun. Pound in a wooden mortar and pestle. Avoid iron.

**Addendum:**
*Su Song et al. note:* According to *Ri Hua Zi*, its flavor is sweet. Prolonged consumption promotes fertility. It treats chronic abdominal disorders, all types of cold qi, and intestinal wind. This herb has male and female forms: the male has yellow-white stems and leaves, while the female is reddish-yellow. For medicinal use, both sexes must be combined; efficacy is thus confirmed. The herb was originally unnamed in the *Materia Medica*. It was later named after He Shou Wu, who observed the vines intertwining at night, consumed them, and derived benefit—hence the name. It is also called *Peach-Willow Vine*.

*The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica* states: He Shou Wu originally came from Nanhe County in Shunzhou, but is also found in Lingwai and the Jiangnan regions. Today, it grows everywhere, with the finest specimens from Xiluo, Songshan, and Zhecheng County in Nanjing. The plant sprouts in spring, its leaves growing in pairs like those of *Dioscorea* but without sheen. The stems trail over bamboo, trees, and walls. In summer and autumn, it bears yellow-white flowers resembling those of *Pueraria*. The seeds are angular, like buckwheat but smaller, the size of millet. The roots are harvested in autumn and winter, some as large as a fist, each with five ridges resembling a small bitter melon. Two varieties exist: red (male) and white (female). When harvesting, wipe the roots clean with cloth while still damp, then slice with a bamboo knife, soak overnight in rice-water, and dry in the sun. Avoid iron. Pound in a wooden mortar. One source advises: harvest the roots in spring, the flowers in autumn, and steam and dry them nine times before consumption. The herb was originally called *Intertwining Vine* but was renamed after He Shou Wu, who benefited from its use.

He Shou Wu was a man from Henan County in Shunzhou. His grandfather, originally named Tian’er, was born weak and remained unmarried at fifty-eight. One day, drunk and lying in the wild, he saw two vines in a field, their stems intertwining and separating repeatedly. Intrigued, he dug up the roots and asked villagers, but none could name them. He dried and ground them into powder, taking it with wine. After seven days, he regained virility; after a hundred days, all his ailments were cured. Within ten years, he fathered several sons and changed his name to Nengsi. He and his son Ting both lived to 160. Shou Wu, who also took the herb, lived to 130. In the seventh year of the Yuanhe era of the Tang, the monk Wenxiang encountered an old man on Mount Mao, who transmitted this account. Li Ao later recorded the formula, noting: the leaves resemble those of *Aphananthe aspera*, glossy and shaped like peach or willow leaves, with a slanted underside. They grow singly, not in pairs. The male plant has yellow-white foliage, the female yellow-red. The two grow apart but intertwine at night, sometimes vanishing. Harvest during late spring, mid-summer, and early autumn on clear, sunny days, collecting both male and female plants. Dry in strong sunlight. Powder and take with wine for best results. When harvesting, collect the entire root, wipe clean with cloth while damp, and avoid damaging the skin. Store in a sealed container, drying it again each month. Take on even-numbered days—2nd, 4th, 6th, or 8th. After ingestion, cover with clothing to induce sweating and perform *daoyin* exercises. Strictly avoid pork and lamb blood. Li Ao’s account is quite detailed, hence its inclusion here.

*Tested Prescriptions* states: For freshly harvested He Shou Wu, remove the skin and soil, then slice thinly with a copper or bamboo knife. Steam in a steamer as for rice, using a ceramic or stone pot (avoid iron). Keep another pot of water boiling beside it, replenishing as needed. When steam rises from the steamer, pour hot water over the herb repeatedly, ensuring it does not overflow, until the He Shou Wu loses all scent. Then take a spoonful of the liquid—this is the herb’s essence, distinct from ordinary decoctions. It treats soft bones, lumbar and knee pain, difficulty walking, and generalized itching. For large, textured He Shou Wu roots, combine one *jin* each of He Shou Wu and *Achyranthes* with one *sheng* of good wine, steep for seven days, then dry. Pound in a wooden mortar, form into honey pills, and take thirty to fifty pills on an empty stomach before meals with wine.

Another formula: For pain beneath the skin anywhere on the body, mix He Shou Wu powder with ginger juice to form a paste. Apply to the painful area, wrap with cloth, and press with a heated shoe sole—highly effective.

*Doumen’s Prescriptions*: To treat scrofula, whether ruptured or not, even if it extends to the chest, use *Ninefold Vine*. Take a root the size of a chicken egg, wash, and chew raw—regular consumption is key. Alternatively, crush the leaves and apply to the sores; the condition will resolve after several applications. Prolonged use darkens the hair and extends lifespan. Some take the root’s "ninefold" head (nine nodes) to attain immortality. The leaves resemble apricot leaves, and the root resembles scrofula nodules—its effects are divine. It can also be used in alchemical arts to subdue cinnabar, following established methods.

One name is He Shou Wu, also called Red Vine.

*Wang’s Extensive Remedies*: To treat stubborn scabies and ringworm covering the body, use equal parts He Shou Wu and mugwort. Boil in water until concentrated, then wash the affected area in a basin—highly effective for relieving pain and promoting flesh regeneration.

*The Tale of He Shou Wu*: Long ago, there was a man named He Shou Wu from Nanhe County in Shunzhou. His grandfather was named Nengsi, and his father was named Yanxiu. Nengsi often admired Daoist arts and followed his master into the mountains. One night, drunk and lying in the wild, he suddenly saw two vines over three feet apart, their tendrils intertwining and only separating after a long while, then entwining again. Astonished by this marvel, he dug up the roots at dawn and brought them home. No one recognized them. Later, an old mountain hermit arrived, and upon seeing the roots, said: "You have no heir, yet these vines are extraordinary—perhaps they are an elixir of immortals. Why not consume them?" He then pounded the roots into powder and took one *qian* with wine on an empty stomach. After several months, he felt stronger and continued taking it, increasing the dose to two *qian*. After a year, all his old ailments were cured, his hair turned black, and his complexion grew youthful. Within a few years, he had a son named Yanxiu, who in turn fathered Shou Wu. Thus, the name He Shou Wu originated. He fathered several children, lived over a hundred years, and retained black hair.

There was a man named Li Anqi, a close friend from the same village, who secretly obtained the formula and took it. He too lived a long life and recorded the story.

He Shou Wu is sweet in taste, warm in nature, and non-toxic. Poria (*fuling*) serves as its guiding herb. It treats five types of hemorrhoids, lumbar and knee ailments, cold-induced heart pain, chronic emaciation from overwork, phlegm accumulations, wind deficiency, and debility. It strengthens sinews and bones, replenishes essence and marrow, fortifies *qi*, preserves youthful appearance, darkens the beard, and prolongs life. For women, it resolves stagnant blood, jaundice, postpartum disorders, red and white vaginal discharge, abdominal toxicity, and chronic dysentery. Its benefits are too numerous to list in full.

Other names include Wild Seedling, Intertwining Vine, Night Union, Earth Essence, and Shou Wu. Originally found in Qianzhou, it now grows throughout the Jiangnan region. Its leaves are glossy, resembling those of peach or plum trees, with male vines being reddish. The roots extend no more than three feet and can be harvested in spring or autumn, then sun-dried. Remove the skin, grind into powder, and take with wine for optimal effect. For acute conditions, use poria decoction as the guiding agent. Store the powdered form in a new ceramic vessel. Avoid pork, blood, and scaleless fish while taking it, as these may diminish its efficacy.

The finest specimens resemble a clenched fist with bead-like nodules, some bearing shapes of birds, beasts, mountains, or peaks—these are treasures. When dug up, peel and eat raw; the taste is sweet, and it can replace grain.

*Eulogy*: Its divine efficacy aids the Dao, recorded in immortal classics.
Male and female vines entwine at night, parting by day.
Consumed, it dispels the need for grain, sustaining through months and years.
It reverses aging, restores youth, and transforms a sickly body into one at peace.
Only those destined may encounter it—pass it on, but do not reveal it lightly.
In this, you shall find your own ease.

The Prefect of Mingzhou, Li Yuan, recorded from empirical accounts: He Shou Wu is produced in Nanhe County of Shunzhou, as well as in Shaozhou, Chaozhou, Enzhou, Hezhou, and Sihui County of Guangzhou—these locations yield the finest specimens. Those from Jinxing County of Yongzhou, Guizhou, Kangzhou, Chunzhou, Qiongzhou, Gaozhou, and Xunzhou are of secondary quality.

This immortal herb, at fifty years of age, grows to the size of a fist and is called "Mountain Slave." Consumed for a year, it turns the beard and temples dark. At one hundred years, it reaches the size of a bowl and is called "Mountain Brother." Consumed for a year, it restores a rosy, joyful complexion. At one hundred thirty years, it grows to the size of a basin and is called "Mountain Elder." Consumed for a year, it causes fallen teeth to regrow. At two hundred years, it attains the size of a *dou* or *kaolao* basket and is called "Mountain Sage." Consumed for a year, one’s complexion becomes childlike, and one’s pace matches that of a galloping horse. At three hundred years, it reaches the size of a three-*dou* *kaolao* basket and is called "Mountain Spirit." Consumed for a year, it extends lifespan, and with prolonged use, one attains a purely Yang body, eventually ascending as an Earthly Immortal.

*Extended Meanings* states: He Shou Wu darkens the beard and temples, but it is incompatible with radishes, which may cause premature graying of the beard and temples, as well as intestinal wind and excessive heat.

**Shang Lu**:
Flavor: pungent, sour; nature: neutral; toxic.

Root governs water distension, mounting lumps, and impediment; when heated and applied, it dispels abscesses and swellings, slays demonic influences, and treats perverse qi in the chest, water swelling, wilting impediment, and fullness with a drum-like abdomen. It dredges the five viscera and disperses water qi. Those resembling a human form possess numinous power. Another name: □ Root; another name: Night Call. It grows in the river valleys of Xianyang.

Tao Yinju states: It is found everywhere in nearby regions. Recipe masters seldom use it dried; for treating water swelling, they slice the fresh root and boil it with live carp to make a broth. Daoists, however, use it in powdered form or as a decoction or fermented preparation, all of which expel corpse worms and enable one to see spirits. Its fruit is also used in numinous medicines. Its flower, called □ Flower, is especially effective.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: There are two varieties, red and white. The white is used medicinally, while the red enables one to see spirits and is highly toxic. It is only applied externally to swellings. If ingested, it harms the person, even causing unceasing bloody dysentery and death.

Modern annotation: Shang Lu, another name: White Prosperity; another name: Dang Lu.

Yuxi et al. note: The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica of Shu* states: Its leaves are as large as an ox’s tongue, thick and brittle. Those with red flowers have red roots; those with white flowers have white roots. It is now found everywhere. The root is harvested in the second and eighth months and dried in the sun.

The *Erya* states: "Suixi is horse’s tail." The *Guangya* says: "Horse’s tail is Shang Lu." The *Materia Medica* records another name: Xi. Today, in Guanzhong it is also called Xi, while in Jiangdong it is called Dang Lu. The *Exegesis* notes: "Those resembling a human form are numinous." The *Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states: "Dang Lu is an envoy; dog meat is forbidden. It is sweet in flavor and highly toxic. It can purge ten kinds of water diseases and unblock throat impediment. Slice thinly, stir-fry with vinegar, and apply externally to swollen throats for relief." *Ri Huazi* says: "White Zhang Lu is bitter and cold in flavor; it harmonizes well with garlic. It unblocks the large and small intestines, drains *gu* toxins, induces abortion, and assists in resolving swollen toxins. Apply externally to malign sores. The red variety is toxic." The *Illustrated Classic* states: "Shang Lu is commonly called Zhang Liu root. It grows in the mountain valleys of Xianyang and is now found everywhere, often in household gardens. In spring, it sprouts, growing three to four *chi* tall, with green leaves like an ox’s tongue but longer. The stem is greenish-red and extremely soft and brittle."

In summer and autumn, it blooms with red-purple flowers in clusters. The root resembles that of a radish but is longer. The root is harvested in the eighth and ninth months and dried in the sun. Its use pertains to the exterior. Ancient alchemists often employed it, and it may also be taken alone. On the fifth day of the fifth month, the root is gathered, placed in a bamboo basket, hung in the northeast corner of the house, and dried in the shade for a hundred days. It is then pounded, sifted, and mixed with well-water to be taken, said to be a secret method of the immortals. For sudden throat pain caused by toxic qi, slice the root, roast it until hot, and apply it over a cloth to the affected area, replacing it when cool—this brings immediate relief.

Its flowers cause mental confusion, forgetfulness, and frequent errors. Gather the flowers, dry them in the shade for a hundred days, and grind them into powder. At dusk, take a square-inch spoonful with water, lie down, and focus on the desired matter—it will then become clear in one’s mind.

The *Erya* calls it *suìtāo*, the *Guangya* calls it *mǎwěi*, and the *Book of Changes* calls it *xiànlù*—all referring to this *shānglù*. However, there are two varieties: red and white. The red-flowered type has red roots, while the white-flowered type has white roots. The red variety is not used medicinally; the white is employed for internal consumption.

There is another plant called *chìchāng*, whose leaves and stalks closely resemble *shānglù* but must not be used, as it harms the sinews and depletes the kidneys—careful distinction is required.

Master Lei states: "When using it, do not mistake it for *chìgě* (red vine), as they appear similar. *Chìgě*’s flowers and stems contain toxins that dissolve sinews and kidneys, so it must not be ingested. The white-flowered *zhānglù*, when aged, is gathered by immortals to make preserved fruit, which can be served with wine."

For processing: first scrape off the outer skin with a copper knife, slice thinly, soak in east-flowing water for two nights, then strain and steam in a steamer. Layer it with soybean leaves, steaming from noon until midnight. Remove, discard the soybean leaves, dry in the sun, and finely chop for use. If soybean leaves are unavailable, use soybeans instead.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*:
For water qi: Peel the white *shānglù* root, cut it into small pieces the size of mung beans, take one large cup, and boil it in three *shēng* of water until reduced to one *shēng* or more. When soft, add one large cup of millet and cook into congee. Take on an empty stomach; if taken twice daily, it may cause excessive purging, so once daily is sufficient for mild relief. Avoid mixed foods.

Another formula: For scrofula and sudden throat pain, pound fresh *zhānglù* root into cakes, place them on the scrofula, and apply moxa three or four times over the medicine.

*The Marrow of the Thousand Gold Prescriptions*:
For water qi and edema: Take six *liǎng* of white *chāng*, extract half a *gé* of juice, mix with half a *shēng* of wine, and administer according to the patient’s size—this will purge the water and bring relief.

Another formula: For sudden abdominal masses resembling stones, with piercing pain and crying out, if left untreated, death occurs within a hundred days. Pound a large quantity of *shānglù* root to extract its juice, or steam it, then place it on a cloth over the abdomen without covering. Replace when cool, applying day and night without pause.

*The Tested Prescriptions*:
For water diseases: Peel and thinly slice *zhāngliǔ*, dry in the sun, and grind into powder. Use three large yellowcatfish, three cloves of garlic, and one *hé* of mung beans, boiling them in a large bowl of water until the beans are soft. Eat the beans first, then mix one *qián* of the powdered medicine with the broth—this will transform the water into qi and disperse it.

*Master Mei’s Prescriptions*:
For edema when unable to take medicine: Boil one *shēng* of *shānglù* and six *liǎng* of mutton in one *dǒu* of water until reduced to six *shēng*. Strain, then prepare a broth with the meat, scallions, and fermented beans as usual. The white variety of *shānglù* is superior.

*Sun Zhenren’s Dietary Prohibitions*:
For all hot toxic swellings: Mix *zhānglù* root with a little salt and apply, changing twice daily.
