Its juice may be consumed, and it promotes hair growth when used as a hair rinse. For swelling, wandering wind, wind rashes, and headaches, grind and apply it as a poultice. It also states: Plantain oil is cold and non-toxic. It treats head wind-heat, women’s hair loss, stops vexation and thirst, and heals scalds and burns.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: Banana root was previously unrecorded as to its place of origin. Tao Hongjing says it originally came from Guangzhou, and is also found in Jiangdong. Root and leaves are indistinguishable, save that the fruit is inedible. Today, it grows in the two Guang regions, Minzhong, and Sichuan, where it bears flowers. The fruit from Min and Guang is exceptionally fine and edible. Though abundant elsewhere, few produce flowers. In recent years, it has been widely cultivated in the capital—all of it plantain.

The varieties of plantain are many. This text refers to the fruiting kind, *ganjiao*. Its leaves broadly resemble those of plantain, but from its furled heart emerges a stalk bearing flowers. Initially, a large calyx forms, resembling an inverted lotus, with ten or more layers, each unfolding like petals. As the layers gradually enlarge, the flower emerges from within, luxuriant and profuse. Red ones blaze like torches, called "red plantain." White ones resemble beeswax, called "water plantain." The flowers greatly resemble ivory, hence the name "ivory plantain." The fruit also varies in green and yellow, with many cultivars, all sweet and delicious. They may be dried and sent afar; when northerners receive them, they are prized as rare delicacies. The people of Min bury the peel in ash to make it smooth as tin, then spin it into cloth resembling ancient *xishuai* fabric.

Its root is extremely cold. Pounded to extract juice and applied to swellings and poisons, or taken for postpartum blood stasis, it is effective. Plantain root is similar in nature. Folk physicians use it to treat seasonal epidemics, manic heat, wasting-thirst, and agitation from mineral or metallic poisoning—its juice may be consumed for all these. Plantain oil treats dark wind epilepsy, where phlegm causes dizziness and fainting. Drinking it induces vomiting and brings swift recovery, proving remarkably effective. It is collected by inserting a bamboo tube into the peel, as one taps lacquer.

*Dietary Therapy*: Governs jaundice. The fruit, eaten raw, is greatly cold. It quenches thirst, moistens the lungs, and may provoke cold disorders. Steamed and dried until the mouth opens, it is pounded and consumed. Cold in nature, it unblocks the blood vessels and replenishes the marrow.

*The Hundred and One Remedies*: For fatal suppurative back sores, pound the root and apply it.

*The Secret Records of Mother and Child*: To treat infantile red wandering sores that spread upward and downward, reaching the heart and causing death, pound plantain root, decoct the juice, and apply it.

The *Extension of Materia Medica* states: Plantain over three years old produces a flower from its heart, one stem bearing a single bloom, entirely like a lotus. The leaves are also similar, though slightly yellow-green, shedding from the base. The flower heart always grows upward, constantly resembling a lotus, yet I have never seen its center. When split open, no stamens appear—all is leaf, though the flower head always droops. Each blossom opens from mid-summer until after mid-autumn. For every three leaves that open, three leaves fall. In the north, its cultivation is rare, and thus it is seldom used. Its fibers are spun into cloth. The juice, applied by women to their hair, makes it black. The rest accords with the *Classic*.

**Reed Root**

**Reed Root**
Flavor: sweet; nature: cold.
Governance: resolves wasting-thirst, guest-heat, and arrests profuse urination.

Tao Yinju states: One must dig for the sweet and pungent roots; those exposed above ground or floating in water are unfit for use.
The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This herb’s root treats retching with inability to eat, stomach heat, and is especially effective for those suffering from cold damage. Its flower, called *pengnong* (蓬蕽, pronounced *nóng*), when boiled in water and the juice consumed, excellently remedies cholera—its efficacy is proven.

Ma Zhi et al. note: The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: Reed root is an envoy, non-toxic. It resolves intense heat, awakens the stomach, and treats unremitting hiccups.
*Ri Huazi* states: It treats alternating chills and fever, seasonal epidemics, vexation and oppression, heart heat in pregnant women, and thirst in those with diarrhea or dysentery.

The *Illustrated Classic* says: The old texts do not record the regions where reed root is produced; today, it grows everywhere in low-lying, damp marshes. Its form resembles bamboo, with leaves clasping the stem and no branches. The flowers are white and form spikes like cogon grass. The roots also resemble bamboo roots but with sparser nodes. Harvest in the second and eighth months, and dry in the sun. For use, one must select the sweet and pungent roots from beneath the water; those exposed above ground or floating are unfit.

Carefully noting the *Erya*: Reed root is called *jiahua* (葭华). Guo Pu comments: *Lu* (芦) is *wei* (苇, reed); *wei* is the mature form of *lu*, just as *jian* (蒹) is called *jian*, identical to *lian* (廉). *Jian* resembles *huan* (雈, pronounced *wán*) but is slender and several feet tall; people in Jiangdong call it *jian*. *Di* (荻) is the same as *di* (荻); *di* refers to *tan* (菼, pronounced *tā gǎn*), which is *luan* (薍, pronounced *wǔ bā*). *Luan* resembles reed but is smaller and solid inside; in Jiangdong, it is called *wuqiu* (乌蓲, pronounced *qiū*), or sometimes *di*. When *di* hardens in autumn, it is called *huan*. Its shoots are all called *tiao* (苕, pronounced *tiáo*), and its sprouts are called *quan* (虇, pronounced *quǎn*). Thus, what is called *luwei* (芦苇, reed) is a single species. What is called *lian* (廉) is now *jian* (蒹). What is called *tan* (菼) is what people use for firewood. Today, few can distinguish *jian*, *tan*, and *luwei*. Moreover, northerners consider *wei* (苇) and *lu* (芦) as two different plants: those growing in waterlogged lowlands are all called *wei*; the slender ones, no thicker than a finger, planted in household ponds and gardens, are called *lu*. Those with slightly larger stalks and a deep jade-green color are called *bi lu* (碧芦, jade reed), which are rare. Thus, the *reed* used in materia medica corresponds to what northerners call *wei*, and they may be used interchangeably. Ancient formulas often employ it alone. Ge Hong’s remedy for retching and hiccups: slice the root, boil in water, and consume one *sheng* in a single dose. The *Proven Formulas* prescribe boiling it in boys’ urine and drinking no more than three *sheng* to cure the condition. Its *pengrong* (蓬茸) treats sudden cholera with critical breathing: take a handful, boil into a thick decoction, and consume two *sheng* at once to recover. It also excels in treating fish and crab poisoning. The shoots taste slightly bitter but are edible, prepared like bamboo shoots—though extremely cold in nature.

The *Tang Materia Medica* adds: It grows in low, damp ground. Stem and leaves resemble bamboo; flowers resemble *di* (荻) flowers. Harvest the root in the second and eighth months, and dry in the sun for use.
Lei Gong states: For use, one must select *ni shui lu* (逆水芦, "upstream reed"). Its roots, growing against the current and appearing yellow, plump, and thick, are sweet in flavor. After harvesting, remove the nodes, root hairs, and the reddish-yellow outer layer, then finely slice for use.

The *Sagely Benefit Formulas*: For poisoning from eating horse meat with itching and pain, slice five *liang* of reed root, boil in eight *sheng* of water, reduce to two *sheng*, and divide into three doses.
The *Thousand Gold Formulas*: For dry retching and hiccups with cold hands and feet, boil three *jin* of reed root into a thick decoction and drink.
The *Handbook of Emergency Formulas*: For poisoning from eating sea bass liver or *houshi* fish, slice reed root, boil into one or two *sheng* of juice, and drink.
The *Master Mei’s Formulas*: For indigestion after eating dog meat, with hardness below the heart, distension, dry mouth, sudden fever, and delirium, boil reed root and drink the decoction.
The *Golden Cabinet’s Treasury Formulas*: For five types of hiccups, stagnant *qi* in the heart and diaphragm, vexation and oppression, retching, and inability to eat, slice five *liang* of reed root, boil in three large cups of water, reduce to two cups, strain, and consume warm at any time.

**Ghost’s Mortar**
Flavor: pungent; nature: warm, slightly warm, toxic.
Governance: Kills *gu* toxins, ghostly infestations, and spectral entities; repels malign *qi* and inauspiciousness; expels evil; resolves all poisons; treats cough with throat obstruction, wind-evil vexation and confusion, loss of spirit with delusory visions; removes superficial visual obstructions; kills severe toxins. Not to be used in decoctions.
Other names: *juexi* (爵犀), *mamu dugong* (马目毒公), *jiujiu* (九臼), *tianjiu* (天臼), *jiedu* (解毒).
Grows in the mountain valleys of Jiuzhen and Yuanju. Harvest the root in the second and eighth months.
Aversion: *yuan yi* (垣衣, wall moss).

Tao Yinju states: Ghost’s mortar resembles *shegan* (射干), white in color and sweet in flavor, warm and toxic. It governs wind-evil, ghostly infestations, and *gu* toxins. The *jiujiu* (nine mortars) grow connected, and those with hair are superior. Also called *jiujiu*, it grows in mountain valleys; harvest in the eighth month and dry in the shade. It also resembles *gouwen* (钩吻). The *mamu dugong* resembles *huangjing* (黄精), with root sockets like a horse’s eye, soft and moist. Ghost’s mortar resembles *shegan*, *zhu* (朮), and the like, with two varieties: those from Qiantang and nearby regions are sweet in flavor, with tufted hair on top, and are the finest; those from Kuaiji and Wuxing are larger, bitter in flavor, without tufted hair, and inferior. They vaguely resemble *dugong* (毒公) but differ in toxicity. Today, physicians frequently use ghost’s mortar and rarely use *dugong*, though I do not know why such a stark difference exists.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This herb grows in the shade of cliffs in deep mountains. Its leaves resemble *bima* (蓖麻, castor bean) and *chonglou* (重楼, Paris polyphylla). It produces a single stem, with one leaf at the tip, though some branch into two. Each year, the stem grows longer, and when it withers, it forms a single mortar.

If one were to grow for twenty years, it would bear twenty mortars—how could it be merely nine? Its root, flesh, skin, and fibers all resemble *shegan*, and what is commonly used today is indeed *shegan*. Moreover, a different plant is often sent from Jiangnan, which is not the genuine article. It is now found in the mountains of Dangyang County in Yingzhou, Yuan’an County in Xiazhou, and Jingshan County in Xiangzhou, though it remains exceedingly rare.

Yu Xi and others note: The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica from Shu* states that its flowers grow between the stems and are red. It is now harvested from the deep mountains of Xiazhou and Xiangzhou in the second and eighth months; the roots are dried in the sun for use.

The *Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states: *Guijiu* (ghost’s mortar) is an envoy herb, bitter in flavor. It governs *shizhu* (corpse attachment), consumptive illnesses, and emaciation from transmitted diseases; it dispels malevolent qi and expels ghosts and spirits.

The *Illustrated Classic* says: *Guijiu* grows in the valleys of Jiuzhen and Yuanju. Today, it is also found in Jiangning Prefecture, as well as in Chu, Shu, Shang, Qi, Hang, Xiang, Xiazhou, and Jingmen Commandery, often thriving in the shade of cliffs in deep mountains. Its leaves resemble *bima* (castor bean) and *chonglou* (Paris polyphylla). Initially, it produces a single stem with one leaf at the tip, though some branch into two. Each year, a new stem grows, and when it withers, it forms a single mortar—thus, after twenty years, it bears twenty mortars. Its flowers grow between the stems, red in color, blooming in the third month, later bearing fruit. The root, flesh, skin, and fibers all resemble *shegan*, and what is commonly used is indeed *shegan*; one must carefully distinguish between them. The roots are harvested in the second and eighth months and dried in the sun for use. Ancient formulas employ it to treat the five *shi* (corpse syndromes), *guizhu* (ghost attachment), myriad poisons, and malign qi.

Another account states: *Guijiu* grows in the shady areas of deep mountains. Its leaves, five or six in number, resemble a goose’s foot. At the tip of the stem is a single leaf like an umbrella, which faces east at dawn and tilts west by dusk, following the sun’s movement. Its red-purple flowers resemble lychee blossoms, nestled beneath the leaves and perpetually shaded from the sun. Each year, it produces one leaf, and when it withers, it forms one mortar. After eight or nine years, it bears eight or nine mortars. However, as each new mortar forms, an old one decays, for the old and new replace one another—hence its folk name, *haimu cao* (harm-mother herb). Plants like *yukui* (taro) and *wutou* (aconite) follow a similar pattern: as new shoots emerge, the old ones die, and the previous year’s corm rots. Yet the *Materia Medica* commentary claims it entirely resembles *shegan*. While *shegan*’s form is indeed similar, its mortars are shallow and thin, vastly different from *guijiu*. *Guijiu*’s mortars resemble eight or nine *tiannanxing* (arisaema) arranged side by side, with a color and texture much like *shegan*. For proper identification, one must seek the living plant; it is no longer found in markets.

---

**Jiaohao (角蒿, horned artemisia)**
Flavor: pungent, bitter; nature: neutral, slightly toxic.
Governs damp-erosive sores and malignant ulcers infested with worms.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: Its leaves resemble *baihao* (white artemisia), its flowers like *qumai* (Dianthus superbus), red and lovely. Its seeds resemble *wangbuliuxing* (Vaccaria segetalis), black and horn-shaped. Harvested in the seventh and eighth months.

*Previously appended in the Tang Materia Medica.*

Yu Xi and others note: The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica from Shu* states that its leaves resemble *shechuang* (Cnidium monnieri) and *qinghao* (sweet wormwood). Its seed pods resemble *manjing* (turnip), with fine black seeds that ripen in autumn. It grows everywhere.

Chen Cangqi states: *Jiaohao* is pungent, warm, and non-toxic. It breaks up blood stasis, descends qi, and when boiled for consumption, resembles *xiaoji* (field thistle). It grows on high ridges, its perennial roots emerging before all other grasses. Another name is *ehuo*. The *Erya* states: *E* is *luo*. The annotation reads: *Jiaohao*. The *Exegesis* says: The *Classic of Poetry · Xiao Ya* states, “Lush is the *ehuo*.” Lu Ji explains: *Ehuo* is another name for *luohao* (artemisia). It grows in marshy fields and ditches. Its leaves resemble *xiehao* (crooked artemisia) but are finer, growing in clusters in the third month. Its stems are edible, either raw or steamed, fragrant and delicious, with a flavor somewhat like *jingliuhao* (water pepper).

Lei Gong states: When using it, do not mistake it for *honghao* (red artemisia) or *xiehao*, both of which closely resemble *jiaohao* except that their seed pods are shorter. After harvesting, chop it finely on a locust wood block for use.

The *Wai Tai Mi Yao* records: For receding gums due to *gan* (infantile malnutrition), take *jiaohao* ash and apply it to the gums at night. The patient must avoid greasy foods, sugar, and dried jujubes.

The *Qian Jin Fang* states: For chronic oral sores that penetrate the chest and cause ulcers, apply *jiaohao* ash—it will take effect overnight. If saliva accumulates in the mouth, spit it out.

The *Gong Qi Fang* records: For infantile mouth sores, apply *jiaohao* ash to the sores—it is miraculous.

The *Yan Yi* states: *Jiaohao*’s stems and leaves resemble *jinghao* (artemisia). It bears pale red-purple flowers, roughly three to four *fen* in diameter. After flowering, it produces horn-shaped seeds about two *cun* long, slightly curved. Its shoots and seed pods are exceptionally effective for oral and dental ailments.

---

**Madouling (马兜铃, birthwort fruit)**
Flavor: bitter; nature: cold, non-toxic.
Governs lung heat, cough, phlegm stagnation, wheezing, hemorrhoids, and fistula sores.

It grows in Guanzhong, its vines twining around trees. Its fruit resembles a bell, divided into four or five segments.

*Now appended.*

Yu Xi and others note: The *Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states that *madouling* is neutral. It governs urgent lung qi, inability to sit or breathe properly, and incessant coughing.

The *Ri Hua Zi* states: It treats hemorrhoids and fistula sores. Burn the herb in a jar to fumigate the affected area; when used in formulas, it is roasted. This is the superior *qingmuxiang* (Aristolochia root), with its roots and seeds used separately.

Harvested in Yuezhou in the seventh and eighth months.

The *Illustrated Classic* says: *Madouling* grows in Guanzhong and is now also found in Hedong, Hebei, Jianghuai, Kui, and Zhe commanderies. In spring, it sprouts vines like creeping stems, with leaves resembling *shanyu* (Dioscorea). In the sixth month, it bears yellow-purple flowers, somewhat like *gouqi* (goji) blossoms. In the seventh month, it produces fruit the size of a jujube, shaped like a bell and divided into four or five segments. Its root is called *yunnan gen* (Yunnan root), resembling *muxiang* (Aucklandia) but the size of a little finger, reddish-yellow in color.

Also called *tu qingmuxiang* (local Aristolochia root). The fruit is harvested in the seventh and eighth months and dried in the sun. It governs lung disorders. The root is gathered in the third month to treat *qi* stagnation below the diaphragm and to relieve stabbing pain.

Master Lei says: When using it, after harvesting, remove the leaves and vines, place it in a raw silk bag, and hang it in the east corner of a house to dry. Then split it into pieces, take the inner portion (note #52), remove the skin and membrane, and clean it thoroughly. Use both the seeds and the skin. Do not use it if the skin and membrane are not fully removed.

*The Sage’s Benevolent Prescriptions*: To treat the five types of *gu* poison, grind three *liang* of *madouling* root into powder, divide it into three doses, decoct each with one cup of water down to five *fen*, strain, and take frequently. The *gu* will be expelled through vomiting; if not fully relieved, take again until recovery.

Another formula: For *cao gu* (vegetable *gu*) poisoning, as recorded in the *Zhengyin Fang* and prevalent in Lingnan—if someone is afflicted by this toxin, causing throat pain so severe it feels life-threatening—grind one *liang* of *madouling* shoots into powder. Take one *qianbi* with warm water, and the toxin will dissolve and be expelled, proving effective.

*The Outer Terrace Secret Essentials*: Cui’s method for snake *gu*—contracted through food or drink—causes a sensation of an obstruction in the throat, neither swallowable nor vomitable, with heart oppression and heat. Taking *madouling* induces vomiting to expel it. Alternatively, take one *qianbi* of musk, which will also induce vomiting of the *gu* toxin.

*The Concise Prescriptions for the Multitudes*: To treat lung *qi* wheezing and cough, use two *liang* of *madouling*, retaining only the inner seeds and discarding the husk. Mix with half a *liang* of *su* (butter) in a bowl, stir evenly, and stir-fry over a slow fire until dry. Roast one *liang* of licorice, then grind both ingredients into powder. Take one *qian* per dose, decoct with one cup of water down to six *fen*, and sip warm. Alternatively, hold the powder in the mouth and swallow the saliva.

*Extended Meanings* says: *Madouling* is a climbing vine that ascends by clinging to trees. When its leaves fall, the bells still hang, resembling horse neck bells—hence its name. When ripe, they split open on their own, though some seeds remain intact. Harvesting should occur between the eighth and ninth months. It treats wheezing and urgency due to lung *qi*.

---

*Xianmao* (Curculigo)
Flavor: pungent. Nature: warm, toxic.
Governs cold *qi* in the heart and abdomen with inability to eat, wind-cold contracture and numbness in the lower back and legs preventing walking, male deficiency taxation, elderly incontinence, infertility, and fortifies the Yang path. Long-term use connects with the spirit, strengthens memory, aids sinews and bones, benefits the skin and flesh, prolongs vitality, and brightens the eyes.
Also called *dumao gen* (solitary cogon root), *maogua zi* (cogon melon seed), or *poluomen shen* (Brahmin ginseng).

*The Transmission of Xianmao* says: Ten *jin* of stalactite medicine cannot compare to one *jin* of *xianmao*—this illustrates its potency.

It grows in the Western Regions and on Mount Dayu. It is also said to be incompatible with iron and cow’s milk. The root is harvested in the second and eighth months.

Now appended.

Maoxi et al. note: *Rihuazi* says it treats all wind-*qi* conditions, extends life, supplements the five taxations and seven damages, opens the stomach, descends *qi*, and enhances bedroom affairs.

Pengzu’s method for single-ingredient use: Soak in rice-washing water, discard the red liquid to remove toxicity, then it will not cause harm.

*The Illustrated Classic* says: *Xianmao* grows in the Western Regions and on Mount Dayu. Today, it is also found in Shu, Jianghu, and the various prefectures of Liangzhe. Its leaves are green like cogon grass but softer, slightly broader, with longitudinal veins on the surface, resembling palm leaves. By late winter, it withers, and new growth appears in early spring. In the third month, it bears yellow flowers like gardenias, but it does not set fruit. Its root is solitary, straight, and surrounded by short, fine roots. The flesh is yellow-white, with a slightly rough, brown outer skin. The root is harvested in the second and eighth months and dried in the sun for use. The variety from Mount Heng bears green flowers and black seeds in the fifth month.

Carefully noting *Xu Chuanxin Fang*: *Xianmao* governs the five taxations and seven damages, brightens the eyes, and boosts sinew strength—dispersing yet supplementing. It was originally transmitted by a Daoist from the Western Regions. In the first year of the Kaiyuan era, a Brahmin monk presented this medicine to Emperor Minghuang, who found it effective. At the time, the formula was kept secret and not disseminated. During the chaos of the Tianbao era, medical texts scattered. Later, the Tripiṭaka master Bukong of the Upper Capital obtained this formula and transmitted it to Minister Li Mian, Minister Lu Sigong, Attendant Gentleman Qi Hang, and Minister Zhang Jianfeng, all of whom benefited from its use. Minister Lu had long taken mineral medicines without effect, but upon obtaining this drug, its benefits were a hundredfold greater. Attendant Gentleman Qi, while governing Jinyun, suffered from declining vitality and recurring wind rashes; after taking it, he recovered. Harvest in the eighth or ninth month, scrape off the black skin with a bamboo knife, cut into pieces the size of soybeans, soak in rice-washing water for two nights, dry in the shade, grind, and sift. Form into pills with cooked honey the size of *wutong* seeds. Take twenty pills each morning on an empty stomach with wine or water. Avoid cow’s milk and beef, as they greatly diminish the drug’s potency.

*The Xu Chuanxin Fang* was compiled by Wang Yan, Prefect of Junzhou during the Later Tang, based on earlier texts. Its formulas were widely circulated at the time, so today in Jiangnan, this drug is simply called *poluomen shen* (Brahmin ginseng).

*The Overseas Materia Medica* says: It grows in the Western Regions. Some roots are thick, some thin, with sinews, resembling brush handles, and have jointed textures. The yellow variety is mucilaginous. In Sanskrit, it is called *ashugandha*. Flavor: sweet, slightly warm, mildly toxic. Governs wind, supplements weakness in the lower back and legs, pacifies the five viscera, strengthens sinews and bones, and aids digestion. Long-term use lightens the body and enhances complexion. It comes from Wucheng and is also found in various prefectures of Shu.

The leaves resemble cogongrass, hence the name *rixianmao* (Sunlit Caltrop). Flavor: acrid, neutral. It disperses yet also supplements, with no great toxicity but slight heat and mild toxicity. Governs the seven injuries in men, brightens the ears and eyes, boosts sinew strength, replenishes bone marrow, and invigorates yang without fatigue. When using, cut with a bamboo knife and soak in glutinous rice water.

Master Lei says: After harvesting, wash thoroughly with clean water, scrape off the outer skin, and on a locustwood chopping block, cut into soybean-sized pieces with a bronze knife. Then place in a loose-woven cloth bag and soak in black soybean water for one night. Remove, mix with wine, and steam from *si* (9–11 a.m.) to *hai* (9–11 p.m.), then dry in the sun. Avoid iron utensils, as it may speckle the beard and temples.

**Yangtao (Actinidia)**
Flavor: bitter, cold, toxic. Governs burning heat, sudden reddening of the body, wind-water accumulations, malignant sores, and eliminates heat in children. Dispels the five viscera’s water and abdominal distension, promotes urination, and boosts qi. Can be used in bath decoctions. Also called *guitao* (ghost peach), *yangchang* (sheep’s intestines), *changchu* (long thorn), *yuyi* (royal arrow), or *diaoyi* (sound: *yaoyi*).

Grows in mountain forests, river valleys, and fields. Harvest in the second month and dry in the shade.

Tao Yinju says: Common in mountains and wilds, closely resembling the domestic peach but not the mountain peach. The fruit is small and bitter, inedible, with deep red flowers. The *Book of Songs* states: *"In the lowlands grows* changchu*—"* referring to this plant. It is no longer used in formulas.

The *Tang Materia Medica* notes: This plant often grows in ditches, moats, and trenches. People boil it to wash wind-itch and various sores and swellings, with excellent efficacy. In Jiannan, it is called *niuzi* root.

Yu Xi et al. note: The *Sichuan Illustrated Classic* states: Grows in flat marshes. Leaves and flowers resemble the peach, but the fruit is as small as a jujube pit. The slender, weak seedlings trail like vines and cannot form trees. Found everywhere today, often growing by streams and gullies. Now called *xizigen* (fine-root), resembling tree peony. Treats swellings.

The *Erya* says: *Changchu* is *diaoyi*. Guo Pu comments: This is today’s *yangtao*. The explanation states: Leaves resemble the peach, flowers are white, and the fruit is like wheat or a small peach.

Lu Ji says: Leaves are long and narrow, flowers are purple-red. Its branches and stems are weak; after growing a foot, they trail over grasses. Today, people use them for drawing water, but they are heavy and prone to sinking, inferior to willow. Near the base, cut the bark with a knife, place in hot ashes to loosen, and it can be used to sheath brush handles.

Chen Cangqi says: Flavor: sweet, non-toxic. Governs wind-heat and emaciation in the elderly.

Steep in wine and consume. Grows in the river valleys of Shu’s mountains. The herb reaches a foot in height, with small, elongated leaves—also called *yangtao* root.

*The Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*: To treat cold damage toxin attacking the hands and feet causing pain, boil *yangtao* and soak the affected area in its juice; mixing with salt and fermented soybeans is especially effective.

**Rat-Tail Sage**
Flavor: bitter, slightly cold, non-toxic.
Governs rat fistula with alternating chills and fever, and unremitting dysentery with pus and blood. White-flowered varieties treat white dysentery; red-flowered varieties treat red dysentery.
Also called *qing* (pronounced *qing*), or *lingqiao*.
Grows in level marshes. Harvest the leaves in the fourth month, the flowers in the seventh month, and dry in the shade.

Tao Yinju says: Abundant in fields and wilds, people gather it to dye black. Also used to treat lower fistulas—boil it thickly to extract the juice, then form into pills for consumption. Today, it is also brewed as a drink.

Yu Xi et al. note: *The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica from Shu* states: Found in low, damp places. Leaves resemble mugwort; in summer, four or five spikes grow at the stem’s tip, resembling plantain. Flowers come in red and white varieties. Harvest the seedlings in the seventh month and dry in the sun for use.

*The Erya* says: *Qing* is rat-tail. The explanation states: This is the herb used to dye black, also called rat-tail.

Chen Cangqi says: Rat-tail sage is neutral. Governs all types of dysentery. Boil the juice or grind into powder for consumption. Purple flowers, stems, and leaves can dye black. Also called crow grass or water green.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: The old texts do not record the regions where rat-tail sage grows, only that it thrives in level marshes. Today, it is found everywhere, though only people in Qianzhong gather it as medicine. The seedlings resemble mugwort; in summer, four or five spikes form at the stem’s tip, like plantain. Flowers come in red and white. *The Erya* calls it *qing*, rat-tail, noting it is the herb used to dye black. Harvest the leaves in the fourth month, the flowers in the seventh month, and dry in the shade. Ancient treatments for dysentery frequently used it.

Yao Shi says: Boil it thickly until the juice resembles thin maltose. Drink five *ge* three times daily. Use red flowers for red dysentery and white flowers for white dysentery to cure it.

*The Sage’s Benevolent Prescriptions*: To treat chronic red and white dysentery with emaciation, grind rat-tail sage into powder. Take one *qian* at any time, mixed with rice porridge.

**Female Green**
Flavor: pungent, neutral, toxic.
Governs *gu* poison, expels evil *qi*, kills ghosts, treats warm malaria, and averts inauspiciousness.
Also called sparrow gourd. It is the root of snake’s tongue, growing in Zhuya. Harvest in the eighth month and dry in the shade.

Tao Yinju says: If this is the root of snake’s tongue, it should not grow exclusively in Zhuya. Commonly used are the leaves of a different herb, but it is unclear which is correct. The *Book of Divination* states: Carrying a tael of its fragments repels epidemics—it is all the more important to recognize the true variety.

*The Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This herb is sparrow gourd. Leaves resemble *luomo* (metaplexis), growing in pairs. The fruit resembles a gourd, about the size of a jujube, hence the name sparrow gourd. The root resembles *baiwei* (swallowwort). Grows in level marshes. Stems and leaves are foul-smelling. The root of snake’s tongue is entirely unrelated.

*The Supplementary Records of Famous Physicians* states: When young, the leaves resemble *luomo*, with round tips and thick stems. The fruit is black, and the juice of stems and leaves is yellow-white—similar to the previous description. If this were the root of snake’s tongue, how could the seedlings grow in Yizhou while the root lies in Zhuya, thousands of *li* apart?

*The Supplementary Records* also says: The white sap of sparrow gourd governs insect and snake venom—this is the sap of female green’s seedlings.

Yu Xi et al. note: *The Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states: Female green is an envoy, flavor bitter, non-toxic. Treats warm malaria with alternating chills and heat; snake’s tongue is its guiding herb.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Details are provided under the entry for snake’s tongue.

*The Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*: To repel epidemic diseases, on the first *yin* day of the first month, grind female green into powder, place in a triangular crimson pouch, and hang it at the front of the bed canopy—highly auspicious.

*The Secret Records of Mother and Child*: To treat sudden abdominal discoloration in children (blue-black or red) with inability to breathe, use this remedy immediately. Also treats sudden death from vomiting and dysentery: place female green powder in the mouth and take with wine. Effective for adults as well.

Zi Xu Yuanjun’s *Inner Transmission of the Lady of Southern Peak*: For sudden death, grind a *qian* of female green fragments and place in the throat. Swallow with water or wine to revive instantly.

**Old Hemp Shoe Soles**
Boil in water and drink the juice. Resolves toxicity from purple fluorite, also governs unremitting cholera with vomiting and diarrhea, and counteracts poisoning from beef or horse meat causing abdominal distension, vomiting, and unremitting dysentery.

Now, according to Chen Cangqi’s *Materia Medica*: Old hemp shoe soles govern wasting-thirst. Boil the juice and consume. For shoe laces the size of jujubes, or women’s undergarments stained with blood, burn two sets of seven large hooked thorn needles along with the three items to ash, mix with lard, and apply to fox-bite sores to extract worms.

First appended in the *Tang Materia Medica*.

Yu Xi et al. note: Chen Cangqi says: Burn old straw shoes and human hair to ash, mix with vinegar, and apply to wandering swellings from heat toxin in children.

Chen Cangqi says: Burn the tips of fourteen hemp shoes to ash and take with well-flower water at dawn to treat enuresis. Also, burn old hemp shoe soles until red-hot, steep in wine or millet gruel, and drink to treat cholera with cramps.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: *Recent Effective Remedies* for bedwetting: Take hemp shoe laces, nosebands, and similar (excluding the soles), measure seven portions, boil in seven *sheng* of water until reduced to two *sheng*, and take in two doses.

Another remedy: For centipede stings, heat a hemp shoe sole and rub the affected area to cure it.

*The Thousand Gold Prescriptions*: For prolapsed anus, repeatedly press with a heated hemp shoe sole to cure permanently. Also, burn one old hemp shoe sole and one turtle head to ash, grind the turtle head into powder, apply to the anus, and press with the shoe sole to prevent further prolapse.

*The Effective Remedies*: For nasal congestion, burn hemp shoe ash and blow into the nostrils to clear immediately. It is also called "Thousand-Mile Steed," referring to the hemp shoe.

*The Broadly Beneficial Remedies*: For nosebleed, burn [hemp] shoe [ash] and blow into the nostrils for instant effect.

**Liujinu Grass** (*Artemisia anomala*)
Flavor: bitter. Nature: warm.
Governs breaking blood stasis and relieving distension. Excessive consumption induces dysentery.
Grows in the Jiangnan region.

*Tang Materia Medica* annotation: Its stem resembles mugwort, reaching three to four *chi* in height. The leaves resemble those of orchid grass but are pointed and elongated. The seeds resemble barnyard millet but are finer, with several spikes growing from a single stem and leaves arranged alternately.

Now, according to the *Alternative Annotation*: In ancient times, this herb was used to treat sword wounds and stanch bleeding as an essential remedy. For postpartum residual ailments, it breaks blood stasis, stops bleeding, and relieves pain with great efficacy.
First appended in the *Tang Materia Medica*.

Kong Yuxi et al. note: The *Sichuan Illustrated Classic* states: Its leaves resemble chrysanthemum, growing four to five *chi* tall. The flowers are white, and the seeds are yellowish-white, forming spikes like those of mugwort. It now grows in Yuezhou. The seedlings are harvested in summer and dried in the sun.

*The Daily Encyclopedia of Materia Medica* states: Liujinu is non-toxic. It treats heart and abdominal pain, descends qi, resolves water distension and blood-qi [stagnation], unblocks women’s menstrual channels and congealed masses, and checks cholera with watery diarrhea. It is also called Liujinu. Harvest in the sixth, seventh, or eighth month.

*The Illustrated Classic* records: Liujinu grass grows in Jiangnan; it is now also found in Hezhong Prefecture, Mengzhou, and Hanzhong. The seedling emerges in spring, its stem resembling mugwort, with four ridges, growing to a height of two to three *chi*. The leaves are green, like willow, and in the fourth month it bears small, yellowish-white flowers resembling *Orostachys*. In the seventh month it sets seed, similar to millet but finer, with several spikes growing from a single stem and leaves arranged alternately. The root is pale purple, resembling lettuce. Harvest the seedling, flowers, and seeds in the sixth and seventh months, using them all together.

Master Lei says: After harvesting, remove the stem and leaves, using only the seeds. For preparation, first wipe the thin husk with cloth until clean, then steam with wine from *si* (9–11 a.m.) to *shen* (3–5 p.m.), and dry in the sun before use.

*Proven Remedies* states: For scalds and burns, it is most effective. Grind Liujinu into powder, first apply glutinous rice water with a chicken feather to the burned area, then sprinkle the powder on top—this prevents pain and leaves no scars. Generally, for burns, first sprinkle salt powder to protect the flesh from damage, then apply the medicinal powder.

*Gusuibu* is bitter in flavor, warm in nature, and non-toxic. It breaks blood stasis, stanches bleeding, and repairs fractures. It grows in Jiangnan. The root clings to trees and rocks, covered in hair, with leaves resembling *Artemisia keiskeana*.

The people of Jiangxi call it *husunjiang* ("monkey ginger"). It is also known as *shian* (stone *Artemisia*) or *gusuibu* ("bone-mending cloth"). Now appended here.

Ma Zhi et al. note: According to the *Yaoxing Lun* (*Discourse on Medicinal Properties*), *gusuibu* is an assistant drug. It can govern toxic qi in the bones, wind-blood pain, the five taxations and six extremes, loss of control in the mouth and hands, heat above and cold below—all of which it effectively treats.

Chen Cangqi states: *Gusuibu* resembles *shiwei* (Pyrrosia) but has a single root, with the rest of its leaves growing on trees. It is also found in Qian and Ji of Lingnan. Its original name was *houjiang* ("monkey ginger"). Emperor Xuanzong of the Kaiyuan era, recognizing its efficacy in treating fractures and mending broken bones, bestowed upon it this name.

The *Rihuazi* states: *Houjiang* is neutral in nature. It treats malignant sores, eroded flesh, and kills parasites. It is a herbaceous vine that grows on trees, resembling ginger but slender and elongated.

The *Tu Jing* (*Illustrated Classic*) says: *Gusuibu* grows in Jiangnan, and is now also found in Huai, Zhe, Shaanxi, and the Kui Road prefectures. Its roots grow on large trees or rocks, often in shaded areas, spreading into vines with yellow hairs and short leaves attached. It also has large leaves forming branches, their upper surface a blue-green with yellow dots, and the underside a greenish-white with reddish-purple dots. Leaves emerge in spring and wither yellow by winter. It bears neither flowers nor fruit; only the root is used medicinally. It may be gathered at any time, and the hairs are scraped off before use. Originally called *husunjiang* ("monkey ginger"), Emperor Ming of Tang renamed it for its remarkable efficacy in treating fractures and injuries. The people of Shu treat sprains, fractures, and tendon or bone injuries by pounding the root into a sieve, cooking it with yellow millet porridge, and applying the mixture to the injured area—highly effective. It is also used to treat deafness: the root is carved into thin strips, fired, and inserted hot into the ear. It is further employed in remedies for women’s blood and qi disorders. Another name is *shimaojiang* ("stone-hair ginger").

Lei Gong says: For use, after gathering, first scrape off all the yellow-red hairs with a bronze knife, then finely chop. Mix with wine to moisten, place in a willow steamer, and steam for two days before removing to dry in the sun. The *Qianning Ji* records: After removing the hairs and finely chopping, mix with raw honey and steam from *si* (9–11 a.m.) to *hai* (9–11 p.m.), then dry in the sun as before. Pound into powder for use. Consuming it roasted with pig kidney on an empty stomach treats tinnitus and also corrects various miscellaneous pains.

The *Lingyuan Fang* (*Spiritual Garden Remedies*) states: For vacuity qi attacking the teeth, causing toothache, bleeding, and itchy, painful gums, take two *liang* of *gusuibu*, finely file, and stir-fry until black. Pound into powder. After routine rinsing, apply to the roots of the teeth, retain for a long while, then spit out. Use before bedtime and swallow afterward—no harm in doing so.

The character *gu* (蠱) was originally written as *chong* (虫), amended according to the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #41 The character *er* (二) appears as *tu* (土) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #42 The character *jia* (加) was originally written as *ru* (如), amended according to the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #43 The character *qiao* (鞘) is suspected to be a miswriting of *shao* (稍). The same applies below. #44 The character *cang* (藏) appears as *zai* (栽) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #45 The four characters *shui yi da zhan* (水一大盏) were originally omitted and have been supplemented according to the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #46 The character *jia* (瘕) appears as *jin* (金) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #47 The character *ming* (明) appears as *hu* (胡) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #48 The character *ji* (楫) appears as *nai* (奈) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #49 The character *nuan* (暖) appears as *xiao* (效) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #50 The character *bian* (编) appears as *pian* (偏) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #51 The character *jing* (菁) appears as *qing* (青) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #52 The phrase *guo le* (裹了) appears as *li zi* (里子) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #53 The *Huiming Xuan* edition adds the character *guo* (国) after *yin* (因). #54 The character *niu* (纽) appears as *xi* (细) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #55 The two characters *gu ming* (故名) were originally omitted and have been supplemented according to the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #56 The character *si* (似) was originally omitted and has been supplemented according to the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #57 The phrase *xu yuan* (虚元) appears as *ling nan* (灵南) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #58 The character *xue* (血) was originally written as *ye* (也), amended according to the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #59 The character *chu* (处) was originally omitted and has been supplemented according to the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #60 The character *rou* (肉) was originally written as *bai* (白), amended according to the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #61 The character *jiu* (酒) appears as *mi* (蜜) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #62 The character *mo* (末) was originally written as *zhong* (中), amended according to the *Huiming Xuan* edition. #63 The character *zheng* (正) appears as *zhi* (止) in the *Huiming Xuan* edition.

**Section Nineteen: Lower Grade Herbs (Part Two)**
*Illustrated Classic and Expanded Materia Medica*, Scroll Nineteen

**Revised and Expanded Materia Medica by Song Dynasty Attending Gentleman for Authentication of Medicinal Materials, Kou Zongshi**
**Collated and Corrected by Song Dynasty Imperial Physician-Instructor for Authentication of Medicinal Materials, Xu Hong**

**Section: Lower Grade Herbs (Part One)**
**Mùzéi (Scouring Rush)**

**Produced in:** Qinzhou
**Flavor:** Sweet, slightly bitter
**Toxicity:** None

**Therapeutic Effects:**
- Treats eye disorders, removes corneal opacity and membranes
- Dissolves accumulations and masses
- Augments the liver and gallbladder
- Brightens the eyes
- Heals intestinal wind, stanches dysentery
- Arrests incessant menstrual bleeding in women

**Combinations:**
- With ox horn fragments (*niújiǎo xiè*) and musk (*shèxiāng*), treats chronic, intractable dysentery.
- With limonite (*yǔyúliáng*), Chinese angelica (*dāngguī*), and *xiōngqióng* (*Ligusticum chuanxiong*), remedies flooding and spotting (red and white vaginal discharge).
- With *huái’é* (*Sophora japonica* galls) and mulberry ear fungus (*sāng’ěr*), effectively treats intestinal wind with bloody stool.
- With sophora fruit (*huáizǐ*) and unripe bitter orange (*zhǐshí*), governs bleeding hemorrhoids.

**Habitat and Description:**
Found in Qin, Long, Hua, and Cheng prefectures, in areas near water. The herb grows in clusters, with stalks reaching approximately one *chi* in height. Each root bears a single stem, devoid of flowers or leaves, segmented at every *cun*, and colored green. It remains evergreen even through the harshest winters. Harvested in the fourth month.

**Newly Revised.**

**From *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica*:**
Woodwhistle (*mùzéi*) grows in the regions of Qin, Long, Tong, and Hua. Its flavor is slightly bitter and non-toxic. It brightens the eyes, treats wind disorders, and checks dysentery. Found in mountain valleys near water. Its solitary stem resembles an arrow shaft, leafless, one to two *chi* in length, green, and remains verdant through winter. Segmented at every *cun*, it may be harvested at any time. Today, physicians employ it extensively, particularly for chronic intestinal hemorrhoids with unremitting bleeding. A proven formula: two *liang* each of woodwhistle and unripe bitter orange (*zhǐké*), one *liang* of dried ginger, and one *fen* of rhubarb. Grind together, stir-fry in an iron pan until blackened (retaining three-tenths of its nature), then pulverize. Take two *qiánbǐ* with warm millet broth before meals—highly effective.

**From *Extensive Beneficial Formulas*:**
For unremitting bloody diarrhea: slice twelve *fen* of woodwhistle, decoct in one *sheng* and eight *ge* of water until eight *ge* remain. Strain and divide into two doses, taken on an empty stomach. A second dose may be taken after walking five *li*.

**From *Extension of the Materia Medica*:**
Finely slice woodwhistle, lightly stir-fry, and grind to powder. Steep two *qián* in boiling water and take before meals to treat *qi* disorders of the small intestine and bladder. Gradual consumption ensures efficacy.

**Jin Grass (*jìncǎo*)**
Pronounced as "jìn." Flavor: bitter, neutral, non-toxic. Governs chronic cough, counterflow *qi*, wheezing, long-standing cold, fright palpitations, scabies, white scalp sores, and *qi* of sores. Kills small skin parasites and may be used to dye yellow, producing a golden hue. Grows in the river valleys of Qingyi. Harvested in the ninth and tenth months. Antagonized by sowbugs (*shǔfù*).

Tao Hongjing notes: Qingyi lies west of Yizhou. The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This herb’s leaves resemble bamboo but are finer and thinner; its stems are also slender and round. It thrives along streams and ditches in marshy lowlands. The people of Jing and Xiang boil it to dye yellow, yielding an exceptionally vivid color. Effective for washing sores. Commonly called "green grass."

The *Erya* states: This is the so-called "royal forage" (*wángchú yáo*). Lu Dian et al. annotate in the *Erya Subcommentary*: "Green" refers to deer bedding (*lùrù*), now called "owl-foot sedge." The *Odes·Wei Wind* says: "Gazing upon the Qi’s banks, the lush green bamboo sways." The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: Jin grass is an envoy. It treats all malign dietary accumulations.

**Dandelion (*púgōngcǎo*)**
Flavor: sweet, neutral, non-toxic. Governs breast abscesses and swellings in women. Boil and drink the juice, or apply as a poultice—swelling dissipates immediately. Also called "hoe grass" (*gòunòucǎo*).

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: Its leaves resemble those of sowthistle, with yellow flowers. When broken, a white sap exudes, which people consume. First appended in the *Tang Materia Medica*.

Lu Dian et al. note in the *Sichuan Illustrated Classic*: Its flowers resemble chrysanthemums but are larger. Both stems and leaves exude white sap when broken and may be eaten raw. Grows in marshes and fields. Harvested in the fourth and fifth months.

**From *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica*:**
Dandelion’s place of origin was not previously recorded. Today, it is found in marshes and fields everywhere. In early spring, it sprouts leaves like sowthistle, with fine spines. A single stem rises from the center, bearing a yellow flower at its tip, resembling a gold coin. When the stem is broken, white sap flows, which people also consume. Commonly called "dandelion" (*púgōngyīng*), a corruption of "servant’s jar" (*púgōngyīng*).

Boil the juice to treat women’s breast abscesses. Pounded and applied to sores, it is also excellent. For malignant thorns and fox-urine sores, crush the root and stem to extract the white sap and apply liberally—the affliction ceases immediately. This formula appears in Sun Simiao’s *Essential Formulas Worth a Thousand in Gold*. Its preface recounts: "On the night of the fifteenth day of the seventh month in the fifth year of Zhenguan, I struck the back of my left middle finger against a garden tree. By dawn, the pain was unbearable. Over ten days, the pain worsened, the sore swelled larger, and its color resembled ripe adzuki beans. Having heard elders speak of this formula, I followed it. The swelling subsided, the pain ceased, and the sore healed, fully recovering in less than ten days." Yang Yan’s *Southern Travel Formulas* also records its efficacy.

**From *Master Mei’s Formulas*:**
For postpartum women unable to nurse, causing retained milk to form abscesses: pound dandelion and apply to the swelling, changing the poultice three or four times daily.

**Grain Essence Grass (*gǔjīngcǎo*)**
**Producing Regions:** Taizhou, Jiangning Prefecture
Flavor: acrid, warm, non-toxic. Governs throat impediment, tooth wind-pain, and all sores and scabies. Fed to horses, it treats diseases such as mange and singed manes.

Harvested in the second and third months from grain fields. Also called "star-crowning grass" (*dàixīngcǎo*). Its small, round white flowers resemble stars, hence the name. Now appended.

Su Song et al. note: *Ri Hua Zi* states it is cooling. When fed to horses, it promotes fattening. The variety that blooms with white flowers in fields between the second and third months forms cinnabar-like mercury granules.

**From *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica*:**
Grain Essence Grass was not previously recorded as to its native regions, but now it is found everywhere. It sprouts in grain fields in spring, with both leaves and stems green, while roots and flowers are white. The flowers are harvested in the second and third months for use. Also called "star-crowning grass," as its slender leaves and small, round white flowers resemble stars, hence the name. There is another variety with fine leaves, slightly longer jointed stems, and reddish roots, found in the Qin and Long regions. Though rarely used in ancient formulas, it is now commonly employed in dental remedies. Chen Cangqi states: its flavor is sweet and neutral. It is also used in veterinary medicine for horses. It bears white flowers and fine leaves.

**From *Collected Verified Formulas*:**
For migraines and headaches: grind one *liang* of Grain Essence Grass into powder, mix with white flour, spread on paper, and apply to the painful area, replacing when dry.

---

**Cow-Flattening Grass (*niúbiǎncǎo*)**
**Producing Region:** Luzhou
Flavor: bitter, slightly cold, non-toxic. Governs heat qi in skin sores; may be decocted for bathing. Kills cattle lice and mites, and also treats bovine diseases. Grows in the mountain valleys of Guiyang.

Tao Hongjing notes: "Modern people no longer recognize this herb, yet bovine epidemics recur generation after generation, and it remains essential in veterinary medicine—though even cattle healers are now ignorant of it."

**From *Tang Materia Medica* Annotation:**
This herb’s leaves resemble those of *Sanicula* or *Ranunculus*. Its roots are like *Gentiana macrophylla* but finer. It grows in low-lying wetlands, and rural folk call it "cow-flattener." Highly effective against cattle lice. The Imperial Medical Bureau stores it under the name *biǎntè* or *biǎndú*.

Su Song et al. note: **From *Sichuan Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica*:**
Its leaves resemble those of *Ranunculus* or *Aconitum*. Now produced in Ningzhou. Harvest the roots in the second and eighth months and dry in the sun.

**From *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica*:**
Cow-Flattening Grass grows in the mountain valleys of Guiyang and is now also found in Luzhou and Ningzhou. Its leaves resemble those of *Sanicula* or *Ranunculus*, and its roots are like *Gentiana macrophylla* but finer. It thrives in low-lying wetlands. Harvest in the second and eighth months and dry in the sun. Now rarely used.

According to *Shennong’s Classic of Materia Medica*, it "kills cattle lice and mites." Su Gong’s annotation states: "The Imperial Medical Bureau stores it as *biǎntè*." In Luzhou, a similar herb is called *biàntè*. It blooms in the sixth month and sets seed in the eighth. Its roots are pounded into powder, mixed with oil, and applied to kill lice and nits. The roots and stems share similar therapeutic properties. This may well be Cow-Flattening Grass, though the names differ—could *biǎn* and *biàn* be phonetic corruptions? Here appended for reference.

---

**Bitter Weed (*kǔ’ǎo*)**
Flavor: slightly cold. Governs lacquer sores on the face, eyes, and entire body.

Tao Hongjing notes: "Found everywhere. Rustics cut and eat its stems raw. Harvest on the fifth day of the fifth month and dry in the sun. Burned to ash, it effectively treats incised wounds."

**From *Tang Materia Medica* Annotation:**
Modern people mistake it for *Rhaponticum uniflorum*, but this is incorrect.

Su Song et al. note: **From *Sichuan Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica*:**
Its seeds resemble those of *Cirsium*. The stem is round and thornless. Harvest the shoots in the fifth month; they may be eaten raw. Found in low-lying wetlands everywhere.

**From *Drug Properties Treatise*:**
Bitter Weed may be used alone. Flavor: bitter, non-toxic.

**From *Ri Hua Zi*:**
Cooling. Treats erysipelas.

**From *Dietary Therapy*:**
Bitter Weed is slightly cold. Eaten raw, it treats lacquer sores. Harvest on the fifth day of the fifth month and dry in the sun. Burned to ash, it is applied to lacquer sores on the face, eyes, and entire body. Overconsumption is inadvisable.

---

**Wood-Sorrel (*cùjiāngcǎo*)**
Flavor: sour, cold, non-toxic. Governs malignant sores, scrofula, and fistulas. Pound and apply as a poultice to kill various parasites. Grows along roadsides.

**From *Tang Materia Medica* Annotation:**
Leaves resemble fine duckweed, growing in clusters. The stem bears three leaves. Also called "vinegar mother grass" or "dove-sour grass."

Now according to **From *Alternative Annotation*:**
Grows in shady, damp places. Commonly called "small sour thatch." Consumed to relieve heat and thirst. Harvest in the fourth and fifth months and dry in the shade. First appended in *Tang Materia Medica*.

Su Song et al. note: **From *Sichuan Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica*:**
Leaves resemble duckweed, with two smaller leaves and one larger leaf at the stem’s end. Bears yellow flowers and black seeds. Grows in low-lying wetlands. Harvest the leaves in summer for use.

**From *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica*:**
Wood-Sorrel, commonly called "sour sauce," was not previously recorded as to its native regions. Said to grow along roadsides, it is now abundant in low-lying wetlands and household gardens in the southern regions, and occasionally found in the north. Leaves resemble duckweed, growing in clusters. The stem bears three leaves, with small yellow flowers blooming between them and black seeds. Harvest the leaves in summer. When young and tender, children often eat it. Southerners use it to polish bronze vessels, making them gleam like silver.

---

**Houseleek (*zuòyèhécǎo*)**
Flavor: sour, neutral, non-toxic. Governs dry mouth pain, bloody dysentery from water or grain, and stanches bleeding. Grows on rooftops in Shangdang, resembling *Artemisia* when young. Also called "tile pine." Harvest in summer and dry in the sun.

**From *Tang Materia Medica* Annotation:**
Leaves resemble *Artemisia*, growing over a *chi* tall. From a distance, it looks like a pine tree growing on old tiled roofs.

Now according to **From *Alternative Annotation*:**
Found everywhere and used in medicine. Particularly effective in hair-growth ointments. First appended in *Tang Materia Medica*.

Su Song et al. note: **From *Sichuan Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica*:**
Harvest the shoots in the sixth and seventh months and dry in the sun.

**From *Sagely Benefit Formulas*:**
For dandruff and scalp wind: dry Houseleek in the sun, burn to ash, steep in hot water, and wash the head. Effective within five to seven applications.

---

**Weak-Head (*ruòtóu*)**
**Producing Region:** Yangzhou
Flavor: acrid, cold, toxic. Governs abscesses, wind-toxin, and swelling. Grind and apply to the affected area. Pound, boil in lye water to form cakes, season with five flavors, and eat as a vegetable. Cooling in nature, it governs wasting-thirst.

**Pierces the Throat, Causing Bleeding When Raw**
**Producing Regions:** Wu and Shu
Leaves resemble *youba* and *banxia*; roots grow as large as bowls. Thrives in shady ground; seeds form where raindrops fall from the leaves. Also called *jǔruò*. Another variety, *banzhang*, has a similar appearance but bears upright flowers in autumn, producing red seeds. Its root is highly effective when applied to abscesses and toxic swellings. The root resembles *ruòtóu* but is fiercely toxic and inedible.
*Now appended.*

Su Song et al. note: **From *Ri Hua Zi*:**
*Banzhang* is an alternate name for *huzhang* (Tiger’s Cane), as described in the previous entry.

**From *Illustrated Classic*:**
*See under* Tiannanxing *(Arisaema).*

---

**Selfheal (*xiakucao*)**
**Producing Region:** Chuzhou
**Flavor:** bitter, acrid; cold; non-toxic. Governs alternating chills and fever, scrofula, rodent fistula, head sores, breaks up concretions, disperses goiter and bound *qi*, treats swollen feet and damp impediment, and lightens the body.
Also called *xiju*, *naidong*, or *yanmian*. Grows in the river valleys of Shu Commandery. Harvest in the fourth month. *Tugua* (Mongolian Snake Gourd) serves as its guiding herb.

**From *Tang Materia Medica* Annotation:**
This herb grows in marshes and lowlands. Its leaves resemble those of *xuanfu* (Inula). It sprouts in early spring, sends up spikes in the fourth month, and bears purple-white flowers like those of *danshen* (Salvia). By the fifth month, it withers. Found everywhere.

**From *Illustrated Classic*:**
*Xiakucao* grows in the river valleys of Shu Commandery; it is also found in the He, Huai, and Zhe regions. It emerges after the Winter Solstice, with leaves like *xuanfu*. Flowers bloom in the third and fourth months, forming purple-white spikes resembling *danshen* flowers; seeds also form in spikes. By the fifth month, it withers. Harvest in the fourth month.

**From *Essential Formulas for Universal Relief*:**
For liver deficiency with eye pain, incessant cold tears, sinew and vessel pain, and photophobia: *Bǔgān Sǎn* (Liver-Supplementing Powder) consists of half a liang of *xiakucao* and one liang of *xiangfuzi* (Cyperus), ground to powder. Take one *qian* per dose, mixed with aged tea. May be taken at any time.

**From *Extended Meanings*:**
*Xiakucao* is now also called *yuchou*. It sprouts in autumn and persists through winter without withering. In spring, it blooms with white flowers; by midsummer, it sets seed and then withers. Ancient formulas prescribe its charred ash for binding topical medicines. When young and tender, it may be eaten as a vegetable—first soaked, rinsed, and steeped to remove its bitter water—treating scrofula and rodent fistula.

*Yanrucao* is non-toxic. It governs unconscious bedwetting during sleep: char until black, grind to powder, and ingest one *fangcunbi* with water. It also treats hiccups. This is the grass found in swallows’ nests. Newly supplemented. Cited from Chen Cangqi and *Ri Huazi*.

**From *Thousand Gold Formulas*:**
For women suffering inexplicable bloody urine: burn the grass from a barbarian swallow’s nest into powder and take half a *qian* with wine. This also treats men.

**From Sun Zhenren’s *Dietary Prohibitions*:**
For sudden outbreaks of malignant sores on the waist—if first erupting near the heart with exudate—apply barbarian swallow’s nest powder mixed with water. Treatment must not be delayed, or the affliction will spread across the body and prove fatal.

*Yazhicao* is bitter in taste, greatly cold, and non-toxic. It governs miasmic malaria with alternating chills and fever, phlegm-rheum and clove sores, muscular obstructions and stagnation, infantile cinnabar toxins, feverish mania and epilepsy, abdominal distension and fullness, facial and bodily qi swelling, heat dysentery, snake and dog bites, and toxic sores such as carbuncles. Boiled with red adzuki beans, it drains water qi, damp impediment, and promotes urination. It grows in the lowlands of Jiangdong and Huainan. Its leaves resemble bamboo, reaching one or two *chi* in height.

The flowers are a deep jade-green, with pointed tips resembling a bird’s beak. Northerners call it *jishecao* ("chicken-tongue grass"), also known as *bizhuocao* ("nose-chopping grass"), while the people of Wu call it *zhi*. The names *zhi* and *zhuo* are phonetically similar. Another name is *bizhuzi* ("jade bamboo"). Its flowers yield an excellent dye.

*Newly supplemented, recorded in Chen Cangqi’s work and the *Rihuazi*.*

**Shancigu root** (*Mountain Water-Chestnut Root*)
Slightly toxic. Governs carbuncles, sores, fistulas, scrofula, and nodular swellings. Grind with vinegar and apply as a poultice. It also peels facial skin and removes blemishes and dark spots. Grows in damp mountain areas. Another name is *jindeng hua* ("golden lantern flower"). Its leaves resemble those of *cheqian* (plantain), and its root is like that of *cigu* (water-chestnut). In Lingling, there is also a variety called *tuancigu* ("round water-chestnut"), with roots resembling small garlic. Its applications are largely the same.

*Newly supplemented, recorded in Chen Cangqi’s work and the *Rihuazi*.*

**From the *Experiential Remedies*:**
For treating sores and swellings: Take *shancigu*—also called *luticao* ("deer-hoof grass")—and pound its stems and leaves into a paste. Mix with honey and apply over the sore. When clear blood is discharged, the treatment is effective.

**Qing** (*Abutilon*)
Flavor: bitter. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.

**Qing (Abutilon) Seed**
Governs red and white cold-heat dysentery; disperse by drinking. Swallow one *fen* to break abscesses and swellings.

*Tang Materia Medica* annotation: The character may also be written as □. People use its bark to make rope.

Now, according to the *Alternative Edition* annotation: Today, people use it to make cloth, rope, and □-hemp. Its seeds resemble those of hemp. For heat-binding abscesses without a head, applying it will form a head at the site.

Harvest the seeds in the ninth and tenth months; dry in the shade. First appended in the *Tang Materia Medica*.

Yu Xi et al. note: The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica from Shu* states: It is a shrub, growing four *chi* tall. Its leaves resemble those of ramie, its flowers are yellow, and its seed husks resemble those of *shukui* (hollyhock). The seeds are black. Ancient formulas used the root. Harvest the seeds in the eighth month.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: *Qingshi* (abutilon seed) was not previously recorded as originating from any specific region; today, it is found everywhere. Northerners cultivate it for weaving cloth and making rope. The plant grows four to five *chi* tall, sometimes six to seven *chi*. Its leaves resemble those of ramie but are thinner, its flowers are yellow, and its seeds are encased in husks like those of hollyhock, with black seeds inside. Harvest the seeds in the ninth and tenth months; dry in the shade for use. Ancient formulas also used the root.

From *Yang’s Obstetrics and Pediatrics*:
For treating red and white dysentery: Take one *liang* of *qingma* seeds, stir-fry until fragrant and cooked, then grind into powder. Take one *qian* with honeyed water; no more than two doses are needed.

---

**Chiche Shizhe (Red Chariot Messenger)**
Flavor: acrid, bitter. Nature: warm, toxic.
Governs wind-cold evil *zhu*, *gu* toxins, abdominal masses, and qi accumulations in the five viscera.

*Tang Materia Medica* annotation: Its seedlings resemble *xiangru* (mosla) and *lanxiang* (eupatorium). Its leaves and stems are red, its roots are purple-red. It grows in the shady areas of mountain streams, found in Xiangzhou. Harvest the roots in the eighth and ninth months; dry in the sun.

First appended in the *Tang Materia Medica*.

Yu Xi et al. note: The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica from Shu* states: Its roots are purple like those of *qiancao* (madder). It grows in the mountain valleys of Xingzhou and Xiangzhou. Harvest in the second and eighth months.

The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: *Chiche Shizhe* is slightly toxic. It treats malign wind and cold qi, and when taken, it brightens the skin and complexion.

Lei Gong states: *Chiche Shizhe* was originally called *xiaojinzhi* ("small brocade branch"). For all applications, coarsely pound it, mix with the urine of a seven-year-old boy, steam until dry, then sun-dry. For every five *liang* prepared, use one *yi* of children’s urine as the standard measure.

---

**Langbazi (Wolf’s Step Seed)**
Slightly toxic.
Governs malign sores, scabies, and ringworm; kills worms and fish.

Tao Hongjing states: It comes from Jiaozhou and Guangzhou, and its shape is flat. Pound it and mix with rice, then cast into water—fish of all sizes will float to the surface dead. People also grind it with vinegar to treat scabies, which is effective.

*Tang Materia Medica* annotation: Today, in the capital, it is called *huanghuanzi* ("yellow ring seed"), also known as *dugu* or *jiuge*. Tao Hongjing says it comes from Jiaozhou and Guangzhou, but today, what Jiaozhou and Guangzhou send to the Imperial Sacrificial Bureau is precisely *huanghuanzi*—no other substance.

Now, according to the *Alternative Edition* annotation: Flavor: bitter. Nature: cold. It is a vine with purple flowers.

---

**Wuyou (Roof Wanderer)**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: cold.
Governs floating heat in the skin, alternating chills and fever, and promotes the flow of qi in the small intestine and bladder.

Grows on the shady sides of roofs. Harvest in the eighth and ninth months.

Tao Hongjing states: This is the green mossy growth on tiled roofs; peel and boil it for consumption.

Now, according to the *Alternative Edition* annotation: Non-toxic. Treats childhood convulsions, heat from seasonal qi, vexation, and thirst.

Yu Xi et al. note: The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica from Shu* states: It is the green mossy growth on the northern, shady side of roofs.

---

**Dijin Grass (Chuzhou)**

**Dijin Grass (Chuzhou)**
Flavor: pungent. Non-toxic.
Governs the free flow of blood in the vessels and may also be used to treat qi. Grows in fields and wilds near roads; that from Chuzhou is especially fine. Its stems and leaves are slender and weak, spreading across the ground. The stems are red, the leaves greenish-purple, and it flourishes in mid-summer. In the sixth month, it blooms with red flowers and bears fine seeds. The seedling and seeds are used.

The *Materia Medica* annotation under *Luoshi* (Trachelospermum) mentions *Dijin*, which is a type of vine; though the name is the same, the species is entirely different. Newly determined.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: *Dijin Grass* grows in Chuzhou and in fields and wilds near roads. Flavor: pungent. Non-toxic. Governs the free flow of blood in the vessels and also treats qi. Its seedling and leaves are slender and weak, spreading across the ground. The stems are red, the leaves greenish-red, and it flourishes in mid-summer. In the sixth month, it blooms with red flowers and bears fine seeds. Physicians today use the seedling and seeds.

The *Materia Medica* annotation under *Luoshi* (Trachelospermum) mentions *Dijin*, which shares the same name but is a different species.

The *Tested Prescriptions* states: To treat intestinal toxins with red and white dysentery, gather *Dijin Grass*, wash it, dry it in the sun, and grind it into powder. Take one *qian* with rice water; it is immediately effective.

*Baichuanru* (Pronounced *ru*, level tone).

The herb governs incessant flooding in women, unceasing vomiting of blood, and dysentery with bloody flux.

Tao Hongjing states: This refers to the large *fubu* (cut and scraped bamboo shavings used to plug leaks). Boil the dried shavings, or burn them into powder and take it.

*The Thousand Gold Prescriptions*: To treat women’s involuntary urination with no awareness of discharge, grind old *chuanru* into powder and take three *qian* with wine.

*The Secret Records of the Mother and Child*: To treat spontaneous bloody urine, take dried powder of old bamboo shavings from the handle of a utensil, three *qianbi* with wine, three times daily.

**Rush (Dengxincao)**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: cold. Non-toxic. The root and seedling govern the five types of strangury. Boil and take fresh. Grows in Chuzhou, Jiangnan. The stem is round and long. People weave it into mats; boiling and taking the mat is even more effective. Now appended.

*The Tested Prescriptions*: To treat night crying in infants, burn the herb to ash, apply to the breast, and let the child nurse.

*The Victorious Gold Prescriptions*: To treat open wounds, chew many rush stems thoroughly, mix with saliva, and apply; wrap with cloth, and the bleeding will immediately cease.

Another formula: To treat small insects or ants that have entered the ear and cannot be removed, soak rush in oil and use it to fish out the insect.

*Extended Meanings* states: Rush also grows in Shaanxi. When steamed and dried, the pith is stripped out for lamp wicks—this is called "cooked grass." There is also unsteamed rush, simply dried and peeled, called "raw grass." Raw grass is suitable for medicinal use.

**Five-Poison Grass**
Flavor: sour. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic. The root governs carbuncles, deep-rooted ulcers, toxic swellings, red and white wandering erysipelas, and bites from insects, silkworms, snakes, and dogs. Grind with vinegar and apply to the affected area, or pound the stem and leaves for application. To prevent toxins from entering the abdomen, boil and take it internally. Grows in flatlands of Jiangdong. The flowers and leaves resemble buckwheat; the root is hard and tight like *gouji*. Also called *wují*, *shewang*. There is also another *canwang* grass, resembling ramie, sharing the same name. Newly supplemented. Recorded by Chen Cangqi.

**Mouse-Ear Cudweed (Shuqucao)**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic. Harmonizes the center, augments qi, checks diarrhea, dispels phlegm, suppresses seasonal qi, and relieves heat-induced cough. Mixed with rice flour to make cakes, it is sweet and delicious. Grows in fertile flatlands, over a foot tall, with leaves covered in white hairs and yellow flowers.

*The Annual Records of Jing and Chu* states: On the third day of the third month, take the juice of mouse-ear cudweed, mix with honey to make powder, called *longshe* □, to suppress seasonal qi. People in Shannan call it *xiangmao*; the flowers are mixed with *ju* bark to dye brown, remaining bright even when worn. People in Jiangxi call it *shuercao*. Newly supplemented. Recorded by Chen Cangqi and *Rihuazi*.

**Listed Plant (Liedang)**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: warm. Non-toxic. Governs the five taxations and seven injuries in men, supplements the waist and kidneys, enables offspring, and dispels wind and blood. Boil or steep in wine for consumption. Grows on rocky cliffs in the southern mountains, resembling lotus root. Harvest when newly sprouted and dry in the shade. Also called *lidang* or *grass cistanche*. Now appended.

*The Mirror of Food and Medicine* states: It governs the arousal of yang affairs. Take two *jin* of *lidang* (also called *liedang*), pound and sift into powder, steep in one *dou* of wine overnight, and drink as desired.

---

**Horse Fungus (Mabo)**
Flavor: acrid. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic. Governs malign sores and equine scabies. Also called *mapi*. Grows in long-rotten places in gardens.

Tao Yinju states: Common folk call it *mapibo*. Purple, soft, and hollow, resembling a dog’s lung; when flicked, powder emerges. Applied to sores, it is highly effective.

Yu Xi et al. note: *The Illustrated Classic of the Shu Materia Medica* states: This is the *mapi* fungus. Soft and hollow like purple floss, it releases purple dust when flicked. Grows in damp earth and on rotten wood; harvest in summer and autumn.

*Extended Meanings* says: Horse fungus—this is what Han Tuizhi of the Tang referred to as "cow’s urine and horse fungus, both gathered and stored." Some grow as large as a *dou*, others as small as a ladle. Remove the membrane, knead with honey, mix with a little water, and sip to treat throat closure and sore throat.

---

**Clog Ash (Jixie)**
Drinking the ash of clog straps in water governs choking, heart pain, and chest fullness.

Now note: *The Alternative Edition* annotates: Clogs and straps exist in Jiangnan; northerners do not recognize them. They are made of paulownia wood for clogs and straps, with rushes woven into soles and hemp threaded through the nose. Those worn long enough to rot are suitable for medicinal use.

Yu Xi et al. note: *The Illustrated Classic of the Shu Materia Medica* states: Take those worn until nearly rotted and broken, and consume with water for good effect.

---

**Blood Resin (Zhihan)**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: warm. Non-toxic. Governs sword wounds, fractures, and internal blood stasis; supplements sinews and flesh; disperses malign blood; descends blood and qi; and treats postpartum blood congealment, abdominal pain, internal cold, and loss of appetite in women. Dissolve in wine and consume, or apply externally to the affected area. Originates from the Western Regions, resembling congealed blood. The foreigners prepare it by decocting licorice, pine resin, *chengru*, and rehmannia with hot blood. Now appended.

Chen Cangqi states: The foreigners test the medicine by severing a child’s foot, placing the medicine in its mouth, and having the child tread upon the foot—if it can walk immediately, the medicine is excellent.

---

**Water Smartweed (Shuiliao)**
Governs snake venom. Pound and apply as a poultice. Squeeze the juice and consume to stop snake venom from entering the heart and causing suffocation. Boil in water to soak and rub the feet, dispersing qi swelling.

*The Tang Materia Medica* annotates: The leaves resemble smartweed, the stems are red, and the flavor is acrid. Grows in low, damp areas near water.

Now note: *The Alternative Edition* annotates: Grows in shallow water and marshes, hence the name *water smartweed*. Its leaves are larger than those of common smartweed. Kneading and eating it in water is superior to smartweed seeds.

Yu Xi et al. note: *Rihuazi* states: Water smartweed—flavor acrid, nature cold, non-toxic.

*Collected Effective Formulas*: To treat foot pain, boil water smartweed into a decoction, adjust to a warm temperature, and repeatedly pour and wash. When the sores dry, they will naturally heal.

---

**Water Grass (Youcao)**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: greatly cold. Non-toxic. Governs damp impediment and disperses water qi. Boil with adzuki beans and consume, but do not add salt. Governs beriberi, stubborn impediment, vacuity swelling, lower abdominal tension, and reddish, rough urination. Pound the leaves and apply to toxic swellings. Also, squeeze the juice and consume to govern wasting-thirst. Grows in paddy fields, resembling knotgrass with long leaves. Horses eat it.

*The Erya* states: *You* is *manyu*. The annotation says: Grows in water; people in Jiangdong call it *you*.

*Evidence and Customs* states: *You* is a water grass.

Now supplemented. Recorded by Chen Cangqi.

*Extended Meanings* says: *You* grass—*The Erya* states: *Qiu* (pronounced *you*), *manyu*. *The Zuo Tradition* also says: "One whiff of fragrance, one whiff of *you*—even after ten years, the stench lingers." This is the grass.

---

**Decayed Reed Screen (Baimangbo)**
Non-toxic.

**Decayed Reed Screen (Baimangbo)**
Governs postpartum blood fullness with abdominal distension and pain, blood-thirst, persistent lochia, menstrual block, stanches reckless bleeding, discharges malign blood, and dispels ghostly qi, enduring pain, and congealed accumulations. Boil in wine and consume. Also, burn to ash and take with wine; those long exposed to smoke are best. Nowadays, easterners make screens from it, often using grass. *The Erya* states: *Mang* resembles cogongrass and can be made into rope. Now supplemented. Recorded by Chen Cangqi.

**Dog’s-Tongue Grass**
Bitter, cold, slightly toxic.
Governs gu-poison, scabies, itchy sores, and kills small worms. *Tang Materia Medica* annotation says: Leaves resemble plantain, without veins, sending up stems with fine yellow-white flowers, growing in clusters along ditches and damp ground. Now according to *Alternative Text* annotation: Scabies, itchy wind-sores, and all such afflictions have worms. Grind to powder, mix, and apply—immediately effective. Collect stems in the fourth and fifth months; dry in the sun. First appended in *Tang Materia Medica*.

**Sea Gold Sand (Haijinsha)**
From Qianzhou.
Governs free flow through the small intestine. Combined with gardenia, mirabilite, and borax, treats heat mania in cold damage. Produced in Qianzhong Prefecture. Harvest in the seventh month.

**Sea Gold Sand (Haijinsha)**
Grows in small clumps, barely one or two *chi* in height. Harvest the entire plant and dry in the sun until slightly desiccated. Place on paper, strike with a staff, and fine sand will fall onto the paper; gather it at once. Repeat drying and striking until no more sand remains. May be used in pills or powders. Newly determined.

*The Illustrated Canon* states: Sea Gold Sand grows in the mountain valleys of Qianzhong; it is also found in Hunan. Initially forming small clumps, one or two *chi* tall. Harvested in the seventh month, dried in the sun, then placed on paper and struck to collect the sand, which falls onto the paper. Dry and strike repeatedly until the sand is exhausted. Governs free flow through the small intestine and is also used in medicines for heat mania in cold damage. Current physicians treat urinary stoppage with abdominal fullness and oppression using the following formula: one *liang* of Sea Gold Sand and half a *liang* of wax-sealed tea, ground finely together. Take three *qian* per dose, decocted with fresh ginger and licorice, without regard to time; if unrelieved, take again.

**Daylily (Xuancaograss)**
Cool, non-toxic.
Treats strangury with sandy urine, drains water qi, and governs wine-yellowing, where the entire body turns yellow.
