The black variety governs red and white uterine discharge in women, blood diseases, concretions and conglomerations, yin pain, alternating yin-yang cold and heat, infertility, and regulates menstrual irregularity.
The yellow, ripe, and aged white variety checks enduring diarrhea, augments qi, and prevents hunger.
The golden variety treats aggregation-illness from rheum retention, abdominal pain, and metal-inflicted wounds.
Also called *sangjun* (mulberry fungus); another name, *mumai* (wood wheat). *Shu Ben Cao* writes *jun* (phonetic: *xun*, *quan* cut).
The five-tree ear, called *nou* (pronounced *ruan*), augments qi, prevents hunger, lightens the body, and strengthens the will.
Grows in the mountain valleys of Jianwei. Harvest in the sixth month during frequent rains, then dry thoroughly in the sun.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: The white root-bark of the mulberry is not recorded in the *Shen Nong Ben Cao* as originating from any specific region, yet it is found everywhere today. It may be harvested at any time, though the portion exposed above ground must not be used. The bark from roots growing eastward is especially efficacious. Some say the white bark of the tree itself may also be used. When first harvested, strip away the coarse outer layer with a bronze knife, then take the inner white portion, slice it, and dry it over a slow fire. The green sap within the bark must not be scraped away, for the medicinal potency resides therein. It is averse to iron and lead and must not be brought near them.

Mulberry leaves regrown in summer and autumn are of the highest quality; gather them after frost. Boiling them into a decoction to soak the hands and feet dispels wind-bi syndrome with remarkable efficacy.

Sang’er, also called sanghuang, includes both the yellow, ripe, aged white variety and the golden variety, all of which may be used. Crush and steep them in wine to treat vaginal discharge. The fruit, *shen* (mulberry), comes in white and black varieties; dry them thoroughly in the sun. Both restore black hair.

The white lichen on the bark, as well as the flowers (also called mulberry flowers, resembling *Marchantia*), may be shaved off with a knife, stir-fried until dry, and used to stanch nosebleeds, vomiting of blood, and similar conditions. The ash from burning mulberry wood, steeped in water to extract its juice, is also frequently employed in medicine.

The insects found on mulberry trees treat sudden heart pain and insufficient flesh in metal-inflicted wounds. The white sap from the bark cures infantile mouth sores; apply it directly for immediate healing. It also relieves dry pain from wounds inflicted by metal blades. After the bleeding stops, peel off the white bark and bind it over the wound, allowing the sap to enter, which is highly effective. The root bark is equally efficacious in winter.

White bark fibers may be spun into thread to suture wounds where the intestines have prolapsed, then coated with hot chicken blood. During the Tang dynasty, An Jinzang used this method after disemboweling himself and recovered swiftly.

The *Immortal Classic* states: "No elixir of immortality may be ingested without first decocting it with mulberry." This is recorded in the *Baopuzi*. Tao Hongjing notes: "Eastward-growing mulberry roots are easy to obtain, but those near riverbanks often emerge from the soil and should not be lightly trusted."

The *Duan Gu Fang* (Grain-Abstention Formula) refers to *mu nou* (wood ear) as *sang shang jisheng* (mulberry mistletoe), while here it is called *wu mu er* (five-tree ear), though the other four trees are not specified. Old mulberry trees produce dry ears—yellow, red-white, and, during frequent rains, soft and moist ones. People gather these to make pickled vegetables, but they are no longer used medicinally.

Chen Cangqi states: Mulberry leaf juice treats cholera with abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. In winter, use dried leaves, boiling them thickly and drinking the decoction. The white sap, extracted by grinding, may be applied to metal-inflicted wounds and infantile lip sores. Finely chop the leaves and decoct them in a large cauldron until they resemble red sugar; this dispels chronic wind and stagnant blood. Leaves with forked branches, called *jisang* (chicken mulberry), are most suitable for medicinal use.

Mulberries benefit the five viscera and joints, unblock the blood and qi, and, when taken over time, prevent hunger. Gather a large quantity and dry them thoroughly in the sun. Pound them into powder, mix with honey, and form into pills. Taking sixty pills daily restores black hair and prevents aging.

Ma Zhi notes: According to the *Yaoxing Lun*, mulberry white bark is a neutral assistant. It treats lung qi panting and fullness, water qi edema, severed injuries, promotes water pathways, disperses water qi, alleviates deficiency taxation with guest heat, headaches, and internally supplements insufficiency.

Sang’er, also called *sangju* or *sanghuang*, is sweet and pungent, non-toxic. It treats women’s flooding and spotting, menstrual blockage with blood stasis, postpartum blood stasis, and men’s *xuanpi* (abdominal masses). It also governs hidden blood and discharges of red blood.

Meng Shen states: Decoct mulberry root white bark and drink the juice to benefit the five viscera. It may also be used in powdered formulas to dispel all wind qi and water qi. Mulberry leaves, roasted and decocted like tea, quench thirst.

*Rihua Zi* states: Mulberry white bark is warm. It harmonizes the center, descends qi, augments the five viscera, dissolves phlegm, stops thirst, promotes urination and defecation, stimulates the appetite, expels abdominal parasites, and checks cholera with vomiting and diarrhea. This refers to the root bark of mountain mulberry.

It also states: Sang’er is warm and slightly toxic. It stanches intestinal wind with bloody diarrhea and treats women’s heart and abdominal pain.

Lei Gong states: For medicinal use, select tender roots from the east side of trees over six years old. After harvesting, strip the thin yellow outer layer with a bronze knife, retaining only the second layer—the white, tender portion with green sap. Chop it on a locust wood block with a bronze knife, then dry it over a slow fire. Do not let the sap on the bark fall away, for the sap is the source of the medicinal power. This medicine is averse to iron and lead.

*The Sagely Benefit Formulas*: To treat severe wind with loss of facial and scalp hair, steep mulberry wood ash in hot water to extract the juice and wash the head and face. Rinse with soybean water to neutralize the alkaline taste of the ash, which is even better. Then, use warm water mixed with mung bean flour to cleanse thoroughly. No more than ten applications are needed for efficacy. Wash the head every three days and the face daily.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: To treat hemiplegia and all wind disorders, chop one large *sheng* of mulberry branches (using this year’s new, tender shoots) and decoct in one large *dou* of water until reduced to two large *sheng*. In summer, submerge the decoction in a well to prevent souring. Drink one cup daily on an empty stomach until finished. Continuous decoction and consumption prevent hemiplegia for life. For wind prevention, consuming one large *sheng* is even better.

Another formula: For the five types of hemorrhoids, prepare sang’er as a thick soup and consume it on an empty stomach with rice until full, three times daily. When the hemorrhoidal orifices suddenly ache like a crow’s pecking, take one *sheng* each of large and small beans, pound them together, steam them in two pouches, and alternately sit on them while hot to cure the condition.

*The Thousand Gold Formulas*: For mouth sores with white patches, first wipe the mouth with hair, then apply mulberry tree sap.

*The Handbook of Emergency Remedies*: For frequent nosebleeds in children, even with slight exertion, roast sang’er until charred, pound it into powder, and insert apricot kernels into the nostrils during bleeding episodes. Several applications will suffice.

*The Master Ge Formulas*: For sudden excessive urination and wasting-thirst, dig three *chi* into the earth to obtain mulberry roots, peel off the white bark, roast until yellow-black, chop, and boil in water to make a thick decoction. Drink freely, or add a small amount of rice, but no salt. Another formula: For incessant postpartum bleeding, roast mulberry white bark and boil in water to drink.

*The Master Mei Formulas*: For edema with inability to sit or lie down, and swelling of the head, face, and entire body, take eastward-growing mulberry branches, burn to ash, leach with water to obtain the liquid, and boil red adzuki beans in it. Eat on an empty stomach until full, and when hungry, consume all without eating rice. Another formula: To relieve pain from metal-inflicted wounds, grind mulberry firewood ash and apply to the wound; excellent.

*The Tested Formulas*: For severe coughing, sometimes with bright red blood in the sputum, take one *jin* of mulberry root white bark, soak in rice-washing water for three nights, thoroughly scrape off the yellow outer layer, chop finely, add four *liang* of glutinous rice, and dry by baking. Grind together into powder. Take one or two *qian* each time, mixed with rice water.

*The Later Tested Formulas*: For lung-toxic sores resembling severe *da feng* disease, *Green Cloud Powder*: Use high-quality mulberry leaves, wash clean, steam thoroughly for one night, then sun-dry and grind into powder. Take two *qian* mixed with water.

*The Guangji Formulas*: For unremitting bloody diarrhea, take one large *liang* of mulberry ear, roast until black, add one large *sheng* and three *ge* of water, decoct to six large *ge*, strain, and divide into three warm doses to be taken on an empty stomach.

*The Minister Qian’s Formulas*: For centipede and spider venom, apply mulberry white bark juice; effective.

*The Secret Records for Mother and Child*: For incessant bleeding after miscarriage, burn mulberry wood borers into powder and take one *fangcunbi* with wine, twice daily.

*The Immortal’s Formulas*: When mulberries are ripe, harvest and sun-dry them. Grind into powder, mix with honey, and form into pills the size of *tong* seeds. Take forty pills with wine on an empty stomach; long-term use is beneficial.

*The Amplification of the Materia Medica* states: The uses of mulberry in the section on mulberry root white bark are somewhat comprehensive, yet the black mulberry fruit is uniquely omitted—this is where the essence of mulberry resides. Harvest the fruit, lightly grind, strain through cloth to remove dregs, and simmer in a stone vessel to a thin paste. Measure the quantity, add honey, and simmer again to a thick paste. Store in a porcelain container. Take one or two *qian* each time, after meals and before bed, dissolved in boiling water. It treats heat and thirst from mineral drug consumption, invigorates the spirit, and clears small intestinal heat; its nature is mildly cooling.

□ Bamboo Leaf
□ bamboo leaf (□ pronounced *jin*), bitter in taste, neutral and greatly cold, non-toxic. It governs coughing, counterflow qi ascent, muscle spasms, severe sores, kills small worms, eliminates vexing heat, wind tetany, throat impediment, and vomiting. The root, made into a decoction, boosts qi, stops thirst, supplements deficiency, and descends qi; it resolves toxins. The juice governs wind tetany. The fruit connects with the spirit and luminous powers, lightens the body, and augments qi. It grows in Yizhou.

*Dan* bamboo leaf, acrid in taste, neutral and greatly cold. It governs phlegm-heat in the chest and coughing with counterflow qi ascent. The sap is greatly cold; it treats sudden windstroke, wind impediment, great heat in the chest, and stops vexation and oppression. The inner skin is mildly cold; it governs retching, warm qi, alternating chills and fever, blood ejection, flooding and spotting, and muscle spasms. Bitter bamboo leaf and sap treat mouth sores, eye pain, brighten the eyes, and free the nine orifices.

Bamboo shoots (*Shu Ben* records as "all shoots"), sweet in taste, non-toxic. They govern wasting-thirst, disinhibit the water pathways, and augment qi; they may be taken long-term.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: □ bamboo, *dan* bamboo, and bitter bamboo are not recorded in the *Shen Nong Ben Jing* as to their places of origin; today, they grow everywhere. There are many types of bamboo, but only these three are used medicinally, and people often cannot distinguish them fully. According to the *Bamboo Treatise*, the character □ is pronounced *jin*; this bamboo is sturdy with short internodes, round in body and firm in texture, its skin white as frost. Large specimens are suitable for boat construction, while slender ones can be made into flutes. However, today’s boat-building bamboo is mostly *gui* bamboo, and the flutes are made from another type, not called □ bamboo.

There are two kinds of bitter bamboo: one grows in Jiangxi and Fujian, with very thick and large culms; its shoots are extremely bitter and inedible. The other grows in Jiangzhe and is also found nearby; it has thick flesh and long, broad leaves, and its shoots are slightly bitter. Commonly called "sweet-bitter shoots," they are the most prized for food, yet they are not known to be used medicinally.

*Dan* bamboo has thin flesh and powder between its nodes. Southerners use it to extract bamboo sap, and physicians exclusively use this type, which aligns closely with the *Bamboo Treatise*’s description with minor differences. Bamboo fruit is no longer used today. Tao Yinju said: Among the many types of bamboo, the preceding entry refers to □ bamboo, followed by *dan* bamboo and bitter bamboo. Another thin-shelled variety is called *gan* bamboo leaf, which is the finest. There are also *shi zhong* bamboo and *huang* bamboo, both prized for their shoots but unused in medicine. For extracting bamboo sap, only *dan* bamboo, bitter bamboo, and □ bamboo are used.

Bamboo fruit grows in Lantian; in Jiangdong, it flowers but bears no fruit. Recently, however, it has borne fruit in patches, resembling small wheat and suitable for making congee. Yuxi said: According to the *Drug Properties Treatise*, *dan* bamboo leaf is sweet and non-toxic; it governs blood ejection, heat-toxic wind, and suppresses mineral drug toxicity, treating wasting-thirst. Bamboo sap treats sudden windstroke with loss of speech; bitter bamboo treats red eyes. It also states: Green bamboo shavings, as an assistant, are sweet; they stop lung atrophy with blood-spitting, nosebleed, and treat the five types of hemorrhoids.

*Rihuazi* said: *Dan* bamboo and its root are sweet, cold, and non-toxic; they dissolve phlegm, treat heat mania with vexation and oppression, windstroke with loss of speech, strong fever and headache, dizziness with falling in pregnant women, stop fright palpitations, and treat epidemic confusion. For children’s fright epilepsy and upward-staring eyes.

The stem and leaves are used together.

It further states: Bitter bamboo is bitter, cold, and non-toxic. It treats insomnia, stops wasting-thirst, resolves alcohol toxicity, eliminates vexing heat, induces sweating, and treats windstroke with loss of speech. When rendered into sap, its functions are the same as *dan* bamboo.

Meng Shen said: Bamboo shoots are cold. They govern counterflow qi, eliminate vexing heat, but may also stir qi and provoke cold disorders—thus they should not be eaten in excess. In Yue, there are *lu* and arrow shoots; fresh ones may be eaten in moderation, but old ones should not be consumed. Though *dan* bamboo and *zhongmu* shoots are delicious, they provoke back obstructions and leg qi.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library* states: For all cases of fractures, broken bones, or sores with swelling, one must be cautious to avoid drafts and excessive fanning. If struck by wind, it may induce tetanic convulsions with lockjaw, which can be fatal. If one has already been struck by wind and feels stiffness in the neck or tension throughout the body, this remedy should be taken immediately: drink two to three *sheng* of bamboo sap. If lockjaw has already set in, force the mouth open with an object to administer it. Avoid cold food, drink, and alcohol. Since bamboo sap is difficult to obtain in emergencies, one may bundle ten or so stalks together, burn them in the center, and collect the sap to save a life.

*The Thousand Gold Prescriptions* states: For seasonal qi lasting five or six days with unrelieved heart vexation and agitation, mix half a cup of bamboo sap with half a cup of fresh water, stir well, and take at any time.

*Master Sun’s Dietary Prohibitions* states: For sudden onset of unidentified malignant sores, burn bitter bamboo leaves, mix with egg yolk, and apply as a poultice.

*The Heart Mirror of Food Therapy* states: To regulate heart vexation and oppression, boost qi and strength, and quench thirst, cook bitter shoots thoroughly and eat freely. Bitter bamboo shoots also govern wasting-thirst, disinhibit the water pathways, downbear qi, and regulate shortness of breath due to wind-heat. Steam or boil and eat them. □ bamboo shoots govern wasting-thirst, wind-heat, boost qi and strength, and provoke eye qi; steam, boil, or stir-fry and eat freely.

*The Concise Prescriptions for Universal Relief* states: For head sores, burn large bamboo shoot husks into ash, measure the sore’s size, mix the ash with raw oil, and apply. Adding a small amount of greasy powder is excellent.

*A Book on Childbirth* states: To treat pregnancy accidents involving falls or sudden impacts causing pain, boil two *ge* of fresh green bamboo shavings in one *sheng* of good wine for three to five boils, and divide into three doses.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: All bamboos and their shoots are slightly cold in nature, so it is clear that their leaves share the same uses. *The Divine Farmer’s Classic* does not mention the properties of shoots or bitter bamboo; if rendering sap into oil, there is no need to be overly selective. Zhang Zhongjing’s *Bamboo Leaf Decoction* uses *dan* bamboo shoots, which are difficult to digest and do not benefit the spleen. A neighbor’s two-year-old child, left momentarily unattended, developed high fever, rough breathing, loss of appetite, excessive sleepiness, head tilting back, moaning, slight retching, closed eyes, and frequent fright—lasting three to five days. Physicians treated it as chronic fright wind, but the treatment was ineffective. By chance, the mother mistakenly administered a fright remedy containing croton seed, dissolving five pills the size of sesame seeds and feeding them to the child. After a while, the child vomited violently. The wet nurse inserted a finger and extracted an object lodged in the throat, about three *cun* long and as thick as a little finger—it was a dried arrow shoot that had been sun-drying on the steps three days prior. That night, all symptoms resolved, and the next day, only harmonizing qi remedies were used to restore health. Such was their difficulty in digestion.

*The Classic* states: "One who diagnoses by inquiry is called a skilled physician." Children cannot be questioned, making them difficult to treat; physicians must be meticulous.

Evodia (*wuzhuyu*) is acrid, warm, and greatly hot, with slight toxicity. It warms the center, downbears qi, stops pain, treats cough with counterflow, alternating chills and fever, eliminates damp impediment and blood block, expels wind evil, opens the interstices, dispels phlegm-cold, and treats twisting pain in the abdomen, all accumulations of cold repletion that do not disperse, malign influx, pain in the heart and abdomen, counterflow qi, and disinhibits the five viscera. The root kills the three worms. The white bark of the root kills pinworms, treats throat impediment, cough with counterflow, stops outflow diarrhea, indigestion, residual blood after women’s menstruation and childbirth, and cures white scaling. Another name is *yi*. It grows in the river valleys of Shanggu and Yuanju.

On the ninth day of the ninth month, harvest and dry in the shade.

*Polygonum* fruit serves as its guiding substance. It is incompatible with *danshen* (salvia), *xiaoshi* (niter), and *baie* (chalk), and is averse to *shiying* (quartz).

The *Illustrated Classic* states: *Wuzhuyu* grows in the river valleys of Shanggu and Yuanju, and is now found everywhere, particularly abundant in Jiangzhe and Shuhan. The tree reaches over a *zhang* in height, with greenish-blue bark. Its leaves resemble those of the *chun* tree but are broader and thicker, with a purplish hue. In the third month, it blooms with red-purple flowers. In the seventh and eighth months, it bears fruit resembling peppercorns; when young, they are faintly yellow, turning deep purple upon ripening. Harvest on the ninth day of the ninth month and dry in the shade.

The *Records of Local Customs* notes: The custom venerates the ninth day of the ninth month as "Upper Nine." By this day, *zhuyu* becomes intensely aromatic and deep red in color, so its clusters are plucked and worn in the hair, said to repel malign qi and endure the winter.

The *Continuation of Qi Xie’s Records* recounts: Huan Jing of Runan studied under Fei Changfang. Changfang told him, "On the ninth day of the ninth month, your household will face calamity. You must leave at once. Have each family member fill a crimson pouch with *zhuyu*, tie it to the arm, ascend a height, and drink chrysanthemum wine—this will avert disaster." Jing followed his instructions, and his entire family climbed a high mountain. Upon returning at dusk, they found their chickens and dogs dead all at once. Changfang, upon hearing this, said, "This has taken their place." Hence, people to this day ascend heights, drink wine, and wear *zhuyu* pouches on this day.

It is said that *zhuyu*’s qi tends to rise, as it pierces the diaphragm, and thus is not used as an ingested medicine.

Zhang Zhongjing treats vomiting with chest fullness using *Zhuyu Decoction*: one *sheng* of *wuzhuyu*, twenty jujubes, one large *liang* of fresh ginger, and one *liang* of ginseng. Boil in five *sheng* of water until three *sheng* remain. Take seven *ge* each time, three times daily. It also treats retching with drooling and headache.

Yu Xi states: According to the *Treatise on Medicinal Properties*, *wuzhuyu* is bitter, acrid, and greatly hot, with toxicity. It governs heart and abdominal ailments, cold accumulations, bound qi below the heart, intermittent heart pain, treats cholera with cramps, cold qi in the stomach, unbearable vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, cures generalized numbness and impediment, undigested cold food, and promotes the flow of qi in the large intestine. Its peeled bark treats lacquer sores, malign influx, stabbing pain in the abdomen, unchecked dysentery, and *cunbai* worms.

Meng Shen says: *Zhuyu* governs heart pain, downbears qi, and eliminates counterflow retching and visceral cold. Its bark also stops toothache. For those suffering from wind-itching pain, take one *sheng* of *zhuyu* and five *sheng* of clear wine, boil together, reduce to one and a half *sheng*, strain, and wash with the warm liquid. For deviation of the mouth due to wind-stroke with inability to speak, take one *sheng* of *zhuyu* and one *sheng* of clear wine, boil together for four or five simmerings. Take half a *sheng* of the cooled liquid three times daily; a slight sweat will bring relief. Caution: it dispels demonic influx qi. Those with open eyes should not consume it. For fish bones lodged in the abdomen causing stabbing pain, boil one cup of its juice and drink to stop the pain. For bones embedded in flesh that will not emerge, chew and apply as a poultice—the bone will rot and come out. For beriberi attacking the heart, mix with fresh ginger juice and drink; this is highly effective.

Lei Gong says: For processing, first remove the leaves, pits, and impurities. Wash in a large basin with salt water one hundred times to naturally eliminate saliva, then dry in the sun for use in pills and powders. For every ten *liang* to be processed, use two *liang* of salt, grind into powder, and add to four *dou* of east-flowing water. Wash in one hundred separate rinses for enhanced efficacy. If using vinegar, first bring the vinegar to a boil thirty times, then add the *wuzhuyu* and continue boiling until the vinegar is exhausted. Dry in the sun. For every ten *liang* used, employ one *yi* of vinegar as the standard measure.

The *Sagely Grace Formulary*: To treat yin-toxin cold damage with reversal cold of the limbs, apply a poultice. Mix one *sheng* of *zhuyu* evenly with wine, place in a silk bag, steam until extremely hot, and apply to the soles of the feet. When the qi flows smoothly and warmth is even, cease the poultice. Repeatedly proven effective.

The *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: The *Collected Verifications* moxibustion method for *zheng* (concretions): Crush three *sheng* of *zhuyu*, mix with wine, and boil until done. Wrap in cloth and apply as a poultice to the *zheng*. When cool, stir-fry and reapply in alternation. If the *zheng* shifts, follow it with the poultice until it dissipates. Another formula: To treat carbuncles, deep-rooted ulcers, and breast abscesses, pound one *sheng* of *zhuyu*, mix with bitter wine, and apply to the afflicted area.

The *Thousand Gold Formulary*: To treat *cunbai* worms, wash four *liang* of *wuzhuyu* root to remove soil, cut, and soak overnight in one *sheng* each of water and wine. Divide and take in two doses at dawn. For all *zhuyu* preparations, use fine roots from the northeast side, which are of superior quality. Those as thick as a finger or larger are unsuitable.

The *Supplement to the Thousand Gold Formulary*: For postpartum deficiency and emaciation, night sweats, and frequent shivering with aversion to cold, take a *zhuyu* the size of a chicken egg, soak in three *sheng* of wine for half a day, then boil and take.

The *Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*: To treat wind-stroke with inability to speak, boil one *sheng* each of fermented soybeans and *zhuyu* in five *sheng* of water until two *sheng* remain. Take gradually.

The *Tested Formulary*: For intolerable intermittent pain in the spleen’s original qi, take one *liang* each of *zhuyu* and peach kernels, stir-fry together until the *zhuyu* turns charred black, then discard the *zhuyu*. Remove the skins and tips from the peach kernels, grind finely, mix with three stalks of scallion (steamed until done), soak in wine, and take warm in three divided doses over three days.

The *Later Tested Formulary*: Supplement for water qi. Boil two *liang* of red *zhuyu* in rice vinegar until soft, grind into a paste, and form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take seven pills with pepper decoction on an empty stomach.

The *Military Ministry’s Handbook of Formulas*: To treat acid regurgitation, where sour qi rises like intoxication with vinegar.

One *ge* of *zhuyu*, three cups of water, decoct to seven-tenths, and take in one dose. Even if the decoction is thick, force it down.

*Master Yang’s Childbirth and Lactation Formulary*: To treat sudden heart pain from malign qi. Five *ge* of *wuzhuyu*, boil in three *sheng* of wine until bubbling three times, divide into three doses.

*Extended Meanings* states: *Wuzhuyu* must be steeped in boiling water to remove its bitter, acrid juice—this should be repeated six or seven times before use. Neither the main text nor the annotations, nor the annotations on medicinal methods, mention this; it is an omission. This substance descends qi most swiftly, but for those with deficient intestines, it will exacerbate the condition.

**Areca Nut**
Flavor: acrid; nature: warm; non-toxic.
Govern: disperses food stagnation, expels water, eliminates phlegm accumulations, kills the three worms and dormant corpse qi, and treats *cunbai* (tapeworm).
Grows in Nanhai.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Areca nut grows in Nanhai. Today, it is found in all prefectures beyond the Five Ridges. It grows as large as *guanglang*, reaching five to seven *zhang* in height, straight and branchless. Its bark resembles that of the green paulownia, and its nodes are like those of cinnamon bamboo. Leaves emerge at the crown, as large as pomegranate leaves, and also resembling those of the plantain. Its fruit forms in clusters, emerging from the leaves, surrounded by thorns like bramble needles, layered beneath. Each cluster contains several hundred fruits, shaped like chicken eggs, all encased in a husk. The flesh fills the husk, pure white. Its taste is bitter and astringent, but when chewed with *fuliu* vine and lime from tiled roofs, it becomes smooth and sweetly delicious. The people of Lingnan consume it as a fruit. Their custom holds that the southern lands are warm, and without this, one cannot dispel miasmic diseases. There are three or four varieties: one small and sweet-tasting, called mountain areca; another large, astringent, and with a large pit, called pig areca; the smallest is called *nazi*. Their functions are not said to differ. It is also said: those long and pointed with purple veins are called *bing*, while round and short ones are called *lang*; *bing* is weaker, *lang* stronger. Today, physicians no longer distinguish finely but consider those shaped like a chicken’s heart, with a stable base and no hollowness, and when split, displaying a brocade-like grain, to be the best. The "large-bellied" variety resembles areca nut, though its stem, leaves, roots, and trunk differ slightly. When harvested with the skin intact, it is called *dafubinglang*. Some say: true areca nut is difficult to obtain, and most of what is sold today is *dafu*. Tao Yinju states: There are three or four kinds. Those from Jiaozhou are small and sweet-tasting. Those from south of Guangzhou are large and astringent, with some having large pits, called pig areca. All are used medicinally. The smallest, called *nazi* by southerners and colloquially "areca grandchild," is also edible. The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: Fresh areca nut is extremely large, but after several days, it rots. Those brought north are first boiled in lye, then dried over fire to preserve them. The kernel treats abdominal distension; crushed raw and taken as powder, it unblocks the water and grain pathways. Applied to sores, it generates flesh and relieves pain. Burned to ash, it treats white sores at the corners of the mouth. Grows in Jiaozhou, Aizhou, and Kunlun. Yu Xi states: According to the *Drug Properties Treatise*, white areca nut is a sovereign herb, flavor sweet, greatly cold. It can disseminate and free the five viscera and six bowels of stagnation, break up hardness and fullness, descend water swelling, treat heart pain, and wind-blood accumulations. The *Overseas Materia Medica* states: Tao Hongjing says: that facing the sun is called areca nut, that facing shade is called *dafu*. Flavor astringent, warm, non-toxic. Governs running piglet and all qi that fails to disperse.

The *Treatise on Beriberi* states: Grind one piece in a cup of sandalwood cow’s urine and take warm on an empty stomach to treat beriberi with congested toxins, water swelling, and floating qi.

Master Lei says: For medicinal use, select those that are well-seated, firm in the core, with grain like flowing water; when broken open, the interior grain resembles brocade—these are excellent. Those that are half-white, half-black, or hollow at the core are not used medicinally. One must distinguish between *bing* and *lang*: those with a round head and short, bulging body are *lang*; those with a large body and coarse purple grain are *bing*. The *bing* has lesser potency, while the *lang* has greater potency. Before use, scrape off the base with a knife and cut finely. Do not expose to fire, lest it lose efficacy. If used after heating, it is better not to use it at all.

The *Sagely Benefit Formulas*: To treat fetal movement with lumbar pain attacking the heart or blood descent, grind one *liang* into powder, boil scallion whites into a thick decoction at any time, and take one *qianbi* mixed in.

The *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For beriberi that is neither cold nor hot, or for elderly or weak persons with abdominal fullness, grind areca nut kernel into powder and take one *fangcunbi* mixed in areca nut shell juice, tea, or fermented soybean juice—this is highly effective.

The *Tested Formulas*: To treat metal-inflicted wounds, apply a powder of white areca nut and a small amount of *huanglian*—this heals immediately.

The *Master Mei’s Formulas*: To treat sourness in the heart, finely grind four *liang* of areca nut and two *liang* of tangerine peel into powder. Take one *fangcunbi* with raw honey decoction on an empty stomach.

The *Sun Zhenren’s Dietary Prohibitions*: To treat vomiting, roast one white areca nut, mix with ten parts of toasted tangerine peel, grind into powder, and decoct in one cup of water down to half a cup to take.

The *Concise Aid for the Multitudes*: To treat long-standing worms in the viscera, roast half a *liang* of areca nut, grind into powder, and take one to two *qian* mixed in a decoction of scallion and honey on an empty stomach.

Another formula: To treat beriberi attacking the heart, grind one large chicken-heart-sized white areca nut into powder and take as a single dose mixed in half a cup of boys’ urine, fresh ginger juice, and warm wine.

The *Extensive Benefit Formulas*: To treat beriberi attacking the heart and abdomen with delirium and loss of consciousness, grind two *fen* of white areca nut kernel into powder. Divide into three doses and take on an empty stomach mixed in five *dahe* of warm urine, twice daily.

The *Imperial Pharmacy Formulas*: To treat phlegm and drool, take one *qian* of areca nut powder in plain hot water.

The *Extension of the Materia Medica* states: Areca nut is described in detail in two books. Nowadays, people also use the pointed, elongated variety in medicine, claiming it is swift and sharply effective. Repeated trials confirm this to be true.

**Gardenia**
Flavor bitter, cold to greatly cold, non-toxic. Governs evil qi in the five viscera, heat qi in the stomach, flushed face with wine blisters, white nasal scabs, red scabies sores, and treats red, painful, hot eyes; great heat in the chest, heart, large and small intestines; vexation and oppression in the heart; and heat qi in the stomach. Also called *mudan* or *yuetao*. Grows in the river valleys of Nanyang. Harvest the fruit in the ninth month and dry in the sun.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: Gardenia grows in the river valleys of Nanyang; today, it is found in all prefectures of the southern regions and western Shu. The tree reaches seven to eight *chi* in height. Its leaves resemble those of the plum but are thicker and harder, or resemble *chupu* seeds. In the second and third months, it produces white flowers, each with six petals, highly fragrant—commonly said to be the *zhanfu* of the Western Regions. In summer and autumn, it bears fruit resembling *hezi*, green when unripe and yellow when ripe, with deep red kernels inside. Harvest the fruit in the ninth month and dry in the sun. Southerners compete to cultivate it for profit. The *Treatise on Trade* says: "A thousand *shi* of *zhixi* is comparable to a household of a thousand chariots," speaking of its vast profit. There are two or three varieties: the mountain gardenia used in medicine is the *yuetao* mentioned in formula texts. Those with thin skin, round and small, with seven to nine ridges, are superior. The large, elongated ones are used for dyeing and are called *fushi* gardenia, unsuitable for medicinal use.

Zhang Zhongjing’s *Treatise on Cold Damage* and other renowned physicians throughout history use gardenia, *yinchen*, fermented soybeans, and licorice in decoctions to treat jaundice. They also use gardenia and rat droppings in decoctions to treat relapse after major illness, often curing with slight purgation. There are countless such formulas, too many to record in full.

Tao Yinju states: "It resolves jade and *zhi* toxins." It grows everywhere. There are also two or three slightly different varieties, with those having seven ridges being the finest. They are harvested after frost, though today they are all used for dyeing.

Yu Xi notes: According to the *Yaoxing Lun*, mountain gardenia eliminates *□* worm toxins, dispels heat-toxin wind, promotes the flow of the five types of strangury, treats *zhong’e* (sudden evil), unblocks the urine, resolves the five types of jaundice, brightens the eyes, cures seasonal illnesses, removes heat, and addresses wasting-thirst with dry mouth, as well as redness and swelling of the eyes.

Lei Gong says: In all cases, do not use the large ones, called *fushi* gardenia, as they are weak. Those resembling a sparrow’s brain, long and with nine red veins, are superior. For use, first remove the skin and fine hairs, then take the kernels, soak them in licorice water overnight, strain, dry over a fire, and grind them into a powder as fine as golden-red cinnabar.

The *Shiliao* states: To treat fresh blood in the stool, burn gardenia kernels to ash, mix one *qianbi* with water, and administer according to the patient’s size and condition.

The *Qianjin Fang*: For fire sores before they erupt, mix gardenia kernel ash with sesame oil and apply as a thick dressing. If the sore has already formed, burn white sugar to ash and dust it on to dry the wound, which will then heal.

The *Zhouhou Fang*: For cholera with abdominal distension and pain, vexation and fullness, shortness of breath, inability to vomit or purge, or cramping, burn fourteen gardenia fruits, grind them to powder, and take with hot water.

The *Meishi Fang*: For heat-toxin with bloody stool or flare-ups triggered by food, split thirty gardenia fruits, decoct in three *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains, strain, and take. Another formula: For relapse after heat illness due to early rising or overeating, decoct ten gardenia fruits in three *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains, strain, and take warm. Lie down to induce slight sweating. If food is not digesting, add three *liang* of rhubarb. Another formula: For relapse after cold damage due to intercourse, causing near-death, closed eyes, and inability to speak, decoct thirty gardenia fruits in three *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains, and take.

The *Shengjin Fang*: For dysentery during childbirth, burn gardenia fruits to ash, grind to a fine powder, and take one spoonful on an empty stomach with hot water. In severe cases, no more than five doses are needed.

Sun Shang’s *Formula #21*: For restlessness after diarrhea following cold damage, if pressing the area below the heart feels soft, it is vacuity vexation. Split fourteen gardenia fruits, add four *ge* of fermented soybeans, decoct the gardenia in four *sheng* of water until two and a half *sheng* remain, then add the soybeans and decoct further until one *sheng* remains. Strain, divide, and take twice. If vomiting occurs, do not take the remainder. Those with pus in their vomit should not take it; the condition will resolve once the pus is expelled.

The *Yanyi* states: Gardenia is used by Zhang Zhongjing to treat insomnia due to vacuity vexation after sweating, vomiting, or purging. In severe cases, the patient will toss and turn, with anguish in the heart; *Zhizi Chi Tang* (Gardenia and Fermented Soybean Decoction) is used. The vacuity precludes the use of rhubarb, as gardenia has a cold toxin. Though gardenia is cold and non-toxic, it treats heat qi in the stomach. After loss of blood or fluids, the organs lack nourishment, generating internal vacuity heat, which only this substance can dispel—a principle already established in Zhang Zhongjing’s *Treatise on Cold Damage*. It also treats lingering heat in the Heart channel with red, rough urination. Remove the skin, stir-fry gardenia, mix with equal parts rhubarb, forsythia, and honey-fried licorice, grind to powder, decoct two to three *qianbi* in water, and take. There is no case it does not cure.

**Purple Mineral (*Zikuang*) and Dragon’s Blood (*Qilin Jie*)**
Flavor: sweet, salty; nature: neutral, slightly toxic. Governs evil qi of the five viscera, vaginal discharge, stops pain, breaks up static blood, promotes flesh growth in metal wounds. These two substances are largely similar with minor differences.

Yu Xi notes: According to the *Rihua Zi*, purple mineral is non-toxic and can be melted to repair cracks in donkey or horse hooves. It also states: Dragon’s blood is warming and non-toxic. Combined with litharge, it is excellent. It treats all malign sores, scabies, and ringworm that do not heal; apply this medicine. Its nature is swift, so do not use excessively, as it may draw out pus.

The *Tujing* states: Dragon’s blood was not previously recorded as to its place of origin. Today, it comes from various southern foreign lands and Guangzhou. The tree grows several *zhang* tall, with a graceful, spreading canopy. Its leaves resemble cherry leaves but have three points.

Its resinous exudate flows from the wood, dripping down like malt syrup, hardening over time into *jie*—deep crimson as blood, hence called "dragon’s blood." It may be gathered at any season. That which tastes salty and reeks of fishiness is "sea-mother’s blood" and must not be used. True *jie* is faintly salty yet sweet, bearing the fragrance of gardenia.

Old accounts claim it closely resembles purple mineral, though they are distinct substances with differing efficacies. Now, according to Duan Chengshi’s *Youyang Zazu*: Purple mineral comes from Zhenla, where the locals call it *leque*. It also grows in Persia. The tree stands over a *zhang* tall, its branches dense and luxuriant, leaves resembling those of the pomelo or orange, evergreen through winter. In the third month, it blooms but bears no fruit. When mist, dew, or light rain moistens its branches, purple mineral forms.

Lei Gong states: For *qilin jie* (dragon’s blood), never substitute sea-mother’s blood, which closely resembles it but tastes salty and fishy. True *qilin jie* is faintly salty and sweet, with a gardenia-like aroma. To prepare, first grind it into a fine powder and sift thoroughly. When needed, incorporate it into pills, powders, or ointments as required—do not pound it with other medicines, lest it scatter as flying dust.

The *Shenghui Fang* prescribes: For postpartum blood dizziness with loss of consciousness and delirium, grind one *liang* of *qilin jie* into powder and take two *qianbi* mixed with warm wine as needed.

The *Guangli Fang* states: To stanch bleeding and pain from metal wounds, apply powdered *qilin jie*—it stops immediately.

The *Yanyi* notes: Purple mineral forms like rock sugar on slender branches, clustered and purplish-black. When crushed, it turns red. Today, it is used to make rouge for silk, though it has become rare.

---

**Borneo camphor and gharu oil**
Flavor: pungent, bitter; slightly cold (some say warm, neutral). Non-toxic.
Governs: evil *qi* in the heart and abdomen, wind-damp accumulations, deafness; brightens the eyes, removes redness and corneal opacity.

Borneo camphor comes from Polu (Borneo). It resembles white pine resin and has the scent of cedar; the clearest specimens are best. Those exposed to wind and sun for long periods—or resembling sparrow droppings—are inferior. It is said that storing it with glutinous (or non-glutinous) rice charcoal and *Abrus precatorius* seeds prevents evaporation.

Gharu oil treats deafness.

The *Tujing* states: Borneo camphor comes from Polu; today, only foreign merchants in the Southern Seas trade it. Legend holds the tree grows seven or eight *zhang* tall, six or seven *chi* in girth, resembling an aged cedar. Its branches spread, leaves round and white on the underside. The fruit resembles cardamom, the bark rough and scaly. The fragrance is the tree’s resin, like white pine resin with a cedar scent. Gharu oil is the clear liquid from the roots, also called *polu gao*.

Duan Chengshi’s *Youyang Zazu* records: The tree varies in girth—slender specimens yield Borneo camphor, found in the heartwood. Persians cut the tree to harvest it. Stouter trees produce gharu oil, which flows from the trunk; they carve a hollow to collect it. The two accounts largely agree with minor differences.

Today, much of the Borneo camphor from Hainan is processed into flakes by heating, often adulterated. For medicinal use, only the raw form is prized—resembling plum blossom petals, it is finest.

The *Tang Ben* commentary notes: The tree resembles cedar. Gharu oil is the clear resin from the roots, while Borneo camphor is the dried resin within the roots. The seeds resemble cardamom, the bark rough and scaly, the fragrance like Borneo camphor. Flavor: pungent. It particularly dispels foul *qi*, aids digestion, relieves distension and fullness, and freshens the breath.

Old texts say it comes from Polu, named after the country—it is cedar resin. Cedars grow in Jiangnan, but their resin has not been tested. Just as some regions lack resin, so too do some banana plants bear no fruit.

*Previously appended in the Tang Ben.*

**《Experiential Remedies》:** For treating sudden *zhongfeng* (wind-stroke) with eyes shut and jaw clenched, where no medicine can be administered—use the middle finger to apply powder and rub the teeth thirty to twenty times, focusing on the molars on both sides, and the mouth will open of itself. If medicine can then be given, grind equal parts *longnao* (Borneo camphor) and *tiannanxing* (arisaema) into powder, mix in a mortar, and prepare on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month at noon. Use from one *zi* (0.1 *qian*) to half a *qian*, called *Kaiguan San* (Mouth-Opening Powder).

**《Later Experiential Remedies》:** For treating seasonal epidemics with *wandou* (pea-like) sores or red sores that have not erupted, causing vexation, manic agitation, panting, delirious speech, or visions of ghosts and spirits—grind one *qian* of *longnao* finely, then gradually mix with fresh pig’s heart blood to form pills the size of *jitou* (foxnut) meat. Take one pill with *zicao* (lithosperm) decoction; the heart and spirit will settle, allowing sleep, and the sores will erupt and heal with proper rest.

**《Extended Meanings》** states: The entry on *longnao* does not fully align with what is described in *《Illustrated Classic》*. This substance greatly unblocks *guange* (diaphragm) heat obstruction. Its pure fragrance surpasses all other medicines, making it especially effective for adults and children with wind-phlegm blockage or sudden heat-stroke. However, it is not a medicine for regular use. Alone, its potency is weak, but as an adjuvant, it excels. It pairs well with tea, though excess will overpower the tea’s aroma—no fragrance in the world surpasses it.

In the Western *Moloduzha* country, within the borders of Southern India, grows *jiebuluo* incense. When dry, it resembles pine trunks with distinct leaves, emitting no fragrance when fresh. After drying and breaking it, the interior contains a fragrant substance resembling mica, clear as ice and snow—this is *longnao* incense. It is also found in the West.

**Shi Zhuyu (Edible Cornel):**
Flavor: pungent, bitter. Nature: greatly hot, non-toxic. Its functions are the same as *Wu Zhuyu* (Evodia), though slightly inferior. It is particularly effective for treating water *qi*.

**《Illustrated Classic》** states: *Shi Zhuyu* was not previously recorded by region. It shares the same functions as *Wu Zhuyu*, and some say it refers to the larger, long-stored grains of *zhuyu* that turn yellow-black and become edible. It is now found throughout the South and North. The tree grows very tall, some reaching a hundred *chi*. Its branches and stems are greenish-yellow, dotted with small white specks.

The leaves closely resemble those of sesame, and the flowers are yellow. The people of Shu call its seeds *ai zi*, likely referring to the *yì* mentioned in the *Book of Rites*—the name having been corrupted from *yuan ai* to *ai*. It is suitable for adding to soups, as it imparts a pungent fragrance, though it should not be consumed in excess, for overconsumption harms the eyes and causes hair loss. It may be gathered at any time.

The *Tang Materia Medica* notes: "Those with thin skins that split open are the genuine variety." Though called *shi zhuyu* ("edible cornel"), it is not suitable for heavy consumption.

Chen Cangqi states: *Shi zhuyu* dispels demonic influences and noxious insect poisons, invigorates *yang*, and relieves toothache caused by worms. It was first appended in the *Tang Materia Medica*. It further notes: "The *Classic* already records *Wu Zhuyu* as the variety with split-open mouths. While *zhuyu* grows throughout the South and North, the finest comes from Wu, hence the name. Both varieties are edible, but for medicinal use, the Wu variety is preferred."

Ma Zhi remarks: According to the *Drug Properties Treatise*, it is incompatible with fluorite. It treats cold-induced numbness, weakness in the lower back and legs, generalized piercing pain, intestinal wind, hemorrhoids, and kills the three intestinal parasites. It dispels deficiency cold.

Sun Zhenren’s *Dietary Prohibitions* states: "Do not consume it in the sixth or seventh months, as it harms the *qi* and induces sores."

---

**Wu Yi (Ulmus Fruit):**
Flavor: pungent. Nature: neutral, non-toxic. It governs perverse *qi* in the five viscera, disperses lingering warmth and toxins in the skin, bones, and joints, expels the three parasites, aids digestion, eliminates *cun bai* (tapeworm segments), and relieves wheezing and panting in the intestines. Alternative names: *wu shi*, *□□* (upper character pronounced *dian*, lower *tang*). It grows in the river valleys of Jin Mountains. The fruit is gathered in the third month and dried in the shade.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: *Wu yi* grows in the river valleys of Jin Mountains, though it is now also found in nearby regions. It generally resembles the elm but is somewhat smaller, and its fruit ripens earlier. This elm is larger, with a foul odor like *□*.

The *Erya · Explaining Trees* records: "*Wu gu*, its fruit is *yi*." Guo Pu comments: "*Wu gu* is *gu yu* (elm). It grows in the mountains, with round, thick leaves. When the bark is peeled and soaked, it yields a pungent, fragrant substance—this is *wu yi*."

The *Erya · Explaining Plants* further notes: "*Wu yi* is *sha jiang*." The annotation states: "Also called *bai kui*," which closely resembles the *Classic*’s alternative name *□* (pronounced *dian* *□* *tang*). Su Gong clarifies: "*Sha jiang* is a corruption of *□□*. However, *wu yi* (the plant) and *wu yi* (the elm fruit) are distinct—one is a herb, the other a tree. Perhaps their *qi* types are similar."

The fruit is gathered in the third month and dried in the shade. It is frequently used in parasite-killing formulas. Today, people often grind it into powder to season dishes, with aged specimens being superior. When stored, it is commonly preserved in salt, which degrades its *qi* and flavor. Such preparations are unsuitable for medicinal use and serve only as food.

The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: *Wu yi* is an assistant herb, with a bitter and pungent flavor. It governs accumulations of cold *qi*, abdominal *zheng* pain, and dispels wind in the muscles and joints that feels like crawling insects.

Tao Hongjing remarks: "Today, it comes only from Goryeo. It resembles elm pods, with a foul odor like *□*. People make it into a sauce for consumption. Its nature kills parasites, and it is placed among stored goods to repel moths, though its odor is objectionable."

Chen Cangqi states: It is made into a sauce for consumption. It treats the five poultry diseases and eliminates sores and ringworm. The variety with a strong odor is superior—this is the mountain elm.

Meng Shen notes: It governs perverse *qi* in the five viscera, skin, and limbs. For heat sores, pound it with lard and apply. For damp ringworm, mix it with white honey. For all sores, combine it with sandalwood-infused cow’s milk. Aged specimens are best. Consumed in moderation, it is beneficial, but excess causes heat and heart pain due to its pungency. It is especially suitable for consumption in autumn, and long-term use treats the five types of hemorrhoids and prevents all diseases.

The *Ri Hua Zi Materia Medica* states: It treats intestinal wind, hemorrhoids, fistulas, malignant sores, scabies, and ringworm.

The *Overseas Materia Medica* records: According to the *Huang[#28]zhou Record*, it grows in Da Qin (the Roman Empire) and is Persian *wu yi*. Flavor: pungent. Nature: warm, non-toxic. It treats cold dysentery, heart *qi*, kills parasites, relieves pain, and addresses women’s uterine wind deficiency and children’s *gan* diarrhea. It works well with chebule and cardamom.

The *Dietary Therapy* states: It disperses abdominal *qi* pain. Mixed with horse milk, it can treat ringworm. Made into a sauce, it is fragrant and delicious, with effects superior to elm pods. Aged specimens are best.

It also counteracts *zhong e* (sudden possession by malevolent spirits) and *gu* toxins.

The *Essential Secrets from the Imperial Library* states: For urgent *qi* in the bladder, it is suitable for descending *qi*. Mix *wu yi* with an equal portion of powdered salt, wrap in silk to the size of a jujube, and insert into the lower orifice. It may discharge turbid fluids and *qi*, with excellent results.

The *Thousand Golden Remedies* states: For parasites in the spleen and stomach causing pain upon eating, sallow complexion, and intermittent pain, this is invariably effective. Take two *liang* of *wu yi* kernels from Shizhou, stir-fry with wheat flour until yellow, grind into powder, and take one *qianbi* with rice broth at any time to cure.

The *Extended Materia Medica* says: There are two varieties of *wu yi*, large and small. Small *wu yi* is the elm pod. The kernels are kneaded and fermented into a sauce, with a particularly pungent flavor. For medicinal use, large *wu yi*—a distinct variety—should be employed. However, small *wu yi* sauces are often adulterated with other substances, so careful selection is necessary. It is indispensable for treating cold and slippery large intestines and excessive cold *qi*.

**Zhi Qiao (Bitter Orange Peel)**
Flavor: bitter, sour. Nature: slightly cold, non-toxic. It governs wind itching and numbness, facilitates joint movement, treats consumptive *qi* cough, fatigue in the back and shoulders, disperses stagnation in the chest and diaphragm, eliminates phlegm retention, promotes water metabolism, reduces distension and fullness, addresses wind in the large intestine, harmonizes the stomach, and relieves wind pain. It grows in the river valleys of Shangzhou. Harvest in the ninth and tenth months, and dry in the shade. For use, remove the pulp and seeds for best results. Its therapeutic effects differ slightly from *zhi shi* (unripe bitter orange), hence this separate entry. Now appended.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: Details are provided under the *zhi shi* entry.

Chen Cangqi says: Its root bark treats *yeji* disease (a type of hemorrhoid resembling pheasant droppings). Take one *fangcunbi* of the powdered form.

The *Shennong’s Classic* prescribes using the fruit, harvested in the ninth and tenth months, though those gathered in the seventh and eighth months are thicker and more pungent.

The *Book of Documents* states: "South of the Yangtze, it is *ju* (mandarin orange); north of the Yangtze, it is *zhi* (bitter orange)." Nowadays, both *zhi* and *ju* grow south of the Yangtze, while north of the Yangtze, only *zhi* exists without *ju*. This distinction arises from separate species, not transformation.

Xu Xi says: According to the *Treatise on Medicinal Properties*, *zhi qiao* (bitter orange peel) is an envoy, bitter and pungent in flavor. It treats wind rashes across the body, where the skin feels like hemp seeds or beans with severe itching; it governs intestinal wind and hemorrhoids, binding *qi* in the heart and abdomen, distension and deficiency in the flanks, and obstruction in the diaphragm. The root, steeped in wine or decocted for mouth rinsing, treats toothache and dissolves phlegm; if *qi* is present, it may be used accordingly.

The *Ri Hua Zi* states: It fortifies the spleen and awakens the stomach, opens the five viscera, descends *qi*, stops retching and counterflow, dissolves phlegm, treats regurgitation, cholera, diarrhea, dysentery, and food stagnation; it breaks concretions, conglomerations, *xuan* and *pi* accumulations, the five types of diaphragm *qi*, dispels wind, brightens the eyes, and addresses lung *qi* and water swelling; it disinhibits the large and small intestines, relieves skin itching, and hemorrhoid swelling (may be roasted and applied as a poultice). For medicinal use, soak until soft, slice, and stir-fry until cooked.

Lei Gong says: Do not substitute *zhi shi* (unripe bitter orange), for their natures and effects differ. When using *zhi qiao*, select those that are pungent, bitter, fishy, and contain fissured oil, which can dissolve all obstructions; aged specimens are best. Before use, remove the pulp, stir-fry with wheat bran until the bran turns charred black, then remove and wipe off the burnt residue with cloth; finally, pound alone into powder.

The *Thousand Gold Prescriptions*: For facial distortion and eye spasms due to wind. Scrape the green outer layer of *zhi* to obtain powder, stopping just before the pulp (yielding five *sheng* of scrapings). Slightly roast to remove moisture, then steep in three *sheng* of wine over low heat to extract the medicinal properties; drink according to tolerance.

The *Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*: For wind stroke with rigid body unable to bend or stretch. Scrape one *sheng* of *zhi* bark, steep in two *sheng* of wine overnight, and take from five *ge* to one *sheng*; when the wine is finished, prepare more.

The *Heart Mirror of Food Therapy*: For water *qi* with skin itching and to brighten the eyes. Pound one *liang* of *zhi qiao* into powder and decoct like tea for sipping.

The *Tested Later Prescriptions*: For incessant wind rashes with itching. Stir-fry three *liang* of *zhi qiao* with wheat bran until slightly yellow, remove the pulp, and grind into powder. Each dose: two *qian*, decoct in one medium cup of water until six *fen* remain, strain, and take.

The *Master Mei’s Prescriptions*: For all sores. Boil *zhi qiao* in water to make a decoction and apply topically.

The *Extensive Aid Prescriptions*: For chronic or recent intestinal wind with incessant bloody stool. Burn *zhi qiao* to black ash while retaining its nature, and grind sheep shinbone charcoal into powder; mix five *qian* of *zhi qiao* powder with three *qian* of charcoal powder. Take with one medium cup of thick rice water on an empty stomach at the fifth watch. If no effect after walking five *li*, take another dose. Results appear the same day.

The *Infallible Prescriptions*: For hemorrhoid cauterization. When hemorrhoids protrude or pain is unbearable, warm *zhi qiao* in pond ash and apply as a poultice; using seven pieces brings immediate relief. Repeat when symptoms recur.

The *Du Ren Prescriptions*: *Shou Tai* Powder: Formerly, when Princess Huyang experienced difficult labor, a Daoist presented four *liang* of *zhi qiao* and two *liang* of licorice, ground into powder. Take one large spoonful on an empty stomach, steeped like tea. Starting from the fifth month, take one dose daily until delivery; not only does this ease childbirth, but it also prevents fetal ailments. Avoid climbing heights or using latrines.

*Zhi shi* (unripe bitter orange).

Taste bitter, sour; nature cold or slightly cold; non-toxic. Governs wind-dampness in the skin resembling hemp or bean-like itching, dispels alternating chills and fever with accumulations, checks dysentery, promotes flesh growth, harmonizes the five viscera, boosts qi and lightens the body, resolves phlegm accumulations in the chest and flanks, expels retained water, breaks up hard masses, disperses distension and fullness, relieves urgent glomus pain below the heart, counterflow qi, flank wind pain, settles stomach qi, arrests sloppy diarrhea, and brightens the eyes. Grows wild in the rivers and marshes of Henan. Harvest in the ninth and tenth months; dry in the shade.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Zhi shi* grows in the rivers and marshes of Henan, while *zhi qiao* grows in the river valleys of Shangzhou. Today, both are found in the Western Capital and the prefectures of Jianghu, with those from Shangzhou being superior. The tree resembles the orange but is smaller, reaching five to seven *chi* in height. Its leaves resemble those of the *cheng* tree and are densely thorned. White flowers bloom in spring, and fruit forms by autumn. Harvest in the ninth and tenth months; dry in the shade. Formerly, it was said that fruit gathered in the seventh and eighth months was *zhi shi*, while that gathered in the ninth and tenth months was *zhi qiao*. Modern physicians often regard those with thick rinds and small size as *zhi shi*, and those with intact, larger fruit as *zhi qiao*, all preferring specimens with inverted bellies resembling the lips of a basin and aged for long storage. Those produced in nearby regions are commonly called "stinking oranges" and are unsuitable for use.

Zhang Zhongjing treats firm, platter-sized masses below the heart caused by water-rheum with *Zhi Shi Mu Tang*: seven pieces of *zhi shi* and three *liang* of *bai zhu*, decocted in one *dou* of water to yield three *sheng*; divide into three doses. When the abdomen softens, the mass resolves.

Tao Yinju notes: Today, it grows everywhere. Harvest, split, and dry for use. Remove the central pits and lightly toast until fragrant. Like tangerine peel, aged specimens are best. The stems and bark of the *zhi* tree treat water swelling and sudden wind-induced joint pain and stiffness.

*Zhi shi* is frequently used in folk remedies but is not employed by Daoists. Chen Cangqi states: The root bark of *zhi shi* treats hemorrhoids; take a square-inch spoonful of the powder.

Generally, *The Divine Farmer’s Classic* prescribes harvesting the fruit in the ninth and tenth months, though the seventh and eighth months yield thicker, more pungent material. Formerly, it was said that south of the Yangtze grew oranges, while north grew *zhi*. Today, both *zhi* and oranges grow south of the Yangtze, while only *zhi* grows north of it. This distinction arises from separate cultivation, not transformation.

Yuxi notes: According to *The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties*, *zhi shi* (ministerial grade) is bitter and acrid. It resolves chest bind in cold damage. Used in *Xian Xiong Tang*, it governs counterflow qi with wheezing and cough, internal cold damage to the kidneys, and yin-yang disharmony with qi stagnation, where it is added accordingly.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For treating wind rashes, soak *zhi shi* in vinegar until moist, then toast over fire until hot. Apply as a poultice at a tolerable temperature; the rash will resolve.

*The Thousand Gold Prescriptions*: For chest impediment with qi congestion and fullness, and discomfort in the heart and diaphragm, stir-fry two *liang* of *zhi shi* with wheat bran until slightly yellow, then grind into powder. Take two *qian* with clear rice porridge at any time.

*The Sagacious Benefit Prescriptions* records the same. Another formula: For chronic dysentery with rectal prolapse, grind *zhi shi* smooth on a stone, attach to a handle, coat with honey, and toast over fire until warm. Alternate poultices on the anus until it retracts.

*The Collected Verifications*: For five types of hemorrhoids, regardless of duration, grind *zhi shi* into powder, form honey pills the size of *tong* seeds, and take twenty on an empty stomach with water.

*The Prescriptions for Saving the Multitudes*: For sudden chest and diaphragm blockage and pain following cold damage, file *zhi shi*, stir-fry with wheat bran until yellow, and grind into powder. Take two *qian* with rice water, twice daily.

*The Broadly Beneficial Prescriptions*: For chronic pediatric dysentery with dribbling and undigested food, grind six *fen* of *zhi shi* into powder and take two *qian* with water. For two-year-olds, administer one *qian*.

*The Secret Records of Mother and Child*: For firm, painful swelling of the female genitals, break half a *jin* of *zhi shi*, stir-fry until hot, wrap in old cloth, and apply as a poultice. Replace when cool.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: *Zhi qiao* and *zhi shi* are the same substance. The smaller form is potent and swift in action, while the larger is mild and gradual. Thus, Zhang Zhongjing used *zhi shi* in *Cheng Qi Tang* for urgent cold damage, reflecting its ability to unblock, drain, and break up hard masses. Other formulas, intended for long-term use to guide stagnant and congested qi, employ *zhi qiao*.

**Magnolia Bark (Hou Po)**
Taste bitter; nature warm or strongly warm; non-toxic. Governs wind-strike and cold damage with headache, alternating chills and fever, fright palpitations, qi and blood impediment, dead flesh, expels the three worms, warms the center and boosts qi, dissolves phlegm and descends qi, treats cholera with abdominal pain and distension, cold counterflow in the stomach, incessant vomiting in the chest, diarrhea with dribbling, fright, lingering heat, heart vexation and fullness, and thickens the intestines and stomach. Also called *hou pi* or *chi po*. Its tree is called *zhen*, and its fruit is called *zhu zhe*. Treats mouse fistula, brightens the eyes, and boosts qi. Grows in Jiaozhi and Yuanju.

Gather the bark in the third and ninth months, and dry in the shade. Dried ginger serves as its assistant; it is averse to *ze xie*, *han shui shi*, and *xiao shi*.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Magnolia bark comes from Jiaozhi and Yuanju. Today, it is also found in the mountain valleys of Jingxi, Shaanxi, Jianghuai, Hunan, and Sichuan, with the finest specimens from Zizhou and Longzhou. The tree grows to a height of three or four *zhang*, with a trunk one or two *chi* in diameter. Its leaves, resembling those of the oak, emerge in spring and remain evergreen. The flowers are red, and the fruit is green. The bark, thick and deeply fissured like fish scales, is best when purplish and moist; thin, pale bark is inferior. The bark is gathered in the third, ninth, and tenth months and dried in the shade. *The Broad Ready Lexicon* calls it *chong pi* ("layered bark"), while some medical texts write it as *hou pi* ("thick bark").

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: Magnolia bark is a ministerial herb, contraindicated with beans, as consumption may stir qi. Its taste is bitter and acrid, its nature strongly hot. It governs chronic cold qi, rumbling in the abdomen like thunder, undigested food, dispels phlegm-rheum, resolves bound water, breaks up static blood, promotes digestion of water and grain, relieves pain, greatly warms stomach qi, checks counterflow vomiting of sour water, treats fullness in the heart and abdomen, and addresses vacuity in the patient with white urine.

Tao Hongjing says: Today, it comes from Jianping and Yidu. The best is extremely thick with purplish flesh; thin, pale bark is inferior. For use, scrape off the rough, scaly outer bark—common formulas often employ it, but Daoist practitioners do not require it. The present annotation notes that specimens from Zizhou and Longzhou are finest.

Ma Zhi says: According to Wu Pu, magnolia bark is classified by Shennong, Qibo, and Leigong as bitter and non-toxic; by the Ji family as slightly warm. Fan Zi records that it comes from Hongnong. *Ri Hua Zi* states: It fortifies the spleen, treats counterflow stomach, cholera with cramping, cold and heat qi, drains the bladder, purges all qi of the five viscera, stabilizes the abdomen in women before and after childbirth, regulates the joints, kills abdominal worms, dispels fright, eliminates vexation and oppression, and brightens the ears and eyes. For medicinal use, remove the coarse bark, then process with ginger juice by roasting or stir-frying.

It is also called *lie po* ("fierce magnolia"). Leigong says: For use, select purplish bark with an acrid taste. If preparing pills or powders, remove the coarse bark and roast with butter. For one *jin* of bark, use four *liang* of butter; after roasting, slice finely. If using in decoctions, roast with eight *liang* of fresh ginger juice, up to one *sheng*.

*The Sage’s Benevolent Prescriptions*: To treat cholera, process with ginger juice, roast over fire until fragrant, and grind into powder. Take two *qian* and a *bi* with unseasoned water, which is effective.

*Master Mei’s Prescriptions*: To treat chronic watery diarrhea, take three *liang* of magnolia bark and three *liang* of *huang lian*, slice, decoct in three *sheng* of water, and reduce to one *sheng*. Take on an empty stomach.

*The Secret Record of Mother and Child*: To treat menstrual block, take three *liang* of magnolia bark, decoct in three *sheng* of water, and reduce to one *sheng*. Divide into three doses and take on an empty stomach. A cure is achieved in no more than three or four doses.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: Magnolia bark is now also found in Yi and Tang Counties of the Western Capital and in Shangzhou. However, it is thin and pale in color, not as thick, purple, and oily as that from Zizhou, nor as bitter in taste. Without ginger processing, it is harsh on the throat and tongue. In the *Powder for Harmonizing the Stomach*, it most effectively regulates the center. To this day, this herb remains widely used, for it both warms the qi of the spleen and stomach and dispels cold qi, making it indispensable to the world.

Tea (*ming*) and bitter tea (*ku cha*)
Flavor: sweet, bitter; slightly cold; non-toxic.
Governor of fistula sores, promotes urination, clears phlegm-heat and thirst, and reduces sleepiness. Harvested in spring.
Bitter tea descends qi and disperses retained food. When prepared as a beverage, adding *zhu yu*, scallions, and ginger enhances its efficacy.

*The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica* states: Tea (*ming*) and bitter tea were not previously recorded as originating from specific prefectures or commanderies. Today, they are found in the mountains of Min-Zhe, Shu-Jing, Jiang-Hu, and Huainan. This is the "bitter tea" (*ku cha*) mentioned in the *Erya*. Guo Pu notes: "Its leaves resemble those of gardenia in size, remaining green through winter, and can be boiled into a broth." Nowadays, early-picked leaves are called *cha*, while later-picked ones are called *ming*. Another name is *chuan*; the people of Shu call it *ku tu*. Today, it is universally referred to as *cha*. The pronunciations of *cha* and *tu* are similar, hence the name. In spring, tender leaves are steamed and baked to remove their bitter water, then ground into powder for consumption—a practice quite different from ancient methods of preparation.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: The *Erya · Explanation of Trees* states: "*Jia* is bitter tea." The annotation reads: "A small tree resembling gardenia. Its leaves remain green through winter and can be boiled into a broth." Today, early-picked leaves are called *cha*, later-picked ones *ming*, and another name is *chuan*; the people of Shu call it *ku tu*. It grows in the mountain valleys of Hanzhong in Shannan. Chen Cangqi states: Tea (*ming*) and bitter tea are cold in nature. They break up heat qi, eliminate miasmic qi, and promote the movement of the large and small intestines. It is best consumed hot, as cold tea congeals phlegm. Tea consists of tender leaves of *ming*, pounded into cakes, and is improved by roasting. Prolonged consumption causes emaciation, reduces body fat, and prevents sleep. First appended in the *Tang Materia Medica*.

*The Tea Manual* states: Mount Meng has five peaks, each with tea gardens, the central one being Shangqing Peak. Long ago, a monk suffering from chronic cold illness was told by an old man: "The tea from the central peak of Mount Meng should be gathered with many hands just before or after the Spring Equinox, waiting for the first thunder. Harvest for three days only. If one obtains a *liang*, brewed with local water, it will cure long-standing illness. Two *liang* will ensure freedom from illness henceforth; three *liang* will strengthen the bones; four *liang* will make one an earthbound immortal."

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library* states: To treat sudden splitting headache—neither from cold strike nor wind strike, but caused by phlegm in the chest and diaphragm with counterflow qi surging upward, known as "counterflow headache"—induce vomiting for relief. Simply boil tea into a beverage of two or three *sheng*, adjust to a suitable temperature, and drink one or two *sheng*. After a short while, vomiting will occur. Repeat this process several times; in severe cases, continue until bile is vomited. This method is harmless, and recovery follows once thirst returns.

*The Mirror of Food as Medicine, Formula #44*: For red-and-white dysentery and heat-toxin dysentery, take one *jin* of fine tea, roast and grind to powder, then steep in a strong decoction of one or two cups and drink. Those with chronic dysentery may also take this.

*Tested Formulas*: To treat sores on the scrotum, grind wax-coated tea into powder, first wash with a licorice decoction, then apply as a poultice—highly effective.

*Additional Notes* states: According to *The Illustrated Classic*, tea is now grown in the mountains of Min-Zhe, Shu-Xing, Jiang-Hu, and Huainan, but only in several locations of Beiyuan in Jianzhou does it possess a nature and flavor uniquely distinct from other regions. Today, it is exclusively called *la-cha* (aged tea), processed into cakes and roasted—fire enhances its quality. Alternatively, buds and leaves may be ground into powder and stored, though if the stool becomes loose, it should not be kept long.

*Extended Meanings* says: *Ming* and *ku-cha* (bitter tea) are what we now call tea. Works such as Lu Yu’s *The Classic of Tea*, Ding Wei’s *Record of Beiyuan Tea*, Mao Wenxi’s *Tea Manual*, and Cai Zongyan’s *Dialogues on Tea Mountains* provide detailed accounts. Ancient texts describe its buds as "sparrow’s tongue" or "wheat grain," referring to their extreme tenderness. Some new buds grow over an inch long, slightly coarse like needles. Only the long buds are of the highest grade, for their roots, stems, water, and soil all possess abundant *qi*. The "sparrow’s tongue" and "wheat grain" varieties are inferior, yet earlier scholars failed to recognize this, mistakenly elevating them in rank. A Tang poet once said: "It dispels stagnation and clears obstruction, offering fleeting benefit for a day." This is quite apt—those who drink tea should consider its full effects. Furthermore, during the Jin dynasty, Wen Jiao submitted a memorial offering one thousand *jin* of tea and three hundred *jin* of *ming*. Guo Pu stated: "Early-picked tea is called *cha*; late-picked is called *ming*." *Ming* is also called *chuan-yun*, referring to older leaves.

*Qinpi* (ash bark) is bitter in taste, slightly cold to greatly cold, and non-toxic. It governs wind-cold-damp impediment, dispels chills, clears heat, removes greenish films and white membranes from the eyes, treats male infertility, female vaginal discharge, childhood convulsions, and bodily fever. It can be used to make an eyewash decoction. Long-term use prevents graying hair, lightens the body, smooths the skin, promotes plumpness, and enhances fertility. Alternate names include *cenpi* and *shitan*. It grows in the river valleys of Lujiang and Yuanju. The bark is harvested in the second and eighth months and dried in the shade. It is assisted by *daji* (euphorbia) and incompatible with *wuzhuyu* (evodia).

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Qinpi grows in the river valleys of Lujiang and Yuanju, and is also found in the prefectures of Shaanxi and Heyang. The tree resembles sandalwood, with branches and trunk of a greenish hue. Its leaves are spoon-shaped, moderately sized, and lack luster. It bears neither flowers nor fruit, and its roots resemble those of the pagoda tree. The bark is harvested in the second and eighth months and dried in the shade. The bark has white speckles and is not rough, commonly called *xingmu*. When soaked in water, it turns a jade-green color; when brushed onto paper, it appears blue-green—this confirms its authenticity.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For red eyes and sores on the eyeball, steep one *liang* of Qinpi in one *sheng* of clear water in a white bowl. In spring and summer, let it soak for the duration of a meal, until the liquid turns green. Then, wrap a small amount of cotton around a chopstick, lie supine, and apply the liquid to the affected eye, starting from the inner corner and filling the entire eye. Though it may cause slight discomfort, this is harmless. After a short while—about the time it takes to eat three to five mouthfuls of rice—lie on one side to drain the warm liquid. Apply ten or more times daily; recovery occurs within two days.

*Shen Cunzhong’s Formula*: Qinpi treats *tian-she* (heavenly snake) toxin, which resembles but is not true leprosy. The *tian-she* is the yellow-flowered spider found in the grass. If a person is stung and then exposed to dew, this disease develops. Boil one *dou* of the decoction and drink to cure.

*The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica, Expanded and Discoursed*, Scroll Twenty-Three
Compiled by Kou Zongshi, Gentleman for Thorough Examination of Medicinal Substances of the Song Dynasty

**Song Imperial Medical Assistant Instructor for the Verification of Medicinal Substances, Xu Hong, Collated**

**Wood Section, Middle Grade**

**Qin Pepper**
Flavor: pungent. Nature: warm. When raw, it is warming; when cooked, it is cooling. Toxic.
Governs: wind-evil qi, warms the center to dispel cold impediment, strengthens teeth and hair, brightens the eyes, treats throat impediment, counterflow retching, concretions and conglomerations, expels old blood, and postpartum residual illnesses with abdominal pain. It induces sweating and benefits the five viscera. Prolonged consumption lightens the body, improves complexion, resists aging, extends years, and connects one to the spiritual.
Grows in the river valleys of Mount Tai and on Qinling, or in Langye. The fruit is collected in the eighth and ninth months.
Incompatible with *Trichosanthes kirilowii* and *Peucedanum japonicum*; counteracts realgar.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Qin pepper grows in the river valleys of Mount Tai and on Qinling, or in Langye. Today, it is also found in the regions of Qin and Feng, as well as in Ming, Yue, Jin, and Shang prefectures. It flowers in early autumn, bears fruit in late autumn, and is collected in the ninth and tenth months.
Tao Hongjing says: It resembles pepper but is larger, with a yellow-black color, and is sometimes called "great pepper."
