In the seventh and eighth months, when the fruit ripens, harvest it; those with six ridges are best. *Records of Strange Things in Lingnan* states: Before the Dharma Hall of Faxing Temple in Guangzhou stand forty or fifty trees, their fruit exceedingly small yet free of astringency, all with six ridges. Each year, the prefectural tribute is drawn solely from this temple. The temple holds an ancient well, its water touched by the roots of the trees, yet the water remains free of bitterness. When the fruit ripens and distinguished guests arrive, the temple monks prepare a decoction to welcome them. The method: take five newly picked chebules, one *cun* of licorice, both crushed, and boil them together with water drawn from beneath the trees. The brew resembles fresh tea. Today, the temple is called Ganming, and six or seven of the old trees remain. The ancient well still stands. In the customs of southern Guangdong, this decoction is highly prized, though its preparation no longer strictly follows the old method.

Liu Yuxi’s *Reliable Prescriptions* records: I once suffered from red-and-white dysentery, and after trying countless remedies without relief, it turned to white pus. General Linghu shared this method: take three fine chebules—roast two and peel them, peel one raw—and grind them together. Mix with one or two *he* of boiling fermented water (plain water will also suffice). For watery diarrhea, add one *qianbi* of licorice powder; if there is slight pus or blood, add two *bi*; if blood is profuse, add three *bi*—all are effective.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: Chebule is an envoy herb and may also be used alone. Its flavor is bitter and sweet. It promotes the free flow of fluids, breaks up stagnant *qi* in the chest and diaphragm, restrains urinary incontinence, and blackens the hair and beard.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: It dispels phlegm, descends *qi*, relieves vexation, treats edema, harmonizes the center, stops diarrhea and dysentery, cholera, running piglet *qi*, kidney *qi*, wheezing and panting due to lung *qi*, promotes digestion, awakens the stomach, treats intestinal wind with bloody stool, flooding and spotting, the five types of *ge* (obstructive) *qi*, threatened miscarriage in women not yet full-term, fetal movement with impending labor, abdominal fullness with panting, and post-dysentery perineal pain. For postpartum vaginal pain, burn it with wax for fumigation or boil it into a hot decoction for washing.

Yu Xi notes: According to Xiao Bing, its flavor is bitter and sour. It expels retained matter, stops chronic diarrhea and dysentery with red or white discharge. Those imported by Persian ships, with six ridges, black color, and thick flesh, are of the highest quality.

Lei Gong states: In preparation, do not use *pili le*, *□li le*, *langjing le*, or mixed-ridge chebules. True chebule has only six ridges; any with more or fewer are mixed-ridge varieties. *Pilu le* has a split in each ridge, while mixed-ridge chebules are round, with patterns ranging from eight to thirteen ridges, called *langjing le*—too astringent for use. For processing, first soak in wine, then steam for a full day. Peel the ridges with a knife, slice finely, and dry by baking before use.

*Tested Prescriptions*: For cough with *qi* stagnation, or chronic cough, take one raw chebule, hold it in the mouth, and swallow the juice. After recovery, if the mouth feels bland and food lacks flavor, boil a bowl of areca nut decoction and drink it—flavor will return immediately. This is a proven remedy from Cheng Mi, an official at the silver mine in Lianzhou.

*Essential Secrets from the Imperial Library*: For all wind-phlegm disorders, wind cholera, indigestion, and constipation, take three chebules, pound to remove the skin, and take with wine—three to five doses will be effective.

*Guangji Prescriptions*: For retching and inability to eat, take two *liang* of chebule skin, remove the pits, stir-fry, and grind into powder. Mix with honey to form pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take twenty pills on an empty stomach, twice daily.

*Sun Zhenren’s Prescriptions*: For chronic *qi* disorders, wrap three chebules in damp paper and roast until the paper dries. Peel off the pits, chew finely, and swallow with one *sheng* of fresh milk, three times daily.

*Extended Meanings* states: Chebule is also suitable for those with *qi* deficiency. Roast it gently and take in small doses. Though it astringes the intestines, it also drains *qi*—its flavor being bitter and astringent.

**Willow Catkins**
Flavor: bitter. Nature: cold. Non-toxic. Governs wind edema, yellowing in jaundice, facial heat and darkening, scabs, scabies, malignant sores, and metal-inflicted wounds. Also called willow floss.

The leaves treat horse scabies and scab sores; boil and wash the affected area, and the horse will recover immediately. They also treat internal bleeding in the heart and abdomen, relieving pain. The fruit resolves abscesses and expels pus and blood. The juice of the seeds quenches thirst.

Grows in the rivers and marshes of Langye.

Tao Hongjing states: Willow is the present-day water willow. When the flowers mature, they drift on the wind like flying snow. Chen Yuanfang used them as a metaphor, referring to the unopened stage. The seeds also disperse with the flowers, and their juice is obtained by soaking in water. Willow catkins are also suitable for applying to moxibustion sores. The bark and leaves treat lacquer sores.

Yu Xi notes: According to *The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties*, bitter willow flowers are an envoy herb. They stanch bleeding, treat damp impediment, spasms in the limbs, and knee pain.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: The leaves treat epidemic febrile diseases, clove sores, corpse transmission and bone steaming consumption, scalds and burns, toxin entering the abdomen with heat and oppression, and those who take mineral drugs and develop great heat and oppression—it drains water *qi*. Boiled into a paste, it reconnects sinews and bones, promotes flesh growth, and relieves pain. For toothache, hold a decoction in the mouth. A decoction of the branches aids digestion.

*Essential Secrets from the Imperial Library*: For jaundice, boil willow branches in one *dou* of water until reduced to half a *sheng*, and drink it all.

*Extended Meanings* states: Willow flowers, as recorded in the *Classic*, are bitter in flavor—these are the newly sprouted ones with yellow stamens. When the flowers dry, the floss emerges, also called willow floss. Collect it to apply to moxibustion sores or make into cushions. Beneath the floss are small black seeds, which rise with the wind and sprout wherever they land in damp places, like *diding* (Chinese violet). They often grow spontaneously in courtyards, not from planting, but like willow floss, they disperse with the seeds.

Chen Cangqi’s account is correct. However, the ancients mistook the floss for the flower, and Tao Hongjing also said: “The flowers follow the wind, resembling flying snow.” This is an error. The *Classic* mentions its fruit and seed sap, which none of the various schools have explained, and which people today no longer use. **Note:** The Buddhist tradition calls the willow *nikulutha* wood. Its seeds are extremely fine, like the delusions of man—though the cause is minute, the karmic fruit is vast. This confirms that the small black seeds arise with the wind.

**Melia Fruit (Chinaberry):**
Flavor: bitter. Nature: cold, slightly toxic.
Governs: warm illnesses, febrile diseases, high fever with delirium, kills the three worms, scabies, and sores; benefits the water pathways of urination.
Also called *jinlingzi* (golden bell seeds); commonly known as *kulian* (bitter melia).
The root is slightly cold.
Treats: roundworms; benefits the large intestine.

Grows in the mountain valleys of Jingshan.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Melia fruit is *jinlingzi*. It grows in the mountain valleys of Jingshan, but is now found everywhere, with those from Shu (Sichuan) being the finest. The tree grows over a *zhang* tall, its leaves dense like the pagoda tree but longer. In the third and fourth months, it blooms with red-purple flowers, their fragrance filling the courtyard. The fruit is the size of a pellet, green when unripe and yellow when mature; the fruit is gathered in the twelfth month. The root may be collected at any time.

Tao Hongjing said: It grows everywhere. On the fifth day of the fifth month, common folk gather its leaves to wear as talismans, claiming they ward off evil. Its root, ground with vinegar and applied to scabies, is highly effective. Boiling the root to make a gruel and eating it expels roundworms.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: There are two kinds—male and female. The male has a red root, bears no fruit, and is toxic; consuming it often induces uncontrollable vomiting, sometimes fatal. The female has a white root, bears fruit, and is mildly toxic. Only the female should be used.

Ma Zhi said: According to the *Drug Properties Treatise*, melia fruit may also be used alone. It governs extreme heat with mania, mental agitation, and restlessness; prepare it as a bath decoction, but do not take it internally.

*Ri Huazi’s Materia Medica* states: Melia bark is bitter and mildly toxic. It treats wandering wind-heat toxins, wind rashes, malignant sores, scabies, leprosy, and urinary tract heat. For all these, decoct and use as a wash. For internal use, only the bark of fruit-bearing trees should be taken. One *liang* of female tree bark may be decocted with fifty grains of glutinous rice to neutralize toxicity. If diarrhea occurs, stop it with cold congee; if no diarrhea occurs, induce it with hot scallion congee. The bark of fruitless male trees causes vomiting and diarrhea, which can be fatal.

Lei Gong said: After harvesting, dry in the sun, then moisten with wine and steam until the outer skin softens. Peel off the skin, remove the flesh, and discard the pit. Do not use the flesh alone. Crush the pit and boil in fermented water for a full day and night. If using the flesh, do not use the pit; if using the pit, do not use the flesh. The seeds that fall after the flowers are called *shizhuyu* (dogwood).

*Essential Secrets from the Imperial Library*: To treat tapeworms, soak melia fruit overnight in pure vinegar, wrap in silk, and insert about three *cun* into the anus, replacing it daily.

*Tested Prescriptions*: For intestinal worms in children causing pain, the *Divine Efficacy Powder* uses two *liang* of bitter melia and half a *liang* of *baiwuyi* (broom cypress), ground to powder. Boil one *qian* of the powder in one cup of water until reduced to two *fen*, let cool, and administer when the pain flares.

Another formula: To treat intestinal toxins with bloody stool, stir-fry bitter melia seeds until yellow, grind to powder, and form into honey pills. Take ten to twenty pills with rice water; highly effective.

Another formula: To treat visceral qi damage in men, with bladder and small intestine disorders, take one hundred *jinlingzi* seeds, soak in warm water to remove the skin, lightly crush two hundred *badou* (croton seeds), and mix with two *sheng* of wheat flour. Stir-fry in a copper pot until the *jinlingzi* turn red and fully cooked. Let cool, remove, discard the pits, and grind the flesh to powder. Take three *qian* per dose, mixed with hot wine or vinegar decoction at any time; discard the flour and *badou*.

**Ailanthus (Tree of Heaven):**
Leaves: bitter, toxic.
Governs: washing sores, scabies, and wind abscesses. Boil in water for medicinal decoction.

Bark: flavor sweet [text corrupt].

**Chu Tree (Stinking Ailanthus):**
Root and leaves are especially effective.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Neither the ailanthus nor the chu tree were previously recorded as to their native regions; both are now found throughout the north and south. The two trees are broadly similar in form and trunk, but the ailanthus is solid, its leaves fragrant and edible, while the chu tree is sparse and foul-smelling, though cooks can roast it to remove the odor. Northerners call the chu tree *shanchun* (mountain ailanthus), while those in Jiangdong call it *guimu* (ghost’s eye), for where the leaves fall, scars remain like *chupu* (gaming pieces) or eyes, hence the name. The wood is utterly useless, as *Zhuangzi* said: “I have a great tree, which people call the chu. Its massive trunk is gnarled and swollen, unfit for the carpenter’s line; its small branches are twisted and curled, unfit for compass or square. Though it stands by the road, carpenters pay it no heed.” Both may be gathered at any time.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: The two trees resemble each other; the chu tree is sparse, the ailanthus solid—this is how they differ.

Chen Cangqi said: Chu wood is bitter and slightly toxic. Its bark governs chronic red and white dysentery, oral and nasal *gan* worms, scabies, and sores; it dispels *gu* toxins, bloody stool, and *guizhu* (ghostly infestation). The root bark expels ghostly qi: take one handful, finely chop, soak overnight in two *sheng* of boy’s urine with one *ge* of fermented soybeans, then strain and warm the liquid to a boil. Take once every three to five days.

Its leaves resemble the ailanthus. Northerners call it *shanchun* (mountain ailanthus), while those in Jiangdong call it *humu* (tiger’s eye). Where the leaves fall, scars remain like white *chu* (gaming pieces)—it is a worthless tree. First appended in the *Tang Materia Medica*.

Ma Zhi said: According to the *Drug Properties Treatise*, chu white bark is acrid, bitter, slightly warm, and non-toxic. It treats red and white dysentery, intestinal slipperiness, hemorrhoids, and incessant bloody stool.

Xiao Bing said: Chu bark governs *gan* dysentery; combine with *diyu* (burnet) for treatment. The root bark is especially effective; it is commonly called *huyan shu* (tiger’s eye tree).

The *Divine Farmer’s Classic* describes the *chun* tree as entirely dissimilar. *Ri Hua Zi* states: *chu* bark is warm and non-toxic. It arrests diarrhea and intestinal wind, and can reduce urinary frequency. For medicinal use, it is stir-fried with honey. Master Lei says: For *chun* tree root, when using the root, the portion not near the western end is superior. Do not use the stem or leaves—only the root. After harvesting, mix with fresh scallions and steam for half a day, then remove the scallions, finely slice, place in a bag, and hang on the southern side of a house to dry in the shade. It is particularly effective for urinary retention.

*The Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*: To treat white scalp ringworm in children where hair fails to grow, take the heart of *chun*, *qiu*, and peach leaves, extract the juice, and apply—highly effective.

*Tested Prescriptions*: To treat intestinal toxin with red and white dysentery, thoroughly wash and scrub fragrant *chun*, peel off the bark, dry in the sun, and grind into powder. Take one *qian* with water—immediate efficacy.

*Yang’s Obstetrics and Pediatrics Prescriptions*: To treat severe *gan* dysentery, pound *chu* white bark and mix with flour to form small pellets. Dry in the sun briefly, then remix—repeat three times. Boil in water until cooked, and add soy sauce, vinegar, or wine as desired. Administer frequently, adjusting the dosage according to the child’s size.

*An Expanded Materia Medica* states: The leaves of the *chun* tree—both *chun* and *chu* are malodorous. However, one variety bears flowers and seeds, while the other has no flowers and does not fruit. The world considers the variety without flowers or fruit, with a large trunk and straight growth, to be *chun*. *Chun* employs its wood and leaves. The variety with flowers and pods, a smaller trunk, and crooked branches is *chu*. *Chu* employs its root, leaves, and pods. Thus, one never sees pods on *chun*—only on *chu*. There is also the *chu* cicada, so it is clear why the ancients, in naming, did not speak of *chun* cicadas but of *chu* cicadas: to distinguish that the tree with cicadas is *chu*, while the one without is *chun*. The distinction is quite evident. When using *chun* leaves or *chu* root, leaves, and pods, one should investigate accordingly.

---

*Yu li ren* (bush cherry kernel) is sour in flavor, neutral, and non-toxic. It governs abdominal water swelling, facial and limb edema, and promotes urination. The root treats swollen gums, tooth decay, strengthens teeth, and eliminates white worms. It is also called *jue li*, *che xia li*, or *di*. It grows in high mountains, river valleys, and on hills. The root is harvested in the fifth and sixth months.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Yu li ren* is not recorded in the *Divine Farmer’s Classic* as to its native region, only that it grows in high mountains, river valleys, and on hills. Today, it is found everywhere. The tree reaches five to six *chi* in height, with branches, flowers, and leaves resembling those of the plum, though its fruit is small like a cherry, red and sweet-sour in taste, with the pit ripening alongside the fruit. The root and fruit are harvested in the sixth month, and the kernel within the pit is used.

Lu Ji’s *Commentary on Plants and Trees* says: *Tang di* is *yu li*. It is also called *que mei* or *che xia li*. It grows in all mountainous regions. Its flowers may be white or red, and by the sixth month, it bears fruit like plum, which is edible. Today, households near the capital cultivate a variety with long, slender branches, densely clustered flowers, and abundant leaves—also called *yu li*—but it is unsuitable for medicinal use.

*The Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states: *Yu li ren* is a ministerial drug, bitter and pungent in flavor. It treats bound qi in the intestines and obstruction of the orifices. The root treats toothache, disperses bound qi, and breaks up accumulations. Tao Yinju says: It grows wild everywhere. The fruit ripens red and is also edible.

*The Ri Hua Zi* states: *Yu li ren* regulates the five viscera, relieves acute pain in the bladder, disperses cold pus in the waist and hips, dissolves undigested food, and descends qi. It further notes: The root is cooling and non-toxic. It treats childhood febrile convulsions—boil it for bathing—and wind-eroded teeth; steep it thickly and hold the decoction in the mouth.

*Master Lei* says: When harvesting, first soak the kernels in hot water, then pare off the tips and remove the skins until they are clean. Steep them in raw honey overnight, strain, dry in the shade, and grind into a paste for use.

*Wei Zhou’s Remedies for Individual Use* records: For beriberi with floating swelling, fullness in the chest and abdomen, urinary and fecal obstruction, and labored breathing, take twelve *yu li ren* kernels, crush them, and extract the juice with water. Crush *yi yi ren* into grains the size of millet, measure out three *ge*, and cook them in the juice to make congee. Consume on an empty stomach for excellent results.

*The Infallible Remedies* prescribes: To treat *pi* accumulations, take *che xia li ren*, briefly scald to remove the skins and any double kernels, mix with dry wheat flour, and pound into cakes. If too dry, add plain water and knead as usual into cakes the size of the patient’s palm. Make two cakes, lightly toast until yellow, then slice and cook thoroughly. Eat one on an empty stomach to induce rapid purgation. If no effect occurs, consume the second, or drink hot congee broth until relief is achieved. Should diarrhea persist past noon, take vinegared rice to stop it. After purgation, one will feel weak. If the illness is not fully resolved, gauge strength and take another dose after one or two days, continuing until the condition is fully cleared. For children, adjust the dosage accordingly. Avoid vinegar, beef, and horsemeat. This remedy is invariably effective.

*The Dietary Therapy* says: For qi stagnation, take forty-nine kernels with wine; further purgation is especially beneficial. It also breaks up *pi* qi and drains water from the four limbs.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library* records: *Zhang Wenzhong’s* treatment for dental caries—boil the white bark of *yu li* root into a thick decoction and hold it in the mouth. Replace when cold; worms will be expelled.

*Yang’s Remedies for Childbirth* states: For urgent edema with bodily swelling and inability to lie down, pound one large *ge* of *yu li ren* into powder, mix with wheat flour, and knead into cakes to eat. Bowel movement will immediately follow, relieving qi and resolving the condition.

*The Extension of Meanings* notes: *Yu li ren* kernels resemble imperial plums, turning red when ripe and edible, though slightly astringent. For use, scald to remove the skins, grind thoroughly, add raw borneol, and apply as eye drops for red eyes. They are abundant in Shaanxi.

The root decocted in water expels wind and treats dental caries.

*Mang cao* (莽草) is acrid, bitter, warm, and toxic. It governs wind-induced head abscesses and swellings, breast abscesses, mounting qi, and conglomerations; dispels bound qi, scabies, and itching. It kills worms and fish. It treats throat impediment with blockage and difficult lactation. For itchy scalp wind, it may be used as a hair wash, but must not enter the eyes. It has alternate names: *mi* (葞) and *chun cao* (春草). It grows in the mountain valleys of Shanggu and Yuanju. The leaves are gathered in the fifth month and dried in the shade.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Mang cao* is also called *wang cao* (□草). It grows in Shanggu and Yuanju, and is now found in the southern prefectures and Shu. Its wood resembles *shi nan* but with sparser leaves, bearing neither flowers nor fruit. The leaves are gathered in the fifth and seventh months and dried in the shade. Another account says it is a vine that twines around trees and rocks. Ancient formulas for wind-toxin impediment and reversal in medicinal wines all used *wang cao*. Today, physicians decoct its leaves in water, hold the hot liquid in the mouth briefly, then spit it out—highly effective for treating dental caries caused by wind. Though it is a woody plant, the *Erya*’s "Explication of Herbs" states: *Mi* (葞) is *chun cao* (春草). The exegesis says: a medicinal herb, *mang cao*. Guo Pu notes: it is also called *mang* (芒), as *mang* and *wang* (□) are phonetically close. That it is called a "herb" refers to its vine-like growth.

*The Materia Medica Properties* states: *Wang cao* is a ministerial drug. It treats qi abscesses, mounting qi with swelling and congealed blood, scrofula, and damp wind; it is not taken in decoctions. It governs head sores and white baldness, and kills worms. Ground with *bai lian* and *chi xiao dou* into powder, mixed with egg white into a paste, and applied to toxic swellings, it should be replaced when dry. Tao Hongjing says: it is now found everywhere in the eastern regions; leaves that are fresh and intensely green are best. People pound it and mix it with rice, then place it in water—fish that swallow it die and float to the surface, yet it is harmless for human consumption. The character *mang* (莽) is also written as *wang* (□), and today it is commonly mispronounced as *wang cao* (□草). *Wang* is pronounced *wang* (罔).

*The Ri Hua Zi* states:

It treats numbness and paralysis of the skin; boil it into a thick decoction and pour it over the affected area. For wind-eroded toothache, throat impediment, and swollen cheeks, boil it into a thick juice, hold it in the mouth, then rinse thoroughly—highly effective.

Lei Gong states: When preparing, gather the leaves and finely chop them. Also chop fresh licorice and water pepper, then place the toxic leaves in a loosely woven silk bag. Steam them in a steamer with the licorice and water pepper for one day. Discard the two adjunct drugs, remove the leaves, and dry them in the sun for use. Do not use leaves with pointed tips or twin growths.

*The Sagely Grace Formulary*:
For tooth decay with cavities, pain, and worms: grind *wang* grass into powder, wrap it in silk, and insert it into the cavity, or bite it at the painful spot. Lower the head to spit out saliva without swallowing—the pain will immediately subside.

Another formula: For welling-abscesses with firm, knotted swellings: grind one *liang* of *wang* grass into powder, mix with egg white, and apply to cloth. Affix it to the affected area, changing it twice daily until healed.

*The Handbook of Emergency Remedies*:
For unruptured welling-abscesses: apply *wang* grass powder mixed with egg white onto thick paper and affix it to the sore. Replace when dry—pain relief is excellent.

For wind-toothache with swollen cheeks: boil five *liang* in one *dou* of water until reduced to five *sheng*. Hold the hot decoction in the mouth, rinse, and spit it out, using the entire amount in one day.

*The Rites of Zhou*:
The *Qian* official is responsible for eliminating destructive creatures; fumigating them with *wang* grass kills them.

*The Extension of Materia Medica* states: *Wang* grass is now commonly called *wang* herb. Boil it into a thick decoction and pour it over the skin for numbness and paralysis.

*The Divine Farmer’s Classic* lists it as *chun grass*. All texts classify it as a herb, yet it is now placed in the wood section, and *The Illustrated Classic* does the same. What is used today consists entirely of woody leaves, resembling *shi nan*. When its branches and stems dry, they wrinkle, and when rubbed, they emit a peppery fragrance.

*The Er Ya·Explaining Plants* states: *Mi* is *chun grass*. The commentary explains: this is *wang* grass, aligning with *The Divine Farmer’s Classic*. This should be fully addressed. In the entry for *shi nan*, Tao Hongjing’s annotation states: it resembles *wang* grass and does not wither in winter—undoubtedly a woody plant.

**Yellow Medicine Root**
Flavor: bitter. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
It governs all malign swellings, sores, and fistulas; throat impediment; and snake or dog bites. Grind the root for consumption, or hold it in the mouth or apply it topically. A climbing vine, three to four *chi* tall, its roots and stems resemble those of young mulberry. It grows in Lingnan.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Yellow medicine root grows in Lingnan, and is also found in the prefectures of Kui and Xia, as well as in Ming, Yue, Qin, and Long provinces. The variety from Zhong and Wan prefectures is superior. A climbing vine, three to four *chi* tall, its roots and stems resemble those of young mulberry. The root is harvested in the tenth month. The variety from Qin province is called *red medicine root*; its leaves resemble buckwheat, its branches and stems are reddish, and it blooms with white flowers in the seventh month. When the root is freshly harvested, it is red; when dried, it turns yellow. Kaizhou and Xingyuanfu also produce a type of *medicine root*, generally similar to *yellow medicine*. It governs perverse qi in the five viscera, clears lung heat, and relieves vexation and agitation. It is also used in veterinary medicine. Harvest the root in spring and dry it in the sun.

*The Proven Formulary*:
For coughing blood: grind one *liang* each of yellow medicine and *han* fangji into powder. Take one *qian* per dose, decoct with one cup of water and twenty grains of wheat. Take warm after meals.

*The Concise Aid for the Multitudes*:
For unceasing nosebleed: grind yellow medicine root into powder. Take two *qian* per dose with a decoction of mint. After a while, mix two spoonfuls of wheat flour with freshly drawn water and consume.

Another formula: For topical application on sores: grind four *liang* of yellow medicine root into powder, mix with cold water, and apply to the sore. Reapply as it dries.

*The Extension of Materia Medica* states: Yellow medicine is also effective for treating heat in horses’ hearts and lungs.

**Oak Mistletoe**
Flavor: sweet, bitter. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.

**Oak Mistletoe**
Governs hemorrhoids, stanches bleeding, treats bloody dysentery, and quells thirst. Use the veins after roasting. The bark is bitter in flavor. Decoct into a thick juice to eliminate *gu* toxins and fistulas—common folk remedies prove highly effective.

*The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica* states: Oak mistletoe is not recorded in the *Shennong Bencao Jing* as to its native regions, but today it grows abundantly in mountain forests everywhere. The tree reaches over a *zhang* in height. The "mistletoe" refers to its leaves, which resemble those of the oak, including its acorn cups—though smaller and of no practical use. Harvest at any time. Both leaves and bark are used. Ge Hong employed its bark to wash all manner of putrid sores and mammary sores.

Yu Xi notes: According to the *Yaoxing Lun*, oak bark may also be used alone. It governs malignant sores; decoct and wash the affected area for excellent results.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: Oak bark is astringent in flavor. It induces vomiting of scrofula and astringes the five viscera.

*The Sagely Benefit Formulas*:
For cold-type strangury, inhibited urination, and acute pain in the penis: Grind oak leaves into powder. Take three *qian* per dose, decoct with one cup of water and a seven-inch section of scallion white until six-tenths remain. Strain and take warm before meals.

Another formula: For mole cricket bites: Burn oak leaves to fine ash, then separately soak oak leaves in water used to wash rice. Use this to wash the sore, then apply a small amount of ash inside the wound for immediate effect.

*The Concise Aid for the Multitudes*:
For vomiting blood: Grind any quantity of oak leaves into powder. Take two *qian* per dose, decoct with one cup of water until five to seven-tenths remain, and consume with the dregs.

*The Secret Record for Mother and Child*:
For red and white dysentery in children and adults: Take one *jin* of fresh oak bark, remove the black skin, and finely chop. Decoct with one *dou* of water until five *sheng* remain, strain, then further reduce to a thick paste. Mix with wine and consume for immediate relief.

*Extension of Materia Medica* states: Oak mistletoe also bears acorn cups, though inferior to those of the oak. Though hard, it is unsuitable for timber. Lightly roast the leaves, then stir-fry with sophora flowers, reducing the sophora by half. Grind together into powder and take with rice water to treat early-stage intestinal wind and bleeding hemorrhoids—particularly effective for cases with pronounced heat. When charred, it is less potent than oak wood.

**Paulownia Leaf**
Flavor: bitter. Nature: cold. Non-toxic.
Governs malignant erosive sores affecting the genitals. The bark governs the five types of hemorrhoids, kills the three worms, and treats *bentu* qi disorder. The flower is applied topically to swine sores. When fed to pigs, it triples their size. Grows in the mountains and valleys of Tongbai.

*Extension of Materia Medica* states: The *Classic*’s annotations on paulownia leaves are ambiguous as to which type of paulownia is intended, making its use difficult to determine. Here, the four varieties of paulownia are described, with their distinguishing features listed below:

One is the white paulownia, used for carving zithers. Its leaves branch in threes, and it blooms with white flowers in pairs, though it bears no fruit. The *Yaoxing Lun* states: Its bark treats the five types of strangury, washes the hair to dispel head wind, and promotes hair growth.

Another is the *rentong*, which blooms early in spring with red flowers resembling *muraya* flowers, forming tubular clusters. Its seeds may be pressed for tung oil. *Ri Hua Zi* states: Tung oil is cold and slightly toxic.

A third is the phoenix tree, which blooms in the fourth month with small, pale yellow flowers like jujube blossoms. Silk-like filaments emerge from its branches, falling to the ground as oil that stains clothing. Its seeds ripen in the fifth and sixth months. Today, people gather and stir-fry them as a snack, though they provoke wind qi. This is the tree referred to in the *Monthly Ordinances* as "the paulownia begins to bloom" on the day of Clear Brightness.

The last is the ridge paulownia, which bears no flowers and is unsuitable for zithers. Its wood is heavy.

**Gallnut**
Flavor: bitter. Nature: warm. Non-toxic.
Governs red and white dysentery, intestinal flux, and promotes flesh growth. Produced in the Western Regions. Also called *moshi zi*.

*The Tang Bencao* notes: It grows in sandy wastelands. The tree resembles the tamarisk.

Modern annotation: Also called *moshi zi*. Produced in Persia. Governs childhood gan-erosion, blackens the beard and hair, treats yin sores and yin sweating, and harmonizes qi in the midst of chaos.

*The Tang Bencao* first appended.

Pei Yuxi states: According to the *Yaoxing Lun*, gallnut serves as an assistant. It treats severe cold in the abdomen and uncontrollable flux in adults and children.

The *Haiyao* records: Following Xu Biao’s *Nanjing Ji*, in Persia, gallnuts vary in size like medicinal seeds. Flavor: warm, neutral. Non-toxic. Governs intestinal flux due to cold and deficiency, enriches the blood, generates essence, blackens the beard and hair, harmonizes qi, calms the spirit, and treats yin toxin atrophy. Use after burning to ash. Zhang Zhongjing employed it for yin sweating: burn to ash, bathe the affected area with warm water, then lightly pat dry with silk before applying the ash in a pouch—highly effective. Persians consume it as a fruit substitute; the Hu people call it *moshi zi*, though it is now mistakenly called *moshi zi*.

Lei Gong states: For *moshi zi*, avoid contact with copper or iron, and do not use specimens startled by fire. The finest are small, finely textured, and lack protruding husks. Grind thoroughly in fermented water using a sandstone mortar or hard green stone, then dry by baking and grind again—do not pound, as this darkens it to the hue of black rhinoceros horn.

The *Guang Qifang* prescribes: For chronic childhood dysentery unresponsive to treatment, slice two gallnuts, stir-fry until yellow, grind, and consume as wontons.

The *Yanyi* notes: Gallnuts are now combined with other drugs to dye the beard.

**Thunder Ball**
Flavor: bitter, salty. Nature: cold, slightly cold. Slightly toxic.
Governs the expulsion of the three worms, dispels toxic qi, and clears stomach heat. Benefits men but harms women. Applied as a topical ointment, it eliminates the hundred diseases of children, expels pathogenic qi, malignant wind, and sweating, resolves heat accumulations in the skin, and expels *gu* toxins, white worms, and tapeworms without cessation. Prolonged use causes impotence. Also called *leishi* or *leishi*. Red specimens are lethal. Grows in the mountain valleys of Shicheng and the soils of Hanzhong. Harvest the root in the eighth month and dry in the sun. *Lishi* and magnolia bark serve as its guides; it is incompatible with *gegen*.

The *Yaoxing Lun* states: Thunder ball is a sovereign; it is incompatible with *xugen*. Flavor: bitter. Slightly toxic. Dispels wind. *Yuanhua* serves as its guide. Governs epilepsy, manic running, and kills roundworms.

Tao Hongjing notes: It now grows in the regions of Jianping and Yidu, appearing as clusters of interconnected spheres.

The *Benjing* states it benefits men, while the *Bielu* records that prolonged use causes impotence—these claims contradict each other.

The *Tang Bencao* annotates: Thunder ball is the *ling* of bamboo. It lacks vines or tendrils, growing sparsely without connection. Now produced in Fangzhou and Jinzhou.

Pei Yuxi states: According to Fan Zi, *leishi* from Hanzhong is superior when white.

Wu Pu records: Thunder ball—Shennong: bitter. The Yellow Emperor, Qibo, and Tongjun: sweet, toxic. Bian Que: sweet, non-toxic. The Ji family: extremely cold.

Lei Gong states: For processing, soak in licorice water overnight, then scrape off the black skin with a copper knife and break into four or five pieces. Soak again in licorice decoction overnight, steam from *si* to *wei*, remove, and sun-dry. Then mix with wine, steam again from *si* to *wei*, and sun-dry before use.

The *Jingyan Qianfang* prescribes: For tapeworms, soak thunder ball until soft, remove the skin, slice, dry by baking, and grind into powder. At dawn, the patient should first consume a small amount of roasted meat, then take one *qianbi* of the powder mixed with half a *qianbi* in thin porridge. Administer during the six *ya* periods or the first half of the month for the worms to descend.

**Black Pepper**
Flavor: pungent. Nature: very warm. Non-toxic.
Governs the descent of qi, warms the center, dispels phlegm, and eliminates wind-cold from the viscera and bowels. Grows in the Western Regions. Resembles *shuli* fruit; used to season food, its flavor is intensely pungent.

Pei Yuxi states: According to the *Rihuazi*, it regulates the five viscera, arrests cholera, treats cold pain in the heart and abdomen, strengthens kidney qi, governs cold dysentery, and neutralizes all poisons from fish, meat, turtles, and mushrooms.

The *Haiyao* records: Following Xu Biao’s *Nanzhou Ji*, it grows in the various states of the Southern Sea. Dispels vacuity-cold of stomach qi, undigested food, cholera with qi counterflow, sudden pain in the heart and abdomen, and cold qi surging upward. Harmonizes qi but should not be consumed in excess, as it damages the lungs. Some say the shade-facing variety is *doukou*, while the sun-facing is black pepper.

Lei Gong states: For use, select specimens without wrinkled shells, as they are more potent. *Han pepper* uses the shell; black pepper uses the seed. For preparation, grind into powder in a stone mortar.

The *Shiliao* states: Treats wind-cold of the five viscera, cold qi pain in the heart and abdomen, vomiting of clear water—best taken with wine or in decoction. For cold qi, swallow twenty-one grains.

The *Yanyi* notes: Dispels cold phlegm from the stomach, stops watery vomiting immediately after meals—highly effective. Overuse disperses qi. Also used for cold-induced slippage of the large intestine, but must be paired with other drugs.

**Sappan Wood**
Flavor: sweet, salty. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
Governs breaking blood stasis. For postpartum blood distension and suffocating distress verging on death, boil five *liang* in water or vinegar to obtain a thick decoction—highly effective.

The *Tang Bencao* annotates: This wood is used for dyeing. Imported from the Southern Sea and Kunlun; also found in Jiaozhou and Aizhou. The tree resembles the *amra*, with leaves like elm but smooth, shoots growing over a *zhang* long, yellow flowers, and fruit that ripens from green to black.

Chen Cangqi states: Sappan wood is cold. Governs cholera with vomiting and counterflow, as well as chronic vomiting—use a water decoction. For breaking blood stasis, wine decoction is optimal.

The *Tang Bencao* first appended.

Lei Gong states: For use, remove the rough bark and knots.

If the heartwood bears a pattern of transverse grain resembling purple horns, it is called "the most honored color within wood," and its efficacy surpasses the ordinary by a hundredfold. It must be finely split, carefully sifted, then steamed with slender plum branches from *si* (9–11 a.m.) to *shen* (3–5 p.m.), and dried in the shade before use.

*The Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*:
For blood dizziness, finely chop three *liang* of sappan wood, boil in five *sheng* of water until reduced to two *sheng*, and take in two divided doses—effective. If sappan wood is unavailable, boil red-dyed clothing to obtain a decoction and take it instead.

*The Overseas Materia Medica* states:
According to Xu Biao’s *Records of the Southern Sea*, it grows along seashores. Its leaves resemble those of *jiang* (Chinese sumac), and its wood is like *nüzhen* (glossy privet). Flavor: neutral. Non-toxic. Governs vacuity taxation with blood aggregation, qi stagnation and obstruction, postpartum malign stagnation with restlessness and rising counterflow, gripping pain in the heart and abdomen, blocked channels and network vessels, and wind-stroke in men and women with clenched jaw and loss of speech. The proper method: finely grind *rutouxiang* (benzoin) into powder the size of a *fangcun* spoon, decoct sappan wood in wine, strain, and mix the powder into the decoction. Immediately induces vomiting of malign matter—effective.

**White Poplar Bark**
Flavor: bitter. Non-toxic.
Governs toxic wind, beriberi with swelling, flaccid weakness of the four limbs with loss of function, toxic qi roving in the skin, and phlegm aggregation. Steep in wine and take. Select leaves that are round and large with small stems, moving even without wind.

*The Illustrated Classic* states:
White poplar was not previously recorded as to its native regions. Today, it grows everywhere, especially in the north, where people plant it around graves. The tree is large, with leaves round like pear leaves, white bark, and wood resembling poplar—hence the name "white poplar." Its bark may be gathered at any time.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states:
White poplar is abundant in Shaanxi, particularly in Yong and Yao prefectures, where locals use it extensively in construction. It readily takes root: when cut, even small splinters driven into soil will sprout. Thus, it propagates easily, not only around graves but also in household courtyards, along roadsides, and wherever the land suits it. When wind arises, its leaves rustle like heavy rain—this is due to the structure of the leaf stems. The claim that they move without wind is unfounded.

**Sago Palm Fruit**
Flavor: bitter, neutral. Non-toxic.
Governs static blood. Its wood resembles *benglü* (fan palm) but is harder. When cut, its interior yields a flour-like substance, with large specimens yielding several *hu*. Consuming it prevents hunger. Its bark can be made into rope.

Now appended.
*The Illustrated Classic* states:
Sago palm grows in the mountain valleys of Lingnan. Today, it is found in the prefectures of the Two Guangs, and households also plant it in courtyards. Its wood resembles *benglü* but is harder. When cut, its interior yields a flour-like substance, with large specimens yielding several *dan*. Consuming it prevents hunger. Its bark is extremely pliable and tough, suitable for making rope. Its fruit grows in spikes at the ends of branches and may be gathered at any time.

*The Overseas Materia Medica* states:
According to the *Records of Lingbiao*, it grows in the mountain valleys of Guangnan. Its trunk, bark, and leaves differ slightly from those of foreign jujube and areca. However, beneath its leaves grow fibers resembling coarse horsehair, which the people of Guang use to weave headscarves. The flour within its bark is highly nourishing. For vacuity emaciation and taxation detriment, weakness of the waist and legs, long-term consumption lightens the body and enables fasting.

*The Record of Strange Things* states:
This refers to sago palm.

**Zelkova Bark**
Very cold.
Governs epidemic headache and heat binding in the intestines and stomach.

*The Tang Materia Medica* annotates:
This tree grows everywhere, often along streams and riversides. Its leaves resemble those of *chu* (ailanthus) but are narrower and longer. Large trees may be several armspans in girth, towering several *ren* high, with extremely rough and thick bark—nothing like sandalwood. Common folk boil it to obtain a decoction for treating water diseases and stopping dysentery. Crushing its tender leaves and applying them to fire-burned sores is effective.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states:
Zelkova bark is now called "zelkova willow" by people. Yet its leaves resemble willow but are not willow, and resemble locust but are not locust. The largest trees reach fifty to sixty *chi* in height, requiring two or three people to embrace. They are abundant in Hunan and Hubei but are considered inferior timber, unsuitable for making implements. The tender bark is stripped and used to bind the rims of baskets and winnowing fans.

**Hooked Camphor Root Bark**
Governs sword wounds and stanches bleeding.

Tao Hongjing states:
It grows in Guiyang and Shaoling and is also called "crow camphor." Physicians rarely use it, but common folk recognize it well. Scraping the root bark into flakes and applying it to sword wounds stanches bleeding and promotes rapid healing—highly effective.

*The Tang Materia Medica* annotates:
Hooked camphor grows in the mountain valleys of Langzhou. The tree reaches over a *zhang* in height. Its leaves resemble those of *nan* (nanmu) but are pointed and long, with red hairs on the underside, like the leaves of *nan* loquat. Gather the root bark in the eighth and ninth months and dry in the sun.

**Stephania Root**
Governs all blood toxins and various qi disorders, sudden turmoil with malign influx, epidemic vacuity taxation, malaria, miasmic diseases, ungratifying phlegm cough, welling-abscesses and swellings, snake and dog toxins, drug and mineral eruptions, and epilepsy—all are governed by it.

Specimens from the north have roots as thick as a finger, black as lacquer; those from the south are yellow-red like *xixin* (asarum).

Now appended.
Chen Cangqi states:
There are several varieties, with different names in the north and south. Their general governance of phlegm is similar, and they may all be close to vines. Northern specimens have roots as thick as a finger, colored like lacquer; southern specimens are yellow-red like *xixin*. Whether northern or southern, if the correct type is selected, it is unclear which is superior. Some are herbs, now included in the Wood section, though they are also listed in the Herbs section.

**Southern Bamboo Branch and Leaf**
Flavor: bitter, neutral. Non-toxic.
Stops diarrhea, dispels drowsiness, strengthens sinews, and boosts qi and strength. Long-term consumption lightens the body, prolongs life, prevents hunger, reverses gray hair, and eliminates aging.

Crush the stems and leaves, soak in juice, and use it to steep non-glutinous rice—nine soakings, nine steamings, nine dryings. The rice grains become tight, small, and black as hard pearls. Store in a bag for travel. Consuming one *ge* daily prevents hunger, enhances complexion, strengthens sinews and bones, and enables long journeys.

Steep its juice to cook rice, called "black rice," also known as "black grass" or "ox sinew"—so named because eating it strengthens one like an ox’s sinews. When its color is red, it is called "patterned candle." It grows on high mountains and does not wither in winter. Now appended.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Southern bamboo is not recorded in the *Shennong Bencao Jing* as to its native region, only that it grows on high mountains. Today, it is found only in the prefectures east of the Yangtze. Its stalks reach three to five *chi* in height. Its leaves resemble those of the *ku lian* (Melia azedarach) but are smaller, and they do not wither in winter. In winter, it bears red berries in clusters. Many households plant it in their courtyards, commonly calling it "southern sky candle." Its branches and leaves may be gathered at any time. It is also called "southern bamboo herb-tree," for though it is a tree, it resembles grass, hence the name.

Yu Xi notes: According to *Rihua Zi*, "black rice grass" benefits the intestines and stomach. Crush it, steep and steam the juice, then dry and consume. It is also called southern bamboo.

**Soapberry Bark**
Slightly toxic. Cleanses grime, removes facial blemishes, and treats throat impediment—inserted into the throat, it opens it immediately. It also treats flying corpse possession. When the seed is burned, its fragrance repels malign qi. Its seeds resemble lacquered pearls. It grows on large trees in southern valleys. Also called *jin lou* or *huan*. Now appended.

*Rihua Zi* states: Soapberry bark is neutral. *Zuan Wen* records: Soapberry is the name of a tree. Its fruit can remove grime, and its pit is black as jet. Someone asked of the *lulu* tree: "Why is it called 'without misfortune'?" The answer: "Long ago, there was a divine shaman named Without Misfortune. This wood could be made into talismans to subdue all ghosts, and he used it to bludgeon them to death. People passed down that this wood was detested by ghosts, so they competed to fashion it into implements to suppress them, hence the name 'without misfortune.'"

*The Extension of Materia Medica* states: Today, Buddhist monks use soapberry seeds as prayer beads, as recorded in Buddhist scriptures. Only small, purplish-red ones are prized. It is now rarely used in medicine, though it is also found in the western capital.

**Catalpa White Bark**
Flavor: bitter, cold. Non-toxic.
Dispels heat, eliminates the three worms, and treats eye diseases.

**Leaves**
Pounded and applied to swine sores, then fed to pigs, they cause the animals to grow three times larger. Grows in the mountain valleys of Henan. Tao Yinju states: This is the bark of the catalpa tree. There are three kinds of catalpa; one should use the type that, when mixed with hemp, does not rot. The leaves treat fire-induced sores on the hands and feet. The method of using paulownia leaves and these leaves to fatten pigs has not been observed; it should be recorded in Shang Qiuzi’s *Treatise on Pig Husbandry*.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: Decocted in water and used as a wash, it treats high fevers in children, all types of sores and scabies, and skin itching.

There are several kinds of catalpa bark; only the *qiu* catalpa is fine, while the others are unfit for use.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Catalpa white bark grows in the mountain valleys of Henan; today, it is found everywhere nearby. Its wood resembles paulownia but with smaller leaves, and its flowers are purple.

*The Erya* states: *Yi* is *zi* (catalpa). Guo Pu’s commentary: This is the *qiu*. *The Book of Songs: Yong Feng* says: *Yi*, paulownia, *zi*, and lacquer. Lu Ji states: *Zi* (catalpa) refers to *qiu* with a loose grain; the white-barked variety that bears seeds is called *zi*. The *zi* with paulownia-like bark is called *yi*. They are largely the same with minor differences. There is also a kind called *shuzi* (rat catalpa), also known as *yu*, which belongs to the *qiu* family.

*Illustrated Classic and Extension of the Materia Medica*, Scroll Twenty-Five
Compiled by Kou Zongshi, Attending Gentleman for Verifying Medicinal Materials of the Song Dynasty

Song Imperial Medical Assistant Instructor for Verifying Medicinal Materials Xu Hong’s Collation
**Wood Section, Lower Grade**

**Oak Nut (橡实)**
Flavor: bitter; slightly warm; non-toxic.
Governs: diarrhea; fortifies the intestines and stomach; nourishes and strengthens the body.
Its husk, powdered and boiled into a decoction, also governs diarrhea and is suitable for dyeing.
Another name: *zhudou*.
Both *jie* (槲) and *li* (栎) bear *dou* (斗, acorn cups), but *li* is superior.
Found in all mountain valleys.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Oak nut is the seed of the *li* tree.
*The Divine Husbandman’s Classic of Materia Medica* does not record its native regions, only that it is found in all mountain valleys—today, this remains true.
The tree grows to a height of two or three *zhang*. In the third and fourth months, it blooms with yellow flowers; in the eighth and ninth months, it bears fruit. Its fruit forms a *zao dou* (皂斗, acorn cup). Both *jie* and *li* bear *dou*, but *li* is superior. Harvested at any time. Both its bark and fruit are used.

*The Erya* says: *Li* (栎), its fruit is *jiu* (捄).
Exegesis: *Li* resembles the *chu* (樗) tree. *Jiu* is the chamber that holds the fruit. Its fruit is the oak nut, enclosed in a *jiu* husk.
*The Book of Songs: Qin Feng* says: "On the mountains grow thick *li*."
Lu Ji states: The people of Qin call *zuo li* (柞栎) *li*.
*The Book of Songs: Tang Feng* says: "Gathered in the thick *xu* (栩)."
Lu Ji states: This is today’s *zuo li*. The people of Xuzhou call *li* *zhu*, or sometimes *xu*. In the capital and Luoyang, as well as in Henan, *li* is also called *zhu*. A term common to all regions.
Thus, *zuo*, *li*, *zhu*, and *xu* are all general names for oak and *li*.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: *Li* tree bark is neutral and non-toxic. It governs watery diarrhea, disperses scrofula, and eliminates malignant sores. Oak nut cups astringe the intestines and stop diarrhea. Boiled and eaten, they stave off hunger in lean years. The husk stops intestinal wind, flooding and spotting, cold and heat diarrhea, and dyes hair and beard. For medicinal use, pound and stir-fry until charred.

Master Lei states: For use, remove the coarse outer bark, steam the oak nut from *si* (9–11 a.m.) to *wei* (1–3 p.m.), then slice into five pieces.

Sun Simiao’s *Pillowbook Essentials* states: Oak nuts are neither fruit nor grain yet most beneficial to people. For those who have not yet ceased consuming grains, eating them is especially fine. They lack *qi* yet receive *qi*; they lack flavor yet receive flavor. They disperse food, stop diarrhea, and make one strong and tireless.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: Oak nut is the seed of the *li* tree. Its leaves resemble those of the chestnut and are found everywhere. Though hard, it is unfit for timber—such is the nature of the wood. Mountain folk use it as food for the poor, though it astringes the intestines. Its wood makes excellent charcoal, surpassing all other woods. Its husk dyes black. If exposed to rainwater, the color fades; unexposed husks are superior. *Jie* also bears husks, but fewer, and its fruit is inferior to that of *li*.

**Sharen (益智子, Black Cardamom)**
Flavor: pungent; warm; non-toxic.
Governs: seminal emission and vacuity leakage; dribbling urinary block; augments *qi* and quiets the spirit; supplements insufficiency; quiets the Triple Burner; regulates all *qi*. For those who urinate frequently at night, take twenty-four seeds, crush them, and decoct with salt—remarkably effective.

According to *The Classic of Mountains and Seas*: It grows in the Kunlun Kingdom.
*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Sharen* grows in the Kunlun Kingdom; today, it is often found in the prefectures of Lingnan. Its leaves resemble those of *ranghe* (蘘荷), over a *zhang* long. Small branches grow beside its roots, seven or eight *cun* tall, leafless. Flowers and calyces form spikes atop them, about the size of a jujube. The skin is white, the interior black—smaller seeds are superior. Held in the mouth, it arrests drooling and spittle. Harvested at any time.

When Lu Xun served as Governor of Guangzhou, he sent *yizhi* zong (glutinous rice dumplings with *yizhi* seeds) to Liu Yu, who responded with *Xuming Tang* (Life-Extending Decoction)—this refers to *yizhi*. Yu Xi notes: According to Chen Cangqi, it arrests retching and hiccups. *Guang Zhi* states: Its leaves resemble *ranghe* (蘘荷), over a *zhang* long. Small branches grow above its roots, eight or nine *chi* tall, leafless and calyx-free. The seeds grow in clusters, about the size of a jujube. The inner segments are black, the skin white—smaller seeds are called *yizhi*. Held in the mouth, it arrests drooling and filth. It comes from Jiaozhi. Gu Wei’s *Guangzhou Ji* records: *Yizhi* has leaves like *ranghe*, stems like bamboo shoots. The seeds emerge from the heart, with ten seeds per branch. The seed flesh is white and smooth. When split into four, the outer skin is removed, and it is boiled with honey to make zong, which has a pungent taste.

**Mouse Plum (Shuli)**
Governor of cold-heat, scrofula, and sores. Its bark is bitter, slightly cold, and non-toxic. It dispels heat toxins from the skin. Also called *niuli*, *shuzi*, or *bei* (椑). Grows in the wild; harvested at any time. *The Illustrated Classic* states: Mouse Plum is the *wuchaozi* (crow’s nest fruit). *The Divine Farmer’s Classic* does not record its native regions, only that it grows in the wild. Today, it is abundant in Shu (Sichuan). Its branches and leaves resemble plum. The fruit resembles *wuweizi* (五味子), deep black in color, with purple juice. The taste is sweet and bitter. Harvest when ripe and dry in the sun. Steamed nine times and soaked in wine, it promotes blood descent. The bark may be harvested at any time. Also called *niuli*. *The Tang Materia Medica* notes: This herb is also called *zhaoli*, *zaoli*, or *wucha*. The tree bark treats sores, cold-heat toxins, and numbness. The fruit governs worms in sores of cattle, horses, and livestock. Crushed fresh or mixed with fat and applied, both are effective. *Dietary Therapy* states: Slightly cold. Governs abdominal distension and fullness. Its root is toxic; a thick decoction held in the mouth treats dental caries. For those with *gan* worms eroding the spine, a thick decoction may be administered—highly effective. The flesh treats distension and grain-induced bloating. Mixed with flour to make cakes and eaten on an empty stomach, it induces purgation after a short while. A cup of root decoction taken on an empty stomach treats spinal *gan*. The decoction may also be used to treat the spine.

**Coconut Skin**
Bitter, neutral, non-toxic. Arrests bleeding, treats nosebleeds, vomiting, and cholera. Boil and drink the juice. The flesh inside the shell augments *qi* and dispels wind. The coconut water governs wasting-thirst; applied to the hair, it darkens and nourishes it. Grows in Annan. The tree resembles a palm; its shell can be made into vessels. *Jiaozhou Ji* states: The coconut contains a liquid that induces intoxication. *Overseas Materia Medica* notes: According to *Jiaozhou Ji*, it grows in Nanhai, resembling a sea palm. The fruit, called coconut, is about the size of a bowl. The outer husk is coarse, similar to *dafuzhi* (益智) or *doukou* (cardamom). The interior liquid resembles wine but does not intoxicate. It governs wasting-thirst, vomiting blood, water swelling, and dispels wind-heat. Those from Yunnan are also good. When Zhuge Liang campaigned in Yunnan, he ordered soldiers to cut down coconut trees to prevent small states from possessing such exotic goods. Overconsumption agitates *qi*. *Extended Meanings* states: When opened, the coconut contains a milky liquid, extremely sweet and fragrant, with a distinct aroma. Inside is a layer of flesh shaped like *guolou* (瓜蒌), with fine ridges, also white but slightly hollow. The texture resembles the pleats of a woman’s skirt. The taste is similar to the liquid. Additionally, there is a layer of white flesh adhering to the shell, which can be scraped off and boiled with the flesh and sugar to make a fruit syrup, resembling white wine in color. Its flavor is like the flesh, yet it is called "wine" by those who fancifully named it. The shell can be made into drinking vessels; if poison is present in the wine, it will bubble. Today, people lacquer the interior, entirely losing the coconut’s original purpose.

**Purple Paulownia (Zijing) Wood**
Bitter, neutral, non-toxic. Breaks up stagnant blood, treats the five types of strangury. Boil thickly and consume. Today, it is often planted in courtyards for its lovely, vibrant flowers. *The Illustrated Classic* states: Purple Paulownia was not recorded in old texts regarding its native regions. Today, it is found everywhere, often planted in courtyards. The wood resembles *huangjing* (黄荆), with small leaves and no thorns. The flowers are a vibrant purple, delightful to behold. Some say it is the *jing* of the Tian family. In autumn, the seeds ripen like small pearls, called *zizhu* (purple pearls). They are especially abundant in the forests and marshes of Jiangdong. Yu Xi notes: According to Chen Cangqi, *zizhu* is cold. It resolves various toxins, carbuncles, throat impediment, flying corpse, *gu* poison, swellings, fistulas, snake and insect bites, silkworm and rabid dog toxins. Boil the juice and consume or wash sores to dispel blood and promote skin growth. Also called *zijing*. The tree resembles *huangjing*, with small leaves and no thorns—it is not the *jing* of the Tian family. In autumn, the seeds ripen, deep purple and round like small pearls. Grows in Jiangdong, found in forests and marshes. *Ri Hua Zi* states: Purple Paulownia wood unblocks the small intestine. The bark and branches are used similarly. The flowers have the same functions.

**Southern Vine (Nanteng)**
Pungent, warm, non-toxic. Governs wind-blood, supplements the aged, arouses yang, strengthens the waist and legs, dispels impediment, reverses graying, expels cold *qi*, and repels wind evil. May be boiled for decoction or steeped in wine. Used in winter. It grows attached to southern trees, hence the name *Nanteng* (Southern Vine). The stem resembles a horsewhip with nodes, purplish-brown in color. Also called *Dinggongteng*. Grows in the mountain valleys of Nanshan. *The Illustrated Classic* states: *Nanteng* is *Dinggongteng*. Grows in the mountain valleys of Nanshan; today, it is found in Quanzhou and Rongzhou. It grows attached to southern trees, hence the name *Nanteng*. The shoots resemble a horsewhip with nodes, purplish-brown, with leaves like apricot leaves but pointed. Harvested at any time.

Beneath this, the *Qianjin Fang* further records *Qianjin Teng* (Thousand-Gold Vine), stating: that which grows in northern lands has roots as thick as a finger, black as lacquer; that which grows in southern soils is yellow-red, resembling *xixin* (Asarum). There is also *Ketengzi* (Gourd Vine Seed), which grows in the mountain forests of Guangnan. Its wood resembles *tongcao* (Rice Paper Plant Vine), taking three years to ripen, turning purple-black. Also called *Xiangdou* (Elephant Bean). Rarely used by physicians, hence appended to this category.

The *Nanshi* recounts: Xie Shuqian of Yanmen had a mother afflicted with illness. One night, he prostrated himself in the courtyard, kowtowing and praying, when he heard a voice from the void say: "Obtain *Dinggong Teng* for a cure." He inquired among physicians and *ben cao* texts, but none knew of it. In the mountains of Yidu, he encountered an old man felling wood, who said it was *Dinggong Teng*, used to treat wind. Xie bowed, wept, and begged for the vine and the method of steeping it in wine. Upon receiving these, the old man vanished. His mother’s illness was thus healed.

**Chinese Fir (*Shanmu*)**
Slightly warm, non-toxic. Governs lacquer sores.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Chinese fir was not previously recorded as to its native regions; today, it abounds in the deep mountains of the southern reaches. Its wood resembles pine but is sturdier and straighter, with leaves growing along the branches like thorns. The *Erya* calls it *bishan*. Guo Pu’s commentary notes: *Shan* resembles pine, growing in Jiangnan. It may be used for ships and coffins, and when made into pillars and buried, it does not rot. Households commonly use it for bucket planks, as it is highly water-resistant. Physicians boil its knots to make a decoction for soaking and rubbing beriberi, with remarkable efficacy.

Liu Zongyuan of Tang, in his *Rescue from Three Deaths*, writes: In the second month of the twelfth year of Yuanhe, I contracted beriberi. By midnight, my chest was obstructed and bound, with a mass in my side as large as a stone. I was near death, insensible from extreme cold for three days, while my family wailed. Zheng Xunmei of Rongyang transmitted the *Shanmu Tang* (Chinese Fir Decoction). After drinking half a meal’s time, I had a great purge, and after three purges, my *qi* flowed freely and the mass dispersed. Take one large *sheng* of the aforementioned fir knots, one large *sheng* of sliced tangerine leaves (where leaves are absent, substitute peel), seven betel nuts crushed with their husks, and three large *sheng* of boy’s urine. Boil together to reduce to one and a half *sheng*, and divide into two doses. If one dose brings swift relief, discontinue the second. The three deaths I faced were truly mortal; only by chance did I receive instruction, and thus survived. Fearing others might suffer a similar affliction, I transmit this.

There is also *Shan Jun* (Fir Fungus), which grows in Yizhou on aged fir trees, resembling mushrooms. It is said to be bitter in taste and slightly warm in nature, governing heart and spleen *qi* pain and sudden heart pain. Harvested at any time.

Tao Hongjing states: Shave it into persimmon-like slices and boil to wash lacquer sores—none fail to heal. There is also *Shuzha* (Hawthorn), which grows over a *chi* above the ground; boiled and used to wash lacquer sores, it is highly effective. Another is *Qigu* (Lacquer Maiden), with fine leaves, often growing beside stones. It also treats lacquer sores. Chicken eggs and crabs are remedies from older formulas.

The *Tang Ben* commentary notes: The wood of Chinese fir, boiled in water, may be used to soak and rub beriberi with swelling and fullness. Ingested, it treats heart and abdominal distension and pain, expelling malign *qi*. *Shuzha* and *Qifu* have distinct functions and are listed among the inferior drugs.

Ma Zhi states: According to *Rihuazi*, it is acrid in taste, treating wind toxin, running piglet *qi*, cholera, and arresting *qi*. Both decocted for ingestion and used for steeping and washing, only oily or foul-smelling fir is effective.

*The Extension of Materia Medica* says: The trunk of Chinese fir is straight and upright, like pine but evergreen, though its leaves are broader and form branches. Mount Lu’s Wanyu Temple has such firs. Shaved into powder and boiled into a decoction, it is used to soak and wash beriberi with swelling and fullness.

**Elder (*Jiegumu*)**
Bitter and sweet in taste, neutral, non-toxic. Governs fractures, knitting sinew and bone, dispelling wind itch, and tooth decay. May be used to prepare bath decoctions. Also called *shuodiao*.

The *Tang Ben* commentary notes: Its leaves resemble *luying* (Sambucus javanica), and its flowers are similar, but it grows into a tree one or two *zhang* tall. The wood is light and hollow, without pith. Cut branches take root when planted, and households often cultivate it. Also called *mushuodiao*. Found everywhere.

The *Tang Ben* first appended it.

Ma Zhi states: According to Chen Cangqi, elder has slight toxicity. Its root bark governs phlegm-rheum, draining water swelling and phlegm malaria. Boiled and ingested, it induces purging and vomiting; do not take excessively. Its leaves govern malaria. Children take three leaves, adults seven, both crushed raw to extract juice. Drink until vomiting occurs.

*The Divine Farmer’s Classic* states it is non-toxic—this is an error.

*The Book of Childbirth* says: To treat postpartum heart vexation, burning heat in hands and feet, near-collapse of strength, blood dizziness with hardness in the heart, and uncontrollable chills and fever, break elder into pieces the size of counting rods, take one handful, boil in one *sheng* of water to reduce to half a *sheng*, and divide into two warm doses. If urination is frequent and malign blood does not cease, this will cure it. Boiling the wood three times yields the same potency. This is a formula to revive the dead.

**Wooden Turtle Seed (*Mubiezi*)**
Sweet in taste, warm, non-toxic. Governs fractures, dispersing bound swellings and malign sores, generating flesh, relieving lumbar pain, eliminating acne and facial blemishes, treating women’s mammary abscesses, and anal swelling and pain. It grows as a vine with five-lobed leaves resembling *shuyu* (Dioscorea), their surfaces green and glossy, bearing yellow flowers. Its seeds resemble *gualou* (Trichosanthes) but are much larger, green when unripe and red when ripe, with thorny flesh. The kernels resemble turtles, hence the name. Produced in Langzhou and the southern regions. Harvested in the seventh and eighth months.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Wooden Turtle Seed is produced in Langzhou and the southern regions; today, it is also found in the various prefectures of Hu and Ling, as well as Hang, Yue, Quan, and Yuezhou. In spring, it sprouts vines with five-lobed leaves resembling *shanyu* (Dioscorea), green and glossy. Yellow flowers bloom in the fourth month, and fruits form in the sixth month, resembling *gualou* but much larger, green when unripe and red when ripe, with thorny flesh.

Its kernels resemble turtles, hence the name. Each fruit contains thirty to forty kernels. Harvested in the eighth and ninth months. The people of Lingnan take the tender fruits and shoots as vegetables, steaming and eating them.

Yu Xi notes: According to *Ri Hua Zi*, grinding it with vinegar dissipates swelling and toxins. *Sun Yonghe’s Prescriptions*: To treat hemorrhoids, take three Wooden Turtle Seeds, remove the skins, pound them to pieces, and grind them in a sand basin into a paste. Pour one large bowl of boiling water into a basin, sit over it to steam until thoroughly warmed, then wash with the hands. Do this no more than two or three times a day.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: Wooden Turtle Seed grows as a vine and withers once a year. Its leaves resemble those of the grape, and its fruits resemble large *gualou*. When ripe, they turn reddish-yellow, with slight thorns that cannot prick a person. Today, it is found everywhere south of Jingnan. The fruits ripen in the ninth and tenth months, and the seeds within are called Wooden Turtle Seeds. Only the roots do not die; in spring, new shoots sprout. Among the seeds, those with one pointed end are male. When planting, one must pair male and female seeds, binding them together with hemp thread. As they grow, remove the male plants so that the female ones may bear fruit.

**Gou Teng (Uncaria Vine)**
Slightly cold, non-toxic. Governs infantile chills and fevers, and the twelve types of fright epilepsy.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Gou Teng* is not recorded in the *Materia Medica* as to its place of origin. Su Gong says it comes from Liangzhou; today, it is also found in Xingyuan Prefecture. Its leaves are fine, its stems long, and between its nodes grow thorns like fishhooks. Harvested in the third month. The character may also be written as *diao* (吊). Ge Hong’s remedies for children frequently employ it. Its red decoction treats sudden pain: use two *fen* each of *diao teng* and roasted licorice, boil in five *ge* of water until two *ge* remain. Take a dose the size of a small jujube, five times by day and three by night. Highly effective.

Additionally, the *Guangji* and *Master Cui’s Remedies* employ *diao teng* bark in various decoctions and infusions for treating infantile fright epilepsy. The *Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states: *Gou teng* (Uncaria Vine), as a ministerial herb, is sweet in flavor and neutral in nature. It governs infantile night terrors, convulsions, and heat congestion. *Ri Hua Zi* notes: it treats visiting hostility and fetal wind. Tao Yinju records: it comes from Jianping. The character may also be written as *gou teng* (钓藤). It is used exclusively for children and does not appear in other formulas.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: it comes from Liangzhou. Its stems are fine and long, with thorns between the nodes resembling fishhooks. The *Extended Meanings* states: *Gou teng* is hollow, a detail omitted by the two *Classics*. It may grow eight or nine *chi* long, or even one or two *zhang*. Found in the mountains of Hunan, Hubei, Jiangnan, and Jiangxi. Some mischievous individuals use it to bore holes into wine jars, siphoning wine by suction—once the flow begins, it continues uninterrupted.

**Zong Lü Zi (Trachycarpus Seed)**
Neutral, non-toxic.

**Trachycarpus Seed (continued)**
Astringes the intestines, arrests diarrhea and dysentery with intestinal wind, stanches flooding and vaginal discharge, and nourishes the blood.

**Trachycarpus Skin**
Neutral, non-toxic.
Stops profuse nosebleeds and hematemesis, breaks abdominal masses, and treats flooding, vaginal discharge, and intestinal wind with red or white dysentery. For medicinal use, burn to ash; do not over-char.

The *Extended Meanings* states: trachycarpus wood is now commonly turned into utensils. Its skin, burned to black ash, treats women’s blood disorders and hematemesis, often as an adjunct to other medicines. Each year, the trachycarpus skin is scraped away; otherwise, the tree will wither and die. Its flowers resemble fish roe, steamed and pickled as a delicacy.

*Master Lei* notes: it treats flooding and vaginal discharge.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: trachycarpus is also called *bīnlǘ*. It grows in Lingnan, western Sichuan, and Jiangnan. The tree reaches one or two *zhang* in height, with no side branches. Its leaves are large and round, forked at the ends of the branches. Layers of skin encircle the trunk, each ring forming a node. The skin is harvested every twenty days, then regrows upward. Yellow-white flowers bloom in the sixth and seventh months. Fruits form in the eighth and ninth months, clustered like fish roe and black in color. The skin and wood are collected in the ninth and tenth months.

The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: on Mount Shicuì (or Mount Cuì), trachycarpus trees abound.

---

**Genkwa Flower**
Flavor: pungent, bitter.
Nature: warm, slightly warm; mildly toxic.
Governs cough with counterflow qi, wheezing with throat rales, swollen throat, shortness of breath, *gǔ* poison, ghost malaria, mounting lumps, abscesses, and swellings. Kills worms and fish, dissolves phlegm-water in the chest, treats excessive laughter and spittle, water swelling, the five types of water in the five viscera and skin, lower back pain, and cold or flesh toxins. Prolonged consumption induces deficiency.

Alternate names: *qùshuǐ* (Water Dispeller), *dúyú* (Fish Poison), *dùyuán*. Its root is called *shǔsānggēn* (Sichuan Mulberry Root) and treats scabies. It can be used to poison fish.

Grows in river valleys of Huaishui. Harvest the flowers on the third day of the third month; dry in the shade.

*Jueming* serves as its guiding herb. Antagonistic with licorice.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: genkwa grows in river valleys of Huaishui, though it is now found everywhere. Its perennial roots and old stems are purple, reaching one or two *chi* in length. The roots penetrate three to five *cun* into the soil, white in color, resembling elm roots. In spring, it sprouts leaves, small and pointed, like those of willow or poplar. Purple flowers bloom in the second month, somewhat resembling *zǐxíng* (purple apricot) but forming spikes, or like wisteria flowers but finer. Harvest on the third day of the third month; dry in the shade. The flowers must be gathered before the stamens form, when the calyx is still small and before leaves appear. Once leaves emerge and flowers fall, they are no longer usable.

The *Wu Jin Materia Medica* states: genkwa is also called *bàiyè* (Withered Leaf), *ér cǎo* (Child’s Herb), or *huáng dàjǐ* (Yellow Spurge). In the second month, it produces green leaves that darken as they thicken. Its leaves may be purple, red, or white.

By the third month, its fruits have all fallen, and only then do its leaves emerge. The variety now produced in Jiangzhou has yellow flowers and is called *huáng yuánhuā* (Yellow Genkwa). During the Han dynasty, the Grand Physician Chunyu Yi of Taicang treated a woman from Linzi named Bowu, who suffered from *náojiǎ* (intestinal parasites forming masses). Her abdomen was swollen, her upper skin yellow and rough, and when palpated, she felt a creeping sensation. Chunyu Yi administered a pinch of genkwa, whereupon she expelled several *shēng* of parasites, and her illness was cured. *Náo* is pronounced *ráo*.

Tao Hongjing states: "It grows everywhere in nearby regions. When used, it should be lightly stir-fried and must not be brought near the eyes." The *Yaoxing Lun* states: "Genkwa is an envoy herb, highly toxic. It can treat abdominal distension and fullness, dispel water qi, and benefit the five viscera. For cold phlegm, nasal mucus, or saliva as viscous as glue, it governs the free flow of blood vessels, treats malignant sores, wind impediment, dampness, all toxic winds, spasms and contractures of the four limbs, and inability to walk. It can purge water swelling and distension." The *Rihuazi* states: "It treats coughs and miasmic malaria. It is found everywhere, a small shrub growing beside ponds and streams. Its flowers bloom profusely in the third month, pale purple in color."

Zhang Zhongjing’s formula: For Taiyang wind-strike with vomiting, purging, and counterflow, where attack is permissible, the *Shí Zǎo Tāng* (Ten Jujubes Decoction) governs. Equal parts of genkwa (stir-fried), *gānsuì* (Kansui root), and *dàjǐ* (Peking spurge) are ground into a fine powder and mixed evenly.

Take ten large jujubes and one and a half sheng of water, boil to reduce to eight *ge*, strain off the dregs, and add the various medicinals. For those of robust constitution, administer one *qiánbǐ*; for the frail, half a *qiánbǐ*. Take warm. If there is no purgation, increase the dose by half a *qiánbǐ* the following morning. After purgation, convalesce with rice gruel. This formula also governs suspended rheum.

The *Jingyan Fang* (Tested Formulas) states: For treating hemorrhoids and fistulas with heads, take genkwa roots of any quantity, wash clean with water, pound in a wooden mortar, and wring out a small amount of juice. Simmer slowly in a silver or copper vessel over a gentle fire until it forms a paste. Pass silk thread through the paste and tie the hemorrhoids; mild pain may occur during tying. When the hemorrhoid becomes agitated and falls off, apply the paste to the opening with a paper swab to eradicate the root. Before it falls off, avoid contact with water.

The *Records of the Three Kingdoms* states: During the early Ping era of the Wei dynasty, there was a Master Green Ox who regularly consumed genkwa. Though he appeared to be fifty or sixty years old, those who knew him claimed he was over a hundred.

*Zhǐjǔ* is pronounced *zhǐ jǔ*.

Flavor sweet, neutral, non-toxic. Governs head wind and lower abdominal cramping. Another name: Wood Honey. Its bark is warm and non-toxic. Governs the five types of hemorrhoids and harmonizes the five viscera. When used as timber for a house, wine stored within loses its flavor—this too is a marvel.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Lu Ji says, "Gou is the *gou*-branched tree." Its wood resembles white poplar. Found in mountains everywhere, its branches twist and do not grow straight. When eaten, it is sweet as maltose. It ripens in the eighth or ninth month and is called Wood Honey. Originally from the south, it spoils wine. If used as a house pillar, all wine in the house becomes thin.

*The Tang Materia Medica* annotates: Its trunk spans a foot in diameter. The wood is called White Stone. Its leaves resemble those of mulberry or cudrania. The tree bears chambers, its fruit like coral, with pits at the ends resembling the fingertips of a leper.

Yu Xi notes: According to *The Sichuan Materia Medica*, the character may also be written simply as 枸 (pronounced *ju*), a tree name from Shu. Near wine, it thins its flavor. The people of Jiangnan call it Wood Honey.

**Purple True Sandalwood**
Flavor salty, slightly cold. Governs malign toxins and wind toxins.

Tao Yinju says: Common folk grind it to apply on swellings from wind toxins—it is also effective, though not as potent as *qingmuxiang*. It also governs wounds from metal to stanch bleeding and treats strangury when used.
