*The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica* states: Rhinoceros horn comes from the valleys of Yongchang and Yizhou. Today, those from Nanhai are superior, while those from Qian and Shu are secondary. Rhinoceroses resemble oxen, with a pig-like head, large belly, and lame legs, each foot having three hooves.

The color is black. It favors eating thorny plants. Each pore of its skin grows three hairs. It has one horn on its head—some say two, others three. According to Guo Pu’s commentary on the *Erya*: the rhinoceros has three horns, one on the top of its head, one on its forehead, and one on its nose. The horn on its nose is the feeding horn, small and not elongated. Some have only one horn. The *Lingbiao Luyi* states: the rhinoceros has two horns, one on the top of its head called the *si* rhinoceros, and one on its nose called the *humao* rhinoceros. The male rhinoceros also has two horns, both being hairy rhinoceroses, yet today most people speak of the one-horned variety. These several kinds all bear grain-like patterns, with coarseness or fineness determining their value. The most prized horns display "heaven-reaching floral patterns." A rhinoceros with such a horn must despise its own shadow, often drinking from muddy water to avoid seeing its reflection. The finest patterns may contain the shapes of a hundred things. Some say the "heaven-reaching" horn is a deformity, though the reason is unknown. There are also "inverted," "upright," and "waist-drum" insertions. The "inverted" type is hollow from the midpoint downward; the "upright" type is hollow from the midpoint upward; the "waist-drum" type is blocked in the middle. The varieties are numerous and wondrous.

The *Yaoxing Lun* states: Male rhinoceros horn, as a sovereign ingredient, is sweet in flavor and slightly toxic. It dispels malevolent spirits, demonic influences, and perverse *qi* from malign attacks; calms the heart and spirit; resolves intense heat; disperses wind-toxins; treats carbuncles, deep-rooted ulcers, sores, and swellings; transforms pus into fluid; and cures epidemic fevers like fire, vexation, and delirium when toxins enter the heart. Tao Hongjing says: Today, they come from the remote mountains of Wuling, Jiaozhou, and Ningzhou. Rhinoceroses have two horns, with the one on the forehead being superior. There is also the "heaven-reaching rhinoceros," whose horn bears a white streak running straight to the tip—this is most spiritually efficacious. Some say it is the water rhinoceros horn, emerging from water. As recorded in the *Hanshu*: the "startled-chicken rhinoceros," when placed among rice, causes chickens to flee in alarm and refuse to peck; when placed in a house, birds dare not perch on its roof. It is also said that the "heaven-reaching rhinoceros" remains dry even in night dew, from which its nature is known. All rhinoceros products seen in markets have been steamed and boiled, rendering them unsuitable for medicinal use; only raw horns are excellent. Even rhinoceros slices have been cooked and roasted—how much less suitable are their shavings? There is also the female rhinoceros, whose horn is very long, with patterns resembling those of the rhinoceros but unsuitable for medicinal use.

Chen Cangqi says: Rhinoceros meat governs all *gu* toxins, snake bites, and beast poisonings, though its efficacy is inferior to the horn. The *Shennong Bencao Jing* mentions the "heaven-reaching rhinoceros," and there are no separate water and land species—only distinctions of refinement. The "heaven-reaching" horn, from a thousand-year-old rhinoceros, is long, sharp, and marked with white stars that pierce through, its tip emitting *qi* that connects to heaven, thus "reaching the heavens" and communicating with spirits. It can part water and startle chickens, hence the name. The *Baopuzi* states: The "heaven-reaching rhinoceros" has a white vein like a thread; when used to hold rice, chickens are frightened. A genuine specimen, carved into a fish and placed in water, will cause the water to part three feet. The nose horn is also called the "slave horn" or "feeding horn."

The *Rihuazi* states: Rhinoceros horn is sweet and acrid in flavor. It treats heart vexation, settles fright, pacifies the five viscera, supplements deficiency and taxation, reduces fever, dissolves phlegm, resolves mountain miasma and stream toxins, calms the liver and brightens the eyes, cures wind-stroke with loss of voice, heat-toxin wind, and epidemic madness. Zhang Yuxi says: According to Chen Cangqi, the *Erya* states: The *si* resembles an ox and has one horn; the rhinoceros resembles a pig and has three horns. It also says they are mostly like elephants, yet also like pigs with three horns. Tao [Hongjing] relied on the *Erya* but did not recognize the error of the three-horned description. It further states that the female is the *si* but differs in form—this is uncertain. Lei Gong says: In preparation, do not use slave rhinoceros, female rhinoceros, diseased water rhinoceros, twin rhinoceros, lower horn rhinoceros, shallow-water rhinoceros, or dry rhinoceros. The best horns are black, with coarse, wrinkled, cracked, and lustrous textures. When processing, file the shavings into a mortar, pound them finely, then grind them ten thousand times in a bowl before incorporating them into medicine. Pregnant women should not consume it, as it dissipates fetal *qi*. In all preparations of horns, salt is strictly forbidden.

The *Shiliao* states: This is merely the mountain rhinoceros; no one has ever obtained a water rhinoceros and taken its horn. The effects of these two kinds are the same. The raw horn is cold. It can be burned to ash to treat red dysentery; ground into powder and taken with water, it also cures sudden malign heart pain, poisoning from food or medicine, heat-toxins, wind in the sinews and bones, heart wind with vexation and oppression—all are healed. Ground with water to extract its juice and given to children, it treats fright-heat. The nose horn is especially excellent. The meat is slightly warm, sweet, and non-toxic. It governs miasmic *qi*, all toxins, *gu* infestations, and malevolent ghosts; when eaten before entering mountain forests, one will not lose their way. It dispels guest heat, headache, and the five types of hemorrhoids, as well as all bloody dysentery. If eaten in excess, it causes vexation, which can be relieved by taking a small amount of musk with water.

The *Shenghui Fang*: To treat vomiting and diarrhea from eating pheasant stew, take one *fangcunbi* of raw rhinoceros horn powder and mix it with freshly drawn water—recovery is immediate. The *Waitai Miyao*: For drug overdose or poisoning with vexation and oppression verging on death, burn rhinoceros horn to ash and take one *fangcunbi* with water. The *Qianjin Fang*: When the urine of *qusou* insects lands on a person’s shadow, it causes sores resembling millet grains clustered together, with a single cluster causing piercing pain. If a part of the body suddenly feels dry and painful as if pricked by thorns or stung by insects, fine sores will appear in clusters like evodia fruit.

If the sores are red around the edges with a white pustule like millet or grain at the center, they also cause the skin to tighten, accompanied by chills and high fever throughout the body. In severe cases, the sores may spread continuously across the waist, flanks, and chest. **Treatment method:** At the onset, grind rhinoceros horn and apply it topically to halt the progression.

*The Master Embracing Simplicity* states: Master Zheng said that by practicing breath-holding to reach a thousand breaths, one may eventually remain underwater for about a day. If one obtains a true *tongtian* rhinoceros horn over three *cun* in length, carve it into the shape of a fish, hold it in the mouth, and enter the water, the water will part for three *chi* around, allowing one to breathe underwater. Moreover, the *tongtian* rhinoceros horn has red veins resembling threads running from base to tip. If a horn is used to hold rice on the ground, chickens will not dare to peck at it and will instead flee in alarm—hence, the people of the south call it the "chicken-frightening rhinoceros." Thus, in regions plagued by insect toxins, when dining at another’s home, one may stir the food with the horn: if white foam rises, the food is poisoned; if no foam appears, it is safe.

*The Extension of Materia Medica* states: For medicinal use, rhinoceros horn must be black and unprocessed by boiling or soaking—hence called "raw rhinoceros." Sichuan and southern rhinoceros horns have fine veins, while black rhinoceros horns may display prominent veins. Yellow rhinoceros horns have very few veins, and none compare to those from the western frontier, which exhibit high, distinct two-legged vein patterns. If the internal image is yellow and the exterior black, it is a "true penetration"; if the internal image is black and the exterior yellow, it is an "inverted penetration." The black variety is considered standard, and those with lifelike vein patterns are prized. A *tong* rhinoceros horn must also have a prominent vein head, clear distinction between yellow and black, unbroken penetration, and smooth, two-legged veins to be of the highest grade. As with deer antler, the tip of the rhinoceros horn contains its most potent essence. The tip of the rhinoceros horn is best when ground for consumption; if used in decoctions or powders, it should be filed into shavings. Those from the western frontier are superior.

**Tiger bone** dispels malevolent *qi*, kills demonic infestations and toxins, relieves fright palpitations, and treats malignant sores and rat-fistula. The skull is especially effective. Its fat treats dog bites. Its claws repel evil spirits. Its meat relieves nausea and vomiting while boosting *qi*.

*The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica* states: Tiger bone, along with its eyes and claws, is not recorded in the *Divine Farmer’s Classic* as originating from any specific region—today, it is found wherever there are mountains and forests. The skull and shin bones are used, with yellow-colored ones being superior. The eyes are often counterfeit; only those obtained directly from the hunt are genuine. The claws and phalanges should retain their fur and be tied to a child’s arm to ward off evil spirits. The flanks and tail tip bear a mark resembling the character *乙*, about one to two *cun* long. These parts, along with the aforementioned, are most potent when taken from male tigers. Deer and tigers used in medicine are often killed by poisoned arrows, and such specimens should not be used, for the poison permeates their bones and blood, posing a risk of harm.

Li Jiang’s *Handbook of the Ministry of War* includes a method for tiger bone wine to treat pain in the arms and shins, effective regardless of severity. Use two *liang* of tiger shin bone, roughly crushed and roasted yellow; one *liang* of antelope horn shavings; and two *liang* of fresh peony root, finely sliced. Steep these in unfiltered wine for seven days in spring and summer, or twice as long in autumn and winter. Drink one cup each morning on an empty stomach. For urgent use in winter, warm the preparation in a silver vessel over a fire for two or three days before consumption.

Tao Hongjing said: Folk remedies warn that eating tiger meat while hot damages the teeth—this is indeed true. A tiger’s head used as a pillow repels nightmares; placed above a door, it wards off ghosts. Hanging its nose above a door ensures the birth of a son. Bones mixed with cinnabar for drawing talismans treat dysentery. Its whiskers relieve toothache. Its claws, tied to a child’s arm, repel evil spirits.

The *Tang Materia Medica* notes: The *Miscellaneous Records* state that tiger dung treats malignant sores. Its eyes treat epilepsy. Bones found in its dung, ground into powder, treat burns. Its teeth treat sores on the glans penis and carbuncles. Its nose treats epilepsy and infantile convulsions.

Chen Cangqi said: The tiger’s *wei* (a bone mark resembling *乙*) instills awe in others; wearing it when assuming office is auspicious, while those without office may be disliked. The *wei* refers to a one-*cun*-long bone resembling *乙* located on both flanks—remove it by cutting the flesh. The tail tip also bears this mark, though it is inferior to the flank version. Its gallbladder treats infantile convulsions. Its meat and hide treat malaria. Bone broth used for bathing infants dispels sores, scabies, demonic infestations, and convulsions. Its dung repels demonic *qi*. Its gaze repels evil and calms the heart. Tigers see at night by emitting light from one eye while observing with the other. Hunters lie in wait and shoot when the light appears; as the arrow strikes, the light falls to the ground, resembling a white stone.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: Tiger meat is sour, neutral, and non-toxic. It treats malaria. Its eyes calm the heart and treat infantile night terrors, malnutrition, and sudden fright.

Lei Gong said: When using tiger eyes, one must inquire about the hunter’s methods. There are male and female, old and young, and those killed by hunting versus those that died from poisoning—only the latter should be avoided, as they may harm the user. To prepare tiger eyes, soak them in fresh sheep’s blood for one night, then dry them over a low fire, grind into powder, and combine with other herbs when ready.

Zhang Yuxi said: Tiger bone is universally used for demonic infestations, corpse infestations, and malignant sores, as noted in the *Drug Pairs*. The *Drug Properties* states: Tiger bone is a ministerial drug. It neutralizes dog bite toxins. Its flavor is acrid, slightly warm, and non-toxic. It treats wind-toxin in the sinews and bones causing spasms and stiffness, wandering *qi* pain, corpse infestations, abdominal pain, warm malaria, and febrile *qi* from cold damage.

Meng Xian said: Eating tiger meat before entering the mountains makes tigers fearful, repelling thirty-six kinds of demonic spirits.

Additionally, tiger eyes treat malaria, repel evil, and address childhood heat syndromes, fright, and palpitations. The gallbladder governs childhood gan dysentery, fright, and spiritual restlessness; grind it with water and administer. The bones, boiled into a decoction for bathing, dispel wind-toxin in the joints. The fat, inserted into the lower orifice, treats the five types of hemorrhoids with bleeding.

From the *Saints’ Benevolent Prescriptions*: To treat scrofula wind in the joints and unbearable pain throughout the hundred joints, take one tiger skull, coat it with ghee and roast until yellow, then pound it to pieces. Place in a silk bag and steep in two *dou* of clear wine for five nights. Warm and drink according to one’s capacity; wondrously effective.

From the *Supplement to the Thousand Gold Prescriptions*: To treat *biaoju* sores appearing on the hands, feet, shoulders, or back—clustered like grains of rice, white in color, and exuding fluid when scraped—mix tiger urine with horse urine, dry in the sun, then burn to ash and apply as powder.

From the *Tested Later Prescriptions*: For white tiger wind with wandering pain and hot swelling in both knees, take tiger spinal bone (coated with ghee and roasted) and black aconite (roasted, peeled, and with the navel removed), each one *liang*, and grind into powder. Each dose consists of two *qianbi*, taken with warm wine twice daily.

From the *Victorious Gold Prescriptions*: To treat severe hemorrhoids with fistula and prolapsed anus, take two segments of tiger shinbone, two *liang* of honey, roast until red, then pound into powder. Mix with steamed cakes and form into pills the size of *tong* seeds. Each dose consists of twenty pills, taken at dawn with warm wine. The night before, first harmonize the large intestine, then administer this medicine.

Zhang Wenzhong: For chronic dysentery with prolonged discharge that does not heal—this is called "resting dysentery"—take tiger bone, roast until yellow and scorched, then pound into powder. Take one *fangcunbi* with water, three times daily; a cure will follow.

The *Extension of the Materia Medica* states: Of tiger bone, the skull, shin, and spinal bones are used in medicine, with a slight internal warmth. Chen Cangqi’s notes on the "yi bone" and the claim that a tiger’s gaze, when shot, falls to the ground like white stone, must have been obtained from hearsay and cannot escape the charge of falsehood.

Someone asked: Why does wind follow the tiger? Wind pertains to Wood; the tiger, to Metal. When Wood is subdued by Metal, how can it not follow? Thus, when the tiger roars, wind arises—this is the natural Dao. This is why tiger bone treats wind-induced spasms, stiffness with inability to bend or stretch, wandering *zhù* afflictions, manic disorders, fright epilepsy, and wind-toxin in the bones and joints.

**Rabbit Head Bone**
Neutral, non-toxic. Governs dizziness and headache, manic disorders.

**Rabbit Bone**
Governs heat in the center and wasting-thirst.

**Rabbit Brain**
Governs frostbite sores.

**Rabbit Liver**
Governs dim vision.

**Rabbit Meat**
Flavor: pungent. Neutral, non-toxic. Governs supplementing the center and boosting qi.

The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica* states: The rabbit was not previously recorded as originating from any specific region; today, it is found everywhere and is considered a superior food. The rabbit’s burrow has six or seven entrances, and its young are born from its mouth—thus, pregnant women are forbidden to eat it.

**Rabbit Head Bone**
Governs dizziness and headache, manic disorders.

**Rabbit Brain**
Governs frostbite sores.

**Rabbit Liver**
Governs dim vision.

**Rabbit Meat**
Supplements the center and boosts qi. However, its nature is cold; excessive consumption depletes primordial qi. It must not be eaten together with chicken meat.

**Rabbit Marrow and Fat**
Both govern deafness.

**Rabbit Fur**
Boiled in water to wash pea-shaped sores. Burned to ash, it governs scalds and burns.

**Rabbit Skin, Fur, and Head**
Burned to ash and taken with wine, they govern difficult labor and retained placenta.

The *Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states: Rabbit bone has a sweet flavor. Meat prepared in the twelfth lunar month as a fermented sauce dispels pea-shaped sores in children. Fur boiled in water to wash pea-shaped sores or applied as a poultice is highly effective.

Tao Yinju says: Rabbit meat made into broth also benefits people. Pregnant women must not eat it, lest the child be born with a cleft lip. Its meat must not be eaten together with white chicken meat, or the face will turn yellow. Eaten with otter meat, it causes the disease of *dunshi* (recurrent corpse-like affliction).

The *Tang Materia Medica* notes: Rabbit skin and fur burned to ash and taken with wine governs difficult labor, retained placenta, and postpartum blood surging into the heart causing deadly distension—this remedy is highly effective. The skin of the head governs *guizhu* (ghostly infestation) where toxic qi lodges in the skin, causing needle-like piercing sensations. It also governs mouse fistula. The fat governs deafness. The meat treats wasting-thirst and fortifies the spleen. Eaten raw, it suppresses cinnabar poisoning.

Chen Cangqi says: The rabbit is cold and neutral. It governs heat qi and warms the spleen. Its fur, burned to ash, governs unhealed scalds and burns. Its bone governs chronic scabies; ground with vinegar and applied as a poultice. Its meat, when eaten over a long period, weakens yang and causes complexion to wither. Eaten with ginger, it causes heart pain. The head governs difficult labor; burned to ash and taken with wine. The rabbit’s burrow has five or six entrances, and its young are born from its mouth—thus, pregnant women must avoid its meat, not only to prevent cleft lip but also due to the young’s oral birth.

Yu Xi says: According to *Rihuazi*, the head bone, fur, and marrow burned into pills hasten childbirth, expel the placenta, and resolve postpartum stagnant blood. Rabbit bone treats sores, scabies, piercing wind, and *guizhu*. The liver brightens the eyes, supplements deficiency, and treats dizziness and eye pain.

Meng Shen says: The liver governs brightening the eyes; combined with *juemingzi* (cassia seeds) and made into pills, it is taken. It also governs those who have taken mineral elixirs and suffer from upward surging causing dim vision; it may be eaten raw, following the method for consuming sheep’s liver. From the eighth to the eleventh lunar month, it may be eaten, especially suitable for those who have taken mineral elixirs. Generally, it harms yang functions and severs the blood vessels.

The *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library* records: The *Certainly Effective* remedy for women’s vaginal discharge. Burn rabbit skin until smoke ceases, pound into powder, and take one square-inch spoonful with wine until cured.

The *Tested Prescriptions*: Childbirth-Hastening Elixir. Take two rabbit heads in the twelfth lunar month, extract the marrow, spread it on clean paper, and let it dry in the wind. Grind two taels of transparent frankincense with the dried rabbit marrow. The day before the twelfth lunar month, begin grinding. At night, when the stars appear, place a table outside, arrange fruits, incense, and tea together, and maintain purity through fasting and ablutions. Facing the Northern Emperor, bow and pray to the Heavenly Master: “Your disciple [name] prepares this medicine to aid women in childbirth. May your divine power assist this remedy to swiftly bring forth delivery.” Bow twice more, then cover with paper and expose to the dew. The next day, before sunrise, mix with pork and form pills the size of chicken’s heads. Store in a paper bag, hang in a well-ventilated place. Take one pill with vinegar soup; if labor does not begin after a long while, take another with cold wine—delivery will follow. This is a divine immortal formula, absolutely effective.

The *Extensive Relief Prescriptions*: To prevent miscarriage before labor. In the twelfth lunar month, take the brain marrow of one rabbit head, spread evenly on paper, and let it dry. Cut into talisman shapes and write the character “生” (birth) on each. When the mother feels labor pains, secure one with a hairpin on her hairpin stock, burn over a lamp flame, collect the ash in a bowl, and take with clove wine.

The *Superior Gold Prescriptions*: To treat cranial abscesses, dorsal abscesses, carbuncles, heat boils, and malignant sores. Finely chop a rabbit head from the twelfth lunar month, place in a jar, and seal tightly for a long time. Apply thickly on cloth and seal the affected area—heat and pain will feel as if sealed with ice. Change frequently until cured.

The *Collected Effective Prescriptions*: To treat hemorrhoids with incessant bleeding and pain. Slowly fry *wanyuesha* (moon-gazing sand) until yellow, then grind into powder. For each two qian, add half a qian of frankincense, and take on an empty stomach with warm wine, three to four times daily until cured. The sand refers to rabbit droppings.

The *Secret Records of Mother and Child*: To treat postpartum vaginal prolapse, burn rabbit head to ash and apply as a poultice.

The *Baopuzi* states: The rabbit lives a thousand years; at five hundred years, its fur turns white. It also says: Rabbit blood mixed with female cinnabar and consumed will summon two divine maidens to serve and be commanded.

The *Amplification of Materia Medica* says: Rabbits with white fur fully embody the qi of Metal; they are especially efficacious in medicine. All rabbits may be eaten in late autumn when the Metal qi is complete. By spring and summer, their flavor changes. The fur behind the elbows of their four legs is called *suishi* and is fed to hunting eagles. The next day, the eagles regurgitate it, intending to purge all fat and make them hungry and swift in pursuit. However, when making fermented sauce, the five flavors must be balanced. Those suffering from pea-shaped sores who also eat this will exacerbate the toxin, risking severe rash and harm.

**Leopard Cat Bone**
Flavor: sweet. Warm, non-toxic. Governs wind infestation, corpse infestation, ghost infestation, toxic qi lodged in the skin causing wandering piercing sensations like needles, heart and abdominal pain with no fixed location, mouse fistula, and malignant sores. The head bone is especially effective. The meat treats all infestations. The penis governs menstrual blockage and male impotence; burned and taken with east-flowing water.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: The leopard cat’s bones and flesh are not recorded in the *Shennong Bencao Jing* as to their native regions, but they are now found everywhere. There are many varieties, of which those with tiger-like stripes are suitable for use, while those with cat-like markings are inferior. In all cases, the skull bones should be used. *Hua Tuo’s Remedies* includes a "leopard cat bone powder" for treating corpse infestation. The flesh governs hemorrhoids and may be prepared as a thick soup or stew for consumption. In the south, there is a kind of fragrant leopard cat, the meat of which is made into raw fish slices; it resembles the northern fox in its raw state, and its preparation yields a very fragrant aroma, faintly reminiscent of musk. South of Yongzhou, there is another variety called the wind leopard cat, resembling a rabbit but shorter, which often dwells in tall trees and waits for the wind to blow it to other trees. Its urine governs wind disorders, but it is very difficult to obtain; only after prolonged rearing can it be procured.

Tao Hongjing said: There are many kinds of leopard cats. Nowadays, the tiger-striped variety is used, while the cat-striped one is not, though the latter is also good. Their bones are extremely difficult to distinguish, so one must procure them oneself to be certain. There is also a yellow, foul-smelling leopard cat, the flesh of which governs mouse fistula. Preparing its meat as a stew in the usual manner is also excellent.

The *Tang Materia Medica* notes: Leopard cat dung, burned to ash, governs intermittent malarial fevers with no fixed pattern of onset; it is highly effective. The domestic leopard cat is also good—it is also called the cat.

Chen Cangqi said: The urine of the wind leopard cat governs all types of wind disorders. People rear it and feed it fruit to tame it. Its urine resembles milk and is very difficult to obtain. It resembles a rabbit but is shorter, dwelling in tall trees and waiting for the wind to blow it to other trees; it is found south of Yongzhou.

Ma Zhi said: According to the *Yaoxing Lun*, leopard cat bone is a ministerial ingredient and may also be used alone. The skull, stir-fried and ground to powder, treats esophageal constriction with inability to consume food or drink.

Meng Xian said: The bones govern hemorrhoids and may be prepared as a stew for consumption, but should not be taken with wine. The head, burned to ash and taken with two *qianbi* of wine, governs hemorrhoids. If one is poisoned by eating wild bird meat, leopard cat bone ash may be taken to resolve it. Roasted bone mixed with musk and realgar into pills treats hemorrhoids and fistula sores. Dung burned to ash governs ghost-induced malaria.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: The bones treat wandering wind and malignant sores; the skull is most effective. Dung burned to ash governs intermittent malarial fevers. The flesh treats wandering wind and similar disorders. The head, burned to ash and taken with wine, treats all types of wind.

According to the *Shu Bencao*: The flesh governs mouse fistula. The *Waitai Miyao* states: For painful hemorrhoid flare-ups, leopard cat meat prepared as a stew is excellent. Eaten as dried meat, it resolves the condition in no more than three meals—this flesh is truly wondrous.

The *Zhouhou Fang* states: For mouse fistula with swollen nodules, pain, or ruptured sores with pus and blood, bury a whole leopard cat and prepare it as a stew in the usual manner, consuming it on an empty stomach.

The *Zimu Milu* records: For infantile ghost-lick sores, burn leopard cat dung to ash, mix with lard from a twelfth-month pig, and apply topically. The *Qianjin Fang* concurs.

The *Shenghui Fang* states: For scrofula with hard, painful swelling that has persisted for years without resolution, use the head and hoof bones of a leopard cat, coat them in suet, roast until yellow, and grind to powder. Take one *qianbi* daily on an empty stomach with rice porridge.

The *Yanyi* states: The leopard cat’s form resembles a cat, and its markings are of two types: one like linked coins, the other like tiger stripes. Both varieties may be used medicinally. Its flesh does not differ greatly in flavor from that of the fox. In Jiangxi, there is a kind called the ox-tail leopard cat, whose tail resembles that of an ox. People often eat it, but it is not known to be used medicinally.

Meng Xian said: The bones govern hemorrhoids and may be prepared as a stew (the pronunciation of *geng huo* is *hao*; it refers to a meat stew). Roasted bone mixed with musk and realgar into pills treats hemorrhoids and fistula sores with great efficacy.

**River Deer Bone**
Slightly warm. Governs depletion damage and seminal emission.
**Flesh**: Warm. Supplements and benefits the five viscera.
**Marrow**: Boosts qi and strength, brightens the complexion.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: River deer bone and flesh are not recorded in the *Shennong Bencao Jing* as to their native regions, but they are now commonly found in marshes and shallow grasslands. They are also called *mi*. There are many kinds of river deer, of which *mi* is the general name. Some have tusks, others do not, but all are used similarly. However, their tusks cannot bite. As Cui Bao’s *Gujin Zhu* states: "The river deer has tusks but cannot bite; the deer has antlers but cannot gore."

From the eighth month to the eleventh month, its flesh is superior to mutton; from the twelfth month to the seventh month, eating it agitates the qi. Daoists use river deer and deer meat as white jerky, claiming it has no dietary restrictions.

Tang remedies include "river deer bone wine" and "river deer marrow decoction," both of which supplement the lower body. Its brain is also used in facial creams.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: River deer flesh is non-toxic. The bones supplement depletion damage, boost essence and marrow, and brighten the complexion. The scent gland beneath its navel treats all types of depletion damage.

Ma Zhi said: According to the *Yaoxing Lun*, river deer bone is sweet and non-toxic.

The *Waitai Miyao* states: It governs tumor disorders. The flesh of river deer and deer, sliced thick like jerky, roasted until hot, and applied to the affected area, may be changed four times for four roastings. When the pus is thoroughly drained, the condition resolves. If not, continue roasting and apply fresh meat—this is excellent.

**Leopard Flesh**
Flavor: sour. Neutral, non-toxic. Governs the stabilization of the five viscera, supplements severe injuries, lightens the body, and boosts qi. Prolonged consumption benefits people.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Leopard flesh is not recorded in the *Shennong Bencao Jing* as to its native regions, but it is occasionally found in the regions of He, Luo, Tang, and Ying. The skull, burned to ash and applied to the scalp, removes wind-induced dandruff. Its fat may be combined with hair-growth remedies; applied in the morning, it promotes growth by evening.

Note: There are several kinds of leopards. The red leopard is mentioned in the *Book of Songs*: "The red leopard, the yellow bear."

Lu Ji’s *Commentary* states: Those with red tails and black patterns are called red leopards. There are also dark leopards—*The Classic of Mountains and Seas* records: "On Mount Youdu, there are dark tigers and dark leopards." And white leopards. Tao Yinju observes: "Leopards are exceedingly rare, and their uses are few; only their tails are prized." The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: "The yin-yang spirit leopard tails and the imperial procession’s leopard tails are held in reverence. Yet what is truly precious about a genuine leopard’s tail remains unclear—it is uncertain on what grounds Tao bases his claim." *Ri Hua Zi* notes: "The flesh is slightly toxic. It strengthens sinews and bones, fortifies will and qi, and makes one fierce and robust." Yu Xi quotes Meng Shen: "Consuming the flesh makes one’s temperament coarse, though this effect subsides after some time. Prolonged consumption enables endurance of cold and heat. The fat may be blended into hair-growth ointments—applied in the morning, it promotes growth by evening. The skull, burned to ash and steeped, removes white dandruff." *Dietary Therapy* states: "It benefits people, strengthening sinews and bones while making one’s temperament coarse and unrestrained. This effect is immediately noticeable but fades after a short while. Long-term consumption, however, renders one’s spirit bold and uninhibited. It solely fortifies the sinews, enabling endurance of cold and heat. Consuming it in the first month harms the spirit."

*Zhang Yuxi’s Amplifications* says: "Leopard flesh has reddish-yellow fur with black, coin-like patterns that are hollow at the center, arranged in close succession. This beast is swifter and fiercer than the tiger, hence its ability to stabilize the five viscera, mend severe injuries, and lighten the body. There is also the earth leopard, whose fur lacks patterns and is not reddish, and whose form is smaller. These are distinct species, not creatures capable of transforming into tigers—such notions are merely metaphors employed by the sages. I record this lest physicians remain unenlightened."

**Brush Tip Ash (aged)**
Governs urinary blockage, frequent and difficult urination, genital swelling, possession by malevolent forces, rectal prolapse, and strangury. Burn to ash and administer with water. *First appended in the Tang Materia Medica.*

Now moved from the Herbs section.
*Illustrated Classic* states: Details are provided under the "Rabbit Head Bone" entry.
Yu Xi notes: According to the *Drug Properties Treatise*, brush tip ash is slightly cold. It may also be used alone—burned to ash, it treats impotence on the wedding night. Administer the ash with wine for excellent results. The brush must be one that has been used until worn.
*Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For urinary blockage with frequent, scant urination and swelling, take one aged brush tip, burn to ash, and ingest with water.
*Superlative Golden Formulas*: To hasten labor and treat difficult birth, the Sacred Inch-of-Gold Powder. Burn one worn brush tip to ash, grind finely, and mix with a cup of raw lotus root juice to administer—delivery will follow at once. If the mother is weak or prone to cold disorders, fearing the lotus juice may induce qi stagnation due to its cold nature, warm it in a silver vessel over boiling water before serving.
*Fan Wang’s Thirty-Six Formulas*: For throat swelling and pain preventing eating or drinking, burn brush tip ash and take one square-inch spoonful with fermented grain liquid.
Calf’s umbilical feces
Governs sudden bleeding from the nine orifices. Burn to ash and take one square-inch spoonful.
Collect from newborn calves that have not yet eaten grass; yellow calves are best.
*Master Yao’s Formulas*: When blood issues from the nine orifices, limbs, or between the fingers—caused by sudden fright—take the umbilical feces of a newborn calf that has not eaten grass, dry in the sun, burn to ash, and ingest one square-inch spoonful with water four or five times daily until cured. It is also said to be effective for nosebleed or oral bleeding.
Civet cat’s yin organ
Flavor: pungent. Nature: warm. Non-toxic.
Governs possession by malevolent forces, flying corpse, gu poison, sudden pain in the heart and abdomen, madness, and demonic possession. Used like musk. Its effects resemble musk. Found in the mountain valleys of the Southern Sea. Resembles a leopard cat; mates with itself. Also called *lingli*.
*Records of Strange Things* states: The civet cat is a single body that embodies both yin and yang. Excise its urethra along with the sac, soak in wine, and dry in the shade. Its scent resembles musk; when mixed with true incense, it is rarely distinguishable. Its use is the same as musk.
*Shock flesh*
Non-toxic.

Governs night terrors in children and loss of mind in adults due to fright. May also be prepared as jerky and consumed. This creature is one struck by celestial thunder.

*Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica, Expanded and Discussed* (卷之二十八) concludes.

**Pig’s Testicles**

Flavor: sweet. Nature: warm. Non-toxic.
Governs cold qi in the lower abdomen, mounting qi, and cold hernia. Consume with wine. Also treats cold-dampness in the waist and knees, impotence, and infertility. Strengthens the sinews and bones, warms the center, and augments qi. For mounting qi, grind equal parts pig’s testicles and *fuling* (Poria) into powder, form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds with wine, and take thirty pills on an empty stomach with warm wine. For sudden mounting qi with unbearable pain, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine. For mounting qi with pain in the heart and abdomen, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine. For mounting qi with pain in the heart and abdomen, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine. For mounting qi with pain in the heart and abdomen, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine. For mounting qi with pain in the heart and abdomen, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine. For mounting qi with pain in the heart and abdomen, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine. For mounting qi with pain in the heart and abdomen, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine. For mounting qi with pain in the heart and abdomen, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine. For mounting qi with pain in the heart and abdomen, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine. For mounting qi with pain in the heart and abdomen, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine. For mounting qi with sudden pain in the heart and abdomen, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine. For mounting qi with sudden pain in the heart and abdomen, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine.

For infantile malnutrition with dampness, grind pig’s testicles into powder and apply to the affected area. For sores on the head, grind pig’s testicles into powder and apply. For scrofula, apply the powdered testicles to the affected area until healed. For chronic *zheng* (consumptive) sores, apply the powdered testicles to the top of the head. For scabies, grind pig’s testicles into powder and apply. For inverted growth of eyelashes, apply the powdered testicles to the affected area. For red and white dysentery, take one *qian* of pig’s testicles (dried and ground) with warm wine. For hemorrhoids, apply the powdered testicles to the affected area. For swelling and pain in the testicles, apply the powdered testicles. For infantile malnutrition, take pig’s urine (white portion) and apply. For swelling and pain in the testicles, apply the powdered testicles. For cold-dampness in the waist and knees, consume the testicles with wine. For mounting qi, take the powdered testicles with warm wine until the condition improves. For longevity and auspiciousness, consume the testicles. For phlegm accumulation with vomiting, consume the testicles with *bingpian* (borneol). For vomiting blood, take the powdered testicles with warm wine. For incessant nosebleed, apply the powdered testicles to the affected area.

*Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica, Expanded and Discussed* (卷之二十九)
Compiled by Kou Zongshi, *Tongzhilang* of the Song, Examiner of Medicinal Materials
Collated by Xu Hong, *Taiyi Assistant* of the Song, Examiner of Medicinal Materials
**Section on Beasts, Lower Grade**
**Pig’s Testicles**

The pig’s testicles are sweet and warm in flavor, non-toxic. They govern fright epilepsy, convulsive illnesses, demonic infestations, *gu* poison, dispel alternating chills and fever, treat mounting *qi* and the five types of *long* (urinary blockages), and resolve spasms caused by pathogenic *qi*. Another name is *tun dian*. Dry them in the shade and store; do not let them spoil.

The pig’s suspended hooves govern the five types of hemorrhoids, latent heat in the intestines, and intestinal abscesses with internal erosion.

The pig’s four feet are slightly cold. They govern all kinds of traumatic wounds, festering sores, and promote lactation.

The heart governs fright-induced pathogenic *qi* and sorrowful resentment.

The kidneys are cold. They harmonize and regulate kidney *qi*, and facilitate the bladder’s function.

The gallbladder governs febrile thirst in cold damage.

The stomach governs supplementing the center and boosting *qi*, stopping thirst and promoting urination.

The teeth govern fright epilepsy in children. Collect them on the fifth day of the fifth month.

The mane fat promotes hair growth.

The lard governs the preparation of various medicinal plasters and resolves the toxicity of *banmao* (blister beetles) and *yuanqing* (green blister beetles).

The meat of the male pig is sour and cold. It treats manic disorders.

Generally, pork is bitter in flavor. It obstructs the blood vessels, weakens the sinews and bones, and emaciates those with deficiency. It should not be consumed long-term; this is especially true for the sick and those with metal-inflicted wounds.

Pig dung governs alternating chills and fever, jaundice, and damp impediment.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: The pig’s testicles are not recorded in the *Shennong Bencao Jing* as to their place of origin. It is said that another name is *tun dian*; dry them in the shade and store; do not let them spoil. According to Yang Xiong’s *Fangyan*: In Yan and Chaoxian, the pig is called *jia*; in the Guandong and Guanxi regions, it is called *zhi*; elsewhere, it is called *shi*; in southern Chu, it is called *xi* (pronounced *xi*); its young are called *xi* (pronounced *xi*); in Wu and Yang, they are called *zhuzi*. In fact, they are all the same. Now, the term *tun luan* (pig’s testicles) likely refers to the young pig. Among the pig’s parts, its uses are the most numerous. Only its meat is unsuitable for consumption; eating it often leads to sudden obesity, which is due to wind deficiency. Tao Hongjing said: The pig’s uses are the most numerous; only its meat is unsuitable for consumption. Those who eat it often become suddenly obese, which is due to deficient obesity. Its fat can moisten the skin, make hand balms, and prevent chapping. Its lard is used in decocting medicines without exception. Do not let it come into contact with water. That prepared in the twelfth month will not spoil for years. The fat beneath the neck is called *fugefang* and is used by Daoists. Its dung juice is highly effective for warm toxin. After eating its meat and drinking wine, one must not lie down in a bed of rice straw. Also, white pigs with white hooves mixed with black should not be eaten. Pig fat is also incompatible with *wumei* (dark plum).

Zhang Yuxi said: According to Meng Shen, the kidneys govern kidney deficiency and should not be consumed long-term. The stomach governs sudden dysentery and weakness. According to *Rihuazi*: The kidneys supplement the water viscera, warm the waist and knees, supplement the bladder, and treat deafness. Though they supplement the kidneys, they also reduce fertility. The stomach supplements deficiency and damage, kills *lao* worms (consumptive parasites), and stops dysentery. Stuffed with glutinous yellow rice, steamed, and pounded into powder, it is highly effective for bladder *qi* and childhood *gan* (infantile malnutrition) with roundworm-induced emaciation and yellow complexion.

*The Outer Terrace Secret Essentials*: For toxic heat disease attacking the hands and feet, causing swelling, pain, and near detachment, use pig fat mixed with sheep dung as an application; this is also excellent.

*The Supplement to the Thousand Gold Wings*: To treat chapped hands and feet with bleeding and pain, or frostbite from winter exposure, causing damage to the face, hands, and feet, as well as heat and pain, take pig brain marrow and place it in hot wine to wash the affected area; this will cure it.

*The Handbook of Emergency Prescriptions*: To treat sudden swelling and abscesses, with the entire body and face greatly swollen, finely mince one raw pig liver and consume it all at once. Do not add salt; vinegar may be used instead.

*The Experiential Prescriptions*: To settle panting and dissolve phlegm, take forty-nine pig hooves, wash them clean, and dry. Place half a *zi* each of *banxia* (pinellia) and alum inside each hoof, seal them in a jar to prevent smoke from escaping, and calcine until thoroughly red. Remove from the fire, grind finely, and add one *qianbi* of musk. For those with upper panting and cough, administer with glutinous rice water; for children, use half a *qian*. This is highly effective.

*Master Mei’s Prescriptions*: To treat postpartum deficiency taxation, painful joints, and incessant sweating, prepare a pig kidney stew with scallions, fermented soybeans, and rice, and consume according to the usual method.

*The Categorized Essentials of Cold Damage*: To treat jaundice in men and women that physicians cannot cure, with yellowing of the ears and eyes, indigestion, abdominal distension and heat, and dry stool in the stomach causing the illness, take one small *sheng* of rendered pig fat, warm it, and consume it all at once, three times a day. When the dry stool is expelled, the condition will resolve.

*The Marrow of the Thousand Gold*: To prepare for childbirth in the ninth month of pregnancy, take one pig stomach, cook it with scallions and the five flavors according to the usual method, and consume it fully. If not finished, eat it again; do not share with others.

*Yao Hezhong’s Prescriptions*: For newborn infants, take one pig gallbladder, decoct it in seven *sheng* of water until four *sheng* remain, strain the clear liquid, and bathe the child to ensure they never suffer from sores or scabies.

*The Secret Records of Mother and Child*: To treat *chui nai* (breast inflammation) with aversion to cold and high fever, soak pig lard in cold water and apply it to the affected area. Change it when it becomes warm; this is effective.

---

The fox’s penis is sweet and toxic. It governs female infertility, vaginal itching, and swelling of the scrotum or testicles in children.

The five viscera and intestines are bitter, slightly cold, and toxic. They govern *gu* poison, alternating chills and fever, and childhood fright epilepsy.

Burning the dung of a male fox wards off evil. That found on wood or stone is genuine.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: The fox was not recorded in the old texts as to its place of origin. Tao Hongjing’s annotation says: There are no foxes in Jiangdong; they are all in the north and Yizhou. Now, they are occasionally found in Jiangnan, with many in Jing and Luo. Their shape resembles a yellow dog, with a pointed snout and large tail. In the northern lands, they are eaten raw as *kuai* (thinly sliced meat), which is very warming. It dispels wind, supplements deficiency taxation, and the penis and five viscera are all used medicinally.

The liver, burned to ash, treats wind—modern physicians use it in *Fox Liver Powder*. The gallbladder governs sudden death.

*The Continued Anthology of Reliable Prescriptions* states: Collect the gallbladder of a male fox in the twelfth lunar month. If someone suddenly dies but has not yet passed the critical moment, grind it slightly in warm water and pour it down the throat to revive them. Always keep it prepared to save lives, for once the moment passes, it will be too late.

Tao Hongjing says: There are no foxes in Jiangdong; they all come from the north and the region of Yizhou. Their shape resembles a leopard cat but is yellow, and they are also skilled at bewitchment.

*The Tang Materia Medica* annotates: The meat and intestines of the fox, made into a thick soup, govern long-standing scabies and sores that do not heal. The intestines govern cattle plague. Burn them to ash, mix with water, and drench the cattle—it surpasses the efficacy of an otter.

Its snout resembles that of a small dog, but its tail is large, and it does not resemble a leopard cat at all.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: The fox is warming and non-toxic. It supplements deficiency taxation, treats malignant sores and scabies, and tonifies according to the corresponding viscus. The ash of its head or tail treats cattle plague when mixed with water and given as a drink. Eating the heart and liver raw dispels demonic possession. Burning the tail of a male fox wards off evil.

Meng Shen says: The fox supplements deficiency; it should be boiled or roasted and eaten. It also governs pathogenic qi in the five viscera, *gu* poison, and alternating chills and fever—prolonged consumption is advisable.

*The Heart Mirror of Food and Medicine* states: To treat fright epilepsy, mental confusion, incoherent speech, and excessive singing and laughter, as well as cold accumulation in the five viscera, *gu* poison, and alternating chills and fever: Take a piece of fox meat and its five viscera, prepare them as one would for eating, and boil them in fermented black bean juice with the five flavors to make a thick soup. Alternatively, make congee or roast and eat it. In the capital, sheep bone broth or crucian carp is used instead of fermented black bean juice.

*The Thousand Gold Prescriptions*: For malignant thorns, take fox dung ash, mix with lard from the twelfth lunar month, and seal the wound. Another prescription: To treat all malignant fistulas with cold and protruding flesh, use fox dung from the first lunar month, dry and grind it into powder, and take one *qianbi* with freshly drawn water before meals.

*Extended Meanings* states: The fox is now used for its liver to treat wind, and its pelt, with fur intact, is made into fur garments. This beast is highly suspicious and listens with great care. Hunters exploit its nature—its suspicion and acute hearing—to capture it, often using traps.

---

**Otter Liver**
Flavor: sweet. Toxic.
Governs *gu* poison from demonic infestation, removes fish bones lodged in the throat, and stops chronic cough. Burn and ingest it. The meat treats epidemic qi, warm diseases, and seasonal cattle and horse illnesses. Boiling its dung and administering it is also effective.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: The otter was not recorded in the old texts as to its place of origin. Today, it is abundant in rivers and lakes, and people in the north domesticate and keep them as pets. *Guang Ya* calls it the "water dog." However, there is also the *bian* (pronounced *bin*; *bian* may also be written as *pin*). The otter is larger, with a head like a horse and a body resembling a bat.

*The Master of Huainan* says: Those who raise pond fish do not keep *bian* otters. Xu Shen annotates: The *bian* is a type of otter. For medicinal use, one should select those that offer fish in sacrifice to heaven. Its meat is cold in nature and governs steaming bone taxation, impeded blood flow, deficiency and fullness of *ying* and *wei*, and menstrual blockage in women due to blood heat, as well as constipation of the large and small intestines. However, it depletes *yang* qi and is not beneficial to men—it should be eaten sparingly. The five viscera and meat are all cold in nature, except for the liver, which is warming. It governs consumptive taxation, cold malaria of the four limbs, deficiency sweating, and guest heat, and also treats postpartum taxation.

All animal livers have a fixed number of lobes, but the otter’s liver grows one lobe per month, reaching twelve lobes in twelve months, with additional lobes that may recede. When using it, one must see its form and strength, for otherwise, there are many counterfeits.

Tao Hongjing says: There are two kinds of otters: the *bian* otter, which is large, with a head like a horse and a body resembling a bat, and is not used medicinally. One should select those that offer fish in sacrifice to heaven. Its bones also treat fish bones lodged in the throat. For households with cattle and horses, one may collect its dung. They are often found along stream banks. Do not eat its meat together with rabbit meat.

*The Tang Materia Medica* annotates: *Miscellaneous Records* states: The four feet of the otter treat chapped skin on hands and feet. Chen Cangqi says: For fish bones that cannot be dislodged, scrape the otter’s foot against the nape of the neck, or boil it and drink the broth. Its pelt and fur treat watery *bian* disease—make a mattress or shoes from them, or boil and drink the broth. Its dung treats fish navel sores; grind and apply it. It also treats horsefly infestations in donkeys and horses—grind finely and pour into the nostrils.

Yu Xi says: According to *The Treatise on Medicinal Properties*, otter liver is a sovereign ingredient, flavor salty, slightly warm, and non-toxic. It treats rising qi, cough, taxation diseases, and consumptive *gu*. Its bones treat incessant retching.

Meng Shen says: Otter liver governs *gu* disease. When an entire household is infected, roast one liver over fire, grind it into powder, mix a *fangcunbi* with water, and take it twice daily. If the condition does not improve, prepare another dose. Note: If taken for water swelling, it will only cure swelling caused by heat toxin and wind deficiency. If the swelling is due to cold qi deficiency, consumption will exacerbate deficiency and swelling. It only treats heat and not cold—it cannot be applied indiscriminately.

According to *Ri Hua Zi*: Otter meat is neutral and non-toxic. It treats water qi distension and fullness, as well as heat toxin and wind. Otter liver treats deficiency taxation and consumptive taxation diseases.

*The Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*: For *gu* infestation from corpses or demons—Ge Hong says this is one of the five *gu* infestations, compounded by various demonic harms. The disease manifests in thirty-six to ninety-nine forms, generally causing alternating chills and fever, dribbling urine, deep silence, and an inability to pinpoint the suffering, yet no part of the body is unaffected. Over months and years, it gradually weakens the patient, leading to death. After death, it spreads to others, even wiping out entire households. If such symptoms appear, urgent treatment is required: Take one otter liver, dry it in the shade, pound it into powder, and take one *fangcunbi* with water, three times daily. If the condition does not improve, prepare another dose.

Yao states it is divinely effective.

**Another Prescription:** For intestinal hemorrhoids with constant bloody stool—burn otter liver and take one *qianbi*.

*The Extended Materia Medica* states: The otter has short limbs, a flattened head, body, and tail, with fur resembling faded purple silk. The largest specimens reach over three *chi* in length from head to tail. It feeds on fish and dwells in water, yet does not die when out of it; it may also rest upon large trees, and is commonly called the "water otter." When tethered in a large water vat, it spins like the wind, creating a vortex—water rises in a mound on all sides while the center dips low, astonishing onlookers. Its pelt is used by the Western Rong tribes to trim the collars and cuffs of their felt garments. When asked why, they say: "Dirt does not cling to it. If dust or sand blinds the eyes, one may wipe them with the cuff’s edge to clear them." Indeed, not even the tips of its hairs gather dust—another marvel.

*The Exemplars of Materia Medica* notes: The claim that otter gallbladders can divide a cup of wine equally has been tested and found false. However, when applied to the rim of a cup, it allows wine to rise slightly above the brim. The tale of dividing cups is merely an ancient and modern misconception that must be corrected. The liver, however, has proven effective.

**Mole (鼹鼹, *yǎnshǔ*, "reclining mouse")**
Flavor: salty. Non-toxic.
Governs: abscesses, all types of fistulas, erosive sores, and yin-region ulcers.
Collected in the fifth month while in the earth, dried, and burned.

Tao Yinju says: Commonly called the "hidden mouse" (隐鼠, *yǐnshǔ*), or *fénshǔ* (鼢鼠, "dust mouse"). It resembles a mouse but is larger, tailless, black, with a long, strong snout. It constantly tunnels through the earth, and can be obtained by digging. Nowadays, in mountain forests, there is a beast as large as a water buffalo, shaped like a pig, grayish-red, with legs like an elephant’s, white on the chest and tail. Strong and docile, it is also called the *yǎnshǔ*. People hunt and eat it; its flesh resembles beef and is often dried into jerky. Its fat is also said to treat fistulas. Some claim this is the "rat king," whose urine, when a single drop falls to the ground, instantly spawns a new rat. In years of rodent plagues, it appears in great numbers. This may not be entirely baseless.

Chen Cangqi says: Mole meat dispels wind, and long-term consumption treats sores, scabies, hemorrhoids, and fistulas. Its fat can be applied to various malignant sores. The *Shennong Bencao Jing* refers to the small, subterranean variety. Tao also describes it as mouse-like with a black tail, constantly tunneling, and obtainable by digging. As the *Classic* states, this is the modern *fénshǔ* with a small, pointed mouth. The *yǎnshǔ*, however, is a beast, not of the rat kind—large as an ox, with short forelegs, its hide used for autumn reins.

*The Extended Materia Medica* states: The *yǎnshǔ* is the *fénshǔ*. Its fur is mouse-colored. Today, they are abundant in the fields of the capital region. Its legs are extremely short, barely enabling movement. Its tail is about one *cun* long, its eyes tiny, and its neck very short. Easy to dig up or shoot with bamboo bows, they are used to feed hawks. Tao was mistaken to further cite the beast found in mountain forests, large as a water buffalo and pig-like with grayish-red fur. If it were a rat, who could witness its urine spawning new rats? Tao’s credulity is excessive, yet true scholars of integrity do not dismiss even baseless claims as false. Now, the *Classic* says it "moves through the earth," leaving no doubt it refers to the *fénshǔ*.

**Flying Squirrel (鼺鼺, *léishǔ*, "leaping mouse")**
Governs: miscarriage and facilitates childbirth.
Found in the mountains of Shandu and Pinggu.

Tao Yinju says: The *léi* is the *wúshǔ* (鼯鼠, "flying mouse"), also called *fēishēng* ("flying life"). It resembles a bat but is as large as an owl or kite, with dark purple fur. It flies at night. People take its pelt and fur for parturient women to hold, easing childbirth. There is also the "water horse," a creature of the sea, belonging to the shrimp and fish class. Shaped like a horse, it also aids in childbirth.

Chen Cangqi says: Tao mentions the water horse, found in the sea, which governs childbirth. When a woman is near labor, she may wear it; otherwise, burn it to ashes and take it with water, or simply hold it in hand. It comes from the South Sea, shaped like a horse, five to six *cun* long, and is a type of shrimp. *The Record of Strange Things in the Southern Regions* states: For women whose difficult labor requires tearing the birth canal, holding this creature makes delivery as easy as a sheep’s. Among living creatures, sheep have the easiest births.

Yu Xi says: According to the *General Remedies for Difficult Labor*, the flying squirrel is slightly warm.

*The Extended Materia Medica* states: The *Classic* does not specify the nature or flavor of the *léishǔ*, but in the *General Remedies for Difficult Labor*, it is described as slightly warm. Its fur is reddish-black with a long tail. When captured, its pelt is used to make warm hats. It can fly downward but not far.

In the mountains of Guanzhong today, they are abundant, their fur extremely dense—these are what people call "flying creatures." The *Annotation* also mentions the "water horse," with a head like a horse, a body like a shrimp, a hunched back, and bamboo-joint markings along its body, two to three *cun* long. Today, it is called the "sea horse."

**Wàntuōqí** (seal navel)
Flavor: salty. Non-toxic.
Governs ghostly *qi*, corpse *zhù*-possession, dreams of intercourse with ghosts, demonic and fox spirits, heart and abdominal pain, malign *qi* from possession, congealed stagnant blood, *xuánpǐ* (abdominal masses), emaciation, and similar ailments.

The *kūnè* beast resembles a fox but is larger, with a long tail. It comes from the Western Rong regions.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Wàntuōqí* comes from the Western Rong, though today it is also found along the Eastern Sea, said to be the kidney of the "sea dog" from Silla. Former accounts describe it as the *kūnè* beast, fox-like but larger, with a long tail. Its pelt naturally bears yellow fur, with three hairs growing from a single follicle. The illustration from Cangzhou, however, depicts a fish-like creature with a pig’s head and two feet. Its navel is reddish-purple, marked with purple spots, entirely unlike the beast. Physicians also use this form, testing its authenticity by placing it beside a sleeping dog—if the dog suddenly startles and leaps as if alarmed, it is deemed genuine.

*Rihuazi* states: The *wàntuō* beast is hot in nature. It supplements the center, boosts *qi*, warms the kidneys and knees, aids *yang qi*, breaks up abdominal masses, treats manic epilepsy and heart-abdominal pain, and disperses stagnant blood.

Yu Xi says: According to the *Drug Properties Treatise*, *wàntuōqí* is a sovereign remedy, strongly heating. It is the external kidney of the sea dog from Silla, harvested intact. It governs men’s chronic abdominal masses, cold accumulations, consumptive *qi*, emaciation, kidney essence depletion, excessive sexual activity leading to kidney exhaustion, and emaciation with debility.

Master Lei states: When using it, one must first examine it carefully, for counterfeits are common. In the sea, there is a creature called the "water phoenix-dragon." When fishermen capture and kill it, they take its kidney, which may be mixed into medicinal preparations. To avoid error, note its distinct features: a pair of organs, each encased in two thin layers of skin enclosing the testicle-like flesh. The outer skin bears white fur with yellow hairs, three hairs sharing a single follicle. Though stored for years, it remains moist as if fresh. For use, soak it in wine for a day, wrap it in paper, gently roast over a fire until fragrant, then finely mince and grind it alone.

*The Extended Materia Medica* states: Today, *wàntuōqí* comes from Deng and Laizhou. The *Drug Properties Treatise* identifies it as the external kidney of the sea dog, while *Rihuazi* calls it a beast. Observing its form, it is neither dog nor beast, nor fish. Its forepart resembles a beast, its tail a fish; its body is covered in short, dense pale blue-white fur, its belly and flanks entirely white, interspersed with pale blue. The white fur bears deep blue-black spots, which fade over time. Its skin is thick and tough like cowhide, often used to decorate saddles. Its navel treats abdominal cold accumulations, essence depletion, and extreme spleen-kidney taxation—its efficacy requires no further testing. The description of a fox-like creature with a long tail is likely unfamiliar to most today.

**Musk deer (jǐ)**
Flavor: sweet. Neutral. Non-toxic.
Governs the five types of hemorrhoids. Roasted and served with ginger and vinegar, it is highly effective. It is also said that excessive consumption may trigger chronic illnesses. Its skull, burned to ash and taken with water, governs flying corpse possession.

It grows in the mountains and valleys of the Southeast.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Musk deer are found in the mountains and valleys of the Southeast. Today, they inhabit all forested regions, with particularly high numbers in Jun, Fang, Xiang, and Han. They belong to the river deer family.

Carefully following the *Erya*: *Náo* and *jǐ* are the same. The "great *náo*" has long, shaggy fur and dog-like feet. The explanation states: *Jūn* is also a river deer. *Máo* refers to long fur; *náo* is pronounced like "nao." The "great river deer" with long fur and dog-like feet is called *náo*. Southerners often eat its meat, though it is tough and less flavorful than river deer. Excessive consumption may trigger chronic illnesses. Its hide makes superior shoes, surpassing all other leathers. Its head is also used medicinally.

Yu Xi says: According to *Rihuazi*, musk deer are cooling and slightly toxic. They may induce miscarriage and cause sores, boils, and scabies.

*The Extended Materia Medica* states: Musk deer belong to the river deer family but are smaller. Their mouths bear long tusks, which they use in combat. Their hide is the finest of all, unmatched in quality, though often marred by tusk wounds. They are found everywhere, with greater numbers in deep mountains. Their cry resembles the sound of a cracked cymbal.

**Wild boar’s gallstone (yězhūhuáng)**
Flavor: pungent, sweet. Neutral. Non-toxic.
Governs sword wounds, stanches bleeding, and promotes flesh regeneration. It treats epilepsy. Ground into a paste the size of a jujube pit and taken twice daily, it is effective.

Yu Xi says: According to Meng Shen, wild boar nourishes the skin and flesh, causing a healthy plumpness. Its gall contains a yellow substance. Ground with water and taken, it treats *zhù*-possession. Its meat surpasses that of domestic pigs, with females being more flavorful. In winter, they feed on acorns in the forest, their meat red and nourishing the five *zang* organs’ wind-*qi*. Its fat, refined to purity, taken with a spoonful in a cup of wine three times daily, promotes lactation in women. After ten days of use, it can sustain three or four children. Its teeth, burned to ash and taken, counteract snake venom. Its gall treats malign heat-*qi*.

*Rihuazi* states: Wild boar governs intestinal wind with bloody discharge. Roasted and eaten, ten meals suffice. The yellow in its gall treats ghostly *zhù*-possession, epilepsy, malign toxic wind, childhood *gān*-*qi*, fright reversal, and "heavenly hanging" (convulsions). Its fat enhances complexion and dispels wind-swelling, toxic sores, scabies, and ringworm. Aged specimens from the twelfth month are best. Its external kidneys, burned with the skin to ash (without over-charring), ground to powder, and taken with water, treat flooding and spotting, intestinal wind with bloody discharge, and bloody dysentery.

*The Mirror of Food as Medicine Formulas* states: For chronic hemorrhoids, incessant bloody discharge from wild fowl, and perianal pain, take two *jin* of pork, slice it, season with the five flavors, and roast. Consume on an empty stomach. A meat broth may also be prepared.

*The Extension of Materia Medica* says: The yellow within the gall of wild boar treats all kinds of childhood epilepsy. In the western regions of the capital, wild boars abound. Their form resembles that of domestic swine, though their bellies are smaller, their legs longer, and their fur brown. They travel in herds, and hunters dare only shoot the last one, for if one of the leading boars is struck, the entire herd scatters and tramples people. Their flesh is red like horse meat, its flavor sweet, and the meat tender, though it may slightly stir wind. The yellow is not always present; when obtained, it is rarely used in the world, though eating it is still superior to domestic pork.

**Worn Drumhide** [neutral in nature]
Governs *gǔ*-poison.

*The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica* states: Worn drumhide governs *gǔ*-poison. Ancient formulas also use it alone, burning it to ash and taking it. Its use is now rare, so it is merely appended here. Tao Yinju says: Use only the perforated, worn portions, burn them to fragments, and take with water. The afflicted will then call out the name of the *gǔ*-master, who may be sent for to retrieve the *gǔ*, and the patient will recover. The same applies to white *rìhé* (previously moved from the Herbs section).

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library* formula for *gǔ*: Take a piece of worn drumhide, five *cun* wide and one *chi* long, and five *cun* of rose root (as thick as a thumb; the *Ben Yuan* says *làngdàng* root). Chop them, boil in one *sheng* of water and three *sheng* of wine, and reduce to one *sheng*. Take to expel the *gǔ*-worms and recover.

*Master Mei’s Formulas* for sudden *gǔ*-poisoning with bloody discharge like goose liver, unceasing day and night, and visceral decay nearing death: If the *gǔ*-master’s name is known, burn worn drumhide to ash and take it, calling out the name to expel the poison. To ascertain the *gǔ*-master’s name, take a small amount of worn drumhide, grind it to powder, and take with water. The patient will soon call out the name.

*The Extension of Materia Medica* says: Of worn drumhides, yellow oxhide is superior. Nowadays, the type of hide is not specified, though donkey or horsehide may also be used. As Han Tuizhi of the Tang said: "Cow urine, horse fungus, and worn drumhide—all are gathered and stored, awaiting use without waste." Today, its applications are few, and it is chiefly used for boiling glue. Only oxhide should be used medicinally.

**Mí Deer Fat**
Flavor: acrid. Nature: warm. Non-toxic.
Governs abscesses, malign sores, necrotic flesh, cold-damp impediment, and slackened limbs that cannot be contracted. Treats wind-head swelling and *qi*, unblocks interstices, and softens the skin. Do not apply near the genitals, as it causes impotence. Also called *gōng* fat. Aversion: rhubarb.

**Mí Deer Antler**
Flavor: sweet. Non-toxic.
Governs impediment, stanches bleeding, and boosts *qi* and strength. Grows in the mountain valleys of Mount Nanshan and along the Huai and sea coasts. Harvest in the tenth month.

Master Tao Yinju said: "Today, they are most numerous in the region of Hailing, gathering in herds of thousands, with many does and few bucks. It is said that a single buck will mate with over ten does, and upon finishing, dies. Its fat, having fallen to the earth, is gathered after a year—this is of fine quality and called *dùn* fat. Taken with wine, it is most efficacious. Yet the *mí* deer’s nature is so lustful and swift that it should not cause impotence. Another tradition holds that it must not be applied near the genitals, lest it cause the member to wither—this makes sense.

The flesh of the *mí* deer must not be eaten together with shrimp, raw greens, plums, apricots, or other fruits, as it harms the eater. Scrape its antler to gather shavings, then roast them to release their fragrance; taken with wine, they greatly benefit one’s vitality. This is recorded in the *Biographies of Master Pengzu*.

Lu Xisheng said: According to Meng Shen, *mí* deer flesh boosts *qi*, fortifies the center, and treats pain in the lower back and legs. It must not be eaten with pheasant meat. Carefully noted: the flesh has little medicinal use, though its consumption slightly supplements the five viscera and replenishes insufficient *qi*. Eating too much weakens the bedchamber arts and triggers beriberi. The bones, however, are most excellent for dispelling vacuity taxation. Boil the bones to make a broth, then brew wine with it—drinking this makes one plump, fair-skinned, and radiant. It is also said that the antler supplements vacuity taxation and fills the marrow.

Method for preparing the antler: cut it into five-inch sections, split them open, and roast until yellow and fragrant, then grind into powder. Take three *qiánbǐ* on an empty stomach with wine. For sudden heart pain, a single dose brings immediate relief. Taken regularly, it makes one’s complexion bloom with red and white like flowers and strengthens the male member. Why this is so remains unclear, for its effects differ from those of the flesh. It may also be simmered into glue, which functions like deer antler glue.

The velvet is far superior to deer velvet and is highly prized in Daoist elixirs. For men suffering from cold *qi* and wind, or pain in the sinews and bones, it may be processed into powder for long-term consumption. Alternatively, grind it into a paste with fermented water and apply to the face to prevent wrinkles and impart a lovely, lustrous glow.

Common folk make boots from its hide, which fumigate beriberi.

*Tested Prescriptions*: To treat depletion of bone marrow in the elderly, the *Mí* Velvet Decoction is prepared thus: take five *liǎng* of *mí* velvet, remove the fur, coat with clarified butter, and roast until slightly yellow, then grind into powder. Simmer with two *shēng* of clear wine in a silver pot over a slow fire until it forms a paste, and store in a ceramic vessel. Take half a spoonful, mixed with warm wine, on an empty stomach before meals.

Shen Cunzhong’s *Brush Talks* states: *Mí* velvet powerfully supplements the Yang, while deer velvet powerfully supplements the Yin. It strengthens the bones and blood, firms the male member, and fortifies the bone marrow. Velvet that is too tender, several inches long, and crumbles like rotten wood when broken is of poor quality. The finest specimens are as lustrous as agate and as red as carnelian."

Donkey dung, when boiled, is applied as a poultice for wind-swelling, scabies, and sores. Its liquid extract treats sudden pain in the heart and abdomen, as well as all forms of *zhù* possession and counterflow. Donkey urine governs *zhèng* and *pǐ* accumulations, unceasing stomach reflux with vomiting, toothache, and water toxin. Mare’s urine governs dry-water; donkey urine governs damp-water—five *gé* per dose is effective. In cases of dry-water, characters drawn on the body remain distinct; in damp-water, they do not. Donkey milk treats infantile heat, acute jaundice, and the like. Excessive consumption induces dysentery. The grime beneath the tail, when washed with water to extract its juice, is mixed with flour into two pellets the size of marbles and baked into flatbread. One is eaten before the onset of malaria, the other at the time of the attack, curing malaria whether chronic or recent, regardless of its cycle.

Yu Xishu states: According to the *Shu Ben*, it is sweet in flavor, cool and purging in nature, and treats wasting-thirst. Donkeys come in many colors, but the black ones are superior. Xiao Bing says: Donkey milk governs heat-jaundice, infantile heat, fright-induced disorders, and red dysentery. *Rihuazi* states: Its milk treats infantile epilepsy, *kèwǔ* possession, and *tiāndiào* wind. Meng Shen says: Its meat governs wind-madness, sorrow, and melancholy, and can pacify the heart and *qi*. Furthermore, the head, singed to remove the hair and boiled to make a decoction, is used to steep yeast for brewing wine that dispels severe wind. Also, fresh fat mixed with fresh peppercorns, pounded thoroughly, and wrapped in silk to plug the ears treats chronic deafness. For those with manic madness who cannot speak or recognize others, three *shēng* taken with wine is effective.

The hide, when draped over a malaria patient, is beneficial. Also, when boiled with the hair to make glue, it treats all wind-toxins, incessant groaning from bone-joint pain—mixed with wine and taken, it is highly effective. Furthermore, the bones boiled into a broth and used to bathe the body treat *lìjié* wind. Also, the head boiled to make a decoction, with two or three *shēng* taken, cures long-standing wasting-thirst without fail. Also, the fat mixed with smoked plums into pills treats chronic malaria—thirty pills taken before an attack. Also, for all wind disorders of the head, one *jīn* of hair is stir-fried until yellow, then steeped in one *dǒu* of wine for three days. Taken in small sips on an empty stomach until drunk, the patient is covered and made to sweat. The next day, the same is repeated. Avoid old stored rice and wheat flour.

The *Wàitái Mìyào Fāng* states: For treating stomach reflux. In my youth, I suffered from this ailment—every time I ate cakes, porridge, or soup, I would soon vomit it all up. During the Zhenguan era, the imperial physicians Xu and his brothers, as well as the families of Chai and Jiang, renowned as master physicians, were ordered by imperial decree to exhaust all treatments, yet none could cure me. I grew increasingly emaciated, and my condition seemed near death. Suddenly, a wandering physician said: Drinking donkey urine is extremely effective. I took two *gé* daily, and afterward, only half of my food was vomited. At dusk, I took another two *gé*, and by the hour of *rén-dìng*, when I ate porridge, the vomiting ceased. By midday the next day, I reported this to the court. Five or six others in the palace suffering from stomach reflux were treated simultaneously, and all were cured at once. This medicine is slightly toxic, so the dosage must not be excessive. Collect the urine while warm and take two *gé* hot. For severe cases, continue for seven days—highly effective. Later, all those treated with it were cured.

*The Extensive Notes on Materia Medica* states: Donkey meat, when eaten, stirs wind, and this effect is especially pronounced with fatty portions—repeated trials have consistently confirmed this. *Ri Hua Zi* claims it arrests wind madness and cures all wind disorders, but this cannot be relied upon. When rendering donkey-hide gelatin, the skin is used to disperse [wind] outward through the skin; still, it must be from a black donkey. The preference for black follows the same principle as using black chicken eggs, black snakes, or black crows. Though the substance treats wind, the deeper rationale lies in its water-like color, which tempers the heat that generates wind.

Badger meat, bladder, and fat are sweet in flavor, neutral in nature, and nontoxic. They govern shortness of breath, fatigue, and cough with counterflow qi. Mix three *gé* with wine and take twice daily. They also treat equine lung disease, intestinal parasites, and similar ailments. The meat cures chronic water distension in those near death: prepare it as a thick soup or stew, and it will purge water with great efficacy. The bladder, dried and ground into a paste the size of a chicken egg, is taken on an empty stomach to induce vomiting of all *gǔ* poisons. Chen Cangqi states: Badger fat governs transmission of corpse-*qi*, *zhù* infestations, and demonic encounters. Melt it in wine and drink. It also kills the parasites of equine spinal sores, and those who have ingested cinnabar or mineral drugs benefit from eating it. Another name is *huān tún*, for it is extremely fatty. First appended in the *Tang Materia Medica*.

Yu Xisong notes: According to Meng Xian, badger meat treats those who have taken cinnabar or mineral drugs and suffer from taxation heat, enduring red-and-white dysentery. Boil the meat, expose it overnight in the dew, and eat it the next morning with fermented sauce on an empty stomach—one meal will cure it.
