For infantile *gan*-induced dysentery, administer the bile into the nostrils or lower body.

*Imperial Grace Formulary*: To treat acute *gan* sores in children, finely grind python bile, mix with water, and apply topically.

*Yang’s Obstetrics and Pediatrics Formulary*: To cure chronic warm dysentery with emaciation, excessive drowsiness, closed eyes when seated, and loss of appetite, take two python bile pellets the size of beans, grind them with boiled *tongcao* (rice-paper plant) juice, and drink an appropriate amount. Also apply to the five centers (palms, soles, and chest) and the lower body.

*Records of the Court and the Common Folk* states: Lu Yuanqin of Quanzhou suffered from *da feng* (severe leprosy), with only his nose unaffected. On the fifth day of the fifth month, he obtained python bile to offer as medicine. Someone mentioned that the flesh could treat wind disorders, so he ate a section of the snake. After three to five days, he gradually improved, and within a hundred days, he fully recovered.

**Snake Slough** (pronounced *shui*)
Flavor: salty, sweet
Nature: neutral, non-toxic
It governs the one hundred and twenty types of infantile fright epilepsy, *qi* (convulsions), *zong* (spasms), *dian* (epilepsy), alternating chills and fever, intestinal hemorrhoids, worm toxins, snake epilepsy, tongue-playing and head-shaking, the five evils in adults, slurred speech, malignant sores, vomiting, coughing, and improves vision. Roasting enhances its efficacy.

Alternative names: *Dragon’s Child Garment*, *Snake Talisman*, *Dragon’s Child Skin*, *Dragon’s Child Single Robe*, *Bow Skin*.
It grows in the river valleys and fields of Jingzhou. Collect it on the fifth or fifteenth day of the fifth month for optimal quality.

It fears magnetite and wine. Tao Hongjing states: "In the grass, one rarely encounters the sloughs of *hui* or *fu* vipers; only the longer ones are mostly from the red-□ or yellow-collared varieties. Their skins are no longer recognizable, but those now commonly obtained are all intact. Those found on rocks are also #4 excellent; burning them effectively treats all malignant sores." Xu Zhixi notes: "According to the *Yaoxing Lun* (*Treatise on Medicinal Properties*), snake slough is a ministerial drug, toxic. It governs the hundred demonic possessions and also treats *xian*-malaria #5." Chen Cangqi states: "According to the *Bencao* (*Materia Medica*), snake slough governs malaria. On the day of an acute episode, insert the slough into both ears; at the onset of an attack, hold a small piece in the hand while also ingesting a mixture of salt and vinegar to induce vomiting." *Rihuazi* states: "It treats *gu* toxins, repels evil, stops retching, cures infantile fright and *kewu* (sudden fright), and hastens childbirth. For scrofula and vitiligo, decoct the slough and apply the liquid topically. For medicinal use, roast it." The *Shiliao* (*Dietary Therapy*) states: "Snake slough dispels evil and brightens the eyes. It treats the one hundred and twenty types of infantile fright epilepsy, alternating chills and fever, intestinal hemorrhoids, *gu* toxins, all #6 □ malignant sores, and calms the fetus. Roast it for use."

*The Holy Beneficence Formulary*: For infantile double palate or swollen, painful double gums, burn the slough into ash and apply topically—efficacious.

*The Thousand Gold Prescriptions*: For untreated swellings with pus, burn snake slough, mix with water, and bind onto the swelling—worms will emerge. Alternate formula: For malignant sores persisting ten years, resembling *lai* (leprosy), burn one whole slough into ash, blend with lard, and apply—excellent.

*The Comprehensive Rescue Formulary*: For transverse presentation in difficult labor, place one snake slough in a jar, seal with salt-clay, and calcine to black ash. Administer two *qian* per dose, mixed with elm bark decoction—immediate effect.

*The Infallible Remedies*: For five types of hemorrhoids with anal prolapse, use a finger-sized dead snake. Dig a pit, burn the snake within, then cover the pit with a perforated board and sit atop it—worms will emerge completely.

*Du Ren’s Formulary*: For *chanhou* wind (constricting throat wind) with throat constriction and obstructed *qi*, roast snake slough until yellow, combine with equal parts *danggui* (Chinese angelica), grind into powder, and take one *qianbi* with warm wine—recovery follows vomiting.

*The Book of Childbirth*: For obstructed labor with hands or feet presenting first, burn snake slough into ash and grind finely. Administer one *qianbi* with east-facing wine, then apply the powder to the hands and feet—delivery will proceed smoothly.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: Snake slough is shed by turning inside out from the mouth, even the eyes are shed. Modern eye medicines frequently employ it for this reason. For medicinal use, wash it clean.

**White-collared Earthworm**
Flavor: salty
Nature: cold, greatly cold
Non-toxic
Governs *shejia* (snake-like abdominal masses), expels the three worms, *fushi* (recurrent corpse malaria), *guizhu* (ghostly infestation), and *gu* toxins; kills intestinal parasites, and may spontaneously liquefy. Treats latent heat in *shanghan* (cold damage), manic delirium, abdominal distension, and jaundice.
Alternate name: *tulong* (earth dragon)
Found in level soil; collected in the third month. Dried in shade.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: White-collared earthworms inhabit level soil, and are found everywhere in lowland marshes and fertile earth. The white-collared variety are the oldest. Harvested in the third month, dried in shade. Another method: split open, remove soil, salt, then sun-dry. Prescriptionists call them *dilong* (earth dragons).

For remedies treating *jiaofeng* (wind-induced foot disorders), this substance must be used as an adjuvant—yet it is also toxic. There was once a man who, having used it in a formula for foot ailments, indeed achieved remarkable efficacy. After his condition resolved, he continued taking it without cessation; by the twentieth day, he grew restless and disoriented, craving water incessantly until he became utterly debilitated. When employing potent medicinals to attack an illness, one must cease administration once the disease is cured.

Its excrement is called *qinlou*; mixed with salt and applied to sores, it dispels heat-toxins.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: Earthworms may also be used alone, possessing mild toxicity. The dried form, stir-fried into powder, governs snakebite toxins. Another name: *dilongzi* (earth dragon offspring).

*The Tang Materia Medica* annotates: *The Miscellaneous Records* states that when steeped in salt to produce a juice, it treats deafness. Salt dissolves *hui* (roundworms), its function akin to that of earthworms. Its excrement seals the wounds of rabid dogs, expelling the dog’s fur with divine efficacy.

Chen Cangqi remarks: Earthworm excrement (fecal soil) treats chronic red-and-white dysentery with enduring heat. Take one *sheng* of the sand-free variety, stir-fry until smoke ceases, then infuse with water to yield half a *dasheng*. Strain and consume on an empty stomach.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: Earthworms treat wind-stroke, epilepsy, expel the three worms, address *chuanshi* (consumptive corpse transmission), epidemic febrile diseases, throat impediment, and snake or insect bites. Another name: *qianrenta* ("trampled by a thousand people"), referring to those crushed on roads. For medicinal use, burn before employing. Its excrement treats snakebites, dog bites, and heat sores—ground with salt and applied topically. For sudden vacuity-heat swelling and pain in a child’s scrotum, mix with licorice juice and apply gently.

Zhang Yuxi notes: According to *The Sichuan Materia Medica* annotation, it resolves *shewang* (aconite) poisoning.

*The Sagely Benefit Formulary*: For wind-induced red eyes, take ten earthworms, roast dry, and grind into powder. At bedtime, take two *qianbi* with cold tea.

*The Thousand Gold Formulary*: For exposed tooth roots, mix earthworm excrement with water into a paste, burn until glowing red, then grind into powder. Blend with lard from a twelfth-month pig and apply thrice daily for lasting relief.

*The Doumen Formulary*: For urinary blockage, strain earthworms through cold water and consume half a bowl of the thick liquid—immediate relief. It also powerfully resolves heat-induced loss of consciousness, reviving those near death.

*The Victorious Gold Formulary*: For instant relief of deafness, place a dried earthworm with salt inside a scallion bulb and apply the resulting liquid as drops.

*The Hundred and One Formulary*: For taxation relapse after intercourse, with swollen or retracted testicles, abdominal colic, or urinary cessation, wring the juice from several earthworms and consume—highly effective.

Another formula: For *gu* poisoning with hematemesis, bloody diarrhea, or rotting liver, steep fourteen earthworms in three *sheng* of bitter wine until they perish, then drink the liquid. Even the dying may be revived.

*An Extension of the Materia Medica* states: White-collared earthworms that die naturally are superior, though they too sing in season. This substance is toxic. Once, a man with abdominal distension heard earthworms singing within his body at night; someone instructed him to soak them in salt water, and he recovered. In the late Chongning era, a soldier in Pingzhou stood barefoot beneath the vice-prefect’s hall during the summer heat and was struck by an earthworm’s venom—beyond saving. Days later, another victim of the toxin was cured after a learned man advised first drinking a cup of salt water, then soaking the feet in salt water. When used medicinally, earthworms should be cleansed of soil and lightly roasted. For treating wind in the kidney viscus and lower *zheng* (damp-heat) disorders, it is indispensable—best taken with salt water. As Wang Jinggong observed: "Even straw and sacrificial meats have their savor—how could earthworms alone be deemed incorruptible?"

Spider: Slightly cold.

Spider:
Governs ailments in adults and children. On the seventh day of the seventh month, collect its web to treat forgetfulness from excessive laughter or play. Tao Yinju states: Spiders comprise dozens of species, yet the *Erya* records only seven or eight. The type used here spins suspended webs resembling fish traps and is also called *□mou*. When bees or centipedes sting, place a spider on the wound to draw out the venom. It also breaks malarial fevers and treats dry retching with cholera. Diviners weave its web into clothing collars to ward off evil. The red-spotted variety, commonly called "bride’s net," is also employed in esoteric arts. Other miscellaneous species are not used medicinally. The *Book of Songs* says: "The *xiaoshao* dwells at the door"—this refers precisely to the spider. The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: The *Miscellaneous Records* states it treats childhood *dingxi* (severe abdominal distension) where the child cannot walk for three years, as well as snake venom, warm malaria, cholera, and counterflow retching. In Jiannan and Shandong, bites from this insect cause wounds to exude silk, often proving fatal. Its web, wrapped around warts or growths, will rot them away in seven days—verified by experience.

Zheng Xiaoci notes: According to *Ri Huazi*, the spotted spider is cold and non-toxic, treating malaria and *ding* swellings. Its web, collected at dawn on the seventh day of the seventh month, sharpens wit and dispels forgetfulness. It also states: The wall-money insect is neutral and slightly toxic, treating childhood vomiting and counterflow, stanching nosebleeds and sores. Drip its juice into the nose or onto sores, including fistula. This refers to the spider that makes cocoons on walls.

The *Sagely Benefit Formulary* prescribes for scrofula, regardless of whether it has a head: Use five large spiders, sun-dried and finely ground, mixed with butter into a salve, applied twice daily.

The *Thousand Gold Prescriptions* treats mouse-fistula with swollen, painful nodules or suppurating sores: Burn fourteen spiders and apply the ashes—highly effective.

The *Leisurely Remedies* addresses chronic diarrhea with prolapsed, painful anus (Black Sage Powder): Wrap one large spider in bottle-gourd leaves, bind tightly, and burn in a container until charred (retaining its nature). Remove, grind finely, and add a pinch of yellow lead. For the aforementioned ailments, first bathe the area with a decoction of alum, scallions, and pepper, then dry and dust the powder onto the affected soft tissue. Press the anus back in with a cloth-covered hand—marvelously effective.

Sun Zhenren’s *Prescriptions* treats centipede bites: Place one spider on the bite; it will drink the venom and die. If pain persists, replace it with a live one.

The *Extensive Benefit Formulary* treats scorpion stings: Grind a spider into juice and apply—it heals.

The *Treasury of Obstetrics* treats postpartum coughing counterflow lasting three to five days, near death: Simmer three to five wall-spider nests and sip the broth—it cures.

The *Amplification of the Materia Medica* states: Spiders have many varieties, all venomous, yet the *Canon* does not specify which type to use. Today, people commonly use those found in household eaves, fence corners, or narrow alleys, spinning round webs with large abdomens and ash-gray color. Their urine causes sores and ringworm.

**Wasp (Yong, pronounced *ye* above, *weng* below)**
Flavor: acrid. Nature: neutral, non-toxic.
Governs chronic deafness, coughing counterflow, toxic qi, foul excretions, and treats nasal obstruction (*zhi*, pronounced *li*).
Its earthen nest treats abscesses and wind-head. Also called "earth bee." Grows in the valleys of Xiong’er Mountains and Jiangke, or in human dwellings.

Tao Yinju states: This type is numerous. Though called "earth bee," it does not burrow into soil but gathers earth to build chambers. One variety is black with a very slender waist, carrying mud to construct nests on walls or household objects, resembling bundled bamboo tubes. It lays millet-sized eggs inside, then captures over ten green spiders from grass to fill the chamber, sealing the entrance as provisions for its offspring. Another variety nests in reed or bamboo tubes, also collecting green caterpillars—one name is *guoluo*.

The *Book of Songs* says: "The *mingling* has young; the *guoluo* carries them away." It admonishes: "Instruct your children to emulate such goodness." This falsely claims that slender-waisted creatures lack females and instead seize green caterpillars, enchanting them through incantations to transform into their own offspring. The poet’s oversight is understandable, but why did the Sage (Confucius) not correct such obscurity? The Sage’s omissions are often of this kind.

*Ri Huazi* states: This insect is toxic. Treats counterflow retching; crush fresh to apply to bamboo or wood splinters. For medicinal use, stir-fry.

Li Hanguang’s *Pronunciation and Meaning* notes: The transformation of caterpillars into offspring through incantations has been observed numerous times in recent years—it is no empty claim.

The *Sagely Benefit Formulary* treats childhood cholera with vomiting and diarrhea: Lightly roast the insect’s nest, grind into powder, and administer a pinch with breast milk—it stops.

The *Amplification of the Materia Medica* states: Though previous scholars have discussed the wasp exhaustively, I dare not abandon the *Book of Songs*’ intent. I once broke open a nest and observed: It indeed contains offspring, half the size of millet grains, white with a slight yellow hue. The carried caterpillar also lies within—specifically a green vegetable worm—positioned beneath the offspring, not adhering to it. It is neither a leaf worm nor a grass-dwelling green caterpillar; seemingly, any insect will suffice. Tao Yinju’s account is closest to the truth. People grind these nests finely, mix with vinegar, and apply to bee stings.

**Bean-Flower Longhorn (Geshang Tingzhang)**
Flavor: acrid. Nature: slightly warm, toxic.
Governs *gu* poison, ghostly infestations, breaks urinary strangury and accumulations, and induces abortion. Harvest in the seventh month and dry in the sun. Also called "spotted cat."

The *Illustrated Classic* states: Details are provided under the *yuanqing* entry.

Tao Yinju states: Collect it when kudzu blooms. Its body is black with a red head, resembling a person wearing a black robe and red headscarf—hence the name "Captain."

This single insect undergoes five transformations, yet its therapeutic uses remain similar. In the second and third months, it dwells upon *yuanhua* (genkwa flower) and is called *yuanqing*; in the fourth and fifth months, upon *wangbuliuxing* (vaccaria seed), and is called the *wangbuliuxing* insect; in the sixth and seventh months, upon kudzu blossoms, and is called the Bean-Flower Longhorn; in the eighth month, upon bean flowers, and is called the "spotted cat"; in the ninth and tenth months, as it prepares to burrow underground for hibernation, it is called the "ground beetle." This is merely a false ground beetle, yet its therapeutic effects remain akin to its kind. The Longhorn carries eggs within its abdomen, white as grains of rice, which govern the treatment of all forms of urinary strangury and accumulations.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: Upon examining the *Ben Cao* and various ancient and modern formulas, no use of the *wangbuliuxing* insect has been found. If this were so, then the four insects would reside in a single place.

Yuxi states: According to the *Shu Ben Cao Illustrated Classic*, it is gathered from kudzu leaves in the fifth and sixth months, resembling *yuanqing* but of a dark gray hue.

Whenever using the "spotted cat," *yuanqing*, Longhorn, or similar insects, they should be stir-fried with glutinous rice until the rice turns yellowish-black, then removed. Discard the head, legs, and wings, wrap in disheveled hair, and suspend from the roof beam for one night before incorporating into medicine.

**Climbing Gecko (Gejie)**
Flavor: salty. Nature: neutral, slightly toxic.
Governs chronic consumptive lung disease, corpse transmission, slays demonic entities and malevolent qi, treats coughing, relieves urinary dribbling, and unblocks the water pathways.
Found in the mountain valleys of Lingnan, as well as upon city walls or amidst large trees. Its body measures four to five *cun*, with a tail equal in length to its body.

Its form resembles the large *shougong* (house gecko), always found in pairs—one male and one female—which call out their own name, "gejie." They are particularly protective of their tails; if they sense someone attempting to capture them, they often bite off their own tails to escape. Those who gather them must preserve the tail, for its medicinal potency remains intact only when the tail is whole.

The *Fangyan* states: "In the region of Guilin, the *shougong* that can vocalize is called *gejie*, for they are similar." The *Tujing* records: "The *gejie* dwells in the mountain valleys of Lingnan, as well as upon city walls or amidst large trees. Today, they are also found beyond the Lingnan range. Their heads resemble those of toads, their backs bear fine scales like silkworm eggs, and their color is yellowish-brown like earth. They measure four to five *cun* in length, with tails equal to their bodies, belonging to the same category as *shougong* and *yanting*." Thus, Yang Xiong’s *Fangyan* notes: "In Guilin, the *shougong* that can vocalize is commonly called *gejie*, for it calls out its own name." The tail holds the full medicinal power; when captured, the creature will bite off its own tail to escape. Their nests are often found in banyan trees, though some inhabit old houses or city towers. To obtain specimens with intact heads and tails, hunters use a long-handled two-pronged iron fork, resembling a pole used for catching birds. They lie in wait among the banyan branches, impaling the *gejie* with one prong through the brain and the other through the tail, preventing it from biting off its tail. They always travel in pairs—one male and one female—and both must be used in medicine. Some say that men of *yang* constitution should use the female, while men of *yin* constitution should use the male.

The *Rihuazi* states: "Non-toxic. It governs lung *qi*, arrests coughing, regulates menstruation, relieves stone strangury, and treats blood disorders." It is also called *haxie*. When preparing it for medicine, remove the head and feet, wash away the scales and internal impurities, then roast with butter for optimal effect.

The *Yanyi* records: "*Gejie* is effective in supplementing consumptive lung deficiency and chronic cough. When deficiency heat accumulates in the lungs over time, it forms sores, leading to coughing of pus and blood, day and night without respite. For those with obstructed throat *qi*, chest and diaphragm constriction, and pain, combine one *liang* each of *gejie*, *ejiao* (ass-hide glue), raw rhinoceros horn, deer antler glue, and antelope horn. Except for the glues, grind the rest into powder, then incorporate the glues. Divide into four doses. For each dose, use three *sheng* of river water in a silver or stone vessel, simmer over a slow fire until reduced to half a *sheng*. Strain the dregs, and sip the decoction warm before bed. Once the dregs are exhausted, pound them again, combine into a single dose, and simmer with three *sheng* of water until reduced to half a *sheng*, then administer as before. If the patient is chronically deficient and averse to water, gradually reduce the amount of water used." Zhang Xingbu’s son, Gao, was gravely ill, and Gu Shumi of the Bureau of Military Affairs sent this formula, which cured him.

**Centipede (Wugong)**
Flavor: acrid. Nature: warm, toxic.
Governs demonic infestation, *gu* poison, and counteracts the venom of snakes, insects, and fish. It slays demonic entities, old *jing* spirits, and *wen* malaria, dispels the "three accumulations," treats cold-heat bind in the heart and abdomen, induces abortion, and expels stagnant blood.
Found in the river valleys of the greater Wu region and Jiangnan. Those with red heads and feet are of superior quality.

**The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica* states:**
Centipedes are found in the river valleys of Wu and Jiangnan, and today they also abound in Jiangsu, Zhejiang, the mountainous regions south of the Qinling, and the areas of Tang and Deng. They often dwell in the walls of houses built with earth and stone. Those with red heads and feet are of the finest quality. They are collected in the seventh and eighth months, though yellow-footed ones are most common. If scorched red over fire, they become unusable. Their nature enables them to subdue snakes—upon encountering a large serpent, they swiftly climb and devour its brain. Tao Hongjing and Su Gong both identified the *jiju* mentioned in *Zhuangzi* as the "sweet-banded" creature, and *Huainanzi* records that "the soaring serpent is imperiled by the *jiju*," both referring to the centipede. Tao Hongjing noted that red-footed centipedes are most abundant around Jingkou, and are also found in Changshan, Gaolishan, and Maoshan, particularly in rotting piles of grass. Care must be taken not to injure them, and they should be dried in the sun. Yellow-footed ones are plentiful but unusable; people often scorch them red to pass them off as genuine, which is false. Another name for the centipede is *jiju*. Zhuang Zhou wrote: "*Jiju* relishes the sweet-banded." *Huainanzi* states: "Though the soaring serpent glides through mist, it is imperiled by the *jiju*." Their nature enables them to subdue snakes—upon encountering a large serpent, they swiftly climb and devour its brain. Centipedes may also spit venom at humans; applying mulberry sap or white salt will cure the injury. *Ri Huazi* notes that centipedes treat *zheng* and *pi* accumulations, demonic possession, and snake venom, and should be roasted before medicinal use. The *Secret Records of the Mother-Child* prescribes centipede juice for infantile *cuokou* disease, where sores the size of millet grains appear on the tongue. Scrape the fingernails, grind the centipede, and apply the paste to the flesh at both ends of the nail; this brings a cure. If no fresh centipede is available, dried ones may be used. *Extended Meanings* states: The centipede’s back is glossy black-green, its feet red, and its underside yellow. For those poisoned by its bite, mix chicken droppings with water to a thick consistency and apply to the wound; this is effective. Garlic also works. Furthermore, centipedes treat cinnabar toxin and tumors. Grind one dried centipede with a piece of alum the size of a soapberry, one thunder-ball fungus, and two *qian* of stemona root, then mix with vinegar and apply. Centipedes also fear slugs and dare not cross their path; if a slug touches a centipede, the latter dies, so people use slugs to treat centipede venom. Mulberry sap and white salt are also effective.

**Leech (Shuizhi)**
Flavor: salty, bitter. Nature: neutral, slightly cold, toxic.
Governs the expulsion of malign blood, static blood, menstrual block, blood amassments, accumulations, infertility, and the facilitation of water pathways; it also induces abortion. Another name is *qi*, or *zhizhang*. It grows in the ponds and marshes of Leize and is collected in the fifth and sixth months, then dried in the sun.

**The *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica* states:**
Leeches grow in the ponds and marshes of Leize, and today they are abundant in nearby rivers and ponds. Another name is *qi*. There are several varieties: those living in water are called water leeches, also known as *mahuang*; those in mountains are called stone leeches; those in grass are called grass leeches; and those in mud are called mud leeches. All can attach to humans, cattle, and horses, biting and sucking blood. In severe cases, they burrow into the flesh, and their breeding causes great harm. Some water leeches reach a foot in length, but smaller ones are preferable for use. They are collected in the sixth month and dried in the sun. Some say that upon collection, they should be placed in a bamboo tube, allowed to dry, then soaked overnight in rice-washing water before being removed and dried again. Alternatively, in winter, they may be fried in lard until yellowed, after which they are usable. When drying leeches, stretch them lengthwise, and if they contain eggs, remove them. Ancient methods sometimes used leeches to consume sores, but they are difficult to obtain when urgently needed. Cui Zhiti advised keeping them in advance for such use. Leeches are extremely hard to kill; even after roasting over fire for a year, they may revive upon contact with water. Stone leeches and others with pointed heads and thick abdomens are unfit for medicinal use. If mistakenly used, they cause unceasing smoke-like irritation in the eyes, gradually leading to dryness and damage—this must be carefully distinguished. The *Treatise on Medicinal Properties* states that leeches serve as an envoy. They break through menstrual block in women, preventing blood taxation and *zheng* accumulations, and treat blood accumulations. Tao Hongjing noted that *qi* has several varieties, and the horse leech, which bites humans and contains blood, is best when dried. Mountain leeches and smaller varieties are not used. When the King of Chu ate cold pickled greens, he swallowed one and was cured of accumulations. Though this was attributed to divine protection, it was also due to the creature’s inherent nature. *Ri Huazi* states that leeches fear lime and break up *zheng* accumulations. They are extremely difficult to prepare: after finely slicing, they must be stir-fried over low heat until yellowed to be considered ready. Otherwise, they may enter the abdomen, breed, and cause harm. The *Tested Prescriptions* treats fractures with leeches dried on a new tile, ground into fine powder, and taken with hot wine in a dose of one *qian*. After a meal’s time, if pain persists, take another dose; when the pain ceases, apply bone-setting medicine and bind it firmly until healed. *Chu Yushi’s Prescriptions* treats falls from heights and traumatic internal injuries with remarkable efficacy. Grind one *liang* each of musk and leeches until broken, then stir-fry until smoke rises, and grind into powder. Take one *qian* with wine to expel stagnant blood; if unrelieved, take another dose. The effect is divine. *Extended Meanings* states that the accounts of Chen Cangqi and *Ri Huazi* are comprehensive. In the capital, large leeches are called *ma bie* (horse turtles), and yellow-bellied ones are called *ma huang* (horse leeches). They fear salt, yet are effective in treating fractures. Neither the *Classic* nor its *Commentaries* mention their preparation—this must be attended to with care. Today, people generally use stir-fried leeches.

**Blister Beetle (Banmao)**
Flavor: acrid. Nature: cold, toxic.

**Blister Beetle (Banmao)**
Governs alternating chills and fever, ghostly infestations, *gu* poison, rodent fistula, scabies, ringworm, malignant sores, deep-rooted ulcers, necrotic flesh, shatters stone-like malaria, blood accumulations, and damages human tissue; induces abortion. Also called "Dragon’s Tail." Grows in the river valleys of Hedong. Harvest in the eighth month and dry in the shade. *Ma dao* (horse knife clam) serves as its assistant; it fears croton seed, *danshen* (red sage), and *kongqing* (azurite), and is averse to *fuqing* (verdigris).

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Blister beetles grow in the river valleys of Hedong, but are now found everywhere. During the seventh and eighth months, when soybeans flourish, these insects are often found on the leaves. They measure five to six *fen* in length, with yellow-black striped patterns on their wing-cases, black abdomens, and pointed beaks, roughly the size of a croton seed. Collect them from the leaves and dry in the shade. Ancient medical texts frequently employ this substance, though its name may also be written as *banli* or *banhao*. It must not be used raw, as this induces vomiting and diarrhea.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* states: Blister beetle, an assistant drug, is also called "Dragon Sprout" and is highly toxic. It treats scrofula and promotes the free flow of water pathways.

Tao Hongjing says: Collect them when soybean flowers bloom; those with yellow-black striped bodies the size of a croton seed are the correct variety.

*Ri Huazi* states: It is averse to soybean flowers. It treats strangury, applied topically for malignant sores and fistula with putrefaction. For medicinal use, remove the wings and legs, then stir-fry until thoroughly cooked. Raw, it induces vomiting and diarrhea.

Ma Zhi says: According to *The Illustrated Classic of the Shu Region*, in the seventh and eighth months, these winged insects with yellow-striped patterns and black abdomens, measuring five to six *fen* in length, are found on soybean leaves and are now present everywhere.

Wu Pu says: Blister beetle is also called *banhao*, *longhao*, *banjun*, *kuifa*, *panqiong*, and *yanqing*. Shen Nong: acrid. Qi Bo: salty.

Tong Jun: toxic. Bian Que: sweet, highly toxic. Found in the river valleys of Henei or among water and rocks.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For chronic dry ringworm with long-standing scabs that exude yellow fluid when scratched, itching especially before rain, use half a *liang* of blister beetle, lightly stir-fried and ground into powder, then mixed with honey for topical application.

*Proven Formulas*: Major remedy for resolving scrofula in adults and children: Take one *liang* of blister beetle, remove wings and legs, and stir-fry with one *sheng* of millet until the millet turns scorched yellow. Discard the millet, grind the beetle finely, and blend with four *liang* of dried mint powder. Form into pills the size of mung beans using egg white. On an empty stomach, take one pill with wax-tea, increasing to five pills daily, then reduce by one pill each day until returning to one pill. Thereafter, take five pills daily.

*Extended Meanings* states: Blister beetle must be stir-fried with glutinous rice until the rice turns yellow. Pregnant women must not consume it, as it can ulcerate flesh. When used in strangury remedies, it is extremely bitter, and dosage should be carefully considered. The following entry, *yuanqing* (green blister beetle), has similar applications and is thus appended here.

Clam is cold in nature and non-toxic. It moistens the five viscera, relieves wasting-thirst, stimulates the appetite, resolves alcohol toxicity, and treats chronic accumulations that cause alternating chills and fever, as well as blood masses in women. Consume it boiled. Though this creature is cold in nature, it counteracts cinnabar and mineral drugs; those who take such substances and then eat clam will suffer abdominal binding pain.

Chu Yushi states: It is wondrously effective for scalds and burns. Burn clam shells to ash, grind to powder, mix with oil, and apply.

*Xiàn* (river snail), pronounced *xiǎn*, is cold and non-toxic. It treats seasonal qi disorders, stimulates the appetite, counteracts mineral drugs and clove sores, drains damp qi, and promotes lactation. Steeped in fermented grain mash and consumed, it is excellent. Soak live snails to extract their juice for washing clove sores. Overconsumption induces cough and cold qi, and depletes kidney essence.

Aged shells treat yin sores and stop dysentery. Snail meat is cold; it dispels sudden heat, brightens the eyes, disinhibits urination, drains heat qi, treats beriberi, damp toxicity, and alcohol toxicity, and resolves yellowing of the eyes. Soak to extract juice and ingest for wasting-thirst. Burned, weathered shells, taken as white ash in a decoction, treat regurgitation and vomiting of food, and eliminate phlegm-water in the chest. Long-stored shells treat stomach reflux and seminal loss.

Chen Cangqi states: Smaller than clams, black in color, they live in river mud and, when wind and rain arise, can use their shells as wings to fly.

Burn □□ shells to ash and ingest the powder to treat hemorrhoids. Chen Cangqi states: □□, also called *shēngjìn*, has hair-like growths resembling clams, is long and flat, and when its shell is burned to ash and ingested, it treats *yějī* disease. Eating its flesh, however, has no therapeutic effect.

*Chēzhé*...

Cold in nature, non-toxic. Treats alcohol toxicity, wasting-thirst, thirst from alcohol, and welling-abscesses with swelling. Its shell treats sores, boils, and toxic swellings. For these two conditions, each time, calcine the shell twice with vinegar, then pound into powder. Alternatively, mix equal parts with licorice, take with wine, or apply the powder mixed with vinegar to the swelling—highly effective.

*Chēzhé* is a large clam, also called *shèn*. It can exhale qi to form towering pavilions; in spring and summer, along the shores of islands in the sea, this qi often appears. The *Shiliao* states: *Chēzhé* belongs to the same category as *qiūyóu*, and neither should be consumed in excess.

**Ark shell (蚶, *hān*)**
Warm in nature. Dispels cold qi in the heart and abdomen, cold wind in the lower back and spine, harmonizes the five viscera, fortifies the stomach, and stimulates appetite. After eating, take with rice to prevent dry mouth. It is also said: warms the center, aids digestion, invigorates yang, and has a very rich flavor; it comes from the sea. Its shell resembles a tiled roof. It is further said: non-toxic, and enriches the complexion.

Its shell, after being calcined three times with rice vinegar, buried until decomposed, and then mixed with vinegar paste to form pills, treats all blood and qi disorders, cold qi, and concretions and conglomerations.

**Razor clam (蛏, *chēng*)**
Sweet in flavor, warm in nature, non-toxic. Supplements deficiency and treats cold diarrhea. When boiled and eaten, it addresses postpartum depletion in women. It grows in sea mud, two to three *cun* in length, as thick as a finger, and opens at both ends. Dispels perverse heat and vexing oppression in the chest. Suitable for those who take mineral elixirs. Must not be eaten after epidemic diseases—strictly avoid.

**Mussel (淡菜, *dàncài*)**
Warm in nature.

Nourishes the five viscera, regulates qi in the lower back and legs, enhances virility, aids digestion, dispels cold qi in the abdomen, and resolves concretions and conglomerations. It may also be roasted until its juices boil forth for consumption. Overconsumption causes vexing oppression and dims the eyes; a mild purgation will remedy this. Northerners often do not recognize it, and though its form is unremarkable, it greatly benefits the body.

It is further said: warm in nature, non-toxic. It supplements deficiency from taxation fatigue, resolves postpartum blood stasis, and treats cold pain in the abdomen, concretions and conglomerations, lumbar pain, moistens the hair, and addresses flooding and vaginal discharge. Roasting a full meal’s portion until satiation yields great efficacy.

Also called *shell vegetable*; frequent consumption in its usual roasted form is bitter and unsuitable for people. First boil it with a small amount of rice, then remove the two locking edges and hairs from the meat, and simmer again with radish, perilla, or winter melon rind—this method is even better.

Chen Cangqi states: *Donghai Furen* (Eastern Sea Lady), sweet in flavor, warm in nature, non-toxic. It governs emaciation from taxation fatigue, postpartum wasting, blood and qi accumulations, abdominal cold, intestinal rumbling, diarrhea, lumbar pain, vaginal discharge, and mounting concretions. Prolonged consumption causes hair loss.

Extracting the meat to make stew is beneficial for people, but it may cause intestinal blockages if heated with stones. It grows in the South Sea, resembling a pearl oyster, with one end pointed and a few hairs held within—coastal dwellers also call it *dan cai* (bland mussel).

A recent annotation states: This is called *shell vegetable*; it is very sweet and delicious, favored by southerners. It treats taxation fatigue with exhaustion, deficiency of essence and blood, hematemesis, women’s vaginal discharge and flooding, and chronic dysentery in men. Boil and consume it freely.

It comes from rivers and lakes. Shrimp without antennae or those that remain white after boiling should not be eaten.

Caution: Small ones found in paddy fields and ditches are slightly toxic. For children suffering from red and white wandering swellings, crush and apply them as a poultice. Those preserved in *zha* (fermented fish) are highly toxic.

Chen Cangqi states: Eating them causes the five pheasant diseases. For children with red and white wandering rashes, crush and apply them as a poultice. When boiled, their color turns a proper red; if eaten by children, chickens, or dogs, their legs will curl and they will be unable to walk. Those from rivers and lakes are slightly larger, and their color turns white when boiled.

Tao [Hongjing] says white ones kill people—this is incorrect. Large ones are found in the sea. (Already covered in the *Shiyi* section.)

If hot rice is packed tightly in a vessel to make *zha* and eaten, it can poison a person to death.

The *Shiliao* states: Neutral in nature. It agitates wind and triggers sores and scabies.

**Viper’s Gallbladder**
Flavor bitter, slightly cold, toxic. It governs □ sores. Its flesh, brewed into wine, treats epilepsy, various fistulas, heart and abdominal pain, bound qi below, and expels *gu* toxins. The mouse it swallows in its belly is slightly toxic and treats mouse fistulas.

Tao Yinju states: The viper is yellow-black in color, with a yellow chin and pointed mouth; its venom is extremely potent. The *hui* is short and flat in shape, its venom no different from the *yuan*; if one is bitten and not treated immediately, death often follows. There are many kinds of snakes, but only these two species and the green *kui* are fierce—their treatments are all covered in separate formulas. All snakes have feet; on the fifth day of the fifth month, heat the ground, pour wine over it, and place the snake in the center—its feet will emerge. Alchemists use the red *lian* and yellow-chinned snakes, often found in household eaves, which swallow mouse pups and fledglings. When their bellies are distended, they are captured, split open, and dried.

The *Tang Ben* annotation states: Snake excrement treats hemorrhoids and fistulas. Keep it in a vessel to collect it. Its skin ash treats clove sores, malignant ulcers, and bone *ju*. Its shed skin governs body itching, illnesses, scabies, and ringworm.

The viper is earth-colored, with an upturned nose, a forked mouth, a short body, and a head and tail that resemble each other. It is highly venomous, also called *yuan* snake—there are no two kinds. It is abundant in the mountains south of the Han and Mian rivers.

Lu Xi states: According to the *Shu Ben Tujing*, its form is thick and short, yellow-black like earth, with white spots and an upturned nose. It is found in Jianzhou, Fangzhou, and Junzhou in the mountains south of the Han River.

*Tu Jing Yan Yi Ben Cao*, Volume Thirty-Three — End
*Tu Jing Yan Yi Ben Cao*, Volume Thirty-Four
Compiled by Song Dynasty *Tongzhilang* and Pharmacognosist Kou Zongshi

The Imperial Medical Assistant of the Song Dynasty, Licentiate for Authentication of Materia Medica Xu Hong, collated and corrected

**Section on Worms and Fishes — Inferior Grade**

**Juice of Field Snails**
Nature: Greatly cold.
Governs: Redness, heat, and pain in the eyes; stops thirst.

The *Yaoxing Lun* states: The juice of field snails may also be used alone. It governs liver heat, redness, swelling, and pain in the eyes. Take seven large ones, wash them clean, and soak in freshly drawn water to remove filth and mud. Replace with one *sheng* of water and rinse again. Then, place them one by one in a clean vessel, sprinkle a pinch of fine salt on their mouths, and collect the juice they exude. Use this to apply to the eyes. After each snail has been used thus, release it.

Tao Yinju states: They grow in paddy fields and along the banks of lakes and streams. Those round and as large as pears or oranges are also boiled and eaten by people. Their boiled juice also treats heat, sobers intoxication, and stops thirst. For eye pain, place a pearl and *huanglian* inside the snail; after some time, juice will emerge. Apply this to the eyes, and the condition will often improve.

The *Tang Ben* annotation states: The *Bielu* records: The shell treats corpse *zheng*, pain in the heart and abdomen, and also governs loss of essence. Soaking the snail in water and drinking its juice stops thirst.

Now, according to Chen Cangqi’s *Bencao*: Field snails, when boiled and eaten, disinhibit urination and defecation, dispel bound heat in the abdomen, and resolve yellowing beneath the eyes. For beriberi surging upward, hardness and urgency in the lower abdomen, red and rough urination, and swelling of the hands and feet, soak the snails alive to extract their juice and drink it to stop wasting-thirst. Crush their flesh and apply it to heat sores. Burn the decayed shells to ash, grind into powder, and take to treat counterflow stomach.

Chen Cangqi states: Those found in paddy fields, round and large, are the ones. Small, mud-dwelling snails with ridges are called *chiluo*; they also stop thirst but cannot descend water. When eating them, first soak in rice-washing water to remove mud. These creatures are extremely hard to kill—if mud is mistakenly left in a wall, they may remain alive for thirty years, able to conceal their *qi* and drink dew. Only when they emerge by boring through and dispersing do they die. Burn the decayed shells to ash, grind into powder, and take to treat counterflow stomach, stomach cold, and sudden heart pain.

Rihuazi states: Field snails are cold and non-toxic. They treat swelling of the hands and feet and heat sores; crush them fresh to extract juice and apply topically.

Yuxi notes: According to the *Shu Ben Tujing*, they grow in paddy fields, as large as peaches or plums, resembling garden snails but pointed and elongated, greenish-yellow in color. They are gathered in summer. The *Shiliao* states: They are greatly cold. Their juice treats heat, sobers intoxication, and suppresses *danshi*.

Do not consume them regularly.

*Shenghui Fang* states: To treat chronic alcohol-induced throat erosion and tongue sores, boil snails and clams from water, scallions, fermented soybeans, Sichuan pepper, and ginger, then drink two or three cups of the broth to cure.

*Shiyi Xinjing Fang* states: For wasting-thirst with unceasing day-and-night water intake, dry mouth, and frequent urination, soak five *sheng* of field snails in one *dou* of water overnight; drink when thirsty. Replace the water and snails daily for best effect. Another method: Boil three *sheng* of water, extract the broth, and drink when cool; the snails may also be eaten.

**Cowrie Shell (贝子)**
Flavor: Salty. Nature: Neutral. Slightly toxic.
Governs: Eye nebula, *gu* possession, *gu* toxins, abdominal pain with bloody stool, the five types of strangury, promotes water pathways, dispels alternating chills and fever with *wen zhu*, resolves muscle, and disperses bound heat. Best used when calcined.
Also called "cowrie tooth." Grows in the marshes of the Eastern Sea.

*Tujing* states: Cowrie shells grow in the marshes of the Eastern Sea; they are also found in the Southern Sea. They are the smallest of the cowrie species, resembling snails in shape. *Jiaozhou Ji* states: Large cowries come from Rinan, as big as wine cups; small cowries are called "cowrie teeth." Both are effective against toxins and are purple in color. Those pure white as fish teeth are also called "cowrie teeth." In ancient times, they were used to adorn military attire and objects; today, they are rarely used except for threading as children’s toys, decorating mirrors and belts, or by painters for burnishing. Harvested year-round.

*Ke* (珂) resembles cowries but is larger, yellow-black in color with white "bones," and can be used to adorn horses.

*Yaoxing Lun* states: Cowrie shells are an envoy. They break the five types of strangury, promote urination, and treat heat mania in cold damage.

Tao Yinju states: These are the small cowrie shells used today to adorn military attire and objects, sourced from the Southern Sea. Burned to fine ash and blown into the eyes, they treat nebula and corneal opacity. Ground true *ma ke* also treats blindness and nebula.

*Rihuazi* states: Cowrie teeth are excellent for treating nebula, *gu* toxins, *gu* qi, and bloody stool. Also called "white cowrie."

Yuxi notes: According to the *Shu Ben Tujing*, they belong to the snail family, shaped like fish teeth, with the purest being best.

*Haiyao* states: Abundant in Yunnan, used as currency. Governs water qi edema and childhood *gan* erosion with vomiting of milk. Used calcined in medicinal formulas.

*Shenghui Fang*: For arrow poison in meats or spoiled dried meat, take half a *qian* of cowrie shell powder mixed with water; effective. Also used similarly for noodle soup poisoning.

*Sun Zhenren Fang*: For food poisoning, hold one cowrie shell in the mouth to induce vomiting.

*Qianjin Fang*: To treat black-speckled eye nebula with roughness and pain in children, burn one *liang* of cowrie teeth to ash, grind to a fine powder, add a small amount of borneol, and apply. Another formula: For removing eye nebula, burn ten cowrie shells to ash, sift finely, and place a dose the size of a *hu* bean on the nebula; lie down for the time it takes to cook one *shi* of rice, and it will dissipate. For fleshy growths, add equal parts true pearl to the cowrie shells.

*Yanyi* states: Cowrie shells, now called "cowrie teeth," resemble purple cowries but are over an inch long, hence the name. Their color is pale white, with some deep purple-black. They treat eye nebula when calcined. Northerners use them to adorn felt hats, sew onto clothing, or as pendants on belts.

**Stone Silkworm (石蚕)**
Flavor: Salty. Nature: Cold. Toxic.
Governs: The five types of strangury, breaks stone strangury, and induces abortion. Its flesh resolves bound qi, promotes water pathways, and clears heat.
Also called "sand louse." Grows in the marshes of the Jiang and Han rivers.

*Tujing* states: Stone silkworms grow in the marshes of the Jiang and Han rivers. Some old annotations describe them as grass roots growing on stones, resembling silkworms. Others consider them living organisms, akin to oysters and clams in the sea. The *Bencao* also calls them "sand lice," but sand lice are tiny waterborne creatures, and there is no consensus. The *Shu Bencao* annotation states: These creatures are found among water and stones everywhere; people use them as fishing bait. The Mahu region produces the most, and locals enjoy eating them, describing their flavor as salty with a slight pungency. Today, they are abundant in Sichuan and Guangxi.

Grass roots resembling silkworms are also called "stone silkworms," found on mountains and stones in Fuzhou and Xinzhou year-round. Their stems are green with nodes; the roots are harvested in the third month and dried by baking. They govern wandering *zhu* wind, disperse blood, and relieve pain. The nodes can also be used alone: grind, sift, and take the powder with warm wine.

The *Tang Ben* annotation states: Stone silkworms resemble silkworms, small with segmented horns, and are green-black in color. They grow in stone crevices along the Jiang and Han rivers, also found on slopes and ridges. Northerners rarely use them, so they are scarcely collected. Today, they are gathered in Longzhou.

*Yanyi* states: Calling them "grass" is incorrect. The *Bencao* says their flesh resolves bound qi, yet the annotations remain uncertain about their habitat. Some attach to stones in water, spinning silk cocoons like hairpins, over an inch long, to shield their bodies. Their color resembles mud, hence the name "stone silkworm." Today, physicians rarely use them; they are merely waterborne creatures, abundant in rivers and mountains.

**Sparrow’s Nest (雀瓮)**
Flavor: Sweet. Nature: Neutral. Non-toxic.
Governs: Childhood fright epilepsy, alternating chills and fever, bound qi, *gu* toxins, and *gu* possession.
Also called "restless abode." Found in Hanzhong; gather and steam. They grow on tree branches, resembling *zhan* (蛅) and *si* (蟖) nests. Harvest in the eighth month.

*Tujing* states: Sparrow’s nests are the nests of *zhan* and *si* (蛅蟖).

Found on tree branches in Hanzhong, now present everywhere. *Zhan* and *si* are *hao* insects, also called *ci*. They are hairy worms, favoring pomegranate trees, resembling silkworms but shorter, with five-colored markings on their backs. Their spines sting, carrying venom. When nearing maturity, they secrete a white fluid from their mouths, which hardens like sparrow eggs—hence the name. Also called "sparrow abscess," as *yong* (abscess) and *weng* (urn) sound alike. Their young form pupae within the urn, much like silkworms in cocoons. Over time, they emerge as moths, laying eggs on branches and leaves, which hatch into flat worms. Old annotations mistakenly identify the urn as insect eggs.

Tao Yinju states: *Zhan* and *si* are *hao* insects. These worms often dwell on pomegranate trees, commonly called *hao* worms, their back hairs also stinging. Their eggs resemble sparrow eggs, as large as croton seeds. Today, physicians rarely use them.

*Hao* is also written as *ci* (七吏切). Yu Xi notes: According to the *Shu Ben* annotations, sparrows favor eating them, hence the folk name "sparrow’s rice urn." *Rihuazi* says: *Ci* are hairy worm nests, toxic. *Yanyi* states: Sparrow’s urns are often found on thorn branches, also called *ji gang zi*. Grinding the worms within for their juice and administering it to children treats fright epilepsy.

**White-Patterned Snake**
Flavor: Sweet, salty. Nature: Warm. Toxic.
Governs: Wind stroke, damp impediment with numbness, sinew and vessel spasms, facial deviation, hemiplegia, joint pain, severe wind with scabies and *lai* sores, sudden wind itching, and weak legs unable to stand long.
Also called "hooked-nose snake"; those with patterns are superior. Found in southern regions and the mountains of Shu commanderies. Harvest in the ninth and tenth months, then dry by fire.

*Tujing* states: White-patterned snakes inhabit southern regions and the mountains of Shu commanderies. Today, they are also found in Qianzhong, Qizhou, and Dengzhou. Their scales form square white patterns like interlocking coins. They favor stinging human feet; in Qian, those stung sever the limb immediately. After recovery, some fashion wooden feet to replace it, allowing continued mobility. Harvest in the ninth and tenth months, then dry by fire. Their efficacy in treating wind surpasses other snakes. However, they are highly toxic—especially the first and last foot of the body, which must not be used. Only the middle section is employed. When dried, soak in wine, remove skin and bones, then roast and store to prevent moth damage.

Leigong says: It is said to treat wind, but how? Because the snake’s nature is to dart, it guides medicinal substances to areas afflicted by wind, thus earning its designation as an envoy. For all snakes, one must discern male from female and their region of origin. The Wushe snake from Qizhou, weighing only three *fen* to one *liang*, is exceptional. The head and tail must be intact, the eyes unclosed as if alive, with a row of reverse-scales two *cun* long, half a *fen* in length, aligned head to tail—such snakes are divinely potent. If such specimens are later obtained, many are reserved for tribute. Those weighing two *liang* and three *fen* are unmatched elsewhere.

Yu Xi notes: According to the *Yaoxing Lun*, white-patterned snake is a sovereign remedy. It governs lung wind with nasal congestion, white *xian* wind on the body, scrofula, macules, and floating wind with rashes. *Taiping Guangji* records: Zhao Yanxi says: For areas stung by venomous snakes, apply snake skin and cauterize it to draw out the toxin, stopping the pain. *Yanyi* states: Among snakes, all have downward-facing nostrils, but this snake’s nostrils point upward. Its back bears square-patterned markings, hence its name. When using it, remove the head and tail, soak in wine for three days, discard the wine, then roast thoroughly and remove all skin and bones. This creature is extremely toxic—one cannot be too cautious.

**Black Snake**
Non-toxic.
Governs: All wind itching with rashes, scabies, ringworm, skin numbness, stubborn impediment, and various winds. Use roasted, in pills or powders, steeped in wine, or prepared as ointments. Its back has three ridges, black as lacquer. Its nature is docile, and it does not bite. In Jiangdong, there is a black-tipped snake that can coil around objects until they die—it is of the same kind. Found in Mount Shangluo.

*Tujing* states: Black snakes inhabit the left side of Mount Shangluo, as well as the mountains of Qizhou and Huangzhou. Their backs have three ridges, black as lacquer. Their nature is exceedingly docile, and they do not bite.

Often found in reed thickets, where its floral scent may be detected, or carried on the southern wind. Most difficult to gather and replenish—often found on reed branches. Even when completely withered, its eyes do not sink; those weighing between three *fen* and one *liang* are of the highest grade. Larger and coarser specimens are heavier but their potency is diminished. Some have reverse scales on the head, arranged in rows of two *cun*, each half a *fen* in length, with head and tail aligned—these are divinely efficacious and exceedingly rare. Counterfeits are made by fumigating other snakes until black, which may deceive the eye, though their eyes lack luster.

Yu Xi states: According to the *Yaoxing Lun*, Black Snake is a sovereign herb, sweet in flavor, neutral in nature, and slightly toxic. It governs heat-toxin wind, skin sores, loss of eyebrows and beard, ringworm, itching, and scabies.

The *Chaoye Qianzai* records: In Shangzhou, a man afflicted with *da feng* (severe leprosy) was shunned by his family and made to live in a thatched hut in the mountains. A black snake fell into his wine jar, and the man, unaware, drank the wine and gradually recovered. Later, snake bones were found at the bottom of the jar, revealing the cause.

The *Shenghui Fang* prescribes a remedy for facial sores and disfigurement: Burn two *liang* of Black Snake to ash, mix with lard from a twelfth-month pig, and apply.

The *Qianjin Fang* treats deafness: Wrap snake fat in silk and insert into the ear—divinely effective.

The *Yanyi* states: Black Snakes with slender, elongated tails that can thread through one hundred copper coins are superior. Some exceed a *zhang* in length, and among snakes, this species is most frequently used in medicine. Once, at the Tangle embankment in Shun’an Commandery, a black snake over a *zhang* long was seen being dragged away by a weasel that had bitten its head—such is the natural order of predation. Merchants often counterfeit them by fumigating other snakes to a black hue; one must be vigilant. The high ridge on its back has earned it the name "Sword-Ridge Black-Tipped Snake."

---

**Dung Beetle**
Salty in flavor, cold in nature, toxic.
Governs: Infantile fright epilepsy, convulsions, abdominal distension, alternating chills and fever, adult epilepsy and mania, cold extremities, limb swelling, and *bentun* (running piglet qi). Also called *jiezhi qiang*. Best prepared by dry-frying.

Found in the ponds and marshes of Changsha. Harvest on the fifth day of the fifth month, steam, and store. Before use, roast; do not place in water, as it induces vomiting. Aversion to goat horn and gypsum.

The *Tujing* states: Dung beetles inhabit the ponds and marshes of Changsha, though they are now found everywhere. Many varieties exist; the largest are selected. Those with high noses and deep-set eyes are called *Hu Qianglang* and are the finest. Harvest on the fifth day of the fifth month, steam, and store. Before use, roast; do not place in water, as it induces vomiting. Frequently used in remedies for infantile *gan* worms.

The heart of the dung beetle governs *ding* sores, though this is not recorded in the *Shen Nong Bencao Jing*. Liu Yuxi’s *Liuzhou Jiu San Si Fang* recounts: In the eleventh year of the Yuanhe reign, I contracted *ding* sores. For fourteen days, the condition worsened daily, and though I applied fine medicines, none proved effective. Jia Fangbo of Changle taught me to use the heart of a dung beetle, and by the next evening, all suffering ceased. The following year, in the first month, I ate mutton and the sores flared again, but the remedy worked just as divinely.

The *Yaoxing Lun* states: Dung beetle is an envoy herb, governing infantile *gan* worms that gnaw the intestines.

Tao Hongjing notes: *Zhuangzi* says, "The wisdom of the *jieqiang* lies in rolling balls." They delight in entering human excrement, forming dung balls and rolling them backward—hence their common name, "ball-rollers." The largest should be selected; there are three or four varieties, with those having flat noses being genuine.

The Tang *Bencao* annotation cites the *Mingyi Bielu*: Pound into pills and insert into the anus to draw out hemorrhoid worms completely, ensuring permanent relief.

The *Rihuazi* states: It can induce abortion, treat *zhuyu* (possession), and when mixed with dried ginger, apply to malignant sores. It extracts arrowheads, and its dung blocks hemorrhoid fistulas to expel worms. For medicinal use, remove the legs and stir-fry.

Ge Hong’s *Zhouhou Fang*: For arrowheads lodged in bone that cannot be extracted, lightly roast *badou* (croton) with dung beetle, grind evenly, and apply to the wound. Soon, the pain will cease, and a slight itch will follow—endure it. When the itching becomes unbearable, shake the arrowhead, and it will come out immediately.

The *Shenghui Fang*: Treats all malignant sores, *shashi* (sand lice), *gongnu* (crossbow wounds), and malignant ulcers. Grind ten dung beetles, preferably dried on the fifth day of the fifth month, into powder, mix with oil, and apply.

The *Waitai Miyao Fang*: For scrofula and wind sores, pound dead dung beetles from the nest into a paste, rub until warm, and apply. The condition will resolve by the next day.

The *Zimu Milu Fang*: For malignant sores and abscesses on the anus of infants, extract juice from dung beetles and apply.

Another remedy: For infantile double tongue, burn dung beetle to ash, mix with saliva, and apply to the tongue.

The *Liu Juanzi Fang*: For rat fistula, burn dead dung beetles to ash, mix with bitter wine, and apply several times to heal. First, wash with salt water.

The *Yanyi* states: There are two types of dung beetles: a large variety called *Hu Qianglang*, with a glossy black body and small yellow markings beneath its wing covers. The young cling to the mother while flying; they do not emerge during the day but fly at night, drawn to lamplight in homes. The smaller variety has a dull black body and emerges during the day, not at night. The *Hu Qianglang* should be used: grind thirty small ones, mix with water, and administer to cattle and horses to treat bloating and blockages—exceedingly effective. Foxes encounter them and devour them completely.

---

**Five Spirits Fat**
Sweet in flavor, warm in nature, non-toxic.

**Five Spirits Fat** governs cold qi in the heart and abdomen, treats the five *gan* disorders in children, wards off epidemics, heals intestinal wind, unblocks and regulates the qi channels, and addresses menstrual block in women. It comes from the northern regions and is the excrement of the *hanhao* bird.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: Five Spirits Fat is produced in the northern lands, though today it is found only in the prefectures of Hedong. It is said to be the excrement of the *hanhao* bird, black as iron in color, and may be gathered at any time. However, it is often mixed with sand and stones, making it exceedingly difficult to refine. If used, it should first be ground with wine and refined through levigation to remove the sand and stones—only then is it of good quality. It is frequently employed in remedies for cold-induced accumulations, as well as in formulas for children and women. Modern physicians use it to treat postpartum blood dizziness, where the woman is unconscious, her qi surging upward causing suffocating distress, and she is unaware of her surroundings. Take two *liang* of Five Spirits Fat, half stir-fried and half raw, grind into a fine powder, and administer one *qian* per dose, mixed with warm boiled water. If the patient’s jaw is clenched, pry the mouth open to administer the medicine—recovery follows immediately upon swallowing. This is called the *Du Sheng San*. It also treats unstoppable uterine bleeding: take ten *liang* of Five Spirits Fat, grind into a fine powder, add five large cups of water, decoct down to three cups, strain, clarify, and decoct again into a paste. Mix in two *liang* of *shenqu* powder, form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds, and take twenty pills per dose with warm wine on an empty stomach—this will halt the bleeding. It is widely used in various formulas.

Su Song states: "Now, considering its designation as an insect with four legs and fleshy wings that cannot fly far, it is thus not classified among birds."

*Tested Prescriptions*:
For treating men and women suffering from unceasing vomiting and retching, where congee, food, or medicinal decoctions cannot be retained, this method proves effective. Take Five Spirits Fat, free of earth or stone, selecting only the finest quality, grind into a fine powder without regard to quantity, and blend with dog gallbladder juice to form pills the size of *qitou* seeds. For each dose, take one pill, grind it finely with heated fresh ginger and wine, then dissolve it in a small amount of ginger-infused wine. Prepare the decoction to be extremely hot, and first prepare congee to a warm, suitable temperature. With the left hand, administer the medicine to the patient without allowing them to rinse their mouth, then swiftly use the right hand to feed them the congee, ensuring it is not given in excess.

*Proven Prescriptions*:
For treating women’s heart pain and unbearable blood-stabbing sensations, the *Shi Xiao San* (Sudden Smile Powder) is used: take equal parts of purified Five Spirits Fat and cattail pollen, grind into powder. For each dose, take two *qian*, simmer with one ladle of good vinegar into a paste, then add one cup of water and decoct to seven parts, administering hot for immediate effect.

Another formula treats unceasing menstrual bleeding: grind Five Spirits Fat into powder, stir-fry until thoroughly cooked and all smoke dissipates. For each dose, take two large *qian*, decoct with two slices of *danggui* and one medium cup of wine to six parts, strain, and administer hot. Three to five doses will prove effective.

*Extended Meanings* states: "Five Spirits Fat is effective in moving menstrual blood but cannot generate blood. There was a person suffering from wandering nebulae in the eyes, which is a disorder of the blood. The heart generates blood, and the liver stores it; when the liver receives blood, one can see. Treating eye disorders without addressing the blood is contrary to principle. This substance enters the liver most swiftly."

One method: take two *liang* of Five Spirits Fat, one *liang* of *moyao*, half a *liang* of *ruxiang*, and one and a half *liang* of *chuanwu* (roasted, skin removed), grind together into powder, and form into pills the size of a bullet using water. For each dose, take one pill, grind with fresh ginger and warm wine, and administer to treat wind-cold blockage of qi and blood, pain in the hands, feet, and body, and cold numbness.

There was also a person bitten by a venomous snake who soon fell into stupor. An elderly monk administered two *qian* of medicine mixed with wine, reviving them. He then applied the dregs to the bite, and after some time, administered another two *qian*, completely dispelling the poison. Upon inquiry, the formula consisted of one *liang* of Five Spirits Fat and half a *liang* of realgar, ground together into powder. Later, those afflicted by poison used this remedy without fail.

Though this medicine is not particularly expensive, counterfeits are common.

**Scorpion**
Flavor: sweet, acrid; toxic.
It treats various wind-induced rashes, wind-stroke, hemiplegia, deviation of the mouth and eyes, slurred speech, and convulsions of the hands and feet. Those that are compact and small are of superior quality. Those from Qingzhou are best.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: According to earlier records, the origin of scorpions was not specified, though the annotation notes that those from Qingzhou are superior. Today, they are found throughout the eastern and western regions of the capital, as well as in Hebei and Shaanxi prefectures. They may be gathered at any time, but only the compact and small ones are desirable. Nowadays, when people capture them, they are killed by scorching over fire and then preserved. Medical texts refer to them as *yixi*. Tao Hongjing’s *Collected Effective Remedies* notes: Scorpions have male and female forms. The male’s sting causes pain localized to one spot, while the female’s pain radiates. If stung by a male, apply well mud and replace it when it warms. For a female’s sting, use mud from the base of tiled roof gutters. Scorpions are frequently used in formulas to treat wind-stroke convulsions of the hands and feet, as well as childhood fright seizures. The *Qie Zhong Fang* treats infantile wind-epilepsy by taking five scorpions, placing them inside a large pomegranate (its top cut off and seeds removed to form a vessel), sealing it with paper and yellow mud, then roasting it over a low fire until dry before gradually increasing the heat to thoroughly char it. Once cooled, the mud is removed, and the blackened contents inside are finely ground. Half a *qian* is mixed with breast milk and administered, immediately calming the child. For older children, it is taken with *fangfeng* decoction. Yuxi notes: According to the *Shu Ben*, compact and small scorpions are called *yixi*. Duan Chengshi’s *Miscellaneous Morsels from Youyang* records: The largest *shufu* insects often transform into scorpions. Scorpions frequently carry their young on their backs—I once saw one bearing over ten offspring, their bodies still white and no larger than rice grains. In an ancient granary in Chenzhou, there are scorpions as large as coins, whose stings are invariably fatal. Jiangnan originally had no scorpions; during the Kaiyuan era, a magistrate’s clerk transported some across the river in a bamboo tube, and they have since spread throughout Jiangnan, where they are colloquially called "magistrate’s clerk insects." Scorpions are often preyed upon by snails, which first track their trails and never leave. The front of a scorpion is called the *zhe* (stinger), and the rear is called the *chai* (tail barb).

The *Experiential Remedies* treats infantile fright-wind by taking one intact scorpion (head and tail unbroken), wrapping it in four *bohe* leaves, roasting it over fire until the leaves char, then grinding them together into powder. This is divided into four doses, taken with warm water. For adults with wind-phlegm, a single dose suffices. Du Ren’s formula for deafness caused by kidney deficiency (curable within ten years with one dose) uses forty-nine of the smallest scorpions and forty-nine slices of fresh ginger (each the size of a scorpion). The two are stir-fried in a copper vessel until the ginger is completely dry, then ground into powder. Taken as a single dose at dusk with warm wine, the patient should drink to intoxication by the third watch—no harm will come. The effect manifests the next day.

*The Extension of Materia Medica* states: Scorpions are used for both adults and children, indispensable for treating infantile fright-wind. Some formulas use the whole scorpion, while others use only the tail, which is particularly potent. Today, those captured under stones in the mountains of Qingzhou are slowly scorched over fire or exposed to the blazing sun. When the scorpions grow thirsty and hot, they are fed green mud until their bellies are full, then killed by fire, which gives them a reddish hue—this is done to increase their weight for sale. Physicians always remove the soil before use.

**Mole Cricket**
Flavor: salty; cold; non-toxic.
It facilitates difficult childbirth, extracts embedded thorns, drains abscesses, relieves esophageal obstructions, resolves toxins, and treats malignant sores. Also called *huigu*, *tianlou*, or *gu*. Found in eastern plains and marshes; those that emerge at night are superior. Harvested at the Summer Solstice and dried in the sun.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Mole crickets inhabit eastern plains and marshes, but are now found everywhere. They burrow in manure-rich soil and emerge at night to forage. When encountered during nighttime travel, people often kill them, believing they are sent by ghosts. They are gathered after the Summer Solstice and dried in the sun, with those emerging at night being the best. The front half of their body is rough and astringent, used to restrain urination and defecation (some say it restrains only urination). The rear half is smooth and promotes urination and defecation. For extracting embedded thorns, the head is most commonly used—this part is also called *gu*. The *Erya* states: *Gu* is *tianlou*. The *Xia Xiao Zheng* records: "In the third month, *gu* begins to call." The *Guang Ya* calls it *shuoshu*, and the *Book of Changes* says: "Advancing like a *shuoshu*." Kong Yingda’s *Justice* explains: It is a creature with five abilities yet masters none. Citing Cai Yong’s *Exhortation to Study*: "The *shuoshu* has five skills but fails to perfect a single craft." The annotation clarifies: It can fly but not over a house; climb but not to the top of a tree; swim but not across a valley; burrow but not to conceal itself; run but not to escape humans. Xunzi’s phrase "the *wushu* has five skills yet is trapped" refers to this same mole cricket. Today, physicians treat stone strangury and promote diuresis by taking one mole cricket and two *liang* of salt, spreading them on a new tile, baking until dry, then grinding into powder. One *qian* is taken with warm wine, and the condition resolves.

Tao Hongjing notes: When the mole cricket emerges on its own, its front half is astringent and restrains urination and defecation, while the rear half is smooth and promotes them. For extracting thorns, the head is most commonly used. This creature is somewhat connected to spirits and ghosts—ancient prisoners once relied on its *huigu* power. Today, when people encounter it at night, they often kill it, believing it is sent by ghosts.

Yuxi notes: According to the *Shu Ben* annotation: The *Erya* states *gu* is *tianlou*. *The Illustrated Classic* records: Harvested at the Summer Solstice, now found everywhere. *Ri Hua Zi* states: Cold; toxic.

For treating malignant sores and edema, as well as swelling of the head and face, it is stir-fried for medicinal use.

Lei Gong states: Its flavor is salty; it is non-toxic.

*The Sagely Benefit Formulas*: For ten types of water diseases with swelling, fullness, panting, and inability to lie down: Grind five mole crickets into powder. Take half a *qian* to one *qian* mixed with hot water before meals; when urination flows freely, the effect is achieved.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For treating fish bones lodged in the throat: Swallow the brain of a mole cricket. It also treats thorns that cannot be extracted—apply it topically, and the thorn will emerge.

Sun Zhenren: For arrowheads lodged in the throat, chest, or diaphragm, or needles that cannot be extracted: Pound a mole cricket to extract its juice and drip it onto the wound; after three to five applications, the arrowhead will emerge on its own.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: The mole cricket—this insect begins its nighttime chirping after the Start of Summer. The *Monthly Ordinances* refers to it as the chirping of the *louluo*. Its sound resembles that of an earthworm, yet it is one of the "five-technique creatures with not a single skill."

---

Pangolin scales (*lingli jia*): Slightly cold. They govern the five malevolent influences, frightful weeping, and sorrowful grief. Burn them to ash, mix one *fangcunbi* with wine or water, and use it to treat ant fistula.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Pangolin scales—formerly, their place of origin was not recorded. Today, they are found in the deep mountains and valleys of Huguang, Jin, Shang, Jun, and Fang. They resemble [illegible] but are shorter and smaller, with a black color. They also resemble carp but have four feet and can move both on land and in water. At midday, they emerge onto the shore, opening their scales as if dead, allowing ants to enter. When the ants fill them, they close their scales and return to the water, causing the ants to float out, which they then consume. Thus, they are most effective for treating ant fistula. They also govern malignant sores, scabies, and leprosy—burn their scales to ash, grind them into powder, and apply topically.

Yang Yan’s *Southern Travel Formulas* treats mountain miasma malaria with Pangolin Scale Decoction. Today, people call it *chuanshanjia* ("mountain-piercing armor"). Recent physicians also use its burned ash, combined with a small amount of nutmeg powder, taken with a drink to treat intestinal hemorrhoids. It further treats unbearable pain in human breast milk: Use one *liang* each of roasted pangolin scales and *mutong*, and half a *liang* of *ziran tong*. Grind these three ingredients into a fine powder. Take three *qian* per dose, mixed with warm wine, without regard to timing.

*The Drug Properties Treatise* states: Pangolin scales are an envoy; they are highly toxic.

To treat mountain miasma malaria and malignant sores, burn the scales and apply topically.

Tao Yinju states: Its form resembles [a certain creature] but is shorter and smaller, and also resembles a carp, with four feet, capable of both land and water movement. When it emerges on shore, it opens its scales and lies still as if dead, allowing ants to enter. Suddenly, it closes them and enters the water, then opens its scales, causing the ants to float out, whereupon it consumes them. Thus, it is most effective for treating ant fistula. However, formulas using it are rare, and it is primarily employed for sores, leprosy, and various *zhu* disorders.

Yu Xi notes: According to the *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica of Shu*, it inhabits deep mountains and valleys, found in Jin, Fang, and Jun prefectures, among others.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: It is cooling and toxic. It treats childhood fright and demonic possession, women’s ghostly weeping, hemorrhoids and fistulas, malignant sores, scabies, and ringworm.

*The Supplement to the Thousand Gold Wing Formulas*: To treat ant fistula, take fourteen pangolin scales, grind them to powder, mix with lard, and apply topically.

*The Concise and Essential Formulas for Universal Relief*: To treat postpartum blood and qi surging upward to the heart causing blood dizziness, take one *liang* of *chuanshanjia* ("mountain-piercing armor"), soak it in boy’s urine overnight, then roast it slowly over a fire until yellow, and grind into powder. Take one *qian* per dose, mixed with a small amount of dog bile and hot wine, without regard to timing.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*:
*The Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies* method for treating ants entering the ear: Burn pangolin scales to powder, mix with water, and irrigate the ear—the ants will emerge.

*Extended Meanings* states: Pangolin scales belong to creatures that dwell in mountain burrows and are also capable in water. Burn one *liang* of scales, preserving their nature, and combine with three nutmeg kernels, ground together into powder. Take two *qian* per dose, mixed with rice water, to treat qi hemorrhoids with pus and blood. In severe cases, add one *liang* of burned hedgehog skin to the powder. Discontinue once the condition improves; the full dose is not required.

*Cantharis*
Flavor: pungent. Nature: slightly warm, toxic.
Governs: gu poison, wind possession, demonic possession, and abortion.
Collected in the third month and dried in the sun.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Cantharis* is not recorded in *The Divine Farmer’s Classic* regarding its native regions; it is now found everywhere. Its form closely resembles that of *Mylabris*, but it is purely bluish-green in color, with a single yellow stripe along its back and a pointed beak. It appears when *Daphne genkwa* blooms in the third or fourth month and is often gathered from the flowers, then dried in the sun. Whenever using *Mylabris*, *Cantharis*, *Epicauta gorhami*, or similar insects, they should be stir-fried with glutinous rice until the rice turns yellowish-black, then removed.
