Discard the head, legs, and wings, wrap the remainder in tangled hair, and hang it under the eastern eaves of a house for one night before use—this removes their toxicity. Tao Yinju notes: Collected when *Daphne genkwa* blooms, it is bluish-black in color and also treats rat fistula. Yu Xi comments: According to *The Illustrated Classic of the Sichuan Materia Medica*, its size and shape resemble *Mylabris*, but it is purely bluish-green. It is now found in Ningzhou. Lei Gong states: *Cantharis*, *Mylabris*, *Epicauta gorhami*, and *Red-Headed Blister Beetle*—these four differ in appearance, habitat, diet, and effects. *Cantharis* has a pointed beak and a single yellow stripe on its back. *Mylabris* has one yellow and one black stripe on its back, with a small red spot at its beak, and dwells on soybean leaves, feeding on their sap. *Epicauta gorhami* is black and yellow, resides on vine leaves, and consumes their sap. The *Red-Headed Blister Beetle* has a large red mark on its forehead and a black body.

The applications of each differ in their uses. For processing *Cantharis*, *Mylabris*, *Epicauta gorhami*, and *Red-Headed Blister Beetle*, mix them with glutinous rice and hemp seeds, then stir-fry until the rice turns yellow-black. Remove the hemp seeds, then discard the wings, legs, and heads. Wrap the remains in human hair, hang them at the eastern corner of the wall overnight, and retrieve them for use at dawn.

Frogs (pronounced *wa*) are sweet in taste, cold in nature, and non-toxic. They govern infantile red qi, skin sores, umbilical injuries, alleviate pain, and supplement insufficiency of qi. Another name is *Long-Legged Frog*. They dwell in water and may be gathered at any time.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Frogs are not recorded in *Shennong’s Classic of Materia Medica* as to their native regions, only that they dwell in water. They are now found everywhere. They resemble toads but have a bluish-green back; they are commonly called *Green Frogs*. Some have yellow patterns on their backs, which people call *Golden Coin Frogs*. Tao Hongjing says: Bees, ants, frogs, and cicadas—these kinds are most numerous. Those with large bellies and green backs are commonly called *Earth Ducks*; their croaking is robust, and they are the frogs referred to in *The Erya* as "those in water." The black ones are called *Clam Children* by southerners, who find them most delicious to eat. These are the creatures now called *Clams*, also known as *Water Chickens*. People in Min, Shu, and eastern Zhe regard them as a delicacy. They say that eating them replenishes deficiency and damage, and they are especially suitable for postpartum women—these are the same.

Tao Hongjing states: Among bees, ants, frogs, and cicadas, their kinds are most numerous. Those large with green backs are commonly called *Earth Ducks*, their croaking robust. Another kind is black, named *Lingzi* by southerners, most delicious to eat. Yet another is small in form and skilled at calling, called *Froglet*—this is the one. Yu Xi says: According to the *Shu Ben* annotation, it belongs to the toad family, dwelling on land; those with green backs and resonant croaking are the ones. *Rihuazi* states: *Green Frogs* are cold in nature and treat childhood heat; those with yellow stripes on their backs are called *Golden Threads*. They kill corpse-attaching parasites, relieve exhaustion, and resolve heat toxins—these are the ones with bluish-green bodies. *Qianjin Fang* states: They govern childhood *red qi*. *Yanyi* says: Frogs are green in color, with slender bellies and pointed mouths; their hind legs are long, hence their leaping ability. When their croaking is loud, they are called *wa* (frogs); when soft, *ha* (clams)—these are the creatures referred to in *The Monthly Commands* as "sparrows entering great waters and transforming into clams." This is also what Han Tuizhi’s poem describes: "All night the green frogs croak till dawn." These, when eaten, are neutral in nature and resolve exhaustion heat.

*Qingling* (upper pronunciation *qing*, lower *ling*): Slightly cold. Strengthens *yin*, arrests seminal emission. *Tu Jing* states: *Qingling* was not recorded in former texts as to its native prefectures; today they are found in abundance near waters. There are several kinds, but the large-eyed green ones are considered best. The red, reddish, and black varieties are not used. Commonly called *qingting* (dragonflies), they are not much sought after, though Daoists frequently employ them. Tao Hongjing says: There are five or six kinds; the large-eyed green ones are used today, also called *Zhucheng* and commonly known as *huli*. Daoists use them to arrest seminal emission. Their eyes can transform into green pearls. The yellow, slender, and black varieties are not used medicinally; they are also called *qingting*. Yu Xi says: According to the *Shu Ben* annotation, dragonflies have six legs and four wings, often flying near streams and ditches. *Rihuazi* states: Dragonflies are cooling and non-toxic. They fortify *yang* and warm the water viscera. For medicinal use, remove wings and legs, then stir-fry for best results. *Yanyi* says: Among dragonflies, one kind is largest, called *Ma Datou* ("Horse’s Big Head") in the capital. Their bodies are green, and the females have a band of azure on their waists. Only males should be used, as Tao Hongjing described: large-eyed and green. Within this kind, none are truly green, though all have large eyes. These creatures emerge from water, hence they often fly above it. As Du Fu wrote: "Dragonflies skimming the water, flying gently."

**Mouse Louse**
Flavor sour, warm, slightly cold, non-toxic. Governs urinary blockage, inability to urinate, convulsions, alternating chills and fever, and promotes water pathways. Treats women’s menstrual blockage, blood stasis, and masses. Also called *Fu Fan*, *Yi Wei*, and *Wei Yu*. Found in Wei Commandery’s Pinggu and on household grounds; collected on the fifth day of the fifth month. *Tu Jing* states: Mouse lice are found in Wei Commandery’s Pinggu and on household grounds; today they are found everywhere. They thrive in damp places beneath jars and in soil pits, often clinging to rats’ backs, hence the name *Mouse-Borne*. The character is now written as *fu* (妇, "woman"), which is erroneous. *The Erya* says: *Pan shu* are *shu fu* (mouse-borne). Guo Pu notes: The insect beneath jars. It also says: *Yi wei* are *wei yu*. *The Odes: Dong Shan* says: "*Yi wei* are in the chamber." Zheng Xuan comments: These creatures appear when a house is uninhabited. Yet *The Divine Farmer’s Classic* also records this name, referring to what people today call *damp-born insects*. Collected on the fifth day of the fifth month. Ancient formulas employ them; Zhang Zhongjing used them in the *Great Turtle Shell Pill* for chronic malaria, as they govern chills and fever. Tao Hongjing says: Also called *shu fu* (mouse-borne), for mice often dwell in pits, and these insects ride on their backs. The character is now written as *fu* (妇, "woman"), which seems unreasonable. Another name is *Shu Gu*. *Rihuazi* states: Mouse lice are toxic. They promote urination and can induce abortion. *Qianjin Fang*: Treats postpartum urinary difficulty. Seven mouse lice, roasted to powder and taken as a single dose with wine. *Yanyi* says: Mouse lice are damp-born insects, multi-legged, their color like earthworms, with transverse ridges on their backs. The largest reach three or four *fen* in length. They are found everywhere, especially under bricks and in damp places, though rarely used.

**Silverfish**
Flavor salty, warm, non-toxic. Governs women’s *shan* masses, urinary difficulty, childhood wind-stroke with stiff neck and arched back—apply topically. Also treats strangury, induces abortion, and when applied to sores, erases scars. Also called *White Fish* and *Yin*. Found in Xianyang’s marshes. *Tu Jing* states: Silverfish are found in Xianyang’s marshes; today they are found everywhere. Few inhabit clothing, but many dwell in books and scrolls. *The Erya* calls them *yin tan* (or *xun liang*), *White Fish*. Guo Pu notes: The insect in clothing and books, also called *bing yu*. Duan Chengshi says: Attendant Zhang Zhou saw melon seeds on a wall transform into white fish, confirming *Liezi*’s claim that rotten melons become fish. Ancient formulas treat childhood urinary blockage by rubbing the navel and lower abdomen with them, inducing urination. Combined with eagle droppings and stiff silkworms, they erase scars when applied to sores. Today they are called *Wall Fish*. Folklore holds that when wall fish enter Daoist scripture cases and gnaw the characters of immortals, their bodies become five-colored. Whoever swallows one may attain immortality.

During the Tang dynasty, Zhang Tang’s youngest son, captivated by such claims, wrote many characters of immortals, cut them into pieces, and placed them in a jar. He then introduced wall fish into the jar, hoping they would gnaw the characters—but they could not. This obsession led to a mental affliction.
*(Note: 蛃 is pronounced bǐng.)*

Yu Xi notes: According to the *Yaoxing Lun* (*Treatise on the Properties of Medicines*), the white fish found in clothing is toxic and promotes urination.

The *Qianjin Fang* (*Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold*) states: For treating sand, stones, or grass lodged in the eye, causing irritation and inability to expel them, mix white fish with breast milk and apply to the eye.

The *Waitai Miyao Fang* (*Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*) prescribes: For eye screens, grind white fish into powder and apply a small amount to the affected area.

Sun Zhenren’s formula advises: For sudden onset of hemiplegia with slurred speech and facial distortion, rub white fish on the area below the ear. If the mouth is drawn to the left, rub the right side; if to the right, rub the left. Cease when the distortion corrects.

The *Zimu Milu Fang* (*Secret Records for Mothers and Children*) treats: Unexplained bloody urine in women by inserting thirty white fish from clothing into the vagina.

The *Yanyi* (*Extension of the Materia Medica*) observes: Clothing fish are most commonly found in old books, occasionally in undisturbed silk, but rarely as much as in aged paper. Their bodies are coated with a thick powder that flakes off when touched. They also gnaw at fur garments, though their uses are few. Their form somewhat resembles a fish, with a tail that splits into two branches. They are commonly employed to erase scars.

**Abalone Shell (Jiaxiang)**
Flavor: salty. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
Governs: fullness and pain in the chest and abdomen, qi urgency, diarrhea, and urinary strangury.
Grows in the South Seas.

The *Tujing* (*Illustrated Classic*) states: Abalone shell is found in the South Seas. Today, it is also present in coastal prefectures of Lingwai, Min, and Mingzhou. It is the operculum of a sea conch.

The *Nanzhou Yiwu Zhi* (*Record of Strange Things from the Southern Regions*) describes: Large abalone shells resemble the surface of a bowl, with a straight, elongated front edge several inches long. The shell is rough and spiny. When burned with other incense, it enhances their fragrance, but when burned alone, it emits a foul odor. It is also called *liuluo* (flowing conch). Among all conches, the *liu* has the richest flavor. Its conch resembles a small fist, greenish-yellow, and four to five inches long. People also consume its meat. It is rarely used in modern medical formulas.

*(Note: 蠡 is pronounced luó.)*

The Tang *Bencao* commentary notes: The conch is the size of a small fist, greenish-yellow, and four to five inches long. Its operculum is burned to ash for use. Southerners also boil and eat its meat, though it offers no particular benefit or harm.

The *Haiyao* (*Marine Materia Medica*) states: It harmonizes qi, clears the spirit, and treats abdominal wind, fistulas, and hemorrhoids.

Chen Shi remarks: It governs nail abscesses, fistulas, snake, scorpion, and bee stings, scabies, head sores, and mouth sores.

Abalone paste is used in lip balms.

The *Guangzhou Ji* (*Records of Guangzhou*) records: Southerners commonly eat it, much like turtle or softshell turtle. There is also a small abalone shell resembling a tiny conch, shaped from its base.

The *Yanyi* adds: Abalone shell excels at directing the smoke of incense. When used with agarwood, sandalwood, dragon’s blood, and musk, the effect is superb.

**Golden Snake**
Non-toxic.

Golden Snake resolves raw gold poisoning. When one is poisoned by gold-based medicines, take a four-inch segment of the snake, roast it until yellow, and boil it to make a decoction. Drink it repeatedly until recovery. It is as thick as a finger and about a foot long, often climbing trees to drink dew. Its body is golden in color, and when exposed to sunlight, it shines. There is also a silver snake that resolves silver-based medicine poisoning.

To test for gold poisoning, at dusk place a piece of silver in the mouth and keep it there until dawn. If the silver turns golden, it confirms gold poisoning, which causes the victim’s flesh to crack like a chicken’s foot.

It is found in Bin and Cheng Prefectures.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: The Golden Snake is found in Bin Prefecture. As thick as a finger and about a foot long, it often climbs trees to drink dew. Its body is golden and shines in sunlight. It can resolve gold poisoning. There is also a silver snake that resolves the five silver-based poisons. Though none have been captured recently, in Ling Mountain Township, Shangrao County, Xin Prefecture, there is a snake strikingly similar to this, which locals call the "Golden Star Earthworm." It is captured in winter and can resolve various poisons, stop diarrhea, and dispel pathogenic heat.

**Millipede**
Flavor: pungent. Nature: warm, toxic.
It governs hard masses and accumulations in the abdomen, breaks up concretions, eliminates polyps, treats malignant sores, white bald patches, and cures alternating chills and fever, glomus, and fullness below the ribs.
Also called "hundred-footed" or "horse axle."
Found in the river valleys of Xuantu.

Master Tao Yinju states: Li claims this creature measures five to six inches in length, resembling a large cricket. In summer, it climbs trees and chirps; in winter, it hibernates. People today call it the "flying centipede," though it may not necessarily be the *malu*. There is also a slender yellow insect resembling a centipede but much longer, commonly called the "earthworm insect." When chickens eat it, they become intoxicated and may even die. As the saying goes: "The hundred-footed creature does not stiffen even in death." This insect has many legs—when cut into segments, each segment continues to move. Perhaps it resembles the *malu*, but since physicians no longer use it and market vendors do not seek it, it remains unclear which is the true specimen.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This insect is as thick as a fine brush handle, three to four inches long, and striped like a gecko. In Xiangyang, it is called *maxian* or *mazhou*, and also *daohuan chong* ("sword-ring insect"), for when it dies, it lies on its side like a sword ring. If a person is poisoned and ingests one, they will die immediately.

The *Extended Materia Medica* states: The *malu* is the "hundred-jointed insect" of today. Its body resembles knotted wood, with fine wrinkles on each segment, rising in a purplish-black hue, lustrous and smooth, with a hundred legs. When dead, it lies on its side like a sword ring, measuring two to three inches in length. The finest specimens are as thick as a little finger. In the Shangyang Palace of the Western Capital and within the inner city’s brick walls, they are abundant. Only the freshest are used in medicine.

The *didan* (ground blister beetle) has a pungent taste, is cold in nature, and is toxic. It governs demonic infestations, alternating chills and fever, scrofula, malignant sores, necrotic flesh, breaks up abdominal masses, induces abortion, erodes malignant flesh in sores, removes nasal polyps, disperses congealed qi and stone strangury, and expels a dead fetus. Ingesting one *daogui* (scant measure) will induce purgation. It is also called *ruanqing* or *wa* (pronounced *wuwa* in the Wu dialect).

It grows in the river valleys of Wenshan and is collected in the eighth month. It is incompatible with licorice.

The *Yaoxing Lun* states: The *didan* can expel the roots of scrofula, which are discharged through the urine or vomited out. It also treats nasal congestion.

Tao Yinju says: The authentic variety comes from Liangzhou, resembling a large ant with wings. The counterfeit is transformed from *banmao* (blister beetles), resembling a large soybean. Though their therapeutic effects are broadly similar, the authentic variety is rarely obtained. The counterfeit may still be used, hence the name *wanyuanqing*. The character *wan* (蚖) is unusual, and this may be an inherited error.

The *Tang Ben* commentary states: Those resembling large ants are now found in Binzhou. Those resembling large soybeans have not been observed.

Yu Xi says: According to the *Shu Ben Tu Jing*, they are collected from grasses and vegetables in the second, third, eighth, and ninth months. Their form is twice as black, and they are transformed from *yuanqing* (green blister beetles).

The *ke* (clam shell) has a salty taste, is neutral in nature, and is non-toxic.

To treat eye nebulae, stanch bleeding, and promote flesh regeneration. It belongs to the shellfish category, growing as large as abalone. Its skin is yellow-black while its bone is white, and it is used as horse ornamentation. It is produced in the Southern Sea, and may be gathered at any time.

The *Hai Yao* states: According to the *Ming Yi Bie Lu*, it grows in the Southern Sea, white like a clam. It treats nebulae, membrane obstructions, and overgrown flesh in the sinews, all by scraping and applying as a topical powder. Beyond these uses, there are no other essential applications.

Master Lei says: The best are those gathered in winter, white and unctuous, with white spiral water-patterns. They must not be exposed to fire, or they immediately become useless. When using, scrape into powder with a bronze knife, grind finely, sift through heavy silk, then grind a thousand times or more before use. This substance is not used in remedies for women.

*Yinghuo* (firefly)
Flavor: pungent. Nature: slightly warm. Non-toxic.
It brightens the eyes, treats fire sores in children, dispels heat qi, counteracts *gu* toxins and demonic inflictions, and connects with the spirit’s essence. It is also called *yeguang* (night light), *fangguang* (radiance), *zhaoyao* (illumination), or *jizhao* (immediate light). It is born in steps, ponds, and marshes. Gather on the seventh day of the seventh month, and dry in the shade.

Master Tao Yinju states: This creature arises from the transformation of rotting grasses and decayed bamboo roots. At first, it does not yet resemble an insect, though its underside already emits light. After several days, it transforms and gains the ability to fly. The people of Fang and Wei capture them, place them in wine to kill them, then dry them. In common remedies, they are seldom used.

**Sea Conch**
The *Baiyi* states: It treats eye pain lasting for years, even three or four decades. Take one live conch, wash it, and place it on a dry surface until its mouth opens. Insert one piece of *huanglian* (coptis) into the conch’s mouth, allowing the conch to drink the *huanglian* juice. Then, use silk to absorb the juice and apply it to the corners of the eyes.
Sun Zhenren: When combined with vegetables and eaten, it treats heart pain.

**Sea Moon**
Flavor: pungent. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
It relieves wasting-thirst, descends qi, stimulates the appetite, and harmonizes the five viscera.

**Single-Legged Wasp**
Usage is as described above. It resembles a small wasp, black in color, with only one leg. It clings to tree roots and cannot be removed or shaken loose. Gather in the fifth month. Found in Lingnan.
There is also a single-legged ant with the same effects as the wasp. It, too, clings to tree roots and cannot be moved or shaken. Found in Lingnan.

**Flying Birth-Insect**
Non-toxic.
It eases childbirth. Take its horn and hold it at the time of labor. Alternatively, burn it into powder and ingest a small amount. The insect resembles a gnawing louse but has a horn on its head.

**Two-Headed Snake**
Seeing it brings misfortune.

The Two-Headed Snake is as thick as a finger. One head has neither eyes nor mouth, while both heads can move. It is found in Kuaiji, and people say it is the bowstring of King Goujian of Yue. In ancient times, Sunshu Ao buried it, fearing that those who saw it would surely die. Seeing a snake with feet is also considered inauspicious. If a snake is burned with mulberry firewood, its feet will appear—there is nothing strange about this. *Illustrated Classic and Expanded Meaning of Materia Medica*, Scroll Thirty-Four, concludes.

*Illustrated Classic and Expanded Meaning of Materia Medica*, Scroll Thirty-Five.
Compiled by Kou Zongshi, Court Gentleman for Ceremonial Service and Verifier of Medicinal Materials, of the Song Dynasty.

**Fruit Section, Superior Grade**

**Cardamom (豆蔻)**
Flavor: pungent. Nature: warm. Non-toxic.
Governs warming the center, relieving pain in the heart and abdomen, stopping vomiting, and eliminating foul breath.
Grows in Nanhai.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Cardamom is *Cao Doukou* (草豆蔻). It grows in Nanhai, and today is found throughout Lingnan. Its shoots resemble reeds; its leaves resemble those of *shanjiang* (山姜) and *du ruo* (杜若). Its root resembles *gaoliangjiang* (高良姜). The flowers form spikes, emerging from the curled young leaves, initially resembling hibiscus. The tip of the spike is deep red; as the leaves unfurl, the flowers emerge, their color gradually fading. Some are yellow-white. The people of the south often gather them as fruit, prizing them highly. When dried in the sun, decocted, and taken, they powerfully dispel cold *qi*, arrest cholera, and resolve alcohol and food poisoning—most excellent.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* says: *Cao Doukou* may be used alone and governs all cold *qi*.

Tao Hongjing says: The best are intensely pungent and fragrant; they may be held in the mouth regularly. They are suitable for use in the "Five Harmonies" gruel. *Lianjiang* (廉姜) is most effective for warming the center and descending *qi*; *yizhi* (益智) is hot; *juyuan* (枸橼) is warm; *ganjiao* (甘蕉) and *jimu* (麂目) are slightly cold.
*糁 (sǎn)*: read as *sùgǎn*.
*枸 (jǔ)*: pronounced *jǔ*.
*橼 (yuán)*: pronounced *yuán*.
*麂 (jǐ)*: pronounced *jǐ*.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: Cardamom’s shoots resemble *shanjiang*; its flowers are yellow-white. Its shoots, roots, and seeds are reddish, resembling *du ruo*. *Juyuan* is cold in nature—Tao’s claim that it is warm is mistaken.

Modern annotation: This is *Cao Doukou*, which descends *qi* and arrests cholera.

*Ri Hua Zi* says: Cardamom flower is hot and non-toxic. It descends *qi*, stops retching, eliminates cholera, regulates the center, and supplements stomach *qi*. It resolves alcohol toxicity. It also states: *Shanjiang* flower is warming and non-toxic. It regulates the center, descends *qi*, aids digestion, and neutralizes alcohol toxicity.

Yu Xi says: According to *The Illustrated Classic of the Shu Materia Medica*, its shoots resemble *du ruo*. In spring, flowers grow at the tip of the spike, resembling hibiscus, with four chambers emerging from beneath the stem. They are white, turning yellow when open. The root resembles *gaoliangjiang*. The fruit is like longan but lacks scales, its interior resembling pomegranate seeds. The stem, leaves, and seeds are all pungent and fragrant. Harvested in the tenth month. It is now also cultivated in gardens.

*The Materia Medica of Overseas Drugs* says: Cardamom grows in Jiaozhi. Its root resembles *yizhi*, with a slightly thicker husk. The kernel is like a pomegranate seed, pungent and fragrant. *Nacao* (蒳草) is a tree with leaves resembling *wanlan* (芄兰) but smaller. Its leaves are gathered in the third month, finely shredded, and dried in the shade. The flavor is nearly bitter with a hint of sweetness.

*The Thousand Gold Prescriptions*: To treat abdominal distension and fullness with shortness of breath, take one *liang* of *Cao Doukou*, remove the skin, and grind into powder. Take half a *qian* with a decoction of unripe papaya and fresh ginger.

*The Expanded Meaning* states: Cardamom is *Cao Doukou*, intensely pungent and slightly fragrant. This name distinguishes it from *rou doukou* (肉豆蔻). When used as a fruit, the flavor is unbalanced. It is unclear what the ancients intended by including it in the fruit section—what significance does this hold? Its nature is warming and harmonizing; it disperses cold *qi* with great speed. The flower is hot in nature. When pickled in the capital, its flavor is not particularly fine, being slightly bitter. It must be effective in resolving alcohol toxicity, hence its use as a fruit. When dried, the flower turns a pale purple.

**Lotus Seed Stem (藕实茎)**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: balanced, cold. Non-toxic.
Governs supplementing the center and nourishing the spirit, boosting *qi* and strength, and eliminating the hundred illnesses. Prolonged consumption lightens the body, confers longevity, prevents hunger, and extends years.
Alternative names: *Shuizhidan* (水芝丹), *Lian* (莲).
Grows in the ponds and marshes of Runan. Harvested in the eighth month.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Lotus seed stem grows in the ponds and marshes of Runan; today, it is found everywhere. It grows in water, and its leaves are called *he* (荷).

Carefully noted: *The Erya* and Lu Ji’s commentary state: *He* (荷) is *fuqu* (芙蕖); in Jiangdong, it is called *he*. Its stem is *jia* (茄); its leaf is *xia* (蕸), pronounced *xiá* or *jiā*; its base is *mi* (蔤), the white *ruo* (蒻) beneath the stem in the mud; its unopened flower is *han dan* (菡萏), and when opened, it is *furong* (芙蓉); its fruit is *lian* (莲), the chamber above being the *fang* (房); its root is *ou* (藕). All these parts are used in medicine today.

*Ou* (藕): Eating the raw stem governs deficiency, thirst, and vexation after cholera, inability to eat, and resolves alcohol and food toxicity.
The flower: Calms the heart and enhances complexion; especially fine for use in incense.
The lotus leaf: Stops thirst and neutralizes mushroom toxicity. Today, it is frequently used in women’s medicine.
The stem’s central node, called *hebi* (荷鼻): Governs stabilizing pregnancy, expelling malign blood, and retaining good blood.
The seed: Governs supplementing *qi*.
The seed that darkens and sinks in water by autumn is called *shilian* (石莲). Lu Ji says: It can be ground into flour like millet, lightening the body, boosting *qi*, and strengthening the person. Physicians roast and grind it to stop dysentery and treat lumbar pain. It also treats hiccups: take six seeds, roast until reddish-yellow, grind into powder, and take with half a cup of hot or cold water to stop them. Only the bitter *yiyou* (苦薏) must not be eaten, as it can cause cholera. Generally, its functions are most effective in governing blood.
*蒻 (ruò)*: pronounced *ruò*.

*The Materia Medica of Medicinal Properties* says: Lotus juice may also be used alone. Flavor: sweet. It disperses static blood. When pounded into juice, it governs unceasing blood ejection, treating both the mouth and nose.

Tao Hongjing says: This is today’s lotus seed. In the eighth and ninth months, gather the firm, black ones, dry, and pound them open. The flower and root are used in Daoist immortality practices. Here, "stem" likely refers to the root—otherwise, it should not be described as sweet. During the Song Emperor’s reign, the imperial kitchen prepared blood dishes. A chef accidentally dropped lotus root peel into the blood, which then failed to coagulate. Physicians have since used lotus to treat blood disorders with great efficacy.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: *The Supplementary Records* states: *Ou* (藕) governs heat and thirst, disperses blood, and generates flesh.

Prolonged consumption induces joy in the heart.

Chen Cangqi says: The lotus receptacle (荷鼻), bitter in flavor and neutral in nature, is non-toxic. It stabilizes pregnancy, dispels malign blood while retaining wholesome blood, and treats bloody dysentery—boil and consume. This refers to the lotus leaf base. The leaf and seedpod also govern blood distension and abdominal pain, as well as retained placenta after childbirth—boil in wine and consume. They further counteract wild mushroom poisoning—boil in water and consume.

Zheng Xuan says: The stem of the *fuqu* (芙蕖) is called *he* (荷). The core of its seed (的中薏), when eaten, causes cholera-like disorders.

Chen Shiliang says: The lotus seed heart, taken fresh and ground into powder, is mixed with rice water and consumed in a dose of three *qian* to treat blood disorders and thirst. For postpartum thirst, it effects immediate cure.

*Ri Hua Zi* says: The lotus root is warming. It arrests cholera, stimulates the stomach and digestion, relieves vexation and oppression, and treats dry mouth and thirst. It calms anger and induces joy. For postpartum blood oppression, grinding and consuming it raw is unproblematic. It also treats metal-inflicted wounds and traumatic injuries, relieving acute pain. Steamed or boiled, it greatly stimulates the appetite. The nodes are cooling. They resolve heat toxins and disperse static blood. For postpartum blood oppression, combine with raw *rehmannia* (地黄), grind into juice, and consume with hot wine or urine—both methods are effective.

It further states: The lotus seed, warming (including stone lotus), boosts qi, stops thirst, fortifies the heart, and arrests dysentery. It treats lumbar pain, seminal emission, and pacifies the heart. Overconsumption induces joy; it is also called *liandi* (莲的). The lotus seed heart arrests cholera.

It further states: The lotus leaf stops thirst, expels the afterbirth, neutralizes mushroom toxins, and treats postpartum dry mouth, heart-lung dryness, and vexation—use in medicine after roasting. It further states: The lotus flower is warming and non-toxic. It settles the heart, lightens the body, enhances complexion, and preserves youthful appearance. It is excellent in incense. Avoid *rehmannia* and garlic.

Meng Shen says: Raw lotus root governs post-cholera deficiency, thirst, vexation, and loss of appetite. While postpartum consumption of raw and cold foods is generally forbidden, lotus root is an exception, as it breaks up blood. Steamed, it greatly tonifies the five viscera and consolidates the lower burner. Consumed with honey, it nourishes the abdominal organs, promotes corpulence, and prevents parasitic infestations.

It may also serve as grain-substitute sustenance. Daoist immortals store stone lotus seeds and dried lotus roots that have endured a thousand years—consuming these refines one to the utmost essence.

It further states: The lotus seed is cooling in nature. It governs insufficiency of the five viscera, damage to the central qi leading to collapse, and benefits the blood and qi of the twelve meridians. Eaten raw, it slightly agitates qi; steamed, it is excellent. When fully cooked, remove the heart, grind into powder, and blend with beeswax and honey to form pills. Taking thirty pills daily renders one free from hunger—this is a formula used by Daoist immortals.

Yu Xi says: According to the *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica of Shu*, it grows in water. The leaf is called *he*, round and over a foot in diameter. The *Erya* states: *He* is *fuqu*. Its stem is *jia*, its leaf *xia*, its base *mi*, its flower *han dan*, its fruit *lian*, its root *ou*, and within its fruit lies the *di*, while within the *di* is the *yi*. The *Erya* explains: *Fuqu* is its general name, also called *furong*; in Jiangdong, it is called *he*. *Han dan* refers to the lotus leaf. *Di* is the lotus seed. *Yi* is the core within. Guo [Pu] notes: *Mi* is the white rootstock submerged in mud. Today, people in Jiangdong call the lotus leaf *furong*, while northerners often refer to the lotus root as *he* or the lotus itself as *he*. In Shu, the root is called *jia*, sometimes using the mother plant to name the flower or the root to name the mother leaf—all these are instances of confused nomenclature, where customary usage has led to error, obscuring the true forms.

Lu Ji’s *Commentary* states: The lotus has a green skin with white inside; the seed is the *di*, and within the *di* lies the green *yi*, which is extremely bitter—hence the common saying, "bitter as *yi*." Sun Zhenren says: Eating lotus seeds without removing the heart causes cholera. The *Heart Mirror of Dietary Medicine* states: The lotus seed is sweet, neutral, and non-toxic. It governs supplementing the center and nourishing the spirit, boosting qi and strength, and eliminating the hundred diseases. Long-term consumption brings joy to the heart, quenches thirst, dispels heat, lightens the body, resists aging, prevents hunger, and prolongs life.

Its root checks heat and thirst, disperses stagnant blood, and promotes flesh regeneration. Prolonged consumption renders the complexion radiant.

*The Sagely Benefit Formulary*:
To treat seasonal qi with vexing thirst: Take half a cup of fresh lotus root juice, blend with one *ge* of raw honey, divide into two doses, and administer.

Another formula: To treat bruising from falls, with malign blood attacking the heart, causing oppression, disorder, and pain: Take five *jin* of dried lotus leaves, burn until smoke dissipates, and grind finely. Before meals, mix three *qianbi* with a small cup of hot boy’s urine, and take thrice daily.

*The Thousand Gold Formulary*:
To treat falls from horses with accumulated blood in the heart and abdomen, and incessant spitting of blood: Grind dried lotus flowers and roots into powder, and take one *fangcunbi* with wine, thrice daily.

*The Post-Verified Effective Formulas*:
To govern spitting of blood and coughing of blood: Dry-fry lotus leaves until crisp, grind into powder, and take two *qianbi* with rice water.

*Master Mei’s Formulas*:
To treat postpartum retention of malign blood surging upward to the heart, causing vexation, oppression, and abdominal pain: Drink one *sheng* of fresh lotus root juice.

*The Emergency Relief Formulas*:
To treat postpartum retention of blood with oppression and heart pain: Parch lotus leaves until fragrant, grind into powder, and decoct one *fangcunbi* in water for administration.

*The Collected Verified Formulas*:
To treat lacquer sores: Take one *jin* of dried lotus leaves, boil in one *dou* of water until reduced to two *sheng*, and wash the sores twice daily until healed.

*The Amplification of Meaning* states: Lotus seeds that dry within the pod become "stone lotus seeds." Remove the flesh, dry in a stone mortar, rub off the reddish surface, and retain the green heart as powder. Add a small amount of *longnao* to make a decoction, which settles the mind and clears the spirit. However, there are also pink thousand-petal and white thousand-petal varieties, both of which are sterile. Thus, there are four grades in total. Among the roots, only the white lotus is superior. Now, within the imperial palace, a jade-green lotus has also emerged—another auspicious sign.

**Tangerine and Pomelo**
Flavor: acrid; warm; non-toxic.
Governs: accumulations and heat in the chest with counterflow qi; facilitates digestion; directs qi downward; checks vomiting and cough; eliminates retained heat in the bladder, water retention, the five stranguries, and difficult urination; governs the spleen’s failure to digest grains; qi surging into the chest; vomiting and counterflow; cholera; checks diarrhea; expels tapeworms. Prolonged consumption eliminates foul odors, directs qi downward, connects with the spirit, lightens the body, and prolongs life.
Alternate name: tangerine peel.
Grows in river valleys of the Southern Mountains and in Jiangnan. Harvested in the tenth month.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Tangerines and pomelos grow in river valleys of the Southern Mountains, Jiangnan, Jiangzhe, Jingxiang, Huguang, and the Lingnan region. The trees reach one to two *zhang* in height. Their leaves are indistinguishable from those of the trifoliate orange, with thorns emerging between the stems. In early summer, they bear white flowers, and the fruit forms in the sixth and seventh months, ripening to yellow by winter, when it may be eaten. Traditional accounts state that the smaller fruit is the tangerine, and the larger, the pomelo. It is also said: the pomelo resembles the bitter orange but is sour and larger than the tangerine. Kong Anguo’s commentary on the *Book of Documents* ("Their tribute was of tangerines and pomelos") and Guo Pu’s annotation on the *Erya* (under "pomelo") both follow this explanation. Moreover, pomelos are found in Minzhong, Lingwai, and Jiangnan—yellow-white and larger than tangerines. In Xiang and Tang regions, pomelos are greenish-yellow and smaller, all with a sour taste, thick peels, and unsuitable for medicinal use. Tao Hongjing notes: This refers to the peel’s function. Eastern tangerines are superior, though those from the Western River also exist but are inferior. Their peels are slightly cold and govern qi, said to surpass tangerines. Northerners also use them, preferring aged peels. The flesh is sweet and sour; excessive consumption generates phlegm and may not be beneficial. Though the peel is used here, as it belongs to the fruit category, it is still appropriately included. Pomelo flesh may be consumed, but it is not used medicinally. Its effects should also direct qi downward.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: Pomelo peels are thick and sweet, unlike tangerine peels, which are acrid and bitter. The flesh resembles that of tangerines, with sweet and sour varieties; the sour is called *hugan*. Nowadays, common folk sometimes miscall bitter oranges "pomelos," which is incorrect. According to the *Master Lü’s Spring and Autumn Annals*: "Among the finest fruits are the pomelos of Yunmeng." Guo Pu states: The pomelo resembles the bitter orange but is larger. Kong Anguo states: The large is called pomelo, the small tangerine—both are sweet and sour. Current annotation: Moved here from the Wood section.

Chen Cangqi states: Beyond the functions of tangerine and pomelo peels, the flesh is cold. Sour varieties congeal phlegm, while sweet varieties moisten the lungs. The peel is suitable for medicinal use; the seeds are not. Varieties include red mandarins, milk mandarins, yellow mandarins, rock mandarins, and sand mandarins. Tangerine types include red tangerines, milk tangerines, flat tangerines, mountain tangerines, and yellow bland tangerines. The peels of these all dispel qi and harmonize the center, while the flesh is generally edible. Among them, the milk mandarin is superior. The *Divine Farmer’s Classic* should be placed in the Fruit section; adding the character "flesh" to the Wood section is incorrect. In Lingnan, pomelos grow as large as winter melons.

*Master Ri Hua’s Materia Medica* states: Tangerines, flavor sweet and sour, check wasting-thirst, stimulate the stomach, and eliminate chest and diaphragm qi. The peel is warming, dissolves phlegm, checks cough, and breaks concretions, conglomerations, *xuan* accumulations, and *pi* obstructions. The seeds treat lumbar pain, bladder qi, and kidney pain—roast, remove the shells, and take with wine for excellent effect. The membranes on tangerine segments treat thirst and alcohol-induced vomiting—roast and decoct in water for a highly effective drink. Pomelos are non-toxic, treat pregnant women with poor appetite and bland taste, expel malign qi from the stomach, aid digestion, eliminate intestinal and stomach qi, resolve alcohol toxicity, and treat bad breath in drinkers.

You Xi states: According to the *Treatise on Medicinal Properties*, tangerine peel, a ministerial drug, is bitter and acrid. It can treat qi in the chest and diaphragm, stimulate the stomach, govern qi dysentery, dissolve phlegm and drool, and treat upward counterflow qi and cough.

Meng Shen states: Tangerines halt diarrhea and dysentery. Eating them aids digestion, opens the chest and diaphragm, and resolves congealed qi from phlegm and repletion. Their qi-descending effect is not as strong as that of the peel. The pulp should not be consumed in excess, as it restrains qi. Though their nature is warm, they quench thirst. Furthermore, take one *jin* of dried peel, pound it into powder, and form pills with honey. Take thirty pills with wine before meals to treat cold qi in the lower burner. Also, take one *jin* of aged tangerine peel and five *liang* of apricot kernels, remove the skins and tips, simmer, and add a small amount of honey to form pills. Take thirty pills with water before meals daily to descend cold qi from the lower abdomen and viscera. This also treats beriberi attacking the heart and hardness below the heart. The *Heart Mirror of Food and Medicine* states: It governs latent heat in the chest, descends qi, dissolves phlegm, and transforms food. Take half a *liang* of tangerine peel, lightly roast it into powder, and decoct it like tea for sipping.

The *Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*: To treat sudden loss of voice with inability to speak, take five *liang* of tangerine peel and three *sheng* of water, boil to one *sheng*, strain, and consume in one dose.

The *Tested Later Prescriptions*: To treat cold qi below the diaphragm and fullness from overindulgence in food and drink, regularly take four *liang* of green tangerine peel and one *liang* of salt. Divide into four portions; discard one portion. Soak the green tangerine peel in hot water overnight, strain, remove the pulp, then mix with the remaining three portions of salt. Stir evenly, wait a while, then stir-fry in a wok until slightly scorched, and grind into powder. Each dose: one and a half *qian* of the powder, half a *qian* of tea leaves, and one *zhan* of water. Decoct to seven parts, let cool slightly, and take regularly. Omitting the tea and simply infusing the powder in boiling water is also effective.

Sun Shangyao’s *Prescriptions*: To treat all kinds of belching and hiccups, take two *liang* of tangerine peel, soak in hot water to remove the pulp, chop, and decoct in one *sheng* of water to five *ge*. Consume hot in one dose. For greater effect, add one *liang* of roasted *zhike* (bitter orange), remove the pulp, and decoct together.

The *Collected Effective Prescriptions*: To treat unbearable lumbar pain, stir-fry tangerine seeds and grind into powder. Each dose: one *qian*, one *zhan* of wine. Decoct to seven parts and consume with the dregs on an empty stomach.

The *Extended Meanings* states: The tangerine (*ju*) and pomelo (*you*) are two distinct species, hence it is said, "also called tangerine peel," implying that the term *pomelo* was originally absent. How could two different substances share identical therapeutic properties without a single distinguishing character? Thus, it is clear that the character *you* (pomelo) is an error. Later generations, failing to investigate its meaning deeply, became confused by the term *you* and arbitrarily created distinctions—this is indeed excessive. Moreover, even green tangerines and yellow tangerines differ in their therapeutic effects, let alone the pomelo, which is a separate species. Guo Pu remarked: "The pomelo resembles the bitter orange but is larger than the tangerine." This is a true recognition of the difference between tangerines and pomelos. If this distinction is not made clear, future generations may mistake pomelo peel for tangerine peel, thereby sowing endless trouble. As the ancients recede into the past, even later scholars of discernment may no longer infer its original intent.

The tangerine is used only for its peel and seeds. The peel is widely required throughout the world. It should be soaked in hot water to remove the pulp, with the rest following the *Classic* and its *Commentaries*. Both seeds and peel are best when self-collected.

There was a person suffering from chronic cough on the verge of crisis. Someone instructed them to dry-fry tangerine peel and fresh ginger, then grind them with equal parts *shenqu* (medicated leaven) into a powder, forming pills the size of *tongzi* seeds. Taking thirty to fifty pills after meals and before bed with rice water, their long-standing bladder ailment was also cured. This method relies on aged tangerine peel, which is one of the "Six Aged" medicinals.

For kidney *zhu* (obstinate disease), lumbar pain, and bladder qi pain, lightly stir-fry the seeds, remove the shells, grind into powder, and take with wine—this brings a cure.

**Jujube (Dazao)**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
It governs pathogenic qi in the heart and abdomen, harmonizes the center and nourishes the spleen, assists the twelve channels, regulates stomach qi, unblocks the nine orifices, supplements insufficiency of qi and body fluids, alleviates great fright, heaviness in the limbs, harmonizes the effects of all medicines, tonifies the center and augments qi, strengthens vitality, dispels vexation and oppression, and treats suspended sensation below the heart and intestinal afflux. Long-term consumption lightens the body, prolongs life, prevents hunger, and bestows immortality.

Alternative names: *ganzao* (dried jujube), *meizao* (fine jujube), *liangzao* (good jujube).
Harvested in the eighth month and dried in the sun.

The kernels of jujubes stored for three years, when burned, taste bitter. They govern abdominal pain and pathogenic qi.

Fresh jujube: flavor sweet and acrid. Overconsumption causes alternating chills and fever; those who are emaciated should not eat it. The leaves, when used to cover *mahuang* (ephedra), promote sweating.
Grows in the plains and marshes of Hedong. Counteracts the toxicity of *wutou* (aconite).
*Fan* is pronounced *fan*.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: Jujube refers to dried jujubes. Both fresh and dried jujubes grow in Hedong. Today, they are found in all northern prefectures, with those from Qing, Jin, and Jiang provinces being particularly excellent. Those produced in Jiangnan are hard, dry, and low in fat.

Careful note: There are many varieties of jujubes. Guo Pu’s commentary on the *Erya* states:
- *Zao* (jujube): *Huzao* (gourd jujube). It is said: "In Jiangdong, large jujubes with pointed tops are called *hu* (gourd)." *Hu* resembles a bottle gourd.
- *Bian*: *Yaoyao* (waist jujube). It is said: "The fruit has a slender waist, now called *luluzao* (pulley jujube)."
- *Jie*: *Baizao* (white jujube). It is said: "This is the common jujube; when white, it is ripe."
- *Ci*: *Suanzao* (sour jujube). It is said: "The tree is small, and the fruit is sour."
- *Zun*: *Yangzao* (goat jujube). It is said: "The fruit is small and round, purple-black in color. Today, it is commonly called *yangshizao* (goat-dung jujube)."
- *Xi*: *Jianzao* (pointed jujube). It is said: "In Yi County of Hedong, large jujubes grow, the size of chicken eggs."
- *Juexie*: *Kuzao* (bitter jujube). It is said: "The fruit tastes bitter."
- *Xi*: *Wushizao* (seedless jujube). It is said: "It bears no seeds."
- *Huanwei*: *Renzao* (short-tasting jujube). It is said: "*Huanwei* means short in flavor."

The sour jujube is listed separately. The remaining varieties are numerous, and while they are cultivated in gardens today, their names cannot all be distinguished. The finest include *shuilingzao* (water-chestnut jujube) and *yuzhao* (imperial jujube), but these are unsuitable for medicinal use.
*Jie* is pronounced *zi xi*. *Ren* is pronounced *wu shen*.

Tao Hongjing said: It was once said that the jujubes of Yi County in Hedong were exceptionally fine. Today, those from Qingzhou are large, with small kernels and abundant fat, and are very sweet. They are also obtained through trade in Yuzhou, where the jujubes are good but slightly smaller. In Jiangdong, the jujubes of Linqin and Jincheng are large but hollow, low in fat, and only the best can be used. Southern jujubes are large and poor in quality, scarcely edible.

Daoist formulas and medicines regard jujubes as an excellent food. Their skin is dispersing, while the flesh tonifies deficiency, which is why they are split when used in decoctions.

The *Tang Materia Medica* notes: The *Miscellaneous Records* states: "Jujube leaves are dispersing. Consuming them causes emaciation, and prolonged use leads to vomiting. They are effective for rubbing hot rashes." The *Ri Huazi* states: "Dried jujubes moisten the heart and lungs, relieve cough, tonify the five viscera, treat consumptive damage, eliminate accumulations and qi in the intestines and stomach, and when burned with calomel, treat infantile malnutrition and dysentery. Those with dental diseases should avoid eating them. Jujubes should not be eaten with raw scallions."

It also states: "Jujube leaves are warm and non-toxic. They treat high fever in children; bathing in a decoction is excellent for treating heat rashes when mixed with kudzu powder. They also treat heat sores."

Yu Xi says: According to Meng Shen, dried jujubes are warm. They govern supplementing body fluids and strengthening the will. The kernels of three-year-old jujubes govern malign qi and sudden *zhu* (obstinate diseases) with adversity.

Furthermore, for treating deafness, nasal congestion, and loss of hearing or smell, take fifteen large jujubes, remove the skin and kernels, and three hundred castor beans, peeled. Pound these together, wrap in silk, and plug the ears and nose. Replace once daily for over thirty days to restore hearing and smell. Treat the ears first, then the nose; do not plug both simultaneously.

Another formula: Ten *badou* (croton seeds), shelled and used raw. Pound with pine resin, wrap in silk, and plug the ears.

It also states: Jujubes wash away pathogenic qi in the heart and abdomen, harmonize the toxicity of all medicines, unblock the nine orifices, and supplement insufficiency of qi. Overconsumption of fresh jujubes causes abdominal distension. Steamed or boiled, they tonify the intestines and stomach, fatten the center, and augment qi.

The finest jujubes come first from Qingzhou, then from Puzhou; those from other regions are unsuitable for medicinal use. For children suffering from autumn dysentery, feeding them *chongzao* (insect-infested jujubes) is effective.

*The Materia Medica of Diet Therapy* states: Jujubes combined with *guixin* (cassia heartwood), white melon seeds, and pine bark, formed into pills and taken long-term, impart fragrance to the body and even to one’s clothing.

Soft jujubes are warming. Overconsumption may stir wind, inducing cold-wind coughs.

*The Sagacious Benevolence Formulary*: To promote hair growth, take a three-foot-long jujube root from an eastward-growing tree, place it horizontally over a steamer, and collect the sweat that exudes from both ends. Apply this to the hair to encourage growth.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For painful hemorrhoid flare-ups, peel a plump jujube, take mercury in the palm, and grind it with saliva until thoroughly mixed. Spread this onto the jujube pulp and insert it into the anus for relief.

*Master Mei’s Formulas*: To treat sudden abdominal colic in the fourth or fifth month of pregnancy, burn fourteen jujubes until charred, grind into powder, and administer with urine.

*Extended Meanings* states: Of jujubes, those from Qingzhou and Puzhou are best for sun-drying and medicinal use, as they fortify the spleen and stomach. Others are merely suitable for consumption. The *yuzhao* (imperial jujube) is sweet, crisp, and delicate, ripening after other varieties. Due to its sweetness, it is prone to insect infestation—what is now called *pulosu* (crumbling crisp). There is also the *yazao* (tooth jujube), which ripens earliest, is sweet with a slight tang, and has a pointed, elongated shape. These two varieties are fit only for eating fresh, not for drying or storage.

Today, people remove the pits from dried jujubes, gently dry them over low heat in a wok, grind into powder, and mix with ginger powder in warm water to harmonize stomach qi. Jujube pulp, when boiled, is also excellent for blending into spleen and stomach tonic pills. Qingzhou jujubes, peeled, pitted, and baked into jujube rings, are transported to the capital as a rare delicacy.

---

**Chestnut**
Flavor: salty. Nature: warming. Non-toxic.
Effects: augments qi, fortifies the intestines and stomach, supplements kidney qi, and enhances endurance against hunger. Gathered in the ninth month from shady mountain slopes.

*The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica* states: Chestnuts were not previously recorded by region, only noted as growing on shady mountains. Now they are found everywhere, with those from Yanzhou and Xuanzhou being the finest. The tree closely resembles the oak, bearing greenish-yellow flowers like those of the walnut. The fruit grows in a spiny husk, clustered like a fist, containing three to five nuts; smaller varieties resemble peaches or apricots, holding only one or two nuts, which burst forth when ripe.

Chestnut varieties are numerous. The *Book of Songs* mentions *shen* and chestnuts. Lu Ji’s commentary notes: Chestnuts grow in all five directions, abundant in Zhou, Qin, Ji, Yang, and Xuan regions. In Wu and Yue, they flourish both within and beyond the city walls. However, only those from Puyang and Fanyang are sweet, rich, and long-lasting in flavor—others cannot compare. Among fruits, chestnuts are the most beneficial. For treating weak waist and legs, they should be eaten raw, lightly sun-dried to remove their woody essence. Those suffering from wind-water qi disorders should avoid them due to their salty flavor.

Boiling the husks and drinking the decoction checks counterflow stomach qi and wasting-thirst. The tree’s bark treats sores and toxins, frequently used in medicine.

*Shen* is pronounced *zhen*.

Tao Hongjing notes: Today, the most abundant chestnuts come from Kuaiji, though those from Zhuji are large with thick skins and inferior taste. Chestnuts from Shan and Shifeng have thin skins and are sweet. A tradition holds that a man with weak legs ate several sheng of chestnuts beneath a tree and was soon able to walk—this exemplifies their kidney-tonifying property. However, they should be eaten raw; if taken as a medicinal supplement, steaming and drying are appropriate.

*Ji* is pronounced *ji*.

*Shan* is pronounced *shí rǎn*.

The *Tang Materia Medica* notes: Chestnut flour surpasses that of water caltrop and gorgon fruit. Chewing raw chestnuts and applying them to sores treats severed or fractured sinews and bones, painful swellings, and stagnant blood—proven effective. Its skin, called *fu*, pounded into powder and mixed with honey, tightens and contracts flesh. The hairy husk treats erysipelas and toxic swellings. Feeding the nuts to children prevents teething. The tree’s white bark, boiled in water, counters *xi* poison.

*Duan* is pronounced *duàn*.

Ma Zhi comments: According to the *Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica from Shu*, the tree grows to two or three *zhang* tall, with leaves resembling oak. Its flowers are greenish-yellow, akin to walnut blossoms. The fruits range from fist-sized to as small as peaches or plums. There are also *ban* chestnuts and *jia* chestnuts, both large trees, as well as *mao* chestnuts, smaller and finer, though their leaves differ little from other varieties. They sprout in spring, bloom in summer, bear fruit in autumn, and wither in winter. They grow everywhere today.

Meng Shen states: Eating chestnuts raw strengthens the waist and legs. Steamed or roasted, they cause qi congestion—those with wind-water qi disorders should avoid them. The tree’s bark treats *dan* sores and toxins.

Caution: Chestnuts should be sun-dried at midday; when eaten, they descend qi and tonify. Otherwise, they retain their woody qi and fail to tonify. Among them, Wu chestnuts are large but tasteless, inferior to northern varieties. The thin inner skin, ground and mixed with honey, smooths facial wrinkles. The husk, boiled into a decoction, checks counterflow stomach qi and wasting-thirst. Raw chestnuts may be roasted in hot ashes until they sweat—eating them thus is beneficial. Must they not be thoroughly heated? Heat causes qi congestion, while raw chestnuts disperse qi. Hence, roasting tempers their woody qi.

The *Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies* states: *Dan* refers to virulent sores of shifting colors. Boiling the spiny husks of chestnuts and washing the sores is effective.

The *Tested Prescriptions* records: For kidney deficiency and weak legs, fill a bag with raw chestnuts and hang it to dry. Each morning at dawn, eat over ten nuts, followed by a porridge of pig’s kidney.

The *Extension of the Materia Medica* notes: To dry chestnuts, nothing surpasses sun-drying; to keep them fresh, nothing surpasses moist storage. Buried in sand, they remain as plump as when first harvested until late spring or early summer. Children should not eat them excessively—raw, they are hard to digest; cooked, they stagnate qi. Eating them at the wrong time breeds worms, often causing childhood *gan* disease unnoticed. The so-called kidney-tonifying effect stems from their salty flavor, which also stagnates qi. In Hubei, there is a variety with rounded tops and pointed ends, called *xuan* chestnuts.

The *Illustrated Classic* cites the *Book of Songs* on *shen* and chestnuts, referring to their resemblance in form.

---

**Grapes**
Flavor: sweet
Nature: neutral
Non-toxic
Governs damp impediment of sinews and bones, augments qi, doubles strength, fortifies will, renders one stout and healthy, enduring hunger, resistant to wind and cold. Long-term consumption lightens the body, prevents aging, and prolongs years. Can be made into wine. Promotes water metabolism and disinhibits urination.

Grows in the mountain valleys of Longxi, Wuyuan, and Dunhuang.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: Grapes grow in the mountain valleys of Longxi, Wuyuan, and Dunhuang. Today, they are found in Hedong and near the capital’s prefectures. Their vines spread extensively, with vigorous growth—one or two plants can cover entire valleys. Their flowers are minute and yellowish-white. The fruits come in purple and white, with round or pointed shapes, and some are seedless. All ripen in the seventh and eighth months. Their juice can be fermented into wine.

I note: The *Records of the Grand Historian* states that Dayuan made wine from grapes. The wealthy stored up to ten thousand *shi*, and aged wine lasted over a decade without spoiling. Zhang Qian, sent to the Western Regions, brought back their seeds, and thus China first acquired them. They are the most prized of northern fruits.

The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: Grapes, as a sovereign remedy, taste sweet and sour. They dispel water qi from the intestines, harmonize the center, treat strangury, and disinhibit urination.

Tao Hongjing remarks: Envoys from Wei often brought them—they resemble *wuweizi* but are sweet and delicious. Wine made from their vine sap is exceptionally fine. Northerners are often robust and cold-resistant, perhaps due to this fruit. They do not grow south of the Huai River, much like how oranges transform north of the Yellow River. Some claim they are the same as the local *yingyu*, though their roots may resemble oranges.

The *Tang Materia Medica* notes: *Yingyu* resembles grapes, but it is a thousand-year-old vine. The method for making grape wine involves fermenting the juice of the whole fruit. *Yingyu* and mountain grapes are also suitable for winemaking. Tao’s claim that vine sap makes wine is erroneous.

*Ying* is pronounced *yú gēng*.
*Yu* is pronounced *yú liù*.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: Grapes were first brought by envoys from Western Xia when they presented lions as tribute. The emissaries also carried grapes as gifts to the prefectures, and those grown in China were all similar. They are most difficult to dry; if not dried, they cannot be stored and will turn sour and inedible. These are the grapes referred to in Li Bai’s verse about Hu people annually presenting grape wine. Eating them causes unexpressed sores and rashes to surface. Overconsumption dulls the eyes.

The grapes from Persia are exceptionally large, some as big as chicken eggs.

**Gorgon fruit** (*Euryale ferox*) is sweet in flavor, balanced in nature, and non-toxic. It treats damp impediment, pain in the lower back, spine, and knees, fortifies the center to dispel sudden illnesses, augments essence and qi, strengthens resolve, and sharpens hearing and vision. With prolonged consumption, it lightens the body, prevents hunger, and confers longevity akin to an immortal. It is also called *yanhuishi* or *qian*. It grows in the marshes of Lei Ze. Harvested in the eighth month. *Qian* is pronounced *jiǎn*.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Gorgon fruit grows in Lei Ze, and today it is found everywhere in watery marshes. Its leaves are as large as lotus leaves, wrinkled and thorny, commonly called *jitoupan* ("chicken-head plate"). The flower produces a fruit resembling a chicken’s head, hence the name. The tender stems, called *weijie*, are gathered as vegetables. The fruit is harvested in the eighth month. Those who consume it for longevity take both the fruit and its seeds, pound them into a paste, dry it in the sun, sift it, and mix it with a decoction of *jinyingzi* to form pills. This is said to fortify the lower body and is called the "Elixir of Water and Land." Classical texts refer to its seeds as *qian*. Tao Hongjing notes: This is the modern *weizi*, whose flower resembles a cockscomb, hence the name *jitou* ("chicken head"). Daoist recipes combine it with lotus seeds for consumption, claiming it prevents children from growing—though this is extreme. Eating it still benefits one. *Wei* is pronounced *wěi*.

*The Tang Materia Medica* annotates: When the fruit’s skin is removed and made into powder, it resembles water caltrop starch and is more nourishing than water caltrop. *Ling* (water caltrop) is pronounced *líng*.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: Gorgon fruit stimulates the appetite and aids qi. Its roots can be eaten as a vegetable.

*The Master of Huainan* says: Gorgon fruit cures neck sores; recluses call it *yantou* ("wild-goose head").

Zhang Yuxi notes: According to *The Illustrated Classic of Shu*, it grows in water, with leaves as large as lotus leaves, wrinkled and thorny. Its flowers and fruit are fist-sized, shaped like a chicken’s head. The fruit resembles a pomegranate, with a greenish-black skin and white flesh like water caltrop kernels.

Meng Shen says: Gorgon fruit made into powder is excellent to eat. It is a longevity elixir; when fed to children, it prevents them from growing taller, thus preserving youth. Eating it raw stirs wind and cold qi, but steaming it and drying it in the sun causes the skin to split. It can also be pounded into powder.

Chen Shiliang notes: Though this plant grows in water, it has a soft root called *jiecai*, which treats pain from bound qi in the lower abdomen and is suitable for consumption.

*Tested Prescriptions* records: To augment essence and qi, strengthen resolve, and sharpen hearing and vision, take three *ge* of gorgon fruit, boil until soft, remove the shells, and grind into a paste. Add one *ge* of polished rice and cook into a congee to be eaten on an empty stomach.

*The Extension of the Materia Medica* states: Gorgon fruit is found throughout the realm today. People along the lakes and marshes of Hebei gather it, pound off the skin, grind it into powder, steam it, and press it into cakes to substitute for grain. However, eating too much harms the spleen and stomach qi and is difficult to digest.

**Raspberry** (*Rubus chingii*) is sour and salty in flavor, balanced in nature, and non-toxic. It stabilizes the five viscera, augments essence and qi, lengthens and firms the yin, strengthens resolve and doubles strength, and promotes fertility. It also treats sudden wind stroke and high fever with great fright. Prolonged consumption lightens the body and prevents aging. It is also called *fupen*, *linglei*, or *yinlei*. It grows in the plains and marshes of Mount Xing and Yuanju. *Lei* is pronounced *lěi*.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Pengluan* is the stem and vine of *fupen* (raspberry). It grows in the plains and marshes of Mount Xing and Yuanju. *Fupenzi* (raspberry fruit) was previously unrecorded as to its native regions, but today it is found everywhere, especially in Qin and Wu. The plant is short, no taller than a *chi*, with thorny stems and leaves. Its flowers are white, and its fruit is reddish-yellow, about half the size of a pellet, with a stem beneath resembling a persimmon calyx. Children often eat its fruit. The stems and leaves are harvested in the fifth month; the leaves can be gathered at any time. In Jiangnan, it is called *mei*, though it grows later there, with shoots appearing in the third month, flowers in the eighth or ninth month, and fruit ripening in the tenth month. Its effects are the same, and it is frequently used in ancient formulas. Its fruit is pressed to extract juice, which is mixed into ointments to prevent graying hair. Its leaves are rubbed to extract juice, which is dripped into the eyes to remove redness and expel thread-like worms—an effective remedy.

Tao Hongjing remarks: Li says it is the *mei* people eat. The present annotation identifies it as the stem and vine of *fupen*. Tao called *pengluan* a root name, the same one Chang Rong used to preserve her complexion. The root and stem are closely related. Li says it is *mei*. According to *The Cutting Rhymes*, *mei* is the *fupen* plant. *Lei* means vine; thus, *pengluan* clearly refers to its creeping vines.

*The Tang Materia Medica* annotates: *Pengluan* and *fupen* are the same thing with different names, referring to the fruit rather than the root—this is also mistaken. It is like *shuqi* and *changshan* being distinct plants, or *xiongqiong* and *miwu* having separate uses. Here, it is appended to the fruit section because its fruit is *fupenzi*. *Mei* is pronounced *mào*.

Chen Cangqi states: It reverses graying and prevents aging. The Buddha spoke of the *sumina* flower used to light lamps—this is that flower. Its juice is taken to make ointments that prevent graying hair. Eating its fruit improves complexion. Its leaves are rubbed to extract juice, which is dripped into the eyes to remove redness and expel thread-like worms. There are three varieties: the one that ripens in the fourth month, sweet and delicious like *fupenzi*, is medicinal; the others are unsuitable. Today, people mistake *maomei* (bramble) for *fupen*.

Zhang Yuxi states: According to Chen Shiliang, all materia medica texts claim it is the root of *fupenzi*. Yet observing those who gather it, the plant described in the *Grasses and Trees* section is *pengluan*, resembling *canmei* fruit, red in color. Its leaves resemble wild roses, bearing thorns, and its taste is sour and sweet. I fear earlier scholars, not recognizing it, mistakenly called it *fupen*.

The *Yanyi* states: *Pengluan* is not *fupenzi*—it is a distinct species. Though withered, its branches and stems do not scatter. Nowadays, people no longer use it; this is what Jia Shan referred to in his memorial.

*Fupenzi* is sweet in flavor, neutral, and non-toxic. It primarily boosts qi, lightens the body, and prevents graying hair. Harvested in the fifth month.

The *Illustrated Classic* states: Details are provided under the *pengluan* entry.

The *Drug Properties Treatise* states: *Fupenzi*, a ministerial herb, is slightly warm, sweet, and pungent. It treats depletion of kidney essence in men and promotes fertility in women. It addresses impotence and strengthens the yang, making it firm and enduring.

Tao Hongjing states: *Pengluan* is the name of the root, unused by physicians—it is what Chang Rong consumed to preserve her youth. *Fupen* is the name of the fruit. Li Shizhen says it is *mei*; today’s *meizi* resembles *fupen* in shape but derives its flavor from its juice, with slightly finer pits. The *fupenzi* used in medicine differs slightly. It remains unclear which is correct.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: *Fupen* and *pengluan* are different names for the same thing, referring to the fruit, not the root. Li’s identification as *meizi* is close. The root is not used medicinally. However, the growing conditions differ: in fertile soil, the fruit is large and sweet; in barren soil, it is small and sour. Thus, the fruit may be sweet or sour, while the root has no sour taste. Tao Hongjing mistakenly took the root as sour and the fruit as sweet, then listed the root under fruits and redundantly included the fruit as a separate entry—this was careless. Now annotated: *Pengluan* is the seedling of *fupen*, while *fupen* is the fruit of *pengluan*. Tao’s and the Tang annotations do not reflect this. Today, *fupenzi* is used to replenish depletion, restore vitality, strengthen the yang, enhance complexion, harmonize the viscera, warm the center, boost strength, treat consumptive wind-depletion, tonify the liver, and improve vision.

The *Ri Huazi Materia Medica* states: *Meizi* harmonizes the five viscera, enhances complexion, nourishes essence and qi, promotes hair growth, strengthens resolve, and treats wind-stroke with fever and fright.

There is also *shumei* (tree raspberry), which is *fupenzi*. Meng Shen says: *Fupenzi* is sour in taste; the best is found in wheat fields in the fifth month. Harvest and dry it under intense sun—if left to rot, it becomes unusable. It also grows in Jiangdong, where it is called *xuangouzi*. Though differing in size and shape, their qi, flavor, and effects are the same. The northern lands lack *xuangouzi*, while the southern regions lack *fupen*—this is due to regional variations in growth timing, not two distinct species.

The *Extended Materia Medica* states: *Fupenzi* grows in long vines and ripens red in the fourth or fifth month. It is abundant in Qinzhou, and also found in Yongxing and Huazhou. When in season, mountain folk gather and sell it. Its taste is sweet-sour, resembling lychee in appearance, about the size of a cherry, soft and red—delightful to behold. If not harvested in time, it rots on the branch and becomes infested with maggots. It benefits the kidneys, reduces urine, and when consumed, one should cover the chamber pot—hence its name. Eating too much generates heat. Harvest when five or six parts ripe, then dry in strong sun while covering with thin silk to prevent spoilage. Today, its juice is boiled into a preserve with a little honey, or simmered into a thin decoction for sipping, to treat lung deficiency with cold. If water touches it during harvest, it cannot be boiled into a preserve.

The cherry is sweet in flavor. It regulates the center, fortifies spleen qi, enhances complexion, and uplifts the spirit. Tao Hongjing says: This refers to today’s red cherry, which is sweet and sour, edible, and its effects resemble those of the earlier-mentioned cherry. Physicians may have indiscriminately included it, though it may not be the same as the present variety.

Additionally, *hutuizi* (silverberry) does not wither in winter, and its fruit should also benefit people.

Some say that those with cold-heat disorders should not consume it. The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: Pound the leaves to apply for snake venom. Drink the expressed leaf juice to prevent snake venom from attacking internally. *Ri Hua Zi* states: Cherry has slight toxicity; eating too much induces vomiting. Yu Xi comments: According to Meng Shen, cherry is warming. It boosts qi, and eating much of it causes no harm. It is also said: This is called *ying* (cherry), not a peach. It should not be eaten in excess, as it may provoke latent wind. The eastern root treats inch-white and roundworms. *Extended Meanings* states: Meng Shen considers cherry not of the peach kind. Yet if not of the peach kind, it is called cherry precisely because its form resembles the peach—what doubt could there be? It is like *muhouli* (actinidia) or walnut, where the name is taken from resemblance. In antiquity it was called *hantao* (cherry-in-bud), suitable for offering in ancestral temples, as the *Rites* says: "First offered in the temple chambers" refers to this. Wang Wei’s Tang poem reads: *"Only after spring offerings in the temple garden / Not from the imperial park where crows peck the remnants."* When children eat it, even a slight excess invariably generates heat. Water caltrop fruit.

Sweet in flavor, balanced, non-toxic. It harmonizes the center, supplements the five viscera, prevents hunger, and lightens the body. Another name is *ling*. *Ji* is pronounced *ji*.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Ji* is the fruit of the water caltrop. Formerly, its native regions were not recorded, but now it is found everywhere. Its leaves float upon the water; its flowers are yellow-white. After the flowers fall, the fruit forms, gradually ripening beneath the water. There are two kinds of fruit: one with four horns, the other with two. Among the two-horned variety, some have tender skins of purple hue, called *fuling*; these are especially delicious when eaten. In the Jiang-Huai region and Shandong, people dry the fruit to make a grain that can serve as staple food.

Tao Yinju says: In Lujiang, it is most abundant, and all are roasted over fire to make grain for sustenance. Nowadays, they are often steamed and dried, then mixed with honey to form cakes, enabling one to abstain from grains and attain longevity.

Among aquatic plants, there is also *gu shou*, which is cold in nature and likely not of the highest grade. Eating it after frost causes impotence. It must not be eaten with white honey, as this generates parasites. *Gu* is pronounced *gu*.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: Water caltrop starch is extremely white and moistening, beneficial to humans. Meng Shen says: Immortals steam water caltrop to make flour, mix it with honey, and eat it to cease reliance on grains. Among aquatic plants, this one is least capable of treating illness. It is also said to chill the viscera, harm yang qi, and cause flaccidity of the penis. It should be eaten sparingly. Overconsumption causes abdominal distension and fullness, which can be relieved by drinking one or two cups of warm wine mixed with ginger. *Dietary Therapy* states: Daoist immortals use it, but it generates cold qi. Holding *wuzhuyu* in the mouth and swallowing its saliva will dispel abdominal distension.

*Extended Meanings* says: *Ji* is now commonly called *lingjiao* and is found everywhere. When boiled and eaten, it can replace grain but does not benefit the spleen. There is also *shuiling*, another type of water caltrop, larger and crisp, suitable for raw consumption. Its medicinal applications in compound formulas remain unrecorded. Eating too much raw water caltrop causes diarrhea and indigestion, for its nature is cold.

**Orange peel**
Bitter and pungent in flavor, warm in nature. When made into sauces or vinegar, it is fragrant and delicious.

Dispels malign qi from the intestines and stomach, aids digestion, and removes floating wind-qi from the stomach. Its pulp, sour in flavor, eliminates nausea, but should not be eaten in excess, as it harms the liver’s qi. Alternatively, wash the pulp to remove its sour juice, finely chop it, and simmer with salt and honey to make a preserve; consuming this dispels floating wind in the stomach. Its tree resembles the mandarin tree but with larger leaves; its shape is round, larger than a mandarin, and fragrant. The peel is thick and wrinkled. It ripens in the eighth month.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Details are provided under the entry for mandarins and pomelos.

Ma Yuxi says: According to Chen Shiliang, the orange is warming and non-toxic. It circulates wind-qi, induces deficient heat, treats goiter, disperses scrofula, and neutralizes fish and insect poisons. It should not be eaten with areca nut, as this causes dizziness and nausea.

*Food Mirror* states: It is warming. Eliminates nausea and stomach wind. Store its peel with salt. Also, the pulp dispels malign qi. Chew it finely with salt and honey.

Master Lei says: It is bitter and pungent in flavor, non-toxic.

*Extended Meanings* says: Orange peel is now used only as a fruit, or its peel is taken to make tea for guests, but it is not seen in medicinal formulas. If one has lingering drunkenness, eating it will quickly restore sobriety. [Entry from the] middle rank of the fruit section.

Plum fruit is sour in flavor, neutral, and non-toxic. It governs the descent of qi, dispels heat and vexing fullness, pacifies the heart, relieves pain in the limbs, treats hemiplegia and numbness, dead flesh, removes green-black moles, malignant sores, checks dysentery, stops excessive salivation, and relieves dry mouth. It grows in the river valleys of Hanzhong. Harvest in the fifth month and dry over fire.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Plum fruit grows in the river valleys of Hanzhong; today, it is also found in Xiang-Han, Sichuan, the Jiang-Huai region, and the Ling Mountains. Consuming fresh plum fruit is sour and harms the teeth, injures the bones, and induces deficient heat; it should not be eaten in excess, and those taking *huangjing* (Polygonatum) should especially avoid it. A decoction of its leaves, taken in concentrated form, cures chronic dysentery. The root treats wind impediment, but those exposed above ground should not be used. In the fifth month, gather the yellow fruit and smoke-dry it to make *wumei* (dark plums). It governs febrile diseases with vexing heat and cholera with agitation and thirst. It is frequently used in formulas for consumptive emaciation, postpartum qi dysentery, and the like.

Tao Hongjing says: This is what is now called *wumei*; when using it, remove the pit and lightly roast it. For febrile diseases with vexing heat, soak in water and drink the juice. Fresh plum and *baimei* (white plums) likely have similar effects. Today, people often use *baimei* in medicinal preparations to apply to moles and erode malign flesh. Those taking *huangjing* are said to be forbidden from eating plum fruit.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: *Miscellaneous Records* states: Plum root treats wind impediment, but those exposed above ground are lethal. Plum fruit benefits the sinews and vessels and dispels impediment.

Chen Cangqi says: The primary function of plum fruit is to quench thirst, but it causes heat above the diaphragm. *Wumei* dispels phlegm, governs miasmic malaria, stops thirst, harmonizes the center, eliminates cold and heat dysentery, and checks counterflow vomiting. Pounded plum leaves, boiled into a thick decoction, make clothes easier to wash. Songyangzi says: Kneading plum leaves in clear water to wash banana-fiber clothing prevents brittleness. I have tested this and found it effective.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: Plum fruit is warming. It stops thirst. Excessive phlegm harms the bones, erodes the spleen and stomach, and induces heat.
