Boiled into a paste, it treats white scalp ringworm. It also governs thirty-six types of wind-related sores: boil a potful, strain, add three *liang* of beeswax, and simmer into a paste. Apply to sores or consume.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: Purslane’s native regions were previously unrecorded, but it now grows everywhere. Though named among the *xian* (amaranth) family, its stems and leaves bear no resemblance to cultivated amaranth. It is also called "Five Phases Herb" due to its green leaves, red stems, yellow flowers, white roots, and black seeds. Two varieties exist: the large-leaved type is inferior, while the small-leaved type is superior. It is said that mercury resides between its nodes and leaves; when dried, ten pounds yield eight to ten *liang* of mercury. However, it is extremely difficult to dry. Crush with a wooden mallet, arrange facing east, and sun-dry for two to three days to achieve dryness—otherwise, it may take years. For medicinal use, remove stems and nodes. Generally, it thickens the intestines and reduces appetite.

Chen Cangqi notes: It breaks abdominal masses and stops wasting-thirst. It also treats equine malignant sores and parasites. This plant is remarkably resilient; even after drying, it revives when placed on soil.

Meng Shen states: Purslane also treats equine toxic sores. Boil in water and administer one *sheng*; apply the decoction topically as well. For damp *xuan*-lichen and white bald patches, mix purslane ointment with ashes and apply—highly effective. It treats *gan*-dysentery, eliminates all wind, and is excellent for dressing staff wounds. Boil a bowl with salt and vinegar, consume on an empty stomach, and after a short while, all white worms will be expelled.

*The Dietary Therapy* records: It prolongs life, enhances longevity, and brightens the eyes. For damp *xuan*-lichen and white bald patches, apply purslane ointment. Burning it to ashes and applying the powder is also effective. To prepare the ointment for thirty-six types of wind, take one *shi* of purslane, two *shi* of water, and three *liang* of beeswax; simmer into an ointment. It also treats *gan*-dysentery and all wind. Finely chop and boil into congee to stop dysentery and relieve abdominal pain.

*The Sagely Benefit Formulas*: For horse bites with toxin entering the heart, consume purslane decoction to resolve it. Another formula: For *fan-hua* sores, burn one *jin* of purslane into ashes, grind finely, mix with lard, and apply.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For scrofula, dry purslane in the shade, burn to ashes, and mix with lard from the twelfth lunar month. Wash the sores with warm water used to rinse rice, dry thoroughly, and apply the ointment for three days.

*The Thousand Gold Formulas*: For all types of armpit odor, pound purslane, mix with honey into balls, wrap in paper, and coat the paper with half an inch of mud. Dry in the sun, then roast until cooked. Break open, mix with a small amount of honey while still warm, first rub the armpits with rough cloth, then apply the medicine under the arms, enduring the intense pain. Bind the arms tightly with a handkerchief to cure.

*The Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies*: For *wandou* sores, burn purslane to ashes and apply to the sores; the roots will emerge with the medicine shortly. If not, reapply—highly effective.

*The Heart Mirror of Food and Medicine* states: It regulates *jiao*-qi, facial and head swelling, abdominal distension and fullness, and scanty, difficult urination. Cook purslane with a small amount of polished rice and soy sauce broth and consume. Another formula: For children’s bloody dysentery, extract one *ge* of juice from fresh purslane, mix with one spoonful of honey, and drink on an empty stomach.

*The Treasured Formulas for Childbirth*: For postpartum bloody dysentery, urinary retention, and umbilical and abdominal pain, pound three *ge* of juice from fresh purslane, simmer briefly, add one *ge* of honey, stir, and consume.

*Extended Meanings* notes: Purslane is often consumed, yet its nature is cold and slippery. This has already been mentioned under the *qingdai* entry.

Garlic has a pungent taste, is warm in nature, and is toxic. It disperses abscesses and swellings, treats sores, expels wind evil, and eliminates toxic *qi*. Single-cloved garlic is also excellent. It enters the five viscera.

Prolonged consumption harms one’s health and impairs vision. Harvest on the fifth day of the fifth month.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *Hu* is the great garlic. Its native regions were not recorded in earlier texts, but now it is found everywhere, cultivated in household gardens. Each head has six or seven cloves; when a single clove is planted, it grows into single-cloved garlic in the first year, and by the following year, it reverts to its original form. The flowers also bear seeds, resembling tiny garlic cloves, which may likewise be planted. Harvest on the fifth day of the fifth month.

According to the *Divine Farmer’s Classic*, it "disperses abscesses and swellings." Li Jiang’s *Handbook of the Ministry of War* prescribes for toxic sores and swellings with incessant wailing and inability to lie down, where the condition is unrecognizable: take two bulbs of single-cloved garlic, pound finely, mix with sesame oil, and apply thickly to the sore, replacing when dry.

Tao Hongjing notes: "Nowadays, people call *hu* ‘great garlic’ and *suan* ‘lesser garlic,’ as their *qi* are similar. Its nature is intensely pungent and foul-smelling, unfit for consumption. Common folk make it into a relish to eat with raw fish—does this not harm one’s nature and shorten one’s life? This herb is only suitable for raw consumption; it should not be cooked. Eating it with fermented green fish causes jaundice. When its stem’s seeds are planted, they first grow into single-cloved garlic, and the following year, they revert to their original form."

*Ri Hua Zi* states: Garlic fortifies the spleen, regulates kidney *qi*, arrests cholera with vomiting and diarrhea, relieves abdominal pain, dispels pathogenic influences, repels epidemics, counteracts *gu* toxins, treats consumptive malaria, cold wind, *xuanpi* (abdominal masses), epidemic *qi*, and when applied as a poultice, it alleviates wind-cold pain, snake and insect bites, malignant sores, scabies, *xi* toxins, and sand lice. Soaking it in mature vinegar for a year enhances its efficacy.

Meng Shen notes: "Prolonged consumption of garlic damages the eyes and harms the liver." For snakebite sores, take one *sheng* of peeled garlic, pound it, boil with one *sheng* of urine for three or four simmers, then soak the affected area from dawn to dusk. If bitten before swelling occurs, chew garlic and apply it immediately, replacing six or seven times. Alternatively, boil one *sheng* of peeled garlic with two *sheng* of milk until soft, consume on an empty stomach, then eat rice afterward. The next day, repeat the process to expel all cold toxins and wind *qi*. For those afflicted by demonic *qi*, take one single-cloved garlic bulb, grind with realgar and apricot kernels into pills, and swallow three on an empty stomach. Sit quietly for a while; the patient will sweat, and the condition will resolve.

*The Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For toothache, roast single-cloved garlic until hot, cut it, and apply the hot end to the painful area, replacing as needed. It also treats worm-induced pain. Another formula: For blockage and fullness with inability to pass urine or stool, roast single-cloved garlic until hot, remove the skin, wrap in silk, and insert into the lower orifice; *qi* will immediately flow.

*The Thousand Golden Remedies*: For sudden dysentery, pound garlic and apply to the soles of the feet. Another formula: For counterflow *qi* with heart vexation and heart pain, pound raw garlic to extract juice and consume two *sheng* to resolve the condition.

*Master Mei’s Formulas*: For abdominal fullness where oral medication cannot be taken, roast a single-cloved garlic bulb until cooked, remove the skin, wrap in silk, and insert into the lower orifice, replacing when cold. Another formula: For centipede bites with unrelenting pain, rub the stung area with single-cloved garlic to stop the pain. Another formula: For snake or viper bites, pound single-cloved garlic and sour grass, then apply to the bite.

*The Concise and Effective Formulas for the Multitudes*: For unstoppable nosebleed unresponsive to medication, take one garlic bulb, remove the skin, grind into a paste, and spread a coin-sized cake about the thickness of a bean. For bleeding from the left nostril, apply to the left sole; for the right nostril, apply to the right sole; if both nostrils bleed, apply to both soles. Once the bleeding stops, promptly wash the soles with warm water.

*The Extended Meanings* states: *Hu* is great garlic, its *qi* extremely pungent. Yet when placed among foul meat, it masks the stench. For those poisoned by summerheat, chew three or four cloves thoroughly and swallow with warm water to recover. Cold water must be avoided.

For sudden bloody flux, take five to seven garlic bulbs, remove the stems and skins, mix with fermented black soybeans in proportion, and pound into a paste. If it can be formed into pills, make them the size of firmiana seeds, and take fifty to sixty pills with rice water—none will fail to recover. For nosebleed, thoroughly mash one clove and apply to the soles of both feet; remove immediately once the bleeding stops. For purple-skinned garlic, slice horizontally into pieces about one *fen* thick. When sores first appear on the back or flanks before distinguishing between *yong* (yang abscess) and *ju* (yin abscess): if yang stagnates in yin, it becomes *yong*; if yin stagnates in yang, it becomes *ju*. *Yong* presents with smooth, red skin, while *ju* shows wrinkled, dull skin. In both cases, cover the sore with a garlic slice and apply moxibustion. If already painful, moxa until pain ceases; if painless, moxa until pain begins. At the first sign, apply moxibustion—none will fail to respond. Carefully assess the center of the sore and apply garlic for moxibustion there. People often overlook such sores at first, seeing them as small and refusing moxibustion—what a pity!

Garlic (small garlic) is pungent in flavor, warm in nature, and slightly toxic. It enters the spleen and kidney channels. It treats cholera with abdominal discomfort, aids digestion, regulates the stomach, warms the center, and dispels pathogenic *qi* and toxins. Harvest on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month.

*The Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica* states: Garlic is small garlic. Its place of origin was not recorded in older texts, but it is now found everywhere. It grows in the wild, with roots and leaves resembling *hu* (great garlic) but much smaller. Harvest on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month.

According to *Erya*: *Yi* is mountain garlic. The commentary explains: *Shuowen* defines garlic as a pungent vegetable. Another source says: "The finest vegetables come from Yunmeng, and their pungent variety is called *xun*." That which grows in the mountains is called *yi*. In the *Divine Farmer’s Classic of Materia Medica*, great garlic is called *hu*, and small garlic is called *suan*. However, the garlic and pungent vegetable mentioned in *Erya* and *Shuowen* refer to today’s great garlic, while *yi* refers to today’s small garlic. Such discrepancies in nomenclature across texts and traditions mean one must exercise caution when using medicinal substances.

*Yi* is pronounced *lide*. *Ri Hua Zi* states: Small garlic is hot and toxic. It descends *qi*, stops cholera with vomiting and diarrhea, aids digestion, treats *gu* poison, and can be applied topically for snakebites, insect stings, and sandfly sores. It should not be consumed in the third lunar month. Meng Shen says: Small garlic is also excellent for treating various poisons and clove sores. It should not be eaten regularly. *Dietary Therapy* states: It treats cholera, aids digestion, warms the stomach, dispels pathogenic *qi*, and is best harvested on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month. It also expels various poisons, clove sores, and toxic sores. It should not be eaten regularly.

*The Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies* states: For cholera with abdominal distension and fullness before vomiting or diarrhea occurs, chop one *sheng* of small garlic, boil in three *sheng* of water until reduced to one *sheng*, and take in one dose. *The Military Ministry’s Handbook* #8: For malaria, take any amount of garlic, grind to a fine paste, mix with a small amount of yellow lead until it forms a mass, and shape into pills the size of chicken’s heads. Once dry, take one pill with freshly drawn water, facing east—highly effective.

*The Extended Meanings* states: Garlic is small garlic, also called *yi*. Its leaves resemble onion needles, its roots are white, and the larger ones resemble water chestnuts. Both the seeds and roots can be boiled and eaten. It is also called *zhai suan* (house garlic). Hua Tuo used garlic relish, which refers to this plant.

Eggplant is sweet in flavor and cold in nature. Those with chronic cold should not consume it in excess, as it harms the body, agitates *qi*, and may trigger sores or chronic illnesses. Another name is *luosu*. It is found everywhere. The roots and withered stems and leaves treat frostbite sores; boil them into a decoction for soaking—highly effective. Bitter eggplant is a small, thorny shrub. Its fruit, ground with vinegar, treats abscesses and swelling. The root can also be used in bath decoctions. It grows in Lingnan.

*Dietary Therapy* states: It is neutral in nature and treats alternating chills and fever, as well as taxation of the five viscera. It should not be eaten in excess, as it agitates *qi* and may trigger chronic illnesses. When cooked, a small amount may be consumed without concern. Those with cold conditions should avoid it, as it may trigger chronic illnesses. The root also treats frostbite sores; boil it into a decoction for soaking.

*The Victorious Gold Formula* states: For traumatic injuries with bruising and swelling, select eggplants grown from seeds left on the plant until fully yellow and large, slice them into pieces one finger thick, dry on a new tile over a fire, and grind into powder. Before bed, mix three *qian* with wine and consume—by morning, the swelling will be completely resolved without a trace.

*The Divine Garden Formula* states: For chronic intestinal wind with unceasing bloody stool, burn eggplant calyxes to ash, retain their nature, and grind into powder. Take three *qian* with rice water before meals.

*The Extended Meanings* states: A variety of eggplant from Silla is pale, slightly purple, with long calyxes and a sweet taste. Its seeds have now spread to vegetable gardens across China. However, this variety is of no benefit and has no therapeutic use—it only harms people. Though later texts describe methods for its use, they ultimately contradict the *Divine Farmer’s Classic of Materia Medica*. Gardeners cultivate it in warm places, heavily fertilizing the soil, and sell it at high prices around the time of Grain in Ear. Since it is not harvested in season, it harms people even more. "Do not eat what is not in season"—how can one be careless about this?

Wild celery seeds are sweet and pungent in flavor, warm in nature, and non-toxic. They treat abdominal distension and fullness, descend *qi*, and aid digestion. Used as a seasoning, they are fragrant like tangerine peel but without bitterness.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: It grows near water and marshes. Its seedlings resemble *guizhen* (beggar’s ticks) and *tiemai* (spinach), its flowers are greenish-white, and its seeds are yellow-black, resembling *fangfeng* seeds. First appended in the Tang *Materia Medica*.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: Young wild celery can be eaten. Its seeds treat sudden heart pain; when stir-fried and consumed, they induce sleep.

Yu Xi notes: According to *The Illustrated Classic of the Shu Materia Medica*, its flowers resemble celery, and its seeds resemble *fangfeng* seeds but are flatter and larger. *Erya* states: *Jiao* is *niuqin*.

Here follows the translation:

---

It is explained: resembling celery, it is an edible vegetable. Its leaves are fine and pointed. It has alternate names: *jiao*, *niuqin*, and *maqin*. Its seeds are used medicinally.

Meng Shen states: when eaten with fermented soybean paste, it enhances all flavors. The root and leaves are inedible. For sudden heart pain, grind the seeds into powder and take with vinegar to cure.

**Yunjiang (Chinese Mustard)**
Flavor: pungent. Nature: warm. Non-toxic.
It treats wandering wind and cinnabar swelling, as well as breast abscesses.

*Ri Hua Zi* states: *yuntai* (mustard greens) is cooling. It treats postpartum blood wind and static blood. Those with body odor should not consume it.

The *Alternative Edition* notes: it breaks up abdominal masses and congealed blood. Modern folk remedies prescribe *yuntai* for blood disorders.

Yu Xi notes: According to Meng Shen, those with preexisting lumbar or leg ailments should not consume it excessively, as it will exacerbate the condition. Furthermore, it severely depletes *yang qi*, induces mouth sores, and causes toothache. It may also generate intestinal parasites.

*Extended Meanings* states: *yuntai* is not particularly fragrant. Its roots survive winter and repel bookworms. Among vegetables, it is not especially prized.

**Boling (Spinach)**
Nature: cold, slightly toxic.
It benefits the five viscera, unblocks the intestines and stomach, clears heat, and resolves alcohol toxicity. It is beneficial for those consuming elixirs of cinnabar and mineral stones. Northerners who eat meat and wheat find it neutral, while southerners who consume fish, shellfish, and rice find it cooling. It should not be eaten in excess, as it cools the large and small intestines. Prolonged consumption weakens the legs, rendering one unable to walk, and may induce lumbar pain. It should not be eaten with eel, as this combination causes cholera with vomiting and diarrhea.

Liu Yuxi’s *Record of Auspicious Conversations* states: spinach originally came from the Western Regions. Its seeds were brought back, like alfalfa and grapes, by Zhang Qian. It was originally brought from the kingdom of Poling, though the name became corrupted over time, and many are now unaware of this.

**Hucong (Shallot)**
Flavor: pungent. It warms the center, promotes digestion, descends *qi*, and kills parasites. Prolonged consumption harms the spirit and nature, induces forgetfulness, impairs vision, and exacerbates chronic illnesses. Those with body odor should not consume it, as it worsens the condition. Its appearance resembles garlic but is smaller, with a round shape, reddish skin, and a slightly elongated, pointed form. It grows in the mountain valleys of Shu Commandery. Harvest in the fifth and sixth months.

*The Dietary Therapy* states: shallots are neutral. They aid digestion and stimulate appetite. Prolonged consumption induces forgetfulness. The root exacerbates chronic illnesses. Furthermore, if one consumes poisonous meat and suffers incessant vomiting of blood leading to severe emaciation and jaundice, take one *sheng* of seeds, wash and boil until they burst, then strain the liquid and let it cool. Drink half a *sheng* in the morning and evening; the bleeding will cease. Those with body odor or dental caries should not consume it, as it will worsen the condition.

Caution: while it benefits the five viscera and supplements insufficient *qi*, it also damages and severs the *qi* of the blood vessels. Excessive consumption harms the spirit; it is merely a pungent vegetable.

**Chun (Water Shield)**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: cold. Non-toxic.
It treats wasting-thirst and heat impediment.

Tao Hongjing states: water shield is cold, or some say cooling. It supplements, descends *qi*, and when made into a soup with carp, also dispels water. However, its slippery nature means those practicing *yangsheng* should not consume it excessively.

*The Tang Materia Medica* notes: prolonged consumption of water shield is highly beneficial. When made into a soup with crucian carp, it effectively treats those with weak stomach *qi* who cannot eat.

It is most suitable for the elderly and should be classified as an upper-grade medicinal. From the third to the eighth month, it is called *sichun* (silk water shield), with a sweet taste and soft texture. From after the Frost Descent to the twelfth month, it is called *guichun* (jewel water shield), with a bitter taste and astringent texture. It is gathered to make soup.

*The Book of Jin* states: Zhang Han, whenever autumn winds arose, would yearn for perch and water shield soup to descend *qi*.

**Shuiqin (Water Celery)**
Flavor: sweet. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
It treats female red discharge, stanches bleeding, nourishes essence, preserves the blood vessels, augments *qi*, and makes one plump, healthy, and fond of eating. Another name: *shuiying*. It grows in the marshes and ponds of Nanhai.

*Qin* is pronounced *qin*.

Tao Hongjing states: considering its therapeutic effects, water celery should be classified as an upper-grade medicinal. It is unclear why it is placed in the lower grade. During the second and third months, when it produces stalks, it can be made into pickles or cooked and eaten. There is also *zhaqin* (rough celery), which can be eaten raw or as a fresh vegetable; in common usage, both are written as *qin*.

The *Alternative Edition* notes: this is celery. There are two types: *diqin* (reed celery), whose white roots are used, and *chiqin* (red celery), whose stems and leaves are used for pickles or fresh vegetables. Its flavor is sweet. The *Classic* states it is neutral, but its nature is greatly cold and non-toxic.

*The Golden Casket Formulary* states: in spring and autumn, dragons deposit their essence into celery. Those who consume it become afflicted, exhibiting symptoms such as blue hands, abdominal distension, and unbearable pain, known as the "flood dragon illness." Take two to three *sheng* of brown sugar, twice daily. The patient will vomit two or three lizard-like creatures, and the illness will resolve.

*The Secret Records of the Mother and Child* states: for infantile cholera with vomiting and diarrhea, finely chop celery, boil it, and drink the liquid freely until the symptoms cease.

**Fanlou (Knotgrass)**
Flavor: sour. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
It treats long-standing malignant sores that do not heal. Harvest on the fifth day of the fifth month at noon and dry for use.

*The Illustrated Classic* states: *fanlou* is also called *jichangcao* (chicken-gut grass). Its place of origin was not previously recorded. Today, it grows abundantly in the fields and wilds of the southern regions, and is also found in damp areas near the capital. Its leaves resemble those of *xingcai* (water shield) but are smaller. In summer and autumn, it produces small white-yellow flowers. Its stems creep and vine; when broken, they reveal fibrous strands, thin and hollow like a chicken’s intestines, hence the name.

The *Classic* lists it under two entries, but Su Gong considers it a single substance with two names.

Caution: According to the *Erya*: *ao* is *lou*, also called *fanlou* or *jichangcao*. In fact, they are the same plant.

Today, though the plant grows across both northern and southern regions, variations in soil fertility may produce differences in its appearance. With its many names, those who have not encountered all of them often mistake it for two distinct species.

*Lou* is pronounced *lü*.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This herb is none other than *jichang* (chicken-gut grass), neither of which appears in the original *Classic*. Yet discrepancies persist in accounts from different locales, where it thrives abundantly along damp ditches and canals. Common folk universally call it *jichang*, while scholars collectively refer to it as *fanlou*. The *Erya* notes that when a single entity bears multiple names, it is termed "one substance with two names."

The *Extended Materia Medica* states: *Fanlou* and *jichangcao* (chicken-gut grass) are one and the same. Though now divided into two entries, the entry for *jichangcao* omits any mention of its properties and flavors, confirming their identity.

*Jichangcao* blooms in spring with small flowers the size of mung beans. Its stems and leaves resemble those of coriander; initially upright, they later sprawl across the ground. Rural households gather it to make pickled greens, and consuming it blackens the hair and beard.

*Jichangcao*:
- Resolves toxic swellings
- Checks profuse urination

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This herb is *fanlou*, and this redundant entry should be removed.

Now, *jichangcao* originally appeared in the *Herbal* under the "Inferior Grade." The Tang annotation deemed it a superfluous entry. Given the similarity in their therapeutic applications, are they not one and the same? It is now appended beneath *fanlou*.

**White Lettuce**
Flavor: bitter
Nature: cold (some say neutral)
- Fortifies sinews and bones
- Benefits the five viscera
- Opens the chest and diaphragm, relieving stagnant qi
- Unblocks the meridians
- Arrests spleen qi
- Whitens teeth
- Sharpens the mind
- Reduces sleep

May be consumed regularly. Those with cold qi who eat it will experience abdominal chill, though it is not severely harmful. Avoid after childbirth, as it induces internal cold and lower abdominal pain.

Chen Cangqi states: White lettuce resembles garden lettuce but has white hairs on its leaves.

**Malabar Spinach**
Flavor: sour
Nature: cold, non-toxic
- Lubricates the center
- Disperses heat

Its fruit:
- Enhances facial complexion

Also called *tiankui* or *fanlu*.

Tao Hongjing notes: It is also called *chenglu*, and many households cultivate it. Its leaves are only suitable for pickling; its cold, slippery nature makes it unsuitable for consumption, except for those bitten by dogs, whose sores will never heal if they eat it. Its seeds are purple, and women steep them in powder for facial application. Some are used medicinally.

**Water Dropwort**
Juice flavor: sweet
Nature: cold, non-toxic
- Treats horse-toxin sores: pound to extract juice, wash the affected area, and administer internally

Water dropwort is a vegetable, recorded in the *Minor Prescriptions*.

The *Wanbi Prescriptions* states: It dispels snake venom and abscesses.

The *Tang Materia Medica* annotates: This vegetable grows wild and is not cultivated. Commonly called *jin cai*, its leaves resemble those of *ji* (shepherd’s purse), and its flowers are purple. It was first appended in the Tang edition.

The *Dietary Therapy* states: Water dropwort, flavor bitter, treats:
- Alternating chills and fever
- Rat fistula
- Scrofula
- Open sores
- Nodules
- Qi accumulations
- Stasis blood

Its leaves treat cholera, with effects akin to *xiangru*. For snakebite, crush fresh leaves and apply as a poultice to draw out the venom. Alternatively, dry and grind the herb, mix with oil, and fry; apply to nodules three to five times for resolution.

**Shepherd’s Purse**
Flavor: pungent
Nature: slightly warm
- Treats *qusou* urine sores
- Overconsumption induces panting

*Ji* is pronounced *jí*.
*Qu* is pronounced *qú*.

《*Tu Jing*》 states: Water dropwort, flavor pungent, nature slightly warm, treats *qusou* urine sores. It grows in shady, damp mountain valleys, trailing as a vine with purple-red stems. Its leaves resemble those of buckwheat but are fleshy. People of Shannan and Jiangzuo enjoy eating it raw. However, overconsumption induces panting, fatigue, weakness, depletes yang qi, and consumes essence and marrow—those with chronic leg weakness must avoid it entirely, for a single bite may cause lifelong affliction. In Guanzhong, it is called *zu cai*. Physicians past and present seldom employ it.

The *Experiential Remedies* records: For hot swellings on the back, extract its juice and cover the sore, piercing the affected area to vent heat toxin. Replace when cool; resolution follows.

**Water Spinach**
Flavor: sweet
Nature: neutral, non-toxic
- Counters *yege* (toxic vine) poisoning; boil and consume, or crush fresh and ingest raw
Cultivated in Lingnan, it trails as a vine with white flowers and is edible as a vegetable. The people of Yunnan eat water spinach before consuming *yege*, as the two substances neutralize each other, rendering the poison harmless. Alternatively, dripping its juice onto *yege* shoots causes them to wither instantly—such is their mutual antagonism.

Zhang Sikong notes: Emperor Wu of Wei once consumed a foot-long *yege* stem, likely having first eaten this vegetable.

**Bitter Endive**
Nature: cold, non-toxic

**Bitter Endive (Wild)**
- Treats facial and ocular yellowing, enhances strength, relieves fatigue, and applies to snake or insect bites. Its juice, when applied to *ding* sores, draws out the root. During silkworm moth emergence, avoid plucking or breaking it, lest the moths develop red rot. Silkworm tenders must also refrain from eating it. After five or six harvests, wild bitter endive becomes sweeter and smoother than the cultivated variety, highly prized.
*Rihuazi* states: Treats facial and ocular yellowing.

**Deerhorn Seaweed**
Nature: extremely cold, non-toxic or slightly toxic
- Dispels heat and wind-qi, cures childhood *guzheng* (bone-steaming heat fatigue). Men should not consume it long-term, as it may trigger chronic ailments, impair the meridians and blood-qi, induce cold numbness in the feet, harm the lower back and kidneys, and dull the complexion. For those taking mineral drugs, it weakens their efficacy.
Found in Haizhou; also present in Deng, Lai, Yi, and Mizhou, growing in the sea. Additionally, it relieves facial heat.
*Qianjin Fang*: Dispels heat-qi.

**Purslane**
Nature: neutral, slightly toxic
- Fortifies the center, descends qi, regulates spleen-qi, dispels head wind, and benefits the five viscera. Cold-qi types should not overconsume, as it provokes qi. Those with preexisting abdominal cold will suffer ruptured abdomens if eaten. Ash from its stems, steeped in water, washes clothes to a jade-like whiteness.

**East Wind Herb**
Flavor: sweet
Nature: cold, non-toxic
- Addresses wind-toxin congestion and heat, headaches, dizziness, liver heat, and red eyes. Suitable for stews, its cooked form is delicious.
Grows in the plains and marshes of Lingnan. Stems reach two to three *chi* in height; leaves resemble apricot leaves but are longer, very thick and soft, with fine hairs on the surface.

It sprouts before spring, hence its name "East Wind Herb."

**Illustrated Classic of Materia Medica, Extended Meanings (Volume 42)**

**Bitter Melon** *(Note: "Huiming Studio edition reads 'Bitter'.")*
- A *qing* of one *mu* yields several *dan*. *(Note: Original reads "must"; amended per Huiming Studio edition.)*
- *(Note: Original includes twenty-four extraneous characters—"Purslane also treats horse-toxin sores: boil in water, administer one *sheng*, and apply to sores. For damp ringworm and white baldness, use..."—deleted per Huiming Studio edition.)*
- Soak in water for three days *(Note: Huiming Studio edition reads "three times daily")*, then steam until thoroughly cooked *(Note: Huiming Studio edition reads "hot")*. Spread to dry, and it becomes white as snow. The *Handbook of the Ministry of War* *(Note: These four characters originally omitted; restored per Huiming Studio edition.)* states: "For eels *(Note: Original reads "maggots"; amended per Huiming Studio edition.)* in the abdomen, take one *ge* of bitter melon seeds, grind into powder, and mix with wine. Also treats stomach *(Note: Original reads "causes people to"; amended per Huiming Studio edition.)* heat and thirst. Do not consume *(Note: Originally omitted; restored per Huiming Studio edition.)* excessively, as it harms the stomach. This *(Note: Original reads "only"; amended per Huiming Studio edition.)* method is recorded in the *Handbook of the Ministry of War*."
- To make *(Note: Originally omitted; restored per Huiming Studio edition.)* preserved bitter melon: pick young fruits, soak in water, and consume *(Note: Originally omitted; restored per Huiming Studio edition.)* as a vegetable. One *jin* of bitter melon can be preserved with one *dou* of salt *(Note: Huiming Studio edition reads "two *dou*")*. Only *(Note: Huiming Studio edition reads "serves as")* an auxiliary *(Note: Original reads "annotation"; amended per Huiming Studio edition.)* remedy, as excessive consumption damages *(Note: Original reads "treats"; amended per Huiming Studio edition.)* the stomach.
